column2: The British banking giant Barclays said Friday it has some exposure to troubled hedge funds that invested in the subprime mortgage market, but any loss from the exposure would not be material to its overall performance.

As the private equity industry gets a lot less private, The Financial Times's Thorold Barker suggests it should be thinking about finding a new name for itself. He brings up one possibility that describes what buyout funds do -- long-term capital management -- but notes that a certain ill-fated hedge fund seems to have ruined that one for everybody. DealBook visited this question in a column in The New York Times in March, and readers responded with plenty of suggestions, including "adaptive equity," "enterprise capital" and "constructive finance."

Lear, the auto parts maker, has delayed a shareholder vote on a $2.9 billion buyout offer from Carl Icahn. The vote was rescheduled to July 12 from June 27 in response to criticism of the bid from shareholders and proxy advisory services. Mr. Icahn made the bid, valued at $36 a share, through his American Real Estate Partners.
A Toronto-based investment banking firm proposed recapitalizing Bell Canada on Friday as an alternative to the three competing privatization offers and one takeover bid for the company.

A federal bankruptcy judge has ordered the Goldman Sachs Group to release to creditors of Enron all documents and materials related to a financial project between the New York investment firm and the company in the latter half of 2001, as Enron spiraled into bankruptcy.
How far will Google, Microsoft, Yahoo or other Internet powerhouses go in their effort to dominate digital advertising, the fastest-growing part of the marketing business?
Will Okun, who's traveling with Nick Kristof in Africa, gets the chance to put his hoop skills to the test in Burundi.

Visa, the biggest credit card network in the United States, took its first official step Friday toward becoming a public company, outlining to federal regulators how it proposes to restructure and combine its global operations.
David Pogue looks at the features of the new iPhone, as furtively as possible.

Shares of Macy's surged Friday on speculation the company was the target of private equity buyout. In the largest jump since November 2005, Macy's stock climbed $2.56, or 6.6 percent, to $41.43, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo's sales team.
HSBC Holdings , Europe's biggest bank, will buy part of a Shanghai office tower to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in the world's fastest-growing major economy.

Fosun International is raising as much as HK$10.85 billion ($1.39 billion) in an initial public offering whose investors include Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, Bloomberg News reported. The company is offering 1.25 billion shares in Hong Kong at HK$6.48 to HK$8.68 each, according to Bloomberg.

Senior executives at Nasdaq spent the weekend locked in discussions over whether they oppose a 1.63 billion euro ($2.2 billion) deal between the London Stock Exchange and Borsa Italiana, according to The Independent.
To get their $17.5 billion deal approved by antitrust regulators, Thomson and Reuters may have to sign off on some significant disposals, notes The Deal.com.

Vonage Holdings is scheduled Monday to appear in the United States Court of Appeals in Washington to make what may be a final stand in fighting charges that its online telephone service infringes patents held by Verizon Communications.

Norddeutsche Affinerie, the largest European copper refiner, said Sunday that it had agreed to buy Cumerio of Brussels, owner of the biggest copper smelter in southeastern Europe, for 777 million euros, or $1.05 billion.
Iraqi Kurdistan has enjoyed de facto independence since 1991 and is now enjoying a building boom.
As a basic cable movie, this dramatized public service announcement is the usual cocktail of clichés.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Images of the Hall of Mirrors after its three-year restoration.
Vintage photographs and images of Staten Island.

Atop what is unanimously regarded as Rome's ugliest monument -- the massive early 20th century Vittoriano in Piazza Venezia -- there is a newly opened viewing platform with fantastic vistas of Rome. Called "Rome from the Sky" (Roma Dal Ceilo) it is acessed via a glass elevator sandwiched between the Vittoriano Monument and the Piazza del Campidoglio, Michelangelo's lovliest square. I'd recommend "Rome from the Sky" as a good first stop to get your bearings in this beautiful but complicated city.
There was no way the Yankees' hot streak was going to last, of course. They had won 14 of 17 games since falling a season-worst 14 ½ games behind Boston on May 29, with a 21-29 record.
Christine Todd Whitman repeatedly denied that there had been a deliberate attempt to play down health risks in Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.
“The court finds that the plaintiff is not entitled to any relief whatsoever,” Judge Bartnoff wrote.
Karla Lightfoot, a yoga instructor and freelance writer, was meditating one day when the name “compassion couture” just came to her.
President Nicolas Sarkozy of France blocked a key element of Turkey’s entry negotiations with the European Union today.
With the N.B.A. draft coming on Thursday, a guide to help evaluate the top players.
The partial roof was dismantled at Center Court on a rainy day at Wimbledon, where the former champions Roger Federer and Martina Hingis advanced.
The Supreme Court’s 5-4 ruling today opened a significant loophole in the 2002 McCain-Feingold law and may affect the strategy of the 2008 campaigns.
Leaders from Israel, Egypt and Jordan met today to show support for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.
A wind-driven blaze near Lake Tahoe that started on Sunday forced 1,000 people to flee their homes today.
At the summit today, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert issued a conditional promise to release Fatah prisoners.
A suicide bomber assassinated several Sunni Aran sheiks who were cooperating with Americans to fight Al Qaeda.
GLG Partners will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company.
North Korea said today it would begin to shut down its main nuclear facility after a dispute over frozen funds was resolved.
No one claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed three Colombians and three Spanish peacekeepers.

Larry Dixon defeated Doug Herbert at the ProCare Rx NHRA SuperNationals at Englishtown, N.J., to win his 40th Top Fuel title, breaking a tie with Kenny Bernstein for second place on the career list.Tommy Johnson Jr. won the Funny Car event. Greg Anderson won the Pro Stock race, tying him with Don Prudhomme for sixth place with 49 victories, and Craig Treble won the Pro Stock Motorcycle event.Dixon beat Herbert out of the gates and inched away as he went down the track with a time of 4.625 seconds at 321.73 miles an hour to Herbert’s 4.675 at 316.30 m.p.h.
The Beavers (49-18) became the fifth team to win back-to-back N.C.A.A. baseball titles, and the first since Louisiana State in 1996-97.
A 12-term congressman, John J. Flynt Jr. twice beat a political newcomer named Newt Gingrich in the 1970s.

Kevin VanDam reeled in a catch of 18 pounds 12 ounces yesterday to retake the lead and capture the Bassmaster Elite Series’ Sooner Run on Grand Lake in Grove, Okla.VanDam’s four-day total weighed 78 pounds 2 ounces, and his $100,000 payday brought his career earnings to nearly $2.5 million.VanDam, a 12-time BASS tournament winner, is the career- leading money winner.

Emma-Jayne Wilson became the first female jockey to win the Queen’s Plate, the first leg of the Canadian triple crown, when she rode the 15-1 long shot Mike Fox to victory yesterday at Woodbine Racetrack. Wilson made her move after the turn to win by half a length.In 2005, Wilson won 175 races and earned more than $6.9 million in purses en route to being named North America’s top apprentice rider. The following year she led all Woodbine riders with 144 victories and finished second in earnings with more than $6.5 million to again be named Canada’s top apprentice.

The defending Dew Cup champion, Nate Adams, won the freestyle motocross event yesterday at the Dew Action Sports Tour’s Panasonic Open in Baltimore. Adams scored a 95.67 with multiple backflips. “Last year I won the first stop and ended up winning the whole tour,” he said. “I’m feeling pretty good.”.

Chief’s Lake claimed a three-and-a-quarter-length victory yesterday in the $107,700 Mike Lee Stakes at Belmont Park, the first leg of the Big Apple Triple for 3-year-olds bred in New York. The series continues with the New York Derby at Finger Lakes on July 14 and concludes with the Albany Stakes at Saratoga on Aug. 22. Chief’s Lake can earn a $250,000 bonus for a sweep of all three. Chief’s Lake, trained by Steve Asmussen and ridden by Garrett Gomez, paid $8.90 for a $2 bet to win.

Vladimir Karpets of Russia won the Tour de Suisse yesterday by finishing sixth in the race’s final stage, a 21-mile time trial in Bern.Luxembourg’s Kim Kirchen finished second over all, and Stijn Devolder of Belgium was third.Switzerland’s Fabian Cancellara, the world time trial champion and the winner of the Swiss tour’s prologue, won the stage in 41 minutes 46 seconds. Karpets crossed in 42:52.“This victory comes in the most beautiful city in the world, in my birth city,” Cancellara said.Vladimir Efimkin of Russia, who led the overall standings heading into the final stage, was more than three minutes behind the leaders. He finished sixth over all.

Patrick Ianni picked a good time to score his first goal in Major League Soccer.Ianni’s headed goal off a corner kick by his teammate Stuart Holden in the 81st minute provided the Houston Dynamo with a 1-0 victory against the Kansas City Wizards yesterday at Arrowhead Stadium.The victory improved Houston’s record to 7-5-1, second in M.L.S.’s Western Conference.Midfielder Brian Mullan had two decent scoring chances before the Dynamo finally capitalized in the 81st minute. Holden’s high corner kick found Ianni’s head at the near post, at the top of the 6-yard box, and Wizards goalkeeper Kevin Hartman had no chance for a save.

An obituary on June 4 of Ed Yost, considered the father of modern hot-air ballooning, referred incorrectly to his use of hydrogen before air inside a balloon was heated with propane. He used hydrogen, which is lighter than air, to fill balloons — not to heat air that had been fanned into balloons.

An obituary on Thursday of Kenneth Franklin, long the top astronomer of the Hayden Planetarium, misstated the definition of a lunation, the unit of time used by a watch he invented for use on the Moon. It is the period it takes the Moon to rotate and revolve around the Earth, not around the Sun.

An article on Saturday about the Senate’s approval of legislation that would require auto makers to produce cars and trucks that get substantially higher gas mileage misstated the final vote. With 92 of 100 senators voting, it was 65 to 27 — not 65 to 37.

An article on Saturday about the Senate’s approval of legislation that would require auto makers to produce cars and trucks that get substantially higher gas mileage misstated the final vote. With 92 of 100 senators voting, it was 65 to 27 — not 65 to 37.

An obituary on Tuesday of Lola S. Wasserstein, the mother of the playwright Wendy Wasserstein and the inspiration for several characters in her plays, misstated her influence on the play “Uncommon Women and Others.” She was the model for the mother of the character Holly Kaplan, not for Holly Kaplan herself. The obituary also referred incorrectly to Holly. She complains that her mother — not seen onstage — is pushing her to find a boyfriend. It is not Holly who pushes her daughter to find a boyfriend. (Holly does not have a daughter in the play.) The obituary also omitted a survivor, a son, Abner Wasserstein.

An article on June 8 about legislation in the House aimed at easing restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research misstated a vote in the Senate in April on similar legislation. With 97 of 100 senators voting, it was 63 to 34 — not 63 to 45.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday of William J. LeMessurier, a structural engineer who repaired a potentially catastrophic flaw in the Citicorp building in Manhattan, misidentified his birthplace in Michigan. It is Pontiac, not Bloomfield Hills.

An obituary on June 14 by The Associated Press of the movie actress Mala Powers misidentified the B-movie series that included one of her early films, “Tough as They Come.” It was called “Dead End Kids and Little Tough Guys”; the film was not part of the “Bowery Boys” series.
Firefighters and other mourners gathered to pay their respects to Daniel F. Pudjak, who died in the line of duty Thursday.

Two children were ejected from a sport utility vehicle on Route 78 in Somerset County yesterday afternoon and were in critical condition. The children, Isaias Rodriguez, 9, and Fernando Tepada, 10, suffered severe head injuries after the driver, Betsy E. Tejeda-Lopez, 34, lost control of the S.U.V., the state police said. She may have fallen asleep as she drove through Bedminster Township about 2:45 p.m. on her way home to Reading, Pa., from New York City, where the group had been visiting relatives, the police said. Isaias, a son of Ms. Tejeda-Lopez, and Fernando, a nephew, did not appear to have been wearing seat belts, the police said. Two other children in the car — Ms. Tejeda-Lopez’s son Eddy J. Rodriguez, 2, who was strapped into a child seat, and Freyla A. Tejeda, 14, the woman’s niece, who was wearing a seat belt — were hospitalized with less serious injuries, the police said. Ms. Tejeda-Lopez, who was wearing a seat belt, had head and chest injuries that were not life-threatening, the police said.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell has signed a bill to penalize gun owners who fail to inform the police within 72 hours of discovering that a firearm has been lost or stolen. The first offense is an infraction, punishable by a fine of up to $90; subsequent offenses would be felonies. In a statement yesterday, she said the law, which takes effect Oct. 1, will help “stem the tide of stolen guns used in crimes.”.

The chief administrative judge for Brooklyn Supreme Court is considering a motion to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the disclosure of secret grand jury testimony by the district attorney’s office. The judge, Neil Jon Firetog, is expected to announce his decision at a hearing today. The case concerns Andria Sergio, 27, who has been charged with hindering prosecution and improperly disposing of a body for her role in the death of her sister’s newborn baby, found on the back porch of the family’s home in Bay Ridge in April. Ms. Sergio’s sister Laura Sergio, 25, has been charged with murder. A defense lawyer, Daniel N. Arshack, has argued that a court filing by prosecutors that included a summary of Andria Sergio’s grand jury testimony was improper and was intended to prejudice jurors. The district attorney’s office has said the summary was included to ensure that the testimony would be accepted as evidence at trial.

A 40-year-old man was fatally shot in the St. Albans section of Queens early yesterday, the police said. The man, identified as Dwayne King of Nashville Boulevard, was shot in the chest about 1:45 a.m. at 176th Street and 110th Avenue, the police said. Relatives said Mr. King was shot at a family barbecue. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. There were no arrests yesterday, the police said.

A Brooklyn man was fatally shot yesterday in the lobby of a building in the Farragut Houses in Vinegar Hill, the police said. The police, who were called to the building just after noon, found the man shot once in the abdomen. He was pronounced dead at the Brooklyn Hospital Center, the police said. Family members identified the victim as Erik Speights, 29, a construction worker and father of two. Daphne Speights, his sister, said the police told her that he was shot in a dispute with strangers that had begun the night before. “Some boys just shot him over a bump and a stare in a store last night,” Ms. Speights said.

A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday morning and accused of leaving a pipe bomb on the hood of his daughter’s car in Staten Island on Saturday, bringing bomb squad officers to both boroughs before he was found, the police said. The man, identified as Baudelio Rodriguez, 47, was feuding with his wife, who had left their home in Sheepshead Bay and was staying with their daughter, the police said. The daughter saw the pipe bomb on her car and called the police Saturday afternoon. The bomb, filled with explosive powder, was safely removed, its fuse unlighted. The police searched Mr. Rodriguez’s house, on East 29th Street, on Saturday night, but they did not find him or any explosives. Mr. Rodriguez was arrested shortly after 1 a.m. at his brother’s house nearby, the police said. He was charged with reckless endangerment, attempted arson, unlawful dealing with fireworks and violating a court order of protection, the police said.
Some environmentalists say that Home Depot is being too inclusive in its new Eco Options marketing campaign.
Rupert Murdoch’s vast media holdings give him a gamut of tools to enhance his financial interests.
Technology executives are trying to shape the Senate immigration bill to meet their demand for foreign workers, but they have had only limited success.
A judge gave five death sentences to the man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gas attacks on Kurdish villagers, but Iraqi interest in the trials has flagged.
The News Corporation and advisers for Dow Jones are close to agreeing on terms to protect The Wall Street Journal’s independence if the company is taken over.
The Rockefeller Foundation has named the first two recipients of the Jane Jacobs Medals, which carry a $100,000 prize for innovative urban thinking.
Bishops of the Anglican Church of Canada narrowly overruled clergy members and laypeople to defeat a proposal to give churches the option of blessing same-sex unions.
The San Francisco Giants spent Sunday afternoon watching Barry Bonds run the bases, reminiscing about Rod Beck on the mound, and pretending they were all back in 1993.
Not even Roger Clemens in relief could help the Yankees, who have lost five out of their last six games to fall back under .500.
Listening to hip-hop and growing up playing pickup basketball in Shenzhen, Yi Jianlian stands as a symbol of basketball discovery that is rippling through China.

A front-page article yesterday described a crackdown in Iran that has included the jailing of three Iranian-Americans, repression or intimidation of nongovernment organizations pressing for broader legal rights, warnings to newspaper editors against articles on banned topics, arrests of advocates for women’s rights and of student leaders, and the detention of 150,000 people for wearing clothing considered not Islamic.
Dustin McGowan was looking for a no-hitter and a milestone for Frank Thomas, all in the same game.
It’s nearly always a mistake to think of the subway as a public conveyance.
An impassioned speech by gay legislator Daniel J. O’Donnell may have been the reason that the New York State Assembly voted to approve same-sex marriage.
The records are part of a slew of documents recently made public at the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University.
Juan Pablo Montoy, the Colombian driver who jumped from Formula One to the American stock-car circuit late last season, got his first Cup victory in his 17th start.
Under the bill, officials in Baton Rouge, will appoint public defenders throughout Louisiana, changing a system considered one of the country’s most negligent.
Safety advocates and politicians have long struggled over how to resolve the perennial summer plague of pool drownings.
Tony Blair, who steps down as British prime minister this week, has many of the right qualities and some worrisome flaws as a possible Middle East peace envoy.
New Jersey Senator Robert Menendez, a Cuban-American, is finding it politically useful to position himself as the Democrat’s conscience on immigration.
The protest against Wal-Mart in the Hasidic town of Monsey, N.Y., has a decidedly religious overtone.
Israel on Sunday agreed to transfer hundreds of millions of dollars of Palestinian tax revenues to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah.
The American commander in Baquba, Brig. Gen. Mick Bednarek, said Iraqi forces are “not quite up to the job yet.”
Hunter Mahan, 25, earned his first PGA Tour victory Sunday, winning the Travelers Championship in a playoff.
A spokesman for the NATO force in Afghanistan confirmed that several Pakistani civilians had been killed by bombing and helicopter fire.
Tamika Catchings scored 18 points and Tamika Whitmore had 15, as the Fever thwarted a late comeback by the Liberty.
Three thousand fans cheered Sunday as the Modi’in Miracles beat the Petah Tikva Pioneers, 9-1 in the first professional baseball game in Israeli history.
Running on a wet track, with the wind blowing in his face, Tyson Gay completed one of the most impressive sprint doubles in the sport’s history Sunday.
Struggle has not been unusual for jockey Andrew Lakeman, who has battled with drug addiction in the past. Yet now he must reckon with yet another obstacle: paralysis.
Congress will achieve a significant victory if it ends the breaks that are skewing the tax code in favor of the most advantaged Americans.
New York’s lobbyists are looking to improve their sullied public image by forming a trade association and, perhaps, hiring a lobbyist to advocate for their interests.
No one claimed responsibility for the attack, which Spain’s defense minister said killed three Colombians and two Spanish peacekeepers.
Britain’s transfer of power entered its final countdown on Sunday when the governing Labor Party anointed Gordon Brown as Tony Blair’s successor.
Ken Griffey Jr. hit his 583rd and 584th home runs against Miguel Batista, tying and then passing Mark McGwire for seventh place on the career list.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) — Landon Donovan scored his 34th international goal, tying Eric Wynalda atop the United States career list, and Benny Feilhaber connected on a volley as the United States rallied for a 2-1 victory against Mexico on Sunday in the final of the Concacaf Gold Cup at Soldier Field.
Rod Beck was a colorful baseball personality and a three-time All-Star. He spent the first 7 of his 13 major league seasons with the San Francisco Giants.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,532 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:.
Church leaders say they are frustrated by Catholic politicians like Rudolph W. Giuliani who say they oppose abortion but do not want to impose their beliefs.
The U.S. secretary of state joined France’s new foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, in deploring the international community’s failure to act.
The new French president proved to be the crucial figure during a European Union meeting, helping to break down the resistance of Poland’s identical-twin leaders to a deal.
New Yorkers and anyone else who rides public transportation in and around the city should mark July 16 on their calendars.
Although 2006 was heralded as the dawn of a golden age of philanthropy, charitable giving was almost flat last year.
Eight years after NATO forces effectively bombed Serbian security forces out of Kosovo, independence for the ethnic Albanian enclave keeps slipping further into the future.
A robotics exercise sponsored by the Science and Technology Directorate at the Department of Homeland Security is trying to find ways to evaluate the performance of robots.
A new video of the BBC correspondent Alan Johnston reportedly showed him wearing an explosives belt. Israeli television said that an Israeli soldier captured a year ago was being held in Gaza.
Mr. Baer was a longtime proponent of open government and served in the New Jersey Legislature for more than three decades.
New evidence tying birth order to I.Q. has intensified the debate over what family dynamics enhance intelligence.
Europeans may claim leadership in fighting global warming, but they get black marks from environmentalists for their fishing policy.
Mr. Sponzo, a Superior Court judge, played a crucial role in a 1976 inquiry that helped clear a youth in the killing of his mother.
A battle for the most coveted spot in a yoga studio, the downside of having a Central Park view and the overwhelming excitement of bingo.
The episode was just the latest brazen escapade in a campaign by Jamia Hafsa, a militant Islamic school for women, and its male counterpart, Jamia Faridia, to embarrass the government of Pakistan.
Chief Justice Robert R. Thomas of the Illinois Supreme Court has lately been disqualifying himself from hearing libel cases, probably because he is a libel plaintiff himself.
More bad weather is forecast for Pakistan and India, and a local official in Karachi said torrential rain had caused “electrocution, falling trees, house collapses and road accidents.”
GLG Partners will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, according to people briefed on the transaction.
Wired magazine, in partnership with Xerox, invited subscribers to upload their photographs to Wired.com. The first 5,000 who did so are now the cover art.
National Lampoon, once a comedic standard-bearer, will again make original films, including the first one it has produced in 18 years, “National Lampoon’s Bag Boy.”
Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo’s sales team.
When ratings boards in the United States, Britain and other nations effectively killed the video game Manhunt 2 last week, I got set for gore. And I found plenty.
The main economic news will come out of the two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, beginning on Wednesday.
The rapper Foxy Brown is robbed, spirits seemed undampened by rain at the Glastonbury Festival and more culture news.
The issue of self-censorship has come into sharp relief because of declining circulation and a concentration of media ownership among the new president’s allies.
A Senate subcommittee is expected to issue a report on how the hedge fund Amaranth Advisors dominated the North American natural gas market last year.
Users of Wikipedia have described obvious mistakes in the design of the Web site’s logo.
Norddeutsche Affinerie, the largest European copper refiner, said that it had agreed to buy Cumerio of Brussels, owner of the biggest copper smelter in southeastern Europe, for $1.05 billion.
A studio’s marketing team paid “Die Hard” fans to repost on YouTube a parody video that used pirated studio content.
The annual June art auctions have made London a more important art capital than it has been for more than 20 years.
“Evan Almighty,” the most expensive comedy in Hollywood history, sold $32 million worth of tickets in its first weekend; “A Mighty Heart” brought in $4 million.
While networks tussled over which would land the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail, the upstart Web site TMZ.com was breaking most of the news.
Tears fell at the New York State Theater for Kyra Nichols’s farewell after 33 years with New York City Ballet, but there were fewer tears than flowers.
In Hollywood, media executives are eagerly preparing for a new era as they hope to position more content where consumers want it: in their hands.

At the end of the new Kelly Clarkson album it finally arrives: a song worth all the fuss. It’s called “Irvine,” and it’s a gentle prayer, sweetened by a strummed guitar, a ghostly hint of pedal steel and (every now and then) a digitized string section.
PBS executives say “History Detectives,” a one-hour program that is something of a cross between “CSI” and “Antiques Roadshow,” has become one of their most popular programs.
The Mets scored early, scored often and relied on another superb outing by John Maine to defeat the Oakland Athletics at Shea Stadium to complete a three-game sweep.
This terrifically exciting new production of “Romeo and Juliet” stars Lauren Ambrose as a Juliet truly to die for.
Kaplan Test Prep and Admissions, a traditional test preparation company, is offering interactive programs for downloading to iPods with video screens.
Recipe searches are among the most popular online endeavors for women, and major advertisers want to be there to greet them.
Corbis, the online stock photo company founded and owned by Bill Gates, plans Monday to introduce a Web site that allows anyone to upload photographs for sale.
Even as your brain tells you that you’ve seen this kind of movement a million times, Mikhail Baryshnikov makes you see it as if never before.
The opening of the Caramoor International Music Festival certainly took a stand for both brevity and levity.
What was looking suspiciously like another lopsided America’s Cup was transformed into a genuine contest, as Emirates Team New Zealand fought back to defeat Alinghi by 28 seconds.
Accounts.
Serena Williams finds herself in a peculiar position: playing the role of favorite, with little pressure to win.
Boingo Wireless is introducing on Monday what it says is the first worldwide flat-rate plan for Wi-Fi hot spots.
Jason Binn will announce this week that his magazine company, Niche Media, will merge with Greenspun Media Group of Las Vegas, creating a network of 16 publications.
An advertising agency for a California winery recently bought space in a magazine where few (if any) ads have gone before.
The party for the release of the film “Captivity” may set a new standard for the politically incorrect.
Annie Dillard has created the sort of narrative that will have acolytes moaning low.

8:30 P.M. (Showtime) SEMPER FI (2007) When he enlisted in the Marines, Jeff Key, above, already had two strikes against him. At 34, he was slightly above the age limit, which a recruiter overlooked because of Mr. Key’s passion to serve. And he was gay. But because no one asked, Mr. Key didn’t tell when he arrived in Iraq — at first. In this documentary, Vince DePersio traces Mr. Key’s evolution from wide-eyed patriot to disillusioned critic of what he calls an immoral war through interviews with Mr. Key and his family, friends and fellow marines as well as footage taken during his tour of duty and excerpts from his one-man play, “The Eyes of Babylon.”.
The diagramed deal occurred during the first session of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in May.
Consumers report greater satisfaction with call centers that they believe are based in the United States, according to CFI Group.
The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.
U.S. intelligence agencies are wasting millions on contractors.
What big-time candy men had hoped would sneak by as a simple rule change has erupted into a food fight that will go far to define how America values culinary pleasure.

With emerging evidence about the long-term health hazards of playing professional football, a hearing Monday will shed light on how the disability-benefit process works — or does not work — for retired N.F.L. players.
On Sunday, José Reyes provided Mets fans with something that probably none of them had seen before — not an inside-the-park home run, but definitely an inside-the-park run home.
Japanese chefs are considering extreme alternatives as shortages of tuna threaten to remove it from sushi menus.
Alessandra Ferri, the fiery dancer-actress, bade farewell to American Ballet Theater as the crowd roared back with fierce love.
After 10 years of warfare in Congo, much of the country is finally enjoying real progress. But in eastern Congo, war is ratcheting up again.

MALVIN--Adrienne Helis, known as Sugar to her family, passed away on June 22, 2007 in Los Angeles, California, where she resided in recent years. Preceded in death by her beloved husband, A. Mal Malvin, noted businessman of New York and Holmby Hills, California. Daughter of the late William G. Helis, Sr., famed thoroughbred sportsman and oil pioneer, and the late Mrs. William G. (Betty) Helis, Sr. noted philanthropist, both of New Orleans, Louisiana. Survived by her stepsons, Ronald and Barry Malvin, her niece, Cassandra Helis Citro of Los Angeles, California, her nephew, William A. Droulia of New Orleans, Louisiana, and and grandnieces and grandnephews. Also survived by her devoted friend, Donna Henry Moore. She was preceded in her death by her sister and constant companion, Diana Helis Henry, philanthropist of Los Angeles, California, her brother William G. Helis, Jr., well known oilman and philanthropist of New Orleans, Louisiana and her sister, Virginia Helis Droulia, sportswoman and philanthropist of New Orleans, Louisiana. Mrs. Malvin was a philanthropist and an avid collector and lover of art and antiques. She was also an accomplished French Chef, having studied at the famed Le Cordon Bleu. Visitation will be Thursday, June 28, 2007, 9:30am to 10:30am with a Service following at 10:30am. Pierce Brothers Westwood Village, 1218 Glendon Ave

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.71 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 4.95 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.23 percent.

CIARLETTA--Albert Perry ''Albee'' of Merrick on June 23, 2007. Beloved husband of Roxanne. Devoted father of Perry. Brother of Mary Joan Sciortino and the late Perry Ciarletta. Special cousin of the Musco's, Pasculli's and Mentesana's. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick. SMITH--Christine Brown. Died June 20th at age 94. Survived by sons Bradley Y. and Timothy Y. Smith and six grandchildren. Widow of Bradley Smith, whom she married in 1944 and who died in 2001. Born in Brooklyn, NY on February 11th, 1913, she was the only child of Christine McLaren and Samuel Twybill Brown. Christine attended Packer Collegiate Institute, graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr College in 1934, and received an M.A. degree in Sociology from Columbia University in 1938. She volunteered as a nurse's aide during World War II. Lived in Setauket, NY most of her life. A lover of children, dogs, flowers, and porcelain, she was a generous, gentle, kind, and amusing person who will be sorely missed.

The new French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, has reasserted his country's traditional role at the diplomatic heart of Europe by emerging as the main force behind a deal that brought the European Union back from the brink of crisis. Mr. Sarkozy proved to be the crucial figure during a fractious meeting, displaying a hyperactive style that helped break down the resistance of Poland's unyielding leaders.

An obituary on Thursday of Kenneth Franklin, long the top astronomer of the Hayden Planetarium, misstated the definition of a lunation, the unit of time used by a watch he invented for use on the Moon. It is the period it takes the Moon to rotate and revolve around the Earth, not around the Sun.

An obituary on Tuesday of Lola S. Wasserstein, the mother of the playwright Wendy Wasserstein and the inspiration for several characters in her plays, misstated her influence on the play ''Uncommon Women and Others.'' She was the model for the mother of the character Holly Kaplan, not for Holly Kaplan herself. The obituary also referred incorrectly to Holly. She complains that her mother -- not seen onstage -- is pushing her to find a boyfriend. It is not Holly who pushes her daughter to find a boyfriend. (Holly does not have a daughter in the play.) The obituary also omitted a survivor, a son, Abner Wasserstein.
To the Editor: Re ''Debate Over Cause of Autism Strains a Family and Its Charity'' (front page, June 18):

SHORTLY after 9/11, Senator Bob Graham, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, called for ''a symbiotic relationship between the intelligence community and the private sector.'' They say you should be careful what you wish for. In the intervening years a huge espionage-industrial complex has developed, as government spymasters outsourced everything from designing surveillance technology to managing case officers overseas. Today less than half of the staff at the National Counterterrorism Center in Washington are actual government employees, The Los Angeles Times reports; at the C.I.A. station in Islamabad, Pakistan, contractors sometimes outnumber employees by three to one.

An obituary on June 4 of Ed Yost, considered the father of modern hot-air ballooning, referred incorrectly to his use of hydrogen before air inside a balloon was heated with propane. He used hydrogen, which is lighter than air, to fill balloons -- not to heat air that had been fanned into balloons. The obituary also included erroneous information from the National Balloon Museum about two of Mr. Yost's balloon flights and the Navy research contract under which Mr. Yost worked, and it referred incorrectly to an associate, Don Piccard. The balloon Mr. Yost flew on Oct. 22, 1960, was not orange striped, it was all white. The Navy research contract that Mr. Yost worked on was held by a company that Mr. Yost and three colleagues from General Mills formed, Raven Industries -- not by General Mills, for which he went to work in 1949. Mr. Piccard, who flew with Mr. Yost on April 13, 1963, in the first hot-air balloon to cross the English Channel, was an employee of Raven Industries, not a partner in the company. On the balloon's descent during that crossing, it flew between newly erected power line poles, but did not narrowly miss power lines, because no lines had yet been strung on the poles.

SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY The main economic news will come out of the two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, beginning on Wednesday. A decision on interest rates will come on Thursday; the Fed is expected to hold rates steady at 5.25 percent. An update on the housing sector will come with reports on existing home sales for May (Monday) and new-home sales for May (Tuesday).
To the Editor: Re ''Pigs With Cellphones, but No Condoms'' (Advertising, Business Day, June 18):

One of the beauties of baseball is that anytime you watch a game, there's a chance you will see something you have never seen before. Early in the Mets' 10-2 victory over the Oakland Athletics yesterday at Shea Stadium, José Reyes provided the 50,143 in attendance with something that probably none of them had seen before -- not an inside-the-park home run, but definitely an inside-the-park run home. Leading off the bottom of the first inning, Reyes, the Mets' swift shortstop, blooped a fly ball down the right-field line with enough hang time that, even though Oakland right fielder Jack Cust fielded it cleanly, Reyes was sprinting for a double. As he slid into second, Cust's throw went high and wide of shortstop Bobby Crosby and bounded across the outfield grass, then across the left-field foul line.

Paris CHOCOLATE, sweet as it is, has set off bitter conflict since even before the conquistadors found Aztecs killing one another over cacao beans. It split families and estranged friends in the candy business to such a degree that when a Cadbury walked into a funeral for a rival he had done wrong, the widow shouted across Westminster Abbey, ''Get out, devil!''

Tomorrow in Washington, several retired N.F.L. players will participate in a congressional hearing on a vexing pro football conundrum: the issue of retired football players and injury. The legion of retired players has become a haunting presence for the National Football League and especially for the N.F.L. Players Association, which keeps one foot in and one foot out of the retired players' lives. With emerging evidence about the long-term health hazards of playing professional football, the purpose of tomorrow's hearing is to shed light on how the disability-benefit process works -- or does not work -- for retired N.F.L. players.

France and the United States appeared the best of friends here on Sunday, as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and France's new foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, joined forces to confront the continuing crisis in the Darfur region of Sudan. Ms. Rice praised the new French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, for playing host to an international conference on the crisis starting Monday and echoed Mr. Kouchner in deploring the international community's lack of action to stop four years of wanton killing in Darfur.

An obituary on June 14 by The Associated Press of the movie actress Mala Powers misidentified the B-movie series that included one of her early films, ''Tough as They Come.'' It was called ''Dead End Kids and Little Tough Guys''; the film was not part of the ''Bowery Boys'' series.

Shim, scumble, saurine, skeg: It's impossible for readers who delight in such words not to be entranced by the way Annie Dillard chooses -- and uses -- her arsenal in ''The Maytrees.'' In the three decades since ''Pilgrim at Tinker Creek,'' the nonfiction debut in which she introduced a prose style so gorgeously precise that every sentence sang, this poet, essayist and journalist has written nine original volumes powered by spare but brilliant language. Now in ''The Maytrees,'' her second novel and a shimmering meditation on the ebb and flow of love, Ms. Dillard has created the sort of narrative that will have acolytes moaning low.
It's like America running out of steak. Sushi without tuna just would not be sushi.

As Wi-Fi hot spots proliferate, it has become possible to open a laptop and connect to the Internet in just about any major airport as well as in thousands of hotels, restaurants, cafes and bars. Yet logging on can sometimes be onerous, and pricing is likely to be expensive and opaque. This has created an opportunity for what are called aggregators, companies that bring together the Wi-Fi networks of many different operators and allow clients to connect in the same manner and at the same price whether they are at a cafe in Los Angeles, an airport in Milan or a hotel in Bangkok.

The NATO force in Afghanistan said Sunday that its soldiers, in pursuing Taliban insurgents on Saturday, had unintentionally chased them across the border into Pakistan, and it confirmed that NATO bombing and helicopter fire caused the deaths of several Pakistani civilians. Pakistani military authorities had earlier placed the civilian death toll at 10.

The story seems familiar to online video users: fans create a parody video using pirated studio content and post it on YouTube, and the studio's lawyers quickly have it removed for violating copyright law. But this time the studio's marketing team relented --and even paid the fans to repost their video. Last August, a New York-based ''comic-rock'' group named Guyz Nite created an online video for their song ''Die Hard,'' a rather worshipful three-minute guide to 20th Century Fox's action-movie franchise starring Bruce Willis. (The song's refrain says, ''We're gonna die, die, die as hard as we can!'') The video used clips from the first three ''Die Hard'' movies, and within days Fox's legal department requested that the video be removed from YouTube.

At first glance, Rudolph W. Giuliani should be an appealing presidential candidate for observant Roman Catholics. The grandchild of Italian immigrants, Mr. Giuliani went to Catholic schools, considered joining the priesthood, and as mayor of New York battled a museum that exhibited a painting of the Virgin Mary adorned in elephant dung. But church leaders say they are frustrated by prominent Catholic politicians like Mr. Giuliani who argue that while they are personally opposed to abortion, they do not want to impose their beliefs on others.

As a card-carrying professor, documents about C.I.A. surveillance of college students tend to get my attention. Here, the family jewels appear to provide more color to the existing portrait. We already know from the bipartisan Church Committee that the C.I.A., the FBI, the Army, and the National Security Agency engaged in deliberate, systematic and long-term programs to spy on Americans during the 1960s and 1970s, with a particular focus on campus protest movements.

A rare gem among the family jewels: a pair of detailed reports signed by James J. Angleton, the legendary chief of the C.I.A.'s counterintelligence staff from 1954 to 1974. They describe an aspect of a longstanding worldwide American program to create and exploit foreign police forces, internal security services, and counterterrorism squads overseas.

(mostly men, in those days) were thinking as they wandered far afield from the C.I.A.'s own charter. The 1947 founding document banned the C.I.A. from domestic spying. Assassination plots against Fidel Castro and other foreign leaders, at a minimum, presented tricky legal and ethical issues for anyone involved.

I have now been through the first 150 pages of the documents in the C.I.A. Family Jewels archive. They are largely a disappointment. In a memo recounting the C.I.A.'s involvement with Mafia figures as the agency plotted to assassinate Fidel Castro, Howard J. Osborn, the agency's director of security, recalls the qualifications of John Roselli as a potential partner for the C.I.A. It's difficult to divine from the memo how well C.I.A. officials understood the inner workings, and alliances, of the mob. At one point, Osborn reports that Robert A. Maheu, a Howard Hughes aide who served as an intermediary between the C.I.A. and the mob, knew Roselli slightly but had been told he was a high-ranking member of the "syndicate.'' For years, the public has known that the C.I.A. spent part of the 1960s concocting plans to assassinate Cuban leader Fidel Castro. None of these plots ever succeeded, and many -- one explored the feasibility of sending Castro a poison-laced diving suit, another tried to rig exotic exploding seashells -- seem ridiculous in retrospect. One of the $64,000 questions from that time is whether these plots were known and authorized by various C.I.A. directors and others outside the agency, including the president. The Senate Select Committee to Study Governmental Operations with Respect to Intelligence Activities, better known as the Church Committee, spent months in 1975 and thousands of pages of testimony examining who knew what, and when. The committee found that the evidence suggested that higher-ups inside and outside the C.I.A .knew about the various assassination plots, but it was not conclusive.
