Note: Updates are being posted at the end of the intro...

The board of directors at Dow Jones and the News Corporation have reached a deal on the make up of an editorial board that would oversee Dow Jones' flagship newspaper, the Wall Street Journal, paving the way for a takeover of the entire company, MarketWatch reported, citing an unnamed source. Reuters, citing two separate sources, said the two "basically agreed" to a structure Monday night, but that several items needed to be discussed.

The Blackstone Group's market value may be declining for a second straight day, but Stephen A. Schwarzman's payout from the firm's recently completed public offering just went up by another few hundred million.

Visitors to Paris often rave about how convenient and easy to use the Metro is. It's inexpensive, goes everywhere, and is relatively clean and quick. But the big, obvious, drawback is, well, most of it is underground. If you're not in a huge hurry and you want a cheap way to see the city ABOVE ground, hop on a bus.

The New York Times has assembled a panel of intelligence experts and historians to review and comment on documents made public today by the Central Intelligence Agency that describe a series of intelligence operations, mostly involving domestic spying, that first came to light in the 1970s. They also include some discussion of assassination plots against foreign leaders. The C.I.A. account of these activities, running nearly 700 pages, is known as the "Family Jewels." It consists of responses by C.I.A. officials to a 1973 directive from the Director of Central Intelligence, James Schlesinger, to inform him of any activities that might violate the agency's charter. Many pages of the material made public today were excised by the agency. Many of the operations were disclosed in press reports in the mid-1970's beginning with a Dec. 22, 1974 story in The New York Times by Seymour M. Hersh. A commission appointed by President Gerald R. Ford and headed by his Vice President, Nelson A. Rockefeller, investigated the C.I.A. activities, as did a Senate committee, chaired by Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, and a House committee, chaired by Rep. Otis Pike, Democrat of New York. The actual text of the responses to Mr. Schlesinger remained classified and unavailable to the public until today.

Whenever I want to spend quality time with my cafe, I am drawn to five star java. A cup may cost as much as 10 euros, but it's served in gold tipped porcelain Limoges by painfully polite waiters in lavish salons where guests can linger for hours.

Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, is far from a publicity seeker. He rarely speaks on the Senate floor, at least in speeches specifically designed to garner big headlines. But when he does, it's surely worth taking a listen.
The showdown anticipated by The Lede and other observers of competitive eating may not happen after all.

Few things get a journalist's back up as quickly as the suggestion that he or she is somehow on the take, being paid by an interested party to influence what appears in the newspaper. So when Gregory Todd, a New York attorney, wrote to ask how New York Times columnists are compensated and whether Nicholas Kristof is receiving money from an African charity or David Brooks is getting paid by Rupert Murdoch, I forwarded the message to Andy Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, with the thought that his response could be quite interesting, as in pyrotechnic. After all, The Times editorial pages under his leadership are aggressive, to say the least.
Alessandra Ferri's farewell performance of Romeo & Juliet with  Roberto Bolle.

Michael Kinsley once wrote about a contest in which the question was: "If you were the author of a book, and could have any words of praise to feature in an ad for it, what would they be?" (One funny entry: "Destroys the philosophical basis of all previous human thought" - Hannah Arendt.)

When it comes to Thomas Allen's remarkable artwork, I'm late to the party. His stuff has appeared in Harper's, and on the covers of some of James Ellroy's novels. And last year Chip Kidd splashed his art around the Fall 2006 issue of Zoetrope. Kidd described Allen's work this way:

Basell, a division of the billionaire investor Leonard Blavatnik's Access Industries, said Tuesday it would acquire a rival chemical company, Huntsman for $5.6 billion, or $9.6 billion including debt. The announcement sent Huntsman shares up $5.40, or 29 percent, to $24.30 at the open of trading Tuesday.

Although he has not officially declared his presidential intentions, Fred D. Thompson, former senator of Tennessee, kicks off what looks a lot like a campaign in Nashville today, with stops this week in South Carolina and New Hampshire.
Stephen A. Schwarzman is quickly learning the downside of being a public company.

In a decision likely to have a significant impact on the 2008 election, the Supreme Court issued a ruling on Monday that changes campaign finance laws for corporations and unions. The Times's Linda Greenhouse and David D. Kirkpatrick report that the court's decision "has the effect of jettisoning a major part of the McCain-Feingold law, which Congress passed in 2002":

The founder of Biovail, the Canadian pharmaceutical company, has filed a $1 million slander suit against a former Banc of America Securities analyst, claiming he was defamed when the analyst called him a "criminal," The New York Post reported Tuesday. The Biovail founder, Eugene Melnyk, claimed he "suffered serious injury to his personal and professional reputation" as a result of comments made by the former analyst, Jerry Treppel.

Amid expectations of more big deals in the energy sector, James Metcalfe, the head of power mergers and acquisitions at Lehman Brothers, is leaving the firm to become global head of power banking at UBS.
Do you have a question for Matt? Submit it here and he will answer as many as he can.
Paris Hilton was freed from jail just after midnight, and once again it was the job of Steve Whitmore, the Los Angeles sheriff's spokesman, to break the news.
John Edwards joked yesterday about his $400 haircut, but he didn't get the same kind of laughs that the late-night professionals do on the same subject.

All five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission will appear before the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday, where they are expected to be asked to defend their agency against accusations that it might favor business interests at the expense of protecting investors. The hearing will mark the first time in more than a decade that all S.E.C. commissioners have been called to testify together, the Associated Press reported.
Images from “Live Free or Die Hard."
The buyout boom may be about to hit a bump.

The asset management firm BlackRock said it had agreed to acquire the fund of funds business of the Quellos Groupfor up to $1.7 billion to expand its alternative investment operations. Following the acquisition, BlackRock said it would combine its hedge and private equity fund of funds activities to form a business that is expected to have more than $25.4 billion in assets under management.

Barclays got a big boost in its takeover battle for ABN Amro when an adviser to the Dutch Supreme Court said that it should allow the Dutch Bank to sell its Chicago-based LaSalle unit to Bank of America.

Caisse de dépôt et placement de Québec and the Canadian buyout firm Onex have pulled out of a group bidding for Bell Canada, the Globe and Mail reported. Their withdrawal from the consortium, which is led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, throws into question the group's ability to muster an offer for Bell Canada.

Bear Stearns may have a lot of explaining to do about a big restatement of losses at one of its troubled hedge funds-and not just to its investors. According to BusinessWeek, the Securities and Exchange Commission recently opened a preliminary inquiry into the near-collapse of Bear Stearns' High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leveraged Fund.

Hillary Clinton is set to get a cash injection from Wall Street for her presidential campaign coffers Tuesday night at a fundraising event hosted by Warren Buffett and organized by Morgan Stanley's chief executive, John J. Mack, as well as a slew of other bankers, private equity executives and hedge fund managers, The Financial Times reported.

In a move that would enable it to branch into new businesses and possibly bolster its value should it go public, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts plans to obtain a securities broker-dealer license, according to The Deal.com.

IntercontinentalExchange on Monday commenced its proxy battle to block the merger of Chicago Board of Trade Holdings with Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, urging C.B.O.T. shareholders to vote against the deal.

Freedom Acquisition Holdings' deal to buy the hedge fund GLG Partners shows how special-purpose acquisition companies can offer a useful way to go public through the backdoor. The Financial Times's Lex column notes that these kinds of companies, known as SPAC's, have become extremely popular lately, raising $4 billion in the United States so far this year.

Unable to work out a merger agreement with Topps, its rival baseball card maker, Upper Deck has decided to take its offer directly to shareholders. Upper Deck said late Monday that it would make a tender offer to acquire its rival trading card manufacturer in a deal that values the company at $425 million.

Twenty-six years ago as a Stanford University graduate student and a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Andreas Bechtolsheim designed a simple but powerful personal computer workstation that would help define the modern technology era.

Federal prosecutors trying to bolster their faltering tax-shelter investigation have essentially dared a federal judge to dismiss charges against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG so that they can appeal the ruling and get the case moving again.

PricewaterhouseCoopers has withdrawn all its audit reports on the bankrupt Yukos oil company amid a tax-evasion investigation into the accounting firm, a decision that some of the oil producer's shareholders said Monday was "spineless." The auditor said that it had withdrawn its audits of Yukos from 1995 to 2004 because of new information that could have influenced those reports had it come to light earlier.

In a sign that the flood of private money in Hollywood only continues to rise, Legendary, the production company of the venture capitalist Thomas Tull, will invest $1 billion in a portfolio of films co-produced by Warner Brothers Pictures.
The Energy Department is creating three bioenergy research centers to find new ways to turn plants into fuel.
Revision3, an online television network created by Digg founders Jay Adelson and Kevin Rose, pulled in $8 million in second-round venture funding, led by Greylock Partners.

Financial shares tumbled Monday on concern that hedge fund losses tied to subprime mortgages would deepen, extending the stock market's worst weekly decline since March, Bloomberg News reported. Bear Stearns, the second-biggest United States underwriter of mortgage bonds, slid to its lowest level in nine months after a Merrill Lynch analyst said it might have to salvage another hedge fund.
Google is pressing for an extension to the Justice Department's oversight of Microsoft's business practices, which for the most part is set to expire in November, according to a court filing Monday.

Hollinger International's former chief lawyer, on trial for fraud with its ex-chairman, Conrad M. Black, is an "honest and trustworthy man" and should be acquitted of all charges, his lawyer told jurors Monday in closing arguments.

The Manulife Financial Corporation will pay $21.3 million to settle claims that its John Hancock investment units secretly diverted client funds to pay for marketing, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday.

A federal appeals court has denied a request by the former Cendant chairman, Walter A. Forbes, to be released pending an appeal of his conviction in a case over one of corporate America's biggest accounting scandals.
I.B.M. said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $7 million as part of a settlement of a federal regulatory investigation involving Dollar General's 2000 financial statements.

The Spanish power company Iberdrola plans to buy the regional utility owner Energy East Corporation for $4.5 billion in cash, the companies announced Monday. The boards of the utilities, meeting in New York and Madrid, agreed to the deal, which would give Energy East shareholders $28.50 a share, representing a 27 percent premium over the closing stock price Friday of $22.37.

Expedia Chairman Barry Diller said Monday he has no plans to cede control of the company to Liberty Media, the travel Web site's other large shareholder. Separately, Breakingviews argued that Mr. Diller's IAC/Interactive should consider streamlining itself by shedding the Home Shopping Network.

The Swiss drug maker Roche said Monday that it would start a tender offer to acquire Ventana Medical Systems for about $3 billion, or $75 a share, after its efforts to negotiate a merger were rebuffed.

The E. D. Smith Income Fund, a trust that owns a variety of private-label food manufacturing operations, said it planned to sell all of its assets to TreeHouse Foods of the United States in a deal valued at about C$217 million ($203 million).
Everquest Financial, a money management firm with ties to two troubled Bear Stearns hedge funds, on Monday withdrew its proposed $100 million initial public offering.

One of the toughest aspects of Darfur to report has been China's involvement in Sudan -- I know, I've tried. Now the best article yet on the subject has come out in the Christian Science Monitor. The article underscores China's web of military and political support for the regime in Khartoum. Here's an excerpt:
Full casting has been announced for "The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein."
The right summer drink at the right moment feels like a lifeline and can stamp itself on the memory for years.
A look at an 18th-century stable in Poland that has been turned into a house.
Apple’s new phone does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.
Shaquille O’Neal, the 325-pound, 7-foot-1 center for the Miami Heat, takes on obesity in his own way on ABC tonight, but not to pontificate.
Images of the life and career of Beverly Sills.

They have waited two long years, and now they have only 24 days to go. As the diehard fans of Harry Potter count the minutes until they can get their hands on "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows," the seventh and final installment in the monumentally successful series by J. K. Rowling, they are engaging in a frenzy of speculation and rumor-mongering about what will happen to their beloved characters.

I won't presume to say whether or not readers were acting altruistically -- only you know why you took the time to write -- but you provided plenty of ideas in response to last week's column and post about an experiment scanning the brains of people as their money went to charity. The two lead authors of the Science paper about the experiment, Ulrich Mayr and William Harbaugh of the University of Oregon, reviewed your comments and wrote a response:
U.S. and Iraqi soldiers moved house to house in Baquba, Iraq, searching for insurgents, and finding many buildings rigged with explosives.
DNA is aiding fossil hunters in the search for human origins by approaching the search for human origins from a different angle.
Jack Valenti, who died on April 26, was a warrior, and he knew how to win. He just looked harmless.
Providing a great product or service is not enough; you have to have customers talking about it.
Young Americans appear to lean slightly more to the left than the general population, according to a new poll.
Documents released by the Central Intelligence Agency showing abuses during the Cold War invite comparisons to the agencies’ actions since 2001.
The New Zealanders crossed the finish line with a 25-second advantage over their nearest rivals.
Senator Richard G. Lugar said was urging lawmakers and President Bush to change course quickly on Iraq.
Senate Republicans blocked a bill that would have made it easier for unions to organize workers.
Officials said the Sunni minister is wanted in connection with an assassination attempt more than two years ago.
Given up for dead two weeks ago, the bill cleared a key hurdle today, bolstering its chances for passage by the Senate within days.
The father of a captured Israeli soldier set in motion a request to Hamas for some sign that he was alive.

A 41-year-old man was killed and 14 people were injured as rival fans swinging metal pipes and throwing rocks clashed yesterday after a match between Argentine clubs in Buenos Aires.At least 78 arrests were reported in the fighting, which spilled onto a busy rush-hour freeway after Tigre defeated Nueva Chicago, 2-1, which was relegated from Argentina’s first division.The police, who appeared initially overwhelmed by the fighting, were backed up by reinforcements firing tear gas and rubber bullets as rock-throwing fans scattered from the stadium in the Mataderos section of the capital.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he was seeking federal disaster assistance after last week’s severe flooding in Sullivan and Delaware Counties. Mr. Spitzer toured the areas yesterday and said he would urge President Bush to make the disaster declaration, which would provide immediate aid for residents in the area, about 100 miles northwest of New York City. Two people died last week and two were still missing yesterday.

The death of a 3-month-old Brooklyn girl in April has been reclassified as a homicide by the medical examiner, the police said yesterday. The girl, Shavannah Pearson, was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center on March 25 because of breathing difficulty. The doctors discovered several fractured ribs, and the infant was transferred to New York University Medical Center. She died on April 3. On Sunday, the medical examiner determined the death was a homicide.

A 23-year-old Washington Heights man was arrested and charged with manslaughter after a 78-year-old man he was accused of attacking died, the police said yesterday. The man, Tarz Youngblood, had been fighting with the victim, Hazen Moorer, at 156th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue about 10:30 p.m. on June 16. The police found Mr. Moorer on the ground with a head injury. He was taken to Harlem Hospital Center, where he died on Sunday, the police said.
Despite struggling at the plate, the Mets earned their fourth win in a row, thanks to Shawn Green’s leadoff homer in the 11th inning.

Because of an editing error, an article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Norddeutsche Affinerie’s agreement to buy the Belgian copper smelter Cumerio misstated the price in dollars. It was $1.05 billion in cash, not $105 billion.

An article last Tuesday about a change in management at the Chelsea Hotel, long known as a haven for artists, writers and musicians, attributed two erroneous distinctions to it. Along with the Rembrandt and the Gramercy Park, the Chelsea Hotel was one of New York City’s first cooperative apartment buildings, but not the first. Also, the 12-story Chelsea was among the tallest buildings in the city when it was built, in 1883, but it was not the tallest in 1902; the tallest that year was the 29-story 15 Park Row, built in 1899.

An article on June 17 about a redevelopment project in Baltimore that has displaced some longtime residents misstated the amount of space Johns Hopkins University will occupy in the project’s research park. It has agreed to lease about a third of the space in the park’s first building, not “a majority of space” in the park. The article also misstated the lowest price for new housing in the development. While the bulk of the housing will indeed start at $250,000, some one-bedroom units are expected to be available for about $200,000, although prices have not been set.

An article in some copies on Friday about the Senate’s passage of an energy bill referred incorrectly at one point to the estimated fuel savings that could result from a mandatory increase in the efficiency of passenger vehicles. Consumption could possibly decrease by more than one million barrels a day, not one million gallons a day. (In the petroleum industry, a barrel is equal to 42 gallons.).

Because of an editing error, an article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Norddeutsche Affinerie’s agreement to buy the Belgian copper smelter Cumerio misstated the price in dollars. It was $1.05 billion in cash, not $105 billion.

A picture caption with a front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdoch’s management of his media company, the News Corporation, misidentified the owner of the British newspaper The Independent. It is owned by Independent News & Media, not by Mr. Murdoch’s company.

An obituary on Saturday of Guy Vander Jagt, a former congressman from Michigan, misstated the circumstances under which he filled an unexpired term in the House of Representatives in 1966. He won the seat in a special election; he was not appointed to the position. (Representatives, unlike senators, cannot be appointed to fill seats.).

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about Wired magazine’s personalizing its cover art with photographs uploaded to its Web site, Wired.com, misstated the name of the company that sold the Web site to Condé Nast, publisher of Wired. It is Daum Communications, not Baum.

The Long Beach Journal on Thursday, about the Friday Workshop, a book club in the Long Island beach community that has been in continuous existence for about 50 years, misstated part of the title of a Shakespeare play that the group recently read. It is “The Winter’s Tale,” not “A Winter’s Tale.”.

A picture caption with a front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdoch’s management of his media company, the News Corporation, misidentified the owner of the British newspaper The Independent. It is owned by Independent News & Media, not by Mr. Murdoch’s company.

Because of editing errors, an article on Friday about the murder conviction of a New York man, Thomas Toolan III, who killed his former companion, Elizabeth Lochtefeld, in Nantucket, Mass., in 2004, misidentified Ms. Lochtefeld’s place of residence and referred incorrectly to Brian Glenny, who prosecuted the case. Ms. Lochtefeld lived in Nantucket at the time, not Manhattan, and Mr. Glenny is an assistant district attorney with the Cape and Islands District Attorney’s Office; there is no “Nantucket district attorney.”.

A picture caption yesterday about opposition to a planned Wal-Mart in the predominantly Hasidic community of Monsey, N.Y., misidentified the man behind the counter of a discount store whose owners are among the opposition. He is Samuel Spitz, the brother of Mirel Kizelnik, an owner — not her husband, Joseph Kizelnik, co-owner of the store.
In a competition with eight states for federal funds to ease traffic jams, New York could lose out if its plan is not approved in Albany.
I.B.M. agreed to pay $7 million as part of a settlement of a federal regulatory investigation involving Dollar General’s 2000 financial statements.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ga., June 25 (AP) — The professional wrestler Chris Benoit, his wife and his son were found dead Monday. The police said they were investigating the deaths as a murder-suicide.

Penn State disciplined 10 players for their roles in an off-campus fight in which at least two people were hurt. The university confirmed that four players were temporarily expelled from July 1 through the end of the summer semester in mid-August for their roles in the April 1 fight. The players’ names were not released because of federal confidentiality laws, the university said, but defense lawyers have identified the four as safety Anthony Scirrotto, defensive lineman Chris Baker, linebacker Jerome Hayes and cornerback Lydell Sargeant. Two other players were put on permanent probation and ordered to attend counseling, and four were put on probation for a year. The discipline is separate from any punishment Coach Joe Paterno may impose.

Two college golfers and a Long Islander in his mid-20s led after the first round of the Metropolitan Golf Association’s Ike Championship at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale. Larry Haertel Jr. of Greenwich, the 2006 Ivy League champion from Brown; John Murphy of Brooklawn, who plays at Old Dominion; and Andreas Huber of Garden City Golf Club, the 2007 Long Island Amateur runner-up, had scores of two-over 72 to lead the field of 104 players. The four-time champion George Zahringer III was a stroke back at 73. Andrew Giuliani, the 2005 champion, shot a 76.

A jockey who kicked his horse in the stomach was suspended 30 days and fined $1,000 by Philadelphia Park officials, his agent said. The decision against the jockey, Victor Molina, came three days after his 40-minute disciplinary hearing for kicking the 2-year-old colt Yes Yes Ohyes in the stomach before a race. Molina’s agent, David Yannuzzy, said he was considering an appeal because the decision was too severe. Yannuzzy blamed the officials for overreacting because Molina’s kick was televised, prompting fans who saw the act to call the track and complain.

The Nebraska volleyball star Sarah Pavan maintained a 4.0 grade point average in biochemistry while leading the Cornhuskers to a 33-1 season and the N.C.A.A. title. Those achievements earned Pavan, a junior from Kitchener, Ontario, the 31st annual Honda-Broderick Cup as the nation’s female college athlete of the year. Pavan beat out the Tennessee athletes Candace Parker (basketball) and Monica Abbott (softball). The other nominees were Paula Infante of Maryland (field hockey) and Heather O’Reilly of North Carolina (soccer). The Canadian soccer player Christine Sinclair of the University of Portland won last year.

Hungary’s central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate, the European Union’s highest, for the first time since 2005 after inflation slowed. Policy makers, led by the central bank’s governor, Andras Simor, left, cut the two-week deposit rate a quarter-point, to 7.75 percent, after holding it since October. A leveling of wage growth also persuaded rate setters to lower borrowing costs, Mr. Simor said. Hungary’s annual inflation rate has quadrupled in the last year as Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany’s government raised taxes and utility bills. Inflation excluding food and energy prices slowed for a second month in May, and an easing of pressures in the labor market reduced concern that prices would rise faster than the inflation target in the medium term.

HSBC Holdings, the European bank, said it would buy part of an office tower in Shanghai to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in China. HSBC agreed to buy naming rights and occupy 20 floors of one of the twin towers of the Shanghai International Finance Center, to be completed by 2010, from Sun Hung Kai Properties, HSBC said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The tower, a few blocks from the bank’s current headquarters, would be renamed HSBC Building-Shanghai IFC. Stephen K. Green, the chairman of HSBC, disclosed the deal at a news conference in Shanghai, but he declined to say how much the bank had agreed to pay.

The Saga Group, a British provider of insurance and vacations to the consumers 50 and older, agreed to merge with the Automobile Association in a transaction that values the two closely held companies at £6.2 billion ($12.4 billion). The deal would enable Saga to offer policies and cruises to the Automobile Association’s older customers and the association to sell roadside assistance to Saga’s 2.5 million clients, the companies said. About 15 million British motorists rely on the association when their cars break down. Saga’s chief executive, Andrew Goodsell, will head the company, and the automobile association’s chief executive, Tim Parker, will quit.

The E. D. Smith Income Fund, a trust that owns a variety of private-label food manufacturing operations, said it planned to sell all of its assets to TreeHouse Foods of the United States in a deal valued at about 217 million Canadian dollars ($203 million). TreeHouse, based in Westchester, Ill., would also assume E. D. Smith’s existing debt and the transaction costs. If the deal goes through, stakeholders should receive up to 9.15 Canadian dollars a unit, subject to a “holdback” of 60 Canadian cents a unit to cover certain expenses, the fund said, which could lower the amount received by unit holders. Units of E. D. Smith, which is based in Winona, Ontario, rose 1.23 Canadian dollars, or 17 percent, to 8.57 Canadian dollars on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
A police officer accused of killing his pregnant girlfriend and her fetus has been ordered held on $5 million bond.
Bangor International Airport is again allowing a group that greets soldiers who pass through the airport to serve them treats: packaged cookies and candies.
The state is scheduled today to execute a convicted murderer who is dying of cancer.
President Bush was presented with a letter from high school seniors urging a halt to “violations of the human rights” of terror suspects held by the United States.
NASA is looking to share unused space aboard the International Space Station for science experiments, officials said.

John Barrasso, a conservative Republican surgeon and recent state senator from Wyoming, was sworn in as a United States senator by Vice President Dick Cheney. Gov. Dave Freudenthal of Wyoming selected him to fill the seat of Senator Craig Thomas, a Republican, who died June 4. Mr. Barrasso, 54, will serve until the beginning of 2009. A special election in November 2008 will decide who will finish Mr. Thomas’s term, which runs to January 2013. Mr. Barrasso has said he intends to run. The Democrats control the Senate by 51 to 49. One Democrat, Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota, is absent from the chamber while recovering from a brain hemorrhage.
Part of a vehicle barrier built two years ago along the Mexican border was erected in the wrong country, Senator Jeff Bingaman said.
Businessmen have offered to post a $1 million cash bond to release a man in prison for having consensual oral sex with 15-year-old girl when he was 17.
Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco has issued an executive order barring city departments, agencies and contractors from using city money for bottled water.

A man who reported that his infant daughter was having trouble breathing has been charged with beating and kicking her, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The father, Joshua Cohen, 20, pleaded not guilty yesterday in First District Court in Central Islip at his arraignment on charges of assault and endangering the welfare of a child, prosecutors said. The police said Mr. Cohen became angry on Sunday evening while watching the girl, whose name and age were not released by the police, and knocked her off a bed and kicked her in the head several times. The child was taken to Stony Brook University Medical Center, and was in critical condition yesterday, the police said.

A man accused of cheating immigrants by posing as a federal agent and promising them green cards and other documents in exchange for money was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to three to six years in prison. The man, John Nevarez, 55, of Manhattan, was sentenced after Justice Edward J. McLaughlin refused to let him withdraw his plea of guilty of grand larceny. The police had accused Mr. Nevarez of using a fake badge to convince immigrants that he could solve their documentation problems. Lt. John Zerillo of the Police Department’s impersonation unit said that Mr. Nevarez charged $8,000 per person in exchange for “absolutely nothing.”.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he was seeking federal disaster assistance after last week’s severe flooding in Sullivan and Delaware Counties. Mr. Spitzer toured the areas yesterday and said he would urge President Bush to make the disaster declaration, which would provide immediate aid for residents in the area, about 100 miles northwest of New York City. Two people died last week when their home was swept away, and as of yesterday, two people were still missing.

The State Transportation Department plans to scale back inspections of most Connecticut bridges in an effort to save money. Judd Everhart, a department spokesman, said that the department planned to inspect bridges in fair condition or better every four years instead of every two, The Hartford Courant reported. That means the inspections will occur half as often as the federal government recommends.

Two drivers were killed in crashes in Manhattan early yesterday, the police said. One, Francis Acosta, 24, of Webster Avenue in the Bronx, was headed north on the Henry Hudson Parkway at a high speed about 3:30 a.m. when his car hit the center divider, the police said. The car flew through the air and crashed onto the southbound West 95th Street exit ramp, the police said. The other driver, Angelo Corpas, 45, of West 138th Street, was killed about 2:30 a.m. when his Cadillac Escalade crashed into a taxi stopped at a red light at East 135th Street and Madison Avenue, the police said. The cabdriver, whose identity was not released, suffered minor injuries, the police said.

The Connecticut Supreme Court has ruled that a man who purchased an Andy Warhol silk screen featuring images of Elvis Presley is the rightful owner, even though the art dealer who sold it to him was later convicted of stealing it from a previous owner. In a decision released yesterday, the court unanimously ruled that the current owner, Peter Brant, could keep the painting, “Red Elvis,” a six-foot-tall work worth as much as $12 million. The former owner, Kerstin Lindholm of Greenwich, had challenged the sale. Her art dealer, Anders Malmberg, was later convicted in Sweden of criminal theft charges in connection with the sale. But the court found that Mr. Brant had made a reasonable effort to confirm that Mr. Malmberg was authorized to make the sale, including hiring a lawyer to conduct an investigation.

In response to the death in March of a freshman who was binge drinking, Rider University said yesterday that it would take steps to curb campus drinking, including banning alcohol at fraternity parties. The freshman, Gary DeVercelly, 18, of Long Beach, Calif., had a blood alcohol content of .426 when he died after a night of drinking at the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house. In April, the university appointed a task force of faculty and staff members and students to come up with ways to address drinking on campus. The group’s recommendations, issued yesterday, include prohibiting alcohol at all social events in residence halls or fraternity houses. Sororities did not allow alcohol at parties even before Mr. DeVercelly’s death. The recommendations will go into full effect this fall. Students over 21 would still be allowed to drink alcohol in their rooms.
New Yorkers will receive a $1 coupon for General Electric fluorescent light bulbs with their Con Edison bills as part a consumer education campaign.

A man was acquitted yesterday in State Supreme Court of charges that he murdered his half-brother. The defendant, Rannik Williams, 23, had been charged with second-degree murder after his half-brother, Michael, 17, was fatally shot in October 2005 in front of the building in East New York where both men lived. Prosecutors said he survived long enough to identify his killer for the police. Rannik Williams was ordered released from jail after his acquittal.

A 2-year-old boy drowned yesterday in an above-ground pool belonging to his relatives, the police said. Justice Neil J. Firetog of State Supreme Court denied a motion yesterday to appoint a special prosecutor to review the disclosure by the district attorney’s office of grand jury testimony in a case involving the disposal of a newborn. His decision allows prosecutors to continue their case against Andria Sergio, 27, of Bay Ridge, who has been charged with hindering prosecution and improperly disposing of a body in the death of a girl delivered by her sister Laura, 25, in April. The baby was found on the back porch of the family home. The cause of death was found to be asphyxiation and hypothermia, and Laura Sergio has been charged with murder. After prosecutors, in a court filing, disclosed a summary of grand jury testimony by Andria Sergio, defense lawyers asked Justice Firetog to dismiss the charges, arguing that the disclosure was improper. Prosecutors successfully argued that the disclosure was meant to ensure that the testimony would be accepted as evidence at trial.

The next president of the College of Staten Island will be Tomás D. Morales, left, the provost and vice president for academic affairs at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, and a professor of education there. Dr. Morales, 53, whose appointment was approved yesterday by the trustees of the City University of New York, earned a bachelor’s degree from the State University of New York at New Paltz and a master’s degree and Ph.D. in educational administration and policy from SUNY Albany. Before moving to Cal Poly, he was vice president for student affairs and dean of students at CUNY’s City College campus from 1994 to 2001. Dr. Morales, whose presidency begins on Aug. 1, will succeed Marlene Springer, who is retiring as president after 13 years.

The National Rifle Association has asked local television affiliates in several states not to air an advertisement created by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s antigun group, Mayors Against Illegal Guns. The ads, which have run in the districts of various members of Congress, urge the repeal of legislation that the mayor argues prevents federal authorities from sharing gun trace data with cities and local law enforcement agencies. Supporters of the legislation say it protects the privacy of gun owners. Jason Post, a Bloomberg spokesman, said the ad was scheduled to begin today in Louisiana and New Hampshire.

REGISTERED TRAVELER PROGRAM While skeptics point to the sluggish pace of the nationwide rollout of the Registered Travel Program, a second competitor, Unisys, said it opened its first program, called rtGO, at Reno-Tahoe International Airport. Membership in rtGO is $100 a year. Under the program, participants cleared in a background security check receive an identification card encoded with biometric data like iris scans and fingerprints. The card provides access to a special security lane. Several other competitors are planning to enter the business but the main operator is Verified Identity Pass, whose Clear program has about 48,000 members and locations at Terminals 1, 4 and 7 at Kennedy International Airport, as well as at airports in Orlando, Fla.; Cincinnati; San Jose, Calif.; and Indianapolis. Verified Identity plans to open a lane soon at Terminal B in Newark. While members get a special lane, so far other planned benefits of the program, like the ability to pass throughout without removing shoes, laptops or outer garments, have lagged behind, pending Transportation Security Administration approval of new technologies.

LEVIEN--Lois. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished and longtime member, Lois Levien. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President George Asch, Secretary $(6$)LEVIEN--Lois, 82, of New York City. Adored wife of the late Henry. Survived by her loving daughters, Nancy and Louise, their husbands, Richard Goodman and Robert Eby, and her grandchildren Eric, David, and Allison. A woman of incredible energy, who shared her love of life and New York with everyone. She was a loving and generous friend to many and an active volunteer and donor to important causes. We lost her too soon and will miss her always. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to The Fresh Air Fund. Services Wednesday, June 27, 9:30am, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue and 65th Street.

The Energy Department is creating three bioenergy research centers to find new ways to turn plants into fuel. The three centers, which the department described as three start-up companies with $125 million each in capital, will be in Oak Ridge, Tenn.; Madison, Wis.; and near Berkeley, Calif. They will involve numerous universities, national laboratories and private companies. The goal of the centers, which are to be announced on Tuesday, is to bring new technologies to market within five years.
To the Editor: Re ''Mr. Mayor, the Nader of '08?'' (column, June 23):

New Yorkers will receive a $1 coupon for General Electric fluorescent light bulbs with their Con Edison bills this August as part of GreeNYC, a $3.4 million consumer education campaign in ecology. The effort, which is being provided to the city at no cost, includes posted advertisements and a broadcast and print media campaign, and suggests 10 ways to save energy, like turning off air-conditioners in empty rooms and using public transportation. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg noted at a news conference introducing the campaign that he would start unplugging the charger for his BlackBerry when it is not in use. He said he had always thought that when the it is not in use. He said he had always thought that when the charger was plugged in but not charging the BlackBerry, no electricity was being used. ''Turns out that is wrong,'' he said.

LLOYD--Frank Van Duyne, 66, the Managing Partner of Harwood Lloyd, Hackensack, New Jersey, died Sunday, June 24, 2007. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, June 28, 2007 at the Bergen Performing Arts Center, 30 North Van Brunt Street, in Englewood, New Jersey at 11:00 a.m. He is survived by his wife, Karen, and daughters, Kathryn Lloyd Champ, Kristina Lloyd Sample and Heather Lloyd Sherman. Beloved grandfather of Kathryn Champ, Olivia Champ, Sophie Champ, Alexandra Sample, Matthew Sample, Charlotte Sample, Oliver Sherman and Isabel Sherman. Dear brother of Eve Lloyd Thompson. Frank was a graduate of the University of Denver where he received a Bachelors of Arts degree and a Juries Doctorate degree from the University of Denver in 1966. At the time of his death, he was the Managing Partner of Harwood Lloyd, one of the premier law firms in the State of New Jersey where he helped nurture and grow the careers of hundreds of lawyers who owe him a great debt of gratitude. Frank was admitted to practice law in the State of Colorado in 1965, the State of New Jersey in 1966 and New York in 1981. He was also admitted to practice law in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit and the United States Supreme Court. He was certified by the New Jersey Supreme Court as a Certified Civil Trial Attorney, a Trustee of the Bergen County Bar Association, President of the Bergen County Bar Foundation, Chairman of the Judicial Selection Committee of Bergen County, the Supreme Court of New Jersey District Ethics Committee and the Supreme Court of New Jersey Fee Arbitration Committee. He was appointed by the New Jersey Supreme Court to the Bergen County Advisory Committee on Differentiated Case Management, Arbitrator of Auto Negligence Cases and the Task Force on Alternate Dispute Resolution. He was a Member of the National Panel of Arbitrators, American Arbitration Association, American, New Jersey, Bergen County and Hudson County Bar Associations, Diplomat American Board of Trial Advocates, Master Justice Morris Pashman American Inn of Court and elected Professional Lawyer of the Year 2000 by the New Jersey Commission of Professionalism. Member of the Board, Hackensack University Medical Center, Chairman of the Board of the United States Equestrian Team, Audit Committee United States Equestrian Team, Board of Directors United States Equestrian Federation, Inc., Board of Directors -National Horse Shows, Member American Horse Shows Association Hearing Committee, President Bernice Barbour Foundation, Board of Trustees and Vice Chairman The Animal Medical Center, Trustee Alfiero and Lucia Palestroni Foundation, Inc., Board of Directors Make-AWish Foundation, Board of Trustees -The Seeing Eye. Also a Member of the Arcola Country Club, Pine Valley Golf Club, Palm Beach Polo & Country Club, The Bears Club and US Seniors' Golf Association. Frank was known and will be remembered for his kindness, and generosity of spirit, his professionalism and charitable works and deeds that benefited so many people and organizations. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Hackensack University Medical Center, 360 Essex Street, Suite 301, Hackensack, New Jersey 07601 in memory of Frank Lloyd.

A picture caption with a front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdoch's management of his media company, the News Corporation, misidentified the owner of the British newspaper The Independent. It is owned by Independent News & Media, not by Mr. Murdoch's company.

The death of a 3-month-old Brooklyn girl in April has been reclassified as a homicide by the medical examiner, the police said yesterday. The girl, Shavannah Pearson, was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center on March 25 because of breathing difficulty. The doctors discovered several fractured ribs, and the infant was transferred to New York University Medical Center. She died on April 3. On Surinday, the medical examiner determined the death was a homicide.

You might have noticed that corporate America has taken a pass on Barry Bonds, that major companies have exhibited little interest in linking their brands to the near-certainty of Bonds hitting his 756th home run this year. Major League Baseball's sponsors are doing nothing to celebrate him for the obvious reasons: He is peevish and has been tailed for years by suspicions of using performance-enhancing drugs. It is worth noting that he has never been revealed to have tested positive for steroids or been indicted.

Hungary's central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate, the European Union's highest, for the first time since 2005 after inflation slowed. Policy makers, led by the central bank's governor, Andras Simor, left, cut the two-week deposit rate a quarter-point, to 7.75 percent, after holding it since October. A leveling of wage growth also persuaded rate setters to lower borrowing costs, Mr. Simor said. Hungary's annual inflation rate has quadrupled in the last year as Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany's government raised taxes and utility bills. Inflation excluding food and energy prices slowed for a second month in May, and an easing of pressures in the labor market reduced concern that prices would rise faster than the inflation target in the medium term.

FRANK--Ruth Fleischl, age 92, wife of 47 years of the late Clarence B. Frank, mother of Marianne Frank Sanbonmatsu, Charles Steven Frank, and the late Gwen Clare Frank. Devoted grandmother and great - grandmother. Ruth passed away on June 23 in Fort Myers, FL. Ruth received her B.A. from Wellesley College and M.S. in Social Work from William and Mary. Did her post-graduate work at Columbia University. And served children as a psychiatric social worker in Standford, New Canaan, and Norwalk. She and her husband built the first ''active'' solar house in Connecticut, and authored a book, ''Something New Under the Sun'', about the experience. Ruth lived on Sanibel Island until 2000. Services will be held June 28 at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. Donations may be offered in her memory to Hope Hospice of Fort Myers, FL.

To the Editor: ''Assembly Leader Wields Power by Keeping Albany Guessing'' (front page, June 20) gets it right about Sheldon Silver, speaker of the New York State Assembly, where so many habitually get it wrong.

A court in Cairo convicted Muhammad Sayyid Saber Ali, an Egyptian nuclear engineer, of spying for Israel and sentenced him to life in prison. Mr. Ali, who worked for Egypt's atomic agency, was charged with delivering information about the agency and one of two nuclear reactors to Israeli intelligence agents in exchange for about $17,000. He admitted that he had delivered reports that he took from the agency but said the information was general, available online and not a secret. In Egypt, a sentence of life is equivalent to 25 years in prison; a pardon for good conduct is possible after two-thirds of the time has been served.

van der Vloed Conte--Gertrude 1932-2007. We celebrate the life of a much loved mother, wife, sister, aunt. Her joy in the simple pleasures inspired us all: R.I.P. Close down the dark house! Once upon a time it was bright, And had a sense of humor. Board up the windows! The sun Fails to smile on their panes. Shut the kitchen! Tins of tea, oatmeal, sugar and Cloves stand still. The teakettle No longer whistles. Lock the doors! People don't Come calling anymore. Momma is dead. Service at Church of the Good Shepherd on June 27 at 10am, 236 E. 31st St. Wake at Gannon Funeral Home 152 E. 28th St. NYC on June 26 from 7-9pm. Suggested donations to above mentioned church.

Because of editing errors, an article on Friday about the murder conviction of a New York man, Thomas Toolan III, who killed his former companion, Elizabeth Lochtefeld, in Nantucket, Mass., in 2004, misidentified Ms. Lochtefeld's place of residence and referred incorrectly to Brian Glenny, who prosecuted the case. Ms. Lochtefeld lived in Nantucket at the time, not Manhattan, and Mr. Glenny is an assistant district attorney with the Cape and Islands District Attorney's Office; there is no ''Nantucket district attorney.''

HSBC Holdings, the European bank, said it would buy part of an office tower in Shanghai to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in China. HSBC agreed to buy naming rights and occupy 20 floors of one of the twin towers of the Shanghai International Finance Center, to be completed by 2010, from Sun Hung Kai Properties, HSBC said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The tower, a few blocks from the bank's current headquarters, would be renamed HSBC Building-Shanghai IFC. Stephen K. Green, the chairman of HSBC, disclosed the deal at a news conference in Shanghai, but he declined to say how much the bank had agreed to pay
