Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Jane, his children, grandchildren, family and friends. Joel J. Kudlowitz, President Marilyn Shebshaievitz, Executive Director $(6$)KAPLAN--Rabbi Allen S., beloved husband of Jane, loving father of Walter, Sarah and David, loving grandfather of Hannah and Noah, died June 22, 2007. Retired Captain in the U.S.N. and Rabbi of Temple Emanu-el. He made a difference in many lives and will live in our hearts forever. We will miss you.

MURDOCH'S BUSINESS IN CHINA As Rupert Murdoch seeks to buy Dow Jones, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal, his record in China has drawn attention for what it shows about his management style. AN I.P.O. IS WITHDRAWN Everquest Financial's initial public offering statement on May 9 disclosed that substantially all of the assets in its $700 million portfolio had been bought from two funds that had suffered heavy losses in March and April when many of the assets in them, backed by subprime mortgages, tumbled in value. Everquest has withdrawn the offering. [C1.]

PASTERNAK--Laura Shul man, 84, of Boynton Beach, Florida, and Stockbridge, Massachusetts, on June 24, 2007. Daughter of the late Joseph and Rose Shulman, loving wife for 63 years to Dr. Richard Pasternak, devoted mother of Doctors Gavril and Reuven Pasternak and Dr. Sara Pasternak Levine, mother by marriage of Mathew Levine, Nancy Pasternak, and the late Sandi Friedman Pasternak, and grandmother of Katie, David, Annie, Andrew, Robert and Jordan Pasternak and Mimi, Max, and Joseph Levine. Services June 26, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY at 11:30, followed by burial at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens.

An article in some copies on Friday about the Senate's passage of an energy bill referred incorrectly at one point to the estimated fuel savings that could result from a mandatory increase in the efficiency of passenger vehicles. Consumption could possibly decrease by more than one million barrels a day, not one million gallons a day. (In the petroleum industry, a barrel is equal to 42 gallons.)

KRIEGER--Leonore, 90, died peacefully at her home in NYC. Formerly of Rockaway Park, NY, beloved wife of the late Dr. Jerome Krieger, she is survived by children Eileen and Peter Davidson, and Kenneth and Lynne Krieger. Devoted grandmother of Ellen, Karen and Jeff, Jed and Alision, Michael and Cara, and Adam, and great-grandmother of Sloane, she was a woman of rare character and intelligence. She was cherished by friends and family for her avid curiosity about the world, and thoughtful interest in the lives of others. Services Tuesday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

The first time I heard Jack Valenti speak, I noted that he was dapper, unexpectedly handsome and short. He had arrived at a meeting of the trustees of the American Film Institute to nominate his friend Kirk Douglas for the annual Life Achievement Award. When he had finished and whirled out, he was still dapper and unexpectedly handsome, but he had grown very big in stature. I had witnessed Mr. Valenti in action, an in-the-flesh version of his autobiography, ''This Time, This Place: My Life in War, the White House, and Hollywood.'' He had exuded charm, established himself as everyone's pal with a few harmless anecdotes, taken the room by surprise with a passionate (and well-prepared) speech and rapidly moved on to his next battle, confident he'd get what he came for. (He did; Mr. Douglas got the award.)

Hate-crime laws have long had their skeptics, and the one enacted by New York State in 2000 is no exception. The law increases the penalties for wrongdoing committed out of hatred of the victim because of factors like race, religion, age, sexual orientation or disability. Beat up someone for being, say, Jewish or black or gay, and you will do extra prison time if convicted. The theory is that a crime motivated by hatred can affect an entire community, not just the victim.

The Alaska high school student who unfurled a 14-foot banner with the odd message ''Bong Hits 4 Jesus'' insisted that it was a banner about nothing, a prank designed to get him and his friends on television as the Olympic torch parade went through Juneau en route to the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City. The school's principal insisted, to the contrary, that the banner advocated, or at least celebrated, illegal drug use, and that the student, Joseph Frederick, should be punished for displaying it. She suspended him for 10 days.

Pope Benedict XVI appointed a French cardinal, Jean-Louis Tauran, to lead the Vatican's newly restored Council for Interreligious Dialogue, which oversees dialogue with Muslims and other faiths. Cardinal Tauran, 64, was the Vatican's foreign minister under Pope John Paul II.

Although he has not officially declared his presidential intentions, former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee kicks off what looks a lot like a campaign today in Nashville, with stops this week in South Carolina and New Hampshire. In those critical early primary states, Mr. Thompson will be meeting Republican Party officials and supporters, and raising money, mostly behind closed doors. Although he has yet to announce his bid for the Republican nomination formally, he has set up a committee for donors called the First Founders.

Federal transportation officials studying New York City's plan to charge drivers who enter the most congested parts of Manhattan on weekdays heard new financial details about the proposal during a meeting yesterday in Washington. The officials also raised questions about whether the State Legislature would sign off on the proposal, which is supported by Governor Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. If it doesn't, the federal officials warned, the program of ''congested pricing'' might not be eligible for millions of dollars in federal funds, state and federal officials said.

CORELLI--Ronald, 78, of Katonah on June 24, 2007. Formerly of Chappaqua. He was the owner and President of Corham Artificial Flower Company in White Plains. He was the loving husband of Angela and loving father to Randall, Elise, John, Jeanne, Christopher and Michael. Adored grandfather of 22. Visiting at Beecher Funeral Home, Inc. 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, Wednesday 24PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10AM at St. Patrick's R.C. Church in Bedford. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Priestly Fraternity of St. Peter, Griffin Road, P.O. Box 196, Elmhurst, PA 18416.

The Supreme Court on Monday closed the courthouse door on a lawsuit challenging the Bush administration's use of taxpayer money to support its Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives. By a vote of 5 to 4, the court ruled that taxpayers could not sue to block federal expenditures that they allege violate the constitutional separation of church and state.

As the manager of last year's National League champion, Tony La Russa of the Cardinals has the privilege of filling out his team for the All-Star Game this year. La Russa, however, calls it more of a challenge. ''The perception that has to be corrected is that you don't pick much of an All-Star team; it's picked,'' La Russa said, shaking his head.

In an alternate universe, this might have been a momentous week, even a historic week, for New York and its beleaguered N.B.A. franchise. Had the Knicks stripped their payroll a few years back and suffered through some rough seasons, they might be stitching a uniform for Greg Oden or Kevin Durant, the two franchise-changing talents who headline Thursday's draft. In another alternate universe, in which the Knicks never traded for Eddy Curry, they might be pondering another dozen intriguing prospects who will fill out the upper half of the first round.

To the Editor: I must voice serious disagreement with ''Why Pro-Choice Is a Bad Choice for Democrats,'' by Melinda Henneberger (Op-Ed, June 22). Simply put, if the Democrats abandon their pro-choice platform, I (and millions of others) will be forced to find a party more in line with our beliefs and values.

Earlier this month, Boston Red Sox fans were angry. All right, Red Sox fans can often get angry when anyone says anything they construe as negative about their team or positive about their team's archrival, the Yankees. But in this particular instance, they were outraged because it was the start of a 17-day interleague segment of the major league schedule, and the Yankees were playing the unimposing Pittsburgh Pirates while the Red Sox were playing the Arizona Diamondbacks, who were practically in first place in the National League West.

WITTENBERG--Noel, Passed away on June 25th. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann of 59 years, who lost her best friend, devoted daughters Audrey and the late Jacquie, son-in-law Richard and grandchildren Sloane, Devon and Derek. He was the son of the late Jack and Rae Wittenberg, and brother of the late Ina Lakritz. Uncle Noel will be missed by his adoring nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews, and by countless friends who were lucky to have him as part of their lives. Born June 13th, 1921, in the Bronx. He served proudly in the Third Infantry Regimen, The Old Guard, in WWII, followed by an extraordinary career in the fashion industry. His passion for Judaism and Israel, and pride in Jewish athletes particularly, was exceeded only by his boundless love for his family. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. at 10AM

An article last Tuesday about a change in management at the Chelsea Hotel, long known as a haven for artists, writers and musicians, attributed two erroneous distinctions to it. Along with the Rembrandt and the Gramercy Park, the Chelsea Hotel was one of New York City's first cooperative apartment buildings, but not the first. Also, the 12-story Chelsea was among the tallest buildings in the city when it was built, in 1883, but it was not the tallest in 1902; the tallest that year was the 29-story 15 Park Row, built in 1899.

To the Editor: We agree with your June 20 editorial ''China and the Chest Thumpers'' that our domestic practices are significantly to blame for our exploding trade deficit and other imbalances. None of us have ever argued that being tough with China or other trading partners will cure all our economic and budget ills. But making sure that we have up-to-date tools to enforce the rules of the international economy is critical to the strength of American industry and the stability of the global economy.

Bangor International Airport is again allowing a group that greets soldiers who pass through the airport to serve them treats: packaged cookies and candies. Concerned about liability and the prospect of food borne illness, the airport last month had asked the group, the Maine Troop Greeters, to stop serving treats, which had expanded from cake and cookies to sandwiches and pizza. Bill Knight, who founded the greeters in 2003, said the group was pleased with the compromise. ''They treat us good,'' he said of the airport, which has allowed the group free use of a room free since 2004.

LINDSEY GRAHAM, a Republican senator from South Carolina, is right: ''The image of Guantánamo Bay and the reality of Guantánamo Bay are completely different.'' It is disappointing that so many embrace a contrived image. Reality for Guantánamo Bay is the daily professionalism of its staff, the humanity of its detention centers and the fair and transparent nature of the military commissions charged with trying war criminals. It is a reality that has been all but ignored or forgotten.

The Supreme Court on Monday took a sharp turn away from campaign finance regulation, opening a wide exception to the advertising restrictions that it upheld when the McCain-Feingold law first came before it four years ago. In a splintered 5-to-4 decision, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said that as interpreted broadly by federal regulators and the law's supporters, the restrictions on television advertisements paid for from corporate or union treasuries in the weeks before an election amounted to censorship of core political speech unless those advertisements explicitly urge a vote for or against a particular candidate.

Eleven businessmen have offered to post a $1 million cash bond to secure release of a man serving 10 years in prison for having consensual oral sex with 15-year-old girl when he was 17. One of the potential donors is Whitney Tilson, a hedge fund manager; the others have remained anonymous. The offer is meant to pressure David McDade, the Douglas County district attorney, into granting bond for Genarlow Wilson, who was ordered released from prison earlier this month after a Superior Court judge ruled that his sentence was a ''grave miscarriage of justice.'' That decision was appealed by the Georgia attorney general, which is keeping Mr. Wilson in prison until at least October when the State Supreme Court is set to hear arguments in his habeas corpus appeal. Mr. McDade has declined to set bond, saying Georgia law forbids it; Mr. Wilson's lawyer disputes that.

Two college golfers and a Long Islander in his mid-20s led after the first round of the Metropolitan Golf Association's Ike Championship at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale. Larry Haertel Jr. of Greenwich, the 2006 Ivy League champion from Brown; John Murphy of Brooklawn, who plays at Old Dominion; and Andreas Huber of Garden City Golf Club, the 2007 Long Island Amateur runner-up, had scores of two-over 72 to lead the field of 104 players. The four-time champion George Zahringer III was a stroke back at 73. Andrew Giuliani, the 2005 champion, shot a 76.

Liberia's former president, Charles Taylor, refused for the second time to attend his war-crimes trial in The Hague, instead continuing to bicker with the United Nations-backed court from his jail cell over the size and financing of his defense team. The presiding judge at the Special Court for Sierra Leone, which is trying him, chided court administrators for not dealing promptly with the defense issue, aggravated since Mr. Taylor fired his lead lawyer this month.

For nearly four hours last Thursday night, Flight 5637, a 50-seat regional jet, was stuck on the ground by bad weather at Kennedy International Airport. The air-conditioning wasn't working, and no one seemed to have a clue about when the plane would take off. I wish I could say I was writing about this because the situation was unusual. Or that it was as bad as air travel can get. But I can't.

For some loyal denizens of YouTube.com, including the politically attuned, the recent redesign of that site that replaced users' choices for the most viewed or highly rated videos with editors' choices in subject categories like news and politics is akin to dictatorship. Detractors say the changes are anathema to the user-generated, popularity-driven ethos of the site and are calling it ''EditorTube.'' Liberal and high-tech bloggers had already complained that CNN had usurped the community's shared power by exercising control over which video questions would be broadcast at the YouTube-CNN debates for presidential hopefuls.

Testifying at a Congressional hearing on Monday about the government's environmental response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, Christie Whitman staunchly defended her statements assuring the public that the air in Lower Manhattan was safe in the days immediately after the attack. Facing some of her toughest Congressional critics, Mrs. Whitman, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, repeatedly denied the critics' assertions that there had been a deliberate attempt to play down health risks or that the White House had improperly influenced statements she made in the weeks after 9/11.

STARR--Jean, of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away peacefully June 23, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Melvin. Devoted mother of Tama and Jonathan and mother-inlaw of Charles Portney and Helen Nielsen. Cherished grandmother of Julie Torres and sister of the late Bernice Stone. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 E. Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

HEFTLER--Thomas, 64. The partners, associates and staff of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan LLP mourn the loss of their long-time colleague, co-managing and managing partner, tragically taken from this world too soon on June 23. A brilliant lawyer and a gentle soul, his contributions to the Firm will be long remembered. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his wife and our partner, Lois Weinroth, and their family. The funeral service for Tom will begin at 1:15pm on Tuesday, June 26th, at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. $(6$)HEFTLER--Tom. A dear friend with a warm heart, thoughtful mind, and beautiful soul. One of the original Biker Boyz. We sure had a lot of fun. We send our love and support to Lois and the rest of the family. We will really miss him. Steve Semlitz and Cathy Glaser $(6$)HEFTLER--Tom. The Migraine and Pain Fund mourns the passing of our good friend and founding Director. His life and work was and will always be an inspiration to us all. The Board, Staff and Doctors of the Migraine and Pain Fund. $(6$)HEFTLER--Tom. HETCO mourns the sudden passing of our good friend and longtime advisor. He helped us get off the ground and kept us going with his wisdom, decency, and sharp legal mind. He will be missed by all those lucky enough to have known him. Steve Semlitz, Steve Hendel, Guy Merison and the people of HETCO.
Where the First Amendment is implicated, the tie goes to the speaker, not the censor. CHIEF JUSTICE JOHN G. ROBERTS JR.,

MALVIN--Adrienne Helis, known as Sugar to her family, passed away on June 22, 2007 in Los Angeles, California, where she resided in recent years. Preceded in death by her beloved husband, A. Mal Malvin, noted businessman of New York and Holmby Hills, California. Daughter of the late William G. Helis, Sr., famed thoroughbred sportsman and oil pioneer, and the late Mrs. William G. (Betty) Helis, Sr. noted philanthropist, both of New Orleans, Louisiana. Survived by her stepsons, Ronald and Barry Malvin, her niece, Cassandra Helis Citro of Los Angeles, California, her nephew, William A. Droulia of New Orleans, Louisiana, and and grandnieces and grandnephews. Also survived by her devoted friend, Donna Henry Moore. She was preceded in her death by her sister and constant companion, Diana Helis Henry, philanthropist of Los Angeles, California, her brother William G. Helis, Jr., well known oilman and philanthropist of New Orleans, Louisiana and her sister, Virginia Helis Droulia, sportswoman and philanthropist of New Orleans, Louisiana. Mrs. Malvin was a philanthropist and an avid collector and lover of art and antiques. She was also an accomplished French Chef, having studied at the famed Le Cordon Bleu. Visitation will be Thursday, June 28, 2007, 9:30am to 10:30am with a Service following at 10:30am. Pierce Brothers Westwood Village, 1218 Glendon Ave

HOLLANDER--Bernard, M.D., Beloved husband of the late Ruth Skolnick Hollander, devoted father of Diane and Arthur Zamansky and Dr. David and Phyllis Hollander, cherished grandfather of Robert and Melissa, Beth and Marshaal, Brian, Leslie and Scott. Great-grandfather of Sawyer Reed. WWII vet, past President Jamaica Medical Center, past President NY State Society of Anesthesiologists, past Vice President Lawrence Board of Education and past President of Aberdeen Golf and Country Club.

The Connecticut Supreme Court has ruled that a man who purchased an Andy Warhol silk screen featuring images of Elvis Presley is the rightful owner, even though the art dealer who sold it to him was later convicted of stealing it from a previous owner. In a decision released yesterday, the court unanimously ruled that the current owner, Peter Brant, could keep the painting, ''Red Elvis,'' a sixfoot- tall work worth as much as $12 million. The former owner, Kerstin Lindholm of Greenwich, had challenged the sale. Her art dealer, Anders Malmberg, was later convicted in Sweden of criminal theft charges in connection with the sale. But the court found that Mr. Brant had made a reasonable effort to confirm that Mr. Malmberg was authorized to make the sale, including hiring a lawyer to conduct an investigation.

An obituary on Saturday of Guy Vander Jagt, a former congressman from Michigan, misstated the circumstances under which he filled an unexpired term in the House of Representatives in 1966. He won the seat in a special election; he was not appointed to the position. (Representatives, unlike senators, cannot be appointed to fill seats.)

WILLIAMS--Roderick O., age 94, died June 22, 2007, at Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT. He is survived by his wife, Dorothea C. of 70 years, a son, Bruce N. and his daughter-in-law, and two granddaughters. He was predeceased by a son, Alan S. in 1993. Graduate of Yale, 1934 and Teachers College, Columbia in 1946. Memorial service announcement will follow at a later date.

General managers give personality tests. They hold individual workouts and measure players. But there is no comparison between watching a player and competing against him. There are skills that are nearly impossible to evaluate from the stands. How does a player react when you shade him to the left? Will he overreach and make a bad play after a missed shot?

A picture caption yesterday about opposition to a planned Wal-Mart in the predominantly Hasidic community of Monsey, N.Y., misidentified the man behind the counter of a discount store whose owners are among the opposition. He is Samuel Spitz, the brother of Mirel Kizelnik, an owner -- not her husband, Joseph Kizelnik, co-owner of the store.

MERGEL--Jeremy, born in Yorktown Heights, and a resident of Manhattan, died suddenly on June 24th. He is survived by his loving wife, Kathryn, his father, Bruce, his sisters, Tamara and Merideth, and his nephew, Matthew. He was also beloved by his mother Bobbi, recently deceased. Jeremy was a realestate manager for Clear Channel, and was highly respected in his field. He was known for his loving, generous nature and his larger than life personality. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, and all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, please consider honoring Jeremy by making a donation to Support Connection of Yorktown Heights www.supportconnection.org Funeral services will be held on June 26th at Clark Funeral Home in Yorktown Heights. Shiva will be held at the Mergel home on Tuesday, June 26th from 2:00-8:00 p.m. and Wednesday, June 27th , 11:00-8:00 p.m.

I have been lucky enough to convert my passion for travel into a successful travel business. For me, business travel is not misery -- it is pleasure. And in the 30 years that I've been doing my work, I hope that I have made a difference in the way that travelers view the world. Yet in my sleep I often wonder if I could have done more. In the '80s, I made the first raft descent of the Alas River in Sumatra, running through the largest orangutan reserve in the world. Timber poaching has reduced the once-luxurious habitat to a scrawny shadow. The ''men of the forest'' are on the brink of extinction, and the wondrous river run is gone.

Recent polls show Americans broadly disapprove of the work Congress is doing, with discontent climbing to levels seen late last year, when the control of Congress changed hands for the first time in 12 years. Disapproval ran as high as 71 percent in a Gallup poll, up 11 points since April and 16 points since February.

An article on June 17 about a redevelopment project in Baltimore that has displaced some longtime residents misstated the amount of space Johns Hopkins University will occupy in the project's research park. It has agreed to lease about a third of the space in the park's first building, not ''a majority of space'' in the park. The article also misstated the lowest price for new housing in the development. While the bulk of the housing will indeed start at $250,000, some one-bedroom units are expected to be available for about $200,000, although prices have not been set.

To the Editor: The number of day laborers across our country is growing. In fact, the most prominent day labor study shows that there are three times as many gathering places for laborers near busy streets, parks and other businesses than at home improvement stores.

WHEN China announced its plans to pave a highway to the Mount Everest base camp in Tibet as part of its 2008 Olympic preparations, adventurers around the world winced at the latest encroachment into the Himalayan wilderness. Mountaineers who have already been to Everest, however, were more likely to greet the announcement of the ''blacktop highway fenced with undulating guardrails'' with little more than a shrug.
To the Editor: Re ''New Focus on a Forlorn Cleveland Tower'' (news article, June 19):
TROYETSKY--Herby. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland,President

The Saga Group, a British provider of insurance and vacations to the consumers 50 and older, agreed to merge with the Automobile Association in a transaction that values the two closely held companies at £6.2 billion ($12.4 billion). The deal would enable Saga to offer policies and cruises to the Automobile Association's older customers and the association to sell roadside assistance to Saga's 2.5 million clients, the companies said. About 15 million British motorists rely on the association when their cars break down. Saga's chief executive, Andrew Goodsell, will head the company, and the automobile association's chief executive, Tim Parker, will quit.

In the first television commercials of his presidential campaign, Senator Barack Obama will begin introducing himself to Iowa voters on Tuesday through a pair of biographical advertisements designed to tell the story of his career before he arrived in the United States Senate. Mr. Obama is not expected to open a full-fledged advertising push until the fall, aides said, but the campaign will slowly start highlighting his life before he gained national prominence delivering the keynote speech at the Democratic convention in 2004.

The Long Beach Journal on Thursday, about the Friday Workshop, a book club in the Long Island beach community that has been in continuous existence for about 50 years, misstated part of the title of a Shakespeare play that the group recently read. It is ''The Winter's Tale,'' not ''A Winter's Tale.''

A suicide bomber on Monday assassinated four Sunni sheiks who were cooperating with Americans to fight Al Qaeda in Anbar Province. Witnesses said the bomber sneaked through security checkpoints, strode into a large Baghdad hotel and detonated an explosive belt just before lunchtime, killing 12 people including the sheiks. The bombing struck at the heart of one of the rare bright spots for the American military. Just last year some senior military officers had all but given up on Anbar, the sprawling western province. But a group of Sunni sheiks banded together to fight Al Qaeda and supply young men to the police, bringing a significant turnabout. Anbar has allowed the American military to claim some success in its long-held ambition of splitting Sunnis away from the sway of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

TRAUBE--Beverly Anderson, a veteran Broadway talent agent whose clients were a who's who of the stage, died last Saturday evening at her home in Queens. She was 77. Her 50-year career made her one of New York's longest running independent agents. She helped launch the careers of Alan Alda, Bernadette Peters, Elliot Gould, Morgan Fairchild, Donna Mills, Gil Gerard and Pia Zadora. Her late husband, Leonard Traube, passed away in 2003. She is survived by two sons, publicist Frederic Traube, president and owner of Pro Sports Music Marketing, a Virginia-based music and sports marketing agency, his wife Lana; and Michael Traube, a New York based artist. A viewing and memorial service will be held June 27 in New York City at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. A memorial will also be held in Los Angeles on July 23.

When Mitt Romney was governor of Massachusetts (his term ended in January), his staff referred to him as LXX. That is Roman for 70, as Mr. Romney was the state's 70th governor. His operations office was branded with LXX on the door. Some aides wore LXX lapel pins and, in the manner of Secret Service agents, used the numerals as code as they whispered ''70'' into their sleeves while rushing along at his side -- just like a presidential campaign. Now that Mr. Romney is actually running for a presidential nomination, LXX no longer applies. But will XLIV lapel pins start to appear? All in good fun, of course, as long as Mr. Romney doesn't start wearing a laurel wreath and toga.

Financial shares tumbled yesterday on concern that losses tied to subprime mortgages would deepen, extending the stock market's worst weekly decline since March. Bear Stearns, the second-biggest United States underwriter of mortgage bonds, slid to its lowest level in nine months after a Merrill Lynch analyst said it might have to salvage another hedge fund.

I was sitting here at sweltering Camden Yards on Wednesday night, trying to come up with fresh verbs to describe what we're watching every night. Slumping, sliding, stumbling, sputtering. They all apply, and many more. The remaining 87 games could test anyone's vocabulary.
My Thursday column is about climate change and its impact on Africa. Please post your comments below.
Editor's note: An earlier version of this column misquoted a phrase from an episode of "Monty Python's Flying Circus"; it has since been corrected.

I will always remember that day in 2004 when I sat on the business side of a Lieutenant Colonel's desk as he "invited" me to go to Iraq with his battalion. Now, as a company commander in the Utah National Guard, one of my duties has been to send others to fight the war in Iraq.

At least a couple of N.B.A. teams hope their pick tonight carries the franchise to a championship. Play general manager: How would you build a winning team, by focusing on the draft or on trades and free agency?
The selling of Coney Island's Astroland Park to developers leaves one last park in the amusement district: Deno's Wonder Wheel Park.

"Bjorn," an imposing figure in a two-horned Viking helmet and a thick, black beard - the stick-on kind - wonders how the candidates plan to deal with illegal immigration. Someone else has "a very, very serious question" - about aliens: Will the candidates agree to Congressional hearings on the existence of extraterrestrials?

During MSNBC's "Hardball" exchange between Elizabeth Edwards and Ann Coulter yesterday (see earlier post today), Ms. Coulter echoed an audience question: "Yeah, why isn't John Edwards making this call?"

The other day in an interview in The New York Times Magazine, Al Gore's daughter Kristin revealed that when she was a child, she couldn't stand to think about wrists. All those veins and tendons. Probably didn't like to gnaw chicken bones either. Too squeamish.

You probably noticed the blog's new banner. It's designed by the always funny and far-ranging Gordon Hull. Aside from presiding over his own burger club, Gordie is a founder of Surface to Air, a New York-based company with branches in Paris and Tokyo that provides creative direction for folks like Marc Jacobs, Adidas and Nike. Surface to Air is a little hard to quantify - it also produces books and has its own clothing line and a store in Paris, on rue Charlot. Gordie's banner looks, I think, suitably couture.

Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. warned that raising taxes on hedge funds and buyout firms may have "unintended consequences" and said Congress shouldn't target firms that go public, such as the Blackstone Group, Bloomberg News reported.
How Peter Homer, an amateur inventor from Maine, bested NASA technology and built a better space glove.

For more than 30 years, the Family Jewels have clouded the C.I.A.'s reputation, even though most of their contents have long been known from official reports and ad hoc disclosures. William Colby - who oversaw the compilation of the Jewels while serving as the agency's operations chief and director-designate - is the source of some durable misconceptions about them. In his memoir, Honorable Men (p. 340), Colby says that the Jewels consist of "693 pages of possible violations of, or at least questionable activities in regard to, the C.I.A.'s legislative charter"; that among the contents are "bizarre and tragic cases wherein the Agency experimented with mind-control drugs"; and that accompanying them was "a separate and even more secret annex" that "summarized a 1967 survey of C.I.A.'s involvement in assassination attempts or plans against Castro, Lumumba and Trujillo."

Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival celebrates its 75th anniversary. Video by The Video Production Team at Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival: Nel Shelby, Ashley Meeder, and Kyle Frederick. Edited by Erica Berenstein.

Finding a silver lining in the cloud created by "Bong Hits 4 Jesus": Writing on The Agitator, his personal blog, Reason senior editor Radley Balko makes the case that Morse v. Frederick "was actually a victory for drug reform advocates, not a setback."

The Times of London today has a long and amusing article about how Bill Bryson, the bestselling travel writer, has become the agitating new president of an anti-litter organization called the Campaign to Protect Rural England (CPRE). Bryson may have been born in Des Moines, but he's out to save England from its sloppy tendencies. The article's author, Stefanie March, has a nice dry style:

The chief executive of Bear Stearns's asset management division, Richard Marin, is taking a stronger role in managing its two troubled hedge funds and appointed the head of the investment bank's mortgage unit head to save one of the funds, two sources familiar with the decision told Reuters.
Public school parents in Brooklyn have started a movement to dump styrofoam tableware in 1,400 city schools.

A coterie of national security and defense experts from the last Clinton administration have formed a new Washington think tank, the Center for a New American Security, that looks an awful lot like a shadow policy apparatus for Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign.

A recent New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll asked young voters about their political views and their opinion, so far, of the candidates and key issues in the 2008 election. The nationwide telephone poll was conducted June 15-23 with 659 young adults ages 17-29. Here are follow-up interviews with some of the respondents.

The "Family Jewel'' documents show in fine detail how the C.I.A., at the direction of high level officials in the Kennedy and Nixon administration, spied on journalists. Top government leaders were infuriated by leaks of classified information to reporters - a view shared by subsequent presidents, including George W. Bush - and instructed the C.I.A. to employ its full arsenal of spy techniques to hunt down the leakers. In some cases, reporters' phones were wiretapped, journalists were tailed and observation posts were set up near their offices to track their comings and goings and their visitors. All this was done despite a legal ban on C.I.A. domestic spying.

Fidelity National Information Services said Wednesday that it would acquire EFD/eFunds, a processor of electronic fund transfers and prepaid card transactions, for $1.8 billion, linking two of the nation's major financial processors.
Paul and I thought the main floor was working well - except for the kitchen.

On the market for the person who has everything is this palace -- Quinta da Princesa -- in Sintra, near Lisbon, Portugal. Houses of this quality rarely come on the market in this area, making this palace a rare gem. Sintra is on a mountainside, overlooking the Atlantic, and is considered one of Lisbon's most desirable suburbs.
He led Britain for 10 long years, and on his retirement day ... he got a new job.

For the last year it has become increasingly clear that the Darfur virus has been infecting and destabilizing Central African Republic to the southwest. Last year's win-a-trip went there, and since then the situation has gotten worse. In addition, a 27-year-old French woman was just killed there, while working for Doctors Without Borders, and so humanitarian groups are going to have to pull back. Now Amnesty International has a new report on the situation:
In the category of small worlds....
And The Lede swings from global warming to one unlikely city breaking out the sleds and parkas.
Matt Marshall of the blog Venture Beat is all but certain that LinkedIn, the business-contact networking site, is preparing to go public.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 27 column, "The Whole World Is Watching."
A 20-year-old student discusses his responses to a CBS/New York Times/MTV poll.

A federal judge on Wednesday ordered Adelphia's founder and his son to report to prison on Aug. 13, nearly three years after they were convicted in one of the largest corporate frauds in the nation's history.

John Stumpf, the new chief of Wells Fargo, said Wednesday that it is "highly unlikely" that the bank will make any big acquisitions outside its existing geographical markets. He did not rule it out, though, telling Reuters that, while "we don't want to be big for big's sake," Wells Fargo would nevertheless "look at a larger transaction out of market."
In her latest web column, Janet Elder, The Times's editor of news surveys and election analysis, writes:

The "bump" on the planned new J.P. Morgan Chase tower near the World Trade Center site is not -- as US Magazine might put it if the subject were a pregnant movie star -- a fashionable one, according to some critics. The architect has said he might change the design, but only slightly.
Most parents would be elated if their child's debut novel got a mention in The New Yorker. But Pete Peterson, senior chairman of the Blackstone Group, seems less than thrilled about it.

Following a grisly murder scene created by a former champion, World Wrestling Entertainment is trying mightily to cut ties with a deed that echoes a sport that stages brawls between feuding, well-built men.
The 4th of July is one week away. Time to start thinking about blowing things up.

In "Moulin Rouge," John Huston's 1952 biopic of the French painter and absinthe-bucket Henri Toulouse-Lautrec, Jose Ferrer played the lead - entirely on his knees. The action begins in a Parisian bar, Toulouse-Lautrec sits supping his deathly-green mouthwash - the barman polishes the glasses. Then the painter clambers down off his stool. Suddenly we're in his point of view, looking up at the great zinc-topped escarpment of the counter; the barman leans over, peers down at us, and speaks the first line of the movie: '"So long, Toulouse!"
The Times's Tim Weiner discusses the importance of the newly declassified C.I.A. documents known as the "family jewels."

Shares in Blackstone, the private equity company that went public last week in what looked like a successful initial public offering, declined again this morning. But this is one company that knows how to time an investment.
"Paper View" was a film I'd wanted to make for a long time, and July 4th provided me with the perfect excuse.

One of the most common comments we get goes: "What can I do to help? You guys talk so much about the problems, and now I want to do something." I don't like to bring up problems without proposing solutions. In this second-to-last entry, I propose concrete action steps to channel passion and idealism into activism and action.

As iPhone Week continues here on Pogue's Posts, here's a bunch of cool info about the virtual keyboard that nobody--I mean, not Apple, not the bloggers, not the reviewers--has said anything about. [Update: DOH!! Apple JUST posted a video about the keyboard. Hmph. Well, it's still not as detailed as what follows.]
Lisa Lam and Joyce Lau from the IHT's Hong Kong office weigh in on dining with a view:
If you haven't read Mark Landler's article on the Trabant, I recommend checking it out.

Patrick Knight, sentenced to death for a double murder in Texas, promised to tell a joke as part of his last words at his execution. After soliciting jokes in a Web campaign dubbed "Dead Man Laughing" and also on CNN, he received over 1,300 submissions. But when the time came last night, his plan crashed and burned, yielding no laughs from what was perhaps the toughest crowd ever.
Angry drivers set fire to at least two gas stations overnight in Tehran after the government announced that gasoline rationing would begin.

Two gas stations were torched early Wednesday in Tehran as angry Iranians protested fuel rationing measures suddenly enforced by the government, while many other Iranians lined up to fill their tanks.
Her name is everywhere.

Releasing the family jewels is a big step forward for the C.I.A. But don't revel in the glasnost just yet. There are still troves upon troves of documents that the C.I.A., F.B.I., and other intelligence agencies are keeping locked away. Dirty tricks from the 1960's and '70s make for interesting reading. But understanding what went wrong before 9/11 makes for better intelligence.

A Russian defector held in a secret CIA prison in the U.S. to determine whether he was a legitimate defector or a Russian intelligence plant. Nothing new. The tale has been told in numerous books and articles over the years.

Summer is back, and so is poison ivy, stronger than ever. The weed is flourishing this year, growing faster and more toxic, and a pair of studies flagged by The Wall Street Journal say an upswing in greenhouse gases is to blame.

On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

In Rupert Murdoch's attempt to buy Dow Jones, the question of price has been on the back burner of late, overshadowed by negotiations over a framework for protecting the editorial independence of the company's flagship publication, The Wall Street Journal.
Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards, keeps making headlines.

Check out the picture of Rome on the front page of Tuesday's IHT It tells two stories: 1. As the article notes, there is too much drinking on the streets of Rome's historic center. 2. (And this is more important from our blog's point of view) There are way too few garbage cans in Rome's center city and no recycling bins whatsoever. So...in this blistering hot town, people who drink bottled water, soda, beer, booze, whatever, are more or less forced to put bottles and cans into general garbage, or (often) just leave them somewhere street side. There is no way to recycle.
David Pogue looks at the features of the new iPhone, as furtively as possible.
Search engines have shortcuts to all kinds of information, like stock quotes and gasoline prices, even song lyrics.
How do I use S.M.T.P. and P.O.P. in setting up e-mail programs?

Despite reports that the board of directors at Dow Jones and the News Corporation had reached an agreement in principle yesterday on protecting the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal, a firm accord between the two parties that would help pave the way for a takeover is not yet a reality, The New York Times noted.

CommScope, a maker of communications equipment, said Wednesday it would buy the Andrew Corporation for $15 per share, or about $2.6 billion. Last year, CommScope offered to buy Andrew, which sells cables and antennas, but quickly withdrew its bid.
Is Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign about to beat its own fundraising expectations? Or, perhaps, has it been low-balling them?

Investors looking for signs that the buyout boom of the past two years may be hitting a wall have two new ones to ponder. US Foodservice, the American unit of the Dutch supermarket Royal Ahold, has postponed its sale of $650 million in bonds that were expected to finance the unit's equity buyout. Before the decision, US Foodservice had twice scaled back its debt offering to help finance its $7.1 billion buyout by the equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice.

Bain Capital agreed to buy the Guitar Center, a retailer of musical instruments, for about $1.9 billion in cash. In a separate deal, Bain said it would acquire Germany's biggest yacht maker, Bavaria Yachtbau, for about 1.3 billion euros ($1.75 billion).

Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the fugitive founder and former chief executive of Comverse Technology who faces 35 criminal counts in the United Sates stemming from backdated options, said Tuesday that he relied on lawyers and accountants when dealing with the securities.

Alexander Khalifman, 41, has won a tournament in Bazna, Romania, that ran from June 15 to 26. What made the tournament unusual was that the field was made up almost entirely of great players from the 1970s and 1980s. What Khalifman, who won the World Chess Federation championship in 1999, was doing in the field is anybody's guess, but he took advantage of his invitation. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the tournament by scrolling down to where it says "Vizualizare."

The Carlyle Group is apparently evaluating an option to go public, despite speculation that the private equity industry's boom may be close to hitting a wall and the news that the Blackstone Group's stock closed below its offering price Tuesday.

EuropaCorp, the film production company founded by the French director Luc Besson, set a price range on Tuesday for a stock market listing, which it said would raise more than 70 million euros ($94.2 million).

As solar start-ups continue to attract the eye of venture capital investors, a solar cell developer Stion said it had raised $15 million in a second round of venture capital led by Lightspeed Venture Partners to advance ongoing work in thin-film materials science.

A London buyout shop, Candover has made an offer valuing Stork, a Dutch conglomerate, at 1.5 billion euros ($2 billion). The companies said Tuesday that Candover will offer 47 euros per share, an 11 percent premium to Stork's closing price June 18, the day before talks were announced a week ago.

Former Vice President Dan Quayle and the ex-Notre Dame football coach Lou Holtz are joining with the chief executive of the sporting goods maker K2 in a bid to raise as much as $500 million in the second-largest initial public offering of a "blank check" shell company on record.

Big Lots, the nation's largest seller of overstocked and discontinued items and whose fare includes organic plant food made from chicken droppings, is losing its novelty for its hedge fund investors, Bloomberg News reported.
The Blackstone Group has become the latest to pull out of a consortium bidding for the Coles Group, the Australian retailer, Reuters reported, improving the prospects of a rival suitor, Wesfarmers.

Citigroup is in advanced talks to buy Automated Trading Desk, an electronic trading firm, for about $700 million, The Wall Street Journal reported. The report noted that the deal marks the latest push by the banking giant into the trading of stocks by computerized programs rather than by people.

Nordstrom appears to have reached a deal to sell its Façonnable chain to a Lebanese private equity firm for about $200 million, The New York Post reported. The report said that Façonnable employees received word of the impending sale on Tuesday, along with the potential for some job cuts.

Silicon Valley's economy, notorious for its booms and busts as it rode each new wave of technology, is on the upswing again. Led by a variety of industries, including clean energy, biotechnology and new media, the regional economy, this time more sober than speculative, is adding jobs. And Thomson Financial says venture capital investments in Silicon Valley rose to $10.5 billion last year, the highest level since 2001.
Stilt walkers entertained crowds, a brass band played, Miss Cyclone made an appearance and a few octogenarians took a ride, all in honor of the Cyclone at Coney Island.

After nearly 15 weeks in court, lawyers in the trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black neared the end of their arguments Tuesday, with the jury expected to begin poring over 100 pages of instructions starting Wednesday.
My lasting image of Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi will be the children and the jarring contrast between their poverty and their beauty.
Nicole Snyder doesn't have a driver’s license, but she is in control when it comes to piloting a 7,000-horsepower jet tractor.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has a string of potentially overzealous hedge funds in its sights.
J. Robert Hillier is turning his attention from the design company he started 40 years ago to a venture that runs obituaries of people, pets and even inanimate objects.

Three former executives of Countrywide Financial, a mortgage lender, have agreed to plead guilty to insider trading in the week prior to the release of a disappointing earnings report, federal prosecutors have said.

The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Merrill Lynch on Tuesday over its treatment of an Iranian Muslim, who the commission says was an analyst in the bank's global markets and investment banking model development group.

Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotècnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotècnia, which also makes solar panels, it said.

Manulife Financial, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Group's mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business.

Coca-Cola will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed.

Saudi Telecom, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the country's largest mobile phone operator.

For decades, wooden sawhorse barriers have been a mainstay at parades and demonstrations in New York City, from the arrival of the Beatles in 1964 to the New Year’s Eve celebrations in Times Square each year.
“Hot House,” Shimon Dotan’s absorbing look at Palestinians held in Israeli jails, is full of remarkable interviews.
Images from the architects' new condo project on Perry Street.
New ideas join the old in the heart of the gracious South.
Despite Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s recent party-hopping and possible independent White House bid, history suggests most voters stick with one party.
The Frugal Traveler visits a cave in South Dakota, then heads to Nebraska to see Carhenge, a replica of Stonehenge made with cars.
Public school parents in Brooklyn have started a movement to dump styrofoam tableware in 1,400 city schools.
“Over the G W” follows a troubled brother and sister as they are committed to a New Jersey treatment center by their well-meaning parents.
In “Live Free or Die Hard,” Bruce Willis is ready to earn our love again by performing the same lovably violent, meathead tricks as before.
Asger Leth’s “Ghosts of Cité Soleil” offers a tour of a notorious, hellish slum in Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti.
New Zealand sauvignon blanc used to be a go-to bottle for its piercing, vivacious refreshment. You can still find wines like that, but you have to choose carefully among producers.
Apple’s new phone does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.
The new Landmarc in the Time Warner Center is three times the size of its original place in TriBeCa, whose menu and competent cooking it replicates but whose warmth it largely lacks.
Bob Schieffer of CBS News, however improbably, has begun moonlighting late-in-life as a country singer.
The Senate Judiciary Committee sent subpoenas to the White House, vice president’s office and the Justice Department.
She defied the male-dominated ranks of the fashion industry and started her own hugely successful company.
Several lawmakers signaled today that they were undecided about supporting the Senate immigration bill.
Meilen Tu, one of the oldest players in the Wimbledon draw, beat Romanian Edina Gallovits.
Protesters set fire to at least two gas stations in Tehran last night after the announcement of the fuel rationing.
By next year, 3.3 billion people will live in towns and cities, according to a U.N. report released today.
Gordon Brown spent years in waiting as Tony Blair’s sometimes loyal, sometimes impatient lieutenant.
Details of the ceremony in which the Queen greets the new prime minister were kept secret - but they were not quite like the movie starring Helen Mirren.
The flooding today forced some residents to climb to the tops of their vehicles, houses and trees to await rescue.
China has launched an overhaul of its food safety regulations in the aftermath of a series of food scares.

A picture with an article on Sunday about the circumstances behind the mass arrests of Brooklyn youths who were on their way to Coney Island for the wake of a slain teenager on May 21 carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The photograph of Asher Callender, 19, one of the arrested teenagers, speaking at a community meeting two weeks after the arrests was by Ramin Talaie for The New York Times — not by Chester Higgins Jr. of The Times.
Rebekkah Brunson had 15 points and 8 rebounds, and the Sacramento Monarchs never trailed in a victory over the Liberty on Tuesday night.

Bolivia rallied to tie host Venezuela, 2-2, in the Copa América last night at San Cristobal, Venezuela, scoring the equalizer when Juan Carlos Arce tipped in the ball in the 83rd minute.Earlier, in a game at Merida, Peru upset the 14-time champion Uruguay, 3-0, on goals by Miguel Villalta, Juan Carlos Marino and Paolo Guerrero.The tournament, South America’s championship, is being played in Venezuela for the first time in its 91-year history. The United States, an invited guest, opens tomorrow against Argentina.
The board voted 5 to 4 to allow increases of 5.75 percent on two-year leases and 3 percent on one-year leases.
In the latest miserable moment in an increasingly discouraging season, Scott Schoeneweis gave up a home run in extra innings that tarnished the Mets’ exciting ninth-inning comeback.
Street artists have speculated for months about the identity of a mysterious figure who has become known as “the Splasher.”

LeBron James said last night that he would play in next month’s FIBA America’s Tournament, in which the United States will try to qualify for the 2008 Olympics.“I’ve had enough time off, and knowing my body more than anybody, I’m ready to play,” James said. “I don’t know how much I’m going to play or how extensively, but I’ll be ready.”For several months, James had said he was “50-50” about playing. With Cleveland making it to the N.B.A. finals, James may have wanted time off after playing more than 100 games since October.
The Orioles beat the punchless Yankees when Scott Proctor walked Ramón Hernández with the bases loaded and one out in the bottom of the ninth inning.
The driver of a bus that crashed on a southern Kentucky Interstate died, bringing the toll to two in the crash that injured more than 60 family members.

A man who lost his ball in a golf course pond nearly lost a limb when a nearly 11-foot-long alligator latched on to his arm and pulled him into the water on Monday, the authorities said. The golfer, Bruce Burger, 50, was trying to retrieve his ball from a pond on the sixth hole at the Lake Venice Golf Club in Venice. The alligator latched on to his right forearm and pulled him into the pond, said Gary Morse, a spokesman for the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. Mr. Burger used his left arm to beat the reptile until it freed him. Mr. Burger was not seriously injured. It took seven Fish and Wildlife officers an hour to trap the alligator, which measured 10 feet 11 inches in length, Mr. Morse said.
The Legislature approved a ban on a late-term abortion procedure, the first state to do so since the Supreme Court upheld a federal ban this year.
The murder trial of a man accused of killing his wife was suspended after the defendant slashed his wrists, authorities said.
A nude driver hit a trooper during a traffic stop and tried to run over two more before officers shot out a tire to end the chase.
Responding to Vice President Dick Cheney’s assertion that his office is exempt from certain security requirements, House Democrats said they would try to eliminate his office’s financing.
New York State wants to expand its network of artificial reefs in the Atlantic Ocean and add another that would be the largest and deepest off Long Island.
The quality of the typical New York City park is determined largely by whether it is in a wealthy or poor neighborhood, according to a study to be released today.
More than a year after leaving the Turin Olympics in tears, after a groin injury derailed her quest for a gold medal, Michelle Kwan has not ruled out a comeback to competitive figure skating.

The Manulife Financial Corporation, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Group’s mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business. The deal is part of a plan by Manulife of Toronto to expand its mutual funds unit. The takeover creates a sales force of 1,500 independent advisers and a business with about 19 billion Canadian dollars ($17.7 billion) in assets under administration. The price was not disclosed.

The Coca-Cola Company will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed. The Takanashi family, which founded the bottler 50 years ago, will retain control of about 65 percent of the company, Charlie Sutlive, a Coca-Cola spokesman, said.

The Altria Group, the cigarette maker, will close a North Carolina factory and increase European production to save $335 million a year by 2011. The shutdown of the plant in Cabarrus County will result in a one-time charge of $325 million in the second quarter, Altria said. The company, which is based in New York, may be preparing to spin off its international unit, analysts and investors said. Factories in Europe will take over production of Marlboros and other cigarettes bound for Japan and the Middle East, which are currently being made in North Carolina. All of Altria’s United States output will be shifted to Richmond, Va. Closing the North Carolina facility, which employs 2,500, will cost about 10 cents a share in the second quarter, Altria said. Expenses will total $670 million by 2011.

Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotècnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotècnia, which also makes solar panels, it said. The purchase will help Alstom, which is based in Paris, expand in the United States and Asia, it said. Buying Ecotècnia strengthens Alstom’s presence in renewable energy as governments seek alternatives to coal, gas and oil. Alstom also sells hydroelectric equipment and worked with Russia’s state nuclear agency in April to develop atomic plants.

The Saudi Telecom Company, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the country’s largest mobile phone operator. Maxis has 14 million subscribers in Malaysia and India. Under the agreement, Saudi Telecom will also acquire 51 percent stake in PT Natrindo Telepon Selular, the Maxis subsidiary in Indonesia, the company said.
Corrections: For the Record

An article in Weekend on Friday about the refurbished Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden at the New York Botanical Garden referred incorrectly to David Rockefeller’s donation in the 1980s for the renovation of an earlier rose garden at the same site. It was in honor of his wife, Peggy, not in memory of her. (She died in 1996.) The article also misstated the name of one kind of rose on display and erroneously listed part of the name as a variety. It is the Rita Levi Montalcini (named after the Nobel Prize winner Rita Levi-Montalcini), not the Rita Levi, and there is no rose called simply the Montalcini.

An article on Monday about opposition to a planned Wal-Mart in the predominantly Hasidic community of Monsey, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the village of Airmont, where another Wal-Mart is located. Airmont is two miles west — not east — of the proposed site in Monsey.

An article on June 13 about a more hospitable approach to day laborers taken by the village of Mamaroneck, N.Y., referred imprecisely to the number of hiring sites in the country. According to the National Day Labor Organizing Network, there are approximately 65 formal sites, like the one at the Strait Gate Church in Mamaroneck. But there are hundreds more informal gathering places for day laborers, including street corners and parking lots. (The first nationwide study of day laborers, released in 2006, counted more than 500 sites.).

An article on Saturday about reaction at a reunion of Antioch College alumni to a decision to close the college misstated the number of students who enrolled in 2006. It was 130 — not 63, which was the number of new students in 2005.

An article yesterday about North Korea’s pledge to shut down its main nuclear plant misstated the plant’s location relative to Pyongyang, the capital. The plant, in Yongbyon, is about 60 miles north of Pyongyang, not south.
A theater review on Monday about “Romeo and Juliet,” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misstated Juliet’s age in the play. She is 13, not 14.

George Zahringer III of Deepdale Golf Club won the 52nd Metropolitan Golf Association Ike Championship yesterday at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale by four strokes over Andreas Huber of Garden City Golf Club. Zahringer, 54, won his fifth Ike title and became the oldest champion in tournament history. He shot 75-71 yesterday for a 219 total.

A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about the handover of nine looted Kenyan wooden statues to the Kenyan government misidentified the official shown at a ceremony at the United Nations. He is Peter Ogego, the Kenyan ambassador to the United States — not Zachary Dominic Muburi-Muita, Kenya’s representative to the United Nations, who also attended.

A chart with the Off the Charts column in Business Day on Saturday, about the inventory of homes for sale, referred incorrectly to the number of unsold houses. They were in the thousands, not hundreds. A corrected graphic is online at nytimes.com/business.

A headline on an article in Business Day on Saturday about the efforts of some companies to provide health insurance for retirees too young for Medicare overstated the number of retirees the program might help. Although about 800,000 early retirees are said to be without health insurance, the program’s organizers say the plan would probably help only a fraction of them, not all.

An article on Friday about a law passed by the New Jersey Legislature that sets ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases misstated a provision of the bill. It requires that emissions be capped at 20 percent — not 80 percent — of 2006’s levels by 2050.

An article on Friday about the Hayward clan of the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, which led the tribe into the casino era but now feels rejected by its current leaders, misstated a comment by John L. Holder, executive assistant to the tribal chairman, about Richard A. Hayward, the tribe’s former leader. He said Mr. Hayward had become rude and undiplomatic as chairman — not undemocratic.

The principle that defendants should be judged by a jury of their peers is a cherished part of the American justice system. But a government watchdog group questions whether that guarantee is being kept in Manhattan.
Kelly Shoppach hit a pinch-hit three-run homer last night to complete a five-run ninth-inning rally that gave the host Cleveland Indians an 8-5 victory against the Oakland Athletics.
Annika Sorenstam’s gradual slide from the top of women’s golf began at the major championship that brought her so much satisfaction.
basketball.

The Atlanta Thrashers sent the rights to the free-agent center Keith Tkachuk back to St. Louis yesterday and reacquired the conditional first-round pick in the N.H.L. draft that they traded to the Blues in February. To acquire Tkachuk in a trade Feb. 25, the Thrashers gave up forward Glen Metropolit, two picks in last week’s draft, and a second-round pick next year.

Scat Daddy, the winner of the Florida Derby, was retired from racing because of an injured tendon in his right foreleg. In his last start, Scat Daddy, trained by Todd Pletcher, finished 18th in the Kentucky Derby on May 5. The tendon injury was discovered after a workout June 10. Scat Daddy won five of nine races.
Bulgaria and Romania will receive stern rebukes from the European Commission for failing to root out corruption and organized crime.
French police were investigating the death of a 14-year-old Spanish girl on the fast Rock ’n’ Roller Coaster ride at the Disneyland just outside Paris.
A Russian citizen has accused Britain’s MI6 foreign intelligence service of trying to recruit him while he was abroad.
Jacques Chirac’s lawyer said the former French president will “very probably” be questioned in the coming months about possible corruption during his term as mayor of Paris.
Russian and NATO leaders meeting in Moscow mitigated confrontational statements but failed to resolve disagreements on a range of issues.
Iran, the world’s second-largest oil exporter, will begin gasoline rationing for private vehicles today to rein in consumption and cut expensive gas imports.
Native groups are threatening to cause major travel disruptions at the start of the forthcoming Canada Day holiday weekend to protest poverty and land claims.
Spanish police arrested three Moroccan men in Barcelona on suspicion that they had links to the North African terrorist group Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.
A developer wants to transform the former Domino Sugar refinery into part of an apartment complex.
A lawsuit by the owner of Pearl Oyster Bar in Manhattan may be the most aggressive use of intellectual property concepts by the owner of a small restaurant.
Young Americans are more likely to favor an open-door policy on immigration, the legalization of gay marriage and government-run health care, a poll found.

Some of New York’s representatives in Congress are seeking to lengthen by at least a decade a post-Sept. 11 insurance program that supporters say is critical to projects like the new World Trade Center. The program, the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act, provides federal insurance backup for catastrophic losses suffered in a terrorist attack. The insurance industry says the program is needed because such attacks are so expensive and hard to predict. The current version expires at the end of this year. Proponents, including Representative Peter T. King, a Long Island Republican, say extending the program is essential for rebuilding the World Trade Center site. Opponents of the extension have said the program is best left to the free market.

The Newark schools superintendent, Marion A. Bolden, promised yesterday to meet regularly with a task force of the city’s gay and lesbian leaders, according to the head of a New Jersey gay rights group. The promise comes after Ms. Bolden ordered a picture of a graduating senior kissing his boyfriend blacked out of the East Side High School yearbook. After an outcry, the school district said it would reissue the yearbooks with the picture unmarked. Steven Goldstein, of Garden State Equality, said Ms. Bolden made the commitment to meet during a phone call that he described as “heartfelt.” A spokeswoman for Ms. Bolden’s office could not confirm that commitment, but said Ms. Bolden met yesterday with Andre Jackson, the student whose picture was blacked out. The superintendent also apologized in front of Mr. Jackson’s classmates at a graduation rehearsal, the spokeswoman said. Mr. Jackson could not be reached for comment yesterday.

Five men were arrested on Monday night and charged with fireworks possession after the police seized a large cache of fireworks and $14,000 in cash, the police said yesterday. The men — Lawrence DiAmbrossi, 43, Christopher DiAmbrossi, 46, John Riccardi, 36, and Albert Slavin, 39, all of Brooklyn, and David Melore, 48, of Freehold, N.J. _ — _ were charged after the police executed a search warrant about 7 p.m. at 2624 East 27th Street in Sheepshead Bay, the police said.

The New York City Central Labor Council announced yesterday that Gary La Barbera was elected president at a delegates meeting on Monday night. Mr. La Barbera, 47, is president of a Teamsters local representing 4,000 construction industry drivers and heads the Teamsters’ district council for the New York metropolitan region, representing 100,000 Teamsters. He succeeds Brian M. McLaughlin, who headed the labor council for 11 years before he was indicted in October on charges of obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribery. The delegates approved a new constitution that gives Mr. La Barbera less power than Mr. McLaughlin had. The council’s board will have more powers; the president will serve as chairman of the board, sharing responsibilities with an executive director who runs operations day to day.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is giving a sixth set of ostensibly anonymous grants, this time worth more than $30 million, to 530 groups through a gift to the Carnegie Corporation. The donations announced yesterday, which range from $10,000 to $150,000, are to benefit a broad cross section of neighborhood-based cultural and social service groups and reflect the mayor’s interest in the arts, education, health and social welfare. Included for the first time are the After Hours Project in Brooklyn, which runs a needle exchange program to help reduce the spread of H.I.V.; the New York Asian Women’s Center, which helps battered women throughout the city; and One Stop Senior Services in Manhattan, which helps the elderly remain in their homes.

The F.B.I. has joined an investigation into the theft of harpoons and other tools used by whalers in the early 19th century from the Cape May County Museum. The six harpoons, a whaling gun and several maritime instruments were kept in a case and were first noticed missing on June 5. The museum estimates that the items are worth more than $7,500. The authorities are monitoring Internet auction sites for signs of the stolen items, Capt. Scott Webster of the Middle Township police told The Press of Atlantic City. Museum officials have said they believe that the culprit was a collector.

A popular Brooklyn pizzeria reopened on Saturday nearly three weeks after it was cited by the city health department for unsanitary conditions. Di Fara Pizza, at East 15th Street and Avenue J in Midwood, was closed after it failed an inspection on June 4, when inspectors found flies, a mouse infestation and bare-hand contact with food. That was the second time since March that the shop had been closed this year. After a visit last week, Di Fara’s reopened. “We passed the inspection,” Dominick DeMarco, the son of the owner, said last night. “It’s just all bureaucracy. You have to go through the paperwork.”.

One man has been killed and five others injured in a series of attacks in the area north of St. James Park in the Bronx, the police said yesterday. Investigators believe that the same group of 4 to 10 men was responsible for four separate attacks, all considered unusual because there was “no robbery or other obvious motive,” said Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly. In the first attack, the assailants surrounded and attacked two men about 2:30 a.m. on June 1 after the men had left a bar. One, John Mateo, 54, died on Sunday from his injuries. Four other men have been assaulted in the area, near Kingsbridge Road and Morris Avenue, the police said. Witnesses said the attackers were men in their early 20s.

IRAN'S judiciary says it expects to announce a decision this week or next in the case of my wife, Haleh Esfandiari, and two other Iranian-Americans, Kian Tajbakhsh and Ali Shakeri, who have been held in solitary confinement at Tehran's Evin prison since early May. The fate of these detainees could be resolved by Iran's government in a number of ways. Only one would be in the best interests of the Islamic Republic: the detainees should be freed and all charges dropped.

Corrections Appended Less than three weeks after Al Gore, the environmental campaigner and former vice president, visited Istanbul to announce its participation in the round-the-world Live Earth concerts on July 7, organizers announced yesterday that the city had been dropped from the roster of nine sites because of a lack of interest coupled with security concerns in advance of general elections on July 22, Reuters reported. ... In South Africa, organizers seeking to stimulate lagging ticket sales moved the Live Earth concert to the 18,000-seat Coca-Cola Dome in Johannesburg from a site 45 minutes by car from the city, Reuters reported.

CUTLER--Barbara Levine, 86, died peacefully on June 23rd in Sarasota, Florida. She was married to the late Michael M. Cutler. Adored mother of Michael D., Thomas, Jonathan and grandmother of Eli, David, Nathan Cutler, and sister, Ellen Levine Levy, brother-in-law Philip and daughter-in-law, Andrea Meyers. Barbara was actively involved and tirelessly devoted to various political and social activities ranging from the local board of Planned Parenthood Federation of America to teaching English to foreign youth and as a guardian ad-litem on behalf of children from troubled homes. She was a strong presence whose life had great impact on countless people and she will be missed by all. A memorial service will be conducted at Kobernik House in Sarasota on August 5, 2007.

''In Between Days,'' the sensitive, modest, thrillingly self-assured first feature by So Yong Kim, was one of the standouts of the 2006 Sundance Film Festival -- exactly the kind of thoughtful, independent work one hopes to find there and too rarely does. Its theatrical release today is an encouraging sign that there is still room, even in the midst of the summer glut, for a small, serious, unpretentious film. The subject -- a lonely young girl coming of age in a winter-bound North American city -- may seem conventional, but Ms. Kim nimbly avoids both narrative and stylistic clichés. There is nothing melodramatic about ''In Between Days,'' apart from the quiet strain of intensified feeling that the main character, a Korean immigrant named Aimie (Jiseon Kim), brings to her own experience. You get the sense that if she did not allow herself small episodes of strong, disproportionate emotion, Aimie would vanish into adolescent ennui.

The Saudi Telecom Company, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the country's largest mobile phone operator. Maxis has 14 million subscribers in Malaysia and India. Under the agreement, Saudi Telecom will also acquire 51 percent stake in PT Natrindo Telepon Selular, the Maxis subsidiary in Indonesia, the company said.

Former President Jacques Chirac will ''very probably'' be questioned in the coming months about a corruption scandal involving political no-show jobs when he was mayor of Paris, his lawyer, Jean Veil, told Europe-1 radio. Two years ago, his ally and former prime minister, Alain Juppé, was convicted in the case, which investigators say helped finance Mr. Chirac's party as it drained millions of dollars from the city's coffers. Mr. Chirac has refused to testify in two other cases that involve events during his years as president: a political dirty tricks campaign and the mysterious death of a French judge in Djibouti in 1995.

The American Film Institute, the country's leading organization for film history and preservation, yesterday named Bob Gazzale, a film historian and television producer, to be its president and chief executive. He will succeed Jean Picker Firstenberg, who is retiring in the fall after 27 years of heading the institute, which is based in Los Angeles. Mr. Gazzale, 42, becomes just the third person to lead the organization since its creation in 1967. The institute's board, including its chairman, Howard Stringer, chairman of the Sony Corporation, unanimously voted him in yesterday. He has been with the institute since 1992, mainly serving as the director of A.F.I. Productions. In a statement, Mr. Stringer said, ''As we say in the movies, we searched for brain, heart and courage, and found it all in our own backyard.''

Filet mignon wrapped in air-cured beef pastirma (7 ounces, which is two medallions, for $15) is another option, as are marinated vegetables, also ready for a rich burnish ($5 for 8 ounces). BEFORE I go telling everybody that the secret to great iced coffee is already in the kitchen, my friend Keller wants me to confess: I didn't know from iced coffee until he showed me the light. It's important to cop to this now, because not a summer goes by that he does not painstakingly remind me, a rabid iced-coffee drinker, that he's the one who introduced me to the wonders of cold-brewed iced coffee. The funny thing is, when the subject came up we were holed up in a summer rental with three friends off the coast of Puerto Rico, on a tiny island not exactly swimming in upmarket coffee houses.
