A set of six place settings, with four cups to hold them, is $30 from Tablesettings, 276 Norwood Avenue, Deal, N.J., (732) 531-0800, or toll-free (866) 934-7437.

QUINSON--Suzanne RichardJaricot born June 24, 1907 in Vourles, France died at home in Larchmont, NY on June 26, 2007. She is survived by her four sons Francois, JeanPaul, Bruno and Luc, 10 grandchildren and 13 greatgrandchildren. Visitation Wednesday, 2-4pm and 79pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home. Funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont at 10am, Thursday, June 28, 2007. Interment at Tyringham Cemetery, MA. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering or Catholic Charities.

The Manulife Financial Corporation, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Group's mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business. The deal is part of a plan by Manulife of Toronto to expand its mutual funds unit. The takeover creates a sales force of 1,500 independent advisers and a business with about 19 billion Canadian dollars ($17.7 billion) in assets under administration. The price was not disclosed.

Senate Republicans yesterday blocked the labor movement's top legislative priority, a bill that would have made it easier for unions to organize workers. In a largely party-line vote, supporters of the bill failed to get the 60 votes needed to cut off debate and allow a vote on the bill. The vote was 51 to cut off debate and 48 against.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is giving a sixth set of ostensibly anonymous grants, this time worth more than $30 million, to 530 groups through a gift to the Carnegie Corporation. The donations announced yesterday, which range from $10,000 to $150,000, are to benefit a broad cross section of neighborhood-based cultural and social service groups and reflect the mayor's interest in the arts, education, health and social welfare. Included for the first time are the After Hours Project in Brooklyn, which runs a needle exchange program to help reduce the spread of H.I.V.; the New York Asian Women's Center, which helps battered women throughout the city; and One Stop Senior Services in Manhattan, which helps the elderly remain in their homes.

DUCEY--John Francis, Jr., 92, of Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida and Northeast Harbor, Maine died on June 22, 2007. He was born on November 2, 1914 to John Francis and Ethel Barroll Ducey in Detroit, MI. He graduated from St. George's School, Newport, RI in 1932 and from Harvard College in 1936. He had a distinguished career in the U.S. Naval Reserve during World War ll, serving on three destroyers, and as captain of the last. He retired from active service as Commander. He worked for American Brake Shoe Company between 1937-1973. He was predeceased by his first wife of 39 years, Katharine Munson, in 1977. He is survived by his wife of 28 years, Marion Schmidt of Buffalo, NY; three daughters, Katharine Hardy, Ethel Coggeshall and Georgina Field; nine grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. A funeral service is scheduled for June 30 at 2:00pm, St. Mary's Church, Northeast Harbor, Maine. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be sent to the St. Mary's Church Building Fund, PO Box 105, Northeast Harbor, Maine 04662
To the Editor:

APRAHAMIAN--Vahe. Vahe was born in 1934 and left his family behind at the age of 14. He attended the Melkonian School in Nicosia, Cypress. Roberts College in Istanbul. MS in Structural Engineering at the University of Iowa in 1962, licensed in 14 states and he spoke four languages fluently and a 40-year member of the American Concrete Institute and committee 213. He founded Engineering Enterprises, a Des Moines, Iowa based company for 25 years. He was a pioneer in designing towers for the Titan Missile Program, Grain Silos, for the ports of Algeria and Egypt and he will also be recognized as the engineer who designed structures for the world-renowned artist ''Christo'', ''The Islands'' in Miami 1983, ''Pont Neuf'' in Paris 1985, and ''Umbrellas'' in California and Japan 1991. Married for 43 years to Donna Rees, they have two children Adrienne and Greg, two spouses Jack and Yoon-hee, and four grandchildren Sophia, Max, Aram and Sara. He has three brothers and two sisters surviving. He was a Philosopher-Engineer. Each day was a masterpiece for 72 years.
SOME white wines are perfect flying solo, for a sip on a relaxed late summer afternoon. But not spirited, citrusy, herbaceous New Zealand sauvignon blancs.

HERSCHKORN--Morton 85, died June 27, 2006. Beloved husband of Frances; loving father of Joel, Lorraine, Stephen and Lee; proud grandfather of Peter and Kathia Herschkorn and great-grandfather of Dylan and Machaella. You are deeply missed.

An article on Friday about a law passed by the New Jersey Legislature that sets ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases misstated a provision of the bill. It requires that emissions be capped at 20 percent -- not 80 percent -- of 2006's levels by 2050.

A popular Brooklyn pizzeria reopened on Saturday nearly three weeks after it was cited by the city health department for unsanitary conditions. Di Fara Pizza, at East 15th Street and Avenue J in Midwood, was closed after it failed an inspection on June 4, when inspectors found flies, a mouse infestation and bare-hand contact with food. That was the second time since March that the shop had been closed this year. After a visit last week, Di Fara's reopened. ''We passed the inspection,'' Dominick DeMarco, the son of the owner, said last night. ''It's just all bureaucracy. You have to go through the paperwork.''

An article last Wednesday about French cheese makers who have stopped making Camembert with raw milk and have withdrawn from the government program that certifies that they use traditional methods misstated some of the standards for that certification, called an Appellation d'Origine Contrôlée. To have an A.O.C., a Camembert from Normandy must be made with unfiltered raw milk, and have a fat content of 38 percent. It is not the milk that has to have a fat content of 38 percent.
BECHER--Bernd. With deep sadness we note the passing of our dear friend. The beauty of the Becher's work is eternal. Our deepest sympathies to Hilla, Max and their family. DJ and Robert J. Dodds, III

An article on Monday about opposition to a planned Wal-Mart in the predominantly Hasidic community of Monsey, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the village of Airmont, where another Wal-Mart is located. Airmont is two miles west -- not east -- of the proposed site in Monsey.

WITTENBERG--Noel. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst record with sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President $(6$)WITTENBERG--Noel, Passed away on June 25th. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann of 59 years, who lost her best friend, devoted daughters Audrey and the late Jacquie, son-in-law Richard and grandchildren Sloane, Devon and Derek. He was the son of the late Jack and Rae Wittenberg, and brother of the late Ina Lakritz. Uncle Noel will be missed by his adoring nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews, and by countless friends who were lucky to have him as part of their lives. Born June 13th, 1921, in the Bronx. He served proudly in the Third Infantry Regimen, The Old Guard, in WWII, followed by an extraordinary career in the fashion industry. His passion for Judaism and Israel, and pride in Jewish athletes particularly, was exceeded only by his boundless love for his family. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. at 10AM. $(6$)WITTENBERG--Noel. Your courageous fight for additional time to be with Ann, Audrey and Richard, Sloane, Derek and Deven mirror the prominent place in our saddened hearts by your passing. Our deepest sympathies are extended to your family. I was privileged to hear numerous portions of your life through conversations packed with laughter and care along with guidance. Your affection, success, and esteem for others are a small number of your impressive traits. The Kalick Family

BY now, everyone is well convinced that tuna is a fine replacement for steak. And by now, many people have realized that the absolute best tuna -- bluefin -- has been overfished. The result is that it's scarce, hard to find, practically unaffordable when available and largely reserved for the classiest Japanese restaurants for use in sushi.

An article on Friday about the Hayward clan of the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, which led the tribe into the casino era but now feels rejected by its current leaders, misstated a comment by John L. Holder, executive assistant to the tribal chairman, about Richard A. Hayward, the tribe's former leader. He said Mr. Hayward had become rude and undiplomatic as chairman -- not undemocratic.

ELY--Clarence Geist, 76, Miami, FL, and Lakeville, CT, died June 22, 2007. Known as ''Geist'', he was born in Philadelphia, PA, on May 29, 1931 and was the son of Van Horn Ely, Jr. and Elizabeth Geist Ely, who was the daughter of Clarence Henry Geist, considered the largest private owner of utilities in the United States in the early 1990s. That grandfather, for whom he was named, built the Seaview Golf Club in Atlantic City, NJ, in 1914, developed The Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Florida in 1928, and built the controversial Geist Reservoir in Fall Creek Valley, PA. He is survived by his companion of 21 years, Margaret H. Douglas-Hamilton, four children, Van Horn Ely, III, Clarence Geist Ely, Jr., Melinda Ely Dubow, Center Marshall Ely, and five grandchildren. Three marriages ended in divorce. Mr. Ely was predeceased by his younger sister, Hope Ely Muzzarelli, who died young leaving a daughter, Elizabeth Gay Pollock whom he raised with his children. She and her four children also survive him.

A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about the handover of nine looted Kenyan wooden statues to the Kenyan government misidentified the official shown at a ceremony at the United Nations. He is Peter Ogego, the Kenyan ambassador to the United States -- not Zachary Dominic Muburi-Muita, Kenya's representative to the United Nations, who also attended.
KRAMER--Manny. We love and miss you on your birthday and everyday. Take good care of Howard. Sally, Terry, David, Margaret and Fred

CORBEN--Susan M., of Roslyn Heights, L.I., on June 25, 2007. Wife of the late Charles F. Survived by sons Richard P. and Peter H. Services Friday, June 29th, at 12:00pm, Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, L.I.

The police were investigating the death of a 14-year-old Spanish girl on the fast Rock 'n' Roller Coaster ride at the Disneyland just outside Paris. A prosecutor said the death appeared to be a result of a pre-existing medical condition rather than a ride malfunction.

WEBER--Beverly A., of New York City passed away on June 23, 2007 at the age of 76. Survived by her beloved sister, Dorothy Johnson of Fair Lawn, NJ, nephew, Kenneth E. Johnson, his wife Phyllis, their daughter, Kim, son, Chris, and two grandchildren. Beverly grew up in West Englewood, NJ and graduated from Teaneck High School. She began her career in the market research field as a supervisor with Daniel Starch & Staff in Mamaroneck, NY. She then spent over twenty years with Bristol-Myers Squibb. In her capacity as Market Research Manager, Beverly traveled extensively to Europe, South America, South Africa and Japan. She later worked as a management consultant conducting marketing and organization development projects. Beverly was a summa cum laude graduate of Fordham University with a degree in Social Science. She was a MENSA member who excelled in problem solving. This year marked Beverly's election as a Half Century member of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. The family will receive friends from 2-5pm on Thursday, June 28th at the Vander Plaat Colonial Funeral Home, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410. A funeral service will be held on Friday, June 29th at 11am at the funeral home. Pastor Peter Hoytema of the Midland Park Christian Reformed Church will officiate, followed by interment in the George Washington Memorial Park in Paramus, NJ. A memorial service will be held in the New York City area at a future time and place to be announced. Contributions in Beverly's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 and to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

The Altria Group, the cigarette maker, will close a North Carolina factory and increase European production to save $335 million a year by 2011. The shutdown of the plant in Cabarrus County will result in a one-time charge of $325 million in the second quarter, Altria said. The company, which is based in New York, may be preparing to spin off its international unit, analysts and investors said. Factories in Europe will take over production of Marlboros and other cigarettes bound for Japan and the Middle East, which are currently being made in North Carolina. All of Altria's United States output will be shifted to Richmond, Va. Closing the North Carolina facility, which employs 2,500, will cost about 10 cents a share in the second quarter, Altria said. Expenses will total $670 million by 2011.

STERN--Douglas E., New York's Swimming and Deep Water Running Maven, died from cancer on Monday, June 25, 2007 at the age of 63. Doug took great pleasure in being a father and husband in addition to running the Doug Stern Swimming Clinic and serving as a teacher and swimming coach at Evander Child's High School in the Bronx for 27 years, where he won coach of the year in 1972. Memorial services will be held on Thursday, June 28 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotècnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotècnia, which also makes solar panels, it said. The purchase will help Alstom, which is based in Paris, expand in the United States and Asia, it said. Buying Ecotècnia strengthens Alstom's presence in renewable energy as governments seek alternatives to coal, gas and oil. Alstom also sells hydroelectric equipment and worked with Russia's state nuclear agency in April to develop atomic plants.

The New York City Central Labor Council announced yesterday that Gary La Barbera was elected president at a delegates meeting on Monday night. Mr. La Barbera, 47, is president of a Teamsters local representing 4,000 construction industry drivers and heads the Teamsters' district council for the New York metropolitan region, representing 100,000 Teamsters. He succeeds Brian M. McLaughlin, who headed the labor council for 11 years before he was indicted in October on charges of obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribery. The delegates approved a new constitution that gives Mr. La Barbera less power than Mr. McLaughlin had. The council's board will have more powers; the president will serve as chairman of the board, sharing responsibilities with an executive director who runs operations day to day.

LLOYD--Frank V. D. The Board of Trustees of The Animal Medical Center acknowledges with sadness the loss of Frank Van Duyne Lloyd. Vice Chairman of the Board and tireless contributor to the cause of healthcare for companion animals, Lloyd will long be remembered and deeply missed by the staff and friends of The AMC. His many benefactions have improved the lives of so many animals in the New York region. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Karen, and his three daughters Kathryn, Kristina and Heather, as well as his loving sister, Eve Lloyd Thompson.

A headline on an article in Business Day on Saturday about the efforts of some companies to provide health insurance for retirees too young for Medicare overstated the number of retirees the program might help. Although about 800,000 early retirees are said to be without health insurance, the program's organizers say the plan would probably help only a fraction of them, not all.
To the Editor:

HEFTLER--Thomas. Words cannot express how deeply sorry we are about this tragic loss. Tom was my mentor, colleague and dear friend, a sweet, wise and gentle man. Our family will sorely miss him. Sincere condolences to Lois, Daniel, Jeffrey and their entire family. Marvin and Helena Goldstein

A sale billed as the biggest auction of Civil War memorabilia ever was conducted Sunday and Monday in Gettysburg, Pa., by Heritage Auction Galleries of Dallas and brought in almost $6.5 million. A silver-, gold- and diamond-encrusted ceremonial sword, above, presented in 1864 to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant by the people of Kentucky, sold for $1.6 million, including buyer's premium. The buyer plans to exhibit the sword, kept by Grant's descendants until the 1960s, at the Texas Civil War Museum in Fort Worth. The battle flag of Gen. George A. Custer, sewn for him out of silk by his wife, Libbie, was bought by a private collector for nearly $900,000, including premium. Custer flew the red-and-blue swallowtail flag, showing crossed swords, in battle during the waning days of the Civil War and at Gen. Robert E. Lee's surrender at Appomattox. He left it at Fort Lincoln, Dakota Territory, before his encounter at Little Big Horn. It remained in the Custer family until the 1950s.

The police arrested three Moroccan men in Barcelona on suspicion that they had links to the North African terrorist group Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, and belonged to a terrorist cell that recruits and equips militants. They were detained at the request of the Moroccan authorities.

To the Editor: Vice President Dick Cheney's refusal to be bound by this administration's own directives regarding classified information (''Agency Is Target in Cheney Fight on Secrecy Data,'' front page, June 22) illustrates his disregard for basic democratic principles.

BROZMAN--Tina. A ''woman a valor'', dignity, honesty and courage. Love profoundly by her husband Andrew and children Nick, Alix, Wallis; family, friends, and dogs Pete, Rolly and Rory. Your impact on the bankruptcy legal profession will last forever. You are unforgettable. Dr. Jerilyn Kronen

WHITE--Timothy. Today is the fifth anniversary of Tim's untimely death at age 50. White, a renowned writer and editor of Billboard Magazine, was a passionate advocate for great music and artists' rights. He was also a devoted husband to Judy and father of twin boys Alexander and Christopher. White was taken all too soon, and we will truly miss him forever. His legacy is alive and well. As Tim himself would say, ''Rock heavily and without shame.'' Maureen

Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee and a steadfast supporter of the president, has conspicuously broken ranks with him on the Iraq war, warning that the United States' standing in the world could be irreparably eroded if the White House does not change strategy soon. ''In my judgment, the costs and risks of continuing down the current path outweigh the potential benefits that might be achieved,'' Mr. Lugar said Monday during a 50-minute speech on the Senate floor, which was delivered after nearly everyone in the Capitol had retired for the evening. ''Persisting indefinitely with the surge strategy will delay policy adjustments that have a better chance of protecting our vital interests over the long term.''

To the Editor: Col. Morris D. Davis (''The Guantánamo I Know,'' Op-Ed, June 26) describes a pristine prison where detainees are given three meals a day. What he ignores is that Guantánamo's new prison facilities subject detainees to virtually total and continuous isolation in tiny windowless cells.

A few months after announcing a $1.3 billion deal with France to rent the Louvre's name and gain access to its collections for a new museum in Abu Dhabi, that oil-rich emirate says it also wants to be the film and television capital of the Arab world. In October it will hold its first Middle East International Film Festival. And today it will announce an agreement with the New York Film Academy, a technical school, to open a branch in Abu Dhabi to train 100 students a year in television and film production. (Tuition at the Manhattan school is $34,000, but the emirate is likely to subsidize a portion of that.) Officials with the Abu Dhabi Authority for Culture and Heritage also said they were soliciting investment in the Persian Gulf region for a sizable fund, to be unveiled later this summer, that would offer financial incentives for film production in Abu Dhabi exceeding those offered by governments in Europe and elsewhere. Sami el-Masri, the authority's director of strategic planning, said the initiatives were aimed at erecting bridges across cultures in a region accustomed to destroying them: ''It's about looking for common denominators at a time when we only look at differences.'' Within the United Arab Emirates, Abu Dhabi has been in something of a footrace to announce cultural and tourist attractions, anticipating a future when the oil wells run dry. Neighboring Dubai is already building a $2.5 billion sports complex and a theme park based on Marvel Entertainment comics, and on Monday a unit of Viacom Inc. said it had signed a deal with a developer in the United Arab Emirates for a $2.5 billion theme park based on its library of films like ''Titanic.''

ELLENBERG--Joseph. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the loss of Joseph Ellenberg, a distinguished alumnus, director of budgets and costs, and Presidential Medallion recipient for his 63 years of devoted service to the university. He began at YU in 1940 as a student and remained to become its senior professional. He was beloved and respected for his dedication to his alma mater and to Klal Yisrael. Heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nanette, son Dr. Gilad (and Miriam) Ellenberg and daughter Aura (and Allen) Schiff, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees
EDELMAN--Morton H., Five years. Our guide and inspiration, deeply missed, forever loved. Diana & Alex
BlackRock, the rapidly growing asset management company, said yesterday that it had acquired the ''fund of funds'' business of the Quellos Group, a boutique investment firm in Seattle.

A Russian citizen has accused Britain's MI6 foreign intelligence service of trying to recruit him while he was abroad. The accusation was made by the authorities and broadcast on national television. The man was not identified but was described as being in fear of his life. Russian television, which is under tight Kremlin control, has repeatedly accused Britain of spying. The campaign intensified last month when a man accused by British prosecutors of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent and foe of the Kremlin, said British intelligence had committed the murder.

Levis Minford has never bought a house that was finished. Building and renovating have become almost a habit for Mr. Minford, a native of Idaho, and he always has some kind of construction project going on. So it was no surprise that, when he was looking for a house outside Warsaw, he settled on an 18th-century stable that had to be turned into a house. Now a film distributor, Mr. Minford was living in Brussels and doing market research for American film studios when, in 1990, he moved to Warsaw, attracted by the business opportunities available in Poland's young free-market economy. In 1995, he was renting a house in Konstancin, a posh spa town outside Warsaw, when he spotted a desolate red-brick stable on the far outskirts of the resort.

BEAR--Charles B. The board of the Time-Life Alumni Society is saddened by the recent death of a former board member, Charles Bear. A graduate of Grinnell College, he later received a Masters in international relations from Tufts' Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. This lead to an executive career in Time Inc., with an early focus on the international expansion of the company. After World War II, as head of Time's international operations, he was based in Paris where he managed the distribution of magazines in 40 countries. When he was seized and held captive by the Russians for four days, he emerged unharmed, except, as he later reported, ''for an overexposure to sauerkraut soup.'' At age 45 he was named managing director of Time Life International, and later he was a key officer of Fortune and Architectural Forum Back in the United Stated. He capped his magazine career as a group vice-president and secretary of Time, Inc., and he became the company's chief administrative officer. He was a member of the U.S Olympic Committee, and he was a consultant to the Commissioner of Baseball. Charles' business wit was legendary. He was a man of few words or many words depending on the occasion. For example, when he recommended to the Time Inc board that a small chain of weeklies be divested, he cogently summarized his judgement with these words: ''...(This company) is something of an appendage to the corporation, a vestigial tail that the dog wouldn't bother to wag if he could.'' He will be missed by his former colleagues for his wit and charm, but he will also be remembered for his brilliant hard-nosed leadership in the world-wide expansion of Time Inc. Don Underwood, President, Time-Life Alumni Society
A theater review on Monday about ''Romeo and Juliet,'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misstated Juliet's age in the play. She is 13, not 14..

SUSSMAN--Rachel. We acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of Rachel Sussman, the pillar of our Synagogue whose unconditional and uninterrupted generosity helped us continue our existence as a Synagogue. Her legacy will not fade in the hearts of our congregants and everyone she touched by her kindness. We wish our most sincere condolences to her family and loved ones. Rabbi, President and Board of Trustees of the West Side Institutional Synagogue $(6$)SUSSMAN--Rachel. Yeshiva University and its Albert Einstein College of Medicine are saddened by the loss of Rachel Sussman, devoted wife of the late Leo Sussman. In memory of her husband, she established the Leo and Rachel Sussman Cancer Research Floor and the Leo and Rachel Sussman Computer-based Education Fund at Einstein. A distinguished and compassionate woman, she was a generous Benefactor who established the Leo and Rachel Sussman Biology Laboratory at YU's Stern College for Women, and the Leo and Rachel Sussman Fellowship Fund for students pursuing advancing Jewish studies at Yeshiva University's Bernard Revel Graduate School. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

An article on June 13 about a more hospitable approach to day laborers taken by the village of Mamaroneck, N.Y., referred imprecisely to the number of hiring sites in the country. According to the National Day Labor Organizing Network, there are approximately 65 formal sites, like the one at the Strait Gate Church in Mamaroneck. But there are hundreds more informal gathering places for day laborers, including street corners and parking lots. (The first nationwide study of day laborers, released in 2006, counted more than 500 sites.)

WECHSLER--Sylvia, 87, died on June 25, 2007. Beloved wife of Stanley, beloved mother of Rabbi Harlan J., Richard L. and Barry A., grandmother and great-grandmother, dear sister. Funeral services Wednesday, June 27, 2007 at 12 noon at Menorah Gardens Chapel, West Palm Beach. $(6$)WECHSLER--Sylvia. The officers, board, members and staff of Congregation Or Zarua extend their deep sympathy to our beloved rabbi and teacher, Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, and his family on the loss of his mother, Sylvia Wechsler. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her family. Michael W. Schwartz, President

An article on Saturday about reaction at a reunion of Antioch College alumni to a decision to close the college misstated the number of students who enrolled in 2006. It was 130 -- not 63, which was the number of new students in 2005.

The Newark schools superintendent, Marion A. Bolden, promised yesterday to meet regularly with a task force of the city's gay and lesbian leaders, according to the head of a New Jersey gay rights group. The promise comes after Ms. Bolden ordered a picture of a graduating senior kissing his boyfriend blacked out of the East Side High School yearbook. After an outcry, the school district said it would reissue the yearbooks with the picture unmarked. Steven Goldstein, of Garden State Equality, said Ms. Bolden made the commitment to meet during a phone call that he described as ''heartfelt.'' A spokeswoman for Ms. Bolden's office could not confirm that commitment, but said Ms. Bolden met yesterday with Andre Jackson, the student whose picture was blacked out. The superintendent also apologized in front of Mr. Jackson's classmates at a graduation rehearsal, the spokeswoman said. Mr. Jackson could not be reached for comment yesterday.

TRAUBE--Beverly Anderson, a veteran Broadway talent agent whose clients were a who's who of the stage, died last Saturday evening at her home in Queens. She was 77. Her 50-year career made her one of New York's longest running independent agents. She helped launch the careers of Alan Alda, Bernadette Peters, Elliot Gould, Morgan Fairchild, Donna Mills, Gil Gerard and Pia Zadora. Her late husband, Leonard Traube, passed away in 2003. She is survived by two sons, publicist Frederic Traube, president and owner of Pro Sports Music Marketing, a Virginia-based music and sports marketing agency, his wife Lana; and Michael Traube, a New York based artist. A viewing and memorial service will be held June 27 in New York City at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. A memorial will also be held in Los Angeles on July 23.

Native groups are threatening to cause major travel disruptions at the start of the forthcoming Canada Day holiday weekend . Shawn Best, a spokesman for the Tyendinaga Mohawk Council, said members would block either Ontario's main highway near Kingston, Ontario, or the rail line between Montreal and Toronto on Friday to protest poverty and land claims. He said that other native groups had told him they planned similar moves in other parts of the country.

The Coca-Cola Company will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed. The Takanashi family, which founded the bottler 50 years ago, will retain control of about 65 percent of the company, Charlie Sutlive, a Coca-Cola spokesman, said.

I LEFT the suburbs 24 years ago and never looked back. The one thing I didn't count on missing was the barbecue, which is what we called it in the olden days, when it was still a tub full of charcoal briquettes topped by a wobbly grate. These days it's known as the grill, and it can resemble a stainless steel spaceship, a birdhouse or a bungalow.

A chart with the Off the Charts column in Business Day on Saturday, about the inventory of homes for sale, referred incorrectly to the number of unsold houses. They were in the thousands, not hundreds. A corrected graphic is online at nytimes.com/business.

A first edition of the first Harry Potter adventure worked financial magic yesterday when it was sold at auction in London for $18,000, the BBC reported. The J. K. Rowling novel, issued in Britain in 1997 under the title ''Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone,'' above (the title in the United States is ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone''), is a rarity, according to the auction house, Bonhams. The publisher, Bloomsbury, gave it an initial press run of 500 copies. Bonhams sold the book to an anonymous buyer. The seller was an unidentified woman who had bought it originally with book tokens that she had been given as a school prize.

The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would consolidate the national creative assignments for its Buick, Pontiac and GMC brands at the Pontiac creative agency. It was the second time in five months and the third time in a year that G.M., once loath to change agencies, had shifted large accounts.

Rudolph W. Giuliani addressed Israeli-Palestinian discord on Tuesday, saying it was pointless for the United States to negotiate with Hamas, the Islamic group that has seized control of the Gaza Strip, and that Washington should work with Egypt and Jordan to bolster Fatah and its control over the West Bank. As he advocated active American engagement, Mr. Giuliani urged caution and broadly criticized the Clinton administration's approach in the 1990s, trying to broker peace with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

HUGHES--David H. November 8, 1918-June 18, 2007. Former Skidmore, Owings and Merrill partner David H. Hughes died on June 18, 2007 in Tucson, Arizona. The cause of death was heart failure. His almost 30 year career with the noted architectural firm began in 1948. He was involved in many projects in the U.S. as well as in Germany, South Africa and France. He retired from SOM in 1975 after establishing a Paris office for the firm. David Huey Hughes was born November 8, 1918, the son of David Ashford Hughes and Anne Wright Hughes. He grew up in Santa Fe, New Mexico and graduated from the Los Alamos Ranch School and from Yale University, class of 1941. The following year he married Ruth Noel Hurley, the daughter of Patrick J. Hurley and Ruth Wilson Hurley. During World War II he served as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force, Squadron 394. He then earned a degree in architecture from Yale before joining Skidmore Owings and Merrill. He was a member of the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, and served on the boards of several schools and clubs in Greenwich, CT. After he retired, he and Ruth divided their time between New York and Santa Fe before moving to Tucson in 1999. His wife Ruth died in 2000. He is survived by his eight children, David Hughes of Chicago, Anne Hughes Kieve of San Francisco, Cecily Hughes of Telluride, CO, Ruth Hughes of The Plains, VA, Ian Hughes of Fairfield, CT, and Wilson, Peter and Graeme Hughes of Tucson, as well as 13 grandchildren.

An article in Weekend on Friday about the refurbished Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden at the New York Botanical Garden referred incorrectly to David Rockefeller's donation in the 1980s for the renovation of an earlier rose garden at the same site. It was in honor of his wife, Peggy, not in memory of her. (She died in 1996.) The article also misstated the name of one kind of rose on display and erroneously listed part of the name as a variety. It is the Rita Levi Montalcini (named after the Nobel Prize winner Rita Levi-Montalcini), not the Rita Levi, and there is no rose called simply the Montalcini.

WHEN I took a job as a zoo keeper one summer in college, I imagined it as a position of considerable, if peculiar, glory. It was volunteer work, which I thought indicated a certain nobility, and it would take place almost entirely outdoors, so while everyone else I knew struggled to stay awake, joylessly checking and rechecking their e-mail, I would be basking in the grassy splendor of Central Park. I envisioned hosing down elephants, tossing mackerels to sea lions, forging a gentle connection with an orangutan. Man-eaters would go cuddly at my touch.

An article yesterday about North Korea's pledge to shut down its main nuclear plant misstated the plant's location relative to Pyongyang, the capital. The plant, in Yongbyon, is about 60 miles north of Pyongyang, not south.
Senator Chris Dodd is not Paris Hilton. Tavis Smiley is not Alex Trebek. And both Michelle and Senator Barack Obama are HIV-free.

Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, leads the annual super strong tournament in Dortmund, Germany, with 3 out of 4 points. Called the Sparkassen Chess-Meeting (which almost sounds like a tea social), the tournament is one of the four elite tournaments on the chess calendar (along with Linares, Corus and the M-Tel Masters). The official Web site for the tournament can be found here.
Well, it took me two weeks to work up the nerve, but I finally read all your comments about my last Hillary Clinton column and see that we have had a pretty major misunderstanding.

Are scientists on the brink of creating entirely new forms of life? In a study published this week by the journal Science, a research team led by Dr. J. Craig Venter and Dr. John I. Glass reported that they had managed to replace the genes of one species of bacteria entirely with the genes of another. Dr. Venter and Dr. Glass will be taking readers' questions about their research and its implications on Friday, and their answers will be posted here. Submit your question below; they will not be able to answer all questions and only those selected will be published. (Editor's note: questions are no longer being accepted.)

Yankees Manager Joe Torre is not the type to bark at his players or flip over a table in the clubhouse to try to motivate them. But Torre admitted he recently thought about taking batting practice with the Yankees "to lighten the mood."

I think this is the third time I have brought this topic up this year, but it's a wonderful sign of a change in Formula One, somewhere. The press conference today at Magny-Cours was again an occasion for a little levity, smiles and outright fun laughter.
The New York Times Co-chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "In Between Days," about a young Korean immigrant in an unnamed American city.
The New York Times Co-chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Ratatouille," the latest offering from Pixar about a gastronomically inclined rat.

In response to a deluge of complaints from users, YouTube.com has reinstated features that allow visitors to its site to sort videos by the number of views, rating and other measures in each of its topical categories - "News and Politics," being one of our favorites.

The so-called marriage gap, in which single people vote differently from married people, has been evident in the last three presidential campaigns, with married voters tending to support the Republican and unmarrieds supporting the Democrat.

Today's unusually late start for reporters was the latest attempt by The Wall Street Journal's newsroom to protest the expected sale of the paper and Dow Jones, its parent company, to Rupert Murdoch's media empire, the News Corporation. A passage from this week's New Yorker may give an indication of just how effective they are likely to be in influencing Mr. Murdoch.

I'm always on the lookout for great wine lists and I'm thrilled when I find one. Last week I wrote about one kind of great list, at Landmarc in the Time Warner Center, where the prices are extraordinarily low even if the wines are not terribly exciting. Yesterday I found a great list of entirely different sort, at Trestle on Tenth in Chelsea, a lovely little neighborhood restaurant with Swiss and French influences. Here, the wines themselves are exciting and the prices are more than fair. I've eaten there enjoyably several times, and here's a review from my colleague Frank Bruni. But while I've always liked the wine list, I think it has improved tremendously in the last few months.
An ad for Accelerade.
Joseph Bertolozzi is using a bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., as an instrument and is composing a suite for it.

In perhaps another sign that buyout boom is slowing down, Dollar General, the national discount chain, has lopped off a potentially risky form of debt from its proposed bond offering, Bloomberg News and Reuters reported Thursday. The retailer has removed $725 million so-called pay-in-kind toggles, or bonds that can be repaid in cash or by the issuing of more debt.
Dwight Macdonald's letters, collected in Michael Wreszin's anthology, "A Moral Temper," are blistering reading - rude, funny, alive. You didn't want to be on the wrong end of a Macdonald thrashing.

France has a new president, and a new presidential baguette. This year, Nicolas Sarkozy and his guests at Élysée Palace will have a Renaissance with their meals -- the baguette made by Arnaud Delmontel. He won this year's prize for the best baguette in Paris, awarded by the mayor's office, which means he'll be the official supplier to the president.

Universal Express, a company that can pay its bills only by illegally selling unregistered shares, has taken out a full-page ad on page C11 of today's Times. It bills the ad as a response to the "undeveloped articles" I wrote about the company last week. (Here are the column and a follow-up article.)
Oracle has its binge of acquisitions to thank for its better-than-expected quarterly profits and sales, according to the software company and some of the analysts who cover it.

The army of lobbying firms hired to battle the effort to increase federal taxes for private-equity managers and venture capitalists continues to grow: A filing made public on Wednesday shows that the law firm Proskauer Rose has signed on to represent the National Venture Capital Association on the matter.
It seems fitting that a ubiquitous piece of technology that everyone takes for granted celebrated its 40th birthday as people line up for the iPhone, the very height of the mania.

In a memo sent to major donors and supporters this morning, Howard Wolfson, the campaign communications director for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, predicted that the Clinton camp would raise "in the range of $27 million" for the second quarter of 2007, which ends Saturday night.
As hedge fund managers inspire fashion trends and TV series, investment bankers have inspired an obituary of sorts from one former member of that profession.

Senate supporters of the far-reaching immigration bill failed to muster the 60 votes needed to close off debate today. It was a procedural vote required to move the bill on to final debate and a vote; 46 senators voted to move it on while 53 voted against the motion.
With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.
A sighting of a celebrated mathematician may not quite be the stuff of Page Six, but it seems perfect for us.
Toss another stick or two on to that smoldering Cold War fire: There's renewed talk of expanding the Russian Empire.
David Pogue answers reader questions on the Apple iPhone.
Umbrellas, tents and pavilions guard against too much sun.
All together: free group workouts in New York.

As menswear designers showcased their latest creations on the runways of Milan this week, many of the shows seemed to have something in common, an animating spirit that reflected today's culture, today's time. That phenomenon, according to The New York Times, was best encapsulated by the editor of Departures, American Express' magazine for the jet set:

If you can't defund him, just impeach him: Some opponents of the idea of impeaching President Bush (such as Washington Post columnist Eugene Robinson) base their opposition on the frightening notion of President Dick Cheney. Writing in Slate, conservative heretic Bruce Fein proposes a solution for that problem: Impeach Cheney. Fein, who was associate deputy attorney general and general counsel of the Federal Communications Commission under President Reagan, writes:
A water purification factory reborn as a hotel and more.

Lyndsay and Patrick Mikanowski's new cookbook, "Egg," is one I'll probably never cook out of. It's crazily conceptual (have a look at the cover, below) and it's as much an art-thing, a dream book, as a food-thing. Most of the recipes are from avant-gardish, well-known chefs - Ferran Adria, Wylie Dufresne, et al. - and most look like they'd require 8 hours and a battery of sous-chefs to duplicate.
After 78 years as part of General Motors, Allison Transmission is switching gears. In a sign of the times, that switch involves some big buyout shops.

Senators, who have been arguing for weeks over provisions of the compromise immigration bill, are set to decide today whether to close debate and vote on passage. Whatever happens, the fate of the immigration bill is likely to have consequences for both parties in the 2008 presidential election.

Just when it seemed that the World Chess Federation had finally settled on a system for selecting the world champion that had some widespread support, it has rewritten the rules again. In a press release earlier this week that can be found here the federation said that the winner of a grand prix series of tournaments held over a two-year period would play a match against the winner of a mega-tournament called the World Cup. The winner of that match would then play a match against the world champion. The grand prix would begin in 2008.

MISC, the world's biggest owner of liquefied gas tankers, postponed a $750 million bond offering, in the latest sign of the turbulence in the debt markets. The Financial Times's Lex column suggests the increased resistance "could be the beginning of a serious bondholder revolt." Separately, an analyst at CreditSights suggested that troubles at two Bear Stearns hedge funds could spread in unexpected ways.

Over the weekend of June 17, executives at Bear Stearns scrambled to avert the collapse of two hedge funds. In the midst of the turmoil, Richard Marin, the head of the Bear unit that ran the troubled funds, "stole away" from the "crisis-hedge-fund-salvation-workaholic weekend" to see the new Kevin Costner thriller "Mr. Brooks."

Analysts said that the sudden promotion of John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargo's chief operating officer, to chief executive, signaled that the bank would probably continue to focus on increasing sales in its core markets in the West rather than merging with an East Coast partner like Wachovia or SunTrust, as many on Wall Street have advocated for years.

Affinion Group Holdings, a marketing-services business that the private equity firm Apollo Management bought from Cendant in 2005, filed to raise as much as $600 million in an initial public offering.

PregLem, a pharmaceutical company based in Geneva, Switzerland, announced Wednesday that it had raised $26 million in series A funding. The funds will help develop and commercialize compounds for women suffering from infertility.

The campaign to brand the Beijing Olympics as "the Genocide Olympics," unless China distances itself from Sudan, is unfortunately creating something of a backlash within China. It would be so important to get Chinese bloggers to scold their government for underwriting the Darfur genocide, but in fact the opposite is happening. Nationalist sentiment and a certain defensiveness is leading Chinese netizens to claim that the Darfur movement is just an effort to prevent Chinese oil companies from exploiting Sudanese oil. Here's a translation of a Chinese blog posting.

Insight Venture Partners wrapped up its latest investment vehicle, Insight Venture Partners VI, with $1.25 billion, a closing that gives the New York firm about $3 billion under management. Founded in 1995, Insight Venture focuses on software and Internet services investments that cover the entire range of private capital investment - from early-stage venture capital deals to buyouts.

The German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media agreed Wednesday to buy SBS Broadcasting of Luxembourg, creating a pan-European broadcaster that can take on Bertelsmann's RTL Group. ProSieben, based in Munich, will pay 3.3 billion euros ($4.4 billion) for SBS and expects a smooth closing next month because the deal does not require the approval of either competition or media watchdogs.

People's United Financial has agreed to buy Chittenden for $1.9 billion in cash and stock, in a deal that will create the largest locally owned bank in New England, with $21 billion in assets and more than 210 branches.

The Carlyle Group postponed a $415 million initial public offering of a fund that invests in bonds backed by mortgages after a slump in the subprime market. The buyout shop "is preparing a supplemental offering memorandum that will contain a revised timetable for the global offering," the Washington-based firm said. The firm had offered investors 18.9 million shares for $20 to $22 each.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice have decided to finance their $7.1 billion buyout of U.S. Foodservice with a bridge loan after canceling a $650 million bond offering, as investors appeared reluctant to back the financing.

The Coles Group, the Australian retailer, said on Thursday that a consortium led by the Texas Pacific Group would not submit a takeover offer for the company by the Sunday deadline but was still interested in making a bid.

Nuveen Investments, an asset management firm, said in a regulatory filing late Tuesday that two separate lawsuits have been filed by shareholders seeking to block a $5.75 billion buyout of the company.
Sierra Health Services said Wednesday evening that 99 percent of its shareholders had approved the company's merger with UnitedHealth Group.

Fallout from the subprime mortgage market meltdown continued as Caliber Global Investment, a $908 million fund based in Britain and managed by Cambridge Place Investment Management, said it would close after losses on subprime-mortgage debt in the United States.

A data center services provider, Equinix, said Thursday it is buying IXEurope, a European data center operator, for about $482 million in cash. IXEurope's shareholders will receive $2.50 for each share held. IXEurope's operations include 14 data centers throughout Europe, which Equinix plans to fold into its brand.

Terra Firma Capital Partners, the private equity firm that has offered 2.4 billion pounds ($4.7 billion) for the British music firm EMI Group, extended its takeover bid on Thursday until July 4. As of June 27, Terra Firma had received acceptances representing 3.5 percent of the music company.

Federal regulators filed charges against a hedge fund manager, Simpson Capital Management, for allegedly defrauding mutual fund investors of millions of dollars in a late-trading scheme lasting more than three years. And in a twist, the chief of the hedge fund in question had family ties to a fund manager whose alleged market abuses set off an industry-wide investigation in the earlier part of the decade.
Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

The Italian government was dealt a setback on Wednesday in its efforts to find a suitor to rescue Alitalia, the nation's flagship carrier, after Aeroflot of Russia abandoned its bid to buy the airline.

A federal jury began deliberations in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul, on Wednesday after more than an hour of instructions from Judge Amy J. St. Eve. The jury of six women and six men deliberated for about two and a half hours before recessing for the day.

For the social software side of Enterprise 2.0, there may be a short window of opportunity for M&A, according to the analyst firm The 451 Group, which takes a look at the potential buyers and sellers in the market for wiki and blogging software. Among the potential acquisition targets named in the report are Six Apart and Atlassian Software Systems; 451 Group analyst Kathleen Reidy considers the software giant Oracle to be the most logical buyer of such assets.

The NASD said Wednesday that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending. The analyst, Jennifer Jordan, who is now a corporate vice president in charge of investor relations at the company, Cadence Design Systems, refused to settle the NASD case and will fight it, her lawyer said.

A bid by the low-cost airline Ryanair to buy Aer Lingus, Ireland's national carrier, was blocked Wednesday as the top European regulator showed a willingness to intervene despite the overturning of past merger prohibitions in court.
The notion that French cinema consists mainly of pretentious soft-core pornography is an ignorant cliché, but “One to Another” does little to disprove it.
“Vitus” places uncomfortable impulses in opposition, then dramatizes them in the most unchallenging way imaginable.
The bachelors of La Viñuela, Spain, welcome "women's caravans" to their rural — mostly male — village.
A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Black's Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war on Wednesday.
Citigroup, the world's largest financial company, was cleared of insider trading in Australia on Thursday in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.
Images from "Encompassing the Globe: Portugal and the World in the 16th and 17th Centuries" at the Smithsonian's Sackler Gallery in Washington.
One hedge-fund hotel is in hot water.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
The casual irreverence of “Burn Notice,” the USA Network’s new drama about an American spy, is a little unsettling.
No national parks, but 20 million acres of public land, much of it far from the crowds.
Standing in the land of the Acadians requires one foot in Canada and one in the U.S.
Wheeled briefcases are exploding in number.
New shows in New York include "Old Acquiantance" and "Gone Missing."

Apple's iPhone goes on sale Friday. Early reviews of the phone have been mostly positive. The Times's David Pogue wrote: Even in version 1.0, the iPhone is still the most sophisticated, outlook-changing piece of electronics to come along in years. It does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, a video game based on the book and coming movie of the same name, has some wonderful things in it, is woefully undeveloped.
How do I get the video and animation to work on Web sites when I am not using a computer running Windows or Microsoft’s Internet Explorer browser?
ClickStart: My First Computer, from Leapfrog, is intended to transform your TV into a computing center for preschoolers.
The iHC5 alarm clock from iHome can connect wirelessly with any digital device that features Bluetooth technology and stream an audio file to the bedroom.
The PowerMonkey is a lithium-ion battery with a charging circuit that lets it connect to most cellphones and portable devices like iPods and PlayStation Portables.
The keyboard comes in jet black and has blue L.E.D. backlights that cast an eerie glow through and around the keys.
The Democratic presidential candidates agreed on a number of domestic issues  as they addressed an audience largely comprised of African-Americans.

The following is a transcript of the Democratic primary presidential debate on PBS. The participants were Senator Joseph Biden, Jr. (D-Del.); Senator Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.); Senator Christopher Dodd (D-Conn.); Former Senator John Edwards (D-S.C.); Former Senator Mike Gravel (D-Ak); Representative Dennis Kucinich (D-Ohio); Senator Barack Obama (D-Ill.); and Gov. Bill Richardson (D-N.M.). The moderator was Tavis Smiley, host of “Tavis Smiley” on PBS. The panelists were Michel Martin, journalist and NPR host; Ruben Navarrette, Jr., nationally syndicated columnist; Dewayne Wickham, USA Today and Gannett News Service columnist. The debate took place at Howard University on Thursday, June 28, 2007. Transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.
The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary plans to integrate schools left hundreds of school districts struggling to assess whether they must change their policies.
For two hours, the match between Aisam ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan and Marat Safin provided a fascinating contrast in players and temperaments.
Enforcing its edict against execution of the insane, a split Supreme Court today overturned the death sentence of Scott Louis Panetti, a delusional Texas murderer.

BAGHDAD, June 28 — A spate of grisly attacks believed carried out by Sunni extremists killed dozens of Shiites around Baghdad over the past two days, just ahead of a planned huge march of devout Shiites through Sunni Arab heartlands to the remnants of a revered Shiite shrine.
All the world’s 600 million housecats are descended from the subspecies known as Felis silvestris lybica, scientists have concluded based on new DNA research.
Scientists exploring the western slopes of the Andes in northern Peru have found seeds of domesticated squash from almost 10,000 years ago.
A judicial review body ruled that a former Libyan intelligence official might have been wrongfully convicted for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing.
The White House said today that it was invoking executive privilege to reject subpoenas for documents.
In a decision of sweeping importance, the Supreme Court today sharply limited the ability of school districts to manage the racial makeup of the student bodies in their schools.
The Israeli government has dropped rape charges against President Moshe Katsav in exchange for his agreement to step down and to plead guilty to lesser charges.
Bald eagles, whose numbers dwindled in the 1960s, are once again flourishing, the interior secretary said today.
President Bush’s effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration policy, a cornerstone of his domestic agenda, collapsed in the Senate.
The grisly discovery in a mostly Sunni village was made on a bloody day in Iraq, as a car bomb attack killed 25.

Paris Hilton read aloud her prison writings as if she had spent a lifetime on Robben Island, and that was surely the highlight of the heiress/actress’s first television interview since her release from jail.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had surgery to have two stents implanted in a coronary artery because of blockage in his heart.

Severe storms last night delayed service on the Long Island Rail Road for more than two hours after floods caused signal problems at the Jamaica station about 7:30 p.m. Service to and from Jamaica was affected after 8 p.m., a railroad spokeswoman said.
The Motion Picture Association of America sued YouTVpc and Peekvid.com, claiming they illegally post copyrighted material.

Sales of alcohol on the trains and at the stations of the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Railroad will continue. As expected, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority declined yesterday to act on a proposal to ban alcoholic beverages on the commuter lines. A board committee that studied the issue said it could not find a correlation between alcohol sales and accidents or arrests involving drunken commuters. The authority’s chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, said the board would not take any action on the proposal, made last year by Mitchell H. Pally, a board member from Long Island. Mr. Pally said he would continue to press for a ban. “It is as if we were giving people a license to drink and drive, and that is unacceptable,” he said. The railroads sell beer, wine and hard liquor in some trains and stations.
Starter Tom Glavine earned his 297th career victory, but the Mets managed just two hits against Anthony Reyes, a pitcher who has struggled this season like few others.

Severe storms caused delays of about two hours last night on the Long Island Rail Road after floods caused signal problems at the Jamaica station about 7:30 p.m., affecting service after 8 p.m. to and from Jamaica, according to a railroad spokeswoman. Pennsylvania Station became so crowded at one point that the Long Island Rail Road’s section was shut to new passengers between 8 and 10 p.m., leaving hundreds of passengers stranded outside. As of 10 p.m., service was restored at all but three stations, where trees had fallen on the tracks. Service was expected to be normal this morning.
Furniture Large and Small.
Citigroup  was cleared of insider trading in Australia in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.
A 19-year-old was fatally shot last night on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said.
A proposal to expand the N.C.A.A.’s drug-testing policy to include street drugs was rejected yesterday by a committee. The measure would have imposed a half-season ban for first-time offenders.

Haile Gebrselassie set two world records in the rarely contested one-hour race yesterday at the Golden Spike, eclipsing the mark for the race and adding another at 20,000 meters along the way. In both events, Gebrselassie broke the 16-year-old records of Mexico’s Arturo Barrios, set in La Fleche, France. He completed 12.77 miles to beat Barrios’s mark by 184 meters, and finished 20,000 meters in 56 minutes 25.98 seconds, nearly a full 30 seconds faster than the previous standard.

Carlos Villaneuva bent a free kick over a defensive wall and into the upper corner of the net for a tie-breaking goal in the 87th minute, giving Chile a 3-2 victory against Ecuador last night in the first round of the Copa America.Chile rallied from deficits twice, with Humberto Suazo scoring in the 21st and 80th minutes. Ecuador, knocked out of last year’s World Cup in the second round by England, got goals from Antonio Valencia in the 16th minute and Segundo Castillo in the 23rd.
House lawmakers will get a raise of about $4,400, which will increase their salaries to almost $170,000.
The Baltimore Orioles blitzed Roger Clemens for four runs in the sixth inning as the Yankees lost for the seventh time in eight games on this road trip.

UBS Securities, the investment-banking division of the Swiss-based UBS, was accused by Massachusetts regulators of dishonest and unethical practices in dealings with hedge-fund advisers. The subsidiary, based in Stamford, Conn., gave hedge-fund managers below-market rent, low-interest personal loans and other benefits to retain and increase business, according to a complaint from the office of William Galvin, the secretary of the commonwealth and its top securities regulator. The complaint also accuses UBS of failing to supervise gifts and gratuities. The action, filed with the state’s Securities Division, seeks a cease-and-desist order, a censure and an undisclosed administrative fine, the statement said. Doug Morris, a UBS spokesman in New York, declined to comment.

Playboy Enterprises will open a 40,000-square-foot entertainment complex, the Playboy Mansion Macao, with dining, entertainment and retail shops, in Macao in late 2009, the chief executive, Christie Hefner, said. The complex will be part of the Macao Studio City complex, with the gambling operations run by a casino operator, Melco International Development, Ms. Hefner, left, said in an interview in Macao. Macao Studio City, a $2 billion joint venture between the Hong Kong-listed ESun Holdings and partners including Silver Point Capital, is next to the Lotus Bridge, which will link Macao and the mainland Chinese city of Zhuhai. It will include a film studio, a million-square-foot shopping mall, and gambling and convention sites.

Poland’s central bank unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate, for a second time this year, on concern that wage growth will force companies to increase prices. The Monetary Policy Council, which is led by the central bank, lifted the seven-day reference rate a quarter-point, to 4.5 percent. ”It is possible that wage pressure will continue to grow, strengthening inflation pressure,” the council said after the meeting. It said inflation might temporarily slow in the third quarter, helped by the healthy financial standing of companies and growing competition among service providers and goods producers. The inflation rate, at 2.3 percent in May, is nearing the central bank’s mid-range target rate of 2.5 percent.

Japan’s industrial production unexpectedly dropped in May for a third month, the longest losing streak in almost two years. Production fell a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent from a month earlier, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said. Slower production diminishes hopes that economic growth will accelerate, in contrast with other reports released in the last week, which said that export growth almost doubled to 15.1 percent in May and retail sales gained for the first time in eight months. The Bank of Japan’s governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said this month that the bank needed more evidence of the economy’s strength before it raises the key interest rate from 0.5 percent.
Two complaints demanded the RC2 Corporation provide medical monitoring to children who may have ingested lead paint from its products.
Mets Manager Willie Randolph said that his right shoulder had been bothersome for a while and that his doctors did not want him to wait any longer to have surgery.

Because of a transmission error, a film review yesterday about “Live Free or Die Hard” misstated the critic’s description of the plot. It should have been described as “logic-defying,” not “logic-defined.”.

A picture caption yesterday with sports articles about the top two college players expected to be selected in today’s N.B.A. draft misspelled the surname of one player. As the articles noted, he is Kevin Durant, not Durrant, of Texas. (Greg Oden of Ohio State is the other top player.).

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a Senate committee hearing on problems at the Smithsonian Institution misstated a finding of two reports on the institution last week. They said that the Smithsonian’s Board of Regents had failed to provide adequate oversight, not “inadequate” oversight. Because of another editing error, the article misstated one of the titles of Sheila P. Burke, a Smithsonian official. In addition to deputy secretary, she is chief operating officer, not chief financial officer.

An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the ability to encode information in a genome referred incorrectly to the number of bases, or letters, in the genetic code of a bacterium in which researchers wrote the E=mc2 formula. The bacterium’s genome has about 4.2 million bases, not 400 million.

A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered — not just state flags.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 2 of Huang Ju, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, the elite group of nine senior officials who rule China, misidentified the committee member responsible for presiding over reforms to the banking and financial systems. It was Mr. Huang — not Jiang Zemin, the former president with whom Mr. Huang was allied.

An article on Friday about government ratings for hospitals misstated the number of hospitals where heart patients are most and least likely to die. The report lists 41 hospitals, not 42, whose death rates are worse than the national average, and 52 hospitals, not 55, whose deaths rates are better than average. A list of the hospitals can be found at www.nytimes.com/health.

A headline and a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about the cancellation of a concert planned for Istanbul, and an effort to stimulate ticket sales for a concert in Johannesburg, misidentified the event whose organizers planned the concerts. It is Live Earth, not Live Aid.

A front-page article on Tuesday about deaths in immigration detention misstated the year that one immigrant detainee died, and the amount of time that elapsed between then and an announcement this month of a federal investigation into her death. Young Sook Kim, who was detained at a privately run center in Albuquerque, died in 2006, not in 2005; the announcement of the investigation came nearly a year after her death, not nearly two years.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the withdrawal from an initial public offering by a company that owned assets of a troubled hedge fund misidentified that fund. It is the Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies fund — not another fund with a similar name, the High-Grade Structured Credit Enhanced Strategies fund.

A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered — not just state flags.
Ashraf Marwan, a son-in-law of former President Gamal Abdel Nasser who has been named by Israeli officials as a source for Israeli intelligence, died in London.
Majzoub al-Khalifa, a powerful adviser to President Omar al-Bashir, died in a car accident in northern Sudan, a presidential source said.
European Union nations have reached a tentative deal with Washington on how American investigators can use bank transfer data provided for antiterrorism investigations.
Walter Veltroni, the popular mayor of Rome, announced that he would seek the leadership of the new Democratic Party.

Speaking at the end of his weekly general audience, Pope Benedict XVI endorsed research using so-called adult stem cells, which are isolated from tissue samples taken from adults rather than derived from human embryos, a technique the Vatican still condemns. “Scientific research must be encouraged and promoted, so long as it does not harm other human beings, whose dignity is inviolable from the very first stages of existence,” the pope said, according to the Italian news service ANSA. “Adult” stem cells can grow into a very limited range of body tissues, replenishing dying cells and regenerating damaged tissues; embryonic stem cells can grow into a wide range of body tissues.
North Korea has test-fired “several missiles,” the United States said, as United Nations nuclear inspectors prepared to visit the Yongbyon reactor.
The new president of New York City’s largest labor union has not forgotten what life is like at the bottom.
The lawsuit had claimed that the St. Barnabas Health Care System defrauded the federal government so badly that other hospitals were deprived of their fair share of Medicare reimbursement.

Researchers report that taking an antidepressant like Prozac may increase a pregnant woman’s risk of having a baby with a birth defect, but the chances appear remote and confined to a few rare defects.
Vice President Dick Cheney’s office had said that his dual role meant that he was technically not part of the executive branch.
The blog of a Bear Stearns executive offers insights into the investment bank’s response to the near collapse of two hedge funds.
Justice Antonin Scalia has lifted the curtain a bit on the differences within the court’s powerful conservative bloc.
Questions are being raised about how much control philanthropists should have over schools they support.

FIFA changed its ban on World Cup qualifying matches at high altitude yesterday, saying it would apply only to games above 9,840 feet. Citing medical concerns for players and an unfair home advantage for highland teams, FIFA last month prohibited international tournaments and World Cup qualifying matches in stadiums above 8,200 feet. The original ruling caused protests as it eliminated matches in the capitals of Bolivia, Colombia and Ecuador, and in the stadiums of teams in Peru, Chile and Mexico. The new ban applies only to World Cup qualifying matches. The ruling still prevents qualifying matches from being played in the Bolivian capital of La Paz.

The American midfielder DaMarcus Beasley transferred to Scotland’s Glasgow Rangers. Beasley, 25, who helped the United States beat Mexico last Sunday in the Concacaf Gold Cup final in Chicago, was injured for much of last season and played only 18 Premier League games for Manchester City. He was on loan to the English club from PSV Eindhoven. Beasley has 15 goals in 68 international appearances. He won two Dutch Eredivisie titles with PSV.

Natasha Hastings and Shalonda Solomon, both three-time N.C.A.A. champions at South Carolina, will give up their senior seasons of eligibility to turn professional. Hastings, from New York, emerged this year as one of the country’s top 400-meter runners. She broke the collegiate record with a time of 49.84 seconds at last week’s United States track and field championships, when she finished second to DeeDee Trotter and earned a spot on the United States team for the world championships. Solomon, from Inglewood, Calif., won the indoor and outdoor N.C.A.A. 200-meter crowns in 2006, and shared a title with the 1,600-meter relay indoor team her freshman year in 2005.

The Red Bulls acquired defender Kevin Goldthwaite from Toronto FC for Todd Dunivant. Goldthwaite played in nine games. He scored the eventual game-winning goal in Toronto FC’s first-ever victory May 12. He also had an assist in a victory over FC Dallas. Dunivant, also a defender, played in seven matches for the Red Bulls. He was acquired last June from the Los Angeles Galaxy. He had two goals and two assists in 22 games last season.
The Senate Judiciary Committee sent subpoenas to the White House, the vice president’s office and the Justice Department, setting the stage for a showdown.
soccer.
It remains to be seen how the Bancrofts — most of whom have not been told what was in the agreement — will react.

ATLANTA, June 27 (AP) — When Evander Holyfield first started boxing professionally, someone asked how long he planned to trade punches. He thought 28 sounded like a reasonable age to hang up the gloves, so he went with that.
The financial crisis that rocked Asia a decade ago is past, but in the countries most affected, a sense of loss persists.
Three moderate Democratic freshmen are complicating efforts by President Bush and Senate leaders to pass a proposed immigration measure this week.
Ladies Who Launch, a women’s network organization, sponsors meetings aimed at getting women with entrepreneurial ideas off on the right foot.
The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission recommended against additional regulation of high-speed Internet traffic.
The tournament’s youngest qualifier ever, Alexis Thompson, 12, joins a field of 24 teens at Pine Needles.
Roughly 900,000 tubes containing a poison have turned up in hospitals and prisons, according to health officials.
In his new role as envoy to the Middle East, Tony Blair will be charged with shoring up Palestinian institutions but not with trying to nail down a peace deal.
Are K Street lobbyists staging a last-ditch fight against finally disclosing their fund-raising clout with lawmakers?
A charter school operator from Los Angeles is seeking to expand into New York with the cooperation of the teachers’ union.

José López drove in Ichiro Suzuki with a double in the 11th inning that eluded a leaping Manny Ramírez at the left-field wall as the Seattle Mariners defeated the visiting Boston Red Sox yesterday, 2-1.
The reduction of a little more than 6 percent of its work force was part of a cost-cutting program designed to save $700 million by 2009.
The United States must embrace global coordination of hedge fund regulation, just as banking regulation is increasingly global.
The record rains that have saturated Texas and Oklahoma in the last two weeks have claimed at least 11 lives.
Some top prospects are a little overwhelmed after being thrown into the vortex of uncertainty, not knowing where they will start their careers and which trades they may be involved in.
The home-furnishings retailer said first-quarter profit rose after customers bought less bedding and curtains as home sales slowed.
An arrest warrant for the Iraqi culture minister continued to draw fire from some Sunni Arab leaders, and negotiations were under way to review the investigation.
Members of Congress insist that retired players should play a bigger role in making it better.

It lasted less than an hour, but a power failure that left big sections of the Upper East Side and the Bronx without electricity yesterday afternoon stirred fears that there may be more dark days ahead this summer.
Discrimination is especially deplorable in the public schools, which are supposed to uphold the values of tolerance and basic fairness.

The chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague is expected to be succeeded by the United Nations official leading the inquiry into the killing of Rafik Hariri, former prime minister of Lebanon.
Investors still appeared skittish ahead of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate decision.
The State of New York is close to enacting three new laws that would set welcome national examples for criminal justice reform.
The jury of six women and six men deliberated for about two and a half hours before recessing for the day.
The proposed legislation for changing the immigration system has brought thousands of angry messages for lawmakers.
The Army has awarded contracts to feed, fuel and house American troops, breaking the job into three deals rather than giving most of the work to one company.
Wells Fargo and its former director of research were fined for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending.
Chinese regulators closed 180 food plants after a nationwide inspection found thousands of violations of food safety rules.
The drop was the largest amount in four months as demand for aircraft, heavy machinery and metals all declined.
The former chief judge of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York helped change international bankruptcy law.
Sybille Bammer, who lost her second-round match to the unseeded Laura Granville, is the only mother among the top 100 tennis players on the Tour.

CARLOS SLIM’S EMPIRE

Forbes magazine recently named the Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim Helú the second-richest man in the world.
John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargo’s chief operating officer, has become chief executive a year and a half earlier than expected.
Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where millions live in poverty, that distinction has been drawing heat.
A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Black’s Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war.
Two Hollywood veterans announced plans to form a new independent film company with $200 million in financing secured from a consortium of private investors.

An illegal immigrant drowned in a border canal after a Border Patrol agent trying to rescue him was hit in the head with a rock thrown by a suspected human smuggler, Border Patrol officials said. The agent fired at least one shot at the suspect and another would-be immigrant, who fled back into Mexico, said an agency spokesman, Patrick Berry.
