Two teenage boys were arrested in the killing of a 17-year-old girl whose burned body was found in the desert, a sheriff said. The boys, both 16, made statements that led detectives to believe they took part in the killing of Amber L. Hess, and a search of their homes produced evidence linking them to the crime, said the Pinal County sheriff, Chris Vasquez. The suspects and Ms. Hess were acquaintances, Sheriff Vasquez said, adding that the teenagers, Nicolas Castillo and Todd Hoke, will probably be charged as adults.

The American bald eagle, a national symbol once almost wiped out by hunters and DDT poisoning, has not only survived but is thriving. The Interior Department will announce today that it is removing the bird from the protection of the Endangered Species Act, capping a four-decade struggle for recovery. Government biologists have counted nearly 10,000 mating pairs of bald eagles, including at least one pair in each of the 48 contiguous states.

Two suspected illegal immigrants died in a fiery head-on collision after the driver of a pickup fled the Border Patrol and swerved into oncoming traffic on a winding, rural road east of San Diego, the authorities said. Several people were seriously injured. The Border Patrol halted its pursuit after reaching the 55 m.p.h. speed limit, said a spokesman, Quinn Palmer.

The state’s highest criminal court refused to reinstate a dropped conspiracy charge against Tom DeLay, the Republican former House majority leader. Two charges, money laundering and conspiring to launder money, remain against the former congressman. He resigned last year amid accusations that he violated campaign finance laws to funnel $190,000 in corporate contributions to Republicans in the state’s 2002 legislative elections. The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals in Austin ruled 5 to 4 against reinstating a count of conspiracy to violate the state’s election code.
Climate change is expected to raise the repair and replacement cost of thousands of infrastructure projects as much as $6.1 billion for a total of nearly $40 billion from now to 2030, the study says.
It has been a humbling year for Bobby Abreu, a No. 3 hitter who has inexplicably tried to bunt through his struggles several times.

A judge ruled that a man serving a 10-year prison sentence for having consensual sex with a 15-year-old girl at a party when he was 17 is not eligible for bond while his habeas corpus case is being appealed. The judge, David Emerson, of Superior Court in Douglas County, ruled that Genarlow Wilson, 21, is not eligible for bail because he was convicted of aggravated child molestation, a crime that is considered one of the “seven deadly sins” under Georgia law. The ruling means that Mr. Wilson will probably spend several more months in prison.

Lawmakers approved a ban on cockfighting that will take effect next year. Louisiana is the last state to allow cockfighting. For years, state legislators resisted animal rights activists’ efforts to outlaw it, but relented this year on the condition that the prohibition take effect next year. The bill goes to Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco, who is expected to sign it into law.

The body of a pilot whose F-15 fighter jet crashed on Tuesday during a training exercise over the Pacific Ocean has been recovered by the Coast Guard, officials said. The pilot was identified as Maj. Gregory D. Young, 34, of St. Helens, Ore.

Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly warned that low starting pay was stifling recruitment efforts and making fewer officers available to participate in the crime-fighting effort known as Operation Impact.
The blaze has seemingly laid to waste that notion that all those who live on Lake Tahoe are rich and invulnerable.
Levi Leipheimer, the winner of this year’s Tour of California, will lead Lance Armstrong’s former team in the Tour de France.
Distrust of the United States has intensified across the world, but overall views of America remain favorable, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center.
A new campaign finance law passed by the City Council would crack down on lobbyists and developers — but not labor unions.
The electronic-payment processor agreed to buy a rival, the eFunds Corporation, for about $1.8 billion to bolster its debit card business.
The move to start a formal review of how the U.S. regulates financial markets and hedge funds comes amid concerns over competition from overseas trading capitals.
The outlook for changes to a comprehensive immigration bill remained in doubt as senators prepared for a vote on whether to end debate and move to final passage.
On a day of sober new promises, Gordon Brown took over from Tony Blair as prime minister, offering Britain a pledge to “try my utmost.”
The reigning champion of the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest in Coney Island is suffering an ailment, but he intends to compete.
The maker of cable for communications companies has agreed to buy the Andrew Corporation for about $2.6 billion to bolster sales to mobile phone and wireless Internet companies.
The moment when Queen Elizabeth II first greeted Gordon Brown, the new prime minister, was called Kissing Hands, but the actual kissing of hands takes place later.

Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police had failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobel’s co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, who is overseeing the case, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio was properly obtained.
Most surgeons fail to report injuries from needles and other sharp instruments, risking their health and that of their families and patients to the threat of diseases.
The electronics retailer said it would immediately start a $5.5 billion buyback program and raise its quarterly dividend nearly a third.
Ann Coulter, the conservative writer, has been the subject of pointed criticism by John Edwards and his wife, Elizabeth.
Fourth-quarter profit more than tripled at ConAgra Foods as a result of strong results from its commodities trading division.
The Guitar Center said it had agreed to be acquired by the private equity firm Bain Capital Partners for about $1.9 billion.
A patent dispute challenged Blockbuster’s entry into online DVD rental. The company also signaled that the new business was taking a toll on its finances.
Love them or hate them, the colorful garbage trucks of Yonkers are hard to miss.

Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobel’s co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. The judge overseeing the case, Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio had been properly obtained.

Three women, including the author of several financial advice books, were indicted on charges of fraud yesterday after prosecutors said they stole $1.6 million from New York area investors. The women — Carla Zimbalist, 62, of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Pam Chanla, 33, of Alhambra, Calif.; and the writer, Jennifer Wilkov, 38, of Brooklyn — were charged with fraud and securities violations, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Ms. Wilkov, whose books include “Dating Your Money, for Couples,” pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court, prosecutors said. Ms. Zimbalist was in custody in California and Ms. Chanla had not yet been arrested, prosecutors said. Mr. Morgenthau said that the three told 23 investors that Ms. Zimbalist and Ms. Chanla would use the investors’ money to renovate homes in Southern California, but that they did not actually own many of the properties and used much of the money for personal expenses.
Hamas, shrewd as it is deadly, has gone to ground in the West Bank, but it remains a powerful presence there.

A federal lawsuit filed yesterday against New Jersey claims that the State Education Department is not meeting its obligation to educate students with disabilities alongside other students. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Newark, relies on a 2004 federal law that calls for including more disabled students in general classrooms and fewer in classes reserved for students with disabilities. The plaintiffs, several groups of advocates for children including the Education Law Center and New Jersey Protection and Advocacy, contend that many school districts have failed to comply with the law and that the state has not adequately enforced it.

Three men were convicted in Federal District Court on Tuesday of charges related to the large-scale smuggling of khat, an African plant chewed as a stimulant. Prosecutors said that two of the men, Ali Awad, 43, and Abdi Emil Moge, 33, both of Minneapolis, were convicted of conspiracy to import khat, and the third, Abdullahi Hussein, 37, of Portland, Me., was convicted of conspiracy to distribute it. A fourth defendant, Abdi Nur Dahir, 32, of Minneapolis, was acquitted. The prosecutors said Mr. Awad and Mr. Moge were among the leaders of a smuggling group operating in the Horn of Africa, Western Europe and the United States. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said the group used express mail and couriers to smuggle tons of khat into this country. He said that couriers frequently carried the leaves in suitcases on commercial flights.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell has directed the State Transportation Department to restore its bridge safety inspection program, which had been scaled back to save money. The governor’s order, issued on Tuesday, came after legislators criticized a plan to inspect some bridges every four years instead of every two years. Governor Rell said the new state budget, which goes into effect July 1, creates 81 engineering inspection positions and will allow the department to return to the two-year cycle.

A judge has declined to make public a motion to dismiss murder charges against a Brooklyn man accused of beating his stepdaughter to death. The motion was submitted on Tuesday to Justice L. Priscilla Hall in State Supreme Court by lawyers for the man, Cesar Rodriguez, 28, who has been charged with killing his stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, 7, in January 2006. In court, defense lawyers said that the motion was based on improper grand jury testimony by the victim’s 11-year-old sibling. Clerks for Justice Hall have denied repeated requests by reporters and a lawyer for The New York Times to view the document. The court attorney for Justice Hall, Machelle Sweeting, said she was reviewing the motion to determine whether portions that include or refer to grand jury testimony can be disclosed publicly. Prosecutors are scheduled to respond to the motion by July 6. Ms. Sweeting said she would determine whether to release the motion “most expeditiously as possible.”.

The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the city’s building code since 1968, greatly expanding fire safety requirements, encouraging environmentally sound construction and simplifying operations at the Department of Buildings. The updated code, which is to be reviewed for possible revision every three years, was approved in a 47-to-0 vote, with one abstention, and will go into effect on July 1, 2008. It adds sprinkler requirements for smaller buildings, raises standards for smoke detectors, strengthens safety regulations for high-rise residential buildings and provides for rebates on permit fees if buildings meet higher environmental design standards and undertake more environmentally friendly practices.
Alinghi was in front from the conservative start to the well-managed finish to level this best-of-nine series at 2-2. A protest was filed after the race by Emirates Team New Zealand.

Around Pebble Beach, big driving events usually involve Titleists and oversized clubheads. Not so in August, when the Monterey peninsula, California’s golf mecca, turns its attention from pars to cars. Classic Car Week, a five-day celebration of vintage and exotic autos, held at various locations in and around Monterey, attracts car lovers from around the world. It gets rolling Aug. 16 with vintage cars making a scenic tour of the peninsula, then picks up speed with races at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, featuring historic automobiles. Along the way, there will be vintage car auctions -- Steve McQueen’s 1963 Ferrari GT250 will be among the items on the blocks -- and a splashy bash at the Quail Lodge in Carmel Valley, highlighted by Land Rover off-road test-drives and helicopter rides to catch the races at Laguna Seca. Tickets to each happening are sold separately.
At least 11 Palestinian militants and 2 civilians were killed in Gaza in the deadliest day since the militant group Hamas took control.
The company will add fewer planes to its fleet and will tweak its flight schedule as it grapples with a slowing economy and high fuel costs.
Nicole Snyder doesn't have a driver’s license, but she is in control when it comes to piloting a 7,000-horsepower jet tractor.

TOTOWA, N.J., June 27 — Five teenagers who graduated last week from Wayne Valley High School have been arrested in connection with the discovery of 16 devices with fuses in lockers at the school, forcing the evacuation of 1,400 students on the last full day of classes.
Pope Benedict XVI has signed a document that would allow more churches to adopt the old Latin Mass that largely faded from use during the 1960s.
At 29 and nearing the end of her career, the Tiawanese-American player Meilen Tu is playing her best tennis.
A Senate hearing about money and gifts that drug makers routinely provide to doctors did not go well for the drug industry Wednesday.
Heading into the N.B.A. draft, the team president Rod Thorn dismisses trade rumors involving his star-cluster of Carter, Jefferson and Kidd.
Of the 25 cities in the South and the West with populations over 500,000, all but three showed gains this decade.
Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee paid homage to Ronald Reagan, low taxes and “the sanctity of life,” while lamenting Congress’s spending habits.

Alando Tucker was the Big Ten player of the year last season. He was an all-American. Some draft analysts project him to go to the Portland Trail Blazers. Not with the first pick — as his credentials may suggest — but with the 42nd pick. The rap on him is that he is a little small to play on the perimeter and does not shoot well.

Three congregations that broke away from the Episcopal Church over the appointment of a gay bishop are not entitled to property claimed by the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles, a California appeals court has ruled.
By next year, more than half the world’s population, 3.3 billion people, will for the first time live in towns and cities, a report said.
The founder of the Adelphia cable TV company, John J. Rigas, and his son Timothy J. Rigas were ordered to report to prison on Aug. 13.
A fire at a toxic waste transfer station in North Carolina was fueled by the same type of oxygen-generating devices that ignited and brought down a jetliner in the Everglades in 1996, a report said.
What the army thinks about a political logjam, and what it decides to do, will be the defining factor in Gen. Pervez Musharraf’s future, most commentators agree.
Angry drivers set fire to at least two gas stations overnight in Tehran after the government announced that gasoline rationing would begin.
The top European regulator showed a willingness to intervene despite the overturning of past merger prohibitions in court.
Aeroflot said it was withdrawing because its advisers had not been given access to what it called critical information on Alitalia’s business.
UBS, Europe’s largest bank by assets, was accused by Massachusetts regulators of “dishonest and unethical” practices in dealings with hedge fund advisers.
New travel restrictions for U.S. citizens traveling to Canada, Mexico, Bermuda and countries in the Caribbean have resulted in a backlog of passport applications.
Enough fertile land could turn into desert in the next generation to create an “environmental crisis of global proportions.”
The Department of Defense has identified 3,560 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Let undrafted basketball players go back to college.
David Cay Johnston of The Times business desk looks at the practice (often foolish) of using public subsidies for private sports ventures. Also, sailing camps that get right to the tough stuff.

Things are not exactly in a groove for Mark Johnson, the happy-go-lucky Champions Tour player known as “Beerman.” He has played unevenly, often plagued by a string of bogeys during rounds that raise his anxiety level and take him out of contention. If he doesn’t turn around his game, he risks losing easy entry into tournaments in 2008.

At least a couple of N.B.A. teams hope their pick tonight carries the franchise to a championship. Play general manager: : How would you build a winning team, by focusing on the draft or on trades and free agency?.

Last weekend, Ken Griffey Jr. played in Seattle for the first time as a Cincinnati Red, receiving a rousing reception and then delighting the fans with two home runs on Sunday. A spate of injuries in recent years sidetracked him, but this 1994 profile of Griffey reminds us that in the mid-90s, the question was when, not if, he would break baseball’s home run records (while wearing his trademark grin). From PLAY’s suggested reading list:.

An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Tony Blair, misstated the circumstances of Prime Minister Clement Attlee’s ouster from office. His party did not lose control of Parliament in the 1950 election; it held on until a second election, in 1951. The article also misspelled the prime minister’s surname. It was Attlee, not Atlee.
A Russian man who had been captured by American forces in Afghanistan and released from Guantánamo Bay was killed in a police raid.
New York festival chooses opening-night film, Asturias prize for Amos Oz, Pearl Buck manuscript resurfaces after decades and more culture news.
Meilen Tu’s playing career is peaking at age 29, making her one of the oldest players in the Wimbledon draw.
Real Army wives are among an average of 3.6 million people who have made “Army Wives” the highest-rated series in Lifetime’s 23-year history.
The covert campaign targeting street art began about seven months ago, with blobs of paint that appeared overnight, obscuring murals and wheat-pasted art on walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan.

The idiosyncratic world of Serb film director Emir Kusturica has been brought to the stage of the Bastille Opera in Paris in “Le Temps des Gitans,” or “Time of the Gypsies.”
The Jacob’s Pillow dance festival in Becket, Mass., has begun its 75th anniversary celebration.
Frederick Ashton’s work, which the Paris Opera Ballet is performing for the first time, is as capable of delighting audiences now as it must have been at its premiere in 1960.

In Peter Cooper’s Village in New York, one apartment stands out for its stained-glass windows, its wall of vines and its spiral staircase to nowhere.

MOST people love sitting in the sun, but they also know the dangers of too much exposure (and leathery, wrinkled skin is the least of them). There are all types of umbrellas, pavilions and tents to provide the necessary shade. Some are portable and sized for an individual; others will cover a crowd.
The NASD said Wednesday that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending.
Dressing the hedge fund man in clothes that are youthful, carefree and reveling  in giddy excess.
The Charlie Parker tribute being held this week at Birdland traffics in nostalgia even as it revels in new talent.
Dmitri Young is making $500,000 this season, a fraction of the multimillion-dollar deals he once had, but he has still surpassed his highest hopes.

An article last week about dog owners who hire runners to exercise their pets misstated the surname of an owner in one reference and misstated the age of a runner. As noted elsewhere in the article, the dog owner is Richard Shein, not Stein, and Roy Scranton is 30, not 26.
In an uptempo song near the end of Cesária Évora’s set on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, her saxophonist, Totinho, swaggered toward her with arms outstretched, as if inviting her to dance.

WECHSLER--Sylvia, 87, died on June 25, 2007. Beloved wife of Stanley, beloved mother of Rabbi Harlan J., Richard L. and Barry A., grandmother and great-grandmother, dear sister. Funeral services Wednesday, June 27, 2007 at 12 noon at Menorah Gardens Chapel, West Palm Beach.

Poor landlines -- they never get to have any fun. Cellphones have wallpaper, cool cases and ring tones, while regular phones are stuck with nothing but a dial tone. Luckily, there's the Ringboxx, a way to add the latest tunes to old phones. To use the Ringboxx, you go online, pay about $3 to download a song or comedy clip, assign it to a specific number and transfer the audio to the device with a U.S.B. cable.

Just down the street from the ''Speakers Corner'' video booth in Toronto (where passers-by record themselves for broadcast on public television), the housewares manufacturer Umbra has opened its first concept store. Conceived as a place to engage the public on design -- the company plans to hold lectures and exhibits there -- the 7,000-square-foot building, right, was created by local firms Kohn Shnier Architects and Figure 3 (which did the sleek white interiors, above). The store will carry both the mainstream Umbra line and the higher-end U+ collection of limited-edition art objects, like the newest version of the Strass Stool ($300) by Michelle Ivankovic, top right, a functional steel seat with dripped-on polyurethane and silicone. Umbra Concept Store, 165 John Street, Toronto, (416) 599-0088 or umbra.com. LAURIE MANFRA

The New York auditions on ''America's Got Talent'' led NBC to its fourth consecutive Tuesday-night win in the ratings, as 11.4 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour competition, according to Nielsen estimates, dominating its competition from 8 to 10. After the show, which features Jerry Springer as host, a repeat of NBC's ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' carried the 10 o'clock hour as well (8.7 million). Although CBS posted a second-place finish in total viewers for the night with its lineup of ''NCIS'' at 8 (8.4 million), ''The Unit'' at 9 (5.5 million) and ''48 Hours Mystery'' at 10 (6.3 million), ABC and Fox finished ahead of CBS among adults 18 to 49. However, ABC and Fox had ratings setbacks of their own. The premiere of ABC's reality show withShaquille O'Neal, ''Shaq's Big Challenge,'' attracted a disappointing 4.4 million viewers in fourth place in the 9 o'clock hour, while Fox's ''On the Lot'' delivered just 2.3 million at 8.

GORDON--Kenny, on your 35th Birthday. Not a day goes by for us without memories bringing smiles to our faces or tears to our eyes. You are missed every minute of everyday. Our aching hearts are always filled with love for you. Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine and Kenya
HADDAD--Adele. My dear friend and sister-in-law Adele. You are now next to your darling Abe. Rest in peace. I will think about you always. -Freda

A headline and a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column yesterday about the cancellation of a concert planned for Istanbul, and an effort to stimulate ticket sales for a concert in Johannesburg, misidentified the event whose organizers planned the concerts. It is Live Earth, not Live Aid.

MANNIX--Helen M. (nee McGratty) formerly of Brooklyn, NY, beloved wife of Francis X. (deceased), died peacefully on June 25 in Greenwich, CT. Loving mother of Mary Ellen Yeomans, Judy Mannix, RGS, and Margot Friedlander, sons-in-law Wayne Yeomans and Michael Friedlander and cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Curt, Kelly and Katy. Visiting at Leo P. Gallagher on Friday, Mass Saturday at St. Mary Parish, Greenwich.

An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the ability to encode information in a genome referred incorrectly to the number of bases, or letters, in the genetic code of a bacterium in which researchers wrote the E=mc2 formula. The bacterium's genome has about 4.2 million bases, not 400 million.

Tom Sizemore's 16-month prison sentence for violating probation in a drug case has been reduced by a judge in Los Angeles, who credited him with 213 days already spent in jail and time spent in drug programs. Deputy District Attorney Sean Carney said Mr. Sizemore would probably serve about half of the nine months remaining. Mr. Sizemore, who appeared in ''Saving Private Ryan'' and ''Black Hawk Down,'' also faces drug charges in connection with an arrest last month in Bakersfield, Calif.

In his new role as envoy to the Middle East, Tony Blair will be charged with shoring up Palestinian institutions, but not with trying to nail down a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians because Condoleezza Rice, the secretary of state, is handling that job herself, administration officials said Wednesday. Ms. Rice has said several times that she intends to spend her remaining months in office trying to push peace talks forward.

QUINSON--Suzanne RichardJaricot born June 24, 1907 in Vourles, France died at home in Larchmont, NY on June 26, 2007. She is survived by her four sons Francois, JeanPaul, Bruno and Luc, 10 grandchildren and 13 greatgrandchildren. Visitation Wednesday, 2-4pm and 79pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home. Funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont at 10am, Thursday, June 28, 2007. Interment at Tyringham Cemetery, MA. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering or Catholic Charities.

For those who want to jump on the eclecticism trend, good ideas can be found this month at the Conran Shop, best known for its modern European and American furniture and accessories. A stash of vintage South African pieces has just arrived and is being displayed alongside the contemporary furniture. The carved-wood sea tortoise ($390) and the diminutive painted stools ($195 each), above, are just a few of the goods. There are also wood bowls ($195) and life-size, carved-wood crocodiles ($1,250) that could peek out from behind a sofa or chair. The Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (866) 755-9079. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

RAND--Rita. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Rita Rand. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family. Harvey L. York, President Robert Fagenson, Secretary

HARRIS--John Albert, April 21, 2007 of New York City, partner of Andy Anselmo. There will be a celebration of life on Saturday, June 30, 2007 at 11:00am at The Marble Collegiate Church on 5th Avenue. Donations to Singers Forum, 48 West 24th Street, New York, New York 10011 of which John was the executive director.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the withdrawal from an initial public offering by a company that owned assets of a troubled hedge fund misidentified that fund. It is the Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies fund -- not another fund with a similar name, the High-Grade Structured Credit Enhanced Strategies fund.

The Army announced yesterday that it had awarded contracts to feed, fuel and house American troops in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, breaking the job into three $5 billion deals to separate companies rather than just one. Since 2001, that dominant contractor had been KBR, formerly Kellogg Brown & Root, the Houston-based concern that used to be a division of the Halliburton Company. In recent years, KBR has been mired in billing disputes over its performance in Iraq, and some members of Congress have accused it of defrauding the government.

The White House has dropped the argument that Vice President Dick Cheney's dual role as president of the Senate meant that he could deny access to national archivists who oversee the handling of classified data in the executive branch. Mr. Cheney's office had said that his dual role meant that he was technically not part of the executive branch.

Three women, one of them the author of several financial advice books, were indicted on charges of fraud yesterday after prosecutors said they stole $1.6 million from New York area investors. The women -- Carla Zimbalist, 62, of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Pam Chanla, 33, of Alhambra, Calif.; and the writer, Jennifer Wilkov, 38, of Brooklyn -- were charged with fraud and securities violations, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Ms. Wilkov, whose books include ''Dating Your Money, for Couples,'' pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court, prosecutors said. Ms. Zimbalist was in custody in California and Ms. Chanla had not yet been arrested, prosecutors said. Mr. Morgenthau said that the three told 23 investors the money would be used to renovate homes in Southern California, but that they did not actually own many of the properties and used much of the money for personal expenses.

An article last week about dog owners who hire runners to exercise their pets misstated the surname of an owner in one reference and misstated the age of a runner. As noted elsewhere in the article, the dog owner is Richard Shein, not Stein, and Roy Scranton is 30, not 26.

Three women, including the author of several financial advice books, were indicted on charges of fraud yesterday after prosecutors said they stole $1.6 million from New York area investors. The women -- Carla Zimbalist, 62, of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Pam Chanla, 33, of Alhambra, Calif.; and the writer, Jennifer Wilkov, 38, of Brooklyn -- were charged with fraud and securities violations, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Ms. Wilkov, whose books include ''Dating Your Money, for Couples,'' pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court, prosecutors said. Ms. Zimbalist was in custody in California and Ms. Chanla had not yet been arrested, prosecutors said. It's unacceptable. It is stonewalling of the worst kind. SENATOR PATRICK J. LEAHY,

The Israeli author Amos Oz, below, was named the winner yesterday of the $65,000 2007 Prince of Asturias award for literature, given by the Prince of Asturias Foundation and named for its patron, Crown Prince Felipe of Asturias, heir to the Spanish throne, Agence France-Presse reported. The jury said that Mr. Oz had ''fashioned the Hebrew language into a brilliant instrument for literary art and the truthful disclosure of the most dire and universal realities of our time, focusing especially on advocating peace amongst peoples and condemning all forms of fanaticism.'' His books include ''Where the Jackals Howl and Other Stories'' and ''My Michael.'' Previous winners include Mario Vargas Llosa, Günter Grass, Doris Lessing, Arthur Millerand Paul Auster. ... The Mexican writer Elena Poniatowska has been awarded the Rómulo Gallegos prize for literature for her novel ''El Tren Pasa Primero'' (''The Train Passes First''), The Associated Press reported from Caracas, Venezuela. The book tells of a railroad worker who engages in the struggle for labor rights in Mexico. The prize, awarded every two years for what is deemed to be the best Spanish-language novel, was created in 1967 and named for the Venezuelan novelist and former President Rómulo Gallegos.

EVERYONE loves a free ride, which explains why there are so many gratis sports gatherings during the summertime. Some events in or near Manhattan are well known, such as the Downtown Boathouse's free access to kayaks and Niketown's group training runs in Central Park. We scoured the city to cull this insider's list of 10 lesser-known free (or nearly free) sports happenings. Each regular get-together has added value that puts it over the top compared with similar free events, whether it's sag wagon support on a 50-mile bike ride or a volleyball court complete with scorekeepers and balls for riverside play. Not to mention that many of the gatherings have regulars whose enthusiasm makes them a riot to row, run and skate with.

FOOD SAFETY CRACKDOWN IN CHINA After weeks of insisting that food in China is largely safe, regulators there said that they had recently closed 180 plants and that inspectors had uncovered more than 23,000 food safety violations. REGULATOR BLOCKS AIRLINE MERGER The top European regulator blocked a bid by the low-cost airline Ryanair to buy Aer Lingus, Ireland's national carrier. The rejection of the deal prompted a robust reaction and the promise of a legal challenge from Ryanair's outspoken chief executive, Michael O'Leary, above. [C3.]

Playboy Enterprises will open a 40,000-square-foot entertainment complex, the Playboy Mansion Macao, with dining, entertainment and retail shops, in Macao in late 2009, the chief executive, Christie Hefner, said. The complex will be part of the Macao Studio City complex, with the gambling operations run by a casino operator, Melco International Development, Ms. Hefner, left, said in an interview in Macao. Macao Studio City, a $2 billion joint venture between the Hong Kong-listed ESun Holdings and partners including Silver Point Capital, is next to the Lotus Bridge, which will link Macao and the mainland Chinese city of Zhuhai. It will include a film studio, a million-square-foot shopping mall, and gambling and convention sites.

''The Darjeeling Limited'' will open the 45th New York Film Festival on Sept. 28 at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center. A comedy directed by Wes Anderson, it stars Owen Wilson, Adrien Brody and Jason Schwartzman and features Anjelica Huston in a story of three brothers re-establishing family bonds during a train ride across India. The centerpiece of the festival, which ends on Oct. 14, will be ''No Country for Old Men,'' directed by Joel and Ethan Coen. Based on a novel by the Pulitzer Prize-winner Cormac McCarthy, the film, starring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, Josh Brolin, Woody Harrelson and Kelly Macdonald, is a thriller about the repercussions of a hunter's discovery of dead bodies, a major heroin stash and $2 million in cash. Also to be seen at the festival are ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,'' the Cristian Mungiu film that won the Palme d'Or at Cannes in May, and Lee Chang-dong's ''Secret Sunshine,'' starring Jeon Do-yeon, who won best actress at Cannes.

Speaking at the end of his weekly general audience, Pope Benedict XVI endorsed research using so-called adult stem cells, which are isolated from tissue samples taken from adults rather than derived from human embryos, a technique the Vatican still condemns. ''Scientific research must be encouraged and promoted, so long as it does not harm other human beings, whose dignity is inviolable from the very first stages of existence,'' the pope said, according to the Italian news service ANSA. ''Adult'' stem cells can grow into a very limited range of body tissues, replenishing dying cells and regenerating damaged tissues; embryonic stem cells can grow into a wide range of body tissues.

''Transparency and Reflection,'' an exhibition of work by Junichi Arai, a 75-year-old textile designer based in Kiryu, Japan, opened Tuesday at Gallery Gen in SoHo. On display are 50 pieces of clothing and 200 fabrics, including some of Mr. Arai's newest designs, which could be used as curtains or room dividers. Sun X Sun, top right, a 4 1/2-by-10-foot, painted, twisted swath of polyester, is a collaboration with Yoshiaki Yuki, a Tokyo artist ($1,300). Golden River, center, a semitransparent, flame-resistant fabric made of gold polyphenylene sulfide, measures 4 1/2 by 19 feet ($3,800). Crocodile, bottom, a blend of polyphenylene sulfide and wool, measures 2 * by 13 feet ($2,800). Through July 28 at Gallery Gen, 158 Franklin Street, (212) 226-7717 or gallerygen.com. ELAINE LOUIE

ALTMAN--David. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed Trustee and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

Back in the summer of 2005 it was no fun being Norman Pearlstine. As editor in chief of Time Inc., he had been battling Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the tenacious special prosecutor investigating the Valerie Wilson case. Mr. Fitzgerald had issued subpoenas to a number of Washington journalists, among them the Time magazine reporter Matthew Cooper, seeking information about their contacts with administration officials who might have been involved in leaking Ms. Wilson's identity as an undercover intelligence agent. When they refused to comply, both Mr. Cooper and Time Inc. were held in contempt. Mr. Pearlstine took the case all the way to the Supreme Court, which early that summer declined to review it. Having thus exhausted all legal remedies, he faced a stark choice: He could continue resisting -- meaning jail time for Mr. Cooper and costly fines for Time Inc. -- or wave the white flag.

TONIGHT will be the first National Basketball Association draft in the era of ''one and done.'' Draft eligibility now begins at age 19, so most high school graduates have to attend college for a year or sit out a year before turning pro. All the focus seems to be on the two most coveted former freshmen, Kevin Durant of the University of Texas and Greg Oden of Ohio State, and how the teams that draft them will fare as a result.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a Senate committee hearing on problems at the Smithsonian Institution misstated a finding of two reports on the institution last week. They said that the Smithsonian's Board of Regents had failed to provide adequate oversight, not ''inadequate'' oversight. Because of another editing error, the article misstated one of the titles of Sheila P. Burke, a Smithsonian official. In addition to deputy secretary, she is chief operating officer, not chief financial officer.

WEBER--Beverly A., of New York City passed away on June 23, 2007 at the age of 76. Survived by her beloved sister, Dorothy Johnson of Fair Lawn, NJ, nephew, Kenneth E. Johnson, his wife Phyllis, their daughter, Kim, son, Chris, and two grandchildren. Beverly grew up in West Englewood, NJ and graduated from Teaneck High School. She began her career in the market research field as a supervisor with Daniel Starch & Staff in Mamaroneck, NY. She then spent over twenty years with Bristol-Myers Squibb. In her capacity as Market Research Manager, Beverly traveled extensively to Europe, South America, South Africa and Japan. She later worked as a management consultant conducting marketing and organization development projects. Beverly was a summa cum laude graduate of Fordham University with a degree in Social Science. She was a MENSA member who excelled in problem solving. This year marked Beverly's election as a Half Century member of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. The family will receive friends from 2-5pm on Thursday, June 28th at the Vander Plaat Colonial Funeral Home, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410. A funeral service will be held on Friday, June 29th at 11am at the funeral home. Pastor Peter Hoytema of the Midland Park Christian Reformed Church will officiate, followed by interment in the George Washington Memorial Park in Paramus, NJ. A memorial service will be held in the New York City area at a future time and place to be announced. Contributions in Beverly's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 and to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

A judge ruled that a man serving a 10-year prison sentence for having consensual sex with a 15-year-old girl at a party when he was 17 is not eligible for bond while his habeas corpus case is being appealed. The judge, David Emerson, of Superior Court in Douglas County, ruled that Genarlow Wilson, 21, is not eligible for bail because he was convicted of aggravated child molestation, a crime that is considered one of the ''seven deadly sins'' under Georgia law. The ruling means that Mr. Wilson will probably spend several more months in prison.

HUGHES--David H. November 8, 1918-June 18, 2007. Former Skidmore, Owings and Merrill partner David H. Hughes died on June 18, 2007 in Tucson, Arizona. The cause of death was heart failure. His almost 30 year career with the noted architectural firm began in 1948. He was involved in many projects in the U.S. as well as in Germany, South Africa and France. He retired from SOM in 1975 after establishing a Paris office for the firm. David Huey Hughes was born November 8, 1918, the son of David Ashford Hughes and Anne Wright Hughes. He grew up in Santa Fe, New Mexico and graduated from the Los Alamos Ranch School and from Yale University, class of 1941. The following year he married Ruth Noel Hurley, the daughter of Patrick J. Hurley and Ruth Wilson Hurley. During World War II he served as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force, Squadron 394. He then earned a degree in architecture from Yale before joining Skidmore Owings and Merrill. He was a member of the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, and served on the boards of several schools and clubs in Greenwich, CT. After he retired, he and Ruth divided their time between New York and Santa Fe before moving to Tucson in 1999. His wife Ruth died in 2000. He is survived by his eight children, David Hughes of Chicago, Anne Hughes Kieve of San Francisco, Cecily Hughes of Telluride, CO, Ruth Hughes of The Plains, VA, Ian Hughes of Fairfield, CT, and Wilson, Peter and Graeme Hughes of Tucson, as well as 13 grandchildren.

What do Americans do for sports in the spring? I asked this question, somewhat facetiously, when it worked out that I wouldn't go overseas this year. Normally I am running around the Tour de France, soccer's World Cup or Wimbledon, but this time around I am saving my travel for domestic stories involving blokes named Beckham and Bonds.

An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about presidential elections involving candidates from the same state, inaccurately described the circumstances involving the selection of Warren Harding as the Republican nominee in 1920. Harding's nomination was not a direct response to the Democrats' selection of another Ohioan, James Cox; Cox was a compromise nominee who was not chosen until after Harding's nomination. The article also misstated the title of Alton Parker, the Democratic nominee in 1904. He was the chief judge of New York, not the chief justice.

CRESCENZO--Andrew ''Mr. C'' devoted husband to Mary, loving father to our dear friends Rick and Cynthia, mentoring grandfather to Gavin and Brad. Our sincere condolences to the entire Crescenzo family who have been our extended family. His love of family and community is a legacy he passes on to his family and all who knew him. Glenn and Lisa Edwards and family

The Canadian postal service, Canada Post, will issue four stamps tomorrow to honor the musicians Gordon Lightfoot, Joni Mitchell, Anne Murray and Paul Anka, whose careers put Canada on the musical map and encouraged other Canadian musicians. Canada, unlike the United States, does not shy away from issuing stamps depicting living people. Mr. Lightfoot last released an album in 2004, and Mr. Anka in 2005, while Ms. Mitchell and Ms. Murray plan albums of new recordings this fall. The stamps, below, are being issued in round sheets of four, resembling a CD.

Walter Veltroni, left, the popular mayor of Rome, announced that he would seek the leadership of the new Democratic Party, to be formed in the fall by merging the centrist Christian Democrats and the former communist Democrats of the Left, two main parties in the governing center-left coalition of Prime Minister Romano Prodi. The widely expected announcement officially makes the 51-year old Mr. Veltroni, a former Communist, the new leading figure of Italian center-left politics and a possible future candidate for prime minister.

An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Tony Blair, misstated the circumstances of Prime Minister Clement Attlee's ouster from office. His party did not lose control of Parliament in the 1950 election; it held on until a second election, in 1951. The article also misspelled the prime minister's surname. It was Attlee, not Atlee. In addition, the biographical note with the article misstated the subtitle of the writer's book. It is ''The Angry Island: Hunting the English,'' not ''Hunting the British.''
To the Editor: Re ''On Fringe of Forests, Homes and Wildfires Meet'' (front page, June 26):

The top international video-game circuit, the World Cyber Games, plans to announce today an agreement with MTV Networks that includes televising the tournament's finals on MTV's Spike network in the fall. The league also plans to provide additional programming for Spike's weekly ''Game Head'' series and for MTV Web sites, including GameTrailers.com and Xfire.com. The deal comes as various gaming, or e-sports, leagues have been trying to figure out how to attract viewers on television in North America. In South Korea, by contrast, at least three satellite networks are devoted to gaming full-time.

Three men were convicted in Federal District Court on Tuesday of charges related to the large-scale smuggling of khat, an African plant chewed as a stimulant. Prosecutors said that two of the men, Ali Awad, 43, and Abdi Emil Moge, 33, both of Minneapolis, were convicted of conspiracy to import khat, and the third, Abdullahi Hussein, 37, of Portland, Me., was convicted of conspiracy to distribute it. A fourth defendant, Abdi Nur Dahir, 32, of Minneapolis, was acquitted. The prosecutors said Mr. Awad and Mr. Moge were among the leaders of a smuggling group operating in the Horn of Africa, Western Europe and the United States. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said the group used express mail and couriers to smuggle tons of khat into this country. He said that couriers frequently carried the leaves in suitcases on commercial flights.
To the Editor: ''In Aiding Poor, Edwards Built Bridge to 2008'' (front page, June 22) proves the cynical saying ''no good deed goes unpunished.''

The Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday issued subpoenas to the White House, Vice President Dick Cheney's office and the Justice Department after what the panel's chairman called ''stonewalling of the worst kind'' of efforts to investigate the National Security Agency's policy of wiretapping without warrants. The move put Senate Democrats squarely on a course they had until now avoided, setting the stage for a showdown with the Bush administration over one of the most contentious issues arising from the White House's campaign against terrorism.

To the Editor: David Brooks (''When Preaching Flops,'' column, June 22) understands the research on the failure of abstinence-only sex education: preaching traditional morality to students doesn't change behavior. But he generalizes that sex education doesn't work.

The chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Carla Del Ponte, is expected to be succeeded by the United Nations official leading the inquiry into the killing in 2005 of Rafik Hariri, former prime minister of Lebanon, United Nations officials in The Hague and in New York said Wednesday. The United Nations official, Serge Brammertz, a well-known Belgian criminologist who has led the Hariri inquiry, has been invited to take up the prosecutor's post at the United Nations tribunal in The Hague in December when his mandate in Lebanon expires, the officials said. Mr. Brammertz, seen as the strongest candidate for the job, has accepted, the officials said. He could not be reached immediately for comment.

At first glance, La Purificadora, a new hotel in Puebla, 90 miles southeast of Mexico City, doesn't look like it was designed by Ricardo Legorreta. For one thing, the colors are neutral (there's some purple, but only in the furniture). ''Imagine, we're this young hotel company, putting conditions on the most important living architect in Mexico,'' said Rafael Micha, managing partner of Grupo Habita, the company that operates the hotel and insisted that the architect tone down his color palette. ''At first he was a bit hesitant.'' But Mr. Legorreta, near left, now in partnership with his son, Victor, far left, finally agreed to turn the 1884 water purification factory into a 26-room hotel. ''When you work around a historical building you do a lot of things you would never accept in a new structure,'' said the younger Legorreta. The architects couldn't touch the facade, and preserved the original walls in the lobby, above right. The result: spaces like the firepit, above left, and pool, top right, that nod to modernism but remain true to the 19th century. Information: www.lapurificadora.com. RIMA SUQI

A front-page article on Tuesday about deaths in immigration detention misstated the year that one immigrant detainee died, and the amount of time that elapsed between then and an announcement this month of a federal investigation into her death. Young Sook Kim, who was detained at a privately run center in Albuquerque, died in 2006, not in 2005; the announcement of the investigation came nearly a year after her death, not nearly two years.

An article on Friday about government ratings for hospitals misstated the number of hospitals where heart patients are most and least likely to die. The report lists 41 hospitals, not 42, whose death rates are worse than the national average, and 52 hospitals, not 55, whose deaths rates are better than average. A list of the hospitals can be found at www.nytimes.com/health.
Manhattan FINANCIAL DISTRICT $511,750

Prvic Luka, Croatia was among the areas benefiting yesterday from a storm system that took a notch off the heat wave rolling through southeastern Europe. Other nations in the region were less fortunate: temperatures reached 111 degrees in Athens and Agros, Greece, and two deaths were reported in Bulgaria and Cyprus, The Associated Press reported. The A.P. also said that the heat killed 42 people in Italy and the Balkan last week.

Poland's central bank unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate, for a second time this year, on concern that wage growth will force companies to increase prices. The Monetary Policy Council, which is led by the central bank, lifted the seven-day reference rate a quarter-point, to 4.5 percent. ''It is possible that wage pressure will continue to grow, strengthening inflation pressure,'' the council said after the meeting. It said inflation might temporarily slow in the third quarter, helped by the healthy financial standing of companies and growing competition among service providers and goods producers. The inflation rate, at 2.3 percent in May, is nearing the central bank's mid-range target rate of 2.5 percent.
To the Editor: Re ''Three Bad Rulings'' (editorial, June 26):

Corrections Appended AS much as I like the word ''cheap'' and its variations -- cheap-jack, cheapskate, el cheapo and the effervescent cheap and cheerful -- I seem to have a hard time actually getting the word into a fashion article. ''Use 'inexpensive,' '' I'm told.

Leashore--Bogart. The Hunter School of Social Work mourns the passing of our former colleague and Dean, Bogart Leashore, who served admirably in that capacity from 1991-2003. His devoted service, commitment to social justice, and expertise in child welfare practice will be much remembered by his peers and students. Jacqueline Mondros, Dean and faculty, staff, alumni of the Hunter School of Social Work Leashore--Bogart. The Hunter College community is saddened by the untimely loss of our colleague and former dean of the School of Social Work. A noted professional Bogart led the school for 12 years and was committed to its values of public education and the practice of social work. His legacy and leadership will be fondly remembered. Jennifer J. Raab, President Hunter College

UBS Securities, the investment-banking division of the Swiss-based UBS, was accused by Massachusetts regulators of dishonest and unethical practices in dealings with hedge-fund advisers. The subsidiary, based in Stamford, Conn., gave hedge-fund managers below-market rent, low-interest personal loans and other benefits to retain and increase business, according to a complaint from the office of William Galvin, the secretary of the commonwealth and its top securities regulator. The complaint also accuses UBS of failing to supervise gifts and gratuities. The action, filed with the state's Securities Division, seeks a cease-and-desist order, a censure and an undisclosed administrative fine, the statement said. Doug Morris, a UBS spokesman in New York, declined to comment.

Continuing its push into entertainment, the Starbucks coffee company will put its promotional muscle behind ''Arctic Tale,'' an environmentally themed documentary set for release on July 25 by Paramount Classics and National Geographic Films. National Geographic brought the French-made ''March of the Penguins'' to the United States, while Paramount Classics distributed the global-warming documentary ''An Inconvenient Truth.'' ''Arctic Tale'' follows a walrus family and a polar bear family. Starbucks recently released Paul McCartney's CD ''Memory Almost Full'' in a venture with the Concord Music Group, and has been looking for movie ventures with help from the William Morris Agency. Starbucks said it planned to organize a ''National Day of Discussion'' about climate change in connection with ''Arctic Tale'' and will invite environmental groups to store events.

PERLO--Margery Boochever, ninety-three, of Sugar Hill, New Hampshire, Beeston Hill, St. Croix, and New York City, died on June 14, 2007. She was the devoted wife of Sidney Perlo, mother of Bruce S. Perlo, Susan P. Magee, and Virginia P. Budney, grandmother of six, great-grandmother of five, and great-great-grandmother of three. A graduate of the Parsons School of Design, and having studied in Paris, she exercised her artistic talents as an interior designer, pianist, and painter. Friends and family were the focus of her life. The memory of her zest for living, positive attitude, boundless energy, common sense, and dignity are her legacy. A memorial gathering will be held at her home in Sugar Hill on August 25, 2007, at 3:30pm. Donations may be made in her memory to the Norris Cotton Cancer Center, 7920 One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, New Hampshire 03756.

North Korea has test-fired ''several missiles,'' the United States said, as United Nations nuclear inspectors prepared to visit the Yongbyon reactor today, which North Korea has promised to shut down. ''The United States is deeply troubled that North Korea has decided to launch these missiles during a delicate time in the six-party talks,'' said Gordon D. Johndroe, a spokesman for the National Security Council. He added that the United States expected North Korea ''to refrain from conducting further provocative ballistic missile launches.'' But a Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Chito Peppler of the Navy, played down the launchings and said they were short-range missiles. ''We believe that this was a routine exercise,'' he said.

Never mind Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Some days, it seems as if the presidential campaign of John Edwards considers his main rival to be Ann Coulter, the conservative writer. Ms. Coulter has steadily targeted Mr. Edwards and other Democratic presidential candidates as she has toured the country promoting a book. And over the last two days, she has been the subject of pointed criticism by Mr. Edwards and his wife, Elizabeth, who called in to a talk show where Ms. Coulter was appearing to ask her ''politely to stop personal attacks.''

A picture caption yesterday with sports articles about the top two college players expected to be selected in today's N.B.A. draft misspelled the surname of one player. As the articles noted, he is Kevin Durant, not Durrant, of Texas. (Greg Oden of Ohio State is the other top player.)

A judge has declined to make public a motion to dismiss murder charges against a Brooklyn man accused of beating his stepdaughter to death. The motion was submitted on Tuesday to Justice L. Priscilla Hall in State Supreme Court by lawyers for the man, Cesar Rodriguez, 28, who has been charged with killing his stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, 7, in January 2006. In court, defense lawyers said that the motion was based on improper grand jury testimony by the victim's 11-year-old sibling. Clerks for Justice Hall have denied repeated requests by reporters and a lawyer for The New York Times to view the document. The court attorney for Justice Hall, Machelle Sweeting, said she was reviewing the motion to determine whether portions that include or refer to grand jury testimony can be disclosed publicly. Prosecutors are scheduled to respond to the motion by July 6. Ms. Sweeting said she would determine whether to release the motion ''most expeditiously as possible.''

WHEN Eric Petit wants to watch a movie on his PlayStation Portable, he pops a DVD into his computer and fires up HandBrake, a program he wrote for converting digital video files to fit onto his pocket-size game player. In a few minutes, the movie is resized to fit on the smaller screen where it can be watched without the plastic disc. HandBrake is just one of a number of popular tools that convert video files into a different format. Format conversions are becoming more common for people who want to watch movies through some means other than the television anchored in the living room. Anyone who wants to watch a show on a cellphone, a game machine or a portable media player like the Archos must become familiar with the alphabet soup of different formats and the software that manages them.

Two years ago Bon Jovi, the pop-metal supergroup from New Jersey, took a gamble by leaning toward the country market with its song ''Who Says You Can't Go Home?,'' featuring Jennifer Nettles of the band Sugarland. It paid off. The song was a country No. 1, and this week Bon Jovi has its first No. 1 album in 19 years with its country-tinged new ''Lost Highway'' (Island Mercury Nashville), which sold 288,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. This week's next two top sellers are also new. The White Stripes' ''Icky Thump'' (Warner Brothers) reached No. 2 with 223,000 sales, and Brad Paisley's ''5th Gear'' (Arista Nashville) opened at No. 3 with 197,000. Last week's No. 1, Toby Keith's ''Big Dog Daddy'' (Show Dog Nashville), fell three spots, and the rest of the Top 10 is a reshuffling of recent hits: Paul McCartney (No. 5), Linkin Park (No. 6), Amy Winehouse (No. 7), Maroon 5 (No. 8), Fabolous (No. 9) and T-Pain (No. 10).

Japan's industrial production unexpectedly dropped in May for a third month, the longest losing streak in almost two years. Production fell a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent from a month earlier, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said. Slower production diminishes hopes that economic growth will accelerate, in contrast with other reports released in the last week, which said that export growth almost doubled to 15.1 percent in May and retail sales gained for the first time in eight months. The Bank of Japan's governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said this month that the bank needed more evidence of the economy's strength before it raises the key interest rate from 0.5 percent.

Sales of alcohol on the trains and at the stations of the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Railroad will continue. As expected, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority declined yesterday to act on a proposal to ban alcoholic beverages on the commuter lines. A board committee that studied the issue said it could not find a correlation between alcohol sales and accidents or arrests involving drunken commuters. The authority's chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, said the board would not take any action on the proposal, made last year by Mitchell H. Pally, a board member from Long Island. Mr. Pally said he would continue to press for a ban. ''It is as if we were giving people a license to drink and drive, and that is unacceptable,'' he said. The railroads sell beer, wine and hard liquor in some trains and stations.

Alando Tucker was the Big Ten player of the year last season. He was an all-American. Some draft analysts project him to go to the Portland Trail Blazers. Not with the first pick -- as his credentials may suggest -- but with the 42nd pick. The rap on him is that he is a little small to play on the perimeter and does not shoot well. Thus, one of the top five players in college basketball seems likely to slip to the second round of the N.B.A. draft.

The IonFlow 50, left, a new air purifier from a Swedish company called LightAir, is energy-efficient, quiet, produces no ozone and, according to a test done by a Swedish government agency, removed over 99 percent of airborne pollutants in a 540-square-foot room. The pollutants collect on the outside of the unit's aluminum ring, so you can see when it needs cleaning. But wait until it is turned off. Otherwise, it will give you a mild shock that can be disconcerting. (An optional plastic guard is included for those with small children or pets.) The ceiling-mountable version is $350; floor-standing models are $395 and $495 for a taller one. Information: orangeskin.com. MICHAEL HSU

The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the city's building code since 1968, greatly expanding fire safety requirements, encouraging environmentally sound construction and simplifying operations at the Department of Buildings. The updated code, which is to be reviewed for possible revision every three years, was approved in a 47-to-0 vote, with one abstention, and will go into effect on July 1, 2008. It adds sprinkler requirements for smaller buildings, raises standards for smoke detectors, strengthens safety regulations for high-rise residential buildings and provides for rebates on permit fees if buildings meet higher environmental design standards and undertake more environmentally friendly practices.
To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman's comportment advice in ''The Whole World Is Watching'' (column, June 27) may be novel in the for-profit world; it is standard practice in the not-for-profit world.

HOLTZMAN--Edward, M.D., June 25, 2007. WWII veteran, Psychiatrist, mentor. The Loved One is always missed. He will be fondly remembered by his children Wade, Niki, Marc, Tara, their families and his loving wife Heidi Kreuziger-Holtzman.

A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered -- not just state flags.

Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobel's co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. The judge overseeing the case, Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio had been properly obtained.

CLAIBORNE--Liz. I will always treasure your sense of grace, humor and style. You were elegant and grounded. You will be sorely missed and never forgotten. You were simply the best. Love, Martin Tandler

Because of a transmission error, a film review yesterday about ''Live Free or Die Hard'' misstated the critic's description of the plot. It should have been described as ''logic-defying,'' not ''logic-defined.''

At least 11 Palestinian militants and 2 civilians were killed Wednesday during Israeli raids in Gaza in the deadliest day of fighting since the Islamic militant group Hamas took control there nearly two weeks ago. Hospital officials in Gaza said that among the dead was a 10-year-old boy, Eiz al-Deen Jondiah, killed in Gaza City apparently by shrapnel from a tank shell. The other civilian was identified as Hazen Jondiah, 30.

Drive across the empty reaches of the Great Plains, from the lost promise of Valentine, Neb., to the shadowless side roads into Sunray, Tex., and what you see is a land that has lost its purpose. Many of the towns set in this infinity of flat have a listless look, with shuttered main streets and schools given over to the grave. With upwards of $20 billion a year in federal payments going to a select few in farm country, you would think that these troubled counties would have a more vigorous pulse. After all, corn and wheat prices are at record highs, and big manses here and there, with Hummers in limestone driveways, indicate that somebody is doing well.
SOLIWODA--Victoria, L.C.S.W. on June 27th. Visiting Friday 2-5pm, 7-9pm at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. For further information call 212-674-8055.
WEKSBERG--Abraham, at 89 years. Beloved husband of the late Hilda. Devoted father of Richard D.

To the Editor: Re ''On Abortion, Giuliani Faces a Potential Fall From Catholic Grace'' (news article, June 25): Although I do not often agree with Rudolph W. Giuliani, I believe that his stance regarding his personal opposition to abortion and his decision against its imposition on the public at large is the correct one.

JONES--Paul M. Paul M. Jones, long known for his contributions to the interior design industry, passed peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Saturday, June 23rd. He was 88. Born on February 15th, 1919 in Dayton, Paul graduated from Ohio State University with a degree in English Literature, served in the U.S. Army during WWII, and was an editor at Family Circle magazine before settling in to a long and successful career in the interior design industry. Beginning in 1958 in a brownstone on East 54th Street, Paul M. Jones, Inc. quickly became a fashionable and highly reputable resource for custom furniture, lighting, and accessories, assisted by his talented manufacturers and his loyal and supportive staff. Several years later, he became one of the very first trade showrooms in the then newly opened D&D building in 1961. Paul was known for his kind, gentle manner and his classic aesthetic, and his influence over the interior design market is still strongly recognized today. An avid reader, he tackled the NY Times crossword puzzle each morning, loved to stroll through Central Park, and lived for his summer holidays on the Isle of Capri. Paul is survived by his adored sister, Naomi Pittman. He is predeceased by his loving parents, Kenton and Anna Jones, dear sister, Ruth Miller, and beloved companions Philip Graf and Michael St. Clair. In Paul's memory, donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy. JONES--Paul M. You were our mentor and a great friend, a true gentleman with a sharp wit and style to match. We thank you for so many wonderful times, and know that you're finally enjoying a Negroni with Philip and Michael. We love you. John Boone & Chris Lockwood JONES--Paul M. We continue to honor our beloved colleague, our dear friend, and a truly gracious gentleman. His contributions to our industry are many, and he will be greatly missed. The Staff of John Boone, Inc.

A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Black's Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war on Wednesday. The Osprey Media Income Fund endorsed a second bid Wednesday for its 20 daily and 34 nondaily newspapers, this one from Black Press, a privately held newspaper company based in British Columbia.

CIRINO--Linda D., died on Wednesday, June 27, 2007. Wife of Antonio Cirino. Mother of Paul Cirino and Mark Cirino. Sister of Donna Davis and Andrew P. Davis. Sister to Jessica G. Davis. Mother to Donna Cirino and Kristen Cirino. Grandmother of Alexander Harold Cirino. Born April 10, 1941. A writer and community leader.

To the Editor: ''Gay Marriage, a Touchy Issue, Touches Legislators' Emotions'' (news article, June 21) speaks of Assemblyman Dov Hikind, ''who said he opposed gay marriage on religious grounds,'' echoing the religious objections expressed by some other members of New York's Legislature. Do we need to remind these legislators that they took an oath of office to uphold the Constitution, not the tenets of their religion?

BALASKAS--John, a successful financial analyst who held positions at several investment firms in New York City, died suddenly in Paris, France on Wednesday, June 13th according to his wife, Mary Jo Rathgeb. Balaskas, who ran his own hedge fund until illness forced him to close in 2003, worked as vice president of Consumer Strategy for Weiss MultiStrategy Advisers. In the Wall Street Journals annual All Star Research Survey, he was named the Top Stock Picker of the Retail Sector in 1999 while employed at Bear Stearns and Co. A devoted husband for fourteen years, Balaskas and his wife Mary Jo shared an enthusiasm for music, sports, reading, cooking, travel, and especially animals including their two Weimaraners, Trixie and Ellie. Balaskas is also survived by his parents, John and Charlotte Balaskas of King of Prussia, sisters Katharine Kelly, also of King of Prussia, Janice Balaskas of Pottstown, PA, and Juliann Balaskas of New York, NY, in addition to many aunts, uncles, cousins and extended family. A funeral was held at Washington Memorial Chapel in Valley Forge Park on June 23, 2007. Interment will be in Valley Forge Chapel Cemetery. A New York memorial service will be held Thursday, June 28th at the Salmagundi Club from 6 to 8 pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the ASPCA or American Liver Foundation.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 2 of Huang Ju, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, the elite group of nine senior officials who rule China, misidentified the committee member responsible for presiding over reforms to the banking and financial systems. It was Mr. Huang -- not Jiang Zemin, the former president with whom Mr. Huang was allied.

The long-lost manuscript of the 1932 Pulitzer Prize-winning Pearl S. Buck novel ''The Good Earth'' has been recovered, The Associated Press reported. The typed manuscript vanished from the author's family farm in Perkasie, Pa., a Philadelphia suburb, around 1966. Jerri Williams, an F.B.I. spokeswoman, said it turned up this month when consigned to a Philadelphia auction house, which notified the authorities. Officials did not say if anyone would face charges related to the manuscript's disappearance. ''The Good Earth,'' about life in rural China, helped Buck (1892-1973) become the first American woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, in 1938.

SCHWAGER--Robert G. It is with deep sadness that we write this obituary for our loving and vibrant father because of his tragic and untimely death. He was an exceptionally gifted surgeon who was deeply devoted to his patients, his alma maters, the University of Virginia, and the Weill Cornell Medical School. He served his country as a naval surgeon in the Vietnam War. He was an avid storyteller with a wonderful sense of humor. He lived life to its fullest with incredible energy and a special passion for sailing. We loved our father and we will deeply miss him. We were his priority and he taught us the importance of education, hard work, and family. We feel blessed to have had him with us to celebrate the continuity of our family. Scott & Viviane, Phaedrus & Mary Beth, Rebecca & Greg, Katherine & Brian SCHWAGER--Dr. Robert G., 64 on June 26, 2007. A prominent plastic surgeon affiliated with NewYork Presbyterian Medical Center and held a private practice on 5th Avenue. Beloved husband of Lori Schwager, devoted father of Scott, Kenneth, Rebecca and Katherine. Brother of Jane Schwager, grandfather of Sarah, Owen, Thomas, William, and Ziggy. Family will receive friends Thursday 79pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Services Friday June 29th, 2007, 11am at Tempel Emanu-el, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Weil Cornell Medical School Scholarship Program, 1300 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021. SCHWAGER--Robert, M.D. The Department of Surgery mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague, Dr. Robert Schwager, Clinical Assistant Professor of Plastic Surgery and Assistant Attending Surgeon. Dr. Schwager received his M.D. from Cornell University Medical College in 1967, and served as an intern and resident in general surgery at The New York Hospital. He was a renowned plastic surgeon, teacher and researcher who made significant contributions during his 36 years at our institution. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Lori, his children Rebecca, Scott, Kenneth and Katherine, his five grandchildren, and to all who loved him. He will be sorely missed. Fabrizio Michelassi, M.D. Stimson Professor & Chair Department of Surgery Weill Cornell Medical College Surgeon-in-Chief New York-PresbyterianWeill Cornell Medical Center SCHWAGER--Robert, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Robert Schwager, Clinical Assistant Professor of Surgery at Weill Cornell Medical College and Assistant Attending Surgeon at NewYork - Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell. Dr. Schwager received his medical degree and residency training at Weill Cornell, where for the duration of his career, he contributed greatly to plastic and reconstructive surgery. He also served on an advisory committee for the medical center and helped raise scholarship money for medical students. A beloved clinician, scientist and teacher, Dr. Schwager will be much missed. Our heartfelt condolences to the Schwager family. Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College SCHWAGER--Robert G. M.D. With great sorrow we mourn the loss of our fellow shareholder and great friend, Dr. Robert Schwager. His kind ways will be missed by all. Our sympathy and condolences are with his entire family. The Shareholders of 927 Fifth Avenue SCHWAGER--Robert G. We mourn the untimely death of our beloved Bob, such a caring friend to our family. Our hearts are forever broken. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife Lori; to Lois, their dear children and grandchildren, whose unfathomable loss we share. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Sylvia, David, Rachel, Courtney & Raphael Posner

One of the few concessions the Paris men's collections have offered to spring is the cropped trouser. Otherwise the clothes look wintry. Flood pants appeared at John Galliano (low-slung, often over printed leggings), Comme des Garcons and Junya Watanabe. Shades of Thom Browne? Maybe. Does it matter?

A Florida millionaire with alleged (but apparently unproven) ties to the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency is auctioning off his private island in the Bahamas. Known as Leaf Cay, the 15-acre island includes 19 buildings, a desalination plant, a freezer building, an airstrip and, best of all, a radar facility. The opening bid is $12 million (€8.9 million). Read the full story from the Miami Herald here.

Campaign wordsmiths have been hard at work finding just the right pitch to nudge, cajole and smooth-talk their supporters into sending in a contribution before tomorrow's midnight fund-raising deadline. In a flurry of e-mails and Web site messages, the campaigns have been trying out increasingly novel pleas.

Whenever The Lede is asked whether he prefers Vermont or New Hampshire, he always answers "yes." But it seems that plenty of other people's opinions come down strongly on one side of the Connecticut River or the other. And as Katie Zezima of The New York Times wrote in this morning's paper, New England's decidedly unidentical twins have been trying in recent weeks to settle once and for all the age-old question of which is the superior quaint, mountainous, vaguely wedge-shaped, lightly populated northeastern state, by means of an Internet straw poll.

During the Great Depression, Congress and the Federal Reserve imposed rules to limit margin borrowing in the stock market. They thought excessive speculation in the 1920s had led to the crash, and perhaps they were right. By then, however, there was little need for the rules because there was little appetite for speculation.

Alison and I have no problem being criticized for our choices about what our house should look like on the outside ("gigantic and ugly," Danielle, or how we have chosen to design the interior ("Oh my your kitchen is full of flaws," Kimberly Brag said.)
Leana Wen, who traveled with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, looks back on her journey.
