It was December 2005, a few days after Paul Lo Duca joined the Mets in a trade with the Marlins, and we were sitting in the lobby of a Manhattan hotel. We spent about 45 minutes that morning talking for an article about him that would be published a few days later, and I remember coming away from the interview thinking that he would be a great addition to the clubhouse.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his June 29 column, "The Murdoch Factor."

A week ago, you may recall, Glacier Girl, a World War II P-38 fighter lovingly restored to airworthiness after 50 years buried in ice in Greenland, took off from New Jersey in the hope of finally finishing the plane's interrupted 1942 mission to reach Britain.

After I walked out of the McLaren Mercedes motor home yesterday and thought about the group interview with Lewis Hamilton that I had just taken part in, it suddenly occurred to me that this must have been a little what it was like with Beatlemania. Pretty much the entire interview dealt with questions concerning how Hamilton was adapting to his new celebrity. Are people recognizing him? (More and more.) Does he like it? (Less and less. Well, not quite, just a matter of a challenge adapting to it.) Is his family happy? (In heaven, more or less.) What does he make of all this press coverage? (Doesn't really read it, but yes, his family is stocking up on the newspapers.) Etc., etc.
An all-American family in Wisconsin takes in a foreign exchange student as a way to bolster their geeky son's popularity.

In giving Balenciaga a new silhouette, Nicolas Ghesquiere has created a modern path for fashion. This is the Balenciaga look: lean, seemingly energized with French street cool, relentlessly sharp in its concept. Only 250 people see his shows each season, a fact that has probably contributed to his fashion leadership. Still, he has managed to walk another kind of line. He has made Balenciaga a global brand - through image, accessories, and an imaginative expansion of lower-priced lines such as knits and trousers. Last week, Ghesquiere was in Milan to open a new Balenciaga shop. Another one is set to open later this year in Los Angeles. Yesterday, I sat down with Ghesquiere in the Balenciaga offices in Paris to talk about fashion, multiculturalism, and the influence of designers in a fast-changing world.

Ask Paul Boomsma, executive vice president of the Luxury Portfolio Fine Property Collection, to spotlight an intriguing market and he'll point to Jávea, a small town on the coast south of Valencia, Spain. Jávea offers the stunning views and picturesque coves of the Costa Blanca without the towers and mass development of the area's other hot spots, he says. "It's very non-touristy," Boomsma said.
Some brides-to-be are upset -- "bawling," according to the New York Post -- because Ronald Burkle, head of the private equity firm Yucaipa, bought a $17 million penthouse in downtown New York.

The fonts are a little off because the guru of anything technological here is Naka, and I don't dare show this entry to him. Naka always manages to avoid the limelight on this trip, so a word about him. He's a Times web producer/photographer/videographer based in Los Angeles who has been traveling with me much of the time since 2003. He's the one who always produces the multimedia shows based on my trips, even though they have my name in big letters and his name in a tiny type that he sets. The reality is that I basically stand on the masking tape and he does the work. On this trip, he put together the videos for Will and Leana.

Bear Stearns on Friday replaced the head of its asset management business after two of the investment bank's hedge funds nearly collapsed because of bad bets on mortgage securities. The turmoil at the funds embarrassed Bear Stearns, widely known for its savvy in handling mortgage risk. The funds were hit by money-losing positions tied to subprime loans, which are made to people with weak credit.

William A. Houlihan, who most recently was chief financial officer of Sedgwick Claims Management Services, has joined UBS as a managing director in its financial institutions group. He will report to Oliver Sarkozy, joint global head of investment banking. Earlier this year, two bankers from the same UBS group, Joe Jiampietro and Eric Warmstein, left for J.P. Morgan Chase.

After my last visit to India, I wrote in this blog that the approach of some Western philanthropists to work with the brothels in Calcutta seemed to me to have failed. The hope had been that by cooperating with DMSC, nominally a union of prostitutes, it would be possible to reduce forced prostitution and the spread of AIDS by encouraging harm reduction strategies such as condom usage.
In lawmaking, as in comedy, timing is everything.

Vassily Ivanchuk of Ukraine has won the Aerosvit tournament in Foros, Ukraine, on the Crimean Peninsula. The tournament ran from June 18 through today. Taking second, a half-point behind, was Sergey Karjakin also of the Ukraine. Games from the tournament, which attracted many of the world's best players, can be replayed here at the event's official Web site.
Shares of Commerce Bancorp, the largest bank in New Jersey, jumped more than 8 percent Friday after the company said its chairman and chief executive, Vernon W. Hill II, was leaving.

I wrote a post last week that mentioned the late short story writer Breece D'J Pancake, and his admirers came out of the woodwork. I got a lot of e-mail about him. So this seems worth saying: today's his birthday. Pancake was born 55 years ago today, on June 29, 1952, in South Charleston, West Virginia.

A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk -- highly speculative talk -- that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

NBC Universal's chief executive, Jeff Zucker, on why General Electric decided against bidding with Pearson for Dow Jones: "When you have shareholders who you have to create value for, you have to be fiscally disciplined. When you are the shareholder that matters, you play a different game," he said, referring to Rupert Murdoch's controlling stake in the News Corporation.

Thousands stood hours in a queue in a downpour last Sunday for a chance to meet, greet and get an autograph from new Formula One racing sensation Lewis Hamilton here at the annual Goodwood Festival of Speed in England.

The war in Iraq and terrorism were front and center at the first two Democratic presidential debates, but yesterday, when all eight candidates appeared on the same stage for the third time during the campaign, they had a chance to go on the record about issues that have received less attention so far.
To Our Readers:

Writing on his blog, Is That Legal?, North Carolina law professor Eric Muller explains why he thinks Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's concurrence in the Supreme Court decision about the Seattle and Louisville school systems isn't as impenetrable as some find it. Kennedy wrote that Seattle "failed to explain why, in a district composed of a diversity of races, with fewer than half of the students categorized as 'white,' it has employed the crude categories of 'white' and 'non-white' as the basis for its assignment decisions."

Perhaps more than any other major city, London is saturated with closed-circuit video cameras. They watch the lobbies of buildings and sidewalks outside for security; they watch the streets to detect traffic jams and to bill motorists who drive in the city center under London's "congestion pricing" system (a plan that New York City officials want to emulate), and some of them are there just for fun.

For most of the last decade, the private equity firms in Germany have argued for preferential tax treatment on the basis of national interest. The breaks are needed, private equity managers said, to help Germany catch up with London and New York, the global centers of the buyout business.
James E. Cayne has a bellyache. And it is not from the crash diet that has caused Mr. Cayne, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, to shed 20 pounds over the last year.

As Rupert Murdoch vies for control of Dow Jones and The Wall Street Journal, another newspaper battle is taking place across the Atlantic. Pearson, the British publisher that owns The Financial Times, is considering a sale of French financial daily Les Echos to LVMH, which already owns rival daily La Tribune.

3i, the private equity firm, said Friday that it has invested $57 million in Fulcrum, a hedge fund administrator, through its Growth Capital division. As part of the deal, Akshaya Bhargava of 3i will become Fulcrum's chief executive. The private equity firm said that its investment will help Fulcrum expand its ability to administer to hedge funds' back-end operations, as well as broaden its reach to funds in Europe and Asia.

Last year, Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of the giant chipmaker, invested in more U.S. deals than some of the biggest venture firms in Silicon Valley, including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital.

Following rumors earlier this month, Moneysupermarket.com Group has officially announced it will proceed with an initial public offering of its ordinary shares thought to be worth 1 billion pounds ($2 billion). UBS has been appointed as its main adviser.
Slowdown? What slowdown?

Britain's Sports Direct has acquired iconic U.S. boxing glove manufacturer Everlastfor 84 million pounds ($168 million), The Telegraph reported Friday. Sports Direct already owns the Sports World chain and the Lillywhites store in Britain, but has been experiencing difficulties as of late.

Former HealthSouth chief executive Richard Scrushy, acquitted two years ago in a major corporate fraud case, and former Alabama Gov. Don Siegelman were both sentenced to prison on Thursday for bribery. A federal judge sentenced Mr. Scrushy to six years and 10 months in prison and Mr. Siegelman to seven years and four months after they were convicted of involvement in a scheme to manipulate hospital building permissions that favored HealthSouth.
School's out, summer's begun, Independence Day impends -- so, naturally, hot dogs are all over the news, one way and another.

Altadis, the maker of Gauloise, Gitane and Ducados cigarettes, is likely to become the subject of a bidding war now that it has revealed that CVC Capital Partners and rival bidder Imperial Tobacco have completed their due diligence work.

Raising the pressure in their campaign to have TD Ameritrade Holding join with another brokerage, hedge funds Jana Partners and SAC Capital sent the brokerage firm a letter Thursday demanding company records and urging Ameritrade to exclude directors appointed by its largest shareholder, Canada's TD Bank, from merger discussions.

ABN Amro has appointed 26-year banking veteran Soh Wah Siaw as its head of consumer banking in China. The former HSBC executive will replace Linda Wong, who was promoted to the head of China operations for the investment bank last year.

Germany's Deutsche Bahn, the state-owned railway company, has acquired the English Welsh and Scottish Railway in a 280 million pound deal. The takeover is expected to take place later this summer subject to regulatory approval, The Guardian wrote.

In a move to boost its fixed-income sales team, Credit Suisse has hired three new bankers in Australia. Chris Dickman, Clare-Louise Nightingale and Adam Roberts-Thomson have all been recruited to new roles with the firm and will also cover New Zealand.

Cancer-related drug developer Serenex picked up $26 million in an equity round which could be its last private funding before a public offering. With the round, the Durham, N.C.-based company's total funding comes to $81 million.

The window for public offerings is slowly beginning to open after largely being closed to technology companies since the double whammy of the dot-com downturn and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, which imposed expensive accounting responsibilities on public companies, The New York Times writes.
In a Series D funding, Paracor Medical raised $44.35 million to complete a pivotal clinical trial of a device to prevent congestive heart failure, says TheDeal.com.

American Capital Strategies continued its buying spree Thursday when it spent about $700 million via two new deals. The publicly traded lender and middle-market buyout sponsor said it had acquired a majority stake in Extream Software for more than $548 million and also committed $100 million of equity to purchase Oceana Media, a movie finance company.

With a view to creating a mining behemoth, Canada's Yamana Gold is eyeing a buyout of two smaller groups for about $4 billion. The move comes during a time when the country's major mineral companies have fallen prey to buyers from abroad. Both Falconbridge and Inco were swallowed up by foreigners in the last two years.

In a $1 billion cash deal, Western Digital said late Thursday it plans to purchase Komag a San Jose, Calif.-based media manufacturer. Western Digital, a hard drive maker, will pay $32.25 per share through a cash tender offer and also pay down $220 million in debt issued by Komag in March that is due in 2014.

With three court filings since March, the Federal Trade Commission has been working overtime to challenge mergers. Next up could be Genentech's $914 million purchase of Tanox, which has been under review for nearly six months.

After three years of hearings and recriminations, a British judge on Thursday refused to extradite the multimillionaire hotelier Stanley S. Tollman to New York, a major setback for prosecutors seeking to bring him to trial on charges relating to a $100 million bank fraud and tax evasion scheme.
A federal court froze the assets of Lake Shore Asset Management, a hedge fund firm run by a former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, after regulators said it overstated its holdings.

Mellon Bank has agreed to pay $16.5 million to the federal government to settle claims that it allowed overwhelmed employees to destroy thousands of federal tax returns and payments in 2001. In turn, the government will not pursue any civil or administrative monetary claims against Mellon, the United States district attorney's office and Mellon Bank said Thursday.
“Dr. Bronner’s Magic Soapbox” mixes method and madness to chart the evolution of a counterculture phenomenon.
What I'm wearing now, bottomless totes, pretty in plaid dresses and more.
The mix of rural charm, wine country sophistication and laid-back beach town makes Mattituck, N.Y., an attractive destination.
A new series on the N network immerses itself so deeply in the pits of class warfare that its characters might as well be carrying cans of mace.
New York City’s 52 outdoor swimming pools opened for the summer season, and New Yorkers did not wait long before diving in.
A meticulous renovation turns back the clock on an ’80s landmark.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Are the washer and dryer in my apartment grandfathered, since they were there before the conversion?
Is there a requirement that a co-op with almost 400 units have two live-in superintendents so that we have full-time coverage?

In the latest move against Chinese imports, the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday effectively blocked the sale of five types of farm-raised seafood from China because of repeated instances of contamination from unapproved animal drugs and food additives.

With wins so hard to come by this season, the Yankees will take what they got on Thursday in Baltimore: an 8-6 lead in the eighth inning of a suspended game. The Yankees and the Orioles will resume this game when the Yankees come to town again on July 27.
Displaying the usual meticulousness associated with the Pixar brand, “Ratatouille” is a nearly flawless piece of popular art.
“Falling” is at once a character study times five and something of a generational snapshot.
At first, second and final glance, Susan Minot’s “Evening” doesn’t seem as if it would translate easily to the big screen. It hasn’t.
Customers eager to buy the cellphone had waited in long lines in front of Apple stores in New York and other cities.
A document calls for an independent group that could block hirings and firings and conduct investigations.
OTTAWA, June 29 — Canadian travelers faced road and rail shutdowns this morning as they set out for the Canada Day holiday weekend amid nationwide protests by native groups.
There was fierce public criticism after Israel agreed to drop rape charges against the disgraced president, Moshe Katsav in a plea deal.
Reversing course, the Supreme Court agreed to review whether detainees may go to federal court to challenge their indefinite confinement.
Many people in the streets near Piccadilly Circus seemed less than troubled here today about the discovery of an explosive device.
The negotiators agreed today on the logistics of shutting down and sealing the nation’s main nuclear reactor.
The soldiers killed today were conducting an operation aimed at reducing sectarian violence, the military said.
A second car containing the makings of a bomb was found today, not far from where another car was found earlier and defused.
Designing, preparing and choosing sails are decisive factors in who will win the America’s Cup.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) — House Democrats on Thursday defeated a Republican effort to block the District of Columbia from subsidizing needle exchange programs intended to curb the spread of AIDS among heroin users.
The Democratic presidential candidates agreed on a number of domestic measures as they addressed an audience largely comprised of African-Americans.
The evacuations came as authorities raided a house believed to be involved in the Internet sale of commercial chemicals.

Three men were shot, one fatally, yesterday afternoon around the Willis Avenue Bridge in Mott Haven, the police said. According to the police, the victims were chased by an unknown number of young men starting at East 131st Street and Willis Avenue before they were shot. The police said they did not have a motive for the shooting and had not been able to identify the assailants. One victim, a 22-year-old man, was shot in the head on the bridge around 4:15 p.m., and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The other two men, a 19-year-old who was shot in the buttocks and the leg and a 17-year-old who was shot in the hip, were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and were reported in stable condition. The police did not identify the victims, but at the hospital last night, a family member, Janis Mackey, said the 17-year-old was Edward Steele of Harlem, her grandson. “They don’t know why they were shot,” she said. “They were in the wrong neighborhood.”.

A Brooklyn teenager was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old Brooklyn man on the subway Wednesday evening, the police said. The police said the suspect, Stephen Scott, 17, had had an argument earlier in the day with the victim, Trevell Belton, before he shot Mr. Belton on the Q train at Avenue U. Witnesses led investigators to Mr. Scott, who was also charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said.
Nashville Predators forward Paul Kariya plans to enter free agency, the latest loss for a team ”fighting for its life,” General Manager David Poile said.

David Beckham will be officially introduced as the newest member of the Los Angeles Galaxy on July 13 at the team’s stadium in Carson, Calif.Beckham will arrive in Los Angeles a few days before his introductory news conference and first training session with the M.L.S. team. Beckham is expected to make his Galaxy debut in an exhibition against Chelsea on July 21 at Home Depot Center.

A 23-year-old woman found fatally shot in a Phoenix alley has been identified as the daughter of the former N.F.L. lineman Luis Sharpe, authorities said.The body of Leah Tamara Sharpe was discovered early Tuesday, and the police said investigators believed it was dumped there. Luis Sharpe played in the N.F.L. from 1982-94 for the Cardinals in St. Louis and Arizona and was a three-time Pro Bowl selection.
It was no surprise that the Nets took 6-foot 10-inch Sean Williams from Boston College with the 17th pick in the N.B.A. draft.
Mellon Bank has agreed to pay $16.5 million to the federal government to settle claims that it allowed overwhelmed employees to destroy thousands of federal tax returns and payments in 2001.
Thursday’s rain allowed the Mets to begin their four-game series against the Phillies without circles under their eyes.
The Knicks traded for Zach Randolph, an All-Star caliber power forward who has been in trouble with his team and the law throughout his six-year career.
The wholesale diamond district on West 47th Street is reputed to be a closed, secretive world in which millions of dollars in gems are traded based on little more than trust and a handshake.
Assemblyman Phil Ramos doesn’t seem to be intimidated by a $320 million gorilla lurking in his local office.

British house prices advanced this month at the fastest pace since December, bolstering the case for an interest rate increase by the Bank of England next week. The average cost of a home rose 1.1 percent from May, to £184,070 ($368,000), according to the Nationwide Building Society, the biggest mortgage lender in Britain. “The bounce-back in June is a bit stronger than expected,” said Fionnuala Earley, chief economist at Nationwide. “It looks like the bank will bring forward the decision to increase interest rates, and increase the risk that rates get to 6 percent this year.”.

Gazprom, Russia’s natural gas export monopoly, said 2006 profit doubled, to a record $22.6 billion, beating estimates, as it sold more fuel at higher prices. Net income surged 97 percent, to 613.3 billion rubles, from 311.1 billion rubles a year earlier, the state-run company said. The profit equals $22.6 billion at the average ruble rate for the period and is 8.2 percent higher than the median estimate of six analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Rising prices in Europe, where Gazprom has a quarter of the market, and increased shipments to former Soviet nations drove the gain in earnings, the highest ever reported by a Russian company. Gazprom, based in Moscow, relies entirely on exports for profit because it loses money on sales in Russia, where prices are capped.

Switzerland’s main watchmaking group urged the government to tighten the rules on what can be called a Swiss watch to stop timepieces with too many foreign parts from reaching the market. Under a proposal by the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry, at least 80 percent of a mechanical watch or 60 percent of an electronic one would have to be made in Switzerland for it to be called “Swiss made,” the group said. The proposal, approved by 87 percent of the federation’s members, will be sent to the government for consideration. The existing ordinance says at least 50 percent must be Swiss made.

Canada’s highest court upheld a law limiting tobacco advertising, ruling that although the restrictions limited the rights of cigarette companies to free speech the curbs were justified by the need to improve public health. The Supreme Court judges said there was nothing wrong with the 1997 law that banned broadcast commercials and advertising aimed at young people and that obliged companies to put large graphic warning labels on cigarette packages. Canada’s three big tobacco companies had argued the limitations unfairly infringed their right of free expression. But in a unanimous decision, the court said the need to protect public health took precedence.

Germany’s unemployment rate slipped to 8.8 percent in June, from 9.1 percent in May, in a sign of better times for the country’s economy. The number of unemployed people fell to 3.687 million from 3.812 million in May, according to the state jobs agency. The agency said that 711,000 fewer people were jobless compared with a year ago. Some German officials have even warned about labor shortages for high-demand skills like engineers, a sign of how far the economy has come in reducing the jobless rate from above 12 percent in early 2006.

TAM, Brazil’s largest airline by passengers carried, agreed to purchase 26 Airbus planes for around $5.4 billion to expand its international routes. The airline, based in São Paulo, said it signed a deal to buy 22 Airbus A350 planes and exercised an earlier option to buy 4 A330 models. The company secured an option to buy 10 additional A350s in the future. The A330s will be delivered in 2010 and 2011. TAM operates direct flights to Paris, London, Milan, New York and Miami.

A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on June 15, about the Japanese artist and curator Takashi Murakami, misspelled the name of the art show he runs. It is Geisai, not Gesai. It also misstated the policy of his company, Kaikai Kiki, on taking a 10 percent agent’s fee for works sold at the show. It does not always take a fee, and in Miami in December it plans to waive it for young artists.

An obituary on Tuesday of J. B. Handelsman, a cartoonist whose work appeared in The New Yorker, included incorrect information from the Web site of The New Yorker for the caption of one of his cartoons for the magazine. The original caption, with a cartoon showing a maitre d’hotel speaking by telephone to a would-be diner, read: “Certainly. A party of four at seven-thirty in the name of Dr. Jennings. May I ask whether that is an actual medical degree or merely a Ph.D.?” The caption in the Web site’s tribute to Mr. Handelsman, which was quoted in the obituary, omitted the word “merely.”.

A front-page article last Friday about nonprofit organizations created by John Edwards that helped keep his political profile alive after the 2004 election referred imprecisely to a donation made to an Edwards campaign committee. Although an individual donor was not identified, the donation was credited to Oak Spring Farms LLC, which listed a New York hotel as its address. The donation was not “anonymous.” The article also misstated the title of one of Mr. Edwards’s campaign advisers. David Ginsberg is a senior adviser for communications; he is not the campaign’s deputy campaign manager, a post currently held by Jonathan Prince.

An obituary yesterday of the fashion designer Liz Claiborne misstated the duration of her working relationship with Arthur Ortenberg, her husband, before the founding of Liz Claiborne Inc. in 1976. Mr. Ortenberg was Ms. Claiborne’s boss for two years, beginning in 1954, not for two decades. The obituary also misidentified the object of the couple’s wildlife conservation efforts in Madagascar. Their foundation sought to rescue the “fish-eagle,” an endangered bird there; they were not trying to save fish and eagles.

A front-page article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by Rebecca Charles, a Manhattan chef who has charged a competitor with unfairly copying her restaurant’s concept, design and menu, referred imprecisely to another chef, David Burke, who has also asserted intellectual property rights. Mr. Burke, who received, and later gave up, a trademark for the term “swordfish chop,” also applied for a trademark on the term “salmon pastrami,” according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. He did not receive a trademark on the term “salmon pastrami.”.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the dearth of university students in Japan misstated the reason that the numbers of college-age children of baby boom parents there peaked in 1992, years earlier than the American peak. It was because Japan’s baby boom was concentrated in the years immediately following World War II, while the American boom lasted until 1962. It was not because Japan’s boom started earlier; both started in 1946.

Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review of “The Irish Play,” at the Irish Arts Center on West 51st Street in Manhattan, misidentified the Web site that gives complete information and offers online ticket purchases. It is hammandclov.org, not irishartscenter.org.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the dearth of university students in Japan misstated the reason that the numbers of college-age children of baby boom parents there peaked in 1992, years earlier than the American peak. It was because Japan’s baby boom was concentrated in the years immediately following World War II, while the American boom lasted until 1962. It was not because Japan’s boom started earlier; both started in 1946.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about evolution and the soul misstated the views that Nancey Murphy, a philosopher at Fuller Theological Seminary, expresses in her book “Bodies and Souls, or Spirited Bodies?” Dr. Murphy argues that neither humans nor animals have souls, not that both have souls. She cited the ideas of Thomas Aquinas on animal and human souls to contrast with her view, not to support it.

An obituary yesterday of Tina L. Brozman, a former New York bankruptcy judge, misstated a holding of Maxwell Communication, on whose 1991 bankruptcy case she worked. It was the parent of The Daily News of New York, not The New York Post.

An article on Wednesday about the filing of federal charges against 29 people accused in plots to smuggle nearly $700 million in real and counterfeit goods from China into the United States misstated the given name of one of those charged, an owner of a trucking company. He is Joseph DePaola, not John.
Kiryas Joel, an Orthodox Jewish enclave in southern Orange County, grew faster than any other community in New York State from 2000 through 2006, according to census data released yesterday.
Voting 5 to 4, the Supreme Court declared that public school systems cannot seek integration through measures that take explicit account of a student’s race.
Employers from food-processing industries and agriculture as well as construction contractors and commercial landscapers were among the most persistent forces pushing for passage of the Senate bill.
The bill was supposed to revamp a popular tax-break program so it would generate more relatively affordable housing while restricting subsidies to luxury high-rises like Trump World Tower.
The Senate, forming blocs that defied party affiliation, could never unite on the main provisions of the measure.

Egypt strengthened its ban on female genital cutting by eliminating a legal loophole that allowed girls to undergo the procedure, the Health Ministry said. The ministry’s step, which came after an 11-year-old girl died last week while undergoing the procedure at a private clinic, canceled a 1996 provision that had permitted the surgery “in situations of illness” should doctors advise it. Female genital cutting, also known as female circumcision, is performed on Muslim and Christian girls in Egypt. A 2005 Unicef report found that 97 percent of Egyptian women between 15 and 49 had had the procedure.

The Constitutional Court lent its support to a government policy of withholding remains of suspected terrorists, a practice causing anguish among families in the Caucasus. Under the policy, bodies are either secretly buried or cremated. Muslim relatives have complained, saying that withholding the dead punishes families, not terrorists, and that no due process determines whether the dead were terrorists at all. Russia calls the practice an effective deterrent. The authorities have withheld remains in several prominent cases, including of leaders in the Chechen separatist movement. After militants briefly besieged the city of Nalchik in 2005, the authorities stacked more than 100 bodies in an unrefrigerated container. It later cremated them all, as relatives begged for their return.

Hou Zhenrun, the head of a small mine outside the northern city of Datong, has been convicted and sentenced to life in prison in the beating death of a reporter, the official Xinhua news agency reported. He was accused of organizing a gang to beat the reporter, Lan Chengzhang of The China Trade News, who died within hours. The death prompted an unusual demand by President Hu Jintao for an investigation.

The Galápagos Islands have been added to a list of endangered World Heritage sites maintained by the United Nations. The archipelago, home to a array of species that inspired Charles Darwin to form his theory of natural selection, has seen annual tourist visits grow to 120,000 from 40,000 in 1996. Introduced plants now outnumber native plants, according to a report prepared by naturalists for a United Nations committee that keeps track of cultural and natural sites of international significance. Altogether 29 out of 830 heritage <a href=

In a rare departure from its usual diplomatic restraint, the International Red Cross denounced Myanmar’s military government, saying it committed abuses that caused “immense suffering.” It said that the regime made thousands of detainees serve as porters for the military, exposing them to risks, and that its armed forces had committed acts of violence and abuse against civilians along the Thai-Myanmar border, including the large-scale destruction of food supplies.

Unions representing more than a million public service workers accepted a government pay offer and called off a nearly monthlong nationwide strike that shut down schools and crippled hospitals. The unions had demanded a 12 percent raise; the government’s final offer was 7.5 percent.
The N.H.L. Players’ Association announced a five-player committee to find a replacement for the former executive director Ted Saskin.
On the campaign trail in 2000, Cindy McCain was mostly a cheerful sidekick to her husband. Not anymore.
Argentina routed a youthful United States team at the Copa América in Maracaibo, Venezuela.

The Dallas Mavericks hired the former N.B.A. head coach Paul Westphal to be an assistant under Avery Johnson. Westphal, out of the league since being fired as Seattle’s coach 15 games into the 2000-1 season, went 267-159 with Phoenix (1992-95) and Seattle (1998-2000).

The Olympic organizing committee bidding for the 2016 Summer Games for Chicago named two new executives to top-level posts. Chicago 2016 named the insurance executive David Bolger as its new chief operating officer and Rick Ludwig, who has worked with several other Olympic organizing committees, as chief financial officer.

A woman who worked on the set of the ESPN talk show “Cold Pizza” is suing the network, saying she was fired after complaining about sexual harassment by the show’s host and a regular panelist. In the suit, the makeup artist Rita Ragone said she was pinched and fondled by the sports commentator Woody Paige and subjected to crude sexual comments by the ESPN host Jay Crawford at the show’s studio in Manhattan. Paige and Crawford were named as defendants in the suit. Ragone said Paige once grabbed her backside so forcefully, she was “propelled forward and into the air.”“It is not true,” Paige said in an e-mail message. He declined further comment. An ESPN spokesman also said the allegations were false.
Rocco Mediate shot his lowest score on the PGA Tour in four years, opening the Buick Open with an eight-under-par 64 for a one-stroke lead.

Some N.F.L. owners want to close the six-team European developmental league because it is losing too much money, said Carl Peterson, the president of the Kansas City Chiefs. N.F.L. Europa, which began operating in its current format in 1995, plays its season from April to June and offers teams an opportunity for young players to gain experience. Peterson said that outweighs the losses, which he said averaged $500,000 for each of the N.F.L.’s 32 clubs.

Ramzee Robinson, who earned the title Mr. Irrelevant as the final player selected in the 2007 N.F.L. draft, agreed on a three-year contract with the Detroit Lions, his agent said. Robinson, a cornerback, was the last of 255 players selected in April. Financial terms were not disclosed.
Former Gov. Don E. Siegelman of Alabama was convicted for his part in a bribery scheme connected to his effort to establish a state lottery.

A woman who was arrested in Philadelphia this month in connection with last year’s shooting of a Staten Island commune leader was ordered yesterday to return to New York City to face an attempted-murder charge. The woman, Rebekah Johnson, left, is accused of shooting and wounding the leader of the Ganas commune, Jeff Gross, on May 29, 2006, after ambushing him. Yesterday, Judge Susan I. Schulman of the Court of Common Pleas in Philadelphia ordered Ms. Johnson, 44, a former resident of the commune, extradited.

A Long Island bar owner pleaded not guilty yesterday to federal arson charges that accuse him of ordering a stationery store on the same block as his bar firebombed. An indictment alleges that the bar owner, Carmine Graziano, 45, hired two men to set fire to the shop, Roseanne’s Cards Galore in New Hyde Park, in August 2003 in retaliation for complaints the owners made about noise and under-age drinking at his bar, Copperfield’s Pub. Mr. Graziano was ordered held without bail yesterday after his arraignment in Federal District Court in Central Islip. Surveillance tapes show two men throwing a rock and then a Molotov cocktail through the store’s front window, prosecutors said. The fire forced the evacuation of several apartments above the store, which was destroyed; there were no serious injuries.

Transportation Security Administration officers at Kennedy International Airport have begun taking over the task of checking passengers’ identification as they approach the security checkpoint, agency officials said this week. The transfer from private contractors to federal security officers is part of an effort to actively look for false documents or signs that a passenger may be acting suspiciously, Ellen Howe, an agency spokeswoman, said on Tuesday. So far, the document checkers are at only some Kennedy security checkpoints, officials said.
Prosecutors want to bring Stanley S. Tollman to trial on charges relating to a $100 million bank fraud and tax evasion scheme.

The former city commissioner of public works yesterday admitted accepting paid trips from city contractors, prosecutors said. The commissioner, Joseph Giambra, 56, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to receiving an unlawful gratuity, said Frank Clark, the Erie County district attorney. Mr. Giambra had been charged with accepting eight trips from representatives of consulting and engineering firms that did millions of dollars of business with the city, Mr. Clark said. Mr. Giambra pleaded guilty to three counts of receiving unlawful gratuities, a misdemeanor. He faces up to a year in jail at sentencing, set for September.

Three workers for the city’s Bureau of Water Supply have been charged with participating in an illegal gun sale on city property, the Department of Investigation said yesterday. Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation, said a supervisor and two subordinates were charged in connection with the supervisor’s purchase of a .45-caliber pistol in the parking lot of a city water facility in the Delaware County hamlet of Grand Gorge. Ms. Gill Hearn said the supervisor, Thomas Ganz, 36 of Grahamsville, N.Y., was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a misdemeanor. The subordinates, James Geraghty, 38, of Stamford, N.Y., and George Pennell Jr., 39, of Liberty, N.Y., were charged with falsifying business records, the department said. Dianne Struzzi, a department spokeswoman, said Mr. Geraghty, who sold the weapon, and Mr. Pennell falsely claimed that Mr. Pennell, who has a pistol permit, was the buyer. Mr. Ganz does not have a valid permit, she said.

Two men accused of hiring hit men to kill a Genovese crime family associate in Brooklyn 13 years ago can be tried on state murder charges, despite being cleared of a similar federal charge for the same shooting, the state’s highest court ruled yesterday. The men, Carmine Polito and Mario Fortunato, were initially convicted of a federal charge of murder in aid of racketeering in the 1994 shooting of Sabatino Lombardi at the San Giuseppe Social Club. A federal appeals court overturned the conviction, finding that prosecutors had not proved that the men had committed the murder to further their standing in organized crime. A state grand jury then indicted Mr. Polito and Mr. Fortunato on murder charges. The men sued to dismiss the case, saying it was prohibited by the constitutional ban on double jeopardy. But New York law provides exceptions to the double jeopardy prohibition, and the Court of Appeals ruled 7-0 yesterday that the case qualified for trial. Mr. Fortunato is free on bail; Mr. Polito is being held at Rikers Island.
The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary plans to integrate schools left hundreds of school districts struggling to assess whether they must change their policies.
Zach Randolph is an All-Star caliber power forward who has been in trouble with his team and the law throughout his six-year career.
The seafood can be sold in the United States only if importers prove it does not contain contaminants.

Following are excerpts from opinions by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy in the court’s 5-to-4 decision yesterday that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a student’s race. Also included are excerpts from the dissent by Justice Stephen G. Breyer. The full opinions: nytimes.com/washington.
Whether it works, whether it sells, or whether it lives up to its promises, it has been a while since there was a morsel as edible as the iPhone.
It is a tribute to conservationists that the bald eagle was officially removed from the federal government’s list of endangered and threatened species.
The United Nations Security Council needs to move quickly to help Lebanon control its border and to pressure Syria into cooperation.
The Supreme Court’s decision on school integration invalidated programs in Seattle and metropolitan Louisville, Ky.
Scientists say they have made a major step toward creating synthetic forms of life.
The National Weather Service predicted that record-breaking rains would continue in the region through the middle of next week.
The central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.25 percent and signaled that it would keep it at that level for some time.
Officials blamed Wednesday’s power failure in Manhattan and the Bronx on a lightning bolt that they said hit a piece of equipment in Astoria, Queens.
The drugstore chain said that quarterly profit more than doubled, helped by lower costs for store closings and labor.
Another company will replace the Circle Line, which has provided ferry service to the Statue of Liberty for more than half a century.
Pension plans may have lower investment gains when they use consultants who have undisclosed conflicts of interest, according to a new report.
Bald eagles, whose numbers dwindled in the 1960s, are once again flourishing, the interior secretary said Thursday.
Mark Messier, Scott Stevens, Ron Francis and Al MacInnis will be inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame on Nov. 12.
The group said the Philippine military has been waging a “dirty war” that has resulted in the death or disappearance of hundreds of activists.
Amplifying on its ban against execution of the insane, the court, voting 5 to 4, overturned the death sentence of a Texas man convicted of murder.
Profit in the fourth quarter rose less than 1 percent, hurt by soaring grain costs, despite a 7 percent increase in sales.
A report complicates recent efforts to thaw relations between the rebels and Colombia’s government, which have fought for four decades.
As expected, the Portland Trail Blazers took Greg Oden and the Seattle SuperSonics took Kevin Durant with the first two picks of the N.B.A. draft.
James E. Cayne, Bear Stearns’ chief, has seen the firm’s carefully honed reputation suffer from the near collapse of two hedge funds.
Scott Schools, the second federal prosecutor to oversee the investigation of Barry Bonds, has been nominated to become a district attorney in South Carolina.

The House rejected an effort to eliminate the vice president’s executive office budget, a move that Democrats tied to Vice President Dick Cheney’s assertion that his office did not need to comply with national security disclosure rules required of other executive branch agencies. Republicans denounced the proposal as political theater. The vote, on an amendment to a 2008 spending bill for the Treasury Department and executive branch agencies, was defeated 217 to 209. Representative Rahm Emanuel, Democrat of Illinois and author of the amendment, said it was the logical outgrowth of Mr. Cheney’s claim that his office was outside the scope of rules imposed on other executive offices.

The mayor of Charleston said Wednesday that the city would buy the site of a fatal furniture store fire and create a park and memorial to the nine firefighters who died in the blaze. “The land is sacred,” said the mayor, Joseph P. Riley. “It’s where nine people died.” The Sofa Super Store showroom and warehouse were gutted by the June 18 blaze. Mr. Riley said he had spoken to the store’s owner, Herb Goldstein, who agreed with the plan. Mr. Riley said the two talked before the mayor traveled to Indiana for the last of the firefighter funerals. “We fully support this idea,” Mr. Goldstein said in a statement.

Investigators are looking into who altered the Wikipedia entry on Chris Benoit, a professional wrestler, to mention his wife’s death hours before the authorities discovered the bodies of the couple and their 7-year-old son. Mr. Benoit’s entry was altered early Monday to say that the wrestler had missed a match two days earlier because of his wife’s death. A Wikipedia official, Cary Bass, said the entry had been made by someone using an Internet protocol address registered in Stamford, Conn., where World Wrestling Entertainment is based. Also, federal drug agents said they had raided the west Georgia office of a doctor who prescribed testosterone to Mr. Benoit. No arrests were made.

Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County prosecutor, did not show up at a hearing to consider his immediate removal as district attorney, a position from which he has been suspended and already pledged to resign. But Mr. Nifong, who was disbarred for his handling of the discredited Duke lacrosse rape case, told the lawyer hired to prosecute his removal that he planned to resubmit his resignation Monday, making it effective immediately. At the hearing, Judge Orlando F. Hudson Jr. of Superior Court said he would reconvene Monday to accept Mr. Nifong’s resignation or issue an order kicking him out of office.

The chairman of the California Air Resources Board, Robert Sawyer, resigned just days after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger expressed displeasure at his board’s delay of an antismog plan. Dr. Sawyer, a prominent air-quality expert and professor emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley, was appointed to the board by the governor 18 months ago. On Friday, however, Mr. Schwarzenegger issued a statement saying he was “deeply disappointed” by a board decision to seek an 11-year delay in enforcement of federal air-quality standards in the San Joaquin Valley, south of Fresno. Mr. Schwarzenegger has made reducing emissions a priority of his second term.

A doctor who performs abortions was charged with violating state law on late-term procedures, a surprise move from a Democratic attorney general who recently unseated a prominent anti-abortion Republican. The new attorney general, Paul Morrison, left, filed 19 misdemeanor counts alleging that the doctor, George Tiller of Wichita, one of the few physicians performing late-term abortions, got second opinions from a doctor who was not financially and legally independent from him, as the law requires. Mr. Morrison’s predecessor, Phill Kline, had unsuccessfully prosecuted Dr. Tiller for different reasons. At a briefing, Mr. Morrison described the charges as a “technical violation” of a 1998 law restricting late-term procedures.

FOURTH OF JULY CELEBRATION Celebrity sightings are not uncommon in New York; spend enough time in the city, and you can run into the likes of Woody Allen, Spike Lee and Julianne Moore. But residents don’t expect to encounter George Washington and Benjamin Franklin, unless those famous faces happen to be in their wallets.

AFRO-PUNK BLOCK PARTY The block party is as much a New York summer tradition as rides on the Cyclone, concerts in Central Park and — unfortunately — the Mister Softee jingle everywhere. On Sunday, as part of its third annual Afro-Punk festival of film, music and art, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will hold its first Afro-Punk block party, on a Fort Greene street that has been party-bereft for several years. “We really wanted to do something that was drawn from the community,” said Tamara McCaw, the community affairs and audience development manager for the academy, and a party organizer. The area “is really exploding,” she said. “There are these young mom-and-pop shops, and independent artists that live in the neighborhood that have this eclectic, funky edge to them.” In addition to family-friendly activities like sidewalk chalk drawing, face painting and T-shirt-making (“nothing is more punk rock than making your own T-shirts,” Ms. McCaw said), there will be fashion, jewelry and crafts for sale from more than two dozen local designers and artisans, including Adrienne Braxton, a baker and familiar neighborhood presence. (Her peach cobbler is probably the best street-corner dessert you’ll find.) The Dustbin Brothers and the D.J. Rich Medina, above, who’s worked with Fela Kuti, will spin tunes; No Surrender, a Brooklyn electro-hip-hop trio, will perform live. With any luck, they’ll drown out Mister Softee. (Sunday from noon to 5 p.m., Clinton Avenue, between Myrtle Avenue and Willoughby Street, 718-636-4100, bam.org) MELENA RYZIK.
JAZZ.

‘E PLURIBUS VENOM’ The paradox of well-heeled and wealthy art collectors fawning over rebellious street art is apparent everywhere in the art world. The graffiti artist known as Banksy is the toast of London, while Shepard Fairey is approaching cult status in Los Angeles for his posters and stickers of the face of the professional wrestler Andre the Giant with the word “obey” emblazoned across them. Mr. Fairey, 37, is now having his first major New York gallery exhibition, split between the Jonathan LeVine Gallery in Chelsea and a rented 6,600-square-foot warehouse exhibition space in Brooklyn for huge graffiti installations and murals. (Last week’s opening in Brooklyn was disrupted by a man trying to set off an incendiary device.) There are about 80 works between the two sites, together forming a comprehensive, 20-year survey of his artwork in various mediums: screen prints, stencils, stickers, album covers, collage, spray paint and more. Despite the range of mediums and styles, the imagery comes off as generic, combining decorative elements with political metaphors, like an image of a couple cuddling a bomb. (Right is “War for Sale.”) It’s Norman Rockwell crossed with the Dead Kennedys crossed with Communist-era propaganda. References to capitalism and war predominate, especially in the Chelsea show, where many works are neatly framed and ready for sale. It is tempting to see this stuff as just another luxury commodity. (Jonathan LeVine Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, ninth floor, 212-243-3822, jonathanlevinegallery.com, through July 21; 81 Front Street, at Washington Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, through July 6.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO.

SEUN KUTI & THE EGYPT 80 Competing with a famous father is tough enough, particularly when that father is Fela Anikulapo Kuti, the Nigerian titan of Afrobeat music who before his death from AIDS 10 years ago was one of the world’s most outrageous and electrifying musical figures. But when Seun Kuti (above), 24, Fela’s youngest son, began performing with his father’s band, the Egypt 80, he faced another formidable contender: his older half-brother Femi, who since the late ’80s has earned the respect of critics and Afrobeat fans — not a crowd easily impressed — for his saxophone populism. Luckily or unluckily for both, their father is truly inimitable, and in addition to his music — a deliriously warped reflection of James Brown’s funk — Fela left a tradition of fearless political dissidence. As Seun Kuti told The Observer, the British newspaper, three years ago when graduating from the Liverpool Institute for Performing Arts, his father’s music is a mission that lives on, with room for plenty of inheritors. “Things in Nigeria are even worse now,” he said, “and however hard it is to live up to his legacy, we have to carry on the fight for liberation and consciousness.” He brings his saxophone and his fight to S.O.B.’s on Sunday for his New York debut, and Femi Kuti and his band Positive Force appear at Central Park SummerStage on July 11. (9 p.m., 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, 212-243-4940, sobs.com; $30.) BEN SISARIO.

‘LE DOULOS’ Jean-Pierre Melville’s brutal and subtly brilliant policier “Le Doulos” (shot in 1962, released in 1963) underscores why the French put the name to film noir. Based on the Pierre Lesou novel published by Gallimard in its celebrated Série Noire line, the film follows the parallel fates of two criminals — Jean-Paul Belmondo as Silien, Serge Reggiani as Maurice — bound by an almost mystical sense of masculine loyalty. Mr. Belmondo, below, who had recently worn a priest’s collar for Melville in “Léon Morin, Prêtre” (1961), enters “Le Doulos” in a more familiar Melvillian costume of a belted trench coat and fedora. A stated friend to Maurice as well as to the police, he first appears masked by an enveloping shadow, his silhouette framed in a doorway. He remains a darkly obscured figure for much of the rest of the story, a disturbing question mark for both Maurice (who believes in him) and the audience (who may not). The story eases and lurches, at times mechanistically, but what sticks and sticks hard is the way Melville fashions an entire world out of a threadbare room, a light swinging as if from a gallows, an ominous hat-check number, filigrees of cool jazz, an hourglass figure that melts into the image of a yapping dog and a masterly sense of cinematic space, exemplified by a lengthy interrogation scene. In “Le Doulos” the camera and the actors move in a silent conspiracy, revealing more about the true nature of a man far in advance of any line of dialogue. “Le Doulos” will be shown in a new 35-millimeter print, making it even easier to swoon into its darkness. (Through July 12, Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, 212-727-8110, filmforum.org; $10.50) MANOHLA DARGIS.

NIK BÄRTSCH’S RONIN “Zen-funk” is the term that Nik Bärtsch, a Swiss pianist, uses to describe the music of his five-piece band, Ronin, above. It’s an eminently printable phrase, but it cleanly misses the mark. True, Mr. Bärtsch composed the pieces for his recent album, “Stoa” (ECM), during a six-month residency in Japan. And, yes, at times those pieces do flirt with funkiness, though to draw allusions to James Brown, as some reviewers have, following Mr. Bärtsch’s lead, is a rather dubious stretch. The problem with the term is its connotation of mind-clearing tranquillity, when Ronin proposes something much more heady and premeditated. “Stoa,” for instance, relies on a precision movement of interlocking parts in a manner suggestive of a timepiece. (The Swiss and the Japanese have long had this expertise in common, after all.) Minimalism is a useful frame of reference, in the same way that it is for some hard-to-classify American bands. One track on the album, “Modul 35,” could be considered an acoustic corollary to the music of Battles; elsewhere there’s a vague resemblance to Tortoise. And videotape of Mr. Bärtsch and his colleagues performing “Modul 33” last fall (find it on YouTube, or at nikbaertsch.com) brings to mind the contemporary chamber group So Percussion. Next week’s showcase, which comes on the heels of festival appearances in Vancouver and Montreal, will mark Ronin’s United States debut. If all goes according to plan, Mr. Bärtsch will engage the drummer Kaspar Rast, the percussionist Andi Pupato, the bassist Björn Meyer and the clarinetist Stefan Haslebacher in a tricky yet ethereal interaction that’s more vivid in performance than on record. Maybe it will be meditative, and maybe it will get funky. Whatever the case, the crowd response will surely outdo the sound of one hand clapping. (Tuesday at 7:30 p.m

The Galápagos Islands have been added to a list of endangered World Heritage sites maintained by the United Nations. The archipelago, home to a array of species that inspired Charles Darwin to form his theory of natural selection, has seen annual tourist visits grow to 120,000 from 40,000 in 1996. Introduced plants now outnumber native plants, according to a report prepared by naturalists for a United Nations committee that keeps track of cultural and natural sites of international significance. Altogether 29 out of 830 heritage sites are listed as ''in danger,'' a spur to greater conservation efforts, The full list is at whc.unesco.org.

For some reason, a large slice of America is obsessed with how much money Hollywood rakes in every weekend. News organizations lead the way, dutifully recording box-office receipts like diligent accountants. Why this happens escapes us, but it is what it is. So let's look at last weekend, when theaters began showing the new Angelina Jolie film, ''A Mighty Heart.'' It landed with a mighty thud, taking in a pitiful $4 million. That put it in 10th place, well behind the leader, a frothy offering called ''Evan Almighty.''

Shares of Beazer Homes USA fell as much as 9.5 percent yesterday, the most since March, after the company fired its chief accounting officer, saying he tried to destroy documents during an F.B.I. investigation. Beazer, based in Atlanta, terminated the accounting officer, Michael T. Rand, after an internal investigation of the company's mortgage unit, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, after the close of regular stock market trading. A message left at Mr. Rand's home was not immediately returned.

William Hutt, one of the foremost Canadian stage actors of his generation and a founding member of the Stratford Festival of Canada in Ontario, where he appeared in or directed 130 productions, died on Wednesday in a Stratford hospital. He was 87. The cause was leukemia, according to the festival's press office.

An obituary yesterday of Tina L. Brozman, a former New York bankruptcy judge, misstated a holding of Maxwell Communication, on whose 1991 bankruptcy case she worked. It was the parent of The Daily News of New York, not The New York Post.

The moral of ''Ratatouille'' is delivered by a critic: a gaunt, unsmiling fellow named Anton Ego who composes his acidic notices in a coffin-shaped room and who speaks in the parched baritone of Peter O'Toole. ''Not everyone can be a great artist,'' Mr. Ego muses. ''But a great artist can come from anywhere.'' Quite so. Written and directed by Brad Bird and displaying the usual meticulousness associated with the Pixar brand, ''Ratatouille'' is a nearly flawless piece of popular art, as well as one of the most persuasive portraits of an artist ever committed to film. It provides the kind of deep, transporting pleasure, at once simple and sophisticated, that movies at their best have always promised.

During an interview on a Boston radio station earlier this month, in anticipation of the San Francisco Giants coming to town, Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling was asked if Barry Bonds was at home run No. 754 and Schilling was pitching, would he give Bonds a pitch to hit.
