To the Editor: Re ''Honoring Rushdie'' (editorial, June 26):

To the Editor: New York's second-home owners have broader voting rights than your June 22 article ''The Principle of 2nd Home, 2nd Vote'' may lead readers to infer. Second-home owners have the perfect right to register and vote at their beach or country homes, even if their primary residence is elsewhere. New York State law gives dual resident voters the right to choose either their primary or their secondary home as their voting residence for all purposes, as long as they have legitimate, significant and continuing attachments to both places. Choosing one, of course, means voting only there, except in those few localities that make a special exception for voting in local elections.

Switzerland's main watchmaking group urged the government to tighten the rules on what can be called a Swiss watch to stop timepieces with too many foreign parts from reaching the market. Under a proposal by the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry, at least 80 percent of a mechanical watch or 60 percent of an electronic one would have to be made in Switzerland for it to be called ''Swiss made,'' the group said. The proposal, approved by 87 percent of the federation's members, will be sent to the government for consideration. The existing ordinance says at least 50 percent must be Swiss made.

Through four days, everything is as expected here -- the strawberries are perfectly ripe, the clouds have made good on their threats of rain, and the draw has proved to be a fine predictor of the results. An improbably dry and sunny day let Wimbledon catch up Thursday to its schedule after days of intermittent delays. Two rounds of the men's and women's singles draw are complete, and each field has been reduced to 32.

Ramzee Robinson, who earned the title Mr. Irrelevant as the final player selected in the 2007 N.F.L. draft, agreed on a three-year contract with the Detroit Lions, his agent said. Robinson, a cornerback, was the last of 255 players selected in April. Financial terms were not disclosed.

This new cedar-sided house is on nearly five acres within 540 acres of preserved land. The house is 5,200 square feet and has four and a half bathrooms, a den, a family room and a formal dining room. There are oak floors, two masonry fireplaces and a back deck. Agent: Sheri Winter Clarry, Corcoran Group; (631) 899-0613; www.corcoran.com/sclarry.

The epic villainy of Walter O'Malley for moving the Dodgers west is like a family legend told through baseball generations: Come on and listen to this story of unparalleled baseball greed, my son. In following the money to Los Angeles, O'Malley initiated a half-century's burst of nostalgia for the old team, for Jackie, Duke, Gil and Pee Wee, for Red Barber and Hilda Chester, for Ebbets Field and for what Brooklyn used to be and could have been.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the dearth of university students in Japan misstated the reason that the numbers of college-age children of baby boom parents there peaked in 1992, years earlier than the American peak. It was because Japan's baby boom was concentrated in the years immediately following World War II, while the American boom lasted until 1962. It was not because Japan's boom started earlier; both started in 1946.

Three workers for the city's Bureau of Water Supply have been charged with participating in an illegal gun sale on city property, the Department of Investigation said yesterday. Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation, said a supervisor and two subordinates were charged in connection with the supervisor's purchase of a .45-caliber pistol in the parking lot of a city water facility in the Delaware County hamlet of Grand Gorge. Ms. Gill Hearn said the supervisor, Thomas Ganz, 36 of Grahamsville, N.Y., was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a misdemeanor. The subordinates, James Geraghty, 38, of Stamford, N.Y., and George Pennell Jr., 39, of Liberty, N.Y., were charged with falsifying business records, the department said. Dianne Struzzi, a department spokeswoman, said Mr. Geraghty, who sold the weapon, and Mr. Pennell falsely claimed that Mr. Pennell, who has a pistol permit, was the buyer. Mr. Ganz does not have a valid permit, she said.

President Bush moved one step closer to a constitutional showdown with Democrats on Thursday, as the White House asserted executive privilege in refusing to comply with Congressional subpoenas for documents related to the dismissal of federal prosecutors. The move prompted Democrats to accuse the White House of stonewalling, and seemed to put the legislative and executive branches on a collision course that could land them in court. It was the second time in Mr. Bush's presidency that he has formally asserted executive privilege, the power first recognized by the Supreme Court in a 1974 Watergate-era case.

Willie Randolph and the Mets were not happy that they were scheduled to play the finale of their four-game series with Cardinals last night. They would have preferred an afternoon game, so they could leisurely make their way to Philadelphia for today's day-night doubleheader against the Phillies. But where the schedule maker did not cooperate, Mother Nature did. Last night's game was rained out, so the Mets will begin their four-game series against the Phillies without circles under their eyes.
DANCE Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

Kobe Bryant is still a Los Angeles Laker despite a trade request, and his acidic discontent is now being broadcast on the Internet. An amateur video of Bryant's profanity-laced rant about the Lakers, which first made news last week, was posted on thekobevideo.com Web site yesterday morning. An audio-only file, in which Bryant calls the Lakers' owner, Jerry Buss, an idiot is also on the site.

TAM, Brazil's largest airline by passengers carried, agreed to purchase 26 Airbus planes for around $5.4 billion to expand its international routes. The airline, based in São Paulo, said it signed a deal to buy 22 Airbus A350 planes and exercised an earlier option to buy 4 A330 models. The company secured an option to buy 10 additional A350s in the future. The A330s will be delivered in 2010 and 2011. TAM operates direct flights to Paris, London, Milan, New York and Miami.

People UBS, the European bank, has hired William A. Houlihan, 52, a former chief financial officer of Hudson United Bancorp, as a managing director focusing on financial services companies. He comes to UBS from Sedgwick Claims Management Services, an administrator of health care and workers' compensation claims.

A Brooklyn teenager was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old Brooklyn man on the subway Wednesday evening, the police said. The police said the suspect, Stephen Scott, 17, had had an argument earlier in the day with the victim, Trevell Belton, before he shot Mr. Belton on the Q train at Avenue U. Witnesses led investigators to Mr. Scott, who was also charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said.

The chairman of the California Air Resources Board, Robert Sawyer, resigned just days after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger expressed displeasure at his board's delay of an antismog plan. Dr. Sawyer, a prominent air-quality expert and professor emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley, was appointed to the board by the governor 18 months ago. On Friday, however, Mr. Schwarzenegger issued a statement saying he was ''deeply disappointed'' by a board decision to seek an 11-year delay in enforcement of federal air-quality standards in the San Joaquin Valley, south of Fresno. Mr. Schwarzenegger has made reducing emissions a priority of his second term.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,561 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday: WINDER, Nathan L., 32, Sgt. First Class, Army; Blanding, Utah; Second Battalion, First Special Forces Group.
Washington LET us now praise the Brown decision. Let us now bury the Brown decision.
To the Editor: Re ''New Scrutiny as Immigrants Die in Custody'' (front page, June 26):

Mark Messier was on a cruise with his parents and Scott Stevens was about to clean his kitchen floor yesterday when they received the news that they had been elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame. ''I still don't have the floor done yet,'' Stevens said three hours later.

To the Editor: It's an astonishingly surrealistic world that Col. Morris D. Davis evokes in his elegy to the Guantánamo Bay prison (''The Guantánamo I Know,'' Op-Ed, June 26), and his praise of the brand of justice dispensed by the Defense Department's Office of Military Commissions.

The Constitutional Court lent its support to a government policy of withholding remains of suspected terrorists, a practice causing anguish among families in the Caucasus. Under the policy, bodies are either secretly buried or cremated. Muslim relatives have complained, saying that withholding the dead punishes families, not terrorists, and that no due process determines whether the dead were terrorists at all. Russia calls the practice an effective deterrent. The authorities have withheld remains in several prominent cases, including of leaders in the Chechen separatist movement. After militants briefly besieged the city of Nalchik in 2005, the authorities stacked more than 100 bodies in an unrefrigerated container. It later cremated them all, as relatives begged for their return.

An article on Wednesday about the filing of federal charges against 29 people accused in plots to smuggle nearly $700 million in real and counterfeit goods from China into the United States misstated the given name of one of those charged, an owner of a trucking company. He is Joseph DePaola, not John.
To the Editor: Re ''Senate Adopts an Energy Bill Calling for Higher Mileage for Cars'' (news article, June 22):

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign announced yesterday that it would raise ''in the range of $27 million'' for the second quarter of 2007, which ends Saturday night, and also warned supporters to prepare for a similarly dazzling result by a leading Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama. While Mr. Obama has declined to provide an estimate of second-quarter fund-raising figures, the campaign yesterday sought to signal its financial strength by disclosing that more than 250,000 people had contributed to his presidential race.

Greg Oden is not a destination snob. Without an ounce of hat envy, Oden tugged on a white Portland cap last night, eager for an eco-friendly embrace from thousands of outdoorsy folks who have one indoor vice: the Trail Blazers. He will take his No. 1 draft status and happily disappear into the Pacific Northwest, where he will play in a 50-watt market for a quirky billionaire owner with a Jimi Hendrix fixation.

A front-page article last Friday about nonprofit organizations created by John Edwards that helped keep his political profile alive after the 2004 election referred imprecisely to a donation made to an Edwards campaign committee. Although an individual donor was not identified, the donation was credited to Oak Spring Farms LLC, which listed a New York hotel as its address. The donation was not ''anonymous.'' The article also misstated the title of one of Mr. Edwards's campaign advisers. David Ginsberg is a senior adviser for communications; he is not the campaign's deputy campaign manager, a post currently held by Jonathan Prince.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about evolution and the soul misstated the views that Nancey Murphy, a philosopher at Fuller Theological Seminary, expresses in her book ''Bodies and Souls, or Spirited Bodies?'' Dr. Murphy argues that neither humans nor animals have souls, not that both have souls. She cited the ideas of Thomas Aquinas on animal and human souls to contrast with her view, not to support it.

Three men were shot, one fatally, yesterday afternoon around the Willis Avenue Bridge in Mott Haven, the police said. According to the police, the victims were chased by an unknown number of young men starting at East 131st Street and Willis Avenue before they were shot. The police said they did not have a motive for the shooting and had not been able to identify the assailants. One victim, a 22-year-old man, was shot in the head on the bridge around 4:15 p.m., and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The other two men, a 19-year-old who was shot in the buttocks and the leg and a 17-year-old who was shot in the hip, were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and were reported in stable condition. The police did not identify the victims, but at the hospital last night, a family member, Janis Mackey, said the 17-year-old was Edward Steele of Harlem, her grandson. ''They don't know why they were shot,'' she said. ''They were in the wrong neighborhood.''

Transportation Security Administration officers at Kennedy International Airport have begun taking over the task of checking passengers' identification as they approach the security checkpoint, agency officials said this week. The transfer from private contractors to federal security officers is part of an effort to actively look for false documents or signs that a passenger may be acting suspiciously, Ellen Howe, an agency spokeswoman, said on Tuesday. So far, the document checkers are at only some Kennedy security checkpoints, officials said.

A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on June 15, about the Japanese artist and curator Takashi Murakami, misspelled the name of the art show he runs. It is Geisai, not Gesai. It also misstated the policy of his company, Kaikai Kiki, on taking a 10 percent agent's fee for works sold at the show. It does not always take a fee, and in Miami in December it plans to waive it for young artists.

Gazprom, Russia's natural gas export monopoly, said 2006 profit doubled, to a record $22.6 billion, beating estimates, as it sold more fuel at higher prices. Net income surged 97 percent, to 613.3 billion rubles, from 311.1 billion rubles a year earlier, the state-run company said. The profit equals $22.6 billion at the average ruble rate for the period and is 8.2 percent higher than the median estimate of six analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Rising prices in Europe, where Gazprom has a quarter of the market, and increased shipments to former Soviet nations drove the gain in earnings, the highest ever reported by a Russian company. Gazprom, based in Moscow, relies entirely on exports for profit because it loses money on sales in Russia, where prices are capped.
To the Editor: Re ''Boy's Drowning Bolsters a Call for Safer Pools'' (news article, June 25):
People
To the Editor: Re ''In Birdsong, a Call to Protect the Earth'' (letters, June 22):
To the Editor: Re ''On Abortion, Giuliani Faces a Potential Fall From Catholic Grace'' (news article, June 25):

During an interview on a Boston radio station earlier this month, in anticipation of the San Francisco Giants coming to town, Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling was asked if Barry Bonds was at home run No. 754 and Schilling was pitching, would he give Bonds a pitch to hit. ''Not on purpose,'' Schilling said. ''I don't want to be Al Downing.''

President Bush on Thursday raised the anticipated death of the dictator Fidel Castro as an opportunity to push for democracy in Cuba, which he called the ''one nondemocracy in our neighborhood.'' ''One day, the good Lord will take Fidel Castro away,'' Mr. Bush said during remarks here at the Naval War College.

President Bush came to the Naval War College here Thursday to press the case for his military strategy in Iraq, even as his National Security Adviser met with Congressional Republicans who have been expressing dissatisfaction with the approach. It was part of a continuing attempt by the administration to shore up its support in the weeks before Congress takes up a critical debate over military spending for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1.

British house prices advanced this month at the fastest pace since December, bolstering the case for an interest rate increase by the Bank of England next week. The average cost of a home rose 1.1 percent from May, to £184,070 ($368,000), according to the Nationwide Building Society, the biggest mortgage lender in Britain. ''The bounce-back in June is a bit stronger than expected,'' said Fionnuala Earley, chief economist at Nationwide. ''It looks like the bank will bring forward the decision to increase interest rates, and increase the risk that rates get to 6 percent this year.''

A Long Island bar owner pleaded not guilty yesterday to federal arson charges that accuse him of ordering a stationery store on the same block as his bar firebombed. An indictment alleges that the bar owner, Carmine Graziano, 45, hired two men to set fire to the shop, Roseanne's Cards Galore in New Hyde Park, in August 2003 in retaliation for complaints the owners made about noise and under-age drinking at his bar, Copperfield's Pub. Mr. Graziano was ordered held without bail yesterday after his arraignment in Federal District Court in Central Islip. Surveillance tapes show two men throwing a rock and then a Molotov cocktail through the store's front window, prosecutors said. The fire forced the evacuation of several apartments above the store, which was destroyed; there were no serious injuries.

An obituary yesterday of the fashion designer Liz Claiborne misstated the duration of her working relationship with Arthur Ortenberg, her husband, before the founding of Liz Claiborne Inc. in 1976. Mr. Ortenberg was Ms. Claiborne's boss for two years, beginning in 1954, not for two decades. The obituary also misidentified the object of the couple's wildlife conservation efforts in Madagascar. Their foundation sought to rescue the ''fish-eagle,'' an endangered bird there; they were not trying to save fish and eagles.

A front-page article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by Rebecca Charles, a Manhattan chef who has charged a competitor with unfairly copying her restaurant's concept, design and menu, referred imprecisely to another chef, David Burke, who has also asserted intellectual property rights. Mr. Burke, who received, and later gave up, a trademark for the term ''swordfish chop,'' also applied for a trademark on the term ''salmon pastrami,'' according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. He did not receive a trademark on the term ''salmon pastrami.''
To the Editor: Re ''Muslims' Veils Test Limits of Britain's Tolerance'' (front page, June 22):

Rodrigo de Rato, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, will quit his post in October, two years before his term ends, the fund said yesterday, citing ''personal reasons.'' Mr. de Rato, 58, a former Spanish economy minister who has led the agency, based in Washington, since June 2004, will leave after the annual meetings of the fund and the World Bank, the statement said.

This new cedar-sided house is on nearly five acres within 540 acres of preserved land. The house is 5,200 square feet and has four and a half bathrooms, a den, a family room and a formal dining room. There are oak floors, two masonry fireplaces and a back deck. Agent: Sheri Winter Clarry, Corcoran Group; (631) 899-0613; www.corcoran.com/sclarry.

This 2,500-square-foot house, built in 1972, has three bathrooms and a one-car garage. The property is just under an acre and is near a beach on the bay. Agent: Vincent Spadola, Lloyd's Realty; (631) 734-9455; www.lloydsrealty.com. Information on properties was supplied by the listing companies.

On three-quarters of an acre on Deep Hole Creek, which leads to Peconic Bay, this 3,200-square-foot Cape has creek views, three bathrooms, a back deck and a dock for a boat up to 30 feet. There are granite counters and oak floors in the eat-in kitchen. There is a den with fireplace. Agent: Charles Mogul, Andrew Stype Realty; (631) 298-8760; www.stype.com.

Striking down an antitrust rule nearly a century old, the Supreme Court ruled today that it is no longer automatically unlawful for manufacturers and distributors to agree on setting minimum retail prices. The decision will give producers significantly more leeway, though not unlimited power, to dictate retail prices and to restrict the flexibility of discounters.

This 2,500-square-foot house, built in 1972, has three bathrooms and a one-car garage. The property is just under an acre and is near a beach on the bay. Agent: Vincent Spadola, Lloyd's Realty; (631) 734-9455; www.lloydsrealty.com. Information on properties was supplied by the listing companies.

In October 2003, the nonpartisan Program on International Policy Attitudes published a study titled ''Misperceptions, the media and the Iraq war.'' It found that 60 percent of Americans believed at least one of the following: clear evidence had been found of links between Iraq and Al Qaeda; W.M.D. had been found in Iraq; world public opinion favored the U.S. going to war with Iraq. The prevalence of these misperceptions, however, depended crucially on where people got their news. Only 23 percent of those who got their information mainly from PBS or NPR believed any of these untrue things, but the number was 80 percent among those relying primarily on Fox News. In particular, two-thirds of Fox devotees believed that the U.S. had ''found clear evidence in Iraq that Saddam Hussein was working closely with the Al Qaeda terrorist organization.''

Stanford, Calif. MILK occupies a special place in our lives and language. It has been dubbed ''nature's most perfect food,'' and we speak sentimentally of the ''land of milk and honey'' and the ''milk of human kindness.''
To the Editor: Re ''Research Finds Firstborns Gain the Higher I.Q.'' (front page, June 22):

Relief supplies have been slow to arrive in parts of Pakistan where flooding from Cyclone Yemyin washed away roads, including this section of the Coastal Highway at Turbat, in the southwest. About 450 people have been killed in recent days as storms swept across Pakistan and Afghanistan.

An obituary on Tuesday of J. B. Handelsman, a cartoonist whose work appeared in The New Yorker, included incorrect information from the Web site of The New Yorker for the caption of one of his cartoons for the magazine. The original caption, with a cartoon showing a maitre d'hotel speaking by telephone to a would-be diner, read: ''Certainly. A party of four at seven-thirty in the name of Dr. Jennings. May I ask whether that is an actual medical degree or merely a Ph.D.?'' The caption in the Web site's tribute to Mr. Handelsman, which was quoted in the obituary, omitted the word ''merely.''

Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review of ''The Irish Play,'' at the Irish Arts Center on West 51st Street in Manhattan, misidentified the Web site that gives complete information and offers online ticket purchases. It is hammandclov.org, not irishartscenter.org.
The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race. CHIEF JUSTICE JOHN G. ROBERTS JR.,

Just three weeks after the most horrendous accident in Formula One in years, when Robert Kubica, escaped injury at the Canadian Grand Prix, the GP2 series support race had its version of a miracle at Magny-Cours on Saturday. On the first lap of the race Ernesto Viso went flying through the air and hit a concrete wall in the car upside down and then spun along the top of the wall for what seemed like forever, before the car landed hard on the other side of the wall and continued its tumble. The race was stopped for an hour as the driver was extracted from his car and sent to hospital. He is reported to be in stable condition, and basically unhurt. Like the accident in Canada, this was another of the kind where it seemed nearly impossible for the driver to have survived. Twice lucky. But it is impossible not to think of Alain Prost's words before the death of Ayrton Senna in Imola, after Rubens Barrichello had a serious accident on the Friday and Roland Ratzenberger was killed on the Saturday. Prost spoke of his belief in the "law of series." Thank goodness the sport has never ceased its driver for safety since then.

The following video may not be suitable for all viewers. In it, PC World's correspondent attempts to damage a shiny new iPhone by shaking it in a Ziplock bag full of keys; by keying it deliberately; by dropping it repeatedly onto concrete; and more. Even I was surprised by the results.

Jean Todt, the Ferrari director, Michael Schumacher, Max Mosley and others have been supporting an interesting medical project for the past several years. Called the Institute for Cerebral and Medullary Disorders, it was founded out of the collaboration of three medical men, Professor Gérard Saillant, an orthopedist and traumatologist and Yves Agid and Olivier Lyon-Caen, neurologists. Saillant has helped heal injured F1 drivers for years, including Schumacher when he broke his leg in 1999 at the British Grand Prix.

In her news analysis, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, a White House correspondent for The Times, wrote that "a string of Republican defections this week" put the president "in danger of losing control over a party that once marched in lockstep with him." Each of the defections - on Iraq, immigration and domestic eavesdropping - is featured on this week's Sunday breakfast menu.
New York Times reporter Susan Saulny visits the East New Orleans street that her parents hope to come back to by Thanksgiving.

With this week's failure of the immigration bill, loathed by many G.O.P. voters and championed by Senator John McCain, talk of trouble for his campaign is picking up volume. Michael Finnegan of The Los Angeles Times examines what one Republican strategist calls a "confluence of forces" working against Mr. McCain:

Bell Canada's directors endorsed a privatization offer worth 35 billion Canadian dollars ($33 billion) from the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners early Saturday, The New York Times reported.

Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, drew his fifth round game against Peter Leko of Hungary and maintained his half-point lead at the Dortmund super tournament with two rounds to play. Trailing him a half-point behind were Viswanathan Anand of India, the world's top-ranked player, and Evgeny Alekseev of Russia. The official Web site for the tournament is here.
In Afghanistan, a bomber's end comes in a flash of terror and a humble grave.
James Blake, the ninth seed, stumbled through his latest disappointment, losing his third-round match in four sets to Juan Carlos Ferrero.
Several experts and officials said that the technology behind two thwarted car bombings in central London seemed to be amateurish.
If approved, the deal would be Canada’s largest takeover and among the largest leveraged buyouts in history.
A young woman was killed last night in an accident on a ride at Playland Amusement Park in Rye, N.Y., a police spokesman said.
The day after the Senate failed to move on a proposal for a broad change in immigration law, it was time to take stock.
Greg Winter and Michael Wines discuss the disastrous spiral that is Zimbabwe’s economy.
Mike Mussina pitched seven sharp innings and Alex Rodriguez had three hits as the  Yankees opened a key 10-game homestand after a disastrous 1-7 road trip.
Authorities say that there was no evidence of terrorist activity at the home of  Miguel Serran, 57, who is facing a felony charge of reckless endangerment.
A new noise code takes effect in New York City this weekend, with fines ranging from $70 for a barking dog to $8,000 for a noisy nightclub.
Baltimore’s Aubrey Huff hit for the cycle last night, but the Los Angeles Angels got a tie-breaking two-run homer from Howie Kendrick in the ninth inning and beat the Orioles, 9-7.
A man accused of swindling diamond dealers out of $3 million worth of stones has fled the country, according to law enforcement officials.

A former San Bernardino County sheriff’s deputy was acquitted Thursday in a videotaped shooting of an unarmed Iraq war veteran who was a passenger in a car that crashed after leading the authorities on a high-speed chase. The former deputy, Ivory J. Webb, was found not guilty of attempted voluntary manslaughter and assault with a firearm for opening fire on Senior Airman Elio Carrion of the Air Force, in an incident that was videotaped and broadcast around the world, said Susan Mickey, a district attorney’s spokeswoman. Mr. Webb, 46, who has left the department, had faced up to 18 years in prison. Airman Carrion was hospitalized for several days after the shooting.

The Louisiana Supreme Court reversed the first-degree murder convictions of a man found guilty of killing four people in 2000. The man, Shon Miller, was convicted of shooting and killing his mother-in-law, Mildred Vessel, 53, outside her home. He then went to a church in Gonzales and shot his wife, Carla Vessel Miller, 25; his son, Shon Jr., 2; and a church deacon, Vaniaro Jackson, 19. The court ruled that a judge’s pre-trial rulings prevented Mr. Miller from pleading not guilty by reason of insanity which resulted in a “constitutionally flawed jury trial.” Prosecutors said they planned to seek a new trial as soon as possible.
The mothers of five children killed in a house fire in Pittsburgh were ordered to stand trial on involuntary manslaughter charges.
Gov. Linda Lingle announced the resignation of her chief of staff, Bob Awana, who is linked to two federal investigations.
A Justice Department official, Rachel L. Brand, who was considered as a possible replacement for one of several fired United States attorneys, has resigned.
On the Fourth of July, a floating pool built on a barge on the Brooklyn waterfront will finally be ready for bathers.
Zach Randolph will pull on a Knicks jersey on Monday, and will spend every day thereafter getting fitted for a new image under the bright lights of the big city.
The police said they had discovered 1.2 tons of cocaine on board a deserted boat that apparently had drifted to the coastal resort of Mbour.
Almost all of the 185,000 gallons of alcohol seized from smugglers trying to sneak beer, wine and liquor into Sweden last year was turned into alternative fuel.
In an effort to turn a page on a reputation for entrenched government corruption, Nigeria’s new president, Umaru Yar’Adua, has taken the unusual step of declaring his net worth.
The Security Council voted to shut down the U.N. units that had searched for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in Iraq before the United States-led invasion.
Hungry victims of floods in southwestern Pakistan rioted, protesting slow, meager aid reaching their marooned villages.

A music review on Tuesday about the alto saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa and the pianist Vijay Iyer, at the Rubin Museum in a JVC Jazz Festival concert, misidentified the people for whom Mr. Iyer wrote the ballad “Remembrance,” which was performed. Although Mr. Iyer dedicated the performance to the pianist Andrew Hill, he wrote the piece as a tribute to his grandparents, not for Mr. Hill.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the trial of the former media executive Conrad M. Black misidentified the London paper that Mr. Black’s former company, Hollinger International, once owned. It is The Daily Telegraph, not The Times of London.

An article on Thursday about growing urbanization included incorrect information from a report by the United Nations Population Fund for the number of Chinese cities expected to have the largest populations over the next decade. Of the 139 cities that had more than 750,000 residents in 2005, nine are projected to have more than 5 million people in 2015; China will not have, as the report said, 83 cities of more than 750,000 within a decade, with six of those having more than 5 million inhabitants.

A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about a scientific advance in the effort to create synthetic life forms misidentified the scientist pictured. He is J. Craig Venter, who directs the institute that made the breakthrough, not Hamilton Smith, a biologist who worked on the project. The article also misstated the educational affiliation of George Church, a biologist who commented on the research. He is at Harvard Medical School, not M.I.T.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about BlackRock’s acquisition of the “fund of funds” business of the Quellos Group misstated the total amount of assets that Quellos manages. It is $20 billion, not $200 billion.

An article on Tuesday about a presentation of New York City’s “congestion pricing” proposal to federal transportation officials in Washington gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the amount of federal money being sought to finance the proposal. It is $536.9 million, not $539 million.

A sports article in some copies yesterday about the Yankees-Orioles game, which was suspended in the eighth inning because of rain after the Yankees had taken an 8-6 lead, referred incorrectly to Major League Baseball’s rule about handling games that are called after the visiting team takes a lead but before the home team has had a chance to bat again. It has been in place since the beginning of the 1980 season; it was not instituted through a rule change before this season. (Yankees Manager Joe Torre mistakenly suggested that his team had benefited because of the recent rule change, but that policy governs the handling of suspended games that are tied.).

An art review in Weekend on June 1 about “182nd Annual: An Exhibition of Contemporary American Art,” at the National Academy Museum on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, referred incompletely to a show at the museum earlier this year, which was cited as an example of shows the academy has been mounting to emphasize its relevance. Although the show, “High Times, Hard Times: New York Painting 1967-1975,” was exhibited at the academy, it was a traveling exhibition organized by Independent Curators International.

A television review on Tuesday about “The Great Inca Rebellion,” on PBS, misidentified the language spoken by a majority of South Americans. While Spanish is more widespread geographically, a small majority of the continent speaks Portuguese — not Spanish — because of Brazil’s large population.
An article in Business Day on Thursday about the trial of Conrad M. Black misstated the makeup of the jury. It has 11 women and 4 men, not 6 women and 6 men.

A review on Page 6 of the Book Review this weekend misstates part of the title of the book by Chris Mooney. As noted in the table of contents and in the bibliographical note, it is “Storm World,” not “Warning.”.

An article on Thursday about growing urbanization included incorrect information from a report by the United Nations Population Fund for the number of Chinese cities expected to have the largest populations over the next decade. Of the 139 cities that had more than 750,000 residents in 2005, nine are projected to have more than 5 million people in 2015; China will not have, as the report said, 83 cities of more than 750,000 within a decade, with six of those having more than 5 million inhabitants.

Sachin Tendulkar became the first player to reach 15,000 runs in one-day internationals while steering India to a six-wicket victory yesterday against South Africa in the Future Cup in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The 34-year-old Tendulkar scored 93 to help India reach its target of 227 with five balls to spare and level the three-match series, 1-1.

A beachside guest house owned by Tiger Woods was destroyed by fire yesterday. No one was in the house, which is in Jupiter Island on Florida’s east coast. A fire official said the fire was caused by lightning. Woods’s residence is near Orlando.

After holding a two-shot lead at the turn yesterday in the Buick Open, Brett Quigley had to scramble to save par on one of the course’s easiest holes and finished the second round in a three-way tie with Jim Furyk and Kenny Perry. All three were at 10-under 134 at the Warwick Hills Golf Club in Grand Blanc, Mich. Perry, the 2001 Buick Open champion, birdied five of his first seven holes and lifted himself from a tie for 73rd with a nine-under 63, a career low.Rocco Mediate (71), the first-round leader, and Scott Verplank (69) and Brian Bateman (70) were one stroke back.

Walter McCarty, a former Kentucky star who played 10 seasons in the N.B.A., has rejoined his mentor, Rick Pitino, as an assistant basketball coach at Louisville. “To be back here with him, it means a lot,” McCarty said yesterday. He played for Pitino in 1996, when Kentucky won the N.C.A.A. title.McCarty replaced Marvin Menzies, who was introduced yesterday as the head coach at New Mexico State. Menzies replaced Reggie Theus, another former assistant to Pitino at Louisville, who left to coach the Sacramento Kings. Theus rebuilt the New Mexico State program in two seasons.

The National Hockey League salary cap for 2007-8 will rise to $50.3 million per team, an increase of $6.3 million, the league and the players union said yesterday. Each club’s payroll must be at least $34.3 million.

Daniel Brière broke off negotiations with the Buffalo Sabres and will test the free-agent market when it opens tomorrow. Brière finished 10th in the league with 95 points (32 goals and 63 assists). But Brière’s agent, Pat Brisson, did not rule out a re-signing with Buffalo.

The Los Angeles Galaxy have traded midfielder Santino Quaranta to the Red Bulls for a conditional pick in the fourth round of next year’s Major League Soccer draft. Quaranta, 22, appeared in six games for the Galaxy this season. He has goals 17 in 80 regular-season M.L.S. games.
Florida signed center Jozef Stumpel to a two-year contract extension yesterday. Stumpel, 34, has 38 goals and 71 assists in 147 games for the Panthers in the past two seasons.

(TMC) DAVE CHAPPELLE’S BLOCK PARTY (2006) “Concert film” hardly begins to describe this movie, directed by Michel Gondry and shot in 2004 on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, above, and in Mr. Chappelle’s hometown in Ohio. It includes appearances by stars like Kanye West, Mos Def, the Roots, Wyclef Jean and Lauryn Hill, along with performances, musical and otherwise, by Mr. Chappelle. HENSHEL--Harry Bulova, on June 29, 2007. Beloved husband, best friend and partner of Joy; adored father of Dayle, Patti, Diane and Judy; grampa of Artemis, Ariel, Jaron and Tasha; loving friend and brother-in-law of Sam Altman, after a long illness. Former Chairman and CEO of Bulova Watch Corporation, also active trustee of Surprise Lake Camp, FEGS and Westchester Philharmonic. A philanthropist, he actively supported those organizations and others, as well as his alma mater Brown University. He loved the track; horseracing and breeding were a life-long avocation. He was and will be remembered as a kind, caring, ethical and gentle man who loved his family and friends, who loved him in return. His wisdom and humor will be missed. Funeral services will be at 10am, Sunday, July 1, 2007 at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale. A music review on Tuesday about the alto saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa and the pianist Vijay Iyer, at the Rubin Museum in a JVC Jazz Festival concert, misidentified the people for whom Mr. Iyer wrote the ballad ''Remembrance,'' which was performed. Although Mr. Iyer dedicated the performance to the pianist Andrew Hill, he wrote the piece as a tribute to his grandparents, not for Mr. Hill.

IF the reaction is anything to go by, the decision by the blog-advertising network Federated Media to deploy its writers to produce marketing copy for Microsoft and Cisco Systems may have set back by a notch or two the efforts of professional bloggers to gain credibility. Federated handles ads for several of the most popular blogs that cover technology and business: TechCrunch, GigaOM, Boing Boing, VentureBeat and several others. Late last week, Nick Denton of the Silicon Valley gossip site Valleywag noticed that several of Federated's bloggers had contributed to a marketing site created for Microsoft.
ENTES--Rose. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Services at Riverside on Sunday July 1st at 11:15am at 180 West 76th Street.

Previous presidents of this vast and often troubled nation are believed to have pocketed billions of dollars from the country's vast oil wealth. In an effort to turn a page on a reputation for entrenched government corruption, Nigeria's new president, Umaru Yar'Adua, has taken the unusual step of declaring his net worth as he begins his four-year term. In papers made public yesterday, Mr. Yar'Adua, a former chemistry teacher, said he had about $5 million in assets, most of it inherited from family members. Nigerian law requires that politicians disclose their assets to the government, but they are not required to make the information public. Mr. Yar'Adua said through a spokesman that he hoped to set an example of transparency in his administration.

NASH--Eric, M.D. Age 96. Born in Holesov, Czechoslovakia. Beloved husband of Liliane, cherished father of Thomas and Peggy, adoring grandfather of Gregory, Katie, Stefanie and Michael, devoted father-in-law of Edward and Elizabeth. Services Sunday July 1st, 12 pm at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer'', Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills, NY. Contributions in memory may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage, attn: Yael Reisman 36 Battery Place, New York, NY 10280.

Columbia University said yesterday that it had selected the architectural firm Davis Brody Bond Aedas to work with Renzo PianoBuilding Workshop (architects of the new headquarters of The New York Times) in the first phase of the university's proposed $7 billion expansion in Manhattanville, also known as West Harlem. The site of the proposed expansion is a 17-acre area just north of Columbia's campus in Morningside Heights. Most of the construction in the first phase will take place in the area bounded by 125th Street, on the south and 130th Street on the north, between 12th Avenue and Broadway, and includes three new buildings: a science center, a graduate school of business and a mixed-use facility. The university's expansion plans, first announced in 2003, are opposed by some in the affected area and are currently under review by the city.

Providence, R.I. IF you sail due south from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, you will eventually come to a tiny tear-shaped island with no beaches, no water and no human beings. Navassa, its enormous limestone cliffs rising straight out of the sea, is the oldest continuous overseas possession of the United States, older than Guantánamo, the Virgin Islands, Hawaii, and Alaska. Older than all of them, Navassa contains American history in microcosm.

A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about a scientific advance in the effort to create synthetic life forms misidentified the scientist pictured. He is J. Craig Venter, who directs the institute that made the breakthrough, not Hamilton Smith, a biologist who worked on the project. The article also misstated the educational affiliation of George Church, a biologist who commented on the research. He is at Harvard Medical School, not M.I.T.
HADDAD--Adele. My dear friend and sister-in-law Adele. You are now next to your darling Abe. Rest in peace. I will think about you always. -Freda
COLEMAN--Martin S. and Janet M. -June 30, 1940 -at last where you want to be together. In our hearts always.

More than 130 players will spill into the N.B.A.'s free-agent market after the clock strikes midnight tonight. That makes at least 130 new pawns in the N.B.A.'s real off-season game: the hunt for Kevin Garnett. The 2007 free-agent class is generally lacking in star power. Point guard Chauncey Billups, who led the Detroit Pistons to the 2004 championship, is the most accomplished player in the bunch. Rashard Lewis, who has spent his nine-year career with the Seattle SuperSonics, will probably be the most coveted. Gerald Wallace, a special talent lingering in obscurity in Charlotte, could be the best find.

ROSENBERG--Helen. December 20th, 1920 -June 28th, 2007. Devoted wife of Mortimer for 63 years. Mother of Alan and Joan, and the late Susan. Adoring grandmother of Andy and Melissa, David and Dara, and Elizabeth. Loving great-grandmother of Josh, Madison and Claudia. An accomplished woman who graduated from the Gugenheim School of Dental Hygiene and co-founder of the Dental Clinic for United Cerebral Palsy in Roosevelt, Long Island. An innovative strong woman who did everything well. She will be missed.

MY flight to the rooftops of Manhattan began on a summery evening when I was denied admission to Hell. Like its Biblical namesake, the place I call Hell is below ground level: you have to take three steps down from the sidewalk to enter. Appointed with red walls and staffed by waitresses in red dresses, the joint literally brims with smoke, fire, alcohol, dance music and other manifestations of sin. I used to go to Hell on a regular basis. It's three blocks from my apartment. It's open from 5 p.m. to 3 a.m. And as you may have already surmised, it's a cigar bar operating under a grandfather clause that allows it to survive as one of the few remaining indoor retreats for aficionados of fine tobacco like me.
To the Editor: Re ''Congestion Pricing Deadline'' (editorial, June 25):

Roger Federer, the world's best tennis player, was holding court at Center Court, but gusts of chaos to the Wimbledon brackets were swirling on the courts around him at the All England Club. More than anything, the ups and downs of American tennis were on simultaneous display. James Blake, the ninth seed, stumbled through his latest disappointment, losing his third-round match in four sets to Juan Carlos Ferrero, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3, 7-6 (4), on Court 1. Blake, who was ranked fourth when the year began, has never advanced past the third round at Wimbledon.

Can an antipsychotic drug from the 1950s be paired with a 1980s antibiotic to shrink 21st-century tumors? Might an anticlotting drug help a steroid relieve arthritis? How about a cholesterol treatment and a pain reliever teaming up to tame diabetes? Alexis Borisy, the pharmaceutical industry's master matchmaker, is betting they can. And if he is right, he may have found a cheap and quick way to develop a new cornucopia of medicines.

Seattle THE Watergate break-in, described by Ron Ziegler, then the White House press secretary, as a ''third-rate burglary,'' passes its 35th anniversary this month. The common public perception is that Watergate was the principal cause of President Nixon's downfall. In fact, the seminal cause was a first-rate criminal conspiracy and break-in almost 10 months earlier that led inexorably to Watergate and its subsequent cover-up.

A woman charged with assaulting and robbing the rapper Foxy Brown was released from jail after Ms. Brown failed to appear before a grand jury to testify against her, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Roshawn Anthony, 23, was released from Rikers Island on her own recognizance Thursday but still faces charges of robbery, assault and grand larceny in the alleged attack last Saturday, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office said. Police say she and three other people robbed Ms. Brown of a Louis Vuitton bag, $500 in cash and credit cards in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Ms. Anthony, who has denied the charges, is scheduled to return to court on Aug. 9.

In trucks that roll down the great American roads, the ordinary ruminant -- that is, your basic cow, sheep or bison -- is afforded more space than the average New York subway rider has the faintest prayer of commanding at rush hour. Rhetorical excess? If only. Overcrowding ruins meat, so the industry and federal government have developed standards to reduce stress on the animals, like requiring that they be able to turn freely. Thus, in general, on the way to the slaughterhouse, all livestock have a more comfortable ride than someone traveling, say, on the No. 4 train during rush hour. ''A crowded subway car is stocked much more densely than a cattle or pig truck,'' said Temple Grandin, the author of animal handling guidelines for the American Meat Institute.

An article on Tuesday about a presentation of New York City's ''congestion pricing'' proposal to federal transportation officials in Washington gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the amount of federal money being sought to finance the proposal. It is $536.9 million, not $539 million.

Shakespeare & Company, the 30-year-old theater company based in Lenox, Mass., announced plans yesterday to transform part of a building on its 33-acre campus into a $5 million arts complex that will include a 150-seat theater, rehearsal spaces and costume and set design shops. The complex, scheduled to be ready by spring 2008, will be used by the company and by other theaters and groups that will be able to rent space. The company, which produces plays like ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' bought 63 acres in 1999 for $3.5 million and sold about half of that property in 2005 for $3.9 million. Plans are still in the works to build a version of the Rose Playhouse, a theater that was active in London during the Renaissance.

BROZMAN--Tina. We lost a giant in the legal profession, a trusted adviser and dear friend. Tina was a major force in the development of international insolvency law as bankruptcy judge and practice leader at her law firm. Her outstanding work, guidance and devotion during the past 15 months on the Refco Capital Markets case, while at the same time openly and vigorously battling ovarian cancer, was an inspiration to all involved. On behalf of the thousands of customers and creditors of Refco around the world, I extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Andy, and to her children, Nick, Alix and Wallis. Words cannot express how deeply saddened I am about this tragic loss. Marc S. Kirschner

The character Farfour, a Mickey Mouse look-alike who preached Islamic domination on ''Tomorrow's Pioneers,'' a Hamas-affiliated children's television show was beaten to death in the final episode Friday, The Associated Press reported. The character was killed by an actor posing as an Israeli official trying to buy Farfour's land. ''Farfour was martyred while defending his land,'' said the show's teenage presenter, adding that the character was murdered ''by the killers of children.'' The show, featuring a giant black-and-white rodent with a high-pitched voice, had attracted attention because the character urged Palestinian children to fight Israel. It was broadcast on Al Aqsa Television, affiliated with Hamas. Israeli officials denounced the show as incendiary and outrageous. It was also opposed by the state-run Palestinian Broadcasting Corporation, which is controlled by Fatah, a rival of Hamas.

The Sports Scoreboard in some copies yesterday included outdated results and standings for golf, tennis and several other sports. The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers. Today's Scoreboard is on Page D6.
STRUHL--Dr. Bernard. Today we celebrate your birthday. We love you and miss you. Your Family

Barbra Streisandreceived France's highest civilian honor two days after performing her first concert in the country, BBC News reported yesterday. President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, with Ms. Streisand, presented her with the Legion of Honor at the Élysée Palace in Paris. ''You are the America that we love,'' Mr. Sarkozy said. Guests at the ceremony included the veteran singer Charles Aznavourand the actor Alain Delon. Ms. Streisand, 65, was accompanied by her husband,James Brolin, and her son, Jason Gould. She sang at Bercy Stadium in Paris on Tuesday before 10,000 fans, including Mr. Sarkozy's wife, Cecilia. Recent honorary recipients of the Legion of Honor include Clint Eastwood and the Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan.

An article on Thursday about growing urbanization included incorrect information from a report by the United Nations Population Fund for the number of Chinese cities expected to have the largest populations over the next decade. Of the 139 cities that had more than 750,000 residents in 2005, nine are projected to have more than 5 million people in 2015; China will not have, as the report said, 83 cities of more than 750,000 within a decade, with six of those having more than 5 million inhabitants.

The Security Council voted to shut down the United Nations units that had searched for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in Iraq thought to have been stockpiled by Saddam Hussein. The last inspectors left Iraq in March 2003, shortly before the United States-led invasion that also ended up discovering no banned weapons in the country. The resolution yesterday directed Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to ensure that delicate proliferation information be kept under strict control and that all unspent money, estimated at $60 million, be transferred to the Iraqi government for its development fund. Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador, said, ''There is no longer any reason to believe significant quantities of Saddam-era weapons of mass destruction remain undiscovered in Iraq.''

An art review in Weekend on June 1 about ''182nd Annual: An Exhibition of Contemporary American Art,'' at the National Academy Museum on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, referred incompletely to a show at the museum earlier this year, which was cited as an example of shows the academy has been mounting to emphasize its relevance. Although the show, ''High Times, Hard Times: New York Painting 1967-1975,'' was exhibited at the academy, it was a traveling exhibition organized by Independent Curators International.

PORTLAND, Ore. Every time a soldier from Oregon dies in the Iraq war, Senator Gordon Smith calls up the mother or surviving spouse, and commiserates. His son killed himself four years ago, he tells them. He knows what it's like to lose a boy.

A television review on Tuesday about ''The Great Inca Rebellion,'' on PBS, misidentified the language spoken by a majority of South Americans. While Spanish is more widespread geographically, a small majority of the continent speaks Portuguese -- not Spanish -- because of Brazil's large population.

A review on Page 6 of the Book Review this weekend misstates part of the title of the book by Chris Mooney. As noted in the table of contents and in the bibliographical note, it is ''Storm World,'' not ''Warning.''

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the trial of the former media executive Conrad M. Black misidentified the London paper that Mr. Black's former company, Hollinger International, once owned. It is The Daily Telegraph, not The Times of London.

To the Editor: Re ''Unrest Grows With Gas Lines Amid Rationing in Iran'' (news article, June 29): Perhaps if the Iranian president were to direct his attention less on seeking the destruction of Israel and more on ''bringing income from oil to the nation's households,'' as he promised when running for election, his leadership would not be threatened as reported. M. Fogiel

''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,'' the highly anticipated drama from Aaron Sorkinthat NBC did not renew for a second season because of disappointing ratings, concluded its run Thursday, attracting 4.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The finale won its 10 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, just ahead of CBS's repeat of ''Shark,'' which drew a larger total audience of 7.9 million viewers. Fox led the night over all and had its sixth consecutive Thursday night victory in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox's game show ''Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?'' finished first in the 8 p.m. hour, with 9.1 million viewers, while the one-hour results edition of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' led at 9 with 9.6 million. NBC and CBS shared second place in the 18-to-49 set, although CBS fared better in total viewers with the help of a ''CSI'' rerun at 9 (9.8 million). ABC finished fourth over all.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about BlackRock's acquisition of the ''fund of funds'' business of the Quellos Group misstated the total amount of assets that Quellos manages. It is $20 billion, not $200 billion.

EDEL--Abraham. Esteemed professor of philosophy, author, and John Dewey scholar, died June 22, 2007, in New York City at 98. Cherished husband of Sima Szaluta, the late May Mandelbaum Edel, and the late Elizabeth Flower; loving father of Deborah and the late Matthew (Kim); devoted grandfather of Keir, Gareth and Stephan; and brother of the late Leon Edel. His life work focused on understanding moral values and the role of philosophy in its connection to the social sciences. Thoughtful, knowledgeable, kind and witty, he was beloved and respected by his family, friends, colleagues and many generations of students. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

EZZES--Erwin H. Our beloved Ez died peacefully in his sleep on June 28. He was a man of intelligence, wit and wisdom; generous, charming and kind. Ez was Lt. Colonel Ezzes, Secretary to the General Staff, reporting to General Eisenhower during World War II. He was President and CEO of United Artists Television Corp. and a consultant to 20th Century Fox. He will be forever in our hearts. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, on Sunday, July 1, at 12:45pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Military Academy, Cornwall - on - Hudson, New York 12520 for the Erwin H. Ezzes Scholarship Fund. Marilyn Ezzes Jim Ezzes Steve Ezzes Britt Ezzes Kate Ezzes Ben Ezzes David Binetter
Philadelphia Just as killer bees sting their way upward from Brazil and alien seaweed clogs the waterways of North America, so Mets fans swarm their way to Philadelphia.
To the Editor: Re ''Justices, 5-4, Limit Use of Race for School Integration Plans'' (front page, June 29) and ''Resegregation Now'' (editorial, June 29):

RATHGEBER--Fredrick E., a longtime senior executive of the Prudential Insurance Company, passed away on June 28th at King James Care Center, Chatham, New Jersey. He was 91. He was born on April 22, 1916 in Flushing, New York and attended Flushing High School. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from Williams College in 1936, he joined Prudential as an actuarial student. He held increasingly responsible positions and in 1947, when the company was forming its Western Home Office in Los Angeles, he was assigned there as Assistant General Manager. He returned to Newark in 1954 and was elected Vice President and Associate Actuary. He was elected Senior Vice President and Actuary in April 1959. In that post he played an important part in devising new insurance products and in the training of actuarial students. In 1966 he was elected Executive Vice President and was a member of Prudential's Executive Office when he retired in 1977. During WWII he served in the Navy on the staff of the Commander of the Air Force, Pacific Fleet, at Pearl Harbor. He was discharged as a lieutenant in December, 1945 and returned to Prudential shortly thereafter. A very prominent life actuary, Mr. Rathgeber was a Fellow of the Society of Actuaries and served as a Vice President and Secretary of that organization. He also served as Secretary of the United States section of the International Actuarial Association. He was a member of the Senior Actuaries Club, the American Academy of Actuaries and the New York Actuaries Club. He was an avid and accomplished bridge player and was a Gold Life Master. He served as President of the Whist Club of the Oranges and the Naples Bridge Center, Naples, Florida. Active in many civic and community affairs, Mr. Rathgeber was a former national board member of the American Red Cross and President of the United Way of Essex and West Hudson. He served as Chairman of the following organizations: the Health Insurance Association of America, the Health Insurance Institute, St. Barnabas Medical Center and the Alumni Fund of Williams College. He was a longtime resident of Short Hills, New Jersey. He also spent many years in Naples, Florida and was most recently living at Sunrise Assisted Living in Madison, New Jersey. Mr. Rathgeber was predeceased by two wives: Marjorie Ehni Rathgeber and Dorothy Thropp Rathgeber. He leaves a son and daughter-in-law, John and Lynne Rathgeber of Mendham, New Jersey and four grandchildren: Marjorie Moreno of Baltimore, Maryland and William, Craig and Natalie Rathgeber of Mendham, New Jersey. A private memorial service and interment will be held at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, New Jersey on July 2nd. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the St. Barnabas Medical Center Foundation to benefit the Cancer Center, 94 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey, 07039. Services by Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ. For more information or to send a condolence to the family, please visit www.bradleyfuneralhomes.com

DECTER--Moshe, loving father of Joshua, dear brother-in-law of Anne Fine, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan last Thursday, June 28. His family and many friends including Lou, Ivan, Lori, and his caretaker Marlyn, mourn the loss of this intellectually gifted, deeply ethical, and genuinely caring man. His profound commitment to Jewish causes for the past 50 years inspired many. Funeral services are scheduled for Sunday, July 1, at 1 pm, at Mount Moriah Cemetery of New Jersey, Fairview, New Jersey.

Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, drew his last round game to sew up his eighth win at the prestigious Dortmund tournament. He finished a full point ahead of his closest pursuers. The official Web site of the tournament with the final standings can be seen here.

I just watched the end of the Twins/Tigers game on ESPN. The Tigers won, 1-0. Marcus Thames hit a home run in the bottom of the eighth inning, and Jeremy Bonderman got the win. He's 9-1. (Gary Sheffield didn't play.)

My Monday column is about a public health challenge in the developing world that we rarely think about: worms, and other neglected diseases. I also argue that it's time to recalibrate our efforts and spread our energies and wealth beyond AIDS treatment to these other ailments. Please post your comments here.

The blog Zoo Station has an interesting post about aid and Africa, noting that at the recent TED conference a Ugandan journalist had attacked Bono and the foreign aid lobby. Bono was apparently rather taken aback, but it is indeed a point of view that you hear periodically from Africans. In Rwanda, President Kagame voiced a similar disquiet about aid to us, and Bill Easterly has taken it to great lengths in his book. I think the debate is useful but that more aid is still beneficial, and that health interventions in particular have a good record. To me, Paul Collier's new book, "The Bottom Billion," gets the balance exactly right.
A powerful new book of photos from Darfur has just been published. Strangely, it's a beautiful book -- of horrors. It's available here from Amnesty International's website or from Instantkarma.org.

When I was in middle school it was an insult to say, "Your mama wears combat boots." That comment usually followed a different gut-wrenching remark bashing someone else's mother. Three weeks ago the little pink plus symbol appeared on my home pregnancy test. In eight months I will be that "mama" who wore combat boots. Suddenly it doesn't sound like such an insult! Having been part of a war and part of our nation's history, I now have the opportunity to teach a member of the next generation the valuable lessons that I have learned.
"I'd like to check you for ticks."

As Formula One probably says goodbye to Magny-Cours, many people are leaving the track with a sense of relief that it is over. It has been a weekend of truly mixed emotions. The highs of great results from Robert Kubica, a return for Ferrari to top form, a Kimi Raikkonen lifting himself out of the doldrums to victory again. But on the other side, another horrendous reminder of how close the circuit is to racing calamity, with the terrible GP2 accident yesterday, from which, fortunately, the driver escaped with only bruising, and like Kubica before him, a small concussion. But the Formula One paddock learned this morning of tragic news. Three people were killed and two were seriously injured in a helicopter accident last night, as they flew from the circuit to a hotel in a nearby town. The injured people were connected to the Bridgestone tire manufacturer, but the identity of the victims has not yet been made public, although it involves at least two Formula One paddock people.

This week we tried out Checchino, a restaurant that specializes in a uniquely Roman version of haute cuisine -- dishes made with offal, or leftover animal parts: tongues, tails, intestines, livers, feet, those little fatty deposits in pig's cheeks. Located (fittingly) at the bottom of a hill across from Rome's old slaughterhouse, the 120 year old family run Checchino provides real Italian fare that (unlike pasta and chianti) has defied globalization.

Aides to Democratic presidential hopeful John Edwards said today that their campaign's strategy of aggressively cultivating small donors was the key to meeting their $9 million second-quarter fundraising goal.
Knicks and knacks from the lovely press box at Citizens Bank Park...
