With the second campaign fundraising deadline over and the Fourth of July holiday week upon us, many of the 2008 presidential candidates will be out in full swing this coming week.

President Bush identifies with Winston Churchill and is now reading a book by Lynne Olson about the group of British MP's, including Churchill, who stood up to Neville Chamberlain in the run-up to World War II. Olson writes today in an interesting piece in today's Wash Post:
Stung by scandal, the Smithsonian needs to dust off America’s collection.
Paperback books of particular interest.
Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
Titles by little-known African-American writers (some newly published, some older) who are particularly worth checking out.
“I dream I’m flying in across Cape Hatteras . . .  where the Tuscarora were. Where the Tuscarora fished and lived and danced and laughed and loved before the measles and the smallpox took them.”
The HBO Bryant Park Summer Film Festival is often accompanied by a 10-second sprint onto the grass to claim a space.
The National Trust for Historic Preservation held a benefit picnic June 23 to celebrate the opening to the public of Philip Johnson’s 1949 glass house, located on 47 acres.
President Putin and President Bush are planning to mix the relaxation of family and fishing with the high anxiety of a growing list of divisive issues.
American and Iraqi officials said that they were seeing a decline in the monthly civilian casualty count in June.
Rear Adm. Eugene B. Fluckey was one of America’s most daring submarine commanders of World War II and a recipient of the Medal of Honor.
The move ends Israel’s fiscal isolation of the Palestinians, which began with the installation of a Hamas government last year.
The campaign of Senator Barack Obama of Illinois said it had attracted 154,000 new contributors from April through June.
The potential bid for Sir Richard Branson’s Virgin Media could be worth more than $20 billion.
The police raided homes in three cities and arrested a fifth person following attempted car bomb attacks in London and Glasgow that officials said were linked.
The anniversary of the transfer from Britain underlined how Hong Kong has become a far more Chinese city.
Evander Holyfield outworked and outclassed Lou Savarese on Saturday night, winning a 10-round unanimous decision to remain undefeated in his latest comeback.

The St. Louis Blues signed the veteran center Keith Tkachuk to a two-year contract yesterday, one day before he would have become an unrestricted free agent. The Blues traded Tkachuk, a four-time N.H.L. All-Star, to Atlanta in February but reacquired rights to him last week. The trade allowed St. Louis to deal exclusively with Tkachuk until today’s deadline for him to become an unrestricted free agent. Tkachuk, 35, had seven goals and eight assists with the Thrashers, after recording 20 goals and 23 assists for the Blues before the trade.

The former Knicks executive who is suing Coach Isiah Thomas for sexual harassment accused him in court papers of urging a cheerleader to flirt with referees. She also stated that guard Stephon Marbury cursed at her, according to newspaper reports yesterday.Anucha Browne Sanders, a former senior vice president for marketing and business operations, filed documents to answer the Knicks’ attempt to have her lawsuit dismissed.In the papers, which were unsealed Friday, Browne Sanders said a cheerleader, Petra Pope, told her Thomas encouraged Pope to flirt with officials before a game against the Nets in 2004, The Daily News reported. Sanders said Marbury directed an obscenity at her after she complained that Marbury’s cousin, who was also employed by the team, had made graphic sexual comments to her staff. Thomas and Madison Square Garden are listed as the defendants in the lawsuit, which charges them with sex discrimination and retaliation. Madison Square Garden said in a statement yesterday that the lawsuit was “riddled with fabrications.”.

The pole-sitter Dario Franchitti led all but eight laps and held off Scott Dixon and Dan Wheldon with the help of a late caution last night for his first IndyCar Series victory at Richmond.Franchitti, whose position atop the point standings gave him the top starting spot when Friday night’s qualifying was rained out, gave up the lead only twice, and even then it was during pit stops under caution. His victory was sealed when a late caution allowed him to conserve fuel, and he pulled away with ease on a restart with six laps to go.

The former Vanderbilt pitcher David Price won the Golden Spikes Award yesterday as the nation’s best amateur baseball player. Taken first in the draft by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, Price was a finalist in 2006 for the award, given out annually by USA Baseball. Price, the first Golden Spikes Award winner from Vanderbilt, finished his junior season with an 11-1 record, a 2.63 earned run average and 194 strikeouts. He broke the team’s career strikeout record with 441 in only 3 seasons and 313 innings.

Sammy Sosa hit his 602nd career homer to break a fifth-inning tie, leading the visiting Texas Rangers to a 5-4 victory against Boston last night and spoiling Josh Beckett’s last start before the All-Star Game rosters are announced today.
The Brewers showed why they are in first and have been for most of the season.
A satirist dressed as a preacher and protesting what he called the Disneyfication of New York City was arrested Friday for harassing police in Union Square.

Felipe Massa outpaced Lewis Hamilton to take the pole position for today’s French Grand Prix. Massa was timed in 1 minute 15.034 seconds on the 2.74-mile circuit for his fourth Formula One pole of the season and the seventh of his career. Hamilton, the series points leader, who has seven consecutive top-three finishes, was second in 1:15.104, ahead of Kimi Raikkonen in 1:15.257.

Tristan Gommendy, a 27-year-old French rookie, looked on through yesterday’s rain-marred qualifying session for the inaugural Champ Car Mont-Tremblant as the provisional pole he won in Friday’s session stood up as the fastest qualifying time for today’s race in Quebec. Will Power took the second spot on the front row with the fastest lap yesterday at 1:20.943. That was well off Gommendy’s pole-winning time of 1:16.776 on Friday.

The veteran forward Adam Mair re-signed for three years with the Buffalo Sabres yesterday. Mair earned a slight raise above the $675,000 he made last season. The deal was reached a day before Mair was eligible to become an unrestricted free agent. Mair had two goals and nine assists in 82 games last season and added a career-high five points in 16 playoff games.

Alexander Vinokourov, one of the favorites to win this year’s Tour de France, acknowledged he had used the services of the Italian doctor Michele Ferrari, but not for medical products.Ferrari, who once advised Lance Armstrong, was found guilty of fraud and malpractice in 2004 but was acquitted on charges of distributing doping products. He won an appeal two years later.Vinokourov, the leader of the Astana team, said Ferrari never offered him medication. “Michele Ferrari is a physical trainer but not my doctor,” Vinokourov said in the French newspaper L’Equipe.

Nashville center Scott Nichol agreed to contract terms with the Predators. Nichol signed a two-year deal that will pay him $750,000 each season, General Manager David Poile said yesterday. Nichol played in 59 games for the Predators last season, posting 13 points (7 goals and 6 assists) and 79 penalty minutes.

Kevin Harvick held off a late challenge by Carl Edwards at New Hampshire International Speedway yesterday to grab his second Nascar Busch Series victory of the season. Harvick, who had not won since the opening weekend at Daytona, led 166 laps.During the postrace inspection, Nascar confiscated an unapproved shock absorber from Edwards’s Ford. Officials said any penalty would be announced next week.

The Minnesota Wild re-signed center Mikko Koivu and defenseman Martin Skoula to multiyear contracts. Terms of the deals were not announced yesterday.Koivu, 24, recorded 54 points and 58 penalty minutes last season while appearing in all 82 regular-season games with Minnesota. Koivu led the Wild in face-offs won, ranked third in assists, tied for third in power-play goals and tied for fourth in goals.Skoula, 27, had 15 assists and 36 penalty minutes with the Wild last season, when he averaged 20:14 in ice time. He ranked fourth on the team in blocked shots (81) and fifth in hits (73).

Jörg Jaksche has become the first rider to admit to using blood doping prepared by a Spanish doctor in the Operation Puerto scandal. Jaksche told Germany’s Spiegel magazine that he had used performance-enhancing drugs since 1997 while riding for a number of teams.“I believe it’s important for the future of the sport that someone comes out and says, ‘O.K., this is how it happens here,’ ” Jaksche told Spiegel.Jaksche, a 30-year-old German who lives in Austria, was suspended by his team, Tinkoff Credit Systems, in May for suspected involvement in Operation Puerto. He said he would make himself available as a witness to the World Anti-Doping Agency, the International Cycling Union and justice officials.The scandal broke in May 2006 when Spanish authorities seized about 100 bags of frozen blood in the Madrid offices of Eufemiano Fuentes. The investigation implicated 58 cyclists and led to five arrests, but a judge threw out the case. The International Cycling Union has continued to pursue the matter.

It was no surprise that Vince Carter opted out of the final year of his contract with the Nets on Friday and officially became a free agent yesterday. But the Nets expect to reach a deal with him — in the four-year, $60 million range — as early as this week.
Tom Pernice Jr. was having a mediocre round Saturday until he hit a five-hole run in which he shot an eagle and four birdies.

Milwaukee bounced back from a tough defeat, scoring nine runs in the first three innings yesterday and making it easy for Ben Sheets to win his sixth decision in a row as the visiting Brewers routed the Chicago Cubs, 13-4.
The sight of pitcher Jorge Sosa limping off the field overshadowed a dynamic performance by Carlos Beltrán and a solid victory in Philadelphia.
Kei Kamara scored his second goal of the season for the Columbus Crew in a 1-0 victory over the visiting Red Bulls in Major League Soccer.
Political Force rallied to beat Fairbanks by one and a quarter lengths yesterday in the $400,000 Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park.
The ASSOCIATED PRESS
A fast-moving wildfire burning in eastern Utah killed two men working in a hay field, and a third man later died from related injuries.
Gallaudet, the nation’s only liberal arts university for the deaf, has been put on probation by its accrediting agency.
John Harris is having more success in his second attempt at professional golf than his three-year stint as a pro in the 1970s.
Starter Kei Igawa ran into early trouble against the Athletics while Oakland starter Chad Gaudin baffled the Yankees, who have now lost 8 of their last 10 games.
A Brooklyn man fatally shot his 21-year-old son in their apartment, then apparently shot himself, authorities said.
A manager of the Mind Scrambler ride at Playland Amusement Park in Rye, N.Y., was killed Friday night after she rode it without wearing her seat belt.
For the second time in three events, Michelle Wie withdrew in the middle of a tournament, the latest disappointing finish in what has become a strange and forgettable season.
Corrections: For the Record
Charges have been dropped against a man who was accused of causing the death of a another man who fell down an elevator shaft last winter, his lawyer said.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer is traveling to the districts of state senators to upbraid them for taking what he has termed a “vacation” and to demand that they return to Albany.

Barry Bonds hit his 750th career home run, an inning after getting a startling hug from a fan in a 4-3, 10-inning loss to Arizona on Friday night in San Francisco. The homer moved Bonds five away from tying Hank Aaron’s record, but Miguel Montero hit a solo homer off Brad Hennessey (1-3) in the 10th for the Diamondbacks and San Francisco lost its third straight.“Everybody in that clubhouse knows he’s going to get a lot of attention reaching this milestone, as he should,” Giants Manger Bruce Bochy said. “It’s going to be a big moment in baseball. Right now, we’re all embarrassed with where we’re at, how we’re playing, things that are happening on the field.”Bonds, 42, led off the eighth with a solo shot off Liván Hernández to tie the score, 3-3. The homer came an inning after a fan hopped a fence and ran out to Bonds in left field. Bonds, a seven-time National League most valuable player, calmly greeted the man and walked him off and into the custody of security personnel.The fan came out over the fence along the left-field line and scurried to Bonds while Orlando Hudson was batting. Bonds did not flinch, putting his arm around the man and walking him off the field — and fans began chants of “Barry! Barry!”“He just wanted to shake my hand,” Bonds told MLB.com while quickly leaving the ballpark. “I told him to come with me so he didn’t get into any more trouble.”The Giants said the man, in the custody of the San Francisco police, would face charges of public drunkenness and interfering with a sporting event. His name and age were not immediately available.

Nashville center Scott Nichol and defenseman Alex Henry have agreed to contract terms with the Predators.Nichol signed a two-year deal that will pay him $750,000 each season, General Manager David Poile said yesterday. Henry signed a one-year contract that will pay him $100,000 at the minor league level and $475,000 at the N.H.L. level.Nicol played in 59 games for the Predators last season, posting 13 points (7 goals and 6 assists) and 79 penalty minutes. In 301 career N.H.L. games with Nashville, Chicago, Calgary and Buffalo, Nichol has posted 64 points (30 goals, 34 assists) and 573 penalty minutes.Henry played in 64 games with Milwaukee of the American Hockey League last season, getting one goal, six assists and 66 penalty minutes.Before joining the Predators last season, Henry played two seasons with Minnesota. Henry has 11 points and 259 penalty minutes in 175 career N.H.L. games with Minnesota, Edmonton and Washington.

It was no surprise that Vince Carter opted out of the final year of his contract with the Nets on Friday and became a free agent yesterday. But the Nets expect to reach a new deal with him — in the four-year, $60 million range — as early as this week.“We’re certainly hopeful,” Rod Thorn, the Nets’ president, said during a telephone interview yesterday. “All of his public pronouncements have been that he would like to play for the Nets. We’d certainly like to have him.”No deal can be announced until July 11, even if they reach an agreement earlier.Carter, 30, joined the Nets less than midway through the 2004-5 season, and they have had limited postseason success with him. But he is a favorite of Bruce Ratner, the team’s majority owner, and as one of the league’s flashiest players, he sells tickets.Last season Carter averaged 25.2 points, 6 rebounds and 4.8 assists.
Uganda’s government and the Lord’s Resistance Army rebels signed an agreement on how to deal with war crimes in the third phase of talks to end one of Africa’s worst conflicts.
A debate over Atlantic Yards may be revived because of a lawsuit that has wrung free hundreds of pages of internal documents.
A persistent drizzle wreaked havoc on the Saturday lineup at Wimbledon.
Jörg Jaksche of Germany has become the first cyclist to admit blood doping in connection with Spain’s Operation Puerto scandal.
Lorena Ochoa, who has been playing Ping equipment for the last 10 years, will finally be paid to use it under a multiyear agreement that varies slightly from most Ping contracts.
Storm-weary residents who evacuated their homes along the rain-swollen Brazos River were allowed to return Saturday but were urged to remain cautious.
Niger is deploying large numbers of soldiers — 4,000 one report says — in the north of the country after a spate of attacks by Tuareg rebels.
The demise of the immigration bill may have damaged the party’s ability to attract more Hispanic voters.
The Korean Free Trade Agreement calls for eliminating tariffs on 95 percent of consumer and industrial products traded between the United States and South Korea.

In a letter, Pope Benedict acknowledged suffering by Catholics under Communist rule, but said it was time to forgive past wrongdoings.
Widening recalls have forced big American companies to focus on potential hazards that were overlooked in the past.
In the first full term of the Roberts court, a third of the decisions were decided by 5-to-4 margins, with Justice Anthony M. Kennedy as the linchpin.
The Rev. Mancuso was the founding abbot of the Monks of New Skete, whose hilltop monastery in upstate New York is renowned for breeding German shepherds.
Filmmakers chose New Haven to take advantage of generous tax credits Connecticut began doling out to production companies last year.
Since her cancer diagnosis, Elizabeth Edwards has become an increasing presence in her husband’s campaign.

(Sundance) THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG It’s a great night for movie musicals by brilliant directors, beginning with Catherine Deneuve (above, with Nino Castelnuovo) in Jacques Demy’s bittersweet and altogether magical sung-through 1964 film (with music by Michel Legrand) about a pregnant shopgirl and the mechanic she loves but doesn’t wait for. The Day Out column on June 17 about a shopping street in Antwerp, Belgium, misstated the Dutch title of a Judith Krantz novel and the name of a popular restaurant. The book is “De Dochter van Mistral,” not “Der Dochter van Mistral,” and the restaurant is ’t Koetshuis, not t’Koetshuis. Also, the column gave an incomplete translation for the name of a museum. The Koninklijk Museum voor Schone Kunsten is the Royal Fine Arts Museum, not the Fine Arts Museum.

THIS Fourth of July, millions of ordinary citizens across the land are planning to celebrate our nation's birthday with that most distinctively American tradition: the backyard toga party. Well, O.K., not really. But the idea might not be so farfetched. Recently, it has seemed that ancient Rome is everywhere -- and especially comparisons of modern America to the ancient empire. Moreover, it is one of the few things on which all segments of the political spectrum -- left and right, Christian fundamentalists and Islamic radicals, Ivy League professors and renegade bloggers -- seem to agree.

SAGON--Martha S., 98, died on June 28, peacefully at home in Washington, D.C. Devoted mother of Patricia Bennett Sagon, also of Washington, beloved wife of the late Philip H. Sagon, daughter of the late Mae and Jacob H. Silverstein. A native New Yorker, she received her Bacherlors degree from New York University and her Masters degree from Columbia University. She moved to Washington with her husband during WWII. Contributions in her memory may be made to The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts or The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, two of the many organizations she passionately supported. Funeral services 2 pm Monday, July 2nd at The Garden of Rememberance in Clarksburg, MD.

When Nona Abad, a 56-year-old former finance assistant, moved into her one-bedroom apartment in Tudor City 18 years ago, she had every reason to believe that she would find serenity in that secluded compound of brick and terra-cotta towers on the eastern edge of Midtown. But even Ms. Abad's work at the United Nations, which sits in view of the towers and employs some of its residents, hadn't fully prepared her for the political battles that have since rattled the 22-story, 440-apartment building where she lives.

LEVIK, an 8-year-old on the loose at Coney Island, was ecstatic. He had come to the amusement park this late spring day with his classmates at the Lubavitcher Oholei Torah school in Crown Heights, which had rented Deno's Wonder Wheel Park for the morning. One contingent careered around the track on the miniature Big Wheel truck ride, each child excitedly swerving his own mercifully nonfunctional steering wheel. Another group headed to the Wonder Wheel, a terrifying attraction that has towered above the Boardwalk since 1920.

JONES--Paul M. Paul M. Jones, long known for his contributions to the interior design industry, passed peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Saturday, June 23rd. He was 88. Born on February 15th, 1919 in Dayton, Paul graduated from Ohio State University with a degree in English Literature, served in the U.S. Army during WWII, and was an editor at Family Circle magazine before settling in to a long and successful career in the interior design industry. Beginning in 1958 in a brownstone on East 54th Street, Paul M. Jones, Inc. quickly became a fashionable and highly reputable resource for custom furniture, lighting, and accessories, assisted by his talented manufacturers and his loyal and supportive staff. Several years later, he became one of the very first trade showrooms in the then newly opened D&D building in 1961. Paul was known for his kind, gentle manner and his classic aesthetic, and his influence over the interior design market is still strongly recognized today. An avid reader, he tackled the NY Times crossword puzzle each morning, loved to stroll through Central Park, and lived for his summer holidays on the Isle of Capri. Paul is survived by his adored sister, Naomi Pittman. He is predeceased by his loving parents, Kenton and Anna Jones, dear sister, Ruth Miller, and beloved companions Philip Graf and Michael St. Clair. In Paul's memory, donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy.

Re ''The Danger of the One-Sided Debate'' (June 24): As the owner-editor of a historic weekly newspaper (161 years old on July 4) and a professional journalist for 42 years, I disagree that the op-ed page of any newspaper is intended to serve as a debate of issues.

LEVIK, an 8-year-old on the loose at Coney Island, was ecstatic. He had come to the amusement park this late spring day with his classmates at the Lubavitcher Oholei Torah school in Crown Heights, which had rented Deno's Wonder Wheel Park for the morning.

ALARMED by what they say is a stubborn reluctance among delinquent borrowers to discuss their financial problems, a consortium of mortgage bankers and community development organizations introduced a public-service advertising campaign last week aimed at getting borrowers to seek help before things turn really bad. ''This is a first,'' said Brad German, a spokesman for Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored corporation that, among other things, buys pools of loans from mortgage banks. ''I've been in the industry since 1978, and I can't recall a time when so many different players, including competitors, have come together to help sponsor an outreach initiative.''

TUWAYJIRI--Sheikh Abdulaziz, 95, possessed of a spectacular mind and renowned as a man of state and a man of letters, died June 10th in Riyadh after an epic life nearly encapsulating the Arabian century. Born into turbulent times in the then fledgling Sultanate of Nejd, battle by battle he witnessed the late Abdulaziz Ibn Saud's recapture of his forebears' former domains and their transformation into the planet's pivotal oil power, the eponymous Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Sheikh Tuwayjiri's career, as a soldier, finance officer, Deputy Commander of the National Guard, Royal Counsellor, and roving Minister of State spanned seven decades and six reigns. An autodidact, a poet and mentor of poets, a bibliophile and patron of public libraries, literature and strategic studies, he published two dozen volumes of both prose and Arabic verse, gaining the sobriquet, ''The Ink of Arabia''. At Harvard's JFK School of Government and London University two chairs are endowed in his name. He is survived by six sons, a large extended family, the people of Majmaa, the Mutayr tribe, and a vast and varied global acquaintance, among them American longtime friends. A singular man, he shall sorely be missed. Lt. Gen. Richard D. Lawrence Peter A. Iseman David E. Long Salem O. Afyouni

Despite all the various injections and sophisticated devices to treat patients with chronic pain, the single most important leap in pain management in the last decade is the increased use of opioids like methadone, morphine and OxyContin.

An article last week about Gustavo Arellano, the journalist who started the newspaper column ''¡Ask a Mexican!'' that became a book of the same name, misstated the e-mail address for readers to write to him. It is themexican@askamexican.net.

FREEMAN WONG starts his day just after midnight, when he heads over to the New Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx to pack his truck with whatever's fresh and attractively priced: skate, salmon, sole, shark, swordfish. Then it's off to his family's store, Aqua Best on Grand Street in Chinatown, where for the rest of the day he checks his fish to make sure their scales feel firm and their eyes shine, one of countless tasks required by the complex regulations that govern the selling of seafood. So when he spots people selling fish outside his door without even a bag of ice in sight, he feels more than the usual resentment toward competitors.

To the Editor: Re ''China's Leader Vows to Uphold One-Party Rule'' (news article, June 27):

THE $73.5 billion global biotech business may soon have to grapple with a discovery that calls into question the scientific principles on which it was founded. Last month, a consortium of scientists published findings that challenge the traditional view of how genes function. The exhaustive four-year effort was organized by the United States National Human Genome Research Institute and carried out by 35 groups from 80 organizations around the world. To their surprise, researchers found that the human genome might not be a ''tidy collection of independent genes'' after all, with each sequence of DNA linked to a single function, such as a predisposition to diabetes or heart disease.

Opportunity in Africa To the Editor:

BECAUSE bonds are supposed to provide ballast to your portfolio in a market storm, it's only natural to worry when your fixed-income holdings start to gyrate, as they have of late. But just as increased volatility in stocks can highlight opportunities for equity investors, the recent rockiness in the bond market can help clarify some decisions for bond holders. Since June, the yield on 10-year Treasury notes has seesawed between 4.87 percent and 5.32 percent -- and currently rests slightly above 5 percent. That is because the bond market can't seem to make up its mind whether the economy is truly growing stronger, or whether troubles in the subprime mortgage market, which have already begun to hurt some hedge funds, might spill over into the broader economy.

THEY called it ''falling off the calendar.'' It was the kind of phrase that I came to understand while teaching a creative writing workshop at the Women's House of Detention on Rikers Island in the 1970s. I learned, for example, that a ''pelican'' lawyer -- black suit, large scoop beak dripping torts? -- was an appellate lawyer and that the dreaded syllable ''bing'' was the term for solitary confinement, calling up the sound of a slamming cell door. But falling off the calendar was the scarily evocative and precise metaphoric phrase for being forgotten by the court system. It meant that the person, unseen, unheard of and uncharged by any judge, had been abandoned behind bars for weeks, months, sometimes years.

EZZES--Erwin H. Our beloved Ez died peacefully in his sleep on June 28. He was a man of intelligence, wit and wisdom; generous, charming and kind. Ez was Lt. Colonel Ezzes, Secretary to the General Staff, reporting to General Eisenhower during World War II. He was President and CEO of United Artists Television Corp. and a consultant to 20th Century Fox. He will be forever in our hearts. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, on Sunday, July 1, at 12:45pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Military Academy, Cornwall - on - Hudson, New York 12520 for the Erwin H. Ezzes Scholarship Fund. Marilyn Ezzes Jim Ezzes Steve Ezzes Britt Ezzes Kate Ezzes Ben Ezzes David Binetter

Because of an editing error, an article on June 17 about theatergoers from outside New York City who take tour buses to see Broadway shows misspelled part of the title of a play. It is ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' not ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolfe?''

I suffered severe back pain some years ago and remember well on several occasions being talked out of the opioid prescription I knew would work. Even though I had been prescribed opioid drugs before and shown no tendency to abuse or overuse, the doctors showered guilt and fear upon me until I gave into their safer preference. (Was that done for my benefit or their own?) Now I worry about liver damage from years of doctor-recommended high doses of acetaminophen.

AFTER the last of the college graduates hug teary parents and toss their tasseled caps into the air, universities pass their charges on to employers, who then face the challenge of transforming students into employees. I often wonder how some of my students will fare in the world of work. After 32 years of teaching, I still delight in hearing that a former student who made careless mistakes on exams and could not turn anything in on time has become exceptionally good at his or her job. Each cohort of college students comes with annoying and admirable attitudes that present challenges and opportunities for their first full-time employers.

KALSON--Sam, died June 28th, 2007, age 84. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Steven, Janet and Carolyne, proud grandfather of Elli, Diane and Stephanie, brother of Irving. Services Sunday 1pm at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer'' (Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd.) Forest Hills, NY.
To the Editor: Re ''Teachers' Merit Pay: A Good Idea?'' (letters, June 24):

To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman's June 24 column, ''The Capitol Energy Crisis,'' rightly chides Congress to do more than the much-ballyhooed 10-mile-per-gallon increase in fuel economy recently passed by the Senate. But there are many reasons, beyond global warming, why this landmark legislation should be stronger.

THE simple truth is that if you want to be heard by your husband, you must speak a language he understands. An example: A friend of mine is married to a wealthy spendthrift who used to drive like a maniac -- tailgating, speeding, weaving between lanes. My friend repeatedly expressed her fear about his dangerous habits but he didn't modify his behavior; money was the language he spoke. She gave him one final warning: slow down or else. He didn't, so without any fanfare, she withdrew $40,000 from their bank accounts and bought herself a luxury convertible. I hear he's a pretty safe driver now.

WHY has the pace of fundamental innovation in military technologies slowed? Why, six years after 9/11, is there no mega-research project -- along the lines of the crash Manhattan Project that 62 years ago produced the first atomic bombs -- to address the plausible security threats to the United States in the 21st century? These two questions say a lot about how innovation happens today, and why concerns about national security, which once motivated civilian scientists and engineers to make crucial contributions to military technologies, may again shape innovation priorities.

Charlie Wonsowicz did not remember having much of a scouting report the first time he pitched to Craig Biggio 20 years ago. ''I was a freshman,'' Wonsowicz said. ''I was just trying to throw the ball over the plate.''

Call it Hybrid Hertz now that the rental car company has agreed to add 3,400 Toyota Prius vehicles by 2008 to its Green Collection, which features fuel-efficient, low-emissions cars like the Subaru Outback, the Ford Fusion and the Buick LaCrosse. ''We knew we had to implement some green initiatives in response to fuel-cost increases, heightened customer concern about the environment, as well as requests from our corporate clients, whose companies are working out their own green policies,'' said Frank Camacho, vice president for marketing at Hertz. He added that 100 Priuses have been allocated to New York City and are to be available not only for daily and weekly rentals, but also by the hour.

Correction Appended FORTY years ago today, ''White Rabbit'' by Jefferson Airplane cracked the Top 40. With it, and hits like ''Light My Fire'' by the Doors, 1967's Summer of Love blossomed. And 40 years later, the media is still commemorating it.

To the Editor:

Stage One: Infatuation I just got e-mail! I can't believe it! It's so great! Here's my handle. Write me! Who said letter writing was dead? Were they ever wrong! I'm writing letters like crazy for the first time in years. I come home and ignore all my loved ones and go straight to the computer to make contact with total strangers. And how great is AOL? It's so easy. It's so friendly. It's a community. Wheeeee! I've got mail!

This summer -- or any summer, for that matter -- there is no such thing as having too many dresses. But with the glut of choices this season, smart shoppers are paring back to a cleaner, more essential chic. Case in point: Steven Alan's cotton Breaker Dress and Christine Tunic, two wearable, washable, stylishly austere ways to face the heat. The Breaker Dress ($265), left, has petal sleeves and an easy A-line silhouette while the Christine Tunic dress ($180), right, is a short, sweet shirt dress that can be worn as a top or a dress; each comes in a cornucopia of plaids, dots or solids (at Steven Alan in New York, 212-343-0692 or www.stevenalan.com).

IT was 7:30 one recent Saturday morning, and Ginkgo, a luminously well-groomed German short-haired pointer, was trotting along leashlessly in the recreation lane of the East Drive in Central Park. Ginkgo's decorous behavior might have been due to the fact that she was separated from the passing cyclists, Rollerbladers and runners not only by a solid white line but also by the threat of an electric shock.

OTHER SIGHTS IN FLORENCE To the Editor: I was interested to read Danielle Pergament's ''36 Hours in Florence'' (June 3). Although she had some wonderful suggestions like the Museo de San Marco and the Museo dell'Opera del Duomo, she left out some obvious ones. I have been to Florence many times and would like to add my suggestions to hers.

From the southernmost tip of Manhattan, even on a clear summer day, Staten Island can appear shrouded in a smoky haze. There's the pollution, which has earned the island the dubious distinction of having the worst air quality in the city. And there's the cigarette smoke, which, according to a report released 10 days ago by the city's Health Department, has hardly dissipated over the last four years, despite declining numbers in every other borough.
FRIEDMAN--Fred. Dearest Fred, Happy Birthday. Today we are celebrating your life and the many years we loved living with you. Linda, Adam, Sara, Erik, and Isabella

HALL--Rev. Rosalie Heffelfinger Episcopal Priest, Author, Philanthropist died Monday morning, June 25, in Noir Moutie, France, of a brain aneurysm. Hall was born in 1928 in Duluth, Minnesota, the daughter of F. Peavey Heffelfinger and Elizabeth Bradley Heffelfinger. She was educated at the Madeira Girls School and graduated from Smith College in 1950. She graduated from the General Theological Seminary in New York City in 1987 and was then ordained in the Episcopal priesthood. She was a prominent priest in Minnesota and served for a time as the canon of The American Episcopal Cathedral in Paris, France. Hall founded Episcopal Group Homes in Minnesota which taught independent living skills to the developmentally disabled. Hall is survived by three sons, Wendell Willkie II, of Darien, Connecticut, and Philip H. Willkie and Frank Peavey Willkie, both of Minneapolis, as well as three granddaughters, Alexandra, Diana and Caroline Willkie of Darien, Connecticut. A memorial service will be held at 10am Monday at St. Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Minneapolis. In lieu of flowers, the family asks friends to consider a contribution to the Greater Minneapolis Council of Churches, an organization that unites people of diverse faiths to serve people in need. (1001 East Lake Street, Minneapolis, MN 55407-0509, 612276-1509. www.gmcc.org)

Sometimes epiphanies come in strange packages. Mine came swathed in parchment paper, handed to me by a cheesemaker friend at the farmers' market. ''Here,'' she said, glancing around furtively, ''try this and tell me what you think.'' I shoved it underneath a bag of flowering broccoli and headed back to the restaurant, where I opened the contraband. It was not, as I suspected, some rare form of hashish; it was butter.

What looked like a comfortable lead for Emirates Team New Zealand in Race 6 of the America's Cup turned out to be something much more fragile, and now Alinghi has a comfortable lead in yachting's premier event. With the tactician Brad Butterworth chomping slowly, patiently on his gum and making the right reads, Alinghi won its third straight race Saturday to move one victory from retaining the America's Cup.

CURIOUS it may be, but there is not a single national park in Idaho, a state with more public forest land, more wilderness, more white water than any other in the country outside of the superlative-trumping asterisk of Alaska. It has two dozen sites as part of a national historical park dedicated to the Nez Perce Indians, but nothing on the order of a velvet-roped shank of mega scenery. So when people decide to go ''Out West'' for a visit, a phrase that always sounds quaint to a Westerner's ear, they usually head for the canyon lands of southern Utah, or the fly-fishing streams of Montana or the aged chasms of Arizona. They fashion their trips around Yellowstone (to be fair, a mostly overlooked sliver is in Idaho), Zion or Grand Canyon - the iconic national parks, all worth a visit of course.

UPON what meat doth this our Caesar feed, that he is grown so great?'' I've been thinking about those words in the context of private equity lately. How does this business make so much money? Are there really a huge number of mispriced securities out there? Are there really a vast number of corporations whose stock is wildly underpriced so that private equity can buy them at above-market prices and then make money after a little spiffing up and wiping clean?

LARCHMONT, N.Y. MICHAEL W. BURTEN, a 24-year-old former marine, is sipping a glass of crisp white wine at an outdoor cafe here, trying to explain how strange and wonderful it is to be home from the war in Iraq.

Two Fridays ago, a 27-year-old named Terrod Wright was shot in the concrete bathroom of Marcus Garvey Park in Central Harlem, right in front of his 5-year-old nephew. The two men who the police said shot Mr. Wright escaped after taking his gold chains and have not been arrested; the victim died several hours later. News of the killing has reverberated through the neighborhood, alarming parents who had already considered some sections of the eight-square-block park, which straddles Fifth Avenue south of 124th Street, off-limits.

A HUNDRED years ago, an amusement park opened its gates on a site hugging the southeastern shore of Brooklyn. Tens of thousands of thrill seekers traveled to the resort, which featured the mandatory attractions of the day: a tunnel of love, a roller coaster, a dance pavilion, a circus. Given the proximity to the water, seafood was undoubtedly devoured, and sunburn could not have been further from the minds of the frolicking beachgoers. The name on the archway of this seaside theme park did not read Dreamland, Luna Park or even Steeplechase. Those signs were a few miles away in Coney Island. Instead, on May 30, 1907, New Yorkers reaching the end of the Canarsie line found themselves at the Golden City Amusement Park.

Lucy Wollin, one of the more ardent fans of the city's greenmarkets, arrived at the Union Square Greenmarket clad in comfortable black sandals with a burlap sack over her shoulder, ready to appraise the day's offerings. It was 8 a.m. on a recent Wednesday, and the market bulged with summer's bounty. ''Look at these interesting lettuces,'' Ms. Wollin said, examining tufts of speckled romaine, red oak leaf and butterhead lettuce with a gem dealer's eye. A farm manager pointed toward a bushel basket near the back of his booth.

After the Yankees were victimized by a one-hitter from Chad Gaudin and Rich Harden yesterday in a 7-0 loss, Posada said firmly, ''It seems like, at times, we just go through the motions, and today is one of those cases.''

PARDEE--Stewart Trevor, of Newport, Rhode Island, age 86, passed away peacefully with family June 21. Sailing was his passion. He worked in advertising and public relations, served in WWII's Amphibian Command, and was inducted into the College Sailing Hall of Fame. He retired with his wife aboard their yacht. He is survived by his wife Erdice and children, Lelia, Trevor, Jr., and Margaret.

A 41-year-old Brooklyn man fatally shot his 21-year-old son in the bathtub of their apartment, then apparently shot himself, the authorities said yesterday. The man had quarreled with his son, who wanted to move out, investigators said, adding that the father left a note saying that he suffered from depression and had been unable to find help.

To the Editor:

New York's Senate leader, Joseph Bruno, must have figured he had an easy sell. The grandfatherly voice of the Republican Party in Albany told reporters recently that the real reason nothing was getting done was that Gov. Eliot Spitzer was obsessed with ''campaign finance reform.'' As Mr. Bruno put it, milking the laughs as expected, ''when you get up in the morning, do your children, your significant others ask you what's the status of campaign finance reform?'' No, of course they don't. So, rather than abandon the reform of the sleazy way campaigns are financed in New York, it is time to rename it. It is time to bring back the term ''sewer money.'' It is time for Albany's politicians to do something about the millions of dollars used by lobbyists to buy New York laws and New York lawmakers.
To the Editor:

An article on June 17 about the increasing use of debit and credit cards for small purchases referred incorrectly to the overall value of such transactions. According to research by MasterCard, transactions of less than $5 totaled $1.32 trillion, not billion, last year.
Tina Rosenberg's article made me shudder. Just how many times have I dodged the bullet of a 30-year prison sentence for doing my professional best to relieve my patients' intolerable chronic pain?

The Bush administration has postponed for at least six months the second phase of the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, which was scheduled to begin as early as January. When implemented, the initiative will require Americans to present passports when crossing a United States border by land or sea. Under the temporary ruling (see www.dhs.gov or www.cbp.gov), travelers without passports will be able to re-enter the country if they have two documents: a government-issued photo identification card (like a drivers license) and a birth certificate. ... Loews Hotels (www.loewshotels.com) is taking the hotel gym trend a step further by offering opportunities for in-room workouts for the preschooler set. This month, Loews, an 18-hotel chain, will make available Fisher-Price Smart Cycles (above), exercise bikes that plug into televisions. The bikes, which must be reserved, enable children 3 to 6 to ''get their workouts in'' while participating in problem-solving games with onscreen characters like Dora the Explorer (and allow parents to pack and shower in peace). The bikes are part of the Loews Loves Kids program, which also includes gift bags and a lending closet that includes games and strollers. Sample starting rates: $139 in Denver and $279 in Miami . ... A North American Rail Pass is now available for 30 consecutive days of unlimited travel on almost any Amtrak (United States) or VIA Rail (Canada) train or route. Adult prices are $999 now through Oct. 15 and $709 for Oct. 16 to May 31. For details, visit www.railpass.com and click on North America passes in the Global Passes section on the left. ... Call-in-Europe (www.call-in-europe.com) has unveiled two calling plans with rollover-minute options for France. The monthly plans are available for $15 (30 minutes) and $30 (75 minutes). Calls made from France to other countries in Western Europe cost 69 cents a minute, and calls to the United States and Canada cost 79 cents a minute. Unused minutes will roll over until the calling plan has been reactivated. For those with no phone: rental cellphones are also available for $2.99 a day, and come with both American and European chargers. ...Air Greenland (www.airgreenland.com) has become the first airline to offer direct flights to Greenland from the United States (Baltimore-Washington International Airport) . Now through Aug. 30, flights are departing the United States every Monday and Thursday to Kangerlussuaq, the country's largest airport, just above the Arctic Circle. Round-trip rates start at $1,100.

A Potent Weapon In the Mosquito War To the Editor: Re ''Mosquito Arrives, Its Enemies Divided'' (June 17):

THEY called it ''falling off the calendar.'' It was the kind of phrase that I came to understand while teaching a creative writing workshop at the Women's House of Detention on Rikers Island in the 1970s. I learned, for example, that a ''pelican'' lawyer -- black suit, large scoop beak dripping torts? -- was an appellate lawyer and that the dreaded syllable ''bing'' was the term for solitary confinement, calling up the sound of a slamming cell door. But falling off the calendar was the scarily evocative and precise metaphoric phrase for being forgotten by the court system. It meant that the person, unseen, unheard of and uncharged by any judge, had been abandoned behind bars for weeks, months, sometimes years.

On July 4, 2001, Takeru Kobayashi, an unassuming 23-year-old from Nagano, Japan, stood before a 30-foot table at Coney Island. He was there for the 86th Nathan's Famous hot dog-eating contest, and few of the 3,000 in attendance could have known what would happen next. Bite by bite, gulp by gulp, the 131-pound Kobayashi consumed 50 hot dogs in 12 minutes, or one every 14.4 seconds, to obliterate the record, 25.

Q. You have sent out hundreds of résumés and have received only automated responses, and not one request for an interview. Is that common, and what can you do about it? A. Welcome to the Internet black hole. That is how Mark Mehler, co-founder of CareerXroads, describes the new universe of job seeking.

Armed with a miniature switchblade, a petite community activist named Enid Klass prowls the leafy streets of Murray Hill. Her goal is to rid the neighborhood of the thousands of fliers touting ''Moving -- $17 Per Man Per Truck'' that for years have been illegally taped to lampposts and bus stops. ''They're a visual blight and a total nuisance,'' said Ms. Klass, a retired researcher for Merrill Lynch. And the culprits are as wily as she is tenacious. ''As soon as we tear them down,'' she said, ''we find even more posted in the same spot a few days later.''

MOST co-op owners know that when they borrow money to buy their apartments, their lenders will file a lien against them. What many owners (and prospective owners) do not know is that there may be liens filed against them for loans they never took out. ''This happens all the time,'' said Peter G. Brav, the president of Good Deed Abstract in Valley Stream, N.Y. It is common for a lender making a co-op loan to ''pre-file'' a lien before the loan is made, even when refinancing an existing loan.
To the Editor: Re ''This Land Was My Land,'' by Timothy Egan (column, June 23):

ROTHMAN--Deborah (nee Gross). Beloved wife of Gary R. Tarnoff and loving mother of David Rothman. A warm and engaging individual of strong will, great intellect, wit and humor, Deborah was a force and a presence. She was a skilled and accomplished attorney and a gifted writer of short fiction. Deborah was a graduate of the Yeshivah of Flatbush and Brooklyn College and held a masters in modern European history from Columbia University Graduate Faculties and a law degree from New York University. In the 1970's Deborah was the Chief of Education Litigation for the Corporation Counsel of the City of New York. She was the lead counsel in a series of well publicized federal lawsuits involving school desegregation and the City's employment practices. After many years in private practice specializing in employment discrimination, Deborah turned to writing fiction, which she truly enjoyed. As Deborah Tarnoff, she published short works of fiction in a number of literary journals and magazines; publication of her additional work is forthcoming. The funeral will be at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street, on Monday July 2, at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Continuum Hospice Care, 1775 Broadway, Suite 300, NY NY 10019 or to the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network (MBC Network.org).

BALOUN--Philip, 61, died at home in Manhattan on Thursday, June 28, 2007 after battling aggressive cancer. He was born on January 22, 1946 in suburban Chicago, IL. Philip started his design company, Philip Baloun Studio Designs, where he worked with some of Manhattan's most prominent individuals and organizations. He dazzled thousands by masterfully creating atmospheres at some of the most famous parties in the last two decades. Mr. Baloun was a pioneer of incorporating floral and set design to create the events of a lifetime. Reputed internationally for his artistry and transformative prowess, he has designed parties throughout Europe, Middle East, Asia and the Caribbean. Philip is survived by his sister Louise and his brothers Paul and Michael. A memorial service is to be announced.

BEING English, I come from a long line of gardeners. Gardens figure in some of my earliest memories of time spent with my grandparents: being taught the names of flowers, being sent to dump the afternoon tea leaves on the compost pile, and being directed occasionally in the tiresome chores of weeding and deadheading.

The Market Week column last Sunday, a look ahead at economic news that can affect financial markets, misstated annual rates of sales of new homes. The government's originally reported rate for April was 981,000, not 9.81 million, and an economists' estimate for May was 925,000, not 9.25 million. (On Tuesday, the government's housing report listed a revised rate of 930,000 for April and an actual rate of 915,000 for May.)

I suffered severe back pain some years ago and remember well on several occasions being talked out of the opioid prescription I knew would work. Even though I had been prescribed opioid drugs before and shown no tendency to abuse or overuse, the doctors showered guilt and fear upon me until I gave into their safer preference. (Was that done for my benefit or their own?) Now I worry about liver damage from years of doctor-recommended high doses of acetaminophen. ''You may have to live with some pain,'' a doctor is quoted as saying. Some? I wonder how that doctor might feel if he had to live with a pain level of 5 or more every day for years and be told the pain was considered adequately managed.

EDEL--Abraham. Esteemed professor of philosophy, author, and John Dewey scholar, died June 22, 2007, in New York City at 98. Cherished husband of Sima Szaluta, the late May Mandelbaum Edel, and the late Elizabeth Flower; loving father of Deborah and the late Matthew (Kim); devoted grandfather of Keir, Gareth and Stephan; and brother of the late Leon Edel. His life work focused on understanding moral values and the role of philosophy in its connection to the social sciences. Thoughtful, knowledgeable, kind and witty, he was beloved and respected by his family, friends, colleagues and many generations of students. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

SINCE 1954, liberal and conservative justices have disagreed about the central meaning of Brown v. Board of Education. Was the purpose of Brown to achieve a colorblind society or an integrated one? Last week, in its 5-to-4 decision declaring that public schools in Louisville and Seattle can't take explicit account of race to achieve integration, the Supreme Court came down firmly on the side of colorblindness. Despite some important qualifications by Justice Anthony Kennedy, at least four conservative justices made clear that they believe that nearly all racial classifications are unconstitutional.

Annabelle Catherine Singer, a daughter of Rosemarie and Isadore M. Singer of Boxborough, Mass., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Eric Noah Schrock, a son of Nancy and Richard R. Schrock of Winchester, Mass. Alan M. Sentkowski, a justice of the peace, officiated. Ms. Singer, 27, is keeping her name. She is a candidate for a doctoral degree in neuroscience at the University of California, San Francisco. She graduated from Wesleyan University and was a Fulbright scholar in 2001 and 2002 in Chiang Mai, Thailand, where through an affiliation with Chiang Mai University she researched the psychological effects of warfare on Burmese refugees.

LAST Sunday morning, as the bells began to toll at Our Lady of La Salette, a Roman Catholic church in Bayside, Queens, a group of women could be seen hurrying into the tiny gray stone building. Following close behind came a procession led by Msgr. Jesé Milagrosa, their professorial-looking, 70-something pastor. Silently he walked down the church's tiny aisle, past its numerous statues, and ascended the altar steps. Then, with his back to the congregants, Monsignor Milagrosa began chanting -- in Latin. For Catholics worldwide, of course, the Mass has generally not been in Latin since the mid-1960s. But Our Lady of La Salette is a traditionalist church, one that has persisted without permission in the old ways even as Rome turned to vernacular languages for its rites.

James Traub's essay (June 17) suggests we veer from the family-values iconography to a more ''realistic'' vision of how we really are in choosing a president. ''Wouldn't it be to our benefit to scramble those boundaries?'' he asks. It sounds to me a lot like what Daniel Patrick Moynihan used to call ''dumbing down'' the ideals we hold so that everyone can fit in -- in this case, into the Oval Office.

As an emergency-medicine physician, I routinely evaluate and treat patients in pain. Among this population are those seeking narcotic prescriptions inappropriately. While these patients can be difficult to distinguish on history and physical exam, an electronic medical record that quickly documents past clinical visits and medications is an invaluable objective tool. Multiple visits and narcotic prescriptions from different doctors are red flags that are easy to spot on the computer: yet another reason to implement a national electronic medical-record system.
The 36 Hours column last Sunday about Bali misspelled the name of a popular place there for coffee drinks. It is Tutmak Warung, not Tukmak.

Beach lovers should not have to fuss with insufficiently capacious totes. A carryall should do just that: carry it all. To that end, a serious straw beach bag by Tag has the potential to house not only a lap dog but also an actual sled dog in the off-season, a small child and his or her sand toys, a panoply of clowns or, more usefully, a clutch of towels, sunscreen, flip-flops and a change of clothes. And it performs beautifully, in water-resistant straw with a lovely fabric lining -- brown lined in blue, aqua lined in cream, or orange with a brilliant geranium. And the price is pleasingly dwarfish in comparison: a mere $32 (at Mxyplyzyk in New York, 800-243-9810).

HOWE--William F., Jr. (Bill), of Boca Grande, FL and Rumford, RI, passed away quietly in his sleep on Tuesday June 26th, 2007. Born in Natick, Massachusetts in 1922 to Brigadier General William Howe and the former Margaret Allen of Nantucket, Bill was preceded in death by his wife of 45 years, Joan Kock Howe and his sister Peggy White. Bill is survived by his sister, Betty Constable of Princeton, NJ and Nantucket; a son, Bill Howe of Annapolis, MD; two daughters, Jinx Howe Horan of Boca Grande and Nantucket and Robin Gross of Rumford, RI and seven grandchildren. Bill served as a 2nd Lieutenant in WWII as a bombardier with the 15th Air Force and earned the Distinguished Flying Cross. A graduate of Phillips Andover Academy and Yale, Bill played hockey and baseball for the Elis. He represented Yale in the inaugural NCAA College World Series and was voted 1st team All American; only one of three players in Yale baseball history. An avid sportsman through life, Bill won the RI State Squash championship several years and was a member of the US Seniors Golf Association. Until his retirement, he was the owner of Howe's Racquet Shop in Providence, RI. Pop will always be remembered for his smile, athletic grace and modest manner; he was a friend to everyone and was truly a representative of this country's Greatest Generation. In lieu of flowers, please consider giving to The Johann Fust Community Library, Boca Grande, FL 33921, The Suncoast Humane Society, 6781 San Casa Drive Englewood, FL 34224 or The Island School, Boca Grande, FL. Details of a service for Bill have not yet been finalized.

NEW CANAAN, CONN.: The National Trust for Historic Preservation held a benefit picnic June 23 to celebrate the opening to the public of Philip Johnson's 1949 glass house, located on 47 acres. Guests watched as 14 Merce Cunningham dancers restaged a benefit performance there from 1967, when the black-and-white photos were taken. From left in those photos: Mr. Johnson and a guest; Henry Geldzahler and Fred Hughes; the interior; the house; Andy Warhol and a guest; a Dan Flavin light sculpture; and the lake fountain. Below right, the art writers Rosamond and John Russell with Christy MacLear, the house's executive director. Kenny Williams did not want to talk about his team. ''Talk about the weather or politics,'' he suggested. Williams's reluctance to talk about his team, the surprisingly poor Chicago White Sox, was understandable. They had lost 22 of 27 games in the previous month and had tumbled to 14 1/2 games from first place from 4 1/2 games behind. There was not much that Williams could talk about without feeling more ill.

It is perhaps a sign of how far sub-Saharan Africa still has to go that the most vigorous -- and certainly the best publicized -- debate about its economic future in recent years has been between two American economists based in New York. On one side of the argument is Jeffrey D. Sachs, the director of the Earth Institute at Columbia University and the author of ''The End of Poverty.'' On the other is William Easterly of New York University, whose ironically titled ''White Man's Burden'' lampoons Sachs as a modern version of a 19th-century utopian. There is indeed something faintly Victorian about Sachs's messianic yet parsimonious conviction that Africa can be saved with $75 billion a year in Western aid. Having spent so much of his energies in the 1990s extolling the virtues of the free market to any Eastern European government that would listen, Sachs now argues -- with equally unshakable conviction -- that the elimination of African poverty can be achieved through state planning. All governments need do is improve agricultural technology, provide antimalaria bed nets, treat diseases like hookworm and distribute antiretroviral treatments to the H.I.V.-infected.

NICKLIN--George, Quaker Psychiatrist, psychoanalyst, and educator, who helped to found numerous educational and professional institutions, died Tuesday in Medford, NJ. He was 81. He was an innovator whose vision of a better world touched many lives. From launching a program of swimming lessons for children and starting a Friends Meeting on Shelter Island where he summered with his family for 50 years, to founding Westbury Friends School, establishing the Long Island Psychoanalytic Institute, and creating the Friends World College experiential education program with campuses on five continents, he brought his creative vision and his energy to hundreds of worthwhile projects, large and small, throughout his life. Born in 1925, he served proudly in the Ninth Infantry Division (Old Reliables) in World War II, where he was severely wounded. After the War, he graduated from Haverford College and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, and had a distinguished career of more than 50 years as a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in New York City and on Long Island. He followed the admonition of George Fox to ''walk cheerfully over the world, answering that of God in every one.'' He was the beloved husband for 57 years of Kate Nicklin, as well as loving father of Emily Nicklin, David Nicklin, Jane Nicklin Olsen, and Sarah Nicklin, proud grandfather of Max, Luke, and Anna Schleusener, Kate, Megan, and Sarafina Kietzman-Nicklin, Emma, Molly, and Elizabeth Olsen, and Graham, Clara, and Olivia Moreno. Dad, thank you for always believing in us. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Westbury Friends School, 550 Post Ave, Westbury, NY 11590. Memorial service to be held at The Purchase Friends Meeting House, Purchase Street (Route 120), Purchase, New York, at 1pm on Thursday, July 12.

QEvery year my co-op board imposes a buildingwide assessment to recapture the New York City co-op tax abatement given to shareholders. This year, they are also recapturing the tax exemption from the New York State School Tax Relief Program. Is this legal? A ''It is legal,'' said Stuart M. Saft, a Manhattan lawyer who is the chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. He added that it was fairly common for co-ops to impose an assessment equal to the total amount of the rebate received in the building. ''This is a relatively painless way of raising revenue,'' he said.

It was with heartbreak and frustration that I read Rosenberg's article. As a social worker who formerly worked for an in-home hospice program in New York, I have encountered numerous patients who described years of battling crippling pain associated with their disease, only to find comfort in the last days of their lives through comprehensive palliative care. It is too bad that society only considers those at the very end of life to be worthy of ''living'' pain-free.

As an emergency-medicine physician, I routinely evaluate and treat patients in pain. Among this population are those seeking narcotic prescriptions inappropriately. While these patients can be difficult to distinguish on history and physical exam, an electronic medical record that quickly documents past clinical visits and medications is an invaluable objective tool. Multiple visits and narcotic prescriptions from different doctors are red flags that are easy to spot on the computer: yet another reason to implement a national electronic medical-record system. Mark Thanassi, M.D. Portola Valley, Calif.

The low point in the relationship between United States Postal Service employees and customers in Brooklyn may well have come in late March, when someone videotaped a fellow customer's five-minute, profanity-laced tirade against an employee at the borough's Kensington post office and posted the clip on YouTube. More than a few commenters on the Web site said they lived in the area and knew how the ranter felt. Several weeks later, in response to other, unrelated complaints, the agency convened a new Customer Advisory Council, a panel of representatives from Brooklyn community boards, with the goal of improving service. The most recent of the group's quarterly meetings, closed to reporters, was on June 21, and the next is tentatively scheduled for Sept. 20.

Thanks to Tina Rosenberg (June 17) for shedding light on a serious issue for chronic-pain sufferers and the doctors who care for them. The fine line between helping and harming is emotionally taxing enough for responsible physicians without the threat of incarceration. These are matters too delicate and medically complex to be decided by those who don't negotiate this very narrow passage on a regular basis.

EVEN at the Pasteur Pharmacy, a drugstore on East 34th Street that specializes in hard-to-find products, the shaving cream men are among the most fervent customers. They gaze up at shelves of creams and balms along the side wall, blocking the aisle back to the pharmacy counter while gently unscrewing plastic tubs bearing old-fashioned calligraphy and hefty price tags to sniff the contents. These are fellows who shun the three-, four- and five-blade contraptions and canned goops for an older mode of shaving that they insist remains the ideal: a straight razor or a safety razor with a double-edged blade, and a fine English cream lathered and applied with a badger-hair brush. They congregate on the Internet, at sites like www.shavemyface.com, and in recent weeks, they have been flocking to Pasteur, on East 34th near Park Avenue and its other location, on Lexington Avenue near 62nd Street, thanks to the brief re-emergence of a beloved brand of shaving cream that many thought was gone for good.

If you didn't fill up your favorite jalopy before reading this, it's probably too late to duck the price rise for gasoline that has been an annual event in Connecticut for three years now, every July 1. That's when the state's ''hidden tax'' on gas -- the levy on the wholesale price -- goes up.

The light turns green and the person in front of you doesn't step on the gas. Someone edges in on you too abruptly at the Midtown Tunnel. You're behind a minivan driving below the speed limit on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Do you yell, gesture, curse or honk? Of course you do. After all, this is New York, and this spring we went from third place to second in instances of aggressive driving and road rage. A new national poll of 2,500 drivers brings word that only Miami is more badly behaved than we are.

It is with a heavy heart that we mourn the passing of beloved friend and relative, Emil. He will truly be missed by so many people who loved and respected him. Blanche & Bernie Etra and family BUCKNER--Emil. You will always be our Uncle Emil. We will miss you. Sandra and Donald, Barbara and David, Jimmy and Bill

WOLFE--Glenn P., novelist, died June 23, 2007, in his home in Bethesda, MD, of lung cancer, on the eve of his 81st birthday. Wisconsin born and raised, he served in the USMC 1943-1946, received his B.A. from USC, M.A. from Columbia, and started his writing career in radio and television, notably the Perry Mason Series. In 1962 he left Los Angeles for Europe, where he met his Danish wife, Neter, 44 years ago and still madly in love. After his return to the US, he has been writing novels, film, drama and comedy. Glenn will be deeply mourned and missed by all for his loving gentleness, enthusiasm, sharp intellect and devastating wit. Love you always, nothing will ever be the same.

BEING English, I come from a long line of gardeners. Gardens figure in some of my earliest memories of time spent with my grandparents: being taught the names of flowers, being sent to dump the afternoon tea leaves on the compost pile, and being directed occasionally in the tiresome chores of weeding and deadheading.

In 1872, the Niagara grape was bred in Niagara County. This white hybrid's red parent, Concord, provided its deeply fruity aroma and flavor. Colonization of Finger Lakes vineyards by European grapes has eroded Niagara's popularity. Sheer Americana, Niagara should be uncorked at July 4 cookouts. Nonvintage Niagara Mist from Chateau LaFayette Reneau, on Seneca Lake, is a crackerjack off-dry version.

BENSON--Dr. Jerome, on May 15, 2007 at his home in Miami Beach after a brief illness, at age 84. Dr. Benson's 40 year medical career included serving as Chief Pathologist and Director of Clinical Laboratories at Mt. Sinai Medical Center and later at the Miami Heart Institute. Jerry Benson was nationally known for his work in the development of the certification process for accreditation of Medical Technology and Medical Laboratory Technician programs. He was a graduate of the Oberlin Conservatory, where he studied as a concert pianist, and the Creighton University School of Medicine. Upon retiring from medicine in 1991 Jerry became an avid student of photography, traveling throughout the world to capture dramatic scenes of wildlife and nature. His work was exhibited throughout South Florida. Survived by his wife Carol Elkins-Benson, daughter Jane Benson, sister Adele Fishman, and many loving nephews, nieces and brothers-in-law and sisters-in-law. Predeceased by daughter Lisa Fe and brother Arthur Benson.

SCHWAGER--Robert G. As a patient of Dr. Schwager, I came to admire his excellence as a surgeon and, in addition, his caring, heartfelt concern for his patients. His untimely passing has left a deep void. May God watch over him always. Lucille B. Scheffer

If portraiture is of the mode and cameos are having a moment, combining the two in an intimate, wearable portrait of yourself or a loved one is a true luxury. Amedeo Scognamiglio, 34, whose family has dealt in fine Italian shell cameos since 1857, decided six months ago to celebrate the diminutive 3-D portrait at Amedeo by M+M Scognamiglio, a boutique devoted to the art (958 Lexington Avenue in New York, 212-737-4100 or www.cameos.com). ''Nothing is more exclusive than to have a cameo carved with your own features,'' Mr. Scognamiglio said. Or maybe those of your spouse, children, mother or all of the above. He carves the very personal mementos himself; also among his commissions in conch are cats, horses and a dog named Rolex. ''We will not forget Rolex,'' he said. From $5,000.SUSAN GUERRERO

LIFE is all about being in the right place at the right time, and getting the opportunity to show your stuff. So many great and talented people never get that opportunity. John Miner (who is now on LSI's board) was my manager when I worked for Intel, and he gave me that shot. He gave me my first opportunity to form a division and become a general manager and run a profit-and-loss statement. It was 1996, and I was 32.

A HANDSOME young man sits across from me on the downtown No. 4 train. He has clear ebony skin, a high brow, symmetrical features. His hennaed dreads graze his shoulders. A black do-rag crowns his head; a yellow scrunchie circles the knee of his jeans. He is reading a book titled ''Ethics in Everyday Life.'' He holds the book in front of his chest with one hand; with the other, he breaks off a piece of the candy bar resting on his knee, a toffee and sesame seed amalgam concoction. A rogue bit of candy falls to the floor and lands near his foot. He looks down.

CHASE--Claire, of New York, NY, died peacefully in her own home on Friday, June 22, 2007. She was born March 9, 1928 in Queens, New York. She graduated from Queens College in 1945. She worked for the Finance Department of New York City as Director of Microcomputer Systems which she held until retirement. After retirement she continued working as a private consultant specializing in software and database management. She co-authored ''Using Microsoft Word'' in 1988. Her political and professional life began in Trinidad and Tobago. There she was an early proponent of the application and programming of system management for the Dominion Oil Company. She was also an early graduate of the ''University'' of Woodford Square, Trinidad. Returning to New York with her family she continued her professional career. Along with her professional responsibilities she pursued her two passions; Civil Rights and Women's Rights. She played key roles with C.O.R.E. and the Manhattan Women Political Caucus, particularly her ardent support of Bella Abzug. In retirement she used her unique talents in aiding various nonprofit organizations. She was inspired by the lives and works of Simone de Beauvoir, Eleanor Roosevelt, Bertrand Russell and Eric Williams. These interests and the generosity she extended to family and friends will define her and be her legacy. Her only brother Irwin Feder lives in Miami. She is survived by her husband of 54 years. Oswald Glean Chase, and son Howard, two grandsons, Philip and Michael Chase. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the American Civil Liberties Union, 125 Broad Street, 18th Floor, New York, NY 10004.

STONEWOOD--Emmanuel, 69, died on June 28. Beloved husband to Leila, devoted stepfather and grandfather to Dave, Bobby, Jan, Soussanna, Mila and Michael Passoff. Manny's love of family and friends, his generous spirit and sense of humor is a legacy he passes on to all who knew him.

In my first post for Home Fires, I began by dumping out my old Army duffel bags and going through my gear while cleaning out the garage. Each week I've been surprised and amazed to read the posts by the other soldier-writers here - Sandi, Michael, Lee and Jeffrey. I've been surprised by my own words and experiences, too. (Believe me, driving to Vegas was a shocker!) And now that a month has passed, I find that in an odd way I've come full circle.

Politicians usually shift their campaigns into high gear on Labor Day, assuming that before then, voters are preoccupied with summertime pursuits. But all the barnstorming this Fourth of July week is another reminder that the wide-open 2008 race is upending the customs of politics.
As some of the leading candidates for president ramp up their campaigning this week, what about those who aren't drawing many headlines or showing strength in the polls?
Other presidential contenders have sold more books, but none of their books have sold for as much as Fred D. Thompson's.

With all the attention devoted to the presidential race, it might be easy to forget that Congressional campaigns are also well under way. So, too, is the fight to raise money for those races. And heading into the summer, Democrats are showing more strength on that front than Republicans.
