'GAZILLION BUBBLE SHOW' Fan Yang spends much of his time onstage waving a wand, but what he creates isn't exactly magic, except perhaps to his young admirers. Mr. Yang, above, described as a bubble scientist, works with soap and water, which seem to attract children in a theater as much as they sometimes repel them in a bath. His ''Gazillion Bubble Show,'' at New World Stages, displays his talents, which have earned him numerous citations in the Guinness Book of World Records, including one for creating the largest bubble wall (156 feet long). On Sunday he said he had set another world record the previous week, by encapsulating 34 people in a bubble house. I was hoping for something similar, only to find the scale of Mr. Yang's feats, at least that day, more modest. In his uninterrupted 70-minute show, he entertains with bubble sculpture and soapy sleight of hand. The multimedia presentation, with taped music, laser effects and video projections, incorporates a brief biography and lots of audience participation.

The kidnappers of the 3-year-old daughter of a British expatriate abducted in the Niger Delta yesterday have telephoned her father to say she is ''in safe hands,'' the police in Port Harcourt said. They said it was not known if the gunmen who seized the girl, Margaret Hill, outside her school had demanded a ransom for her release.

FISCHER--Edward P., Treasurer Emeritus of the former Mobil Oil Corporation, died peacefully on Wednesday July 4th at his home in White Plains, NY. Ed was born on November 17, 1908 in Brooklyn, the youngest of three children. His brother Valentine predeceased him in 1997 and his sister, Louisa predeceased him in 1948. After completing high school in Brooklyn, he earned his bachelors degree in business at New York University. Ed began his career with Mobil Oil Corp. (then the Standard Oil Company of New York) in Long Island City, NY. He later joined the accounting department at the company's headquarters in Manhattan. Ed rose through the ranks, eventually achieving the position of Corporate Treasurer in 1959, and held the position until his retirement in 1974. Upon his retirement, he was appointed as a consultant with athe company for the next 10 years. Ed moved to White Plains in 1940. He was a member of the Westchester Hills Golf Club for more than 60 years, a portion of that time as treasurer and also serving on the Board of Directors. He was a member of Westchester Country Club for more than 25 years and served on the Board of St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains for several terms. He was predeceased by his first wife Margaret Kelly Fischer in 1934 and his second wife, Susan Kelly Fischer in 1972. Ed is survived by his wife of 28 years, Kathryn (Kay) Gahan Fischer, his daughter Margaret O'Grady and her husband, Terence of Wellington, FL and his three granddaughters, Maureen Delano and her husband Mark of Briarcliff Manor, NY, Ellen Maloney and her husband Tom of Granite Springs, NY and Cathering Jahn and her husband Albert of Lancaster, PA. Also surviving him are 10 great-grandchildren. Visitation for the family and friends will be held on Friday, July 6th from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday, July 7th at 10:30am at Our Lady of Sorrows Church in White Plains followed by interment at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Memorial donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 S. Broadway, 4th floor, White Plains, NY 10601. McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home Inc. 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605. (914)949-7777

A principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who is also the son of Peter Martins, the company's master in chief, faces a drug charge in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where the troupe is staging summer performances, The Associated Press reported. Nilas Martins, 40, was charged with cocaine possession, the police said. An officer was walking by Nilas Martins's parked BMW in Saratoga Springs shortly after 1:30 a.m. on Tuesday and saw him trying to hide what turned out to be a bag containing a half-gram of cocaine, the police said. Mr. Martins pleaded not guilty to the charge, a felony punishable by up to seven years in prison.

The Coast Guard rescued more than 110 participants in a sailing regatta, most of them children 11 to 15 years old, from Dublin Bay after a sudden squall capsized a number of the small craft. All had life jackets. Fifteen were taken to hospitals with symptoms of hypothermia. Others described on television how they were thrown into the water off Dun Laoghaire when the wind toppled the boats.

This property is almost an acre and has 398 feet of frontage on Lake James along with a covered dock and a boat lift. Built in 1997, the house is 3,434 square feet and has two and a half bathrooms, vaulted ceilings, a formal dining room and a hot tub on the screened porch. There are also a gas fireplace, a three-car garage and a back deck on two levels that faces the lake. Morganton is about 90 miles from Charlotte in the western part of the state. Broker: Polly Leadbetter, Lake James Real Estate, (828) 584-9999; www.lakejamesrealestate.com.

A Belgian court sent Bernard Ntuyahaga, a former major in the Rwanda Army, to prison for 20 years for his role in the killing of 10 United Nations peacekeepers from Belgium in 1994, at the start of the Rwandan genocide.
SHADOW COMPANY Opens today in Manhattan.

The wraparound deck on this waterfront log home looks out on the 134-mile-long Lake Barkley, in western Kentucky. Built in 2000, the house is 3,576 square feet and has 285 feet of waterfront. It has three bathrooms, an office that can be used as a fourth bedroom and two unfinished basement rooms that could also be turned into bedrooms. The lake allows motorboats, and a boat slip is available at the community dock. Cadiz is about 80 miles from Nashville, Tenn. Agent: Terri Bozeman, Lake Area Properties, (270) 522-1588; www.lakebarkley.biz.

D'AMATO--George G. The partners, associates and staff of D'Amato & Lynch mourn the passing of its founding partner, George G. D'Amato. George was a legal legend of insurance law. George was particularly known as one of the creators and prime movers in the development of directors and officers liability insurance, as well as insurance for accountants and lawyers. George was a valued advisor and skilled negotiator and above all a gentlemen. George was devoted to his wife, Dorothy, and his son David. He will always be cherished in our hearts and never forgotten. D'AMATO--George. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the loss of our dear friend and loyal supporter George D'Amato. Our condolences to his wife Dorothy and the entire D'Amato family. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO D'AMATO--George. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Dorothy, his son David, his sister Gloria, and the entire family. Attilio Petrocelli, President Roger Blumencranz, Sect'y D'AMATO--George G. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member, George and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Dorothy, and the entire family. Board Of Governors Stuart B. Wilkins, President D'AMATO--George Jr. The Reitmans and extended family extends our deepest sympathy. George was my best friend and business associate for 50 years, needless to say he will be sorely missed.

Nine people were killed when a small cargo jet blew a tire on takeoff and crashed onto a highway in northwestern Culiacán in northwestern Mexico. Three people aboard the plane died, along with two soldiers patrolling the airstrip and a family of four in a car on the highway, the authorities said.

CIMINO--Joseph A., M.D., beloved husband of Peggy. Loving father of Andrea, Laura, Lisa, Joseph, Linda, Margaret, and John. Devoted grandfather of Margaret, Cameron, Vincent, Matthew, Nicolas, Joseph, and Natalie. He was a dedicated public health advocate and served as the New York City Commissioner of Health, Commissioner of the Westchester County Medical Center, President of New York Medical College, and professor and chairman of the Department of Community and Preventive Medicine at the college. He was a dedicated physician and teacher and will be missed forever, but his legacy of love, generosity and compassion will live on in the hearts of all his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the memory of Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, Chairman of the Department of Community and Preventive Medicine, New York Medical College, Development Office, Administrative Building, Valhalla, NY 10595 or to the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor. Visitation will be held at the Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY (914-631-0621) on July 6 from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Services will be held on July 7 at 10:30 am at the church of the Magdalene in Pocantico Hills, NY.

'TAP CITY' Dance performances are hard to come by in the middle of the summer, so it seems fitting that tap, which is given scant stage space throughout the year, would take New York by storm every July in the form of ''Tap City,'' Tony Waag's wide-ranging showcase of styles, traditions and generations. The festival kicks off on Wednesday with ''Tap Youth/Tap Future,'' an evening of performances by youth ensembles. This celebration of American youngsters is followed by ''Tap Internationals'' on Thursday. Born centuries ago on this continent, tap is a child of many cultures, so it's no surprise that some of the most vibrant experimentation is now being conducted as far away as Finland and Japan. Artists from these countries, as well as from Spain, Brazil, Estonia and South Africa, will offer glimpses of where tap dance is headed worldwide. (Max Pollak, right, and his company, Rumba Tap, perform on Thursday.) Of course, American tap isn't doing so badly, and next Friday some of this country's most exciting individuals and ensembles, including Michelle Dorrance, Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, Ayodele Casel and Jason Samuels Smith, will hit the wood. Festival performances conclude on July 14 with Mr. Waag leading ''Tap & Song,'' a spirited homage to vaudeville and comedy routines. He will be joined by luminaries like Derrick K. Grant and Brenda Bufalino. But the real star of that show will most likely be the irrepressible Mable Lee, the venerable tap elder whose hemlines seem to get shorter with every year she's been in show business. And that's a lot of years. (Wednesday through July 14, at 7 and 9:30 p.m., the Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com, atdf.org; $40.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

ICE FACTORY '07 This summer's outbreak of theater festivals, one of the more virulent in recent memory, continues apace. Aside from those recently closed (Brits Off Broadway, Gayfest NYC) and those happening now (Women Center Stage, Hot!), there are more on the way (Lincoln Center Festival, Fresh Fruit and others) leading up to the biggie -- the New York International Fringe Festival -- which will soon grab most of the headlines and actors. But SoHo Think Tank's annual Ice Factory festival is older (this is its 14th showing ) and far less chaotic than the Fringe. Seven plays in seven weeks, one at a time: nice and simple. The festival has previously provided an arena for envelope-pushing companies like Elevator Repair Service, Pig Iron Theater Company and Les Freres Corbusier to develop new work for possible productions, and the fare this time around will be equally offbeat. First is ''No More Pretending (a k a the Return of Indiebot)'' by Kirk Wood Bromley, the artistic director of Inverse Theater, which has been producing new American verse plays since 1998. Mr. Bromley's play is itself a celebration of indie theater and centers on a reunion of three actors who used to work together and have since traveled different paths. It closes tomorrow night to make way for next weekend's offering -- a tall tale by Rachel Shukert about a promiscuous frontiersman, presented by the Bushwick Hotel theater company -- and the five additional productions that follow. Forthcoming highlights include Alena Smith's ''Lacy Project'' (July 25 to 28), directed by Susanna Gellert and starring Kristen Connolly (above). Ms. Smith's play, developed at the Yale School of Drama, was a finalist for the 2006 O'Neill Playwrights Conference and a 2006 Princess Grace Award. Ice Factory '07 will end with a closing-night dance party on Aug. 18. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 7, Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street, SoHo, 212-868-4444, smarttix.com; $15; $10 for students and 65+.) STEVEN McELROY

FOR CHILDREN BROOKLYN CHILDREN'S MUSEUM (Sunday and Tuesday) You can discover the world through all the cultures that are represented in Brooklyn, and that's what young museum visitors will do in a series of global programs. On Sunday from noon to 5 p.m., ''Ciao Italy'' will include a game of bocce and investigations into the mysteries of Italian opera and olive oil making. On Tuesday from 1:30 to 3 p.m., ''Ethiopian Cuisine'' will offer a flavorful introduction to the country's spicy cooking and a party in which it's safe to forget your manners: Eating with the hands is required. At 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights, (718) 735-4400, brooklynkids.org. Free with admission: $5; free for members.
To the Editor: Re ''Bush Evokes Revolutionary War to Bolster U.S. Cause in Iraq'' (news article, July 5):

JENKINS--William Maxwell, April 19, 1919 -June 27, 2007. A son of the Northwest, Bill Jenkins, 88, died peacefully at his home on Bainbridge Island, Washington surrounded by his family. Bill believed that ''the best of times is now'' and daily lived that motto. His indomitable presence and ability to drink in life in big gulps charmed us all. Born in Sultan, Washington, the son of Warren and Louise Jenkins, Bill spent his early life in Everett, Washington and was a 1937 graduate of Everett High School. He graduated from the University of Washington in 1941 and the Graduate School of Business at Harvard University in 1943. During WWII, as part of the Navy Combat Demolition Unit, Bill landed at Omaha Beach. For his heroism under fire Bill was awarded the Navy Cross and the French Croix d'Guerre with Palm. Bill began his banking career at Seattle First - International Bank in 1945. In 1962 he was named CEO of Seafirst and served in that capacity until his retirement in 1982. Under his leadership, Seafirst became the dominant bank in the Northwest, eventually becoming one of the top ten most profitable banks in America. Bill served on the board of directors of many corporations, among them, United Airlines, Pacific Northwest Bell, Safeco, and Scott Paper. Additionally, he was a past-President of the Association of Reserve City Bankers. Bill is survived by his wife Ann Ramsay-Jenkins, his children: Cordy Beckstead; Ann Rohrbacher; William Jenkins; Karen Olanna; Peter Jenkins; David Jenkins; Barbara Jenkins; and Ann's son, Adam Cornell. Survivors also include 20 grandchildren and five great-granchildren. At the request of the family, remembrances may be made to the William M. Jenkins and Ann Ramsay-Jenkins Endowed Scholarship Fund, The College Success Foundation, 1605 NW Sammamish Road, suite 100, Issaquah, Washington. The foundation provides college scholarships and mentoring to low-income, high potential students. A reception will take place July 16th at the Men's University Club, 1004 Boren Ave., Seattle, WA. A private interment will take place at Arlington National Cemetery. Sign the online guestbook at: www.cook familyfuneralhome.com

A German film fund will grant subsidies worth $6.5 million to Tom Cruise's new film, ''Valkyrie,'' Reuters reported. The grant, from a fund with an annual film-subsidy budget of $82 million, exceeds the total cost of most German movies. Last week the German government barred the filmmakers from using a location where the military officer portrayed by Mr. Cruise was executed for a failed attempt to assassinate Hitler. A spokesman for the German government said that Mr. Cruise's affiliation with Scientology had nothing to do with that decision. The Finance Ministry, which controls state properties, said filming is generally banned at the location -- now a national shrine -- because of a previous bad experience with a German filmmaker.

CARDILE--Julius J. Hon. Priory of New York of the Sovereign Order of the Orthodox Knights Hospitaller of Saint John of Jerusalem, mourns the passing of its Prior Emeritus who served for a decade and was involved in numerous charitable causes. Cesare Santeramo, KCSJ Chancellor, Council of the New York Priory CARDILE--Julius J., on July 2, 2007, beloved husband of the late Mary nee Contrucci, cherished father of Paul. Attended St. Peter's College, Fordham and NYU for law. Belonged to numerous organizations and clubs, most notably Colonel of the State of Kentucky, and Prior, Grand Conservator and Commander Grand Cross of the Order of Saint John. Devoted to Italian and Church studies and activities. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Saturday 79 pm and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Monday 10:30 am St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington at 66th St. Memorial contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to any charity, church and organization in his name.

This post-and-beam house has 200 feet of frontage on Gull Lake in central Minnesota, an area that has thousands of lakes. Gull Lake allows motorboats. The house is 2,287 square feet and is on just over a half-acre. It has three bathrooms, including a master bath with a jetted tub. There are vaulted ceilings, granite counters in the kitchen, a stone fireplace, a lower-level bunk room and a one-car garage. Brainerd is 125 miles north of Minneapolis. Broker: Jim Christensen, Kurilla Real Estate, (800) 939-2147; www.lakeshorebroker.com.

KAPLAN--Marcella (Abrams), aged 102, of New York City died July 3, 2007. Born in Hobart, NY, Marcella led a full life filled with travel, family and friends. She worked for many years as personal assistant to Gottlieb Hammer, Executive VP of the United Jewish Appeal. She enjoyed theater, concerts and traveling to many parts of the world. A longtime member of the 92nd Street YMHA, she was a well known bridge player there every Tuesday and Thursday for over 60 years. Ms. Kaplan is survived by many loving nieces and nephews who will miss her sharp wit, colorful observations and deep love for her family. Contributions in her memory can be made to the United Jewish Appeal.

SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON For a drummer, Pamela Patrick uses the word harmony a lot more than you'd expect. ''You have all of these different drummers, you communicate with all of them and come up with harmony -- well, not harmony in the usual sense,'' she said, grasping for the term to describe her show tonight. She needn't have looked any further. With her djembe on her lap, Ms. Patrick will lead a drumming circle in the first concert in this year's Sunset Jam on the Hudson, a weekly series created nearly two decades ago by the Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Her task: to blend what could become a cacophony of rhythm into a distinct song. Her band: anyone who happens to drop by. ''It's a combination of performing and teaching,'' said Ms. Patrick, an accompanist at New York University who specializes in African and Caribbean drumming. ''It's exciting to get everyone to play a rhythm that sounds good and feels good.'' Other performers leading circles in this summer's series are Maguette Camara, who directs the conservancy's drumming sessions for teenagers and teaches African dance at Barnard-Columbia, and Mary Knysh, who also plays flute, mandolin and other instruments. Ms. Patrick, who has led circles for seven years, says they draw an ''intergenerational, interracial'' crowd. In addition to harmony, racial and otherwise, the drumming circles have another appeal: as Ms. Patrick's easy smile when she played recently suggests, tapping out a rhythm can be just plain fun. (Fridays from 6:30 until 8:30 p.m., through Aug. 24, Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park, Lower Manhattan, 212-267-9700, bpcparks.org; free, drums provided.) MONICA DRAKE

KELLEHER--Rev. William A.; of Bronxville on July 5, 2007. Brother of Miriam A. Kelleher and the late Agnes P. Kelleher. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9pm Saturday and 2-5pm Sunday. Mass of the Eucharist Sunday 7pm at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church on Monday July 9 at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave, Hawthorne, NY 10532

Pfizer settled a lawsuit against a rival drug maker, Novartis, for alleged infringement of a United States patent for the antibiotic medicine Zithromax. Pfizer sued Novartis and Sandoz, a unit operating in the United States, in February 2006 in federal court in Wilmington, Del., saying it would be irreparably harmed by the rival companies' use of the invention for forms of crystal azithromycin; Pfizer sought unspecified damages. The parties have agreed to settle all claims over the 2005 drug patent, and the suit was dismissed June 25, according to court papers. Pfizer is based in New York, and Novartis is based in Basel, Switzerland.

THE sharp-shooting human rights litigator and National Security Agency antagonist Ann Beeson (words and a dead-on grasp of the Constitution are her chosen weapons) is evidently not inside her new office at George Soros's Open Society Institute. It is way too quiet in here. Ms. Beeson and the sounds of silence are an oil-and-water proposition. She is, after all, a Texan: talks with a twang and tells it like a storyteller even when she's arguing before the United States Supreme Court, which, as a top lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, she has done twice. Successfully. Wearing orange, her signature shade, both times. Even her favorite color is noisy.
COOK--Richard, On the one month anniversary of his death, the family of Richard A. Cook wishes to remember his good humor and his generosity to family, friends and his favored organizations.

REWIND: A CANTATA FOR VOICE, TAPE AND TESTIMONYBeethoven wrote odes to freedom and political equality. John Adams gave music to Richard M. Nixon's diplomatic mission to China. Now the South African composer Philip Miller has honored the 10th anniversary of his country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearings in song. Music is less inherently foreign to these hearings than it was to Metternich's Vienna or Nixon's trip to China. The hearings were conceived as a way to allow ordinary people to voice their grievances and memories of a country under apartheid, stimulating the healing process; and when the proceedings became heated, everyone joined in hymns until things calmed down. Some of those hymns have a place in ''REwind,'' above, as does digital sampling, recordings of the testimony and contributions from the Total Praise Choir of the Emmanuel Baptist Church in Brooklyn. While he mingles these local voices in his work -- the piece is being presented as part of Celebrate Brooklyn -- Mr. Miller, well known in South Africa for, among other things, his collaboration with the visual artist and filmmaker William Kentridge, is trying to give voice to the ethos of his own nation. Accordingly, the piece also features some leading South African voices, like that of Sibongile Khumalo, a genre-busting singer, classically trained, known as a jazz performer, experienced in opera and hailed as a ''marvel'' in The Chicago Tribune for her appearance in the South African opera ''Princess Magogo'' at the Ravinia Festival in 2004. The work is best described as a collage of national styles, from traditional Zulu techniques to protest music of the apartheid era; presumably this fits right in with the colorful melting pot that is Brooklyn. (Tonight at 7:30, Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-855-7882, brooklynx.org; free.) ANNE MIDGETTE

AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites

What part of Valentino's extraordinary 45th anniversary party will people talk about most? Dante Ferretti's recreation of the Temple of Venus and Rome, with the Colosseum right in front of you? The feeling that you were seeing 30 years of W magazine come alive? The fact that everything was glamorous and extremely classy yet relaxed? The exhibition at the Museum of Ara Pacis? The moment at the museum when Valentino took Karl Lagerfeld's hand and walked him around to some of the displays? The Chinese-themed tent near the Villa Borghese that was built just for Saturday's black-tie dinner, and will be torn down tomorrow? The $10 million-plus price-tag for the weekend?

Even when most of Major League Baseball insisted upon walking Barry Bonds every other time he came to bat, the St. Louis Cardinals were aggressive with him. Tony La Russa, the Cardinals' manager, seemed to take pride in pitching to Bonds. La Russa, after all, managed Mark McGwire in 1998, when McGwire hit 70 home runs and gave opposing teams every reason to work around him.
For live updates of tonight's Brazil-Chile game by Duncan Irving, click "read more" then bash your F5 or "refresh" key to keep current.

Approximately 21 hours have passed Jose Reyes's ill-advised decision not to run out a ground ball, enough time I would suspect, for everyone to get his point across. Willie Randolph was irate last night and had pointed comments before tonight's game about what he perceived was a discouraging pattern. Reyes still remained apologetic, acknowledging what he did was wrong and saying he hoped it wouldn't happen again.

In Mexico there are no licensing or registration requirements for real estate agents, which means your bartender in the nightclub might show up as your agent the next day. Anyone can represent themselves as an agent. While rare, stories abound of unscrupulous or simply under-prepared agents fouling up deals.

One of the finalists for my Win-A-Trip contest, Amelia Knopf, salved her regret at not winning by organizing her own trip to Africa. Hats off to her, for that's what I'd love to see more young Americans do. And in some ways, you'll have a better and more memorable trip if you go alone, or with a friend, rather than having me as your travel agent. Read Amelia's blog here.

The Lewis Hamilton effect is felt everywhere. When I left the paddock last night after 10:30 PM - when I took the photo below to provide another view of the new McLaren motor home, as promised - it took 25 minutes to drive back to my hotel in Northampton. When I returned to the track this morning shortly after 8:00 AM, it took an hour and a half. The Hamilton phenomenon is living up to expectation.

Let's just say there won't be a whole lot of word-mincing on ABC's "This Week with George Stephanopoulos" on Sunday. Guests include Representative John Conyers, the Democratic chairman of the House Judiciary Committee who will hold hearings next week to examine presidential pardons. "We're going to review all of them, including Clinton's, Bush one, Bush two, we'll go back as far as they want," he told Fox News Radio. "This Week" also has Representative Ron Paul and former Senator Mike Gravel, who are running for the G.O.P. and Democratic presidential nominations, respectively, and are known for their uninhibited debate styles and small-but-enthusiastic supporter bases.

Before American fans get *too* excited about the U-20 team beating the young Brazilians, it might be good to remember that the Brazilian U-20 side have been far from impressive up in Canada. They lost to a Poland team that was bad enough to have lost to the US, 6-1, and they had to scramble to beat South Korea.
The government has until Monday to protect the redacted names of baseball players who were supplied performance-enhancing drugs by a former Mets clubhouse attendant.

The ratings polls are in from Sam's Army, the traveling supporters of the US national team. The average ratings below reflect the general disappointment with the Nats at the Copa América, but they also show that a handful of players impressed the fans who pay the closest attention.
A record-breaking heat wave in the Southwest is pushing northward.

For many G.O.P. primary voters, Fred D. Thompson is the alternative to the current major Republican candidates because they believe he's both reliably conservative and viable in a national election. But new questions are surfacing about his reliability on the abortion issue.

With group play completed and the knockout round about to begin, here is a look at how nations have done in the 41 previous editions of the Copa América. Note how the South American big three --Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil -- dominate the tournament, having won 35 Copas among them. Those three countries, plus Chile, made up the entire field in the inaugural 1916 tournament.
Roger Federer will have a chance to match Bjorn Borg’s modern record by winning his fifth consecutive Wimbledon.

The 20th edition of the Ciudad de Léon tournament is underway in Spain. It features a series of three matches on consecutive days among four players. The matches are four games with each game being played at the fairly rapid rate of 20 minutes per game plus 10 seconds added after each move. The official Web site for the tournament is here.

Sure Via Condotti is Rome's most famous shopping street, and the perfect place to go if you're looking for Burberry or Prada -- high price brands sold in elegant glass and marble stores that are the same all over the world. But for me and my teenage daughter Cara (a world-class shopper), by far the most interesting shopping street in Rome in the narrow, zig-zagging Via Del Governo Vecchio (map), just a stone's throw from bustling Piazza Navona, but generally serene and underpopulated.
Lebanon's troubles are not principally about Islamic militancy, but some fear the country could attract more of it, especially from the Iraq war.
Janel McCarville had a season-high 18 points and a career-best 12 rebounds for the Liberty (9-8).
Greg Winter speaks with Alissa Rubin, a Times Baghdad correspondent, about American claims that Iran is secretly helping insurgents kill U.S. soldiers in Iraq.
Alex Rodriguez rejoined the Yankees’ lineup and showed off All-Star form Friday night, hitting a home run that tied him with Lou Gehrig on the career list and leading the Yankees to a wild win.

Jozy Altidore, a forward for the Red Bulls of M.L.S., scored in each half yesterday in Ottawa to help the United States to a 2-1 victory over Brazil in the Under-20 World Cup. The United States finished atop Group D with 7 points. That left Brazil, the four-time champion, with only 3 points, trying to secure one of four berths given to third-place teams.
Mike Pelfrey has made eight starts this season, losing seven after the Mets’ defeat to the Houston Astros at Minute Maid Park on Friday night.
FREEHOLD, N.J., July 6 (AP) — The parents of a 14-month-old boy who weighed just 10 pounds when he was found dead in a home stocked with food were sentenced on Friday to three years in prison.

A marijuana advocate will not spend time in prison despite a conviction for growing and distributing hundreds of marijuana plants, a federal judge ruled. The man, Ed Rosenthal, 63, was convicted in May on three cultivation and conspiracy charges. But the judge, Charles Breyer of Federal District Court, said a one-day prison sentence was punishment enough for Mr. Rosenthal, who said he planned to appeal his conviction. “I should not remain a felon,” he said. Mr. Rosenthal was convicted on the same charges four years ago. Judge Breyer sentenced him to one day in prison because Mr. Rosenthal reasonably believed he was immune from prosecution because he was acting on behalf of Oakland city officials. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit overturned that 2003 conviction and ordered a retrial because of juror misconduct.

A gunman opened fire from a balcony inside the New York-New York casino in Las Vegas and injured four people, before being tackled by off-duty military reservists. A woman was bruised and scraped when she fell as the crowd fled the casino. All the injuries were described as minor, the authorities said. The police arrested Steven Zegrean, 51, of Las Vegas, in connection with the shootings, Capt. James Dillon said. “All we know so far is that he was emotionally distraught,” Captain Dillon said. Family members said Mr. Zegrean had been divorced for several years and was estranged from most of his family.
The planned weekend launching of a spacecraft to explore two of the solar system’s largest asteroids was delayed again because of problems with a tracking ship and aircraft.

Representative Jim McDermott said he would ask the Supreme Court to decide whether he had a right to disclose contents of an illegally taped call involving House Republican leaders a decade ago. A federal appeals court ruled in May that Mr. McDermott, Democrat of Washington, should not have given reporters access to the taped call of Republicans discussing the ethics case against former Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia. Mr. McDermott’s offense was especially egregious because he was a senior member of the House ethics committee, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said in a 5-to-4 ruling. The ruling upheld a decision ordering Mr. McDermott to pay Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, more than $700,000 for leaking the conversation.

Abortion providers will face new regulations for their clinics and new restrictions on teaching sex education classes under a bill signed into law by Gov. Matt Blunt, a Republican. The measure places more abortion clinics under government oversight by classifying them as ambulatory surgical centers. It also bars people affiliated with abortion providers from teaching or supplying materials for public school sex education courses. Missouri Right to Life, which backed the measure, argued that groups like Planned Parenthood had a conflict of interest in supplying sex education materials because they could make money if female students went to their clinics.

The owners of a nightclub where a fire killed 100 people in 2003 are starting a fund to help pay educational costs for the more than 75 children who lost a parent in the blaze, a partner in the fund said. The fund is being directed by brothers Jeffrey and Michael Derderian, their childhood friend Jody King and the three men’s wives, Mr. King said. It would probably cover expenses like tutoring, proms, athletic equipment and scholarships for students up to 12th grade, he said. The fire at the Station nightclub in West Warwick began when a band’s pyrotechnics ignited soundproofing foam the Derderians had installed around the stage. The brothers pleaded no contest last year to involuntary manslaughter charges.
The team said it would sponsor a summer camp run by the Chinese Baseball Association, donate a video batting machine to the league and continue their grass roots and marketing efforts.

An article on Thursday about a German backlash against plans for a mosque in Cologne, known for its Gothic cathedral, referred incorrectly to the size of polls taken for a local newspaper there, assessing the popularity of the mosque. The sample of 500 people was sufficient for a scientific poll; that sample was not “small,” nor did its size limit the poll’s “usefulness as a gauge of popular sentiment in a city of one million.”.
A military-appointed panel agreed on a final draft of a new constitution, which, if approved, would make elections a possibility.
The man who owned a karaoke bar in Liaoning Province where 25 people were killed in a giant explosion this week had stored more than a ton of TNT in the basement.

A front-page picture caption on Thursday with an article about an increase in the number of legal immigrants seeking to become United States citizens referred incorrectly to the group of service members shown being sworn in at a naturalization ceremony in Baghdad on Wednesday. They were all members of the United States Army; no members of the Marine Corps were shown, nor were any marines naturalized during the ceremony.

A picture caption yesterday with an article about a project documenting Mexican influences and folklore in the ranching West referred incorrectly to the musicians shown performing near Nampa, Idaho. They were performing for researchers from the Western Folklife Center, not as part of a benefit for the center.
Yuri Luzhkov, the powerful Moscow mayor praised as a reformer and vilified as an autocrat, was inaugurated for a fifth term.
An article in Business Day on Thursday about the South Korean search engine Naver.com misstated the number of workers at its parent company, NHN. It has 2,700 employees — not 27,000.
Parliament approved a bill barring all drivers under the age of 21 from drinking a drop of alcohol before taking the wheel.
The oil company BP agreed to freeze millions of dollars in payments to its former chief executive, John Browne, and its departing global refining chief, John Manzoni.
The city of Xiamen is considering a ban on anonymous Web postings after residents mounted a successful Internet campaign to suspend construction of a $1.4 billion chemical plant.

The High & Low Finance column in Business Day yesterday, about the stock performance of companies controlled by Donald J. Trump, misstated the date at one point that Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts went public. As the column noted elsewhere, it was in June 1995, not 1994.

An article on Thursday about the over-the-top Fourth of July parades for which Round Pond, Me., has become famous misspelled the surname of a man who was married while riding a float during this year’s parade. He is Kyle Westhaver, not Westhaven.

An article in some copies last Saturday about preparations for the opening of the Floating Pool Lady, a barge with a built-in swimming pool docked in the East River off Brooklyn Heights, included incorrect information from a representative of the barge owner about its previous name. (The error first appeared in an article on Oct. 31, 2006, about the barge’s arrival in New York.) Its former name was C500, not New Orleans. Also, the article last Saturday misspelled the surname of a construction supervisor. He is Steven Sivak, not Spivak.
A court sentenced Bob Denard, France’s best-known mercenary, to a year in prison for his role in mounting a coup in the Comoro Islands off southeast Africa in 1995.

A front-page picture caption on Thursday with an article about an increase in the number of legal immigrants seeking to become United States citizens referred incorrectly to the group of service members shown being sworn in at a naturalization ceremony in Baghdad on Wednesday. They were all members of the United States Army; no members of the Marine Corps were shown, nor were any marines naturalized during the ceremony.
Graig Nettles, Goose Gossage, Mickey Rivers and Mike Torrez said the 2007 Bronx Bombers could still make a run at the playoffs.
DETROIT, July 6 (AP) — The highest-scoring offense in baseball was too much for the team with the best record in the majors.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP) — Kevin McClatchy not only preserved baseball in Pittsburgh as the Pirates’ owner, but he also accomplished what was once seen as the impossible by getting a new stadium, PNC Park, built.

John Paddock was promoted to coach of the Ottawa Senators yesterday after two seasons as an assistant. He takes over a team that reached the Stanley Cup finals this spring. Paddock, 53, is the sixth coach in franchise history. He is replacing Bryan Murray, who was promoted to general manager in mid-June. Paddock was coach of the Winnipeg Jets from 1991 to 1995, compiling a record of 106-138-37.

Dick Pound, the chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency, told the International Olympic Committee assembly that “more than a handful” of Olympic sports had failed to comply with antidoping rules, endangering their place in future Games. Pound later declined to say which sports or exactly how many were in danger. But a WADA report distributed at the meeting showed that 13 of the 35 Olympic sports federations were not in compliance as of May 4. It also indicated that only 21 of the world’s 203 national Olympic committees had complied.

Defenseman Sean Hill, who became the first N.H.L. player suspended for violating the league’s drug policy last season, completed a one-year deal with the Minnesota Wild. Hill, 37, played for the Islanders last season. He was suspended for 20 games on April 20, hours before their playoff loss to Buffalo. He will miss the first 19 games this season.

FIFA will back down from its ban on matches in La Paz, Bolivia’s capital. Sepp Blatter, the FIFA president, said he was responding to a request from Evo Morales, the president of Bolivia. Morales led a campaign to overturn a ban on international matches at altitudes of more than 8,200 feet. The ban was announced in May.

After losing Chris Drury and Daniel Brière to free agency, the Buffalo Sabres made sure they held onto the high-scoring forward Thomas Vanek. The Sabres signed Vanek, 23, to a seven-year, $50 million contract, matching the offer from the Edmonton Oilers. Vanek, entering his third season, became one of the N.H.L.’s top-paid players after he led Buffalo with 43 goals last season. He also finished 20th in the league with 84 points.

California-Berkeley defeated Georgetown by four and a half lengths in the most lopsided of four quarterfinals yesterday, and it led three other United States teams into the semifinals of the Temple Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta in England. The Cal crew will now race Brown. Colgate and Cornell will meet in the other semifinal.

Qualifying for the Pepsi 400 in Daytona, Fla., was rained out yesterday, leaving several teams out of the season’s second race at Nascar’s most storied track. Jeff Gordon, the Nextel Cup series points leader, was awarded the pole. Denny Hamlin will start second, followed by Matt Kenseth, Jimmie Johnson and Jeff Burton. Boris Said was sitting on the pole before steady rain forced officials to cancel the qualifying session with 14 cars left to make runs. Nascar uses owner points to set the starting grid when qualifying is canceled.
A gunman walked up to a car carrying a family of four on Long Island Friday and opened fire, according to police.
Dave Williams has rebounded from the surgery he underwent to repair a herniated disk and is scheduled to be the Mets’ starting pitcher Sunday.
The nation’s most common cardiac malfunction, once thought harmless, is now being treated with costly medical procedures.
The presidential candidate, who has positioned himself as an opponent of abortion rights, appears once to have been hired as a lobbyist to work on the other side of the issue.
Two of the medical doctors arrested in connection with  the bungled car bomb attacks had made inquiries about practicing medicine in the United States.
China sentenced a former top drug safety official to death and disclosed an investigation into cellphone batteries after one reportedly exploded, killing a man.
The director of the National Hurricane Center, already squabbling with the National Weather Service headquarters, is facing an insurrection from his staff.
While Lebanon’s troubles are not principally about Islamic militancy, some fear the country could attract more of it, especially from the Iraq war.
Gov. M. Jodi Rell has vetoed a bill that would have given the state comptroller the authority to prescribe special accounting rules for the state.
The job market looked much like the economy as a whole last month: subdued but strong enough.
Neifi Pérez, a veteran utility infielder for the Detroit Tigers, has become the first major league player to be suspended for using a banned amphetamine.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

ALCOA QUESTIONED ON ALCAN BID Alcoa said that United States antitrust regulators had asked for more information about its $27.8 billion hostile takeover bid for a Canadian competitor, Alcan. Alcoa said it would comply with the request from the Department of Justice “as soon as possible,” without saying what details it would provide. Alcoa reiterated that it intended to complete the takeover this year. The offer expires Tuesday and can be extended. Alcan has urged shareholders to reject Alcoa’s bid, saying it is too low. (BLOOMBERG NEWS).
Officials insist that there will be no Guyanese-American Family Fun Day this year, but they have no idea whether people will show up for the annual event anyway.
In three years, sales of 100-calorie snack packs have passed the $20-million-a-year mark, as consumers don’t seem to mind paying more for less.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has increasingly been alluding to her spiritual life, but she has come under attack for it.
Barack Obama has joined Hillary Rodham Clinton on the misguided bandwagon of those seeking to penalize China for manipulating its currency.
For years now, plans and sometimes mere illusions about ways to replace New York City’s dismal and disheartening Penn Station have been debated.
It’s nice, for once, to be able to applaud how Congress is handling the annual appropriations bill for the three agencies that have the most to say about the environment.
Justin Morneau homered three times in the second game of a doubleheader and the Minnesota Twins capped a huge day on offense by routing the Chicago White Sox, 12-0, last night.
In Nascar’s Nextel Cup, Tony Stewart has somehow failed to lead the most important lap of every race: the final one.
To millions of legal immigrants, the federal government is sending a message that it wants them all to go away.
A divided federal appeals court panel in Cincinnati ruled that a lawsuit’s plaintiffs could not show injury from a National Security Agency program.
Connecticut’s Episcopal bishop has retaliated against the leadership of a congregation in Bristol for objecting to the church’s position on homosexuality.
When state legislators attacked Suffolk County Executive Steve Levy, it gave him the opportunity to play the local hero defending his constituents from Albany.
The United Automobile Workers union has cracked open the door a little wider to the kind of deal on retiree health benefits that Detroit auto companies would like to see.
The 29 residents of Bridgeville, Calif., are sour on the fact that their town has been sold on eBay.
Wimbledon is no longer a pigeon’s paradise thanks to Wayne Davis and his flock of Peregrine falcons.
Ms. Wyse authored more than 65 books and coined the slogan, “With a name like Smucker’s, it has to be good.”
The Universal Music Group of Vivendi told Apple that it would not renew its annual contract to sell music through iTunes, executives briefed on the matter said.
UBS, based in Zurich, refused to explain the reason for the sudden departure of Peter A. Wuffli, its chief executive.
Tiger Woods is one under at the halfway point of the AT&T National, in a tie for 12th but with a lot of work to do in his inaugural event as a host.
A suspected member of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia was executed for an August 2003 bomb attack, which killed Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, a politician and cleric.
According to data released by the Israeli government, 90 percent of Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank sprawl beyond their official boundaries.
The new chief, William J. S. Elliot, a lawyer and public servant, made little attempt to diminish the problems facing the national police force.
A surveillance video shows guards at a state prison struggling to open the door to a cell in which one prisoner is killing another prisoner — a convicted pedophile priest.
Two years after an unceremonious dismissal that drew street protests and appeals from public officials, the oldies radio format is returning to WCBS-FM.
In a setback for President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, the  main private shareholders of EADS agreed to give DaimlerChrysler the right to name the chief executive.
Omega Advisers, the $6 billion hedge fund, will pay $500,000 to resolve an investigation into its investment of more than $100 million in Azerbaijan.
The Tupperware Brands Corporation has been on a mission to update its Betty Crocker image.
Lenny Wilkens resigned Friday as the vice chairman of the Seattle SuperSonics, and Chauncey Billups agreed in principle to re-sign with the Detroit Pistons.
Some experts think that the hunt for extraterrestrial life should be greatly expanded to include something they call “weird life.”
The parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has raised its offer to buy the Chicago Board of Trade for the third time.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, plans to propose raising the cost of burning oil, gas and coal, in a move that could shake up the debate on global warming.
A high-pressure system brought highs of over 110 to parts of the Southwest, leading to hundreds of fires.
A former member of the only commune in New York City faces 25 years in prison for attempted murder.
PricewaterhouseCoopers, which audited Tyco International when it was run by executives who later went to prison, has agreed to pay $225 million to settle claims.
Federal authorities have filed court documents outlining a suspected dogfighting operation on property owned by Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick.
At a time when most presidential candidates are searching for ways to distance themselves from Washington, Joseph Biden is taking the opposite approach.
A day after raiding Dominique de Villepin’s home, judges  investigating allegations that he unlawfully tried to wreck Nicolas Sarkozy’s presidential hopes, searched his offices.
Johnny Frigo was a versatile jazz bassist and violinist who toured with Jimmy Dorsey and was a co-writer of the jazz standard “Detour Ahead.”
Wall Street ended the first week of the third quarter with a respectable gain, shaking off early losses as investors found signs of strength in the June employment report.
Farm animals found running loose in New York City often end up living at Farm Sanctuary, 175 acres of vegan nirvana in the Finger Lakes region.
India has only about 2.5 million people infected with H.I.V., less than half of previous estimates, the Indian health minister and U.N. health officials said.
As Mexico celebrates the centenary of Frida Kahlo’s birth, the largest retrospective ever of her work attempts to look beyond what Mexicans call Fridamania.
Legal Aid lawyer Peter A. Barta pleaded not guilty to felony charges of unlawful surveillance.
For the first time since 1957, all the major rivers in Texas are at flood stage.
There are an estimated 300 shamanistic temples within an hour of Seoul’s bustling city center, and in them, shamans perform their clamorous ceremonies every day.

Bobby Model, an accomplished rock climber and professional photographer who has covered outdoor adventures throughout the world, is recovering at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York after sustaining severe brain trauma when a rock crashed through his truck’s windshield in South Africa on June 7.
A series of armed robberies over the last three months at sweets shops has the Boston police scrambling to give the robber his just desserts.
To be an American cyclist in the Tour de France is to toil in the shadows of two prominent and controversial American riders: Lance Armstrong and Floyd Landis.
Motorcycles have become the symbol of economic freedom in Vietnam, as its economy surges. But they are also a main source, together with cars, of serious air pollution.
Answers to some commonly asked questions about atrial fibrillation.
The Blackstone Group seems to have picked the right property to sell — itself — at the ideal time.
Residents of one Long Island town feel the plans to fortify a proposed post office with barbed wire and bulletproof glass are a form of racial profiling.
“Snapped”  remains among Oxygen’s highest-rated shows, having had an instrumental role in recasting women’s television away from its celebrations of victimhood to its new fetish for female aberrance.
Keep everyone within a tight geographic area, and maintain a small number of members.

The singer Avril Lavigne, below, is being sued by members of a 1970s rock band who claim her current hit song, “Girlfriend,” was lifted from one of their own, Billboard.com reported. Tommy Dunbar, the founder of the Rubinoos, filed suit in San Francisco on Monday contending that “Girlfriend” bears striking similarities to the Rubinoos’ song “I Wanna Be Your Boyfriend,” written in 1979 by Mr. Dunbar and the band’s former road manager James Gangwer. The band is best known for its 1977 remake of the Tommy James and the Shondells hit “I Think We’re Alone Now.” Ms. Lavigne’s manager, Terry McBride, said that the suit had “no basis,” and that a musicologist he consulted saw “no similarities of melody, choral progression or meter.”.

Eva Longoria of ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” and Tony Parker, the National Basketball Association star, were married in a civil wedding ceremony yesterday by the mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delanoë, Reuters reported. Well-wishers and photographers got only a fleeting glimpse of the celebrity couple, though, as they arrived at a town hall in Paris. The civil service came in advance of a church service, expected today, that is said to be taking place at the Château Vaux-le-Vicomte, south of Paris.

Julie Chen and “Big Brother” returned to CBS Thursday, drawing solid ratings in line with the reality show’s premiere a year ago. The latest version of the series, which adds a new twist in the form of “America’s Player,” a houseguest whose assignments are decided by a vote of viewers, delivered 7.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Though “Big Brother” led its time slot among adults 18 to 49, a rerun of Fox’s “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” outdrew it in total viewers (7.8 million). Fox earned top ratings for the night over all, winning at 9 p.m. as well, with a second repeat (8.5 million) of the game show. CBS’s “Pirate Master” (5.2 million) edged ahead of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (5 million) to finish No. 2 in the 9 p.m. hour. CBS’s “CSI,” the night’s most-watched show, dominated at 10 p.m. (9.3 million), making CBS runner-up for the night over all. ABC and NBC shared a distant third place.

Former Vice President Al Gore, an organizer of the Live Earth concerts, said yesterday that Washington had been added to today’s global event, with the country stars Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood to perform there, Agence France-Press reported. Mr. Gore said that the National Museum of the American Indian had offered its site for today’s concert. The last-minute addition came after organizers failed to bring Live Earth to the capital’s Mall because other events had already booked the space. A Congressional resolution was introduced to let the show be held on the Capitol grounds, but some Republicans resisted the effort. Concert organizers also said that Madonna had invited Gogol Bordello, the Gypsy-inspired punk band based in New York, to perform with her during her set at Wembley Stadium in London.
A more stressful new year begins for doctors in July, when the new interns arrive in our emergency rooms, clinics and wards.
City Ballet dancer sidelined for the summer season, Live Earth adds a stage in Washington, Avril Lavigne is sued and more culture news.

Nilas Martins, right, a New York City Ballet principal dancer arrested on a cocaine charge, will not appear for the rest of the company’s season in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., City Ballet said yesterday. “The company regards this as a private, though serious, matter,” it said in a brief statement, adding that the decision was “consistent with company policy.” Mr. Martins’s lawyer, E. Stewart Jones Jr. of Troy, N.Y., said his client and the ballet company agreed that the publicity presented too much of a distraction. Mr. Martins, 40, the son of Peter Martins, the company’s master in chief, maintains his position with City Ballet and will return for the Lincoln Center season, Mr. Jones said. The dancer was arrested around 1:30 a.m. Tuesday. The police said he was trying to hide a bag containing a half-gram of cocaine. “He denies any knowledge of what that substance was,” Mr. Jones said. “He has a very innocent explanation for how that substance came to be.” A hearing scheduled for yesterday was put off until Aug. 3, he added. “There’s a lot that’s not known to be ferreted out before this case can be discussed and resolved.”.

J. K. Rowling, the best-selling author, said that at the 11th hour she changed the last word of the final book in the Harry Potter series, the BBC reported. Ms. Rowling acknowledged that the word “scar” had “for ages” been the last word in “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.” Harry Potter has a lightning-bolt scar on his forehead as a result of a failed curse by his nemesis, Lord Voldemort. Ms. Rowling would not say what she changed it to. In an interview with NBC’s “Today” yesterday, Daniel Radcliffe, who plays Harry Potter in the film version of the series, predicted that his character would die in the final book. But he said that he had no inside information to confirm that.
A painting by the Italian Renaissance artist Raphael that had not been seen publicly for more than 40 years was sold at auction Thursday for $37.2 million, The Associated Press reported.

Matt Groening, creator of “The Simpsons,” says the long-awaited film version of the popular television series will be deliberately “imperfect,” BBC News reported. Mr. Groening said the movie was “a tribute to the art of hand-drawn animation, which is basically disappearing.” He added that “all the animated movies these days are computer generated,” but that the “Simpsons” film was being created in “the old-fashioned, clumsy, ‘erase it if you don’t do it right’ way.” A 10-minute preview shown to journalists featured Bart Simpson skateboarding naked through downtown Springfield and his sister Lisa meeting a potential new boyfriend. Another sequence showed the rock band Green Day being booed off a stage for expressing environmental concerns. The show’s executive producer, Al Jean, denied that the film represented a winding down of the Simpsons franchise. Instead, he said, it would help “bring more people in” to the series, which was first broadcast in December 1989. “The Simpsons Movie” is scheduled to be released on July 27.
This is summer: it is a time to read and for me at least, despite what many may think, reading is play.
Security officials said they recovered two antiaircraft guns and one submachine gun with a telescopic sight from a rooftop barely a mile from the airport in Rawalpindi, Pakistan.
When it comes to renovating Les Halles — nicknamed the belly of Paris, the appropriate motto might well be: If at first you fail, keep trying.
The argument that the cure to the nation’s health care problems is a single-payer system is worth consideration, but filmmaker Michael Moore left out the trade-offs.
In a program split between organ classics and audacious arrangements, Cameron Carpenter showed that the digital organ can produce the grand sound of a pipe organ.

The book “MayDay! Asking for Help in Times of Need” says learning to ask for help is not just good for altruistic reasons; it makes business sense.
Seventy-seven drummers, arranged in a coil, will play a piece called “77BOADRUM” in the Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park, between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.
Stocks receiving coverage by analysts for the first time tend to jump significantly, so the obvious question is, Where will Wall Street turn its attention next?

During a performance of  “Peter and the Wolf,” with Kevin Kline,  it seemed as if a storyteller and his musical accomplice were re- enacting a favorite bedtime story.
The U.S.A.-1 team in the Senior Bowl world championship, which starts in Shanghai on Sept. 30, will be Gaylor Kasle, Russ Arnold, Dan Gerstman, Dan Morse, John Sutherlin and Bobby Wolff.
Argentine modern dance will celebrate itself and its long history in a minifestival of its own at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. tonight through Tuesday.
It seems that anything will go wrong that can for Mike Stanisz, a 33-year-old New Jersey man with plans to get married on Friday, July 13.
Government restrictions, imported fish and summer residents threaten a tradition in the Hamptons.

9 P.M. (Starz) TALLADEGA NIGHTS: THE BALLAD OF RICKY BOBBY (2006) Ricky Bobby (Will Ferrell, left) has stayed on top of the Nascar standings with the help of his best friend, Cal Naughton Jr. (John C. Reilly), who always comes in second. But jealousy, a new rival (played by Sacha Baron Cohen) and a loss of nerve threaten Ricky’s position as No. 1, and he must prove he still has what it takes in this popular comedy.
Thanks to a pair of little-known French players, Wimbledon had one of the greatest upsets in its history, and Andy Roddick had one of his career’s biggest disappointments to mull.
A former high-ranking official at China’s top food and drug watchdog agency has been sentenced to death.
Employers added 132,000 jobs in June, fewer than in May but consistent with an economy still shaking itself out of a slump.
There has been a leveraged-buyout boom, in part because of financial alchemy that allows those who put up the cash to think they have investment-grade investments.
America’s first blind diplomat, Avraham Rabby, spent the last two years surveying Trinidad’s political landscape and composing cables to Washington in Braille.
A Brooklyn man hopes that Gov. Eliot Spitzer will show him the same mercy that President Bush recently showed to I. Lewis Libby Jr.
An increasing number of parents are turning to baby-sitting co-operatives for free and reliable child care.
After dispatching Juan Carlos Ferrero in four sets, Roger Federer started his news conference in English, switched to Swiss German, then High German, and finally to French.

With five more home runs, Barry Lamar Bonds will become baseball’s new home run king. In a perfect world, Bonds would then retire gracefully — as a San Francisco Giant — at the conclusion of this season.
Because drugs don’t work very well with atrial fibrillation, and may even be dangerous, doctors have long been eager to find other treatments.
Once considered relatively harmless, doctors now recognize that atrial fibrillation may make patients more prone to heart attacks and strokes.
There is an astounding reluctance to criticize or properly discipline police officers, no matter how egregious their conduct.
While corporate America’s family sagas are often mired in public drama, Comcast’s smooth father-to-son handoff offers a different model.
All six of the above-the-title producers for the musical “Xanadu” are Broadway neophytes.
For a man now so reviled in many parts of the baseball world, Alex Rodriguez’s life story was sympathetic and sad, Dickensian with a Latin twist.

PALL--Sheldon A., age 81, on July 5th, of Delray Beach, FL formerly of Staten Island, NY. Former owner of Sunset Decorators in Staten Island. Devoted father of Lori (Mark), Roni, Jamie and Brian (Ellen). Devoted companion of Annette Lattof. Adored grandfather of Leah, Benjamin and Rebecca Pall. Services Sunday, 9:15am at Schoem Memorial Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

FATT--Arthur C. You were born on July 7th, 1907 and you would be a century old today. Seven was your number, you were the youngest of seven children, you lived on 77th St. and Grey Advertising, your baby, was at 777 3rd Ave. You were a positive force in all our lives. Enjoy your Pot-aufeu Daddy in heaven. Barbara and Marjorie

KAN--Joan, on July 3rd, 2007, of NYC and Englewood, NJ. Survived by brother Richard Pollak of Palo Alto, CA. Beloved of family and many friends. A life devoted to theatre and to those close to her. Remembrances to the Actors Fund.

An article on Thursday about a German backlash against plans for a mosque in Cologne, known for its Gothic cathedral, referred incorrectly to the size of polls taken for a local newspaper there, assessing the popularity of the mosque. The sample of 500 people was sufficient for a scientific poll; that sample was not ''small,'' nor did its size limit the poll's ''usefulness as a gauge of popular sentiment in a city of one million.''

CHALFIN--Miriam L., age 75, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on July 6, 2007 after a year long illness as a result of a brain tumor. Deeply beloved wife of 50 years of Dr. David Chalfin, devoted mother of Dr. Nina Chalfin Rubin and Eli Chalfin, adored and adoring grandmother of Alex, Jake, Sam, and Max, dear mother-in-law to Dr. Lee Rubin and Ruth Chalfin. She also leaves her sisters Jeannette Gehrie, and Rhoda Marks. She was a graduate of NYU in fine arts, attended the Bank Street school, received a masters in social work at Hunter College, and was a member of the guidance department at the Ethical Culture School. Her passion, warmth and generosity, lively wit, hilarious stories, deep understanding and keen intelligence will be greatly missed by her family and by scores of loving friends and colleagues. Donations in her name may be made to The Human Rights Watch or Doctors without Borders. Services at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., on Sunday July 8, 2007 at 2pm.

A court sentenced Bob Denard, France's best-known mercenary, to a year in prison for his role in mounting a coup in the Comoro Islands off southeast Africa in 1995. A separate court will have to decide whether Mr. Denard, 78, who has Alzheimer's disease, will serve time in prison. The French Army intervened in the Comoros, a former French colony, and captured Mr. Denard's mercenaries, who said they acted with the knowledge of the French government.

An article on Thursday about a German backlash against plans for a mosque in Cologne, known for its Gothic cathedral, referred incorrectly to the size of polls taken for a local newspaper there, assessing the popularity of the mosque. The sample of 500 people was sufficient for a scientific poll; that sample was not ''small,'' nor did its size limit the poll's ''usefulness as a gauge of popular sentiment in a city of one million.''

A painting by the Italian Renaissance artist Raphael that had not been seen publicly for more than 40 years was sold at auction Thursday for $37.2 million, The Associated Press reported. The portrait of Lorenzo de' Medici, a member of Florence's ruling family and the great patron of the Italian Renaissance, had been in the private collection of an American art dealer for nearly half a century. Auctioneers at Christie's in London had expected the painting to sell for $20 million to $30 million. The portrait was sold to a private collector bidding on the telephone. Completed in 1518, two years before Raphael's death, the painting features a finely dressed Lorenzo de' Medici in gold and red brocade with delicate fur trim in front of a dark green background. Painted on canvas -- something Raphael rarely did because he preferred to paint on panels -- the portrait is in superb condition, a Christie's spokesman said.

CRESPIN--Regine. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of the great French soprano, Regine Crespin, who sang 129 performances here between 1962 and 1987. Her magnificent tone, incomparable style, and subtle interpretations made her performances extraordinarily beautiful. In recent years, she generously made time to coach the members of our Lindemann Young Artist Development Program. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Dir.

LANDAU--William. The son of immigrants whose creative approach to marketing and service helped establish a successful New York/New Jersey independent Ethan Allen retail organization died July 5 at his home in Fort Lee, New Jersey. Born to Rose and Morris Landau December 4, 1925 in the Bronx he was raised in a home where Yiddish was the primary language. He attended the competitive Townsend Harris High School (1941), rising at 4am to first assist his father in the window-washing business. In WWII he witnessed the horrors of the Nazis when his unit entered Ohrdruf, the first death camp liberated by the Western Allies. He attended City College (1947) on the GI bill. He met Laura Haskel in the Catskills and after a dogged pursuit that included tickets to the hit production of South Pacific he succeeded in winning her hand. They were wed September 8, 1951. Bill later entered the furniture business with a buddy from the army. In 1962 with the encouragement of Nat Ancell, co-founder of Ethan Allen he opened his first Ethan Allen Gallery in River Edge, New Jersey. At a time when the typical furniture store featured rows of product arranged by price, he and his wife Laurie pioneered the concept of selling room settings of coordinated home furnishings. The Landaus won awards for their creative approach. One TV spot featured Bill in white tie and tails, baton in hand, ''conducting'' a sale. In 1998 CEO Farooq Kathwari awarded him Ethan Allen's Golden Kite proclaiming ''he has served as an inspiration and role model for generations of Ethan Allen family members, including his own... He has applied his talent, creativity, vision and sense of humor to everything he does...'' Bill's motto was ''I may not ever be the biggest furniture operation around but I want to be the best.'' Today, The Landau family operates service-oriented Ethan Allen Design Centers in Bergen County, New Jersey and Rockland and Westchester Counties in New York. An avid runner, Bill competed in four New York Marathons, his last at age 60. His death was due to pancreatic cancer. His final weeks were a display of his courage and dignity, and he died peacefully at home surrounded by his close-knit family. He is survived by Laura Landau, his loving partner of 55 years and three daughters: Lois Leeds, Pamela Connolly, and Nancy Gillon. Seven granddaughters: Rebecca Kowal and Melissa Leeds; Jackie, Margot and Katie Connolly; and Leah and Danielle Gillon. His first greatgrandchild also a girl, Isabella Kowal, was born in April. A sister, Frances Illivicky lives in Queens and a brother Samuel Landau in White Plains. Funeral services: Noon, Sunday July 8, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey (201) 843-9090.

He was and will be remembered as a kind, caring, ethical and gentle man, who loved his family and friends, who loved him in return. His wisdom and talent will be missed. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, July 8, 2007 at 10:00am at the Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557, 516-295-3100. Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

J. K. Rowling, the best-selling author, said that at the 11th hour she changed the last word of the final book in the Harry Potter series, the BBC reported. Ms. Rowling acknowledged that the word ''scar'' had ''for ages'' been the last word in ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.'' Harry Potter has a lightning-bolt scar on his forehead as a result of a failed curse by his nemesis, Lord Voldemort. Ms. Rowling would not say what she changed it to. In an interview with NBC's ''Today'' yesterday, Daniel Radcliffe, who plays Harry Potter in the film version of the series, predicted that his character would die in the final book. But he said that he had no inside information to confirm that.

HILLER--Catherine. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY, mourns the passing of our beloved member Catherine Hiller. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Susan Zelman HILLER--Catherine. Beloved wife and life partner of the late Frederic Hiller, died on July 5, 2007, at age 90, three weeks after sustaining serious injuries in a pedestrian accident. She is survived by her sons Lee and Richard, her daughters-in-law Bonnie and Marsha, her grandchildren Lauren, Ruth, Michael, Oliver and Caleb, their spouses, Phil, David, Cara and Maya, great grandchildren Molly, Sarah, Simon, Naomi and Joshua, her sister Ruth Eisner, and many nieces and nephews and dear friends. Services at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Sunday, July 8 at 9:30 am. Shiva will be held at Catherine's home, Floral Park, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Frederic and Catherine Hiller Scholarship Fund of the American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology www.ats.org, DonorsChoose www.donorschoose.org and Hadassah www.hadassa h.org.

A front-page picture caption on Thursday with an article about an increase in the number of legal immigrants seeking to become United States citizens referred incorrectly to the group of service members shown being sworn in at a naturalization ceremony in Baghdad on Wednesday. They were all members of the United States Army; no members of the Marine Corps were shown, nor were any marines naturalized during the ceremony.

Yuri Luzhkov, left, the powerful Moscow mayor praised as a reformer and vilified as an autocrat, was inaugurated for a fifth term. In his 15 years as head of Russia's richest city, he has transformed it from a gray, Soviet megalopolis into a sparkling modern capital, amassing along the way political clout eclipsed by just a few, among them President Vladimir V. Putin. Mr. Luzhkov had indicated that he would like to step down this December, and his reappointment has fueled speculation that he was staying on because the Kremlin wanted to tap his influence to gain votes for its candidates in parliamentary elections in December and the presidential election in March.

India has only about 2.5 million people infected with H.I.V., less than half of previous estimates, the Indian health minister and United Nations health officials said yesterday. As a result, instead of having an estimated 5.7 million cases, the most in the world, India is now in third place, behind South Africa, with 5.5 million, and Nigeria, with 2.9 million.

JENKINS--William Maxwell, April 19, 1919 -June 27, 2007. A son of the Northwest, Bill Jenkins, 88, died peacefully at his home on Bainbridge Island, Washington surrounded by his family. Bill believed that ''the best of times is now'' and daily lived that motto. His indomitable presence and ability to drink in life in big gulps charmed us all. Born in Sultan, Washington, the son of Warren and Louise Jenkins, Bill spent his early life in Everett, Washington and was a 1937 graduate of Everett High School. He graduated from the University of Washington in 1941 and the Graduate School of Business at Harvard University in 1943. During WWII, as part of the Navy Combat Demolition Unit, Bill landed at Omaha Beach. For his heroism under fire Bill was awarded the Navy Cross and the French Croix d'Guerre with Palm. Bill began his banking career at Seattle First - International Bank in 1945. In 1962 he was named CEO of Seafirst and served in that capacity until his retirement in 1982. Under his leadership, Seafirst became the dominant bank in the Northwest, eventually becoming one of the top ten most profitable banks in America. Bill served on the board of directors of many corporations, among them, United Airlines, Pacific Northwest Bell, Safeco, and Scott Paper. Additionally, he was a past-President of the Association of Reserve City Bankers. Bill is survived by his wife Ann Ramsay-Jenkins, his children: Cordy Beckstead; Ann Rohrbacher; William Jenkins; Karen Olanna; Peter Jenkins; David Jenkins; Barbara Jenkins; and Ann's son, Adam Cornell. Survivors also include 20 grandchildren and five great-granchildren. At the request of the family, remembrances may be made to the William M. Jenkins and Ann Ramsay-Jenkins Endowed Scholarship Fund, The College Success Foundation, 1605 NW Sammamish Road, suite 100, Issaquah, Washington. The foundation provides college scholarships and mentoring to low-income, high potential students. A reception will take place July 16th at the Men's University Club, 1004 Boren Ave., Seattle, WA. A private interment will take place at Arlington National Cemetery. Sign the online guestbook at: www.cook familyfuneralhome.com

On June 25th the Supreme Court held in Morse v. Frederick that it was all right to discipline a high school student because he and some of his friends had unfurled a banner reading "Bong Hits 4 Jesus" at a school-sponsored event.

The retrospective exhibit of desginer Valentino's clothes at Rome's Ara Pacis Museum is, simply, stunning. And I do not think I have used that word in 20 years as a journalist. There are hundreds of the designer's gowns displayed on tall gold mannequins, posed around this ancient Roman monument, as if they were paying tribute to the emporer Augustus on his return from the provinces he had just conquered. The mix is breathtaking.

I was asked recently if Hong Kong had an indie-rock scene. All I could do was respond with a weak "well, it's still young and developing," and point to the Fringe Club, where three local groups played Saturday, thanks to a monthly band night organized by HK Live (www.hk-live.com), from HK Magazine, a free weekly where I used to work.Coincidentally, I ended up at the Fringe's rooftop terrace the very next day for my favorite meal of the week: brunch, which is now being served by the people at Soho Soho, the old "modern British cuisine" restaurant.So I figure now is as good a time as any to introduce what is often called Hong Kong's alternative arts center.The Fringe Club (www.hkfringeclub.com) was founded in the early '80s by two Hong Kongers, Benny Chia and Catherine Lau, who transformed a rambling dilapidated colonial building into a homegrown cultural center, and still run it today.

José Jimenez, who threw a no-hitter as a rookie with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1999, was one of two Dominican athletes removed from the Pan American Games yesterday after they tested positive for banned substances. Jimenez, who last pitched in the majors for the Cleveland Indians in 2004, tested positive for anabolic steroids. The boxer Rafael Fernandez Sosa was also barred by the Dominican Republic Olympic committee.

Striker Diego Forlán scored twice as Uruguay knocked host Venezuela out of the Copa América with a 4-1 victory in a quarterfinal in San Cristobal. Uruguay advanced to a semifinal game against Brazil, which routed Chile, 6-1, in Puerto La Cruz.
