Hélio Castroneves earned his third straight pole at Watkins Glen International in New York, covering the 3.4-mile, 11-turn road circuit at 136.021 miles an hour during qualifying for the Watkins Glen Grand Prix.

Lewis Hamilton will start from the pole position in the British Grand Prix, his first Formula One race in his home country. Hamilton had a fastest lap of 1 minute 19.997 seconds on the 3.2-mile circuit as time ran out in the qualifying session, edging Kimi Raikkonen by 0.102 seconds. Hamilton is trying to become the first Englishman since Damon Hill in 1994 to win the British Grand Prix.

The United States Olympic Committee apologized yesterday after a worker scrawled “Welcome to the Congo!” on a board in the organization’s Rio de Janeiro news media center for the Pan American Games, which begin Friday. The newspaper O Globo published a photograph of the message on its front page yesterday and ran a headline saying the joke was “full of prejudice.” The U.S.O.C. issued a “deep apology to the people of Brazil and Rio de Janeiro” in a statement yesterday, and said the worker who wrote the phrase was disciplined and is no longer a member of the United States delegation.

Alberto Salazar, the three-time New York City Marathon champion, was released from the hospital, one week after he had a heart attack at the Nike campus outside Portland, Ore. Officials at Providence St. Vincent Medical Center declined to provide details of Salazar’s condition.

Anita DeFrantz finished a distant last yesterday in an election for a seat on the International Olympic Committee’s executive board, leaving the United States again without a seat on the Olympics’ most influential body.“We unfortunately are still in the least-favored nation status,” she said. DeFrantz, a former Olympic rower, received six votes in an election won by the incumbent, Gerhard Heiberg of Norway, with 49 votes. The United States has been without representation on the executive body since Jim Easton lost his seat in elections in February 2006.

Wladimir Klitschko beat Lamon Brewster with a technical knockout after six rounds yesterday in Cologne, Germany, to successfully defend his International Boxing Federation and International Boxing Organization heavyweight titles.Brewster was the last man to defeat Klitschko (49-3). In 2004, Brewster beat Klitschko with a fifth-round technical knockout to win the vacant World Boxing Organization championship.

Harvard defeated Brown by two lengths yesterday to advance to the final of the Ladies Plate for elite eights at the Henley Royal Regatta in Henley-on-Thames, England. In the Diamond Sculls semifinals for international single scullers, Jamie Schroeder from Potomac Boat Club lost to Alan Campbell, who is Britain’s top sculler, by one and a half lengths.In the Remenham Cup semifinals for international women’s eights, Brown lost to the German national squad representing Dortmund Rowing Club.In the Fawley Cup quarterfinals for schoolboy quadruple sculls, Maritime Rowing Club from Norwalk, Conn., lost to Sydney Rowing Club from Australia and the composite crew from Malvern Preparatory School in Pennsylvania and Miami Rowing Club lost by two and a half lengths to Windsor Boys’ School of England.

Tony Parker and Eva Longoria exchanged vows in a Paris cathedral that once served French royalty — stage two of a weekend wedding extravaganza that began with a civil ceremony and was to end last night at a storied French chateau.Guests at the service included Longoria’s “Desperate Housewives” co-stars Teri Hatcher, Nicolette Sheridan and Felicity Huffman. Ahead of the brief service on Saturday, Parker and Longoria married in a civil ceremony in Paris on Friday before a modest crowd of about 40 guests, including some of Parker’s San Antonio Spurs teammates and the French soccer player Thierry Henry.Parker, a 25-year-old who was born in Belgium and grew up in France, asked Paris Mayor Bertrand Delanoë to officiate. Parker’s friends translated when Delanoë gave a speech calling Parker a model in the fight against racism.Police cordons kept the public away from the cathedral, Saint-Germain-l’Auxerrois, which is across from the Louvre in Paris.

Gerhard Heiberg of Norway, the Olympics’ top marketing official, was re-elected yesterday to the powerful executive board of the International Olympic Committee, defeating three other candidates. Heiberg, who oversaw the 1994 Winter Games in Lillehammer, Norway, won on the first round of a secret ballot. He received 49 votes and was followed by Juan Antonio Samaranch Jr. of Spain with 22 votes, Mustapha Larfaoui of Algeria with 15 and Anita Defrantz of the United States with 6.As head of the I.O.C. marketing commission, Heiberg is responsible for negotiating sponsorship deals with global corporations.

The Yankees right-hander Jeff Karstens pitched three and a third scoreless innings yesterday in his first minor league rehabilitation start since breaking his right leg two months ago.Karstens allowed three hits, one walk and struck out two in a Gulf Coast League game against Philadelphia minor leaguers. He is scheduled to join Class A Staten Island for his next start.Karstens was hurt April 28 in a game against Boston. On his first pitch, he was hit on the side of his knee by Julio Lugo’s line drive.The right-hander Phil Hughes, who has been sidelined since May 1 by ankle and hamstring injuries, is scheduled to make his first rehabilitation start Monday for Class A Tampa.

Modern-day protestations notwithstanding, Peruvians have long credited Hiram Bingham III as the “scientific discoverer” of Machu Picchu, which is to say that he made the shrouded Inca city known to the outside world (Arthur Lubow, June 24). At the time of his discovery, in 1911, he made no secret of the fact that several Peruvians, academics in Cuzco as well as farmers in the Urubamba Valley, knew of the ruins. But they did nothing with this knowledge. Bingham acted on it. He cleared, investigated, photographed and publicized Machu Picchu. Keep in mind that the Urubamba Valley is studded with Incan ruins (some undiscovered even today), and in the early 1900s no one paid them much attention.

An article on June 24 about the United States’ efforts to promote democracy in Iran misstated the date that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to request financing for the cause. She took the position in 2005 at the start of the second Bush administration, not a few weeks before she made that committee appearance.

When Gunter Grass revealed last summer that he had served in the Waffen SS as a teenager, he was roundly condemned. Now Grass's memoir, ''Peeling the Onion,'' has been published in the United States, and, beginning on Page 1, John Irving offers a ringing defense of his friend and mentor. Grass, of course, is no stranger to political controversy. Irving thinks it's different in America: ''When you're interviewed as a writer in this country,'' he said in an e-mail message, ''you're rarely asked about your politics; in fact, if you express a political opinion, the interviewer often looks uncomfortable. Maybe writers in America aren't supposed to be political? Movie stars, and other celebrities, are routinely mocked for their politics. But in Europe, a writer is expected to have political opinions -- and to express them. My parents never withheld their political opinions; I got my politics from them. I'm a liberal -- like a lot of people nowadays, a deeply discontented Democrat. I support Planned Parenthood; I'm an abortion-rights activist. Yet, of my 11 novels, I would describe only two ('The Cider House Rules' and 'A Prayer for Owen Meany') as political novels -- in the case of 'Cider House,' I would say it's positively polemical.''

In her essay on the ''ordination'' of Jane Via, Jan Jarboe Russell (June 24) writes that if ''not for the accident of her sex,'' Via would make an excellent candidate for the priesthood. In Catholic theology, gender is very much not accidental: it is both intentional (in that a person's gender is ordained by God) and essential (in that it is a fundamental part of a person's soul). That is, gender is not merely a fluke of biology but an integral part of who we are as people.

GREENOUGH--Beverly Sills, It is with deep sadness that the staff, Board of Trustees and volunteers of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, New York City Chapter mourn the death of our longtime board chair, Beverly Sills Greenough. We extend our condolences to Beverly's family and especially to our very dear friend and volunteer, Meredith (Muffy) Greenough on the loss of her mother. Beverly was not only an incredible and inspiring woman who was exceptionally devoted to Muffy and her family, she was a champion for all people living with multiple sclerosis, raising awareness and moving us closer to a world free of this disease. We will think of her often and miss her dearly.

JENKINS--William Maxwell, April 19, 1919 -June 27, 2007. A son of the Northwest, Bill Jenkins, 88, died peacefully at his home on Bainbridge Island, Washington surrounded by his family. Bill believed that ''the best of times is now'' and daily lived that motto. His indomitable presence and ability to drink in life in big gulps charmed us all. Born in Sultan, Washington, the son of Warren and Louise Jenkins, Bill spent his early life in Everett, Washington and was a 1937 graduate of Everett High School. He graduated from the University of Washington in 1941 and the Graduate School of Business at Harvard University in 1943. During WWII, as part of the Navy Combat Demolition Unit, Bill landed at Omaha Beach. For his heroism under fire Bill was awarded the Navy Cross and the French Croix d'Guerre with Palm. Bill began his banking career at Seattle First - International Bank in 1945. In 1962 he was named CEO of Seafirst and served in that capacity until his retirement in 1982. Under his leadership, Seafirst became the dominant bank in the Northwest, eventually becoming one of the top ten most profitable banks in America. Bill served on the board of directors of many corporations, among them, United Airlines, Pacific Northwest Bell, Safeco, and Scott Paper. Additionally, he was a past-President of the Association of Reserve City Bankers. Bill is survived by his wife Ann Ramsay-Jenkins, his children: Cordy Beckstead; Ann Rohrbacher; William Jenkins; Karen Olanna; Peter Jenkins; David Jenkins; Barbara Jenkins; and Ann's son, Adam Cornell. Survivors also include 20 grandchildren and five great-granchildren. At the request of the family, remembrances may be made to the William M. Jenkins and Ann Ramsay-Jenkins Endowed Scholarship Fund, The College Success Foundation, 1605 NW Sammamish Road, suite 100, Issaquah, Washington. The foundation provides college scholarships and mentoring to low-income, high potential students. A reception will take place July 16th at the Men's University Club, 1004 Boren Ave., Seattle, WA. A private interment will take place at Arlington National Cemetery. Sign the online guestbook at: www.cook familyfuneralhome.com

SHOULD American taxpayers help Con Ed provide New York City's financial district with a safer power supply? The Department of Homeland Security thinks so. It has decided to pay the electric company as much as $25 million to install a high-tech line between two substations in Lower Manhattan that would be more resilient than the current line in the event of a terrorist attack, severe weather or a simple operating error by the electric company.

Would he be running for president at all?

NEAR HUE, ON THE HUONG (OR PERFUME) RIVER, April 30, 2007 ''We went along very slowly and the sound of the paddle in the water was the only sound that broke the silence. It was delightful to think that I had all those hours before me to enjoy the sense of well being and I thought to myself how when I was once more in Europe, imprisoned in stony cities, I would remember that perfect night and the enchanting solitude. It would be the most imperishable of my memories. It was a unique occasion and I said to myself that I must hoard the moments as they passed.'' W. Somerset Maugham, writing about his trip to Hue to celebrate Tet with the emperor, in ''The Gentleman in the Parlour'' (1930)

The stock market surged during abbreviated trading last week, propelled by the wave of mergers and acquisitions that has buoyed it for months. Hilton Hotels rose 36.6 percent for the week, the best performance in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. On Tuesday, the Blackstone Group announced that it would buy Hilton at a 40 percent premium to the hotel chain's closing price on Monday. That rich valuation had a ripple effect: Starwood Hotels and Resorts, Marriott International and Host Hotels were all among the top weekly performers in the S.& P., with gains of more than 8 percent.

An article on June 24 about the United States' efforts to promote democracy in Iran misstated the date that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to request financing for the cause. It was Feb. 15, 2006, not Feb. 14. The article also misstated the duration of her term as secretary of state to that point. She took the position in 2005 at the start of the second Bush administration, not a few weeks before she made that committee appearance.

CHALFIN--Miriam L., age 75, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on July 6, 2007 after a year long illness as a result of a brain tumor. Deeply beloved wife of 50 years of Dr. David Chalfin, devoted mother of Dr. Nina Chalfin Rubin and Eli Chalfin, adored and adoring grandmother of Alex, Jake, Sam, and Max, dear mother-in-law to Dr. Lee Rubin and Ruth Chalfin. She also leaves her sisters Jeannette Gehrie, and Rhoda Marks. She was a graduate of NYU in fine arts, attended the Bank Street school, received a masters in social work at Hunter College, and was a member of the guidance department at the Ethical Culture School. Her passion, warmth and generosity, lively wit, hilarious stories, deep understanding and keen intelligence will be greatly missed by her family and by scores of loving friends and colleagues. Donations in her name may be made to The Human Rights Watch or Doctors without Borders. Services at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., on Sunday July 8, 2007 at 2pm.

SHOULD American taxpayers help Con Ed provide New York City's financial district with a safer power supply? The Department of Homeland Security thinks so. It has decided to pay the electric company as much as $25 million to install a high-tech line between two substations in Lower Manhattan that would be more resilient than the current line in the event of a terrorist attack, severe weather or a simple operating error by the electric company.

WEINER--Daniel. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) are saddened by the death of Dr. Daniel Weiner, a member of our Board of Directors and Overseers since 1971. Dr. Weiner made significant contributions to the cause of refugees and the work of the IRC, notably in setting up refugee medical programs in Southeast Asia, South Asia, Bosnia and elsewhere. Dr. Weiner was involved in emergency medical care from his first mission to Vietnam in 1966 and was instrumental in setting up the IRC Health Unit. He also maintained a private medical practice in New York. Throughout his distinguished career in medicine and with the IRC, Dr. Weiner worked tirelessly for the cause of freedom and human rights. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his daughter Rachel, his sons Michael and David, and their families. Alan Batkin and Jonathan Wiesner, Co-Chairmen of the Board Tom Brokaw and Maureen White, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers George Rupp, President

To the Editor:

LANDAU--William. The son of immigrants whose creative approach to marketing and service helped establish a successful New York/New Jersey independent Ethan Allen retail organization died July 5 at his home in Fort Lee, New Jersey. Born to Rose and Morris Landau December 4, 1925 in the Bronx he was raised in a home where Yiddish was the primary language. He attended the competitive Townsend Harris High School (1941), rising at 4am to first assist his father in the window-washing business. In WWII he witnessed the horrors of the Nazis when his unit entered Ohrdruf, the first death camp liberated by the Western Allies. He attended City College (1947) on the GI bill. He met Laura Haskel in the Catskills and after a dogged pursuit that included tickets to the hit production of South Pacific he succeeded in winning her hand. They were wed September 8, 1951. Bill later entered the furniture business with a buddy from the army. In 1962 with the encouragement of Nat Ancell, co-founder of Ethan Allen he opened his first Ethan Allen Gallery in River Edge, New Jersey. At a time when the typical furniture store featured rows of product arranged by price, he and his wife Laurie pioneered the concept of selling room settings of coordinated home furnishings. The Landaus won awards for their creative approach. One TV spot featured Bill in white tie and tails, baton in hand, ''conducting'' a sale. In 1998 CEO Farooq Kathwari awarded him Ethan Allen's Golden Kite proclaiming ''he has served as an inspiration and role model for generations of Ethan Allen family members, including his own... He has applied his talent, creativity, vision and sense of humor to everything he does...'' Bill's motto was ''I may not ever be the biggest furniture operation around but I want to be the best.'' Today, The Landau family operates service-oriented Ethan Allen Design Centers in Bergen County, New Jersey and Rockland and Westchester Counties in New York. An avid runner, Bill competed in four New York Marathons, his last at age 60. His death was due to pancreatic cancer. His final weeks were a display of his courage and dignity, and he died peacefully at home surrounded by his close-knit family. He is survived by Laura Landau, his loving partner of 55 years and three daughters: Lois Leeds, Pamela Connolly, and Nancy Gillon. Seven granddaughters: Rebecca Kowal and Melissa Leeds; Jackie, Margot and Katie Connolly; and Leah and Danielle Gillon. His first greatgrandchild also a girl, Isabella Kowal, was born in April. A sister, Frances Illivicky lives in Queens and a brother Samuel Landau in White Plains. Funeral services: Noon, Sunday July 8, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey (201) 843-9090. LANDAU--William/d. We mourn the loss of a beloved brother, brother-in-law, and wonderful uncle. You will be remembered forever in our hearts. Frances and Martin Ilivicky Ellen and Ira Siegman Howard and Sarah Ilivicky Samuel and Barbara Landau David and Melanie Landau Richard and Lynn Landau

A Brooklyn man was killed in a drawn-out gunfight with the police yesterday after squeezing a lifetime of mayhem into less than 20 minutes, carjacking and crashing two cars, firing at an apartment door and a carful of strangers, and then finally at officers who closed in after he squirmed out of a passenger's side window, the police said. After the police shot him on a busy Crown Heights street, the man, Victor Gordon, 23, got up and resumed shooting before officers fired a final barrage. He was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital, the police said, and as night fell, they counted at least 122 shell casings strewn along Park Place near Albany Avenue, where the shootout took place.

SCHIFF--Bernard J. 7/7/21-4/ 9/05. A Renaissance man: all arts inborn. Also heroic (he enlisted as a teenager and was highly decorated in WWII Air Force for active duty in the South Pacific, 499th Bombardment Sq., 345th Bombardment Group). Postwar, his career began by doing P.R. for big-name stars like Cab Calloway and for foreign governments, until he headed various ad agencies that tapped him to produce, direct, and write music and lyrics for children's tv shows and oversee all else needed to market products for children. One such was for a toy called FOOTSEE, that broke all sales records since the Hula Hoop. An earlier example that girls may remember was TINY TEARS, a doll that cried ''real tears''. It was then that his pioneering TV techniques were invented that still influence current TV commercials today. Dearest Piglet, HUNDRED ACRE WOOD is no fun since you're gone! Love,Pooh

Two new sites have been added to Unesco's World Heritage in Danger list: the Galápagos Islands and the Niokolo-Koba National Park in Senegal. The park, rich with wildlife, was added because of poaching and plans to build a dam near the property on the Gambia River, while increased tourism was a major factor in the decision to add the Galápagos, according to the World Heritage Committee. Meeting last month in New Zealand, the committee noted that the number of days spent by passengers on cruise ships in the area has increased by 150 percent in the last 15 years. Nineteen islands make up the Galápagos, which in 1978 became the first site placed on the World Heritage List. They have been called ''a living museum and showcase of evolution'' (above, a marine iguana). According to the committee, the increase in tourism has ''led to the introduction of more invasive species.''

There is an ethnocentric overtone to the entire argument that artifacts of Peruvian origin are best preserved and studied under the roof and auspices of Yale University. Of course the funding that uncovered and brought Machu Picchu to light came from Yale, and no one denies that. However, ''scholarly interest'' can be pursued anywhere, and ultimately the ethical and logical course is that all artifacts that convey the vital importance of cultural heritage belong to the culture of origin. It is sad but common evidence of our sense of entitlement that we in the West consider whatever we get our hands on to be ours.

They joined forces two years ago to combat global poverty under the flag of Live 8, and rock and pop stars and their myriad fans around the world threw their voices behind a good cause again on Saturday, this time that of raising awareness about global warming through a campaign called Live Earth. In eight major concerts attended by hundreds of thousands and watched on television or the Web by many hundreds of millions more, local and international celebrities backed solo and group acts to promote individual, corporate and government action to slow, even reverse, climate change.

There is an ethnocentric overtone to the entire argument that artifacts of Peruvian origin are best preserved and studied under the roof and auspices of Yale University. Of course the funding that uncovered and brought Machu Picchu to light came from Yale, and no one denies that. However, ''scholarly interest'' can be pursued anywhere, and ultimately the ethical and logical course is that all artifacts that convey the vital importance of cultural heritage belong to the culture of origin. It is sad but common evidence of our sense of entitlement that we in the West consider whatever we get our hands on to be ours. Jack Cuffari Nutley, N.J.

PELZ--Caroline Lockwood Duncombe, 88 of Berlin, NY and Bennington, VT retired educational administrator, died Thursday June 28, 2007 at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center, of a stroke. She was born December 20, 1918, raised in Briarcliff Manor, NY and graduated from Briarcliff Manor High School in 1935, from The Bishops School in La Jolla, CA in 1936, and from Barnard College in NYC in 1940. Her parents, the late David Sanford Duncombe and Helena (Ebert) Duncombe of Briarcliff Manor, retired to Berlin NY in 1960. Caroline married Edward J. Pelz of New York City in 1942. He was in the Navy 1942-1945, and in the personnel department of The New York Times 1946-1982. Caroline was director of admissions at Grace Church School in New York City 19721987, and previously worked at Allen-Stevenson School and the Educational Records Bureau there. She was a trustee of Barnard College 19631967 and president of its alumnae association, and was the recipient in 2005 of Barnards Lifetime Alumnae Service Recognition Award. Survivors include her husband Edward of Berlin and Bennington; daughters Cami Pelz Elbow of Amherst, MA and Patricia Pelz Hart of Aliso Viejo, CA and son Sanford M. Pelz of NYC. Five grandchildren: Abigail Elbow of Washington, DC Daphne Hart of Aliso Viejo, CA Ben Elbow of Anchorage, AK and Chris and Jon Pelz of NYC. Four nieces and nephews: Beth Butler of Las Vegas, NV Ted Duncombe of Drexel Hill, PA David Duncombe of Appleton, WI and Peter Duncombe of Las Vegas, NV. A daughter, Margaret L. Pelz of Seattle, WA died in 1978. A memorial service will be held Monday July 23, 11am at St. Johns Episcopal Church, 35 Park St. in Williamstown, MA.

Biking is fast becoming the transportation of choice in environmentally aware European cities. Take Paris, for instance. As of next week, the French capital will have more than 10,000 bikes for rent at 750 stations (right) around the city, providing both tourists and residents with an opportunity to feel environmentally chaste, not to mention giving them a fun, fast way to explore. Called Vélib', the program allows riders to pick up and drop off the three-speed bikes at any one of the various stations spread throughout the city. The first 30 minutes are free; after that the cost is 1 euro, or about $1.35, for the first half-hour, 2 euros for the second half-hour and 4 euros for each half hour after that.

WHILE individual Americans debate the merits of globalization, corporate America has already moved overseas, with dramatic financial results. United Technologies is a case in point. Fully 60 percent of its total sales are either made in the U.S.A. and exported, or made and sold offshore. It exports Pratt & Whitney engines and Sikorsky helicopters, mostly from Connecticut. And its Otis elevator and Carrier air-conditioning subsidiaries have carved out leading positions in emerging markets like China, where the two divisions assemble most of their products.

Where dodo birds once thrived, the Costa Marina, a cruise ship, will soon travel. On Dec. 22, the ship will become the first in the industry to leave Mauritius for 14-day cruises in the Indian Ocean. Ports of call include Mombasa, Kenya; and Nosy Be, Madagascar. Excursion opportunities will include Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam Botanical Garden (Mauritius) and Tsavo East National Park (Kenya). Rates start at $1,879 a person, double occupancy (www.costacruises.com). ... More cruise news: Norwegian Coastal Voyage is offering deals that include air fare from Miami, Los Angeles and New York to Santiago, Chile, for its 13-day Chile and Antarctica cruise, which visits Ushuaia, Argentina, and includes visits -- weather permitting -- to Half Moon and Deception Islands and Petermann Island in Antarctica. The offer is valid for reservations through July 31 for eight cruises between Nov. 21 and Feb. 17; rates start at $4,999 a person, double occupancy (www.norwegiancoastalvoyage.us). ... A new resort, the Solage Calistoga, is scheduled to open in Napa Valley on Thursday. The resort will have a bistro; a 130-foot swimming pool with a separate children's pool; a spa with a ''mud bar,'' where guests recline on elevated platforms and are painted with volcanic mud; free bicycles; and spacious guest rooms, pictured above. The 89-room resort will also welcome pets, use solar power and serve locally grown produce. Starting rates are $325 between Nov. 1 and April 30; and $425 between May 1 and Oct. 31 (www.solagecalistoga.com). ...Tomorrow marks the start of a new Web site that locates rental vacation homes across the country. Pickpackgo.com, a free service that will expand to include an international selection of properties, allows travelers to search for rentals in a number of ways, including travel dates, location, amenities, and number of bedrooms.
THEATER Jason Zinoman

Wynne 1939 Annual Giving Endowment, care of: Princeton University Development Office, 330 Alexander St., Princeton, NJ 08540 or The Princeton Historical Society, 158 Nassau St., Princeton, NJ 08540.

She is the daughter of Teresa Barrios Gentzkow of Portland, Ore., and the late Robert Gentzkow.

Services Sunday, 9:15am at Schoem Memorial Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

Modern-day protestations notwithstanding, Peruvians have long credited Hiram Bingham III as the ''scientific discoverer'' of Machu Picchu, which is to say that he made the shrouded Inca city known to the outside world (Arthur Lubow, June 24). At the time of his discovery, in 1911, he made no secret of the fact that several Peruvians, academics in Cuzco as well as farmers in the Urubamba Valley, knew of the ruins. But they did nothing with this knowledge. Bingham acted on it. He cleared, investigated, photographed and publicized Machu Picchu. Keep in mind that the Urubamba Valley is studded with Incan ruins (some undiscovered even today), and in the early 1900s no one paid them much attention.

I intended to offer points of departure for the imagination rather than provide a concrete answer to the question of how it will all end. ANDREA DEZSÖ, an artist and a professor at Parsons the New School for Design

SINGER--Rachel, on June 29, 2007. Beloved sister of Sol Singer, Maurice Singer and Charlotte Gilbert; devoted and cherished aunt to Mitchell and Alicia Singer and to Ian and Allison Gilbert. Born in Antwerp, Belgium in 1940 she came to New York City in 1948. Graduated City College of New York in 1962 and there after joined the Peace Corp and served in the Philippines. She continued to serve in the Peace Corp as an Administrative Assistant in Washington, DC. She returned to New York City and for nearly 25 years she was the Administrative Assistant to the President of the New York City Blood Center. Rachel loved to sing, was an avid folk dancer and a regular theater goer. She was the hub of the Singer family, she will be terribly missed. Donations may be made to Cancer Research and to the National Holocaust Memorial Museum. SINGER--Rachel. The Trustees, officers and employees of the New York Blood Center mourn the loss of our special friend, an exemplary employee, who personified the Blood Center's mission and values. Rachel's sudden illness and death deeply sadden her colleagues at work and in the research and healthcare community served by the New York Blood Center, all of whom have long appreciated Rachel's dedication, commitment and performance. We will miss her always and be indebted to Rachel for her many contributions during her nearly 25 years as Executive Assistant to the President. Our sympathies are with Rachel's family, friends and colleagues. On behalf of the New York Blood Center Howard Milstein, Chair, Board of Trustees New York Blood Center Robert L. Jones, CEO/President New York Blood Center

In his analysis of the outcomes in the Middle East that remain possible, Feldman completely ignores Benjamin Netanyahu, who right now rides so high in popularity that he will probably be the next prime minister of Israel. Apparently that would be a disaster in Feldman's eyes, even if it would be the best outcome for Israel. Bava Cohen Brooklyn

BAILEY--Helen Phelps. At the 5th anniversary of her death, she is remembered with affection and admiration by friends, family, colleagues and students. Professor of French Language and Literature for 43 years and Dean of Studies for 15 years at Barnard College, she was a graduate of Barnard and earned a Ph.D. from Columbia University. She studied also at McGill University and at the Sorbonne. She authored a book, ''Hamlet in France from Voltaire to Laforgue,'' and did the first known translation from French of a play by St. Therese of Lisieux. The French Government awarded her the Palmes Academiques for her fostering of French culture and arts. Until shortly before her death at age 90, she was a lector and choir member at her church, St. John's of Leonia, NJ. She encountered everyone on an equal footing, with a rare combination of kindness and objectivity that made her a dear and valued friend.

Cherished mother of Marsha Gershberg of Scottsdale and Short Hills and Carol Taxon of Manhattan; loving grandmother to Cheryl and Jason Brodsky, Meredith and Samantha Gershberg.

To the Editor: ''Largely Alone, Pioneers Reclaim New Orleans'' (''Patchwork City'' series, front page, July 2) establishes a bittersweet truth about the slow recovery of New Orleans: the realization that people have had to do it without timely government ''help.''

I do not think Yale University should return its relics of Machu Picchu. While the Peruvian government talks about foreign dominance today, the Peruvian rulers of Spanish descent never ceased to build Christian churches on top of Incan temples and consistently suppressed indigenous cultures before the arrival of Bingham. It is to Peru's benefit to maintain an international interest in the country's tourist industry, and this can best be done by allowing foreigners to become acquainted with its attractions in museums around the world.
POP Kelefa Sanneh

PILOSI--Robert N., M.D., passed away on June 27, 2007 in Port St. Lucie, FL after a brief illness. He and his wife are residents of Long Island, but had been vacationing in Florida. Dr. Pilosi graduated from Georgetown Medical School 1960. After completing a residency in psychiatry, he worked at Catholic Charities in New York City and Nassau County. He joined the staff of East Plains Mental Health Center in Hicksville, NY in 1977. Now known as Central Nassau Guidance and Counseling Services, Inc., this nonprofit agency has grown into a multi-service institution, serving people with mental health disabilities and difficulties with substance abuse. In his 30 years as Medical Director of Central Nassau, Dr. Pilosi used wisdom, knowledge, sensitivity and humor to provide guidance to his colleagues as well as treatment to his patients. Dr. Pilosi also had a large private psychiatry practice in Hicksville. He is survived by his beloved wife of 38 years, Mary Grimes Pilosi. Dr. Pilosi will be greatly missed by his wife, friends, colleagues and patients. Memorial services will be held at a later date on Long Island. Contributions in his memory may be made to Central Nassau Guidance and Counseling Services, Inc. 950 South Oyster Bay Road, Hicksville, NY 11801.
Legging It Out Willy Taveras of Colorado leads the majors with 27 bunt hits. Juan Pierre of the Los Angeles Dodgers is second with eight.
To the Editor:

The Ethicist was dangerously wrong in his response to the woman whose nanny recently revealed that she takes antipsychotic medication for bipolar disorder. The care of children always comes before any considerations of ethics and others' feelings. If the mother has misgivings of any sort about her caregiver, the nanny must go immediately. Laurie Rozakis Farmingdale, N.Y.

BALDINGER--Dan. We have lost one of our closest and dearest friends. The Seaman family extends love and sympathy to the Baldinger family. His intelligence, creativity and wit will forever be in our memory. He was also a very nice guy. Mort and Lois Seaman

To the Editor: Regarding Seth Sherwood's ''The Road Back to Damascus'' (June 24): Syria is governed under a brutal authoritarian regime, is a longtime violator of basic human rights, harbors anti-Western, anti-Semitic terrorist groups, is identified by the United States government as a state sponsor of terrorism, and is an ally of the Iranian regime.

D'AMATO--George G. The partners, associates and staff of D'Amato & Lynch mourn the passing of its founding partner, George G. D'Amato. George was a legal legend of insurance law. George was particularly known as one of the creators and prime movers in the development of directors and officers liability insurance, as well as insurance for accountants and lawyers. George was a valued advisor and skilled negotiator and above all a gentlemen. George was devoted to his wife, Dorothy, and his son David. He will always be cherished in our hearts and never forgotten.

We extend our deepest and most heartfelt sympathies to Linda Johnson and family. We will miss Hal. Jerry Chazen, Holly Hotchner, Nan Laitman, Barbara Tober, and the entire Board and Staff of the Museum of Arts & Design.

HILLER--Catherine. Beloved wife and life partner of the late Frederic Hiller, died on July 5, 2007, at age 90, three weeks after sustaining serious injuries in a pedestrian accident. Catherine was known for her ready smile, her warmth, her long and close friendships, and for her devotion to her immediate and extended family. She was a beautiful person, both outwardly and inwardly. She will be sorely missed by all those whose lives she touched. She is survived by her sons Lee and Richard, her daughters-in-law Bonnie and Marsha, her grandchildren Lauren, Ruth, Michael, Oliver and Caleb, their spouses, Phil, David, Cara and Maya, great grandchildren Molly, Sarah, Simon, Naomi and Joshua, her sister Ruth Eisner, and many nieces and nephews and dear friends. Services at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Sunday, July 8 at 9:30 am. Shiva will be held at Catherine's home, Floral Park, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Frederic and Catherine Hiller Scholarship Fund of the American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology www.ats.org, DonorsChoose www.donorschoose.org and Hadassah www.hadassa h.org.

It takes a certain sense of the ridiculous to think, never mind write, that the United States has a clear and attainable path to the semifinals of the FIFA U-20 World Cup in Canada. That, however, is the case as the American team plays Uruguay in the second round of the well-attended tournament, with the winner advancing to a quarterfinal match against either Austria or Gambia in Toronto on Saturday.

In George Orwell's magnum opus, "1984," Winston Smith, the initially exiguous, then rebellious, and finally cerebrally rinsed protagonist, imagines and re-imagines the manner of his death. He pictures himself, released from the dreadful torture chambers of the Ministry of Love, and walking down a sunlit corridor. There is no prickle of nape hairs to anticipate the fatal blow, as he is culled, painlessly, from behind by a high-velocity rifle bullet. It is the very essence of the hideous totalitarian regime of Oceania to encourage doublethink in its citizens, even as they're being executed.
No matter where they go, the Democratic presidential candidates face questions about the war in Iraq.
Interesting stories from around the Web:

The antiwar activist Cindy Sheehan, whose 24-year-old son was killed in Iraq three years ago, said in May that she was quitting her prominent role in the anti-war movement and severing her ties with the Democratic party. But her retirement from politics may prove short-lived.

Former North Carolina Senator John Edwards, who has called poverty "the great moral issue of our century," will break from fund-raising and stumping in the early primary states for three days next week to talk about his plans for improving the lives of poor Americans.

A party invitation landed in my inbox. I thought the party seemed exclusive, but a bunch of people I know got the same e-mail. "You don't want to miss this," the invitation said. But everyone did want to miss it, except me. I decided to go by myself.

Vice President Dick Cheney's popularity has hit an all-time low, with recent polling by The New York Times and CBS News suggesting that he has replaced Dan Quayle as the most unpopular vice president in recent history.

To drive traffic to their Web sites, corporations pay Google to display an ad for their products with certain keywords and phrases. The presidential candidates for 2008 are doing the same: search for "tort reform," and a link to the Web site of Senator John McCain, a Republican, may turn up, while "universal health care" may draw the campaign site of Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, a Democrat.

The hometown newspaper in Glasgow counts six people worthy of the red carpet treatment for subduing two terrorists trying to crash a truck laden with fuel into the airport. Other reports focused on at least two names, Michael Kerr and Steven Clarkson, who was said to have "floored" one of the men.
Bill Proenza, the embattled director of the National Hurricane Center, was reassigned today, ending a short insurrection among a large chunk of a staff that he led since December.

The movie "Ratatouille" had another big weekend at the box office, grossing more than $29 million from Friday through Sunday. That puts its cumulative domestic earnings at nearly $110 million after a week and a half in release. It's officially a hit.
We can't say that we weren't warned.
In case you weren't in front of your television on Sunday morning, "Win a Trip With Nick Kristof" was featured in a segment called "Voices" on ABC's This Week program.

Delphi, the bankrupt car parts maker, said on Monday that it has ended a $3.4 billion financing plan formerly led by Cerberus Capital Management to haul itself out of bankruptcy, but added that it expected to sign a new deal this month. The company, formerly a part of General Motors, said it still planned to emerge from Chapter 11 by the end of the year.

In case you're not quite up to speed on how the US sub-20 team have done so far at the FIFA U-20 World Championship, here's something to study as part of the run-up to Wednesday's USA-Uruguay match in Toronto (which we'll bring to you live on this blog at 6:45 p.m. Eastern time): a highlight reel of the Young Americans' first three games at the tournament.

Al Gore's Live Earth concerts are wrapped up, and the numbers are in. According to the pollsters at Rassmussen Reports, they aren't the sort that send concert promoters - or political advisers - into states of rapture:

On Sunday, The New York Times published an item in its "Suits" column observing that, as two hedge funds managed by Bear Stearns were sinking last month in what has become commonly referred to as a "crisis," Bear Stearns chief executive James E. Cayne was playing multiple rounds of golf. A previous article in The Times reported that Richard Marin, the head of the Bear unit that ran the troubled funds, stole away from what he called a "crisis-hedge-fund-salvation-workaholic weekend" to see a movie.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his July 9 column, "Health Care Terror."
Buyout firms often say they create growth by investing in companies for the long term, avoiding Wall Street's quarter-to-quarter myopia.
A sucker may be born every second, but heroes take much longer -- roughly 100 hours in the United States, according to the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.
Updates on some topics that we are keeping track of at The Lede.

Last week, John Edwards hinted to Bloomberg TV that he would favor the "carried interest" bill in Congress that would raise taxes for most private-equity fund managers. Now, the Democratic presidential candidate has gone further, lending his support to three different proposals that would increase taxes on buyout managers and hedge funds.
The Taliban and other militant groups in Afghanistan are taking aim at public schools.

Danone, the French food conglomerate, said Monday it was offering $16.8 billion to buy Dutch baby food company Royal Numico, which is recommending that shareholders accept the deal. The announcement came less than a week after Kraft said it would pay $7.2 billion for Danone's cookie division.

Fugitive executives are an old story in business, with Comverse's Jacob Alexander only the latest such example. But the tale of the hedge fund manager who had managed to stay on the run for five years after losing a $400 million bet against the tech bubble of the late 1990s ended on Friday when he was caught in Austria, Reuters reported.
In his Web column today, Patrick Healy writes from Paris:

Democratic U.S. Rep. Dennis Kucinich seems to like setting ambitious goals for himself. Running for president is one. Slowing the rush of initial public offerings by managers of alternative assets (private equity and hedge funds) is another.
Everywhere you looked in Sunday's papers, at home and abroad, you found long, lumbering articles about J.K. Rowling and her boy Harry. (One of the better ones is here.)

Simon Wilson, the editor of the BBC's Middle East bureau, blogged today about the freeing of his Gaza correspondent, Alan Johnston. When Mr. Johnston went missing on March 12, his editor felt "enormous responsibility" to take a lead role in finding him, he wrote. That meant meeting with "savory and less savory characters" and heading to Gaza, where he and his colleagues soon faced the same threats as Mr. Johnston, and retreated to Jerusalem:

Intel will invest about $219 million for a stake in VMware and a seat on the board of the Silicon Valley software company that parent EMC is taking public, the companies said on Monday. The investment is intended to speed adoption of VMware's software technology on computers using Intel semiconductors, expanding an ongoing strategic relationship.
Subaru WRX commercial, for Web site and television.
LaBranche has long been in the business of bringing together buyers and sellers of stock. But is the company itself looking to connect with a buyer?

Lavender farmers in the south of France are savoring the wind drifts this year like precious bottled perfume. This summer's relentless rains have produced a bountiful crop in the prime territory for lavender along the Plateau de Valensole. And growers claim the gush of water has intensified the lavender fragrance and hues of purple and mauve flowers.

The signs touting the 78th All-Star Game in San Francisco, a.k.a, the Barry Bonds Game, are everywhere. From thousands of fans crowding the streets around AT & T Park to television reporters doing stories from McCovey Cove to hotel employees wearing All-Star polo shirts, it is all All-Star Game, all the time.

Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft's Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

The board of directors of Topps, the maker of Bazooka bubble gum and baseball cards, recommended on Monday that shareholders reject Upper Deck's tender offer, but said it plans to continue talks with its suitor.
As lawmakers return to Washington today from a weeklong Congressional break, a fresh debate over the Iraq war is set to begin.

With a dizzying array of candidates, a front-loaded primary calendar and a campaign that is unusually intense even though the election is still 16 months away, a bit of voter fatigue seems natural. In interviews across the country, The Times's Adam Nagourney sees signs that the electorate has been worn down by the early campaign, but he also notes that voters are hardly disengaged:

With a shareholder vote just a few days away, Carl Icahn's investment vehicle has increased its offer to buy the Lear Corporation, a maker of automotive seating systems. Lear also delayed the vote, which was previously scheduled for Thursday and has already been postponed once.

Alliance Bank, Kazakhstan's largest retail lender, has priced a secondary stock offering at $14 to $17.30 per global depository receipt that will mark its opening on the London Stock Exchange, The Financial Times reported. With 50.28 million depository receipts scheduled to be sold, the offering is valued at between $704 million and $870 million.

With most of the attention focused on Iraq, where more than 150 people were killed in a weekend attack and the White House is starting to talk "gradual withdrawal," The Wall Street Journal takes a look at another war that has endured in relatively glorious stalemate for 54 years.
A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

Sequa, a maker of aerospace and automotive parts, said Monday it had agreed to a $2.7 billion takeover bid from the private equity firm Carlyle Group, representing a 54 percent premium to the closing price of Sequa's shares on Friday.

On Monday, the private equity industry will find itself facing another antagonist. Moody's, the debt-rating agency, will issue a report that criticizes the increasing use of debt to buy companies and questions claims that public companies are better off being taken private, The Financial Times reported.

Cedar Fair Entertainment, the nation's third-largest theme-park operator, has asked Bear Stearns to gauge private equity firms' interest in a buyout of the company, The New York Post reported, citing unnamed sources. So far, interest among the buyer pool has been tepid, The Post said.
Singapore Airlines is reviewing the future of its stake in Virgin Atlantic, a move that may presage a sale, The Telegraph reported Monday.
Apollo Management raised its offer for the chemical maker Huntsman by 75 cents, to $28 a share, or $6.5 billion, on Sunday, MarketWatch reported citing The Wall Street Journal.
CVC Capital Partners, Europe's second-largest buyout firm, on Monday agreed to purchase Netherlands-based Univar for $2.07 billion.

After ousting its chief executive last week, many have speculated that UBS would split itself to jump-start growth. But the chairman of the Swiss banking giant ruled that out Sunday, saying instead that it may buy even more businesses.

Hedge funds and private equity funds both charge whopping fees. Beyond that, the two kinds of investment firms present vastly different benefits and drawbacks for public investors -- which will become clearer as more of them choose to go public, Lex suggests.

Private equity firm H.I.G. Capital will announce plans for an ambitious European expansion on Monday, The Financial Times reported. The Miami-based outfit will open offices in London, Paris and Hamburg after raising $818 million for small- to mid-sized buy-outs and investments in the region.

Reuters is likely to put one of its electronic trading platforms and two key financial databases up for sale to get its 8.8 billion pound merger with Canada's Thomson approved by the regulators, The Daily Telegraph reported Sunday.

Britain's Barclays is looking to get out of the subprime mortgage-backed securities business after the bank revealed the depth of its involvement with two failed Bear Stearns funds. A review of several of the bank's businesses is under way as it tries to reduce its exposure to consumers with low credit ratings.
Morgan Stanley will buy Daewoo Engineering & Construction's Seoul headquarters for $1.04 billion, Bloomberg News reported on Monday.
The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group has acquired a 10 percent stake in Vietnam's top stock broker, Saigon Securities for $88 million.
A potential fight is brewing over Everlast Worldwide as a New York investor group faces off against a British sports retailer in a bid for control of the company.

A group of angry investors in Bally Total Fitness has made its own offer to block the struggling gym operator's plan to file for bankruptcy protection. On Saturday, The New York Post reported, Bally said it had agreed to open its books to the shareholders who proposed an alternate restructuring plan.
The billionaire Ronald Perelman has asked Florida's Supreme Court to overturn an appeals court ruling that stripped him of a $1.58 billion jury award against Morgan Stanley in 2005, Reuters reported.
PricewaterhouseCoopers has agreed to pay $225 million to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by Tyco International shareholders, The Boston Globe reported on Saturday.
Deutsche Bank has appointed Chew Soon Gek as chief investment officer in Asia for its private wealth management division.

Prada is denying reports that it is in talks over a potential sale of the company to the billionaire Richard Caring. The Sunday Times, citing unnamed sources, said it was in negotiations with a "handful of potential buyers," including at least two private equity firms. The Daily Telegraph reported Monday that Prada has put a 3 billion to 3.5 billion euro ($4.1 billion to $4.8 billion) price tag on the business.

China's Times Limited, a supermarket operator, has raised $113 million in an initial public offering in Hong Kong. However, demand from both retail and institutional investors was less overwhelming than for public offerings of other Chinese retailers including New World Department Store, which last week attracted $1.8 billion worth of orders from the retail market.

Atomic Energy of Canada, the country's flagship nuclear reactor company, is being pursued by several foreign and domestic companies, including a group led by General Electric, that are interested in an ownership stake, The Globe and Mail reported Saturday, without naming sources.

A Dutch court is expected this week to overturn a lower court's ruling that prevented ABM Amro from selling its United States unit LaSalle, but to raise questions that could lead to an investigation by the lower court and delay the sale for months.

Constant Contact has filed a registration statement for a proposed initial public stock offering that would raise about $86 million, the Mass High Tech Business Journal reported Monday. If the I.P.O. is completed, the common stock would trade on the Nasdaq Global Market under the symbol CTCT, according to its S.E.C. filing.

TissueLink Medical, a maker of devices that control bleeding during surgery, has completed a $20 million Series E round of venture capital. The round was led by previous investors Arnerich Massena & Associates and RiverVest Venture Partners.

Omega Advisers, the $6 billion hedge fund run by Leon Cooperman, will pay $500,000 to resolve a federal bribery investigation into its investment of more than $100 million in Azerbaijan with the Czech financier Viktor Kozeny. Prosecutors in New York agreed not to charge Omega, after the 2004 guilty plea of a former executive, Clayton Lewis, who admitted conspiring to bribe Azeri leaders. Omega admitted no wrongdoing.
Tao Tsuot and Financial Levers, two Israeli investment companies, said Sunday that they led a group that had agreed to buy the Lipstick Building in Manhattan for $648.5 million.
It's not over 'til it's over.
Some say the best way to see Maine’s natural beauty is atop the 420-foot public observation tower on the Penobscot Narrows Bridge.

The Harvard Observatory holds more than a century of astronomical records.

The president invoked executive privilege today to defy subpoenas from Congress for testimony on the firings of prosecutors.
The seemingly epic 2008 presidential campaign actually gets people’s blood boiling in cafes and bars in Paris.
The U.N. nuclear monitoring agency agreed today to send experts to North Korea as part of a process that is intended to lead to the closure of the country’s nuclear facility.
“One will recover, and one is clinging to life,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today.

Chris Greisen threw seven touchdown passes and ran for another to help the Georgia Force defeat the Philadelphia Soul, 65-39, last night in the Arena League playoffs. The Force (15-2) will play host to the Columbus Destroyers for the National Conference championship Saturday.Troy Bergeron took the opening kickoff 56 yards for a touchdown. Greisen passed for 301 yards, and Chris Jackson had 10 receptions for 169 yards and scored four second-half touchdowns.
The Red Bulls (7-5-3) evened the season series, after losing to Colorado (4-8-5) on May 13, thanks to a goal by John Wolyniec.

The Suffolk County police said they arrested a 27-year-old man yesterday and charged him with the murder last week of his aunt, Sharon Kurtz, 48, in Brentwood. The man, Kenneth Hubbard, who lived with Ms. Kurtz on Calebs Path, went into her bedroom Thursday morning to steal money, and when Ms. Kurtz awoke and saw him, he strangled her, the police said. Her body was discovered later that day by her brother, the police said. Her bedroom door had been locked, the police said, and her death was not deemed suspicious until an autopsy was performed the next day.

A 53-year-old woman was killed and three other people were injured when a powerboat collided with a sailboat on the Connecticut River yesterday afternoon, the authorities said. The operator of the powerboat, Gregory Siege, 44, of Madison, was pulled from the water and charged with reckless operation while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, said Dennis Schain, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Protection. The accident happened just before 4 p.m. near Long Island Sound, Mr. Schain said.

The owner of a Bronx moving company was found dead at a business he owned yesterday afternoon, the police said. The victim, Angel Ortega Jr., 39, was found just before 1 p.m. by his wife at the Jiffy Moving Company on Light Street, the police said. He had been shot once in the leg and once in the chest, and was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. No arrests had been made yesterday evening.

A federal judge has thrown out a $2.5 million jury award against the town of East Haven tied to the police killing of a 21-year-old man in 1997. The judge, Alvin W. Thompson of Federal District Court, in a decision released Saturday, cited a United States Supreme Court decision that municipalities are immune from punitive damages. A federal jury in July 2003 ruled that Sgt. Robert Flodquist of the East Haven police used excessive force and committed a civil rights violation when he killed Malik Jones. It awarded $2.5 million in punitive damages to Mr. Jones’s family. The officer was cleared of wrongdoing after a state investigation. The jury found that the town was ultimately responsible for the civil rights violation. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A man was stabbed to death on Marcy Avenue during a midmorning dispute with a group of assailants, the police said. The man, 41, whom the police did not identify yesterday evening, was stabbed three times in the chest about 10:25 a.m. in front of 503 Marcy Avenue, the police said. Witnesses told the police that the man was assaulted by two or three others during an argument. He was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said.
Deisha Bennett said she did not know why the man she planned to marry shot up her apartment as he went on a rampage that ended in his death Saturday.

A planning group has begun a test project to see whether New York would be suitable for a bicycle sharing system common in European cities. The five-day project, started yesterday and sponsored by the Forum for Urban Design, makes 20 bicycles free for a half-hour ride after users provide credit card information to ensure their return, said David Haskell, the group’s executive director. The bikes have been lined up at a SoHo gallery called the Storefront for Art and Architecture.
Board members plan to meet today with Ronald W. Burkle in an effort to find a bidder other than News Corporation.

A trainer for the heavyweight champion Wladimir Klitschko said that the boxer fought most of his title bout against Lamon Brewster with a broken left hand.The trainer, Jamen Ali Bashir, told The Associated Press yesterday that Klitschko broke his middle finger during the fight. Klitschko iced his hand immediately afterward, and is now wearing a cast from his left hand past his elbow. “It will take eight weeks to heal,” Bashir said.Despite the injury, Klitschko dominated the fight Saturday night. Brewster’s trainer, Buddy McGirt, stopped the fight before the seventh round, and Klitschko kept his International Boxing Federation and International Boxing Organization titles.

Bill Maas, a 45-year-old former All-Pro lineman and broadcaster, faces charges of drug and weapons possession after being arrested Friday night during a roadside search near Peoria, Ill. Police found a .22-caliber revolver, five grams of suspected marijuana, five grams of suspected cocaine and 28 pills of suspected Ecstasy in Maas’s sport utility vehicle.Maas was charged with felony possession of a controlled substance and unlawful use of a weapon. Maas was drafted out of Pittsburgh by the Kansas City Chiefs in 1984 and was twice named to the All-Pro team. He joined Fox Sports in 1996 and worked for the network through last season.

Nery Castillo scored twice as Mexico hammered Paraguay, 6-0, yesterday in their Copa América quarterfinal in Maturin, Venezuela. Mexico handed Paraguay its worst defeat since 1980, when it lost by the same score to Brazil. Mexico advanced to a semifinal game Wednesday against the tournament favorite Argentina, which defeated Peru yesterday, 4-0. Brazil plays Uruguay tomorrow in the other semifinal.

With airport fire trucks blasting water cannons in salute, the crew of the America’s Cup champion Alinghi returned to Switzerland yesterday and was hailed by the country’s president as a symbol of Swiss pride and diversity.Ernesto Bertarelli, the billionaire head of Alinghi, hoisted the silver trophy at the aircraft door. He was applauded by fans and a government delegation. “I’m enormously proud to be here in Geneva with you for the second time,” said Bertarelli, who made Switzerland the first European nation to successfully defend the title in yachting’s premier event. Switzerland scored a major upset in 2003 by taking the Cup from New Zealand, bringing sport’s oldest international trophy to Europe for the first time in more than 150 years. On Tuesday, Alinghi’s dramatic one-second win over Emirates Team New Zealand in Valencia, Spain, ended the closest America’s Cup regatta in 24 years, a 5-2 Swiss victory. Bertarelli declined to say whether the next Cup would be held in two or four years and whether it would be contested in Valencia.

Tim Cahill scored in injury time as Australia rescued a 1-1 draw against Oman in its opening Asia Cup match in Bangkok. Cahill, a midfielder who plays for Everton of the English Premier League, volleyed into the net from close range for Australia. Oman took the lead in the 32nd minute on a strike from Badar Mubarak.

Chelsea acquired wing Florent Malouda of France from Lyon for an undisclosed fee. Chelsea said on its Web site that it wanted to sign Malouda before leaving for its preseason tour to the United States, which begins Saturday in Stanford, Calif. Malouda, 27, was voted the best player in France’s Ligue 1 last season.
Nigerian gunmen released a British toddler, her parents said, days after she was kidnapped in the country’s oil-rich south.
Across the country, voters said the presidential race had become much too intense, much too soon.
Some aides to the president want to forestall Republican defections by announcing an intention to gradually withdraw American troops.

The St. Louis Cardinals’ Albert Pujols has agreed to participate in tonight’s Home Run Derby in San Francisco, even though he is mired in a career-worst power slump. Pujols, who has 16 home runs, and Alex Rios of the Toronto Blue Jays were the final participants added.
Despite a vibrant local economy, Atlanta’s surge in foreclosures offers a glimpse of what experts fear may be in store for other U.S. cities.

Jacoby Ellsbury, a left-handed center fielder of Native American descent who looks and plays like a younger, faster Johnny Damon, has started off his year by hitting .452 at Portland.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 8 (AP) — A fast-growing blaze in southwestern South Dakota killed one person and destroyed 20 homes on Sunday, while hundreds of people evacuated homes in the path of a fire in Washington State.
The attack, which killed around 150 people on Saturday, has highlighted fears that insurgents facing military crackdowns are shifting to remoter regions.

Nouadhibou, Mauritania, is the western terminus for a mile-and-a-half-long train that is not meant for passengers but is used for transportation anyway.

Scott Dixon held off Sam Hornish Jr., Dario Franchitti, Tony Kanaan and Marco Andretti over the final 14 laps to win the Watkins Glen Grand Prix Sunday.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 8 (AP) — Crews from Harvard and California-Berkeley were among the winners Sunday at the Henley Royal Regatta.

It was left to Johan Inger, whose “Dream Play” completed the program, to celebrate the distinctions of the company’s young dancers.
After producing some of TV’s most successful recent shows, Ben Silverman is trying to revive NBC’s slumping entertainment division.
Roger Federer matched Bjorn Borg’s record of five consecutive wins at the All England Club by defeating Rafael Nadal in five sets.
Thousands of New York’s pickiest music connoisseurs spent hours in line to witness what was basically a glorified drum circle.
In countries where A.T.M.’s are few or nonexistent, cellphones are helping microlenders bring financial services to poor and remote areas.
The Great Wall of China was voted as one of the new seven wonders of the world, items from the Dutch national art collection are going on sale through eBay and more culture news.

The London production of “The Drowsy Chaperone,” which opened at the Novello Theater on May 14, is to close on Aug. 4. “London ticket sales for our show have been slower than needed to sustain a longer run at the Novello,” said an announcement from the producers. The Broadway production, which opened on May 1, 2006, is still running at the Marquis Theater. ... Martha Plimpton has been chosen to replace Missi Pyle as Helena in the Shakespeare in the Park production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” opening in previews on Aug. 7 and continuing through Sept. 9 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. An announcement said that Ms. Pyle withdrew because of an unexpected scheduling conflict. ... Danny DeVito was honored for lifetime achievement in cinema at closing ceremonies on Saturday at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival in the Czech Republic. The top prize at the festival, the biggest such event in Central Europe, went to an Icelandic film, Baltasar Kormakur’s “Myrin,” about a group of pugnacious men.

The fifth annual “Spirit of Django Reinhardt” concert, celebrating the hot swing of that jazz guitarist and his 1930s collaboration with the jazz violin pioneer Stéphane Grappelli in the Quintet of the Hot Club of France, will be in New York on Aug. 1 at Frederick P. Rose Hall, the home of Jazz at Lincoln Center. Performers will include the Gypsy guitarists Dorado Schmitt and his son Samson Schmitt, the accordionist Ludovic Beier, the bassist Brian Q. Torff and the John Jorgenson Quintet.

More than 1,000 paintings, statues and other objects from the Dutch national art collection are going on sale through eBay, Agence France-Presse reported. The government’s decision, a response to the cost of conserving the works, has outraged some artists and cheered others. “They called me the Picasso of Amsterdam,” complained one painter, Robert Kruzdlo. “I do not paint rubbish.” But another painter, Willem Oorebeek, said, “I don’t see the auction as a loss, but more of a renaissance of my work, a rediscovery.” Marina Raymakers, a spokeswoman for the Netherlands Institute for Cultural Heritage, which manages thousands of state-owned art works, said, “These are works that have not been on display in 100 years or works that do not fit in with the kind of exhibitions in museums.” She added that many were produced in the 1980s under government subsidies to support artists.

When all the votes were counted the Great Wall of China was still standing — as one of the new seven wonders of the world. So were the Colosseum in Rome; the Taj Mahal in India; Petra in Jordan, above; Machu Picchu in Peru; the Statue of Christ Redeemer in Rio de Janeiro; and the Chichén Itzá pyramid in Mexico. The Associated Press reported that in the balloting, conducted by New7Wonders (new7wonders.com), a nonprofit organization, about 100 million votes were cast online and in text messages, leaving open the possibility that some people voted more than once. The losers among 14 other nominated landmarks included the Eiffel Tower, the Statue of Liberty, the Acropolis, the Kremlin, the Sydney Opera House and Easter Island. The pyramids of Giza, the competition’s sole survivors from the traditional seven wonders of the ancient world, were declared above the fray after indignant Egyptian officials said it was ”ridiculous” to even put them in such a competition. Yesterday the Egypt government said that the Great Pyramid was the only true wonder of the world. Zahi Hawass, secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities in Cairo, told Agence France-Presse that the vote had “no value” because, he said, “the masses do not write history.”.

Victor Willis, the original policeman in the disco group the Village People, is planning to perform for the first time in about 25 years, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Willis, 55, will appear on Aug. 31 at the House of Blues in Las Vegas in a preview of the Victor Willis Disco Dance Tour. That tour is scheduled to begin in March and take him around the United States and to Australia, Britain, Japan, Norway, Germany and Canada. “He’ll come out on his motorcycle” and perform Village People hits and other numbers, said his press representative Alice Wolf. Mr. Willis was one of the writers of “Y-M-C-A” and “In the Navy.” He was arrested last year in San Francisco, where he pleaded no contest to possessing drugs and was sentenced to three years’ probation. Ms. Wolf said he completed a nine-month treatment program in April.

Johnson & Johnson reassigned the creative accounts of six brands.  Also, Nokia chose Wieden & Kennedy as worldwide lead agency and Refinery was acquired by G2 Worldwide.

The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.
Online travel agencies like Travelocity and Expedia are looking overseas as growth in domestic bookings has slowed.

After falling some 15 miles from the finish, Robbie McEwen clawed his way back to win the stage from London to Canterbury.  He’s back on his bike in Belgium today.

8 P.M. (TCM) SPIELBERG ON SPIELBERG Steven Spielberg, left, talks about his successful Hollywood career in this documentary having its premiere tonight. Afterward TCM is showing some of his major hits, starting at 9:30 with “Jaws” (1975), the film credited with starting the idea of the summer blockbuster and firmly establishing Mr. Spielberg’s career. And at 1:30 a.m. you can see “Close Encounters of the Third Kind” (1977), the touching movie about extraterrestrials.

STEINBERG--Eugene R., 87, on July 7, 2007. Loving husband of Ruth (nee Kotcher). Cherished father of Rana (Douglas) Binder, Mimi (Richard) Wolkin, and Patty (Michel) Stella. Adored grandfather of Jenny, Caroline, Christine, Lillie, Amy, and Amanda. He will always be lovingly remembered. Services Tuesday, 11:30am at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY.

BENSON--Fannie (nee Schutz) of Hewlett, formerly Valley Stream. Died at age 89 on July 5, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Richard Benson. Mother of Barbara (Jerry) Kaplan and Joan (Richard Greene) April; grandmother of Alex April. Dearest friend of Claire Friedheim. She earned a Master's Degree in History from Brooklyn College and had taught for many years at Oceanside Junior High School. Funeral services will be private. Donations to the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library, 1125 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557 are appreciated.

KOVICH--Beatrice. Our gentle, loving friend. Your endless warmth, generosity, and good humor touched all who knew you. Our broken hearts go out to Paul, Jaeger and Jane. The sun rose and set on them for you and your goodness will live on in them always. We have lost a truly exceptional friend. Bea, we will love you and treasure your memory forever. Ron, Jean, Jackie, Alex, and Chloe KOVICH--Beatrice Tapper, died suddenly on July 6th as a result of a tragic rafting accident. A devoted and loving wife to Paul and loving and dedicated mother of Jaeger and Jane. Bea was a kind and gentle person loved by her friends and family. Her warmth and friendship touched all who knew her. She is also survived by her sister-in-law Susan Tapper Segal, her niece and nephew Elyse Tapper Cardon and David Cardon and their children Bella and Sylvie and her niece Kimberly Tapper. Memorial Services will be held Tuesday 11:45am at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. A graveside service will follow at 1:30 pm at Beth Israel Cemetery, US Highway 1, Woodbridge, NJ. Donations in Bea's memory made be to either The National Hemophilia Foundation, 116 West 32nd St., NY, NY 10001 or Facing History and Ourselves, 16 Hurd Rd., Brookline, MA 02445-6919. She will be forever missed and eternally remembered.

NOONAN--John J., ''Jack'', of New York City, passed away Friday morning with family by his side at the age of 73 due to complications from a stroke. Born December 2, 1933. Loving husband of Teresa for 37 years, beloved father of James, John Jr., and Michael, brother of Kathleen Newberger, uncle, grandfather, and great-grandfather. He served in the U.S. Naval Air Force during the Korean War. Proud member of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local No. 3, Jack studied Labor Relations at Cornell University and served as Chairman of the Elevator Division for many years. His love, wisdom, and stories will be missed greatly. Visitation Monday and Tuesday 2-4 pm and 7-9 pm at Arlington Benson Dowd Funeral Home, 8315 Parsons Blvd, Jamaica, NY, (718) 658-4434. Funeral service Wednesday 9:30 am at St. Nicholas of Tolentine R.C. Church, 150-75 Goethals Ave, Jamaica, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Stroke Association.

WYSE--Lois. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and benefactress, Lois Wyse, who served for many years as a member of the Beth Israel Board of Trustees, and who had been a member of the Beth Israel Board of Overseers since its inception. Lois will be remembered for her philanthropic support of numerous programs and for her expert counsel on public relations and marketing issues affecting the hospital. To her children, grandchildren and all of her loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Morton P. Rose Hall, the home of Jazz at Lincoln Center. Performers will include the Gypsy guitarists Dorado Schmitt and his son Samson Schmitt, the accordionist Ludovic Beier, the bassist Brian Q. Torff and the John Jorgenson Quintet.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.94 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.66 percent.

The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the increasing use of dance in commercials, misstated part of the name of the agency that created a campaign centered on a dance routine for the Nair product line sold by Church & Dwight. It is the Joey Company, not the Joey Agency.

White House officials fear that the last pillars of political support among Senate Republicans for President Bush's Iraq strategy are collapsing around them, according to several administration officials and outsiders they are consulting. They say that inside the administration, debate is intensifying over whether Mr. Bush should try to prevent more defections by announcing his intention to begin a gradual withdrawal of American troops from the high-casualty neighborhoods of Baghdad and other cities. Mr. Bush and his aides once thought they could wait to begin those discussions until after Sept. 15, when the top field commander and the new American ambassador to Baghdad are scheduled to report on the effectiveness of the troop increase that the president announced in January. But suddenly, some of Mr. Bush's aides acknowledge, it appears that forces are combining against him just as the Senate prepares this week to begin what promises to be a contentious debate on the war's future and financing.

CUTS LOOM AT WALL STREET JOURNAL If the $5 billion bid by the News Corporation to buy Dow Jones & Company falls through, declining advertising will mean significant cuts in The Wall Street Journal's newsroom staff, according to senior editors and a person close to Dow Jones management. DIRECTIONS IN CYBERSPACE With the cleverness of a Wall Street arbitrageur, David Ulevitch, left, founder of OpenDNS.com, has figured out how to use the Internet's unique identifiers to make a business out of the propensity of Web surfers to make simple typing errors. [C6.]

Marci was a woman of great intelligence, a steadfast friend who cared. She loved people and lived her life with dignity and kindness. She will be deeply missed.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about Ralph J. Roberts, the founder of Comcast, and his son Brian, its chief executive, misstated the surname of a company executive who commented on their relationship. He is David Cohen, not Calhoun.

QUARTERLY REPORTS Earnings season begins in earnest with the second-quarter report of Alcoa on Monday. Other earnings: Chevron and Pepsi Bottling, on Tuesday; Genentech and Yum Brands on Wednesday; Marriott and Nordstrom, on Thursday; and General Electric, on Friday. ECONOMIC DATA A snapshot of the retailing sector emerges with reports on same-store sales for June (Thursday) and the government's report on retail sales for June (Friday). Other reports: May consumer credit (Monday); May wholesale trade (Tuesday); the trade deficit for May (Thursday); and May business inventories, June import prices and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

The news that two of Senator John McCain's top advisers were quitting his presidential campaign broke suddenly this morning, but as conservative and liberal bloggers weighed in throughout the day, few seemed surprised by the development and even fewer were lamenting it.

Ronald Burkle, the Los Angeles billionaire, and Brad Greenspan, a founder of MySpace, are exploring the possibility of combining forces on a bid for Dow Jones to thwart a takeover by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, The Associated Press reported citing an unnamed source.

The jury in the racketeering and fraud trial of Conrad Black, the fallen former head of Hollinger, sent a note to the judge Tuesday saying they are unable to reach a verdict and asking for advice. The note read to the court by U.S. District Judge Amy St. Eve said: ''We have discussed and deliberated on all the evidence and are still unable to reach a unanimous verdict on one or more counts. Please advise.''
