Remains of a baby mammoth were discovered in the permafrost of northwest Siberia, adding to some scientists' hope of resurrecting the species, the BBC reported. The 6-month-old female calf was on the Yamal peninsula and is thought to have died 10,000 years ago. Scientists have said it could be the best preserved specimen of its type. Its trunk, eyes and some fur are still intact. The mammoth was found in May by a reindeer herder, and last week an international delegation of experts examined it. If viable DNA can be extracted, it might theoretically be cloned.

A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about the show ''Equal, That Is, to the Real Itself,'' at the Marian Goodman Gallery on West 57th Street, misspelled the given name of an artist whose works are displayed. He was Rudolf de Crignis, not Rudolph.

Amtrak will roll out a new generation of automated ticket machines at stations across the country, starting in Pennsylvania Station, railroad officials said yesterday. The machines, which officials said would eventually operate in 150 stations in the nation, will replace a version that has been in service since 1999. By the end of this month, Amtrak hopes to have 19 of the blue self-service machines installed at Penn Station. Officials said the kiosks, which have brighter screens and better panels, can complete a sale in about 30 seconds, down from the 60 seconds needed on the current machines.

WILLETT--Victoria T., 67, died peacefully on July 8th at her home in Manhattan after a valiant fight against cancer. She was a graduate of the Ethel Walker School, as well as Mt. Vernon and Finch Junior Colleges. She is survived by her two sons, Jackson Willett of Newport Beach, CA and Scott Willett of New York City. She also leaves a sister, Mary Elizabeth Pendl, a nephew Gregory Pendl and two grandchildren, Emily and Jack Willett of New York City. A memorial service will be held at the St. James Church in Manhattan on Wednesday, August 1st at 3:00pm, followed by a reception.

JOYCE--Thomas S., passed away peacefully on June 30, 2007 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx, after a long struggle with lung cancer. Loving husband of Stacy Joyce (nee O'Connell), he is also survived by his parents, Joseph and Katherine Joyce of Quincy, MA, his sister Beverly Marandett of Derry, NH, his brother Robert Joyce of La Jolla, CA and his sister Ann Ansary of Centennial, CO, as well as his many inlaws and his nieces and nephews whom he loved and counted as his own. Tom was born in Boston, MA, graduated from Denver University and lived for many years in Denver, CO before moving to New Rochelle, NY in 2001. He was the Practice Support Manager for the Litigation Department of NYC Law Firm, Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler. Memorial services will be held at Holy Name of Jesus Church in New Rochelle, NY on July 16 at 11 am and at the Common Market in Quincy, MA on July 14 at 1 pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to www.lungcanceralliance.org.

Britain's relationship with Russia came under new strain on Tuesday as Prime Minister Gordon Brown registered ''deep regret'' at Russia's refusal to extradite Andrei K. Lugovoi, accused here of murdering a former K.G.B. agent, Alexander V. Litvinenko. British officials at the prime minister's office and the Foreign Office protested the decision in unusually sharp language.

The country's largest guerrilla group said it had erred in its management of the abduction of 11 lawmakers who were killed in its custody last month. Details remain sparse about the conditions in which the hostages were killed, with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, maintaining that they died in cross-fire at an encampment that came under military attack. ''We failed in our mission to care for them and bring them to a hostage exchange,'' FARC said in a statement. The comments were seen as a response to large protests last week to the killings and to the use of abductions to make political demands.

GARDNER--Lee Richard. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Lee Richard Gardner. His family's devotion and commitment to Jewish values and tradition have left a legacy of hope for countless individuals, strengthening our ability to help those in need in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to Lee's wife, Harriet; to his children, Mindy and Larry, and Karen and Richard, to his stepchildren Kenneth and Marc; to his grandchildren; to his greatgrandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

She is survived by four children, nine grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Graveside service July 14, at 12:30 p.m. in the Cheney Section of East Cemetery, Manchester, CT.

We are dealing in a lot bigger issues than we used to — flat earth, terrorism, war — than just deals.”

Sergey Brin, sitting atop the Zeitgeist at Google, is hardly a press hound. But as one of the people of the moment, he was willing to show a little leg on the way out of Thursday morning’s conferences.
Sir Howard Stringer, head of Sony, has always made his own friendly way, including allowing for an impromptu press conference Thursday just in front of the sacred Duck Pond.

DealBook slunk back to its table in The Inn after the noon break and was typing a few dreary items — and then suddenly heard an avuncular, folksy voice — the voice of God, only less scary, from the next table over.

The camera crews were lounging outside The Inn at Sun Valley while the anointed (i.e. the folks who were actually invited to the Allen & Company conference) attended a briefing on terrorism — we think.
Jason Bazinet, an analyst at Citigroup, this week pegged the chances at 75 percent that Liberty Media would buy the rest of satellite television giant DirectTV and spin it off as a tracking stock.

DealBook suggested in an earlier post that Rupert Murdoch was feeling sanguine about his prospects of clinching Dow Jones — well, we actually said he looked sanguine — but his comments to Seth Sutel of the Associated Press suggest that he may be a bit frustrated with the Bancroft family’s back-and-forthing. “They keep changing their mind,” he told the AP, walking away from the lunch outside the Inn.

One of the big surprises of Herbert Allen’s Sun Valley retreat this week was the news that former British Prime Minister Tony Blair would be among the guests. Though no official announcement was made, the news broke via various media on Wednesday afternoon.

The Allen & Company summit in Sun Valley is a lot like high school, albeit with fewer available girls and a group of B.M.O.C.’s that are defined by net worth in the billions as opposed to what they can bench press.

The Mets summarily dismissed the hitting coach Rick Down and, in a somewhat more surprising move, essentially released Julio Franco today to clear space for two fast outfielders. Only one of them, Lastings Milledge, will play. The other, Rickey Henderson, who will not be used if another outfielder is injured, has been added to the coaching staff. His role? TBD.

Several people have commented on the BBC poll in Iraq that I mentioned. There have been a series of polls conducted in Iraq, available here, and I would strongly recommend a look through them. One reader referred to a poll supposedly in July, but actually it's a January 2006 poll that in fact I've referred to in previous columns.

Univision, Telefutura and Galavisión continue to do extremely well with their soccer telecasts this summer. After running up big numbers recently with the Gold Cup, Univision and the two other Spanish-language television networks it owns have split among them telecasts of the Copa América and the FIFA U-20 World Cup. In New York especially, they have registered some astonishingly high numbers.

Alex Rodriguez, who was the highest-paid eight-place hitter in baseball history at the end of last season, has restored himself to the position of the best player in baseball in 2007. Rodriguez has 30 homers, 86 runs batted in and a .317 average, stunning statistics for slightly more than half a season.

The Massachusetts Democratic Party released a video today that tears into presidential candidate Mitt Romney, featuring him in a series of moments while campaigning for governor of Massachusetts in 2002, in which he downplays his affiliation with the Republican Party.

Everyone is raving about Leo Messi's goal against Mexico last night, and fair enough (though for our money, the goal by Gabriel Heinze was just as beautiful and astounding), but the player who vexed the Mexicans at least as much as Messi was Carlos Tévez. All night long Carlitos gave el Tri's backline fits, and not just when he won a questionable penalty that led to the third goal, but the entire evening, right from the first minutes of the match.

It's World Population Day, a day to think about how well the world has followed that advice to "be fruitful and multiply." In Sub-Saharan Africa and other parts of the developing world, birth rates are very high, but so are maternal deaths in childbirth -- a trend that the United Nations is trying to stop.

The White House's status report on Iraq "benchmarks" is the big subject of the day. If you've got a lot of time on your hands, check out Ilan Goldenberg's "fact check" of the report at National Security Network, which finds in sum that "some benchmarks claimed as 'satisfactory' only demonstrate minimal progress, not achievement. Others have been achieved on the surface, but fail to accomplish the overall purpose of the specific measurement."

The Times's David W. Chen writes today that in response to a lawsuit filed by Republicans seeking public disclosure of e-mail messages he exchanged with the state union president who is also a former companion, New Jersey Gov. Jon S. Corzine said he had decided simply to stop using e-mail.

Cerberus Capital Management is a lot less publicity-shy than it used to be. This week, Mr. Snow was in Detroit speaking about the dangers of a fuel-efficiency bill making its way through Congress.

One of the largest investors in Brink's is maintaining pressure on the security company to split up to boost its flagging stock price. Included in a regulatory filing Thursday was a letter from MMI Investments, an activist hedge fund, pointing out the share performance of Brink's to a newly public competitor and urging further action.
John P. Mackey, the co-founder of Whole Foods Market, has never lacked for personality. As it turns out, that was only the half of it. For seven years, Mr. Mackey had an online alter ego.

JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs have been hired by Apollo Management to advise on on its expected initial public offering. The Financial Times said late Wednesday that this is the first sign of a comeback by other Wall Street banks after the early dominance of Morgan Stanley and Citigroup in the battle to underwrite private equity floats.

Merrill Lynch raised its bid for Berenice Fondo Uffici to 437 million euros ($602 million), surpassing an offer by Goldman Sachs for the owner of about 50 Italian office buildings from Milan to Palermo. Merrill bid 770 euros per Berenice unit, according to a statement Thursday, 8 euros more than Goldman offered Wednesday. Berenice has attracted seven bids from three groups in less than two months.

Leveraged buyout firms paid investment banks $8.4 billion during the first half of 2007, according to data compiled by Freeman & Company and Thomson Financial. Blackstone Group led the pack of folks paying huge sums to Wall Street with $685.4 million in the first six months of 2007.

Angry BCE bondholders are preparing a lawsuit against the company in a bid to win better terms in the leveraged buyout of Bell Canada by Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan. The bonds have plunged 20 percent or more in recent months.

The mining giant Rio Tinto has offered to buy the Canadian aluminum company Alcan for $38.1 billion, the companies said Thursday, in a friendly takeover that counters a hostile bid by United States-based Alcoa.

Cerberus chairman John Snow said on Wednesday that he feels confident about Chrysler's prospects. "We're committed to Chrysler; we're committed to making it an enormous success," he told a Detroit Economic Club audience. He also said that Cerberus had no plans to sell Chrysler or to take it public after making it profitable again.

Republican presidential candidate Mike Huckabee's comment yesterday that Michael Moore is an example of "why the health care system costs more in this country" -- an apparent reference to Mr. Moore's weight -- drew a sharp response from one of the filmmaker's associates.

The Bush administration warned lawmakers on Wednesday not to raise the tax rate of private equity and hedge funds or their managers, maintaining that it would injure the economy and discourage risk-taking.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted rules ensuring that it can sue hedge funds for misleading investors, after a court ruling put in doubt the regulator's authority over the $1.6 trillion industry.

Goldman Sachs was unable to name its co-head of investment banking in Asia as chief executive of its Beijing joint venture because his knowledge of Chinese was too weak, Bloomberg News reported, citing people at the firm. Richard Ong, an ethnic Chinese born in Malaysia, didn't write Chinese well enough to take a mandatory test for senior managers.

After its $3 billion offer to buy Ventana Medical Systems was rebuffed Wednesday, Roche Holding indicated it may be willing to raise the bid. Roche chief executive Franz Humer described Roche's current offer as "full and fair" in a letter to Ventana Chairman Jack Schuler, Bloomberg News said, but he left the door open to a compromise.

The London Stock Exchange's plan to merge with Italy's bourse took a serious hit on Wednesday after the L.S.E.'s biggest shareholder, Nasdaq, blocked its attempt to win approval for a massive share issue to fund the 1.1 billion pound deal.
Playing Hendrix for a night has become the new karaoke.

In one of the largest single venture capital investments seen recently, Starfire Systems has raised $10 million from Palladium Equity Partners. Starfire is based in New York state and makes nanostructured ceramic materials for use in industries such as aerospace, automotive, energy and electronics.
Newmont Mining said it will offer $1 billion in convertible senior notes to help repay debt and complete major projects in Australia and Peru, The Denver Business Journal reported.

Russian bank Vneshtorgbank said Wednesday that it is considering a sale of its 5 percent stake in EADS, The Associated Press reported on Wednesday. Although the news that Russia's second-biggest bank had bought the EADS stake was surprising when it was announced last year, it is understood that Russian government would have even enjoyed raising its position in the company.

Bear Stearns' High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leverage Fund has cut its debt in half to $600 million after selling off assets, Bloomberg News reported on Wednesday. The fund owed creditors $1.2 billion as of June 26 but the ailing securities firm filed the new numbers in a regulatory filing Tuesday.
VirtualLogix has raised $16 million in a Series B round of venture capital funding. The new cash will allow the company to continue bringing virtualization to the device world.
TA Acquisition, an affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management, has been given a green light in its quest to buy Tower Automotive for $1 billion.

Compuware's poor financial results are inciting renewed speculation that the company could be a prime takeover target, TheDeal.com said Wednesday. Shares in the software maker plunged more than 20 percent after said it expects first-quarter sales of about $278 million, below analyst estimates of $303 million.

General Electric will not go through with a deal to buy two Abbott Laboratories diagnostic units for $8.1 billion in cash, the two companies said Wednesday without specifying reasons, except to say that they had failed to agree on final terms and conditions.
Images from “Feelings,” the exhibition of Martin Creed’s work at Bard College.
President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan defended the raid on the Red Mosque in Islamabad as necessary.
Images from “Joseph Cornell: Navigating the Imagination” at the Peabody Essex Museum.
House gifts that make a splash.
Covering 124 miles in three days by peddle power.
Activists in Spain are encouraged by the European Commission's recent move to take Spain to the European Court of Justice over its controversial land laws.
Music, plywood and cornstarch and more.
The budding attractions of the fertile valley.
A look back at some of John Travolta's memorable performances.
If eating in Palermo’s rustic trattorias seems like visiting someone’s home, that’s because it often is.
Photos of Comédie-Française’s “Fables de La Fontaine."
Today's New York Times reports on two very expensive luxury items.
Dell’s new XPS M1330, available only in tuxedo black, crimson red and pearl white, is the thinnest 13-inch-screen notebook.
How do I use my cellphone as a modem?
It is not just Apple that stands to make big profits from its effort to redefine the mobile phone industry.
The Raon Everun ultramobile PC, which starts at $799, has a 4.8-inch touchscreen and a full mini-keyboard with touchpad.
Jackie Estacado has to wait a little while before any minions show up in The Darkness, a first-person shooter from Starbreeze Studios.
Sanyo, Olympus and Pentax have introduced waterproof camera/camcorders that come surf-ready.
Some of President Bush’s aides acknowledge that the surge of American forces that Mr. Bush defended so ardently today is already on borrowed time.
Dr. James W. Holsinger Jr. told a Senate panel today that he would resign before putting politics over science.
Two Reuters journalists were killed today during a battle between the American military and Shiite militias.

JERUSALEM, July 12 — An Israeli soldier was killed early this morning during a military incursion in the central Gaza Strip, an army spokesman said. He was the first Israeli killed in combat since November 2006.
Dry conditions, high temperatures and ample tinder contributed to a rash of wildfires in western states today, with blazes in Utah endangering coal mines, methane wells and gas pipelines.
Sharpe James was indicted today on 33 counts of fraud and depriving government of honest services.
President Bush told lawmakers that they had no business trying to manage the war hours before they approved a measure to withdraw most combat troops from Iraq by April 1, 2008.
Police are investigating whether the gang used stolen cars to pull off shootings and recruit prostitutes, officials said.
The Mets, seeking to inject some life into a struggling offense, have fired their hitting coach, Rick Down, and have added Rickey Henderson to the coaching staff.
The Rangers avoided a potentially fractious arbitration hearing with goalie Henrik Lundqvist and gave him a healthy raise with a one-year, $4.25 million contract.
college football.

Oklahoma must erase its victories from the 2005 season and will lose two scholarships for the 2008-9 and 2009-10 school years, the N.C.A.A. said yesterday. The penalties stem from a case involving two players, including the Sooners’ starting quarterback, who were kicked off the team in August for being paid for work they had not performed at a Norman, Okla., car dealership. The N.C.A.A. said Oklahoma was guilty of a “failure to monitor” the employment of the players.Oklahoma’s president, David Boren, said the university would appeal the N.C.A.A.’s finding and the ruling that it must erase the victories. Oklahoma has 15 days to notify the N.C.A.A. in writing of an appeal.The Sooners went 8-4 and defeated Oregon in the Holiday Bowl in 2005. Records from that season involving quarterback Rhett Bomar and offensive lineman J. D. Quinn must be erased, the N.C.A.A. said. Last August, just before the Sooners began preseason practice, Coach Bob Stoops dismissed Bomar and Quinn from the team after the university determined they had been paid for work not performed at Big Red Sports and Imports.

Cleared of rape charges, the former Duke player Collin Finnerty is transferring to Loyola of Maryland. Finnerty, 21, who will play for the Greyhounds next season, released a statement yesterday saying he looked forward to finishing his college career at Loyola.Finnerty, Reade Seligmann and Dave Evans were indicted last spring on charges of rape, kidnapping and sexual offense after a woman told the police in Durham, N.C., that she was attacked by three men at a March 2006 party where she was hired to perform as a stripper.The case steadily unraveled, and North Carolina state prosecutors who eventually took over from the district attorney dropped all charges.
In the month since Sharpe James was notified by federal prosecutors that he could face criminal charges for corruption, the city’s political establishment has been bracing itself for an indictment.

Receiver Kevin McMahan, the last player taken in the 2006 N.F.L. draft, was signed yesterday by the Giants.McMahan was waived by the Oakland Raiders in last year’s final cut. He had several tryouts last season before signing a reserve/future contract with Indianapolis on Jan. 11. He was waived by the Colts on June 22.At the University of Maine, McMahan played in 44 games and caught 130 passes for 1,995 yards and 25 touchdowns. He had career-high totals of 59 catches and 13 of the team’s 17 touchdown receptions as a senior.

Gaël Monfils of France upset top-seeded Nikolay Davydenko of Russia, 3-6, 6-4, 7-5, yesterday in the first round of the Swiss Open in Gstaad. Monfils and Davydenko were tied at 5-5 in the third set Tuesday when rain forced the match to be suspended.Also, Stefan Koubek of Austria defeated second-seeded Mikhail Youzhny of Russia, 6-4, 6-3, and third-seeded Richard Gasquet of France defeated Ruben Ramírez Hidalgo of Spain, 6-3, 6-4.
China revised its 2006 economic growth data to a 12-year high of 11.1 percent, from 10.7 percent.
Alcan, the Canadian aluminum producer, said it had signed agreements with third parties to evade a hostile $28.8 billion takeover bid from Alcoa.
Japan’s wholesale inflation accelerated in June as oil and other commodity prices rose, prompting food and packaging companies to pass on costs to clients.
Chaparral Steel has accepted a $4.22 billion takeover offer from Gerdau Ameristeel in the latest consolidation move in the steel industry.

A front-page article on Monday about New York City’s plan to set up an extensive network of cameras and roadblocks in Lower Manhattan to thwart terrorism reversed the sources of the $25 million secured to help pay for the network. The Department of Homeland Security has contributed $10 million and the city $15 million. The article also referred incompletely to the status of the plan. It does not need City Council approval because the Council has already approved the budget that includes the $15 million outlay.

An article yesterday about a federal report on the collapse of a tunnel ceiling in Boston’s Big Dig project misstated the role of Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff in choosing the epoxy that failed to hold the ceiling’s anchor bolts in place. Bechtel, which was hired to oversee the project, reviewed specifications for the epoxy that were written by Gannett Fleming, Inc., a subcontractor; Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff did not write the specifications.

An article in The Arts last Thursday about the use of water in theatrical productions in New York this summer misstated the timing of the death of the father of Sarah Ruhl, a playwright whose adaptation of “Eurydice” has the title character descending to the underworld in a rainy elevator. He died in 1994, not “recently,” and thus the production does not have that as another dimension.
An article on Sunday about efforts by homeowners to battle beach erosion on Nantucket, Mass., misspelled the name of a company that operates a sand pit there. It is Holdgate Partners, not Holgate.

A film review on July 4 about “Rescue Dawn,” written and directed by Werner Herzog, misspelled the title of another Herzog film with which “Rescue Dawn” was contrasted. It is “Fitzcarraldo,” not “Fizcarraldo.”.

An obituary on Tuesday about John R. Hogness, the first president of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, omitted some survivors. They include a brother, David S. Hogness of Palo Alto, Calif., and 10 grandchildren.

A headline and article yesterday about a Russian Orthodox Christian group’s patrols of a Moscow park to evict gay men who like to gather there incorrectly implied that the patrols were continuing. While they began in mid-June, the police stopped them on June 23, following a brawl at the park involving some of the group’s members.

An obituary on July 4, and in some copies on July 3, about the opera star Beverly Sills, misstated the name of a children’s radio show on which she made her debut at the age of 4, and referred incorrectly to the host. It was “Rainbow House,” not “Uncle Bob’s Rainbow House,” and Bob Emery, the host, was known as Big Brother Bob Emery, not Uncle Bob.

An article on Saturday about a surveillance video showing the killing of an inmate at the Souza-Baranowski maximum-security prison in Massachusetts in 2003 referred incorrectly to the prison. It is a state facility, not a federal one.

An article on July 4 about the quick condemnation by Muslim leaders in Britain of the recent attempted terror attacks there misstated the year of the terror attacks that Hassan Butts, the writer of a column denouncing violence, said had once inspired him to want to become a suicide bomber. The attacks were in July 2005, not 2007.

A headline and article yesterday about a Russian Orthodox Christian group’s patrols of a Moscow park to evict gay men who like to gather there incorrectly implied that the patrols were continuing. While they began in mid-June, the police stopped them on June 23, following a brawl at the park involving some of the group’s members.
AOL has agreed to make it easier for its remaining customers to leave as part of a $3 million settlement.
The apparel company Liz Claiborne said that it planned to cut 600 to 800 jobs and that it might sell 16 brands.
Yum Brands reported a 12 percent rise in quarterly net earnings and nudged up its profit forecast for the year.
Several Hollywood executives called for the end of the entertainment industry’s system of paying so-called residuals for the reuse of movie and television programs.
It is only summer league, but the Knicks are 2-0 and youngsters like Renaldo Balkman and Demetris Nichols are making Isiah Thomas, the coach and president, look good and feel good.

Britain, France and Ghana circulated a Security Council resolution authorizing the creation of a 26,000-member joint United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force of military and police personnel to replace the overwhelmed 7,000-person African Union force in the Darfur region of Sudan. Violence there, much of it committed by government-supported fighters, has cost more than 200,000 lives and driven 2.5 million people from their homes. The force, which the Sudanese government agreed to in June only after months of resistance, would be empowered to “use all necessary means” to protect itself and its facilities, to prevent violations of cease-fire agreements by armed groups and to “protect civilians under threat of physical violence.” Deployment would begin within 90 days of passage of the measure.

Rejecting recommendations by government prosecutors and lower courts, a Chilean Supreme Court judge has ruled that Alberto Fujimori, the former president of Peru, should not be extradited to his homeland. Mr. Fujimori was overthrown in 2000 and left exile in Japan to come to Chile in 2005. Peruvian courts have charged him with corruption, human rights violations and other crimes during the decade he was in power, but Judge Orlando Álvarez said they had not supplied sufficient proof. The Justice Minister, María Zavala, said, “We’ve lost the battle but not the war.” She predicted that the verdict would be overturned when an appeal reached the full Supreme Court.

The European Union will exclude medicine patent provisions from future trade deals with poorer countries to ease their access to cheaper drugs, the bloc’s executive commission announced in Strasbourg, France. The European Commission is responsible for negotiating trade agreements for the 27-nation Union. It was responding to a call from the European Parliament, which wants the bloc to do more to help poorer countries prevent the 12 million deaths each year from tropical diseases. Parliament members said a 1994 global trade agreement on intellectual property rights has restricted the development of affordable copycat treatments for poorer countries.

The former prime minister Dominique de Villepin may face charges for his part in a 2004 plot to smear Nicolas Sarkozy before Mr. Sarkozy won the presidency. The so-called Clearstream affair involved false documentation that listed Mr. Sarkozy, then Mr. de Villepin’s chief political rival, as the beneficiary of bribes paid to a secret bank account. Mr. de Villepin was called back from a vacation last week when investigators searched his Paris home and office. He has since issued a statement saying that he will answer investigators’ questions later this month and that he may be placed under official investigation.

A 2-year-old toddler was beheaded and chopped up in a slum in Nairobi, the capital, the police said. The killing occurred during a fierce crackdown on an illegal sect blamed for a string of murders and decapitations. The boy’s mutilated torso was discovered in a maize farm and his head 500 yards away at a river bank, the police said. The condition of the body raised speculation of a link to rites used by the politically linked Mungiki sect. The remains were discovered hours after the police said they had killed 12 people in a crackdown on organized crime gangs in Nairobi, including members of Mungiki.
If the Yankees are going to make a move this season, now would presumably be the time. And at some point, the top pitching prospect Phil Hughes could be part of that push.
Nearly two years later, going home to New Orleans is a receding dream for thousands of evacuees.
The hunt for those suspected of undermining former Surgeon General Richard H. Carmona was in full swing on Capitol Hill.
A White House report will cite satisfactory progress on some benchmarks but will  qualify other verdicts by saying it is too early to make final judgments.
For seven years, John P. Mackey, the co-founder of Whole Foods Market, had an online alter ego.
Vanderbilt University announced that E. Gordon Gee, its chancellor of seven years, would leave to become president of Ohio State University in Columbus for the second time.

A man who sued his dry cleaner for $54 million over a pair of missing pants is not giving up on his lawsuit. The man, Roy L. Pearson, has filed a motion asking a Superior Court judge in Washington to reconsider her verdict. Mr. Pearson, a District of Columbia administrative law judge, says the judge in his case failed to address his legal claims when she ruled that the cleaners did not violate a city consumer protection ordinance. Mr. Pearson claims the cleaners failed to live up to his expectations of a “Satisfaction Guaranteed” sign. The motion comes less than a week after the owners of the dry cleaning business asked the judge to order Mr. Pearson to pay $83,000 in legal fees.
The Popular Revolutionary Army, leftist rebels, took responsibility on Tuesday for the explosions that day and on July 5.

A stolen computer storage device had triple the number of taxpayers’ identifications than had been previously reported, Gov. Ted Strickland said, but he emphasized there was no indication the data had been compromised. The names and Social Security numbers of 561,126 people who had not cashed state income tax refund checks were on the device, according to a continuing review of the information it held. That brings the total number of taxpayers affected to more than 786,000, Mr. Strickland said. The device was stolen June 10 from an intern’s unlocked car.

Two Philadelphia City Council members sued the Pennsylvania legislature over its failure to pass gun-control legislation that would allow the city to curb an epidemic of gun violence. Pennsylvania’s cities are forbidden by state law from making their own gun laws. The Council members, Darrell L. Clarke and Donna Reed Miller, are seeking a court declaration that state lawmakers, by refusing to allow Philadelphia to pass its own gun ordinances, have failed to protect Philadelphians from illegal firearms, which have been linked to most of the 212 homicides in the city so far this year. A spokesman for the speaker of the Democratic-controlled State House declined to comment because he said he had not seen the lawsuit.
Minnesota Republicans have set Feb. 5 for their caucuses next year, joining voters in 17 other states in what is shaping up to be a national presidential primary.
Federal records suggest that China is not the only country that has problems with its exports.
The video is largely an echo of blame that some New York firefighters have long placed on former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for a number of circumstances related to Sept. 11.
In the wake of a two-day-long battle at Islamabad’s Red Mosque, which left more than 60 dead, the outlook for Pakistan’s embattled president remains uncertain.
Mrs. Johnson was a calm and steadying force for her often moody or volatile husband, President Lyndon B. Johnson.
China banned manufacturers from making toothpaste with diethylene glycol, a poisonous solvent used in some antifreeze, the state news agency, Xinhua, reported.
A consortium planning to buy the student loan giant Sallie Mae said that legislation aimed at reducing subsidies to lenders might harm the $25 billion deal.
Ventana Medical Systems said that its board had rejected an unsolicited $3 billion cash tender offer from the Swiss drug maker Roche Holding.
The United Parcel Service has embraced the latest methods to improve deliveries and air safety.
Seven Republican senators broke ranks with their party, but failed to muster enough votes to advance a plan to extend soldiers’ time home between overseas deployments.
Investigators set up a bogus company and bought materials that could be used in a so-called dirty bomb.
Four men were convicted Tuesday in the 2005 killing of an American anthropologist in Brazil’s northern jungle.
Ichiro Suzuki’s stylish play was the marquee moment in a game that had a familiar ending, with the American League edging the National League on Tuesday night.
Motorola’s troubles worsened on Wednesday when it announced that sales and profits would fall considerably short of earlier projections.
Senator John McCain of Arizona made a mobile phone call to his top fund-raisers from the Capitol, raising ethics questions.
Nintendo expects its popular Wii game machine will continue to be in short supply, while Sony said it is seeing increased PlayStation 3 sales after announcing a price cut.

A New Jersey Supreme Court justice should be censured because he created an appearance of impropriety when he interceded in a dispute between his son and a high school football teammate, a state panel said yesterday. The panel found that the justice, Roberto A. Rivera-Soto, 53, a Republican appointed by Gov. James E. McGreevey in 2004, violated judicial rules against using the prestige of his office to advance a private interest. His fellow Supreme Court justices must now decide whether to censure; take some other action, including suspension or removal; or decide that no punishment is warranted. Justice Rivera-Soto’s lawyer, Bruce P. McMoran, told The Star-Ledger of Newark that he was gratified because the committee found that his client did not intend any harm. The panel said Justice Rivera-Soto handed out his business cards to a police detective and contacted prosecutors and judges in Camden County to discuss the juvenile delinquency complaint he had filed.

A White Plains lawyer was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to one to three years in prison for stealing more than $500,000 from her aunt, prosecutors said. The lawyer, Shelly Ann Rivera, 40, represented her aunt in two real estate sales in 2005 and 2006, and on her behalf accepted proceeds of $480,000 and $522,248, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. But when asked to provide $860,000 to buy a property in Riverdale last October, Ms. Rivera fled to Las Vegas, prosecutors said. She was arrested there, and later pleaded guilty to grand larceny, prosecutors said, adding that Ms. Rivera was also ordered to pay $700,000 in restitution.

Bradley International Airport was shut down for about 40 minutes yesterday after security screeners found a grenade in a Utah man’s luggage. About 500 passengers and employees at one terminal were evacuated from the area between the curbside check-in and the ticket counters until the grenade was found to be fake, said John Wallace, an airport spokesman. The state police said the grenade appeared to be a dud military souvenir. Its owner, Harold S. Falslev, 78, of North Logan, Utah, was charged with breach of the peace.

Data released by two research firms shows that New York City’s foreclosure rates have risen more slowly than those in the rest of the nation. The number of foreclosure auctions in New York City increased 19 percent from the second quarter of 2006 through the second quarter of this year, according to data tracked by the research firm PropertyShark.com. These increases are far smaller than in Miami, where they rose 146 percent, and Los Angeles, where they jumped 202 percent, according to Ryan Slack, PropertyShark’s chief executive. Data released by RealtyTrac, a research company in Irvine, Calif., shows that filings in all stages of the foreclosure process were 42 percent higher last month than in June 2006 and that national rates rose 87 percent.

A 41-foot raft, made of reeds and wooden planks and flying the flags of several countries, set out yesterday on a two-month voyage to the Azores and Spain in an attempt to prove that Stone Age people could have crossed the Atlantic Ocean. The craft, the Abora III, named for a Canary Islands sun god, was towed from its berth at Liberty Landing Marina past the Statue of Liberty and south through New York Harbor, to be cut loose once it passed into the open sea. The captain, Dominique Görlitz, 41 — who has spent years preparing for the expedition — and a crew of 10 men and 2 women plan to land at Pontevedra, Spain. He estimated that the voyage would take five weeks. The group seemed unfazed by the prospect of crossing the Atlantic during hurricane season in a tiny craft with two wooden huts and a toilet shack on deck.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s medical bills from his April car crash could reach nearly $400,000, a spokeswoman for the governor said yesterday. The spokeswoman, Lilo H. Stainton, said that a state insurer had paid 31 bills totaling about $17,701 and that 24 bills for $63,000 should be paid by Friday, leaving an expected balance of about $300,000. She said the governor would reimburse the insurer from his personal accounts. Mr. Corzine suffered 15 broken bones, lost half the blood in his body and spent 18 days in the hospital after a crash on the Garden State Parkway. He was not wearing his seat belt.

Saying he had found himself voting against the Republicans on many issues, including education, health care and the minimum wage, Assemblyman Michael Spano, of Yonkers, announced yesterday that he had switched his party affiliation from Republican to Democrat. “This is where I belong,” he said. Mr. Spano’s switch changed the Democratic-Republican proportion in the Assembly to 109 to 41. Mr. Spano said he had not been promised, and did not expect, any committee chairmanships. Noting that his district, where Democrats outnumber Republicans 2 to 1, is heavily middle class, he said he believed that the national Republican Party “has basically lost its ability to communicate with the average American.” Mr. Spano’s switch puts him in a better position to run for mayor of Yonkers this year, as rumors have him planning to do.
To the Editor:.
The federal lawsuit says that adolescent girls were shackled and forced to eat and to use the bathroom while wearing the shackles.

A federal lawsuit filed yesterday accuses the Toys “R” Us toy store chain of singling out black customers in a pattern of race-based stops, searches and wrongful detentions. The suit, on behalf of people who say they believe they were unlawfully or unreasonably detained or searched because of their race, was filed in Federal District Court and seeks class-action status. It says policies put in place by Toys “R” Us have subjected blacks to unjustified and unwarranted scrutiny, and it seeks $400 million in damages as well as a court order to end discrimination. The retailer, based in Wayne, N.J., dismissed the allegations as “entirely ridiculous,” and said in a statement, “Toys ‘R’ Us respects all of the families who shop with us, and we do not tolerate discrimination of any kind.”.
Old Man is one of the many modest, white-collar gamblers at New York City’s illegal clubs.
With a Monday deadline looming for passage of his congestion pricing plan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg flew to Idaho Wednesday for a Sun Valley retreat.
Trying children as adults — except in isolated cases involving extreme violence — is both inhumane and counterproductive.
The News Corporation announced that its all-business news cable channel, to be called the Fox Business Network, will start on Oct. 15.
Citing a lack of evidence, an investigator recommended dropping all charges against an infantryman accused of murdering three Iraqis in Haditha in 2005.
To attract a younger customer, Bayer HealthCare is starting an online game for Aleve Liquid Gels, a product that was introduced in March.
City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher submitted Wednesday to a DNA test by investigators looking into allegations that he raped a woman at his district office in Queens.
For his 45 years in the booth, Mets announcer Ralph Kiner will be honored Saturday night against the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium.
General Electric will not go through with a deal to buy two Abbott Laboratories diagnostic units for $8.1 billion in cash, the two companies said.
While the San Antonio Spurs were winning their fourth N.B.A. championship last month, the Silver Stars were quietly coalescing into an elite group in the W.N.B.A.
The foiled terrorist attacks in Britain have prompted anxiety and soul searching in India, whose economy is bolstered by its citizens’ ability to work overseas.
As real estate elsewhere languishes, Manhattan property is still escalating in price, and that includes parking spots.
At least 14 Phillipine marines were killed late Tuesday in heavy fighting with suspected Abu Sayyaf on Basilan island, in the southern part of the country.

Gov. Charlie Crist said he did not expect serious opposition from utilities in Florida, where 28 percent of the electricity is produced by coal, a fuel that produces high levels of heat-trapping gases.
The Bush administration tried to turn Dr. Richard Carmona, former surgeon general, into a propagandist and political cheerleader.
It was heartbreaking to read the other day about the shooting of six young schoolgirls by armed rebels out to discredit the government in Afghanistan.
The president seized on the news as an opportunity to go on the offensive against Democrats for refusing to make permanent the tax cuts he said were working.
Researchers studied what happened when people who had not had insurance suddenly could have their health care paid for by the federal government.
When Mets Manager Willie Randolph takes the field Thursday with his right arm in a sling, it will not be the first time a New York manager has led his team in that condition.
The newly released recordings provide a fresh glimpse of the political Richard M. Nixon as the Watergate clouds were just beginning to form.
Several officials speculated that the robbers, who were guards at the bank, had connections to the militias, allowing them to escape without being searched.
John W. Snow, the chairman of the firm that is buying Chrysler, said that a bill to raise fuel economy standards could devastate the American auto industry.
Michael Bradley scored in the 107th minute, and the United States rallied past Uruguay, 2-1, last night to advance to the quarterfinals of the FIFA Under-20 World Cup in Toronto.
The Portland Trail Blazers have agreed on a buyout with guard Steve Francis, who was acquired in a draft-night deal with the Knicks.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted rules ensuring that it can sue hedge funds for misleading investors.
Genentech, the biotechnology company, posted a 41 percent increase in second-quarter profit on sales of its cancer drugs, continuing a positive earnings streak.
By coordinating care and keeping their patients out of the hospital, doctors can help reduce overall health care spending, Medicare officials said.
Officials said that they discovered a note scrawled on a wall in a campus building last month.
Brazil’s national amateur team hopes that a strong performance in the Pan American Games can help put baseball on the map in the country.
Flooding could become more severe in the Northeast if nothing is done to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, a report warned.
School and government officials believe that in teaming up, they can operate more efficiently and tap into higher interest rates on investments.
Officials predicted that a 20 percent rate cut in the state’s much-criticized workers’ compensation system would lead to the savings.
The Bush administration warned lawmakers not to raise the tax rate of private equity and hedge funds or their managers, maintaining that it would injure the economy.
Bucko Kilroy spent 64 years in the National Football League as an All-Pro lineman and was later celebrated as a personnel executive and scout.
ERIE, Pa., July 11 — A pizza deliveryman who was killed when a bomb around his neck detonated after he robbed a bank in 2003 had actually helped to plan the robbery, federal officials said Wednesday.
The Simon Wiesenthal Center has called on the Vatican to discipline a powerful Polish priest for making anti-Semitic comments.
An examiner reviewing the 2005 bankruptcy of Refco said that two law firms and two accounting firms could be sued in connection with the firm’s collapse.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey has stopped using e-mail in response to a lawsuit seeking e-mail messages he exchanged with the state union president who is also a former companion.

It’s rare that you can walk up to a major sporting event at the last minute and get tickets, but the British Open offers just that option. Because links golf courses are virtually treeless and so spread out, gallery space is not a problem. And thus, neither is ticket availability. Open crowds can approach 50,000 a day, and last year, at Royal Liverpool, 230,000 spectators turned out for the whole week, including practice rounds. For next week’s Open at Carnoustie, Scotland, you can still order tickets online or purchase them by walking up to the gate. Daily prices range from about $40 dollars on Monday through Wednesday to about $100 Thursday through Sunday. A weekly pass runs about $380. Parking costs $20 daily, or $80 for the week. Significant price breaks are available for spectators ages 16-21 and 65 and over. Travelers be forewarned, however. There’s precious little to do in Carnoustie besides watching the tournament. Most tourists stay near St. Andrew’s and make the 45-minute trip to Carnoustie for the golf.

Pedaling a mountain bike for 24 hours straight might sound like some strange form of torture. But the enduring race format, which involves solo and relay-team riders cranking as many laps as possible in 24 hours on a pre-marked course, is now celebrated at dozens of events around the country each summer. Two of the biggest -- the 24 Hours of 9 Mile in Wausau, Wis., and 24 Hours of Killington in Vermont -- take place the weekend of July 28. At the Killington race, part of a national series of six 24-hour races, riders pedal a 9.28-mile course that includes a thigh-killing 1,798 feet of elevation gain per lap. Team and solo riders pedal through the day and night, donning powerful bike lights once the sun sets to illuminate the twisting technical trail. Points are racked up with each completed lap. In Wisconsin, 24 Hours of 9 Mile is the national championship race for one of cycling’s strangest of subgenres. The solo winners will spin through more than 200 miles of knobby-tire riding, starting Saturday at 10 a.m. and not stopping until Sunday at the same time, when they finish, ragged, muddy, and zombie-like, but smiling from knowing they just pulled off the nearly impossible.

An article yesterday about a federal report on the collapse of a tunnel ceiling in Boston's Big Dig project misstated the role of Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff in choosing the epoxy that failed to hold the ceiling's anchor bolts in place. Bechtel, which was hired to oversee the project, reviewed specifications for the epoxy that were written by Gannett Fleming, Inc., a subcontractor; Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff did not write the specifications.

PAIGE--Marvin, 74 Renowned Restaurateur and Iconic New Yorker passed away at Roosevelt Hospital on the evening of July 4th. He was surrounded by family and friends. Marvin was a celebrated New York City restaurateur known for such places as Pal Joey's, Sniffen Court Inn, Boodles, The Tin Lizzie, Charlie's, Jose's, Hamburger Harry's, Chelsea Lobster Company, Max, and the famed Jazz club The 5-SPOT Jazz Gallery, a home base for such jazz greats as Thelonius Monk and Art Blakey. This was a combination of Marvin's passion for jazz and the restaurant business. He was a pioneer in Chelsea, opening the legendary Claire Restaurant in the early eighties, following the enormous success of Claire Key West. Both were designed by TonyAward winning Broadway set designer Robin Wagner and were of considerable importance in the gay community. He was a vibrant New Yorker, an icon known throughout the city for his graciousness, charm, wit, benevolence, and love of his community, as was evident by his generous support of a variety of causes such as God's Love We Deliver, of which he was a founding contributor. Marvin was also a beloved leader with SGI USA. He was deeply committed to Soka Gakkai International, as the practice based on the teachings of the Nichiren school of Mahayana Buddhism had transformed his life. He was famous for the best Key Lime Pie in the universe, a recipe that remains a family secret. He leaves behind an adoring son, Daniel and daughter-in-law Sue, his soul-mate Pat Vega and her loving family Suzanne, Ruby, Paul, Allison, Sachi, Brian, and Matthew. Marvin will be deeply missed as he touched and embraced so many lives. He was a man whose heart truly runneth over. A memorial service will be held on July 18th, 2007 at 6:30pm at the SGI New York Culture Center, 7 East 15th Street, New York, NY 10003. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to SGI USA and God's Love We Deliver.

Data released by two research firms shows that New York City's foreclosure rates have risen more slowly than those in the rest of the nation. The number of foreclosure auctions in New York City increased 19 percent from the second quarter of 2006 through the second quarter of this year, according to data tracked by the research firm PropertyShark.com. These increases are far smaller than in Miami, where they rose 146 percent, and Los Angeles, where they jumped 202 percent, according to Ryan Slack, PropertyShark's chief executive. Data released by RealtyTrac, a research company in Irvine, Calif., shows that filings in all stages of the foreclosure process were 42 percent higher last month than in June 2006 and that national rates rose 87 percent.

BUCKOLD--Werner. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of our past National President, Werner Buckold. He served us for many years in various leadership capacities and his demise represents a void which we can never refill. George W. Schaeffer, President BUCKOLD--Werner. Mr. Buckold emigrated to the United States from Germany in 1938 and immediately began work in the men's neckwear business, in which he remained active until his death Tuesday, July 10 at age 92. During World War II Mr. Buckold served three years with the U. S. Fifth Army in Italy. Active in B'nai Zion, a charitable organization that supports humanitarian projects in Israel and the United States, he was national president from 1990 to 1994. He was married 53 years to his beloved Ellen, and after her death, to his much loved Addie Sherr, who died in 2004. Werner was a man of optimistic, indomitable spirit, passionately interested in world events who nurtured old friendships and created new ones throughout his life. He was the glue in his family and he brought old world charm and dignity into the lives of all who knew him. He will be deeply missed by his daughters, Leslie Schweitzer-Miller and Emily Andelman, son-inlaw Robert Miller, stepson James Sherr, six grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, and hundreds of friends and family throughout the United States and Italy. Funeral Services will be held 10 am Friday, July 13 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Werner Buckold Memorial Fund, c/o Bnai Zion, 136 East 39th St., NY, NY, 10016.

SHICKMAN--Herman. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Herman Shickman, a treasured Benefactor. With his wife Lila, he was a generous donor of Old Master paintings and drawings, making possible the acquisition of Caravaggio's ''Denial of Saint Peter'' and giving a number of outstanding works in recent years, including Michiel Sweerts' ''Man Holding a Jug,'' Ingres' ''The Virgin Adoring the Host,'' and Bonvin's ''A Woman Spinning Flax.'' These remarkable works of art will inform and inspire visitors and scholars for generations to come. We extend condolences to Lila and to the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chrman Philippe de Montebello, Dir Emily K. Rafferty, President

To the Editor: I do not agree with your editorial regarding Dr. James Holsinger's nomination as surgeon general (''A Nominee's Abnormal Views,'' editorial, July 10). He is a talented physician who has proved throughout his impressive career in public service and education that he is dedicated to caring for all Americans.

In an unusually blunt session here on Wednesday, several of Hollywood's highest-ranking executives called for the end of the entertainment industry's decades-old system of paying so-called residuals for the reuse of movie and television programs after their initial showings. The executives stopped short of saying they would demand an immediate end to residuals in the coming, and most likely difficult, negotiations with writers, actors and directors. But they were emphatic in calling for the dismantling of a system under which specific payments are made when movies and programs are put on DVD, shown abroad or otherwise resold.

A 2-year-old toddler was beheaded and chopped up in a slum in Nairobi, the capital, the police said. The killing occurred during a fierce crackdown on an illegal sect blamed for a string of murders and decapitations. The boy's mutilated torso was discovered in a maize farm and his head 500 yards away at a river bank, the police said. The condition of the body raised speculation of a link to rites used by the politically linked Mungiki sect. The remains were discovered hours after the police said they had killed 12 people in a crackdown on organized crime gangs in Nairobi, including members of Mungiki.

WARD--F. Champion. The New School notes with sadness the July 2nd passing of Dr. F. Champion Ward, a former Chancellor of The New School and Acting Dean of its Graduate Faculty, past Dean of the College at the University of Chicago and former Ford Foundation Vice President. A distinguished innovator in higher education and an esteemed colleague, Dr. Ward was an influential proponent of The New Schools founding, interdisciplinary principles. His wise counsel and generosity of spirit left an enduring mark on our institution. The entire New School community expresses deep condolences to Dr. Ward's wife, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Philip Scaturro, Chair, Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President, The New School

KURIANSKY--Edward J., attorney and long time resident of New York City died at the age of 63 on Tuesday, July 10, 2007 in New York City. Mr. Kuriansky was Senior Managing Director of Citigate Global Intelligence, based in New York. Prior to joining Citigate Global, he was Commissioner of the New York City Department of Investigation under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. A former federal and state prosecutor, Mr. Kuriansky was prominent in the fields of investigations, intelligence and compliance for more than 37 years. He served as New York State's Deputy Attorney General and Special Prosecutor for Medicaid Fraud Control, and as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York. Mr. Kuriansky received a J.D. degree from Harvard Law School and graduated from Dartmouth College, where he was elected Phi Beta Kappa and accorded highest honors as a Rufus Choate Scholar. Following law school he served as a Law Clerk to Manhattan Federal Judge Morris E. Lasker. Mr. Kuriansky was born in Stamford, Connecticut and is the son of Julius and Isabelle Kuriansky. Survivors include Dr. Judith Kuriansky of New York City, Joan Kuriansky, of Washington, DC, Kim Master of New York City, and an extended circle of intimate friends and members of the Arthur and Kuriansky families. Funeral services will be held in Stamford, Connecticut at Congregation Agudath Shalom, 301 Strawberry Hill Ave. at 1:00 PM on Friday, July 13, 2007. Contributions in honor of Edward Kuriansky can be directed to funds that will be established in his memory at the Rogosin Institute for Medical Care and Research, New York City, the Hillel Center at Dartmouth College, or the Harvard Law School Edward Kuriansky Fund.

JACKS--Ronald A., a retired senior partner of the Chicago-based international law firm of Mayer, Brown Rowe and Maw, died July 6 in Auckland City Hospital in New Zealand. Mr. Jacks, 71, resided in Matapouri, NZ and Annapolis, MD. He was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in February. During his legal career, he was a trial attorney in the appellate section of the civil division of the U.S. Department of Justice; a special assistant to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy and chairman of the Attorney General's Honor Graduate Program; founding president of the Reinsurance Association of America; general counsel of the CNA Insurance Companies; a partner with Isham Lincoln & Beale; and head of the Insurance Practice Group at Mayer Brown until retiring in 1997. He continued to engage in international insurance and reinsurance arbitrations and mediations. An honor graduate of the University of Minnesota Law School, he was an editor of the Law Review and a member of the Order of the Coif. He served as a member of the American Bar Association's Standing Committee on Law and National Security and was chairman of the ABA's Committee on International Insurance and Reinsurance Law. He served as president of the U.S. Chapter of the International Association of Insurance Law (AIDA) and was a member of its worldwide Presidential Council. He was a founding member of ARIAS U.S. and a director emeritus. He also served on the Board of Governors at the University of Minnesota Law School. An avid yachtsman, Mr. Jacks enjoyed both long distance cruising and ocean racing, in the United States and abroad. He was member of several yacht clubs, including the Cruising Club of America. He is survived by his wife, Kathryn J. McIntyre; sons Brian Carter (Jeri) of Mundelein and Bradley Ward (Ampy) of Los Angeles; grandson Benjamin Carter of Mundelein and brothers Craig (Kathy) of Mound and Gary of St. Louis Park, both in Minnesota. Mr. Jacks was cremated in Auckland on July 7. A private memorial service will be held at his home New Zealand on July 13. A second memorial service will be held in Chicago at St. James Cathedral on August 14 at 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to City of Hope in Duarte, CA or North Haven Hospice in Tikipunga, NZ.

An article on July 4 about the quick condemnation by Muslim leaders in Britain of the recent attempted terror attacks there misstated the year of the terror attacks that Hassan Butts, the writer of a column denouncing violence, said had once inspired him to want to become a suicide bomber. The attacks were in July 2005, not 2007.
An article on Sunday about efforts by homeowners to battle beach erosion on Nantucket, Mass., misspelled the name of a company that operates a sand pit there. It is Holdgate Partners, not Holgate.

To the Editor: In ''Some Thoughts on Sickness After Seeing 'Sicko' '' (Editorial Observer, July 5), Philip M. Boffey wonders ''how common the abuses may be'' and points out that while the World Health Organization does rank the American health care system 37th, that is ''two notches above Cuba.''

Rejecting recommendations by government prosecutors and lower courts, a Chilean Supreme Court judge has ruled that Alberto Fujimori, the former president of Peru, should not be extradited to his homeland. Mr. Fujimori was overthrown in 2000 and left exile in Japan to come to Chile in 2005. Peruvian courts have charged him with corruption, human rights violations and other crimes during the decade he was in power, but Judge Orlando Álvarez said they had not supplied sufficient proof. The Justice Minister, María Zavala, said, ''We've lost the battle but not the war.'' She predicted that the verdict would be overturned when an appeal reached the full Supreme Court.

A headline and article yesterday about a Russian Orthodox Christian group's patrols of a Moscow park to evict gay men who like to gather there incorrectly implied that the patrols were continuing. While they began in mid-June, the police stopped them on June 23, following a brawl at the park involving some of the group's members.

Vanderbilt University announced that E. Gordon Gee, its chancellor of seven years, would leave Aug. 1, to become president of Ohio State University in Columbus for the second time. With earnings of about $1.2 million, Mr. Gee has been one of the highest paid university chiefs in the country. He has also held an unusual number of campus presidencies, having previously served as president of Brown University, the University of Colorado and West Virginia University, as well as Ohio State from 1990 to 1997. Officials at Vanderbilt, in Nashville, said Mr. Gee, 63, raised substantial money for the university and helped propel it forward. The university's board backed him last year in the face of criticism that he spent too lavishly.
