Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about increased delays at Kennedy International Airport paraphrased incorrectly a comment from JetBlue about discount carriers, which it said were particularly hurt by the delays. JetBlue said such airlines suffered because they do not sell full-fare tickets to help offset losses -- not because they ''do not discount fares.''

In 1966, when we first meet them, Petey Greene (Don Cheadle) and Dewey Hughes (Chiwetel Ejiofor) present an easy, obvious contrast. Dewey, rising fast in the management ranks of a Washington R&B radio station, favors trim suits and dark ties. When he speaks on the air, listeners are apt to mistake him for a white man. Petey, serving 10 years for armed robbery in a Virginia penitentiary, is a man of an altogether different -- and, to Dewey, much lesser -- sort. His speech is laced with profanities and put-downs, and he manages to look flashy even in prison, where he accessorizes his state-issued denims with bright red shoes and a flowery neckerchief. Their subsequent friendship, which spans an era of social upheaval and fashion turmoil, is at the center of ''Talk to Me,'' Kasi Lemmons's funny, earnest, affectionate new film. Ralph Waldo Greene, as Petey was called on his birth certificate, was a beloved figure in Washington's African-American community from the late 1960s until his death in 1984 of cancer. A radio D.J., nightclub comedian and television host, he put himself forward as a no-nonsense voice of the streets, a funny, sometimes angry mix of trickster, prophet and provocateur. As portrayed by Mr. Cheadle, Petey Greene is a person of quick wit and tender heart, an irrepressible hustler whose fundamental integrity is never in doubt.

An Israeli soldier was killed during a military incursion in the Gaza Strip, the first to be killed in combat since November 2006, an army spokesman said. Hamas claimed responsibility. On the West Bank, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian man at a checkpoint near Tulkarm. An army spokeswoman said that the man, a member of Islamic Jihad, got out of his car and opened fire on the soldiers first. Three pipe bombs were found in the car.

L'Oréal, the cosmetics maker, said second-quarter sales rose 10 percent on gains in Eastern Europe and Asia and a recovery in North America. Sales rose to 4.25 billion euros ($5.85 billion) from 3.85 billion euros a year earlier. L'Oréal, based in Paris, has expanded in emerging markets from Russia to Brazil to stoke growth as customers in those countries spend more money on cosmetics products. ''Our most dynamic category was skin care,which has a lot of added value,'' the chief executive, Jean-Paul Agon, above, said on a conference call.

A Queens man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 3 1/2 years in prison for conspiring to distribute millions of copies of counterfeit motion pictures, federal prosecutors said. The man, Rafael Gonzalez of Richmond Hill, and 20 other people had been charged with distributing millions of counterfeit movies around the world, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. He said Mr. Gonzalez operated a printing factory in the city that made packaging for pirated DVDs. Mr. Gonzalez pleaded guilty on Feb. 22 to charges of conspiracy to commit copyright infringement and trafficking in counterfeit labels, prosecutors said.

JAZZ IN JULY Since taking over as artistic director of the 92nd Street Y's Jazz in July series two years ago, Bill Charlap (above) has managed a smartly subtle renovation. Leaving intact the erudite yet welcoming tone established by Dick Hyman -- his esteemed predecessor, fellow pianist, former mentor and distant cousin -- Mr. Charlap has nudged the series gently but perceptibly toward effervescent modernity. His third season comprises a promising batch of concerts, beginning on Tuesday with a tribute to the music of Quincy Jones and Oliver Nelson, as performed by the venerable alto saxophonist Phil Woods and an eight-piece backing band. It's an unusual choice but a sensible one: during his apprenticeship years, Mr. Woods worked with both Mr. Jones and Mr. Nelson, in big bands unfairly remembered more for their crisp commercial appeal than for their artistic merit. And Mr. Woods probably didn't need to be coaxed into the idea. A few years ago he made an album called ''This Is How I Feel About Quincy'' (Jazzed Media), with Mr. Charlap on piano. At first glance it seems odd that Mr. Woods isn't also appearing on Thursday's concert, a tribute to Charlie Parker (his primary influence) and Dizzy Gillespie (another of his early employers). But that program, bearing the subhead ''Bebop Today,'' features musicians mostly born in the '60s, like the tenor saxophonist Eric Alexander, the alto saxophonist Jon Gordon and the trumpeter Jim Rotondi. And while the Jazz in July patronage still favors a more classic repertory -- Wednesday's concert, ''Cole Porter: All Through the Night,'' was the first in the series to sell out -- Mr. Charlap places admirable faith in the engaging spirit of the music. The second installment of Jazz in July, from July 24 to 26, will spotlight another bebop stalwart, the octogenarian saxophonist James Moody; a generation-spanning, Grammy-winning Latin-jazz ensemble led by the pianist Eddie Palmieri and the trumpeter Brian Lynch; and a piano-centric evening with Billy Taylor, Barbara Carroll and Eric Reed. Judging by the support Mr. Charlap has drummed up in past seasons, tickets will probably go fast. (Tuesday through Thursday at 8 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, 212-415-5500, 92y.org; $50.) NATE CHINEN

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo filed legal papers yesterday challenging the standards used by federal authorities to determine whether to extend the license of a nuclear reactor. Mr. Cuomo filed the papers in support of a legal challenge to the relicensing of the Indian Point nuclear plant in Westchester County by Andrew J. Spano, the county executive. The plant's owner, Entergy Nuclear, wants to extend the licenses of the plant's two active reactors for 20 years beyond their expiration dates of 2013 and 2015. Mr. Cuomo said federal regulators needed to evaluate more than the condition of the reactors before making a decision, and to consider factors like evacuation plans, the operator's performance and the risk of terrorism. An Entergy spokesman said those issues were already included in continuing regulatory oversight.

The Democrats have established a commanding and growing dominance over Republicans in securing contributions online, reshaping the fund-raising landscape heading into the 2008 elections. Online donations are emerging as a cornerstone of the fund-raising efforts of Senator Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards, who have raised roughly a third of their money through Internet contributions, mostly in small-dollar amounts. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been aggressive online as well. Their efforts have paid off with a rapidly growing army of small donors, many of whom have demonstrated a willingness to give again and again.

Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, kept repeating a certain word when he was asked about Bobby Abreu on Thursday night after Abreu had three hits and three runs batted in during a 7-3 victory against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. ''He's so important for us,'' Torre said. ''He knows he's important. He's really important.''

Although the welcome was warm for all the presidential candidates who spoke here Thursday at an N.A.A.C.P. forum, no one else was greeted with as much enthusiasm as Senator Barack Obama, whose mere presence on the stage shot adrenalin through the mostly African-American audience of thousands. Although this was not a debate -- the event was billed as a forum for ideas -- it was as if Mr. Obama, the only black candidate, enjoyed the home field advantage over the seven other Democrats and one Republican who had accepted invitations. And he performed as if he knew it.

A picture caption in The Arts on Wednesday with an article about the dancer Danny Tidwell misidentified the site of an international ballet competition where he was shown performing in 2002. It was Jackson, Miss., not Shanghai.

The European Court of Human Rights ordered Russia to pay damages to a Chechen man for the disappearance of his brother, who had been detained by Russian authorities in October 2000. The ruling, which blamed Russia for failing to make a record of the detention of Ayubkhan Magomadov, said that Russia had offered ''no plausible explanation as to what happened to him after his detention.'' Mr. Magomadov is presumed dead, one of thousands of people thought to have been killed by police and soldiers during the Chechen war that began in 1999.

The Vatican has named Edwin F. O'Brien, left, the archbishop for United States military services, to replace Cardinal William H. Keeler as head of the Archdiocese of Baltimore. The archdiocese is the oldest Roman Catholic see in the United States, with about half a million Catholics. Archbishop O'Brien, 68, served as a chaplain at West Point and later alongside troops in Vietnam. A native New Yorker who served for two decades in the New York archdiocese, he was often mentioned as a contender to head that archdiocese. In Baltimore, Archbishop O'Brien succeeds Cardinal Keeler, who served as archbishop there for nearly two decades. Cardinal Keeler, who is 76, had submitted his resignation, as required by the Vatican at age 75.

KAHN--Michele Davidow, 55, passed away on July 12 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital after stoically fighting lung cancer for more than two years. She was the beloved wife of Thomas Kahn for 35 years, loving devoted mother of Andrew, Elizabeth and Victoria, the cherished daughter of Sanford and Saundra Davidow and the adored sibling of Arline Shaffer and Harry Davidow. Michele received her BA from Beaver College and her MBA and MSW degrees from Columbia University. She later pursued her passion for the decorative arts through an MA from the Cooper Hewitt division of the Parsons School of Design. Captivated by the designs of Louis Comfort Tiffany, Michele worked on the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Tiffany show entitled Laurelton Hall and a traveling exhibition of Tiffany objects. She lectured at Sotheby's and the Smithsonian on this subject. As a longtime resident of NYC, she savored the vibrancy and culture of the metropolis, while balancing this passion with a love of literature and foreign exploration. With her husband, Tom, and friends she attended concerts, operas and theatre throughout the year. She also loved adventure. From her early travels to Argentina and Eastern Europe to her more recent voyages to China, Russia and Australia. Michele had bright eyes for new places and their arts. A devoted philanthropist, she supported the arts, education and lung cancer research. Michele was stylish, vivacious and deeply intellectual and carried a sharp wit wherever she went. She loved to entertain and delight her family and friends with a good story, and fabulous cooking and baking. Her indomitable spirit will always be with us. The family funeral is at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn on July 13 at 11am. The family will be sitting Shiva at 25 Central Park West, Saturday, Sunday and Monday from 6-9pm. A Memorial Service will be planned for early fall. KAHN--Michele. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Michele Kahn. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, Pres. Robert A. Calinoff, Sec. KAHN--Michele. We mourn with deep sorrow and a profound sense of loss the passing of our dear friend, Michele. She has been an intelligent, passionate, caring, generous and humorous member of our group of friends for many years and we will miss her terribly. Our hearts go out to Tom, Andy, Elizabeth, Vicky, her parents, sister, brother and the rest of this warm and loving family. The families: Felderman, Herzeca, Knight-Greenfield, Komisar, Powell-Prescott, Rabinowitz, Temel KAHN--Michele. JBI International, formerly the Jewish Braille Institute, is profoundly saddened by the passing of Michele Kahn, wife of longtime Trustee and Officer, Thomas G. Kahn. Our heartfelt thoughts and condolences are with the family during this time of sorrow. We are certain that Michele's memory will endure as a continuing blessing and inspiration for her entire family. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman Barbara B. Friedman, Honorary Chairman Dr. Ellen Isler, President

Cecilia Sarkozy, the wife of France's new president, Nicolas Sarkozy, visited five Bulgarian nurses in Tripoli, Libya, who have been sentenced to death for infecting more than 400 children with H.I.V. Mr. Sarkozy told reporters in Épinal, France, that she would meet with the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Thursday night. On Wednesday, Libya's Supreme Court upheld the death sentences, although an independent investigation has found that the infections were caused by unsanitary conditions. In Benghazi, where she met with families of the children, Ms. Sarkozy said that her visit was ''not official'' but that she had been sent ''as a mother,'' Agence France-Presse reported.

WILD ARTS WEEKEND A show titled ''I'm Chewing Cud'' may not sound like a big New York hit, unless Broadway suddenly takes a decidedly bovine turn. But there's at least one stage where it's destined for success: that of the Wildlife Theater Players at the Prospect Park Zoo, who will, well, milk the life of Aggie, the zoo's cow, for all its dramatic potential. This brief, tuneful production will be just one of the highlights of the zoo's first Wild Arts Weekend, a celebration of how animals inspire human creativity. ''It's a great way to connect people in the community with conservation,'' said Karen Tingley, the zoo's curator of education. ''We were able to bring in artists from all over Brooklyn.'' The author Darrin Lunde will visit with the illustrator Patricia J. Wynne to sign copies of their new books, ''Meet the Meerkat'' and ''Hello, Bumblebee Bat.'' ''Darrin will also make meerkat puppets with the kids, and Pat is going to do drawing demonstrations,'' Ms. Tingley said. The literary world will be further represented by the members of the writers' group Pen & Rose, who will read from and sign ''Tales With Tails,'' their collection of children's stories about creatures like the red panda and the white rhinoceros.

To the Editor: ''Politics and the Yuan'' (editorial, July 7) continues the debate over China's manipulation of its currency and contends that there is no guarantee that a rise in the value of the yuan would boost American workers' wages. There is a related issue, however, that if properly acted on would surely boost American workers' wages but that has not been raised in this debate: China's continued outlawing of a free labor movement.

Almost half a million people have been evacuated from a flood zone along the banks the Huai River in central China, as heavy rain caused the river to rise to its highest level in years, state media said. The evacuations took place in Anhui, left, Jiangsu and Henan Provinces, where several cities and transportation arteries risked inundation. Water from the Huai has been diverted to nearby rivers, but levels remain dangerously high, the official Xinhua news agency reported. Flooding in southern China has killed 360 people so far this summer, according to official reports.

President Bush's nominee to become surgeon general has been criticized by gay rights groups for writing a report in 1991 for the Methodist Church that characterized gay sex as unnatural and unhealthy. Partial minutes of the church committee that called for the report show that many of the criticisms leveled at the report in recent weeks were echoed by committee members at the time.

To the Editor: ''A Deal for the Public: If You Win, You Lose,'' by Adam Liptak (Sidebar column, July 9), provided timely coverage of a disturbing trend in which some state attorneys general hire private-sector personal injury lawyers on a contingency-fee basis to sue various industries or individual companies. It pointed out that taxpayers may pay either way, regardless of litigation outcomes.

Six Lebanese soldiers were killed in fighting with militants inspired by Al Qaeda holed up in a Palestinian refugee camp in north Lebanon. In nearly eight weeks of fighting between the army and Fatah al Islam in and around the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, 178 people have been killed, including 90 soldiers and at least 68 militants.

Two 17-year-old men were fatally shot yesterday in two separate attacks, one in the Bronx and another in Brooklyn, the police said. One of the victims, Victor Maldonado of Flushing, was found shot in the head at 1404 Edwards Avenue in the Bronx shortly before 3 p.m., the police said. He was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he later died. The other man, whose identity has not been released pending family notification, was shot in the abdomen about 6:30 p.m. at 2955 West 29th Street in Coney Island, the police said. He was taken to Coney Island Hospital, where he later died. There have been no arrests in either shooting.

BASTILLE DAY Tomorrow is Bastille Day, when French nationals and Francophiles all the world over commemorate the storming of the Bastille in 1789. In addition to the celebratory dinners taking place this weekend at bistros and brasseries, there are also a slew of street festivals, parties and tournaments. Depending on how much you love wine, cheese and croissants, you could potentially visit them all, starting tomorrow with the Les Halles Waiters Race. Competitors run two and a half blocks holding a tray with a half-full glass and an open bottle of water. The server who reaches the finish line first without spilling wins the race, if not a tip. In the evening, there's the Bastille Day Ball at Spotlight Live. Joe Battaglia and the New York Big Band will perform, and a D.J. will spin French electronica. On Sunday there are two festivals. Uptown, organizations including the French Institute-Alliance Française take over 60th Street, between Fifth and Lexington Avenues, for their annual fête; this year, said Robin Massee, an organizer, ''we're trying to highlight different parts of France.'' There will be booths for the cuisine of the Brittany and Alsace regions (crepes and Kougelhopf cake, respectively), as well as rum from Martinique. Can-can dancers (shown above), French bands and D.J.'s will perform; in honor of the Tour de France, there will be a stationary-bike race.

A REFORMER BETRAYS HIS CAUSE Zheng Xiaoyu, the Chinese bureaucrat who was executed Tuesday for accepting bribes from drug companies, began his career as a reformer seeking to make China's drug supply safer. His rise and fall, documented in a confession he wrote in prison, offers a glimpse inside China's flawed regulatory system. Responding to the outcry over dangerous imports from China and other unsafe toys, the head of the Consumer Product Safety Commission is preparing regulatory proposals that could mandate broader inspections of imports and stiffer penalties for ignoring safety rules. [A12.]

The family of Nicole Brown Simpson is seeking a share of the rights to the O. J. Simpson book ''If I Did It'' that could be awarded solely to the estate of Mrs. Simpson's friend, Ron Goldman, under a proposed federal bankruptcy settlement, The Associated Press reported. Mrs. Simpson, the ex-wife of O. J. Simpson, left, and Mr. Goldman were killed in 1994. Judge A. Jay Cristol said at a hearing on Wednesday in Miami that he would put off approval of the settlement to allow more time to sort out all the issues in the matter.
AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites

Another toddler was kidnapped by gunmen in the volatile Niger Delta region, the fourth child in less than two months. A 3-year-old boy was seized from his father's sport utility vehicle on his way to nursery school, the Nigerian police said. Kidnappings of foreign oil workers have been on the rise in the Niger Delta as militants press for a greater share of the country's oil wealth, but criminal gangs are suspected in these cases.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer has extended for one year, to Aug. 14, 2008, the period in which anyone who worked or volunteered at ground zero after Sept. 11 can register with the State Workers' Compensation Board, even if the person is well. Most workers' compensation claims must be filed within two years of an accident or injury. But because some illnesses take many years to develop, state laws give ground zero workers and volunteers the chance to register with the board to preserve their right to file claims if they become ill in the future. Joel Shufro, executive director of the New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health, said that as many as 60,000 workers and volunteers might have pitched in to help at the disaster site, but that only about 20,000 have registered. Registration forms are available at the Web sites of the Workers' Compensation Board, www.wcb.state.ny.us/, and the Committee for Occupational Safety and Health, www.nycosh.org/.

SUSAN MARSHALL No fool she, Susan Marshall has chosen to make her debut choreographing in the round in Bard College's Spiegeltent; you have to really make an effort to look bad inside these fabulous Belle Époque oddities, surrounded by velvet canopies, columns and beveled mirrors (oh my!). Just ask Marlene Dietrich, who sang in one of these Old World pavilions in the 1930s. Not that Ms. Marshall, a veteran choreographer coming off the 20th season of Susan Marshall & Company, should need that much help with this Fisher Center commission. Her last work, ''Cloudless,'' above, a sublime series of vignettes, wowed audiences with its deft snapshots of human nature and wonderful gestural language, winning her a Bessie. The material itself, as strange as it was emotionally resonant, was top-notch. But it was the dancers who brought it to marvelous life, so it's happy news indeed to hear that the same performers will be featured in this new, site-specific work. Like ''Cloudless,'' it will be structured as a series of discrete but interconnected dance-theater snapshots. But given the setting, expect plenty of nods to burlesque, cabaret and vaudeville. And let's not forget the Spiegeltent menu, complete with homemade desserts and local wines. (Tomorrow at 3:30 and 8:30 p.m. and Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., 845-758-7900, fishercenter.bard.edu; $35.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

Campaigns' financial reports are due to the Federal Election Commission tomorrow, but early-bird filers get not only the weekend off but also lots of weekend coverage and analysis of their spending. Along with an overall decline in campaign cash from the first quarter to the second, Mitt Romney, a Republican, saw a drop in donations from Massachusetts and Utah, suggesting that he has "tapped out the network of rich Mormons and wealthy financiers that drove him to lead other Republican candidates in the first reporting cycle," report Ross Buettner and David D. Kirkpatrick in The Times.

An appeals court upheld the conviction and 30-month sentence of former Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta. Mr. Campbell was appealing his sentence for tax fraud on the basis that it was too long. His lawyers also argued at his June 8 hearing before the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit that his Sixth Amendment rights were violated because he was not allowed to have the counsel of his choice at trial. Mawuli Davis, one of Mr. Campbell’s lawyers, said he was disappointed. But, Mr. Davis said, “we’re prepared to continue to fight.” During the proceedings leading to Mr. Campbell’s trial, he tried to hire Craig Gillen, an Atlanta lawyer, but the government opposed the move because Mr. Gillen’s law partner represented one of Mr. Campbell’s co-defendants in the federal corruption case that focused on members of his administration.
“Captivity” the movie has been thoroughly eclipsed by “Captivity” the marketing.
Representatives of first families stretching back half a century came to pay condolences at the funeral of Lady Bird Johnson.
Linus Gerdemann, riding in his first Tour de France, won the seventh stage today to take the yellow jersey.
President Vladimir V. Putin announced today that Russia would suspend its obligations under a cornerstone cold war-era arms limitation treaty.

Funny Cide, the 2003 Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, was retired yesterday, nine days after winning the $100,000 Wadsworth Memorial at Finger Lakes. Jack Knowlton, of Sackatoga Stable, the group that owns the horse, said Funny Cide was healthy.“He came in a winner and goes out a winner and he accomplished a lot in between,” Knowlton said. “We want to give him an opportunity to enjoy his retirement.”.
The Yankees could not overcome the least effective outing of the season for Roger Clemens and continued their season-long struggle to hit left-handed pitching in a loss to the Devil Rays.
John Maine, the Mets’ most consistent pitcher this season, put the first three runners on base and then allowed a grand slam as the Mets fell behind early and lost to the Reds.

The Energy Department proposed $3.3 million in fines against managers of the Los Alamos nuclear weapons laboratory because of a security breakdown in which classified documents were found in a trailer-park drug raid in northern New Mexico. The bulk of the civil penalties, $3 million, was levied against the University of California, the longtime former manager of the laboratory. The penalties were the largest such fines the department has ever imposed. The enforcement action stems from an incident in October 2006, when the police found more than 1,000 pages of classified documents and several computer storage devices in a trailer occupied by a former worker at the laboratory. The papers were found during a police drug raid that focused on another person living in the trailer.

A pain-management doctor who prescribed large amounts of opiates to patients at his clinic in McLean was sentenced to nearly five years in prison. Prosecutors had sought a life term for the doctor, William E. Hurwitz, 61, who was convicted in April on 16 counts of drug trafficking. The authorities claimed Dr. Hurwitz crossed the line from doctor to drug dealer with his high-dose treatments.

Louisiana became the first state to outlaw the late-term procedure it calls partial-birth abortion, when Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco signed legislation allowing doctors to be prosecuted for performing it. The new law allows the procedure in only one situation: when failure to perform it would endanger the pregnant woman’s life. Ms. Blanco, a Democrat, signed two bills that create criminal penalties for doctors who perform the surgery: fines of $1,000 to $10,000, and jail terms of one to 10 years. The statute is parallel to the federal ban that President Bush signed into law in 2003 and that was upheld by the Supreme Court in April.

A truck driver was arrested Thursday and charged with criminal homicide in the death of an Ashland City woman, and the police said he confessed to killing five other people — a Nashville woman; women in Indianapolis and Lake Station, Ind.; a woman in Suwanee, Ga.; and a person in Birmingham, Ala. The man, Bruce Mendenhall, 56, once ran unsuccessfully for mayor of Albion, Ill., where he lives. He was arrested in connection with the death of Sara Hulbert, 25, who was found fatally shot two weeks ago at the same truck stop where Mr. Mendenhall was arrested.

The Senate confirmed Pete Geren to be secretary of the Army, four months after his predecessor, Francis J. Harvey, resigned amid outrage over conditions at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Mr. Geren, left, who served as an assistant to Donald H. Rumsfeld when he was defense secretary, has been serving as acting secretary since March. He won confirmation as Democrats in Congress pushed for a troop withdrawal from Iraq and some Republicans defected from President Bush and his war strategy. Mr. Geren served as a Democratic congressman from Fort Worth from 1989 to 1997. He was nominated to become Army secretary in May.

Vang Pao, a former Laotian general accused of being the ringleader in a plot to overthrow the communist government of Laos, was freed on bail in Sacramento. Federal Magistrate Dale Drozd ordered Gen. Vang Pao, who is 77 and a leader of Hmongs in the United States, released on a $1.5 million bond after relatives agreed to post four properties in Sacramento, Fresno and Westminster, Calif., as collateral. Several hundred people gathered outside the courthouse cheered as the general walked out. “We’re just happy he’s released, and I’m sure the Hmong community is happy,” said John Balazs, Gen. Vang Pao’s lawyer. Gen. Vang Pao and 10 other men are accused of planning to buy nearly $10 million worth of machine guns, antiaircraft missiles, rocket-propelled grenades, mines and other weapons to topple the government in Vientiane, the capital of Laos.

A Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday for a walking tour of Revolutionary and Civil War Manhattan sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours misstated the telephone number for reservations and information. It is (212) 465-3331.

An article in the Square Feet section of Business Day on Wednesday about an office and retail development in the Bronx referred incorrectly to a neighborhood where another shopping complex, the River Plaza, is situated. River Plaza is partly in the Bronx and partly in Marble Hill, which is in Manhattan — not in the Bronx.

An article in the Square Feet section of Business Day on Wednesday about an office and retail development in the Bronx referred incorrectly to a neighborhood where another shopping complex, the River Plaza, is situated. River Plaza is partly in the Bronx and partly in Marble Hill, which is in Manhattan — not in the Bronx.

A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a film review of “My Best Friend” reversed the descriptions of the two characters in the photograph. The character played by Daniel Auteuil is the middle-aged misfit and the one played by Dany Boon is his tutor in friendship.
A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about “Gypsy” at City Center misstated the opening date. It is tonight, not Tuesday.
When the Nets re-signed Vince Carter, their best offensive player, to a four-year, $61.8 million deal, they celebrated as if Michael Jordan had just landed in East Rutherford.

NEWARK, July 13 — Since a companion of former Mayor Sharpe James bought nine parcels of city-owned land at below-market rates and quickly resold them at huge profits, at least three of the houses have been gutted by fires. At least two have gone through foreclosures.

The French luxury goods giant Louis Vuitton has ended its sponsorship of the America’s Cup after 24 years because of concerns that the event has become too commercial. The chief operating officer of America’s Cup Management, Michel Hodara, called the criticism an exaggeration.

Anschutz Entertainment Group has reached a preliminary agreement to sell its stake in the Chicago Fire to the Los Angeles-based Andell Holdings. Financial terms were not disclosed. In January, Anschutz sold another team, D.C. United, for a Major League Soccer-record $33 million.

Igor Andreev upset the defending champion Richard Gasquet, 7-5, 6-2, at the Swiss Open in Gstaad to reach his first semifinal of the season. Andreev will face Andreas Seppi, who defeated Martin Vassalla Arguello, 6-4, 6-0. In the other semifinal, Paul-Henri Mathieu, who defeated Gaël Monfils, 6-1, 4-6, 6-3, will play Radek Stepanek, who beat sixth-seeded Marc Gicquel, 6-3, 6-3.

Fresh off her fourth Wimbledon title, Venus Williams will face Nadia Petrova today in the singles opener of the Fed Cup semifinal between Russia and the United States at Stowe, Vt. Also today, Vania King of the United States plays Anna Chakvetadze. Tomorrow, Williams plays Chakvetadze and King will face Petrova in singles before King and Lisa Raymond play Petrova and Elena Vesnina in doubles.

Ronny Thompson, the younger son of the Hall of Fame coach John Thompson, resigned yesterday as basketball coach at Ball State, citing concerns about the university’s internal investigation into suspected violations of N.C.A.A. rules. Ball State was 9-22 last season. The university has said Thompson and his staff broke N.C.A.A. rules by attending voluntary off-season team workouts and lying about their involvement.
The men’s basketball teams in the Big East Conference will play an expanded 18-game schedule in 2007-8. The Big East has not played an 18-game conference schedule since 1998-99.

Argentina striker Hernan Crespo has been cleared to play in tomorrow’s Copa América final against Brazil. Crespo sprained a thigh muscle in Argentina’s second game at the tournament. He had three goals before his injury.

Gordon Gee, the new president at Ohio State University, told reporters that college athletics had to be fixed at the national level and that he would have “zero tolerance” for player misbehavior at Ohio State. When he was chancellor at Vanderbilt, Gee disbanded the athletic department because he contended sports had become too separate from the rest of the university. He said yesterday that he did not believe the approach would work at Ohio State, but added, “It’s very important for us to set a very high standard for ourselves.”.
A handwritten journal detailed a planned terrorist attack on a Suffolk County high school with a “hit list” of specific students.

The Memphis Grizzlies signed forward-center Darko Milicic, the No. 2 overall pick in the 2003 draft. Terms were not disclosed. Milicic averaged 8 points and 5.5 rebounds last season for the Orlando Magic, which allowed him to leave to clear room for Rashard Lewis’s signing.
Horse Racing.
A political dispute in Albany has cut off a critical source of low-cost financing for nonprofit organizations in New York City.
Johnny Damon said that he enjoyed playing so close to home so much he might want to finish his career with the Devil Rays.
Human rights activists accused organizers of a Pan-African music festival of mistreating a group of pygmy musicians by housing them in tents at the city zoo.
A judge in Brazil issued a warrant for Boris Berezovsky in a money-laundering case involving the soccer club Corinthians.
A Nigerian toddler abducted on his way to nursery school in the oil-rich south was returned safely.

A legal rights promoter who fought forced evictions in Shanghai and was jailed for two years died shortly after being released on medical parole, said Human Rights in China, a group in New York. The authorities in Shanghai had rejected requests by the family of the promoter, Chen Xiaoming, to release him early on the ground that he had a chronic illness. Mr. Chen, who was jailed for “disturbing order in court,” died of a hemorrhage after being moved to a civilian hospital on July 1, the group said.
United Nations peacekeepers in Congo are under investigation on charges of exchanging food for gold with members of militias from neighboring Rwanda.

The United Nations investigation of the 2005 killing of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri has identified a number of people possibly involved, but Lebanon’s worsening situation has made it difficult to gain cooperation from witnesses and recruit staff members, the inquiry’s chief, Serge Brammertz, said in a report to the Security Council. He said his commission had discovered many “commonalities” between the killing and 17 political attacks.
The bill appeared to be a last-ditch effort to pass a plan by Monday, which federal officials have said is the deadline for a plan to be eligible for federal financing.

Significant drops in Massachusetts and Utah seem to suggest that he has tapped out his network of rich Mormons and wealthy financiers.

Alex Rios had three hits and drove in the go-ahead run as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-5, last night.
Former Newark Mayor Sharpe James is seen as both a protector and a profiteer; whether he is convicted of fraud depends on which description seems more convincing.
The indictment against Sharpe James, the former mayor of Newark, is stunning most of all for the list of luxuries he allegedly charged to taxpayers of his impoverished city.

Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter, finished second before a cheering crowd in Olympic Stadium in Rome, trailing only Stefano Braciola, who won in 46.72 seconds.

KAHN--Michele Davidow, 55, passed away on July 12 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital after stoically fighting lung cancer for more than two years. She was the beloved wife of Thomas Kahn for 35 years, loving devoted mother of Andrew, Elizabeth and Victoria, the cherished daughter of Sanford and Saundra Davidow and the adored sibling of Arline Shaffer and Harry Davidow. Michele received her BA from Beaver College and her MBA and MSW degrees from Columbia University. She later pursued her passion for the decorative arts through an MA from the Cooper Hewitt division of the Parsons School of Design. Captivated by the designs of Louis Comfort Tiffany, Michele worked on the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Tiffany show entitled Laurelton Hall and a traveling exhibition of Tiffany objects. She lectured at Sotheby's and the Smithsonian on this subject. As a longtime resident of NYC, she savored the vibrancy and culture of the metropolis, while balancing this passion with a love of literature and foreign exploration. With her husband, Tom, and friends she attended concerts, operas and theatre throughout the year. She also loved adventure. From her early travels to Argentina and Eastern Europe to her more recent voyages to China, Russia and Australia. Michele had bright eyes for new places and their arts. A devoted philanthropist, she supported the arts, education and lung cancer research. Michele was stylish, vivacious and deeply intellectual and carried a sharp wit wherever she went. She loved to entertain and delight her family and friends with a good story, and fabulous cooking and baking. Her indomitable spirit will always be with us. The family funeral is at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn on July 13 at 11am. The family will be sitting Shiva at 25 Central Park West, Saturday, Sunday and Monday from 6-9pm. A Memorial Service will be planned for early fall. $(6$)KAHN--Michele. We record with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Michele Kahn. We send our sincere condolences to her husband Thomas, children Andrew, Elizabeth and Victoria and the entire family in their time of sorrow. Her many years of friendship and kindness will be remembered. Philip Laskawy, President Robin Carlin, Secretary Quaker Ridge Golf Club $(6$)KAHN--Michele. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff note with sadness the passing of Michele Kahn, wife of our esteemed Board member, Thomas Kahn. We express our sincere condolences. The Ackerman Institute for the Family $(6$)KAHN--Michele. We honor the memory of our dear friend Michele. Our prayers are with her family in their time of sorrow. -The Golds $(6$)KAHN--Michele. We Will Miss You -Fussie Cookie!! A longtime friend of our family who was always integral to the time we spent with her; may it be on vacation, in Bermuda, significant family occasions and many other times. Our thoughts are with the entire Kahn Family and remember that ''Time Takes All But Memories''. Susan, Jim and Hannah Baumann

The smuggling was reported to have taken place on Congo's eastern border, about a thousand miles from the capital, Kinshasa. An investigation of Pakistani soldiers turned up evidence of gold smuggling by one person, he said.

PETERSON--Raymond J., 88, Trustee of The Hearst Family Trust, Board Member of Hearst Corporation and longtime Hearst Magazines executive, passed away on Wednesday, July 11, 2007 in Palm Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 17, 2007 at 4pm at St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue, New York City. Immediately following, a reception will be held from 5:30-7 pm on the 44th floor of Hearst Tower (300 West 57th Street, New York City). In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Lourdes-Noreen McKeen Residences, 315 South Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33401. Please send checks to the attention of: Sister Mary Anne Dennehy. Phone: 561-650-8947.

KOBACKER--Arthur J., age 83, formerly of Columbus, died at his residence in Boca Raton, FL, on the 12th of July 2007. He was a graduate of the Columbus Academy (1941) and Yale University (1945) and served as a Lt. JG in the US Navy during World War II. Art incorporated the Kobacker Shoe Company and, in 1960, opened his first shoe store. The business grew to 700 self-service shoe stores in 32 states. In Columbus, he was the recipient of many honorary degrees and awards including Humanitarian awards from Temple Israel, Sertoma, Ronald McDonald House, and Columbus Education Association, and was honored by Junior Achievement Business Hall of Fame, US Peace Corps Partners for Peace Award, and the Columbus Foundation. He was the President of Children's Hospital, a member of the Young Presidents Organization and the Advisory Council for Israeli-Palestinian Peace. For many years, Art was passionately interested and active in the economic issues of African communities, and worked to help develop and implement programs to assist African peoples in achieving prosperity and health. He was also a former Trustee of the Ohio Humanities Council, Columbus College of Art and Design, Life Care Alliance, Heritage House, United Way of Franklin County, Council for Ethics in Economics, Governor's Commission on Educational Choice, Columbus Museum of Art, Boy Scouts of America, Columbus Chamber of Commerce, Affordable Health Council, Private Industry Council of Franklin County, Franklin University, Columbus Academy, Temple Israel, American Red Cross of Jefferson County, and the American Cancer Society. In Florida, he was a Trustee of the Urban League of Palm Beach County and the United Way of Palm Beach County. He also served on the Board of the National Foundation of Alternative Medicine. Art was a former Director of the Lionel Corporation and CoFounder of Dollars for Scholars in Steubenville, OH. In 1997, Art and Sara Jo, his wife, donated to the United Way of Palm Beach County, FL, the largest gift in its history. Art, Sara Jo, their son Alfred, and Niki Kobacker made a substantial gift to Hospice at Riverside Hospital and as a result, a state-of-the-art residential hospice facility was built and named Kobacker House. The Kobacker Company participated in the Adopt - A - School program with an inner-city elementary school in Columbus. Mr. Kobacker's gift to ''I Know I Can'' helped ensure that no Columbus High School graduate would be prevented from going to college due to a lack of funds. Art was married to Sara Jo Borisky 58 years ago and they have a daughter, Peggy Kobacker (David) Shiffrin, of Washington, DC, a son, Alfred J. Kobacker, II, of Columbus, OH; grandchildren Aronson and Miriam Kobacker and Laura and Carrie Shiffrin; a brother James (Barbara) Kobacker. Art is also survived by his dear friend Roy Pollard, Jr. He was preceded in death by his parents, Alfred and Ida Kobacker, and his sister, Regina (''Genee'') Kobacker Fadiman. Family will receive friends from 4 to 7 pm, on Sunday July 15, 2007 at the Schoedinger Midtown Chapel, 229 E. State St., Columbus, OH. Funeral service will be Monday, July 16, 2007 at 10 am at Temple Israel, 5419 East Broad St., Columbus, OH. Rabbi Emily Rosenzweig officiating. Interment at Green Lawn Cemetery in Columbus. Contributions in his memory may be made to Village Academy, 400 SW 12th Ave., Delray Beach, FL 33444, ''I Know I Can'', 20 Governor's Place, Columbus, OH 43203, and the Religious Action Center, 2027 Massachusetts Ave. NW, at Kivie Kaplan Way, Washington, DC 20036.

GERINGER--Eleanore N. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her husband Harold, and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President $(6$)GERINGER--Eleanore (nee Nissen), passed away peacefully on July 13, 2007 at the age of 75, after battling Lung Cancer and Parkinson's Disease. Eleanore had a very fruitful and productive life, teaching English at the Bronx High School of Science, was an active participant in community affairs, including at the Park Avenue Synagogue and most importantly, as a loving and dedicated wife, mother and grandmother. She will be deeply missed by her family. Eleanore is survived by her devoted husband Harold, with whom she recently celebrated their 53 Wedding anniversary, and her children, Geoffrey, Laura and her husband Fred, and Elizabeth and her husband Gary. Eleanore is also survived by her adoring grandchildren, Benjamin, Alyson, Rachel and Spencer. The funeral service will be held on Sunday July 15 at 11am at the Plaza Community Chapel, on 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.
ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila

The emergency Palestinian government led by Salam Fayyad stepped down Friday night to be replaced by a caretaker Palestinian government led by -- Salam Fayyad. The new government is the same as the old one, with a few additional ministers. But it will have an indefinite mandate so long as the current Palestinian parliament is unable to form a quorum.
POWELL--Ann B., on your birthday, remembered with love and admiration. Love, Harry

FINK--Florence, died July 11, 2007. Mourned by her daughter Nancy Marcus and son-inlaw George, her grandchildren David and Paul, and their wives Amy and Lisa, her great-grandchildren, Andrew and Sarah, and her loving companion Arthur Gold. Friends are invited to a celebration of her life, Saturday July 14, at 1:00pm at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 91 Hampton Street, Sag Harbor, NY. Contributions in her name may be made to the Free Library of Philadelphia Foundation, 1901 Vine Street, Room 111, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

An American who worked for a Halliburton subsidiary pleaded guilty yesterday to receiving kickbacks in exchange for awarding a Kuwaiti company nearly $13 million in contracts to supply the American military with semi-tractor-trailers, refrigeration trailers and fuel tankers in Iraq and Kuwait in 2003. The employee, Roger A. Heaton, 58, of Houston, worked for the subsidiary, KBR, as part of a logistics contract. KBR, formerly known as Kellogg, Brown & Root, was a subsidiary of Halliburton until it became a separate entity earlier this year. The contract has so far paid the companies $20 billion to supply the military with food, fuel, housing and other necessities.

Gary Sheffield, who is known for making candid and controversial comments, said in an HBO Sports interview that Yankees Manager Joe Torre treated black players differently from whites during Sheffield's three seasons with the team. ''When I was there, the couple of blacks that was there, every one of them had an issue with the organization,'' he told ''Real Sports'' for its July 17 program. ''They had an issue with Joe Torre.''
To the Editor: Re ''For Clinton, Faith Intertwines With Political Life'' (front page, July 7):

An editorial last Saturday about a State Department bulletin that prompted a rush of applications for unavailable green cards gave the wrong date for the application deadline. It was July 31, not July 2.

MOONEY--Irene M., on July 10, 2007. Daughter of the late Thomas and Mary Mooney of County Clare, Ireland. Sister of the late Thomas and Raymond Mooney. Survived by many loving nieces, nephews and cousins. Former parishioner of St. Jerome's Church, Bronx, NY. Longtime resident of Stuyvesant Town. Retired U.F.T. special education teacher, NY School for the Deaf and Blind. Longtime volunteer at St. Vincent's Hospital and NYC Ballet. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10am at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th St., NYC. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

The Pulitzer Prize-winning, best-selling author Cormac McCarthy, above with Oprah Winfrey, has signed a two-novel deal with his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. ''We don't know anything about them,'' Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, said. ''But two new novels by Cormac McCarthy is good enough for us.'' Knopf has published Mr. McCarthy's work since his breakout novel, ''All the Pretty Horses,'' in 1992. ''The Road,'' which was published last year and won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction, was selected for Ms. Winfrey's book club earlier this year and has sold about 225,000 copies in hardcover, according to the publisher. And there are 1.1 million paperback copies in print.

FOLLINI--Nilda (nee Baldante). Nilda Follini died peacefully at home on July 12. She was 95 years old. Beloved wife of the late George Follini, devoted mother of Barbara Colombo, Judy Paletta and Nancy Follini and husband Joseph Gilbert. Loving grandmother to Patricia Varley, George and Jackie Paletta, Diane and Bill Bradsell, Stephen and Christine Paletta, Michael and Kate Paletta, Barbara Colombo, Laura and Rob Arena. Proude great-grandmother of 20. Faithful aunt to cherished nieces and nephews and dear friend to many. She was born in New York City on February 7, 1912. She grew up the youngest of eight children. Nilda and George started their construction business with a typewriter in the basement of their home on Grace Avenue in the Bronx. Edenwald Contracting Company was one of the most successful construction companies in New York for over 50 years. Her motto and legacy to all ''Loving, Caring, and Sharing'' will remain with us forever. She will be deeply missed. Visiting hours will be at Bennett Funeral home, Sunday 2-8pm 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583. Funeral mass will be held on Monday, 10am at St. Pius X Church. 91 Secor Road, Scarsdale. Interment to immediately follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorn, NY. Donations can be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester. 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601-4403.

In a rare battle between American and uniformed Iraqi forces, United States troops backed by fighter jets killed six Iraqi policemen and seven gunmen during a predawn raid in which they captured a rogue police lieutenant, the military said Friday. American commanders said that during the raid, against an Iraqi police position in eastern Baghdad, their forces had come under ''heavy and accurate fire'' from a nearby police checkpoint as well as surrounding rooftops and a church.

LURIA--Catherine, our beloved Catherine Luria died on May 9th, 2007. She is missed deeply by her four children and 12 grandchildren. A graveside service will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I. on Sunday, July 15 at 10:00am. Call Ann 914441-1856 with inquiries.

Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma typically strikes people in their 50s or 60s, although it can occur earlier. The disease occurs when white blood cells, which help prevent infection, become cancerous. Unlike some other cancers, lymphoma appears to be becoming more common; scientists do not know why. The drugs Bexxar and Zevalin are approved to treat a subcategory of the disease known as follicular lymphoma, a slow-growing variety that can be put into remission but not cured. From 15,000 to 20,000 new cases of follicular lymphoma are diagnosed in this country each year.

To the Editor: ''So Much Paperwork, So Little Time to Teach,'' by Samuel G. Freedman (On Education column, July 4), suggests that we're driving down performance and driving out teachers because of overwhelming ''paperwork'' for classes of English language learners.

15% STAKE IN RUSSIA FIELD Christophe de Margerie, the chief executive of Total, said his company would book for accounting purposes 25 percent of the reserves of Russia's giant Shtokman natural gas deposit, after signing an agreement with Russia's Gazprom to develop the field. Gazprom, however, has stated that the license to the field and control over all future gas sales will remain 100 percent Russian owned. Mr. Margerie, above, told reporters in Moscow that because his company was taking financial risks in the development phase, it would be appropriate to book the reserves. ANDREW KRAMER VIACOM IN TALKS WITH CHINA Viacom has held exploratory discussions to develop theme parks in two regions in China that could also include movie co-production ventures. Sumner Redstone, Viacom's executive chairman, said he was in ''very tentative'' talks with Chinese officials to build theme parks in China's richest city, Shanghai, and Changsha. The structure would be similar to a theme park deal in South Korea whereby Viacom licensed its brand to projects, which are financed largely locally.
To the Editor: Re ''Health Care Terror,'' by Paul Krugman (column, July 9):

BERKLEY-LEHR--Sheila. Artist and educator, died on July 11th. Beloved mother of Allison, Hugh and Amy Lehr, and grandchildren, Noah and Anna Samuels. She will be deeply missed by mother, Betty Berkley, siblings David Berkley and Joan Johnson and friend, Georges Wajnberg. She was predeceased by her father Herman in 1975. Through her art, she strove to build connections between people. A strong woman, she found and created beauty in the world and opened our eyes to life's possibilities.

GILBERT--Stephen, passed away peacefully on July 12, 2007. Wonderful and beloved husband of Sandra Gilbert for 46 years, adored and cherished father of Holly Gilbert Mayer and Ira Gilbert. Born on January 18, 1932, he was a proud graduate of Columbia University and served as a neurologist in Brooklyn. He was a bright, unique, irreplaceable spirit. Funeral services will be held at 12:15pm on Sunday July 15 at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday became the latest Democratic presidential candidate to support efforts to raise tax rates for private equity and hedge fund managers. Two other leading Democratic candidates, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois and John Edwards, the former North Carolina senator, have already called for an increase in the tax rate for partners of investment funds.

A legal rights promoter who fought forced evictions in Shanghai and was jailed for two years died shortly after being released on medical parole, said Human Rights in China, a group in New York. The authorities in Shanghai had rejected requests by the family of the promoter, Chen Xiaoming, to release him early on the ground that he had a chronic illness. Mr. Chen, who was jailed for ''disturbing order in court,'' died of a hemorrhage after being moved to a civilian hospital on July 1, the group said.

JACOBSON--Irma Beit, widow of Aron H. Jacobson, on July 12, in the 100th year of a remarkable life. A great lady of firm resolve and indomitable spirit, she was deeply devoted to family and friends. Her lively curiosity, sense of humor and genuine caring will be sorely missed. She was one of a kind. Services at 11am, Friday July 20th at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. Irma was a Trustee of National Jewish Medical and Research Center and contributions to it at: 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, Colorado 80206, attention: President's Office; in lieu of flowers will be appreciated.

The New York City Ballet will announce on Monday its plans for the 2008 winter season, to run Jan. 2 through Feb. 24 at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. Among the highlights are a special farewell performance by the principal dancer Nikolaj Hübbe, above right, on Feb. 10, as well as world premiere ballets by the Italian choreographer Mauro Bigonzetti and the company's resident choreographer, Christopher Wheeldon. The season will open with George Balanchine's ''Jewels,'' which had its premiere in 1967. The season will also feature the return of Peter Martins's staging of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' which played for two weeks in the 2007 spring season.

The United Nations investigation of the 2005 killing of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri has identified a number of people possibly involved, but Lebanon's worsening situation has made it difficult to gain cooperation from witnesses and recruit staff members, the inquiry's chief, Serge Brammertz, said in a report to the Security Council. He said his commission had discovered many ''commonalities'' between the killing and 17 political attacks.

For classical beauty it is hard to beat Rome's traiditonal "must-see" piazzas, like Piazza Del Popolo with its matched baroque churches and Piazza Colonna with its gracious obelisk. But one of my favorites is the far more startling (disturbing?) early 20th century Piazza Mincio, a fantastical art nouveau gem, which combines elements of Gaudi and Escher.

Vicky Galindo hit a three-run home run and Jessica Mendoza drove in three runs to power the United States to a 9-0 victory against the Dominican Republic yesterday at the World Cup of Softball in Oklahoma City.The Americans (3-0) have outscored opponents by 26-1 at the World Cup and by 122-3 in 13 games this year.The United States was to face Japan last night in a rematch of the past two World Cup finals.

Lawyers for Trevor Graham, a track coach indicted in a federal investigation of steroid use by pro athletes, are seeking to have the charges dismissed because Justice Department officials are suspected of leaking information to the news media.Graham was charged in November with three counts of making false statements to federal agents. In documents filed Friday in San Francisco federal court, Graham’s lawyers cited widely published reports by The Associated Press that Graham “was expected to be indicted” as grounds for the dismissal. The articles ran the day before he was charged Nov. 2.

Matt Nagy threw for five touchdowns and ran for two more, and the visiting Columbus Destroyers held off a late rally by the Georgia Force to win the Arena Football League’s National Conference championship, 66-56.The Destroyers (10-9) advanced to the ArenaBowl for the first time. They will meet the San Jose SaberCats for the title in New Orleans. The host SaberCats advanced to their third ArenaBowl in six seasons with a 61-49 victory over the defending champion Chicago Rush. The top-seeded SaberCats (15-3) won their 12th straight game and were unbeaten at home.

Officials in New Orleans hope to land the N.F.L. draft. The Greater New Orleans Sports Foundation sent a letter to Commissioner Roger Goodell seeking to stage the annual draft, which is in April, and turn it into a weeklong celebration, including a Mardi Gras-style parade and civic events involving retired N.F.L. players.New York has played host to the draft since 1965. It is scheduled to be at Radio Music City Hall next year, where it was held the past two years.

Kevin Harvick took the lead from his teammate Jeff Burton with 27 laps to go, then held off Matt Kenseth to win the Nascar Busch Series race at Chicagoland Speedway yesterday. It was the fourth victory at Chicagoland for Harvick, who won the first two Cup races there in 2001 and 2002 and won the track’s Busch race in 2005.

A New Jersey judge has denied a request by the former Giants defensive end Jeremiah Parker to reduce his 10-year prison term for a child-endangerment conviction.Parker was convicted in 2003 of endangering the welfare of a child after the death of Elijah Kelly, the 4-year-old son of Parker’s former girlfriend, Tauleah Kelly; Tauleah Kelly pleaded guilty in return for testifying against Parker and is serving a seven-year prison term.Elijah Kelly died May 14, 2001, from a head injury after abuse from his mother and Parker, prosecutors said.

The Pan American Games got off to a sputtering start yesterday in Rio de Janeiro with baseball postponements and reports of a delay in televising gymnastics, one of the premier sports at the event.Organizers postponed two baseball games — the United States vs. the Dominican Republic, and Brazil against Nicaragua — after a power outage at the new stadium.It was not the way the Brazilians wanted to begin the biggest sporting event they have ever staged, particularly since they are seeking to put on the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics.ESPN Brazil reported problems at another new site, the Rio Multisport Arena, that led to the delay of coverage of the men’s team gymnastics competition. The opening ceremony was accompanied by a few problems Friday night at the famed Maracanã stadium, but it was a spectacular show. Security was so strict that many fans could not get to the newly renovated stadium in time.

Detroit Tigers catcher Iván Rodríguez was suspended yesterday for one game by Major League Baseball for his conduct during a game against the Seattle Mariners on Thursday.Rodríguez, who was also fined an undisclosed amount, was ejected from Thursday’s game in the fourth inning for arguing that he was interfered with while trying to throw out a base stealer.As Rodríguez, a 14-time All-Star, was trying to throw out Adrián Beltre at second base, the batter, Yuniesky Betancourt, was bent over and astride the plate. Rodríguez avoided making contact with Betancourt, but his throw sailed over second base and into center field for an error that allowed Beltre to advance to third.Rodríguez then began arguing with the plate umpire Mike Winters and at one point appeared to come close to bumping him — if not making contact.

Phil Mickelson mastered a strong wind to shoot a three-under-par 68 yesterday for a one-stroke lead over Gregory Havret after the third round of the Scottish Open in Luss.Mickelson had a 54-hole total of 12-under 201. Havret shot a 70.José Manuel Lara finished with a 74 to drop five strokes off the pace. Steve Webster shot a 69 and was third, three strokes back of Mickelson.Mickelson’s round included a walk into the water at the third hole after his second shot hit the green and spun back into a pond. He wore waterproof pants to hit his submerged ball out to 8 feet and holed the putt for a birdie.

An article last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, about the Leuthold Undervalued and Unloved fund, misstated its return for the first six months of 2007. It was 6.2 percent, not 4.5 percent.

The Economic View column last Sunday, about financial effects of globalization, incorrectly attributed a paraphrased comment and a quotation about current trends of stronger international economic growth and a declining dollar. It was Jeff Tyler, senior vice president of American Century Investments — not Rob McCarthy, an analyst at Banc of America Securities — who said he expected the trends to continue several more years and that “It’s a 5- to 10-year kind of workout.” It was also Mr. Tyler who said that among his firm’s mutual funds, the Global Growth fund is one that is particularly well suited to capturing international growth of United States companies.

(Lifetime) STATE OF MIND File this one under “didn’t see it coming.” The ever-affecting Lili Taylor stars in this new drama about a New Haven psychiatrist whose life goes into a nose dive when she catches her husband cheating on her with their couples therapist. DELLACANE, a Bronxville-based rock band, made it into the final round of the Emergenza Music Festival, which bills itself as “the largest international contest for unsigned bands.” The group was one of 28 acts in the final competition, held July 6 and 7 at Webster Hall in New York City. An answer in the Q & A column on July 1, about tax abatements for New York City co-op owners, misstated certain eligibility provisions. The abatements are available to those who own three or fewer apartments in a co-op; owners of three apartments are not excluded from receiving rebates. In addition, sponsors of co-op conversions are never eligible, even if they own three or fewer apartments.

An article last Sunday about the actress Nikki Blonsky included incorrect information from Ms. Blonsky about the circumstances of her casting in the film “Hairspray.” As a previous correction reported, Morgit Management, which represented her at the time, sent New Line Cinema an e-mail message with a Web link to a copy of her audition tape, which had been made with the help of the management company. THE FINAL DAYS OF ’80S.

ALL SPRING, IT WAS virtually impossible to walk a city block without treading on a pair of Reva Ballerina flats from Tory Burch: rubber-soled, whisper-light leather flats with comfy elastic backs. If they sported double T logos instead of double Cs, well, they cost less than $200 a pair, so you could compensate by buying them in every color. For fall, Ms. Burch decided to bulk up with a quilted version of the Reva, called the Quinn, which shipped earlier this month and which has been selling in droves. In colors like lipstick red and sunny yellow that move easily from warm to cool weather, the Quinn also comes in gold metallic, black suede and black patent leather; $225 at toryburch.com or (212) 334-3000.

FORGET TRAIL MIX. For parents who are too, um, busy to go shopping for camp goodies, Scholastic Camper Care Packages are custom-made baskets chockablock with wholesome mental treats for children spending the summer in the controlled wilds. Parents — or their reasonable facsimiles — can phone (800) 724-6522 and a consultant will guide them through the store’s assortment of games, crafts activity kits, comic book novels, trivia and joke books and, of course, real books, to construct a made-to-order basket. Top-selling crafts kits include design-your-own pillowcase, make-your-own bunk lantern, fingernail art and the T-shirt as canvas. With purchases over $75, the company will include a tin camp tote and a specially designed letter to your happy camper — because naturally, if you’re too busy to shop, you’re too busy to write.

SANDBOARDING ON A DESERT EXCURSION OUTSIDE DUBAI, MARCH 3, 2007 Per Svenkvist, 55, from Kristinehamn, Sweden, the managing director of G.E. Energy (Sweden): “My wife and I went out on a half-day trip in a four-wheel-drive car in the desert with a professional driver. That was quite exciting, almost like surfing but on sand dunes. I’m fond of downhill skiing, so I was very interested in trying sandboarding, too. On snow you glide much easier; here you have to have some speed to start gliding, and then suddenly you stop because of the friction. If this picture had been taken a little later, you would have seen me falling all over the sand. That’s how it ended.” As told to Seth Kugel.

KAHN--Michele Davidow, 55, passed away on July 12 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital after stoically fighting lung cancer for more than two years. She was the beloved wife of Thomas Kahn for 35 years, loving devoted mother of Andrew, Elizabeth and Victoria, the cherished daughter of Sanford and Saundra Davidow and the adored sibling of Arline Shaffer and Harry Davidow. Michele received her BA from Beaver College and her MBA and MSW degrees from Columbia University. She later pursued her passion for the decorative arts through an MA from the Cooper Hewitt division of the Parsons School of Design. Captivated by the designs of Louis Comfort Tiffany, Michele worked on the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Tiffany show entitled Laurelton Hall and a traveling exhibition of Tiffany objects. She lectured at Sotheby's and the Smithsonian on this subject. As a longtime resident of NYC, she savored the vibrancy and culture of the metropolis, while balancing this passion with a love of literature and foreign exploration. With her husband, Tom, and friends she attended concerts, operas and theatre throughout the year. She also loved adventure. From her early travels to Argentina and Eastern Europe to her more recent voyages to China, Russia and Australia. Michele had bright eyes for new places and their arts. A devoted philanthropist, she supported the arts, education and lung cancer research. Michele was stylish, vivacious and deeply intellectual and carried a sharp wit wherever she went. She loved to entertain and delight her family and friends with a good story, and fabulous cooking and baking. Her indomitable spirit will always be with us. The family funeral is at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn on July 13 at 11am. The family will be sitting Shiva at 25 Central Park West, Saturday, Sunday and Monday from 6-9pm. A Memorial Service will be planned for early fall. $(6$)KAHN--Michele. We honor the memory of our dear friend Michele. Our thoughts and our prayers are with her family at this time. May theirwonderful memories help all who miss her. The Golds $(6$)KAHN--Michele. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind are deeply saddened by the death of Michele Kahn, beloved wife of Thomas Graham Kahn, our esteemed colleague, former Treasurer and longtime member of the Board of Directors. She and her family have been active and generous supporters of The Guild's programs for years. We extend our sympathies to the entire family. Pauline Raiff, Bd. Chairman Alan R. Morse, Pres. and CEO $(6$)KAHN--Michele. We Will Miss You -Fussie Cookie!! A longtime friend of our family who was always integral to the time we spent with her; may it be on vacation, in Bermuda, significant family occasions and many other times. Our thoughts are with the entire Kahn Family and remember that ''Time Takes All But Memories''. Susan, Jim and Hannah Baumann

TO many Americans, the execution last week of China's former top food and drug official after he confessed to taking bribes was an extreme reaction by the Beijing government to growing worries about the safety of Chinese exports. After recalls of everything from toothpaste and tires to pet food and toy trains, China's leaders decided to make an example of Zheng Xiaoyu, 62, whose punishment came just six weeks after he was found guilty. Indeed, Senator Charles Schumer of New York, a leading critic of China, called it a ''surreal response.''
THEATER Ben Brantley
To the Editor: Re ''On the Wrong Side of 5 to 4, Liberals Talk Tactics'' (Week in Review, July 8):

An article last Sunday about a younger generation of librarians misstated the name of a library organization that held a conference in Washington last month. It is the American Library Association, not the American Librarian Association.

The Economic View column last Sunday, about financial effects of globalization, incorrectly attributed a paraphrased comment and a quotation about current trends of stronger international economic growth and a declining dollar. It was Jeff Tyler, senior vice president of American Century Investments -- not Rob McCarthy, an analyst at Banc of America Securities -- who said he expected the trends to continue several more years and that ''It's a 5- to 10-year kind of workout.'' It was also Mr. Tyler who said that among his firm's mutual funds, the Global Growth fund is one that is particularly well suited to capturing international growth of United States companies
JAY LENO

At a time when artists tend to exhibit too young and too frequently, it comes as a surprise to discover a painter who exhibits his pictures only when he really has something he considers ready to show. In fact, Neil Jenney, the subject of a thoughtful show at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., exhibits so rarely that his exhibitions arouse an almost devotional interest and curiosity among art lovers.
To the Editor:

An article last Sunday about Patti LuPone, who is playing Rose in a three-week run of ''Gypsy,'' at City Center, misstated the age of Arthur Laurents, the author of the book of the musical. He turned 90 yesterday, not 89.

WILLIAMS--Robert Hayden Loving husband and father, died Tuesday, July 3rd , of natural causes at the age of 81 years. Robert lived the last ten years in Oregon, living between Cape Mears and the downtown Portland Area. While in Portland, he enjoyed the city in no small measure, attending the Symphony, the Opera, and a unique relationship with Portland State University as a member of the Friends of the Library, the PSU Foundation, and serving on the committee to select a new librarian. Prior to his residence in Portland, Robert lived in Coalville, Utah, for eighteen years and served as Summit County Treasurer, co-founder of KPCW public radio in Park City, from where he would broadcast a weekly classical music program. Robert also owned Ryan's Bar and Dolly's Bookstore on Main Street in Park City. His primary career was as an insurance broker to the entertainment industry from 1952 to 1979 in Los Angeles, California, where he worked for the Fireman's Fund, CBS, and as owner and president of the Albert G. Ruben Company. In this capacity, Robert worked with some of the great talent agencies and studios in Hollywood, and innovated preproduction insurance for the movie industry. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College, class of 1947, and served in the United States Navy during World War Two. He was born to Lida and Frank O. Williams, October 31, 1925, in Kingston, Pennsylvania moving soon thereafter to Maplewood, New Jersey, living there until he went to college. Robert is survived by his wife of 57 years, Joan Hackett Williams of Portland, Oregon, sons Kenneth Shales of Portland Oregon, Mayor Robert Dana of Park City, Utah, Evan David of Salt Lake City, Utah, Todd Jeffery of Los Angeles, California Grant Edward of San Diego, California, ten grand children and one greatgrandchild. The family wishes to express a warm thanksgiving to all who have contributed to the life and times of this wonderful man and to assure each one of them that they are remembered well through the memories, stories, and attributes each gave to him in his life. These gifts remain in us now and we are forever grateful to you all. Our lives will be his memorial. Respectfully, The Williams Family

It is a testament to Yankee know-how that actual rocket scientists are seeking the input of ''basement brainstormers'' and ''garage tinkerers'' in the NASA-sponsored contests. I found Jack Hitt's (July 1) mention of an unnamed oil sheik, who was wary of stimulating our nation's famous ingenuity, ironic. Perhaps we would not be jeopardized by our dependence on Middle Eastern oil today if similar contests, stimulating innovations on alternative energy sources, had been instituted in the mid-70s when we were hit by the first of many oil shocks.
PATTI LuPONE The Entertainer

PAIGE--Marvin, 74 Renowned Restaurateur and Iconic New Yorker passed away at Roosevelt Hospital on the evening of July 4th. He was surrounded by family and friends. Marvin was a celebrated New York City restaurateur known for such places as Pal Joey's, Sniffen Court Inn, Boodles, The Tin Lizzie, Charlie's, Jose's, Hamburger Harry's, Chelsea Lobster Company, Max, and the famed Jazz club The 5-SPOT Jazz Gallery, a home base for such jazz greats as Thelonius Monk and Art Blakey. This was a combination of Marvin's passion for jazz and the restaurant business. He was a pioneer in Chelsea, opening the legendary Claire Restaurant in the early eighties, following the enormous success of Claire Key West. Both were designed by TonyAward winning Broadway set designer Robin Wagner and were of considerable importance in the gay community. He was a vibrant New Yorker, an icon known throughout the city for his graciousness, charm, wit, benevolence, and love of his community, as was evident by his generous support of a variety of causes such as God's Love We Deliver, of which he was a founding contributor. Marvin was also a beloved leader with SGI USA. He was deeply committed to Soka Gakkai International, as the practice based on the teachings of the Nichiren school of Mahayana Buddhism had transformed his life. He was famous for the best Key Lime Pie in the universe, a recipe that remains a family secret. He leaves behind an adoring son, Daniel and daughter-in-law Sue, his soul-mate Pat Vega and her loving family Suzanne, Ruby, Paul, Allison, Sachi, Brian, and Matthew. Marvin will be deeply missed as he touched and embraced so many lives. He was a man whose heart truly runneth over. A memorial service will be held on July 18th, 2007 at 6:30pm at the SGI New York Culture Center, 7 East 15th Street, New York, NY 10003. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to SGI USA and God's Love We Deliver.

ZAMOFF--Ruth Frankel, 93, at home on July 9th. Wife of the late Nathan. Mother of sons Barry and Richard. Daughter of the late Frieda and Benjamin Frankel. Sister of the late Max. Grandmother of Mitchell, Jamie, Dore, Fern, Bennett, Jeffrey, and Robyn. Great-grandmother of eight. Her wit, intelligence and inspiration, especially in the final years of her life, will be sorely missed by her family and by many loving friends of all ages and walks of life. Donations in her name may be made to Jewish Social Services Agency (JSSA) in Rockville, Maryland.

Of all the campaign themes that will emerge leading up to the 2008 primaries, one you probably won't hear a lot about is experience. That's because the candidates who are at the moment best positioned for the nominations of their parties have surprisingly little of it. At a time when the nation looks for a leader to meet profound challenges to its decades-long dominance as an economic and military power, the five candidates who lead in state and national polls -- Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama, John Edwards, Rudy Giuliani and Mitt Romney -- have won a grand total of five statewide elections in their cumulative political careers and have served a combined 20 years in statewide office. (Fred Thompson, who may soon be among the leaders in the Republican field, served eight years in the Senate.) In fact, the executive with the longest tenure in the group is Giuliani, who would be the first mayor in history to ascend to the presidency without holding some higher office first. Meanwhile, candidates with long careers spent mastering foreign and domestic policy, like Joe Biden and John McCain, have been flailing. In a round of television ads that feel more like a cry for help than a campaign pitch, Bill Richardson -- the two-term governor of New Mexico and a former congressman, U.N. ambassador and energy secretary -- sits in a drab office somewhere (Iowa, perhaps?), enthusiastically showing off his résumé while a clueless middle manager, entirely uninterested, rushes him along.
To the Editor:

Derek Jeter signed one baseball, then another and another. He leaned back in his chair in the visiting clubhouse at AT&T Park in San Francisco on Tuesday and exhaled. Soon, there would be more items for him to authenticate with his looping signature. Every year, the All-Star Game is an autograph bonanza. Players sign dozens of baseballs, bats and jerseys. Many of the players act like fans and hustle for signatures, too. Not Jeter, the Yankees' shortstop. He left San Francisco with no autographs.
