To the Editor: A July 8 letter castigated Al Gore for not once mentioning ''the fastest, most effective and most efficient solution for climate change: carbon taxes.'' But Mr. Gore has voiced support for a carbon tax repeatedly, including in his testimony to the House of Representatives on March 21, when he called for a long-term tax shift to replace payroll taxes with a tax on carbon emissions.

KOBACKER--Arthur. The Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism mourns the passing of Arthur Kobacker, a generous benefactor to a range of civil rights, peace, education and health care issues. His support of social justice was deeply informed by his Judaism; our center's Arthur and Sara Jo Kobacker Building, in Washington, reflects this. We offer our sincere condolences to Sara Jo and the family.

KLUGHERZ--Esther Yablonsky, 94, retired school secretary, died June 6 at Montgomery Hospice, Rockville, MD. Born in Brooklyn in 1912, she was married to Richard (1910-1988) for 52 wonderful years and is survived by children Peter Klugherz and Laura Klugherz Seldman, six grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. She worked at Seward Park High School, NYC Board of Education for more than 25 years. Resident of Leisure World, Silver Spring, MD. since 1991, she led the Book Discussion Group and was a senior activist for world peace. Esther lived life fully: attended theatre, ballet, concerts; loved museums, Art, the Adirondack Mountains, played bridge, anagrams, the piano, tennis, and golf, was a walking dictionary, gourmet cook and blueberry pie maestro. Loved by family, coworkers, neighbors and friends

Dedicated teachers force themselves to look for the nugget of truth that may be embedded in even the snidest comment. For example, a student's sarcastic crack to Holmberg, at the end-of-semester interview, actually raises a useful pedagogical question: Wouldn't it be more productive to schedule these one-on-one meetings early in the semester, when both teacher and student can set goals?

Henson of Carmel Valley, Calif., was married yesterday to Andrew Carl Tolonen, a son of Carol Tolonen and Carl J. Tolonen of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Marilyn Anderson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Mrs. Tolonen, 30, is a data management specialist, working with DNA sequencing at the Broad Institute, a research center in Cambridge, Mass., that is affiliated with Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She graduated from the University of Colorado. Her father is a lawyer in practice in Carmel Valley.

McPHILLIPS--Joseph A. III, The revered headmaster of the American School of Tangier, Morocco, died June 10th after a fall in his home in Tangier. The accident occurred five days before the school's 57th commencement, at which the singer Jimmy Buffett gave the commencement address. A graduate of Andover and Princeton, Mr. McPhillips, 71, became headmaster of the school in 1972 and presided over its transformation to a largely Moroccan student body as well as the establishment of a sister school in Marrakech. Under his energetic and flamboyant leadership, the school developed an exceptional academic reputation and served in these troubled times as a bridge between the Islamic and Western Worlds. Many of its graduates attended American universities. Among his many friends were Oliver Stone, Tennessee Williams, Bernard Henri-Levy, Diana Vreeland, Pierre Berge, Frank Wisner and Joseph Verner Reed. Paul Bowles composed music for his annual graduation plays, and Yves Saint Laurent designed the costumes. He is survived by a brother, Dr. Frank McPhillips of Mobile, AL, and a sister, Lynn Meador of Point Clear, AL. Memorial contributions may be sent to American School of Tangier c/o Sumner Rulon-Miller, Chairman, 531 E. 72nd St, NYC, NY.

KIERNAN--Reverend James. The Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, students, and alumni of St. John's University express their profound sorrow at the passing of Reverend James Kiernan, C.M., who enriched this University community through distinguished service in a variety of roles. As Vice President for Campus Ministry and later as Senior Vice President of the Staten Island campus, he served the students of this institution for more than a decade, sharing his remarkable faith and embodying the Vincentian values of caring and humility that are central to our special mission. More recently he gave his time and talents as a member of the Board of Trustees. Our University community expresses its deep affection and boundless gratitude for all that he has been and done for us. Our love and prayers are with his family and his Vincentian confreres. Thomas E. McInerney, Chair, Board of Trustees Rev. Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

Maya Jasanoff's essay (July 1) could have been more effective if she'd skipped the attempt to foment sympathy for what amounted to America's first losers. I ended up focusing less on the intriguing points she was making and more on the ill-advised try at making me feel sorry for the plight of the British loyalists, who constituted some 20 percent of the 1770-era American populace -- a definitive minority, by any measure. Worse yet was the labeling of the postwar accounts of this hard-luck lot as a ''wrenching archive of woe'' -- which amounts (in the case of one outspoken loyalist) to ''loneliness, illness and deprivation.'' Lonely is as lonely does.
To the Editor:

Katherine Nichols's nearly unbelievable account of her experiences living with her husband, who has primary progressive aphasia, a form of frontotemporal dementia, reads like an episode of ''Dr. Phil'' (Lives, June 24). But for those of us who work with patients and families affected by this disease, hers is a painfully accurate description. It typically strikes at a younger age than Alzheimer's, when people are still in their productive work years. The consequences are evident in every aspect of life.

Rather than considering students ''fussy postadolescent clientele,'' judging their reactions as ''obviously wrongheaded'' and trying to guess at the private identities of those who criticize his approach, I suggest Holmberg reframe his view of the educational process. If he engages his students as ''co-learners'' whose ideas -- and yes, even critiques of The New York Times -- are essential to classroom success, I think his teaching satisfaction and student ratings would soar.

The efforts of the various ''ad-mins,'' ''bureaucrats'' and ''stewards'' to keep Wikipedia free from bias are indeed refreshing in the opinion-driven world of online information. However, the 20-somethings who dutifully delete ''evil'' from references to the Virginia Tech gunman should know that bias can show itself in subtler and more pernicious ways. For example, using the length of an article as a measure of the subject's importance, Wikipedia consistently favors the current and the kitschy (as I write, Scooter Libby's entry is longer than either Richard Nixon's or William Shakespeare's). While the Wikipedians' devotion to being unbiased is admirable, as they mature they will learn that ''fair'' and ''true'' are two very different things indeed.

INTERNATIONAL 3-10 Russia to Suspend Treaty President Vladimir V. Putin formally notified NATO governments that Russia will suspend its obligations under the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, a key Cold War-era arms limitation agreement, in response to American plans to deploy a missile shield in Eastern Europe. 1

A new ''passport card'' is in development as the State Department, in consultation with the Department of Homeland Security, works to find an affordable alternative to traditional passports for United States citizens crossing to Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean and Bermuda by land or sea. A recent Homeland Security press release said that the State Department ''has developed an ambitious and aggressive schedule to begin issuing the Passport Card to the public as soon as possible in 2008.'' The first phase of the land and sea portion of the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative goes into effect on Jan. 31, 2008. Starting then, United States and Canadian citizens will need to present specific forms of identification.

BERO--Robert. Artist and printmaker, Robert Bero died peacefully at his home in Tuxedo Park, New York on Sunday, June 24. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1941, Bero studied at the Pratt Institute (BFA) and at Yale University (MFA). He later taught at SUNY, Potsdam, Brown University and SUNY, Purchase. John Canaday of the New York Times wrote that ''Bero's enormous woodcuts, years in the making and days in the printing expand the horizons of printmaking.'' Bero's work has been exhibited at the Library of Congress, the Smithsonian Institution, Cornell University, Yale University, the Museum of Fine Arts, Cincinnati, and the Society of American Graphic Artists. Along with his artistic contributions, Robert Bero was a valued mentor to his students and a friend to many in the Tuxedo Park area. His warmth, kindness, and endless knowledge of art will be deeply missed.
To the Editor:

BENNET--Robert F. Formerly of New York City where he started and ended his career in real estate, died on July 4th at his home in Annapolis, Maryland, of congestive heart failure. He was 95. Described by many as a ''Gentleman of the Old School'' Bob was a major figure in New York real estate for many years, principally with Douglas Elliman, where his wisdom, so graciously dispensed, benefited all around him. His role covered most aspects of the business and so many of the cooperative conversions and new developments in Manhattan during his time -buildings like the Excelsior, Dag Hammarskjold Tower, the Galleria, Museum Tower carried his signature. Starting out, in his youth, as he frequently recounted, collecting rents on the Lower East Side, with all the complexities of those situations -he rose to the highest levels, where he achieved recognition throughout the industry. Bob's relationship with major developers transcended many differences of opinion, personality and objectives, but achieved always a high level of accomplishment for all concerned and lasting friendships were formed. His knowledge, his integrity, his wise counsel and his special sense of humor will always be remembered fondly by all who knew him and particularly by those who worked with him under his leadership. During World War II, Bob volunteered for the Army Air Corps. He served with the rank of Captain in Africa and India. He was a man of many interests, also overseeing the development of his two nieces and two nephews after the loss of their parents at an early age. Love of flying his aircraft, Mooney, with his long time war buddy came next. He was a self-taught painter, enjoyed working in his workshop and both he and his wife loved dancing and traveling abroad. Surviving are his wife, Nanette Norris Bennet, his nieces, Mary Bruton Reid of London, England, Frances Bruton of Albuquerque, New Mexico, and his nephew Robert Bruton of New York City. He was predeceased by his nephew William Bruton, also of New York City. A memorial service will be held in Annapolis on July 22. Burial will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity, international or local, or to AmeriCares, 88 Hamilton Avenue, Stamford, Connecticut 06902. Services are by The John M. Taylor Funeral Home of Annapolis.

Investors overcame earnings warnings from Home Depotand Sears Holdingsand dismissed concerns about the subprime mortgage market, sending the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to record highs last week. Wall Street ended the week strongly as the Dow Jones surged past 13,900 for the first time, reversing a nearly 150-point drop on Tuesday. The S.& P. 500 set a trading high of 1,555.10 in Friday's session, breaking a seven-year record of 1,553.11 that was set in March 2000.

In this week's issue, Roy Blount Jr. praises ''American Food Writing: An Anthology With Classic Recipes,'' edited by Molly O'Neill. Blount is himself known as an attentive eater and a very fine food writer, so we asked him about his collection of food books. ''I probably have 30 or 40 books on food, but where they all are, at the moment, is another question,'' he replied by e-mail. ''Our kitchen -- where I used to keep all my food-related books, unless they were by A. J. Liebling or Calvin Trillin or someone else whose books reside in Humor or some other section -- has just been renovated. And my wife is in the process of moving all her stuff into our house, which is of course a boon and a blessing including more books on food, but I can't even find my copy of the late Ernest Mickler's 'White Trash Cooking,' which might be my favorite just on grounds of nostalgia and unfinicky exuberance.''

I have both an appreciation of the wisdom of ancient cultures and a modern skeptical mind (Benjamin Anastas, July 1). Though I am willing to accept there might be some deep knowledge that the Maya acquired that modern science can't yet explain, I have reassured myself there is no cause for alarm from the end of the Mayan calendar. Since nothing cataclysmic happened in 3114 B.C., at the beginning of the calendar, there is no reason to believe something terrible will happen at the end.

ALL SPRING, IT WAS virtually impossible to walk a city block without treading on a pair of Reva Ballerina flats from Tory Burch: rubber-soled, whisper-light leather flats with comfy elastic backs. If they sported double T logos instead of double Cs, well, they cost less than $200 a pair, so you could compensate by buying them in every color. For fall, Ms. Burch decided to bulk up with a quilted version of the Reva, called the Quinn, which shipped earlier this month and which has been selling in droves. In colors like lipstick red and sunny yellow that move easily from warm to cool weather, the Quinn also comes in gold metallic, black suede and black patent leather; $225 at toryburch.com or (212) 334-3000.
To the Editor: ''Heart Therapy Strains Efforts to Limit Costs'' (front page, July 7) brought appropriate attention to a problem that too frequently is minimized.

MUCH OF THE WORLD ASSOCIATES Heidi Klum with outrageous lingerie (the kind that only looks better when embellished with giant fluffy angel wings), not dark, simple separates. But when she isn't illuminating the runway for Victoria's Secret, Ms. Klum, 34, the model and Project Runway host, covers up considerably. ''Lately I've been wearing all of my mom's old bell bottoms with platform flip-flops, and yesterday at the flea market I bought a Dior coat with gold buttons and gold pilot stripes on the sleeves,'' said Ms. Klum, who shops at the Chelsea flea market and has homes in the West Village and in Beverly Hills, Calif. ''I have 10-year-old pieces I still bust out, and I like finding things all over the place, from expensive stores to H&M.''

FORGET TRAIL MIX. For parents who are too, um, busy to go shopping for camp goodies, Scholastic Camper Care Packages are custom-made baskets chockablock with wholesome mental treats for children spending the summer in the controlled wilds. Parents -- or their reasonable facsimiles -- can phone (800) 724-6522 and a consultant will guide them through the store's assortment of games, crafts activity kits, comic book novels, trivia and joke books and, of course, real books, to construct a made-to-order basket. Top-selling crafts kits include design-your-own pillowcase, make-your-own bunk lantern, fingernail art and the T-shirt as canvas. With purchases over $75, the company will include a tin camp tote and a specially designed letter to your happy camper -- because naturally, if you're too busy to shop, you're too busy to write.
CLASSICAL Anne Midgette

Perhaps Holmberg should step back and reconsider the evaluations by his journalism students when they accuse him of a liberal bias. Why had he ''used The Times as an educational tool'' in class without including a newspaper on the other side of the political spectrum as well? Writing off student criticism as simply ''echoing the political bent of their parents'' was dismissive. It is in the college years that students are most likely to rebel against the attitudes of their parents. I hope he will give this more thought. His students may be more perceptive than he thinks.

Los Angeles AMID the debates -- and the looming deadline -- over Mayor Michael Bloomberg's congestion pricing plans for the city, one recent traffic measure has caused little uproar: increased fines ($115) for drivers who block the box. Indeed, many New Yorkers support the mayor's plan, which means that not just regular police officers, but also the city's more than 2,800 traffic agents have the authority to hand out tickets for an infraction known as blocking the box. And why not? Few things enrage travelers more than the driver who blocks the intersection, intensifying the already suffocating traffic congestion.
JUDGE AND JURY A Much-Needed Spectacle

HOME sellers and buyers are acutely aware of house prices in a local market, but these days even owners who plan to stay put should be attuned to changes in market value, mortgage finance specialists say. That's because homeowners face less financial flexibility than they once had, especially in areas where home sales are stagnant or falling.

THE FINAL DAYS OF '80S excess may have been symbolized by the MCM pocketbook logo: a pair of rearing medieval lions in aggressive repetition that only the truly resolute shopper could remember. Now, as with all things '80s, the international luxury brand MCM is roaring back, this time minus the pride of lions. The company's patent tote is quietly becoming a bag of note, seen on the arm of style-makers like Sofia Coppola, generating lengthy waiting lists at the company's flagship in Berlin and selling swiftly at Colette in Paris and Harrods in London. This week, the bag will arrive in the United States at Bloomingdale's and Intermix stores, in black, silver, gold and purple, left ($995 to $1,150).

An article last Sunday about the actress Nikki Blonsky included incorrect information from Ms. Blonsky about the circumstances of her casting in the film ''Hairspray.'' As a previous correction reported, Morgit Management, which represented her at the time, sent New Line Cinema an e-mail message with a Web link to a copy of her audition tape, which had been made with the help of the management company. She won a tryout as a result of that e-mail message, not a copy of the tape she sent separately by mail.

As a lawyer representing health care providers, including doctors who have allegedly overprescribed narcotics, I read Tina Rosenberg's article (June 17) with great interest. Our government's focus on prison as a problem-solver has ruined Dr. McIver's life. The chilling effect on the medical profession cannot be measured or overstated. Particularly in rural areas, where specialists are rare or nonexistent, doctors fear prescribing adequately for patients in pain. As the baby boomers age, there will be more patients and fewer doctors. Those doctors not behind bars will be reluctant to adequately treat the increasing numbers of aging citizens with chronic conditions, some of which can bring excruciating pain.

She was famous for her wonderful home-made desserts and Viennese cuisine at her beautiful Yorktown home, where all felt welcome. We shall miss her.

Daniel Patterson's article on making butter at home (Food, July 1) brought back memories of summer evenings on our porch in Greens Farms, Conn., during World War II. Rationing was in effect, and margarine was a white brick in which one mixed yellow coloring. The simple solution: We filled a quart Mason jar with whole milk, which was passed around to be shaken by all family members and guests, in turn, during the cocktail hour.

To the Editor: ''Transferring Up,'' by Jonathan Kozol (Op-Ed, July 11), outlines a series of six provisions to amend the No Child Left Behind Act to promote the transfer of children from low-performing to high-performing schools.
Judge Bully To the Editor:
SELDES AND LANSBURY Stars Who Still Shine

If watching the Tour de France in the comfort of your living room makes you want to hop onto two wheels and race through the streets of Manhattan until you find a decent baguette, then the Tour de France Culinary Bike Tour might be for you. The tour stops at five French restaurants representing different regions of France, like Marseille in Midtown, which specializes in Provençal dishes, and Cafe d'Alsace, below, on the Upper East Side, which serves Alsatian dishes. The fee for the seven-hour, 18-mile tour is $95. It includes bike and helmet, guide and food samples -- like croissants in the morning and bouillabaisse for lunch -- at each restaurant (it costs $85 for those with their own equipment). Tours take place today, next Sunday and on July 29, and meet at Second Avenue and 69th Street at 9:30 a.m. Reservations: www.bikethebigapple.com. ...You know Brooklyn is a tourist destination when a Comfort Inn opens there. The hotel -- at 279 Butler Street, near Third Avenue and between the Cobble Hill and Park Slope neighborhoods -- is near the site of the proposed Atlantic Yards complex. Rates start at $179 (www.comfortinnbrooklyn.com). ... The Austrian Airlines Vacation Center (www.austrianair-vacations.com) is offering seven air and rail packages now through Oct. 31. The packages, which range from $939 to $1,999 a person, include the Central Europe Rail Steal, which offers airfare from New York, Chicago or Washington to cities like Krakow, Poland; Prague; or Budapest, and a second-class rail pass with five days of unlimited travel within Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Austria and Slovakia. Another package is the Balkan Rail Steal, which flies from the same cities in the United States to cities like Sofia, Bulgaria; Bucharest, Romania; or Istanbul, Turkey, and offers a first-class rail pass with five days of unlimited travel in those countries, as well as Greece and Macedonia. For all packages, participants may fly home from a different city and must complete rail travel within one month.

BARBER--Dr. Russell, November 4, 1934-June 5, 2007. Former Religion Editor for NBC for 15 years. He produced and hosted a television show call ''The First Estate: Religion in Review''. He interviewed well know figures like ''Mother Teresa,'' ''The Dali Lama,'' ''Norman Vicente Peale''. He was a contributing editor to the Today Show and NBC New Specials. He earned three Emmys, one Garbriel and numerous other industry and religious awards. He served on the board for the Institute on Religion & Public Policy and was an advisor to the Templetone Prize for progress in religion. Most recently he had been involved in the United Nations ''World Harmony Run'' with Guru Shri Chinmoy. Russell is deeply missed.

BALKIND--Benjamin Hart, died July 12th, 2007. He was the beloved husband of Mary Jo, dearest father of Sarah Adler, the late Benjamin L. Balkind, and Buck Balkind, and doting grandfather of Karey Jo, Max, Sammy and Teddy. After graduating from Harvard University and Yale Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review, he became the law clerk for Judge Otto Schoenrich of New York. He then became a partner in the New York law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt and Mosle, where he practiced international corporate law in Africa and South America. Ben was an accomplished athlete, bridge player, and outdoorsman. However, we will remember him most for his courage, perseverance, dry sense of humor, generosity, and kindness. He was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather, and friend. He set an example for us all. We will miss him dearly. There will be a memorial Service at St. John's Church, Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor at 2pm on July 21st. A reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Memorial foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, NY, NY 10018, or the Arthritis Foundation, National Office, Memorial donations, P.O. Box 932915, Atlanta, GA 31193-2915 would be appreciated

RUSSO--Fred B., passed on peacefully on July 12, 2007 surrounded by his entire family and very close friends. He was 40 years old and lost his brave battle from Metastatic Melanoma. Freddie is survived by his mother, Connie; his siblings, Angela, Michael and Gianna. His nephews; Alex, Ben and Sebastian. A memorial service, mass and repast luncheon have been planned. Please contact fredbrusso@aol.com for further information.

Roy Jones Jr., 38, took a 12-round unanimous decision against undefeated Anthony Hanshaw last night in Biloxi, Miss., and won the vacant International Boxing Council light heavyweight title. It was the second win in five fights for Jones (51-4).

JAFFE--Grace Carol, July 9, 2007. Wondrous mother of Nina and David, luminous Lala of Louis, Jacob, and Jonathan, sweet sister of the late Manny Cohen. A beloved, creative spirit.

An article last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, about the Leuthold Undervalued and Unloved fund, misstated its return for the first six months of 2007. It was 6.2 percent, not 4.5 percent.

Their Congressional approval ratings may be sagging, but Democrats in the House and Senate have overwhelmingly outraised their Republican counterparts in the past three months. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee raised $17.6 million from April through June, according to figures to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. The National Republican Senatorial Committee reported raising $8.6 million in the same period.

GERINGER--Eleanore (nee Nissen), passed away peacefully on July 13, 2007 at the age of 75, after battling Lung Cancer and Parkinson's Disease. Eleanore had a very fruitful and productive life, teaching English at the Bronx High School of Science, was an active participant in community affairs, including at the Park Avenue Synagogue and most importantly, as a loving and dedicated wife, mother and grandmother. She will be deeply missed by her family. Eleanore is survived by her devoted husband Harold, with whom she recently celebrated their 53 Wedding anniversary, and her children, Geoffrey, Laura and her husband Fred, and Elizabeth and her husband Gary. Eleanore is also survived by her adoring grandchildren, Benjamin, Alyson, Rachel and Spencer. The funeral service will be held on Sunday July 15 at 11am at the Plaza Community Chapel, on 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. $(6$)GERINGER--Eleanore. We mourn with deep sorrow and a profound sense of loss the passing of our dear friend. She will always be a part of our lives. Our hearts go out to Harold and the family. Sally and Harold Sandi and Norman Sylvia, Anna and Faye Selwyn and Dottie Paula and Larry

Wesley K. Clark takes sometimes correct, sometimes cheap and always obvious shots at the Bush administration. WILNER--Augusta Jane, age 66, died July 11th, 2007. Daughter of Ruth Einstein Wilner and the late J. Alfred Wilner, noted fair labor advocate. She is also survived by her sister Susan Butler Plum, her brother-in-law Dr. Fred Plum, Michael, Christopher, Carol Plum, and six cousins. A gifted photographer, wit, musician and school volunteer tutor, she will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Mannes College The New School for Music at 150 West 85th Street, NYC 10024.

The Vows column on July 1 about the marriage of Jordan Roter and Guy Stodel referred incorrectly to the California beach where the bridegroom proposed. It was in Ventura, where the couple had stopped on a bike tour, not in Ojai, where they were guests at an inn.

Devon Jamara Powers was married on Friday to David Colin Bennion at the Grand Ledge Opera House in Grand Ledge, Mich. The Rev. Versey A. Williams, a minister of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, performed the nondenominational ceremony. Ms. Powers, 29, who is keeping her name, is a daughter of Mandy and Lee R. Powers of Lansing, Mich. She is a doctoral candidate in media studies at New York University, where she is also an adjunct instructor in the department of media, culture and communication. She graduated from Oberlin College. Her father is a consulting mechanical engineer in Lansing to the automotive industry. Her mother, a nurse, works in the Lansing office of the Centers for Disease Control.

Shortly before the Yankees' 6-4 victory against Tampa Bay on Saturday night, a reporter from an Asian television network asked Manager Joe Torre if the third-year starter Chien-Ming Wang was the ace of his staff. Torre smiled and acknowledged that Wang was very good but that such a characterization might rankle veterans like Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte. But Wang certainly looked like an ace after raising his record to 10-4, giving him twice as many victories as Pettitte, who is second on the staff in wins.

de ROHAN-CHANDOR--Emilie. The Board of Directors of the Herzfeld Foundation records with deep sorrow the passing of our past president, loyal board member and esteemed colleague on July 5, 2007. We extend our sincere condolences to her daughter, Alice, son-in-law, Mitchell Scwhartz, beloved grandsons, James and Alex, and sister, Jane H. Rowen. Emy & Emil Herzfeld Foundation, Inc.

I would think that a retired four-star general would be able to appreciate the unique brand of threat that Al Qaeda poses to the United States, which is different from the threats posed by the former Soviet Union (Deborah Solomon, July 1). Indeed, the Soviets were larger in number, better-resourced and in possession of nuclear weapons; however, this threat was somewhat tempered by the reality of mutually assured destruction. Had the Soviets struck against the United States, we would know almost immediately where the attack was coming from and be able to retaliate. The Soviets had a vested interest in making sure that a nuclear attack was not launched by accident or miscalculation.

THE NEWS Senator David Vitter of Louisiana confessed to a ''very serious sin'' after his phone number was found on a list of client numbers kept by a woman accused of running a prostitution ring. BEHIND THE NEWS The senator, a 46-year-old Republican, has depicted himself as a champion of family values and has called marriage ''the most important social institution in human history.'' He confessed after Deborah Jeane Palfrey, the so-called D.C. Madam, released the phone numbers. Prosecutors say she ran a prostitution ring; she says it was an escort service.

Even as companies in China, Germany, Japan and the United States churn out silicon photovoltaic cells -- which convert sunlight into electricity -- at a blazing and accelerating rate, many experts have become convinced, paradoxically it would seem, that the technology is an also-ran, at least as far as global climate change goes. They say that unless the technology advances much faster than the market is managing on its own, solar cells will play only a marginal role in limiting the buildup of "greenhouse" gases in the atmosphere from the burning of fossil fuels. And yet, a quick glance at websites like solarbuzz.com gives an idea of how hot the solar cell market is these days.

Houghton Mifflin said on Monday that it would acquire the Harcourt unit of Reed Elsevier for $4 billion in cash and stock, uniting two of the biggest names in educational publishing. Houghton Mifflin will buy Harcourt Education, Harcourt Trade and Greenwood-Heinemann for $3.7 billion in cash and $300 million in stock, the company said in a statement.

Shareholders of the Lear Corporation, the automotive seat maker, rejected Carl C. Icahn's $2.9 billion buyout offer, handing a victory to a group of investors who led a five-month battle against the sale of the company. A unit of the Blackstone Group will buy DJO, a maker of knee and ankle braces, for $1.6 billion including debt, the companies said on Monday. The cash offer of $50.25 a share represents a 19 percent premium over DJO's closing price of $42.10 on Friday.

There has not been enough investment to generate large amounts of power and there has not been the scientific research needed to commercialize the technology so that it is a good corporate investment.

The tributes to Sanford I. Weill to his corporate -- and political -- prowess line the walls of the carpeted hallway that leads to his skyscraper office, with a panoramic view of Central Park. The trophies, from magazines to a pen used by President Bill Clinton, tout his achievement in building Citigroup into the most powerful financial institution since the House of Morgan a century ago.

CNBC reported Friday that the Hollywood Country Club is examining whether Bear Stearns chief executive James Cayne changed his golf scores to allow him to win the July 4 tournament at the New Jersey club.
The Renewable Energy Group, a biodiesel producer, filed with regulators on Monday to raise up to $150 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

The takeover battle for ABN Amro heated up on Monday as the Royal Bank of Scotland consortium raised the cash element of its 71.1 billion-euro ($98 billion) offer. The bid is above that of the consortium's British rival, Barclays, which made an all-stock bid worth about 64 billion euros. ABN Amro's board has recommended shareholders accept the bid from Barclays.

Applebee's International, which recently settled a proxy fight with the investment firm Breeden Capital Management, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by pancake restaurant chain IHOP Corporation for $25.50 a share, or $1.9 billion.

Bank of America may be too patriotic for its own good. While the bank does more business in the United States than any of its competitors, its returns are being eroded, Bloomberg News reported Monday.

Not long ago Carl Icahn's bid for Lear would have been a rapidly done deal. But recently, shareholders have become increasingly hostile toward managements and boards for accepting what they perceive to be lowball bids, and have been aggressively filing suits to block deals.

Warner Music has begun talks with private equity firms about a potential break-up bid for EMI ahead of next Thursday's deadline, The Telegraph reported on Saturday. EMI agreed last week to a 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) bid from a private equity group, Terra Firma, throwing further cold water on hopes of a counter bid by Warner.

Morgan Stan­ley's chief executive, John Mack, has invited senior staff to a fund raiser for Hillary Clinton on Monday, in what The Financial Times called "a pointed endorse­ment of the Democratic presidential hopeful from an important backer of President George W. Bush in 2004."

Banking group HBOS is considering a 1.2 billion pound ($2.5 billion) bid for Quintain Estates and Development, which owns London's Wembley Arena. The Times of London reported that HBOS' corporate banking unit an 11.9 percent stake in the property company last week and is believed to have hired Merrill Lynch to look at the possibility of a takeover.

In a move that could thwart a proposed $3.7 billion merger between Nasdaq and OMX, the Dubai International Financial Center, owner of the Dubai stock exchange, is preparing an offer for the Nordic stock market group, Reuters reported citing a report in The Daily Telegraph.

A member of the Bancroft family is making a last-ditch attempt to block Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. from buying Dow Jones, Reuters reported on Monday, confirming a story in The Wall Street Journal. Christopher Bancroft, whose family controls Dow, has recently approached hedge funds and private equity firms, in a move to acquire enough voting shares to give him the power to thwart a sale, the report said.

Geoff Lawson, the former Australia fast bowler, said he had been appointed coach of the Pakistan cricket team to succeed Bob Woolmer, who died four months ago at the World Cup.Lawson, 49, said in an interview with Australia’s Sky News that Pakistan Cricket Board officials called him yesterday to confirm his appointment. The board was set to make an announcement today, Lawson said.

Ending nearly three months of suspense about his future, Miami Heat center Alonzo Mourning said last night at his annual Zo’s Summer Groove charity game in Miami that he would play again next season — a choice he kept secret to the end, insisting he was still deciding just hours before the actual announcement.“I want to redeem myself and try to help this team redeem ourselves as an organization and try to get back on track,” Mourning said. “That wasn’t the Miami team you saw in the playoffs last year.”He added, “It left a sour taste in my mouth and it’s time to really end it all on the right note.”This was the third straight summer Mourning considered retirement before choosing to keep playing. Next season will be his 15th in the N.B.A., not including a full year he missed with kidney problems that led to a transplant in 2003.
An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.7 hit northwestern Japan, causing small tsunamis and swaying buildings, but little significant damage.

An article on Thursday about a decision by the Libyan Supreme Court to uphold the death penalty for five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor, all of whom were found guilty of intentionally infecting Libyan children with the virus that causes AIDS, misidentified the title of Dimiter Tzantchev, a Bulgarian official who issued a statement about the case. He is the spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; he is not the foreign minister, the job held by Ivailo Kalfin.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) — It was the kind of game Phillies fans had seen thousands of times before.

The funeral of Officer Russel Timoshenko, who died Saturday, five days after he was shot during a traffic stop in Brooklyn, has been scheduled for 9:30 a.m. Thursday at the I. J. Morris funeral home in Flatbush.

The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Each player was suspended by the league Saturday without pay and was scheduled to miss the first seven games of next season. Artest would lose a little more than $470,000 in salary, about $50,000 more than Jackson.Jackson released a statement through the Golden State Warriors saying he accepted his suspension. But the union, comparing the penalties with other recent suspensions given to players for off-the-court reasons, may take action. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. Jackson pleaded guilty last month to a felony count of criminal recklessness for firing a gun outside an Indianapolis strip club last fall, when he was with the Indiana Pacers. The union has 30 days from Saturday to file an appeal to be heard by an arbitrator.

Arturo Gatti, a two-time world champion, said he was retiring Saturday after being stopped in the seventh round by Alfonso Gómez in a 147-pound bout.A stunned crowd of more than 9,000 in Atlantic City — where Gatti, 35, is almost as revered as the New Jersey icons Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi — looked on as Gómez punished Gatti, his former idol. Gatti, who grew up in Canada and moved to Jersey City in 1991, has a career record of 40-9.

Ending nearly three months of suspense about his future, Heat center Alonzo Mourning said last night at his annual Zo’s Summer Groove charity game in Miami that he would play again next season — a choice he kept secret to the end, insisting he was still deciding just hours before the actual announcement.“I will be coming back,” Mourning said.This was the third straight summer Mourning considered retirement before choosing to keep playing. Next season will be his 15th in the N.B.A., not including a full year he missed with kidney problems that led to a transplant in 2003.

Fourteen months after giving birth to her first child, Jennie Finch threw a three-hitter yesterday in her longest outing of the year as the United States advanced to the championship game of the World Cup of Softball with a 7-0 victory against Canada in Oklahoma City.Finch (1-0) struck out eight in six innings and extended her scoreless streak to 19 1/3 innings.“I haven’t felt this good in a long time,” said Finch, whose son, Ace, was born in May 2006. “It’s been a long year of hard work in the weight room and on the field trying to get back.”The United States (5-0) was the only team to make it through round-robin play undefeated. It will play Japan in the final. Japan defeated China, 3-1, late last night.
Detective Joshua Hahn remained in critical condition after being shot in the chest while trying to break up a fight outside a pizza parlor.

Two teenagers riding on the outside of a sport utility vehicle early Saturday were hurt when they slipped off, the Suffolk County police said. The two were standing on the rear bumper of a Ford Explorer and hanging onto the roof rack while the S.U.V. traveled down East Main Street in Kings Park, on Long Island, about 3:30 a.m., the police said. Both teenagers slipped as the driver, Taylor Kern, 17, of Kings Park, increased speed, the police said. One, Raymond Cuiffo, 16, of Selden, suffered a head injury and was in critical condition at Stony Brook University Medical Center, the police said. The other, Dylan Revere, 17, of Kings Park, suffered non-life-threatening injuries, the police said. Mr. Kern was charged with leaving the scene of an accident and reckless endangerment, the police said.

A Grammy-nominated rapper pleaded not guilty yesterday in the shooting of a 23-year-old woman in the meatpacking district early Saturday. The rapper, Remy Ma, 26, was charged with attempted murder, assault and weapons possession. The performer, whose real name is Remy Smith, surrendered to the police on Saturday night. She is charged with shooting Makeda Barnes-Joseph about 4 a.m. Saturday, the police said. Prosecutors said Ms. Smith and the shooting victim knew each other. Ms. Smith’s S.U.V. was found abandoned after a one-car accident two blocks from the scene of the shooting, the police said. Ms. Barnes-Joseph was in good condition in a hospital yesterday.

Residents of Jersey City and Hoboken were urged to continue boiling their drinking and cooking water yesterday, the day after a break in a water line caused widespread water losses and low pressure in the two cities. Residents of high-rise apartments in south Hoboken and the Newport section of Jersey City still had low pressure or no water at all after a contractor accidentally ruptured a 36-inch water main on Saturday afternoon. The incident disrupted service for several hours, although it was restored to most of Jersey City and Hoboken early Saturday evening. Full restoration of service was made more difficult because the main is more than 100 years old, the utility, United Water, said. The company said it could not estimate when repairs would be complete. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A man was stabbed to death in University Heights on Saturday evening, the police said. Shortly after 7 p.m., the police received reports of an assault inside 2285 University Avenue, officers said. When officers arrived, they found David Fuentes, 30, of 2300 University Avenue, had been stabbed repeatedly in the torso, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene. No arrests had been made as of yesterday evening.

Hundreds of officers were called in to control an unruly crowd of more than 500 young people who clashed beginning about 11 p.m. Saturday when revelers from a block party tried to crash another event in Ossining, the police said. No one was hurt and no one was arrested during the confrontation, which started when a block party merged with a sweet 16 party, Ossining Police Sgt. John Greenan said. Officers from the state police, Westchester County and New Rochelle were called in, and Sergeant Greenan said it took the officers until 3 a.m. yesterday to get everyone to leave.
The peace conference in Mogadishu was postponed until Thursday when none of the top opposition leaders showed up.
Katie Douglas scored 18 points and Cheryl Ford had 16 points and 13 rebounds to lead the East to its second straight victory, 103-99, against the West on Sunday.
Paris is trying to reduce traffic congestion by launching an ambitious bicycle program that will offer more than 20,000 bikes by the end of the year.
President Festus Mogae, who has served as president for 10 years, said he will hand over power to Vice President Seretse Khama Ian Khama in early 2008.

Lastings Milledge once again played a starring role in the finale of the Mets’ four-game series against the Cincinnati Red, hitting a two-run double that lifted the Mets to a victory.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,606 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:.

The third European Open Championships were held in Antalya, Turkey, June 15 to 30, with a much smaller American attendance this year because of tournament conflicts. The only medalists from the United States were Amos Kaminski and Sam Lev (winners of the Senior Teams with Yeshayahu Levit, Pinhas Romik, Adrian Schwartz and Rami Sheinman from Israel) and Victor Markowicz and Victor Melman (equal third in the Senior Teams with Shalom Zeligman from Israel and Aleksander Jezioro, Julian Klukowski and Jerzy Zaremba from Poland).
French government negotiators were in talks late Sunday with the two main private shareholders of EADS seeking to complete a deal on simplifying the company’s management structure.
Sony is trying to edge into Internet videos with a Web site called Crackle that will feature short segments by aspiring filmmakers.
The Pitchfork Music Festival was defined by an unlikely mixture of modesty and effrontery.

“Missing: Esquire Logo,” begins a cryptic item posted to Esquire.com on July 12. “Several days ago, in a burst of enthusiasm during a photo shoot, Benicio del Toro tossed our logo into the Los Angeles River in downtown L.A. It was last seen floating toward the Pacific Ocean at about 8 knots. Sentimental value. Possible reward.”.

Veteran opera buffs know all too well what it’s like to sit incredulously through some pointlessly elaborate new production wondering how it was possible to squander so much money for so little effect.

COMPANY REPORTS Earnings season gets into full swing, particularly for technology, financial and drug companies. Reports will come from Charles Schwab and Mattel (Monday); Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, Novartis, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Altria, AMR, Delta Air Lines, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Pfizer, Southwest Airlines and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, Continental Airlines, Dow Jones, First Data, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Motorola and Wyeth (Thursday); and Boston Scientific, Caterpillar and Citigroup (Friday).

KATZENOFF--Norma (Goldstein), 79, passed away July 14, 2007. Daughter of the late Meyer and Libby Goldstein, sister of the late Sylvia Sladon and Seymour Goldstein, Norma was the beloved wife and lifetime friend of Robert, cherished mother of Joanie (George) and Scott (Susan) and loving grandmother of Beth, Stacy, Marcus and Michael. Norma was a master bridge player and avid reader and found any excuse to laugh. Shiva will be held at 69 Crest Road, Chappaqua, NY and the family requests that all donations go to the Alzheimer's Association.

SEIDMAN--Irving, 90, passed July 12. Beloved husband of Eleanor for 64 years; loving father of Larry, Robbie (who, sadly, passed in 2003) and Leon; loving father-in-law of Ann and Lisa; adoring grandfather of Jesse, Suzanna, Jenny and Stephanie. WWII veteran. A truly wonderful man who built buildings, loved tennis, bridge and, most of all, his family. And his family loved him dearly and will miss him.
To the Editor: Re ''In Economics Departments, a Growing Will to Debate Fundamental Assumptions'' (Education page, July 11):

The San Francisco Opera's world-premiere run of Philip Glass's ''Appomattox,'' with the baritone Dwayne Croft as Robert E. Lee and the bass-baritone Andrew Shore as Ulysses S. Grant, will take place on Oct. 5 through 24, in seven performances at the War Memorial Opera House. With a libretto by the Tony Award winner Christopher Hampton, the opera about the surrender that ended the Civil War will be conducted through Oct. 20 by Dennis Russell Davies in his debut with the company, which commissioned the work. The final performance, when the baritone Brian Leerhuber will portray Lee, will be led by Sara Jobin.

HARD--Frederick Bourne, a resident of Edgehill in Stamford, CT died peacefully at age 96 on July 1, 2007. Mr. Hard had been for some time at the top of the seniority list of the New York Stock Exchange, having acquired his seat in 1933. During his long career, he served as partner and floor broker for several New York City firms, including Taylor, Smith & Hard, W. R. K. Taylor & Co., McMullen and Hard and lastly, for H. G. Wellington & Co., Inc. until his retirement. Born on October 10, 1910 in Sayville, New York, he was a son of Anson Wales Hard, Jr. and Florence (Bourne) Hard, a daughter of Commodore Frederick G. Bourne. On January 31, 1933 he married Hildegarde Stevenson, daughter of Joseph H. Stevenson and Hildegarde Kobbe. He and his wife lived in Bay Shore, New York and he commuted for many years to work at the New York Stock Exchange in the City. Mr. Hard was predeceased by three brothers, Anson Wales Hard, III, George Wales Hard and William Lawrence Hard and one sister, Florence H. ''Cherie'' Hughes. He is survived by his wife, Hildegarde, a brother, Kenneth Blanchard Hard and three sons, Frederick Bourne, Jr., of Wardsboro, Vermont; Michael Wales, of Tucson, Arizona and David Francis, of Boulder, Colorado. Also surviving are seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren, as well as many nephews, nieces, grandnephews and grandnieces. Instead of a formal service, relatives and friends are asked to set aside a few minutes, beginning at 2:30 PM EDT on Saturday, July 21, 2007 to remember him as each person feels appropriate. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Long Island Maritime Museum, P.O. Box 184, West Sayville, NY 11796, where Mr. Hard was one of the founders and served on the Board of Trustees for many years.

ATTERBURY--George Rosengarten, on July 10, 2007 at 95 of Ithan-Villanova, PA. Survived by his wife and five children, 10 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren, brother and two stepchildren. Services are pending. StuardArdmore: 610-649-0243

Beloved son of the late Samuel and Rose Fried, beloved brother of Phyllis Trautman, brother-in-law of Lois and Gerry Kirsh, uncle of Roy, Beth and David and Sam and Becky. Donations in his memory can be made to Westchester Day School or the Brandeis School. He will always be with us. Selma and Danny Bernice and Sam Sandy and Herb

To the Editor: ''Mr. Cheney's Minority Report,'' by Sean Wilentz (Op-Ed, July 9), identifies me as author of the 1987 Iran-contra committee's minority report. But I strongly disagree with his presenting the report as if it were in lockstep with Oliver North's view of the president as the ''sole organ'' of foreign policy.

FRANKEL--Catherine (Carrie), passed away on July 14th at the age of 99. Loving wife of the late Nathan, cherished mother of Jeanne Margolies and Ronnie and Kenny Berman. Adored grandmother of Marc and Margie Margolies, Melissa and Billy Gildin, Beth and Jonny Cohen, Jamie and Hera Berman and Neil and Beth Berman. Devoted great-greandmother to Ashley, Tyler, Hunter, Anderew, Brett, Robbie, Zachary, Brandon, Nathan, Mackenzie, Harper and Reese. Services Tuesday, July 17, 9:30am at Boulevard-Riverside Chaples, Hewlett.
BAUMWELL--Earl. Dad, we love you and miss you every day. Lisa, Jed and Peter

GOLDBERG--Rhoda Ochser, of Pensacola FL, formally of Dix Hills, NY, after a long illness on July 14th 2007. Mother of Alan and Jackie Goldberg of New York City, Jacqui and Matt O'Connell of Pensacola FL, grandmother of Jason, Ryan, Emily Rose, and Samuel George, sister of Anita and Philip Miller, wife of the late George Sundick Goldberg, with whom she shared 40 years of marriage. Mom was an art teacher by trade, and later became a leading authority on needlecrafts and the best selling author of 7 books on various needle arts. Mom was an incredibly involved parent, from PTA president to Cub Scout and Brownie leader. Her grandson Ryan began therapeutic horseback riding 4 years ago at The Leaning Post Ranch, and has gone on to be a two time Special Olympics gold medalist. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Mom's honor to: Panhandle Youth Assistance Program, Inc. 4150 Cedar Springs Dr, Molino, FL 32577. Funeral graveside at New Montefiore Cemetary, Farmingdale NY, Tuesday July 17th at 11:30am. Call I.J. Morris at 631-499-6060 for information. You will be truly, sorely and forever missed. Go keep Daddy company.

For Barry Bonds, the countdown has resumed: four home runs to tie Hank Aaron at 755, five to break the record. But Bonds has left what he described in San Francisco during the All-Star Game festivities as his town, his friends, his people. And now, the Giants will be playing four games, beginning today, in Chicago, where the fans in the ''friendly confines'' of Wrigley Field are not likely to be any friendlier to him than fans elsewhere in his travels in a Giants road gray uniform. And the Giants' schedule has raised the possibility of not only adding another controversy to the steroids suspicions surrounding Bonds, but also creating a reprise of the commotion over the former commissioner Bowie Kuhn's involvement in Aaron's approach to Babe Ruth's previous record, 714.

He is the spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; he is not the foreign minister, the job held by Ivailo Kalfin. (Go to Article)

Bidding has reached $1.5 million for a pair of John Lennon's gold wire-rimmed sunglass frames with curling ear stems, above, the BBC reported. ''The interest has been phenomenal,'' said John Warner, the sales director of the online auction house 991.com. ''Our phones have been in meltdown.'' Lennon wore the spectacles during the Beatles' 1966 tour of Japan, where the band played five dates in the Nippon Budokan hall in Tokyo but otherwise was isolated for security reasons at the Tokyo Hilton. During his stay Lennon became friendly with the band's Japanese translator, Junishi Yore, and after the final concert they exchanged gifts. Mr. Yore, who later became a television producer, gave Lennon a set of traditional copper cups; Lennon gave him a pair of his sunglasses. In a handwritten note from 1984, when he parted with the glasses, Mr. Yore told how, as a mark of respect, he removed the black lenses on the day Lennon was shot dead in New York in 1980. Mr. Warner said the sunglass frames came to the auction site from an American collector. Bidding is open until July 31.

In a good fairy tale, royalty is often a presence, and the new ballet of ''The Tinder Box,'' based on a story by Hans Christian Andersen, is no exception. Costumes and sets for the performances, which began on Saturday and continue through September at the Pantomime Theater in the Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen, are the work of Queen Margrethe of Denmark, 67 (above left, with performers), who has designed costumes for two previous Andersen adaptations. ''It has been incredibly fun to try again,'' she said. Written in 1835 by the author of ''The Ugly Duckling'' and ''The Little Mermaid,'' ''The Tinder Box'' tells of a soldier who finds a magical tinderbox that brings him vast riches but also nearly gets him killed.

To beat the Tampa Bay Devil Rays in a highlight festival Sunday, 7-6, the Yankees came from behind twice, survived inconsistent pitching, turned four double plays on the infield and threw out three runners from the outfield. They got a two-run homer from Derek Jeter, who also drove in another run. Their starting catcher, Wil Nieves, barely avoided ejection after an oral confrontation behind the plate with the umpire C. B. Bucknor. Their other catcher, Jorge Posada, was called for interference when a swinging bat hit his glove.

A sports article on Friday about Rick Dell, who was named the director of baseball operations in Asia for Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly to the length of a clinic he is attending in Guangzhou, China, where 140 coaches are being trained and certified. It runs for one week, not three. (Go to Article)

John Ferguson, a renowned roughneck on five Stanley Cup championship teams with the Montreal Canadiens who later became a general manager and coach in the National Hockey League, died Saturday at his home near Windsor, Ontario. He was 68. The cause was cancer, said his son, John Jr., the general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

An article on Thursday about a report predicting dire flooding and other weather changes in the Northeast if nothing is done to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated part of the title of Rohit T. Aggarwala, who said at a news conference accompanying the report's release that cutting emissions would not necessarily have a negative cost to business and consumers. He is New York City's director of long-term planning and sustainability, not stability. (Go to Article)

KAHN--Michele Davidow, 55, passed away on July 12 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital after stoically fighting lung cancer for more than two years. She was the beloved wife of Thomas Kahn for 35 years, loving devoted mother of Andrew, Elizabeth and Victoria, the cherished daughter of Sanford and Saundra Davidow and the adored sibling of Arline Shaffer and Harry Davidow. Michele received her BA from Beaver College and her MBA and MSW degrees from Columbia University. She later pursued her passion for the decorative arts through an MA from the Cooper Hewitt division of the Parsons School of Design. Captivated by the designs of Louis Comfort Tiffany, Michele worked on the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Tiffany show entitled Laurelton Hall and a traveling exhibition of Tiffany objects. She lectured at Sotheby's and the Smithsonian on this subject. As a longtime resident of NYC, she savored the vibrancy and culture of the metropolis, while balancing this passion with a love of literature and foreign exploration. With her husband, Tom, and friends she attended concerts, operas and theatre throughout the year. She also loved adventure. From her early travels to Argentina and Eastern Europe to her more recent voyages to China, Russia and Australia. Michele had bright eyes for new places and their arts. A devoted philanthropist, she supported the arts, education and lung cancer research. Michele was stylish, vivacious and deeply intellectual and carried a sharp wit wherever she went. She loved to entertain and delight her family and friends with a good story, and fabulous cooking and baking. Her indomitable spirit will always be with us. The family funeral is at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn on July 13 at 11am. The family will be sitting Shiva at 25 Central Park West, Saturday, Sunday and Monday from 6-9pm. A Memorial Service will be planned for early fall. $(6$)KAHN--Michele. We deeply mourn the passing of one of our oldest and dearest friends. Our lives will not be the same without Michele. Our hearts go out to all her family. Renee and Philippe Levi Nancy and Mike Kozeradsky Fern and Peter Margulies

MAHONEY--Stephen J., 73, formerly of Corry, PA died July 4, 2007 , at home, in Hilton Head Island, SC. He was son of the late Stephen and Agnes Graham Mahoney. He attended Our Lady Help of Christians in Brooklyn, graduated from LaSalle Academy in Manhattan and from Fordham University in 1955. He was a lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corps and served as an infantry officer in Okinawa and Japan. He worked for Davidson Steel Corporation in Manhattan. In 1964, he joined McInnes Steel Co. in Corry. He was with McInnes Steel for 34 years as General Sales Manager and VicePresident. He retired from McInnes in 1996 as President and C.E.O. He served as a member and officer on the Board of Directors of many charitable and professional organizations. He is survived by his former wife of forty years, Barbara J. Mahoney of Lansdale, PA; a son, Stephen Mahoney of Lakewood, CO; two daughters, Maribeth Pabst (Robert) of Glen Rock, NJ and Deirdre Garcia (Luis) of Audubon, PA and six grandchildren. Sandra Reed of Hilton Head Island, SC was his close friend and companion. Funeral services were held in Corry on July 10th, 2007 at St. Thomas the Apostle RCC. Memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 103, Corry, PA l6407 or to the Corry YMCA, 906 N. Center Street, Corry, PA l6407.

KALB--Morton I., on July 15, 2007, beloved husband of Mary. Loving father to Harry, father of Marjorie and Douglas. Stepfather to Harvey Strauser (Michelle) and Jill Marquette. Cherished stepgrandfather to Emily and Wilson Strauser. Brother to Hannah Beer and the late Rhoda Sherman. Brother-in-law to Leonard Sherman and Abraham Beer. Uncle to Jeffrey Sherman, Sandy Mayo (Mark), Dennis Beer (Joan), Susan Beer Schwartz (Sandy), and many grand nieces and nephews. Son of the late Harry and Shirley Kalb and Lillian Lam Kalb. Born and raised in Manhattan, Mort was a loyal, generous friend and business associate to many. He possessed a most engaging satiric sense of humor and he was an avid Yankee fan. He was a compassionate and authentic gentleman whose ability to live in the present moment touched the spirit of all who knew him. Service Tuesday, 11:45 am at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th and Amsterdam.

SWERBILOV--Sally Parker, age 80, passed away on July 11, 2007, in her home in Meredith, NY. She was a Federal Commissioner of Mediation and Conciliation from 1971-1995. Before that Sally was a Mediator with the NJ Public Employment Relations Commission. She also worked in the Deptartment of Research and Negotiations, District Council 37, AFSCME. From 1955 to 1967 Sally was a National Representative for the American Federation of Teachers. In 1954-55 Sally was a Senior Fulbright Scholar, Leicester, England. Her positions also included, from 195254 Coordinator of Films at the Labor Education Division of Roosevelt Univ., Chicago; and from 1949-1952 a research assistant in the Education Department of the AFL. Sally leaves her devoted husband of 45 years, Zarvin; her beloved sons Daniel and Nicholas and their cherished wives, Diane and Beatrice. Sally was very proud of her grandsons: Max, Zusse, Nick Dan, and Justin; proud of her nieces: Meg Smith, Julie Chavez, Kate Porter, and Kathryn Reuter; her nephews: Ben Donner, Michael Seeber, Stephen Seeber. Her sister Carol Parker Donner and brother-in-law John Donner remained in her heart as did brother-in-law Boris Seeber and sister-in-law, Dorothy Seeber.

To the Editor: Re ''Patrons' Sway Leads to Friction in Charter School'' (front page, June 28): The board of trustees of the Beginning With Children Charter School did have a significant issue regarding the governance of the school. The three school staff members, the three parent members and the foundation members all had another relationship with the school that conflicted with their primary assignment of governance. This situation required remediation.

He was respected and loved by all who knew him.

O'Connor of Yorktown Heights, NY and his sister Kathleen McIntyre of Hopewell Junction, NY and Virginia Tyhacz of Brookfield, CT, as well as several devoted nieces and nephews. the family is having a private viewing at Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home 2-4 and 7-9pm. The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.96 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.04 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.68 percent.

A top Bush administration official urged Congress on Sunday to drop its efforts to limit the American troop mission in Iraq, at least until a more definitive progress report comes in September, and he appeared to try to set lower expectations for what the report would show. Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, gently rebuffed a proposal from two leading Republicans who favor a changed policy on Iraq, Senators Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and John W. Warner of Virginia. Their proposal would give President Bush until October to submit a plan to begin limiting the involvement of American forces in Iraq.

Harrison Ford turned 65 on Friday, but 18 years after appearing in ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' he is at work on the fourth installment of the adventures of the intrepid archaeologist. Despite his many starring roles since then, Mr. Ford, right, hasn't grown too big for his breeches or his familiar fedora, the producers told The Associated Press. His outfit still fits, and he is doing many of his own stunts. ''He's doing them; he just has a few more ice packs and a few more massages,'' said Kathleen Kennedy, a co-executive producer with George Lucas. After a week in Connecticut and a week in New Mexico, the production is on location for three weeks on Hawaii's Big Island, which is standing in for a South American rain forest. The untitled film is scheduled for release on May 22.

ROBINSON--George J. II, a long time New York and international maritime executive, died July 13 surrounded by Tucky, his wife of 63 years, and their five children. Born in Brooklyn, New York, December 7, 1920, he left Niagara University to enlist in the Navy where he attended Notre Dame University's Midshipman's School. He served in the Pacific and rose to Lieutenant J.G. He moved to Hillsdale, New Jersey in 1950 where he lived for 54 years. He is survived by his sisters Virginia Gladwell and Sister Mary Borgia, his children Susan King, Patsy Michaels, Marylou Robinson, George Robinson III and Jody Fargo. Grandfather to ten, great-grandfather to three, his legacy of love continues. Visiting Tuesday 2-4, 7-9 Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave. Wyckoff, NJ, Funeral Mass Wednesday, 11am at St. Cassian R.C. Church, 187 Bellevue Ave., Upper Montclair, NJ 07043.

President Festus Mogae has announced that he is stepping down next year after a decade at the helm of this diamond-rich southern African nation. Mr. Mogae, 67, told members of the governing Botswana Democratic Party on Saturday that he would serve an additional nine months as head of state and then hand over the position to Vice President Seretse Khama Ian Khama before a general election in October 2009.

When the British advertising magnate Charles Saatchi opens his new gallery on Kings Road in London early next year, admission to the 70,000-square-foot exhibition space will be free. Although museums in London do not charge for admission, they do impose an entrance fee for special exhibitions. At the Saatchi gallery there will be no charge to see either installations from its permanent collection or special shows. Phillips de Pury & Company, the boutique auction house with headquarters in New York, will partner with the Saatchi Gallery to finance the initiative. Officials at the Saatchi Gallery estimate they will now be able to attract about one million visitors a year.

If the Yankees and the Red Sox are searching for a new aspect of their rivalry to explore, they could look to their support in stadiums like Tropicana Field, a haven for opposing fans. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays drew 123,806 for a four-game series against the Yankees that ended Sunday. That number included sellouts Saturday and Sunday, the first consecutive sellouts at Tropicana Field in team history, and accounted for more than one-sixth of the total attendance at the stadium this year.

WALKER--Florence Dauman, on July 14, 2007 at age 97 in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved wife of the late Irving Walker, loving mother of Robert Walker. Visitation Tuesday July 17th, 6-8pm at Riverside Funeral Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NY, NY. Burial Wednesday July 18th, 1:30pm at Riverside Cemetery, 12 Market Street, Saddlebrook, NJ.

Nearly a fifth of Harry Potter fans say they plan to skip immediately to Page 608 to find out who's standing when the final volume of the boy wizard's adventures is published on Saturday, Reuters reported. According to a poll of 500 children taken for the British bookstore chain Waterstone's, 17 percent are going to peek to see precisely what the author, J. K. Rowling meant when she said ''more than two'' characters would die in ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.'' But a third of the children said they were prepared to stay up all night to read all the way through. ...Two girls have been camping out since Tuesday in front of Gulliver's Books in Fairbanks, Alaska, to be among the first to get their hands on the seventh volume, The Associated Press reported. The sisters, Chloe Bostian, 18, and Sydney Bostian, 11, have been living out of their parents' camper in the store's parking lot. ''It's the big finale, and all the questions are going to be answered,'' Chloe said.
DIONNE--Albert. Our sympathy and support go to our friend and partner. Bill Dionne and his family at this time of loss. Robert M. Hayes President, Medicare Rights Center

MULLIGAN--Roseanna Connelly, age 84, devoted wife of the late Hon. William H. Mulligan, former dean of Fordham Law School, member of U.S. Court of Appeals (2d Cir.) and partner of Skadden Arps. Loving mother of Anne O. Hartmere, William H. Mulligan, Jr. (Mary Liz) and Stephen E. Mulligan; adoring grandmother of Michael C. Hartmere (Virginia), Maura Logan (Kevin), Jenny, Billy, Kate and Rory Mulligan, great-grandmother of Jacob, Stephen and Abigail Hartmere; caring sister of Genie Flannery and Neil Connelly. Elegant, beautiful and dignified, she will be sorely missed by everyone who knew and loved her. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7-9 Tuesday and 2-4 and 7-9 Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Thursday, July 19 at 10 am.

The rich got richer when it came to presidential fund-raising last quarter as the Democrats saw their big financial edge over the Republicans extend even to lesser-known candidates. And in both parties the financial gap between the leaders and the rest of the pack widened. All told, the eight Democrats running for president raised more than $80 million from April 1 to June 30, while the 10 Republicans raised less than $50 million, according to the campaigns, which released details on Sunday night of their fund-raising and spending.

Over the protests of music retailers, the pop star Prince gave away about three million copies of his new 10-track album, ''Planet Earth,'' yesterday in copies of the British newspaper The Mail on Sunday, Agence France-Presse reported. The album is not scheduled to go on sale until July 24, and Prince also plans to give away copies of the CD to fans who attend the 21 concerts he will give in London next month and September. A spokesman said, ''Prince's only aim is to get music direct to those what want to hear it.'' Peter Wright, the editor of The Mail on Sunday, told BBC radio yesterday that it had paid Prince for the license to produce the album and to press and advertise it. Reports have put the fee at $500,000 to $1 million. In a speech last month Paul Quirk, co-chairman of the Entertainment Retailers Association, representing British music stores, objected to the giveaway, saying, ''It is an insult to all those record stores who have supported Prince throughout his career.''

We've spent the last few posts looking back at the Copa América to find the lessons of Brazil's pragmatic victory, Argentina's frustrated brilliance, Mexico's revival, Venezuela's success both on and off the field -- and all of it seems pretty straightforward. But then there are the lessons that US soccer may or may not have learned ... if only we could figure out what those lessons are.

The latest U.S. Treasury data on international capital flows indicates that China was a net seller of Treasury securities in May. The numbers, which are estimates and should not be taken as gospel, indicate that China unloaded about $6.6 billion of Treasuries -- around half of them Treasury bills and the rest long-term securities.

Pogo Producing agreed Tuesday to sell itself to another oil and gas producer for $3.5 billion in cash and stock, but the deal with Plains Exploration & Production was as much about shareholder activism and taxes as it was about energy.

After Britain's "clear and proportionate signal" regarding Moscow's refusal to hand over a suspect in the murder of Alexander V. Litvinenko, Moscow is promising a "precisely targeted and adequate" response.

Day one of the U.S. Women's Championship ended with Anna Zatonskih, the defending champion, Camilla Baginskaite, Katerina Rohanyan and Tsagaan Battsetseg tied for the lead, each with 1.5 points out of 2. While watching David Wells, as round as ever, pitch six clever innings in San Diego's 5-1 victory over the Mets on Monday night, it was hard, as always, not to wonder how good the left-hander might have been if he focused more on conditioning throughout his career.

Why would a firm in the traditionally secretive hedge-fund business want to open its kimono as part of an initial public offering? In the case of Och-Ziff Capital Management, William Hutchings of Financial News has a theory. Citing the language in the offering prospectus, he suggests that one of the main reasons behind Och-Ziff's proposed $2 billion offering is to make sure its partners feel the pain if they underperform.

A jaguar, according to Dictionary.com, is a large spotted feline, sporting a tawny coat with black rosettes. It's also the name of the British brand of sports car, which has been put up for sale by the Ford Motor Company. Ever since Ford bought Jaguar (the car company, not the cat) in 1990, there has been some confusion in the States over the correct way to say its name.
So much for schadenfreude.
The Rolling Stones might be the one rock band from the 60s that can get away with playing a private show for investment bankers without having to endure complaints that they are "selling out."

This is the point where we start taking down the nets, uprooting the corner flags and closing up our blog until next time. Soccer fans are a fortunate bunch: the sport is played year-round. And thanks to the expanding digital universe, we get to see most of it on TV. This past weekend, you could watch the U-20s slugging it out in Canada, catch the final stages of the Copa América, and watch Iraq beat Australia in the Asian Cup. MLS will stage its All-Star game this Thursday, David Beckham suits up for the LA Galaxy against Chelsea on Saturday (provided his dodgy ankle allows him to play), before you know it the European calendar will be starting up and ... well, you've got to stop somewhere.
