Now that all of the presidential campaigns have filed their latest financial reports, news organizations are slicing and dicing the data, looking for the story behind the numbers. A natural place to start is with Illinois Senator Barack Obama, who raised more money last quarter than any other candidate, Democrat or Republican. The Times's David D. Kirkpatrick, Mike McIntire and Jeff Zeleny focus on another data point the Obama campaign has been touting - the 258,000 donors the campaign has attracted since the beginning of the year.

Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world's largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch's subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan Chase and other Wall Street firms are stuck with at least $11 billion of loans and bonds they cannot readily sell, after being compelled to dig into their own pockets to finance parts of at least five leveraged buyouts in the last month, Bloomberg News reported.

The Alliance Bancorp, a residential mortgage lender based in Brisbane, Calif., has filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy and will liquidate its assets. The company listed assets and debts of more than $100 million each in its bankruptcy petition, which was filed Friday in Delaware.

Citigroup agreed to pay $978,000 to settle a New Jersey investigation into accusations that it failed to supervise two brokers whose trading strategies cost clients, including many older customers, more than $3 million, state regulators said Monday.
General Motors said on Monday that it was buying 50 percent of the Italian diesel engine maker VM Motori from Penske and would introduce a new high-performance V6 diesel engine built by VM Motori.

The days of throwing money to hedge funds focusing on mortgage-backed securities are over as margin requirements have toughened, The New York Post reported Tuesday. Citing unnamed managers at three hedge funds, the paper said that investment banks like Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns have cut back on extending loans to such funds.
Novartis on Tuesday showed growing interest in pursuing takeovers, just as its core pharmaceuticals business suffered the most severe competition to date from lower-priced generic rival products.

Just days after failing in its bid to acquire the chemical maker Huntsman, Basell, a Dutch manufacturer, said Tuesday it would buy another American competitor, Lyondell Chemical, for $12.1 billion in cash.

On the heels of a rival bid by a the Royal Bank of Scotland-led consortium, Barclays is planning to raise its offer for ABN Amro, The Financial Times reported Tuesday. But analysts warn that Barclays should instead pick up its marbles and go home.
The Karachi Stock Exchange is entertaining offers from overseas partners for a 10 percent stake in the company ahead of its initial public offering, which could happen early next year.

Deutsche Bank and Pirelli & C. Real Estate will buy Baubecon from Cerberus Capital Management for 350 million euros ($482 million) in a transaction valued at 1.7 billion euros. A Deutsche Bank unit, RREEF, will purchase 60 percent of Baubecon's residential properties while Pirelli Re will acquire the rest.

BASF is in talks with a potential buyer of part of its plastics operation that generate $4.4 billion in revenue. The operations include factories in Belgium, Mexico, Brazil, South Korea and India, reported Bloomberg News citing a BASF e-statement on Tuesday.

Banco Votorantim plans to open an investment-banking unit to take advantage of record stock and bond offerings in Latin America's biggest economy. The Brazilian bank is controlled by a billionaire, Antonio Ermirio de Moraes and is the country's 10th-biggest financial group.

Spurred on by speculation of a second takeover offer, shares of Orica, an explosives maker, rose 5.5 percent on the Australian Stock Exchange Tuesday. The company previously rejected a bid of 32 Australian dollars a share, or 9.95 billion Australian dollars ($8.7 billion), but there is new talk of bid of $37 a share, Bloomberg News reported.
HSBC has confirmed its interest in a takeover of the Korea Exchange Bank in a deal possibly valued at more than 2.5 billion pounds ($5.1 billion), The Daily Telegraph reported Tuesday.
Territory Resources has offered 966 million Australian dollars ($843 million) in a takeover bid for Consolidated Minerals, Bloomberg News reported.

MassMutual and the Jefferies Group are coming to NovaStar Financial's rescue. The struggling subprime mortgage lender will receive $150 million in new equity as part of multiple agreements from the two groups.

Three former Securities and Exchange Commission officials, including two former chairmen, William H. Donaldson and Arthur Levitt, on Monday asked for permission to intervene in a Supreme Court dispute that could determine whether defrauded investors can recover money from third parties, The Washington Post reported.

Certeon has drummed up $15 million in a Series B round of venture funding. The round was led by RRE Ventures with Sigma Partners, Globespan Capital, Dow Employees' Pension Plan, and Union Carbide Employees' Pension Plan also participating.

Credit Suisse has acquired about 15 percent of India's Park Hotels chain. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but unnamed sources told Finance Asia that Credit Suisse will pay between $50 million and $55 million for the stake to value the hotel chain at around $350 million.
Indonesia will see its largest initial public offering next month when it sells almost 26 percent of Bank Negara Indonesia, the country's third largest bank by assets, The Financial Times reported.

UBS has been hired to help China's largest oil and gas group, PetroChina, raise up to $6 billion in what will be one of the biggest listings on the country's mainland market. The Financial Times said that the deal highlights UBS's determination to grab a big slice of the Chinese public offerings market.

As the high-yield debt market stalls, investment banks are increasingly holding the bag. According to data compiled by Bloomberg News, Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan Chase and the rest of Wall Street have about $11 billion worth of loans and bonds they cannot readily sell.

Haitong Securities shareholders have approved a plan to quadruple its capital to help expand into investment banking and compete with overseas brokerages, the company said. The Shanghai-based company, one of China's three publicly traded brokers, will sell 1 billion new shares for at least 13.15 yuan ($1.74) each to no more than 10 institutional investors including mutual funds, brokers, asset managers and insurers.

Apax Partners is in talks with Air France about a possible bid for Spain's Iberia, The Financial Times reported. A rival group led by the Texas Pacific Group and British Airways has already made an indicative offer valuing the Spanish carrier at $4.7 billion.

A Barcelona-based drugmaker Laboratorio Almirall has agreed to spend 255 million pounds ($518.9 million) on Reckitt Benckiser's Hermal skincare unit. TheDeal.com noted that Almirall, which raised about 634 million euros in an initial public offering last month in Spain, has a market value of about 2.3 billion euros.
An investment group backed by the Carlyle Group has pulled out of the bidding to buy Queen Seaport Development, the bankrupt operator of the legendary Queen Mary cruise liner.

Novocell, a stem-cell researcher, has drummed up a further $25 million in venture funding from insider investors. The latest round was led by Johnson & Johnson Development. Other insiders included Sanderling Ventures, Asset Management and Pacific Horizon Ventures.

Apparent Networks raised $13.6 million in a Series B round, with new investors Bain Capital Ventures and JMI Equity at the lead. Apparent Networks, a network performance management software maker, plans to ramp up growth with increased emphasis on high-volume channel partnerships, TheDeal.com said.

Carrefour is expanding its reach in Spain by agreeing to pay 200 million euros ($275.4 million) for 250 Spanish discount retailers, TheDeal.com reported. The Spanish stores are being acquired from a privately held German retailing giant Tengelmann Warenhandelsgesellschaft.
A new generation of risqué cabaret acts is giving a nod to the politics of today.

Over the weekend, Mission West Properties, a real estate investment trust, said it had begun negotiations about being acquired in a deal valued at about $1.8 billion by an unnamed "leading real estate private equity fund." TheDeal.com said that although media reports pegged the presumed buyer as Starwood Capital Group Global, the group declined comment on Monday.
Lincolnshire Management's portfolio company, Cutters Wireline Service, has purchased Lone Wolf Wireline for an undisclosed price, TheDeal.com reported Tuesday.

By its own measures, everything looks good at ACA Capital Holdings, a financial management and insurance company. But other numbers do not look so good, and the stock price is falling rapidly. The company will not comment on what is going on.

Rupert Murdoch reportedly moved a major step closer to achieving his long-standing aim of acquiring The Wall Street Journal when Dow Jones tentatively agreed to be acquired by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation yesterday.
“The Bill Engvall Show,” beginning tonight on TBS and starring Mr. Engvall, a popular force in the Blue Collar Comedy Tour, is perhaps best approached as a drinking game.
Having learned something from “American Idol,” “Without Prejudice” shifts its focus almost entirely away from the contestants and puts it squarely on the judges.

Demand for calorie labels on restaurant food is sweeping the country. New York City is ahead of the trend - a law requiring calorie counts to be posted next to prices in some restaurants went into effect July 1, though it will not be enforced until October.
Three-bedroom homes in Northport, Me., and Traverse City, Mich., and a loft condo in Los Angeles.

I don't really know if Andy Phillips can be an everyday first baseman in the major leagues. I know that his minor-league numbers have been terrific. I know that he is hitting .375 this month and playing very well in the field.
The company told investors that two of its troubled hedge funds that bet heavily on risky subprime loans now have “very little value.”
A toxic cloud from the crash poisoned about 20 people and forced another about 800 to evacuate their homes, authorities said.

The White House political office directed the nation’s drug czar and his deputies to appear at about 20 political events with vulnerable Republican members of Congress before the 2006 elections, according to documents.
The federal government still has limited capacity to detect a disease outbreak and track its progress across the country.
Yahoo said its net income for the second quarter was $161 million, or 11 cents a share, almost unchanged from the same period a year ago, as revenues rose to $1.7 billion.
The chip maker, a closely watched indicator of the overall health of the technology industry, reported net income of $1.3 billion, on revenue of $8.7 billion in the second quarter.
After overseeing the rising fortunes of the Xbox 360 game console, Peter Moore will run the sports division of the leading game publisher.
The results of toxicology tests on Chris Benoit’s body revealed that he had been injecting himself with testosterone shortly before the killings.
R. James Nicholson’s term was marked by the theft of a laptop computer that compromised the personal information of tens of millions of people.
What appear to be pages from the eagerly awaited final installment in the series have been circulating online.
The World Trade Organization called on the United States and Europe to lower their farm barriers in return for greater access to India, Brazil and other parts of the developing world for exports.
A blast went off at a site in Islamabad where the embattled former chief justice of the Supreme Court was set to speak.
The U.S. faces “a persistent and evolving terrorist threat” from Al Qaeda, according to the nation’s intelligence agencies.
The British government expelled four Russian diplomats in retaliation for Russia’s refusal to extradite the main suspect in a murder investigation.
A series of severe thunderstorms packing heavy rainfall were moving across the Upper Midwest.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg accused Albany lawmakers of failing to take action against climate change and air pollution.
Pratibha Patil, who is likely to be elected India’s first female president on Thursday, has faced vitriolic attacks.
In the Iraqi Parliament, the political bloc loyal to the anti-American Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr halted its four-and-a-half-week boycott.
Japanese authorities today suspended the operation of a nuclear power plant damaged by yesterday’s earthquake.
The Mets’ offensive ineptitude helped Michael Barrett’s two-run single in the second inning hold up and spoil starter Jorge Sosa’s return from the disabled list.

Tairia Flowers homered and Cat Osterman allowed only three hits as the United States defeated Japan, 3-0, in the World Cup of Softball championship game in Oklahoma City last night. It was the Americans’ 22nd victory in a row and second consecutive World Cup title.
Dow Jones & Company tentatively agreed to be acquired by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation on Monday.

A former police officer ran down his ex-girlfriend and her new companion in a courthouse parking lot and was fatally shot in a gunfight with a police officer in Totowa, N.J., last night, officials said. The officer was also shot, but was not severely wounded.
ATLANTA, June 16 (AP) — Ken Griffey Jr. passed Frank Robinson for sixth place on the career home run list in the Cincinnati Reds’ 10-3 victory over the Braves on Monday night.

The state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, and his staff said yesterday that more than a hundred pages of internal records were discovered to be missing after the resignation in the spring of David Loglisci, a former top official in their office. Mr. Loglisci was deputy comptroller for pension investment and cash management under Mr. DiNapoli’s predecessor, Alan G. Hevesi. The documents were related to investment decisions made by the state pension fund. All but two or three pages of the records have been recovered from other sources, members of Mr. DiNapoli’s staff said. The issue of the missing records has emerged as Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares, are investigating ethical and management lapses during Mr. Hevesi’s four-year tenure. Mr. Hevesi pleaded guilty to a felony and resigned in December after being accused of ordering state workers to chauffeur his ailing wife. Mr. DiNapoli said that the documents’ absence was noticed soon after Mr. Loglisci resigned and that the Albany County district attorney’s office was notified at once. The missing documents were reported on Monday by The New York Post. Efforts to reach Mr. Loglisci for comment last night were unsuccessful.

Water utility officials last night lifted an advisory that residents of Jersey City and Hoboken boil water before drinking it. The move came two days after a break in a water line caused widespread loss of service and low pressure in the two cities. United Water, the utility that serves Jersey City and Hoboken, issued the advisory about 5 p.m. Saturday after a contractor accidentally ruptured a 36-inch water main that was installed in 1924. Crews began working around the clock to fix the main, and the advisory was lifted after the repairs were completed. Laboratory tests of water samples taken throughout the affected areas showed that the water remained safe at all times while the advisory was in effect. The utility is investigating how the accident occurred.
For the second game in a row, Andy Phillips drove in the pivotal run for the Yankees, who survived another shaky start from Kei Igawa for their ninth victory in 12 games.

ALBANY, July 16 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer raised about $3.7 million during the first six months of his first term, despite limiting himself to contributions of $10,000 or less, according to campaign finance filings released on Monday by the State Board of Elections.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 16 (AP) — Seve Ballesteros officially retired from golf Monday, ending a career filled with spectacular shots.

The prosthetic legs that the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius uses provide less air resistance than normal legs, the International Association of Athletic Federations said yesterday.Pistorius, who wears curved carbon-fiber prosthetic legs, hopes to compete at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. The I.A.A.F., the sport’s governing body, has been reviewing footage of Pistorius’s running the 400 meters Friday in Rome to determine if his prosthetic racing legs give him an unfair advantage. Pistorius ran 46.90 seconds to finish second.

Because of an ankle injury, David Beckham was limited to some stretching and kicking drills in his first practice yesterday since joining the Los Angeles Galaxy. He is scheduled to make his debut Saturday in an exhibition against Chelsea, but Galaxy Coach Frank Yallop said Beckham was day to day.

An article on Saturday about a guilty plea by an employee of a Halliburton subsidiary who admitted receiving kickbacks in exchange for awarding contracts to supply equipment to the American military in Iraq and Kuwait misidentified that employee. It was Anthony J. Martin, 58, of Houston who pleaded quilty — not Rodger A. Heaton, who as attorney general for the Central District of Illinois prosecuted the case.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the anonymous online postings of John Mackey, chief executive of Whole Foods Market, misstated the status of a Securities and Exchange Commission examination of the posts. It is an informal inquiry, not a formal one.
Corrections

An article on July 7 about Bridgeville, Calif., which is up for sale for the third time in five years, referred incorrectly to the role eBay played in the town’s sale the first two times. The town was advertised on the Web site’s real estate auction site; it was not auctioned off or otherwise sold through a typical eBay transaction between buyers and sellers, or “through the impulsive rush of online bidding.”.
Because of an editing error, a television review yesterday about “Greek,” on ABC Family, misstated the date the series began. It was July 9, not last night.

An article on July 8 about the dispute between the White House and Congress over the dismissal of United States attorneys misstated the number of prosecutors who were fired. It was 9 — not 93, the total number of the Justice Department’s United States attorneys.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about lobbying by hedge fund and private equity fund executives against a proposal that would increase their tax liability misspelled the surname of one executive, a co-founder of the Blackstone Group. He is Stephen A. Schwarzman, not Schwartzman.

An article in Sunday Styles this week about the popularity of the video game Guitar Hero among bar patrons misspelled the surname of an artist whose song appears in the game, and misstated the title of that song. He is Stevie Ray Vaughan, not Vaughn, and the song is “Texas Flood,” not “Texas Blood.”.

A picture caption on Saturday about anxiety in the Muslim world over the radicalism among its doctors and engineers misidentified the religion of Dr. George Habash, founder of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a leftist group, whose photograph was shown with those of Muslim professionals identified as militants. He is Christian, not Muslim.

A sports article yesterday about the Yankees’ victory over the Devil Rays on Sunday referred incorrectly in some copies to the teams’ series this weekend at Yankee Stadium. They will play four games, not three.
If all goes well with the rest of his rehabilitation assignment, Moises Alou, who has not played since straining his left quadriceps May 12, should rejoin the Mets next week.
Three New York City public school teachers and two former officials from Touro College were indicted for a “cash for grades scheme.”

About 2,000 firearms seized in Essex County are being destroyed, Paula T. Dow, the Essex County prosecutor, said yesterday. Ms. Dow said about 500 of the seized firearms — assault weapons, rifles and handguns — were destroyed yesterday. She said the county had 155 homicides in 2006, 127 of them gun-related, and has had 78 homicides this year, 56 of them involving guns.

Four men claiming to be police officers — including two wearing New York Police Department shirts — burst into an apartment early Saturday, molested a woman and stole several valuables, the Yonkers police said yesterday. Detectives do not believe the intruders were police officers, Lt. Diane Hessler said. The men knocked at the apartment door, identified themselves as police officers when a 33-year-old male tenant opened the door, and ordered him to the floor, the police report said. The men had badges and handguns and shouted, “Where are the drugs?” as they ransacked the apartment. Two of the men entered a bedroom and sexually abused a 30-year-old woman, the police said. The men left with a cellphone, a laptop computer, a diamond ring and a gold chain, the police said. No arrests had been made by yesterday afternoon.

A behavioral health care organization and its parent companies have agreed to pay more than $1 million in back wages to 143 employees, the federal Labor Department said yesterday. The company, Stonington Behavioral Health in North Stonington, doing business as Stonington Institute, and its parent companies, Universal Health Services and U.H.S. of Delaware, were accused by the federal agency of paying employees less than the federal minimum and overtime wages. A spokesman for Stonington Institute did not return a phone call seeking comment yesterday. The companies agreed, without admitting liability, to a consent judgment to resolve the matter, the Labor Department said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The city has filed legal papers in support of a challenge to New York State’s method of selecting judges that is now pending before the United States Supreme Court, officials said yesterday. The case, New York State Board of Elections v. Lopez Torres, is scheduled to be argued before the court in October. Challengers claim the current use of judicial conventions to pick State Supreme Court judges is unconstitutional, and lower courts have agreed, proposing a system of open primaries rather than conventions, which are typically dominated by political parties. The primaries have been stayed pending the Supreme Court’s ruling. Although the city favors a merit-based appointment system for judges, Michael A. Cardozo, the corporation counsel, said yesterday that the current system “desperately needs to be reformed.”.

A senior at Lewis S. Mills High School who was forced to resign as class secretary last spring after she used a vulgarity to describe school officials on a public Web site filed a lawsuit yesterday in New Britain Superior Court, claiming that her right to free speech was violated and seeking a new student election during the coming school year. The senior, Avery Doninger, 16, was banned from running for re-election, forbidden to wear a T-shirt promoting free speech and removed as a graduation speaker after her Web site post. .

A man charged with shooting a Mercer County Sheriff’s Department detective outside a pizza restaurant on Sunday was arrested in Trenton yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Billy Walter Heisler, was charged with attempted homicide and was being held yesterday in $1 million bail. “Heisler is a dangerous felon with a history of violence,” said the Mercer County prosecutor, Joseph L. Bocchini. Mr. Bocchini said Mr. Heisler, 27, was believed to be a ranking member of the Sex, Money, Murder sect of the Bloods street gang. He is charged with shooting Detective Josh Hahn, 29, after Mr. Hahn tried to intervene in a dispute between Mr. Heisler and his sister, Shannon. Detective Hahn was in critical condition yesterday.

The city has extended the period during which the public can comment on proposed photography rules that have been criticized by civil libertarians, officials said yesterday. The proposed rules would require a permit and proof of $1 million in insurance for any group of two or more people filming in one location for 30 minutes, or five or more people using a tripod camera for more than 10 minutes. The city planned to stop receiving public comments on the rules on June 27, but it has agreed to extend the period to Aug. 3, city officials said. Christopher Dunn, of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said yesterday that the rules would unreasonably burden photographers and “open the door to selective and discriminatory enforcement.”.

The judge presiding over Jayson Williams’s retrial for the fatal shooting of a hired driver in 2002 ruled yesterday that parts of a 911 call made by Mr. Williams’s brother the night of the shooting should be excluded from the trial. The entire tape was played during Mr. Williams’s original trial. Yesterday, Superior Court Judge Edward M. Coleman ruled that statements made by Mr. Williams’s brother Victor regarding the emergency could be played, but other statements — including an assertion that the driver, Costas Christofi, shot himself — could not be played. Mr. Williams, above, a former player for the New Jersey Nets, was acquitted of aggravated manslaughter in 2004 but was convicted of trying to cover up the killing. The defense has said that Mr. Christofi’s shooting was an accident. Jurors were unable to reach a verdict on a charge of reckless manslaughter, for which Mr. Williams now faces a new trial.

Posco, the South Korean steel maker, said its second-quarter net profit rose 56 percent on cost-cutting and robust sales of value-added steel products. Posco, based in Pohang, said net profit for the three months ended June 30 climbed to 1.11 trillion won ($1.21 billion) from 716 billion won a year earlier. Sales rose 25 percent, to 5.82 trillion won ($6.34 billion). “Steep cost reduction and strong demand for high-end products such as auto steel plates and electrical steel gave a hefty boost to the second-quarter result,” said Ko Min-jin, a company spokeswoman.

Reliance Communications, a mobile-services provider in India, said it was buying Yipes Holdings of San Francisco, a provider of managed ethernet and application-delivery services, for $300 million. “Yipes will accelerate Reliance’s entry into the $90 billion global market for enterprise and institutional data services,” the chairman, Anil Ambani, said at a news conference. Reliance bought Yipes from a group of investors including JP Morgan and the venture capital firms Norwest Venture Partners, Sprout Group and Crosslink Capital. Reliance said it would expand Yipes in the United States from 14 cities to 30 and would branch into Asia, Europe and Africa.

India’s biggest software company, Tata Consultancy Services, said profit in the April-June quarter rose 37 percent from a year ago, as new outsourcing contracts helped offset a stronger rupee and higher salaries. Net income rose to 11.86 billion rupees ($291 million) in the quarter, up 37.4 percent from 8.63 billion rupees ($187 million) in the period a year ago, the company said. Revenue rose to 52.03 billion rupees ($1.28 billion) from 41.44 billion rupees ($900 million). Tata, based in Mumbai, said it won six customers, including a leading Asian telecommunications company, with contracts valued at more than $100 million each for the fiscal year ending in March.

International Business Machines will purchase the DataMirror Corporation for 170 million Canadian dollars ($161 million) to gain programs that help businesses access data faster. I.B.M. bid 27 Canadian dollars a share for all the outstanding common stock of DataMirror, which is based in Markham, Ontario. The price represents a 20 percent premium to DataMirror’s closing price on Friday, which was 22 Canadian dollars a share. I.B.M. will gain more than 2,200 customers with the purchase.

The Empire Company, which owns the Sobeys supermarket chain in Canada, agreed to buy Thrifty Foods for 260 million Canadian dollars ($249 million) including debt. The acquisition, which will quadruple the number of grocery stores Empire has in British Columbia, includes 20 stores, a distribution center and a wholesale division. Thrifty Foods, with 3,700 employees, will become a unit of Sobeys.
A black man charged in the shooting death of a white youth who followed his son home after a racially tinged quarrel at a party will face a jury later this year.
Senator Barack Obama’s campaign has used novel tactics, like counting sales of $4.50 key chains as contributions, to pump up numbers and build support.
South Africa charged two apartheid-era officials on Monday with attempted murder in the poisoning of a prominent black minister in 1989.
A federal judge’s sharply worded ruling blaming prosecutors was the latest twist in what the government has billed as its showpiece tax shelter case.
The Bush administration signaled that it will make a major push for peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
A man trying to take down a power line to steal and sell the copper inside was electrocuted, the Butler County sheriff’s office said.

Ten steamfitters who work in tunnels under the United States Capitol and other federal buildings have settled a whistle-blower retaliation case against the architect of the Capitol after complaining of asbestos exposure.
The House passed a measure that would allow the State Department to hire Foreign Service retirees to help handle a backlog of 2.9 million passport applications.
After a weeklong strike, Orange County’s bus drivers overwhelmingly approved a new contract and expected to be back on the road within days.
An Amtrak train struck a car at a crossing in Lakeland, Fla., killing four people in the car.
A terminal at Miami International Airport was evacuated after the authorities found what they thought looked like an explosive device, but it turned out to be a box of cremated human remains.
The doctor arrested in the deaths of four patients at a New Orleans hospital after Hurricane Katrina sued the state attorney general.

The World Bank has debarred two India-based pharmaceutical companies from consideration for bank contracts because a bank investigation found they had colluded to fix prices on a bank-financed maternal and child health project in India. Nestor Pharmaceuticals is ineligible for three years, Pure Pharma for one year. The case prompted Paul D. Wolfowitz, then the bank’s president, to delay some $700 million in loans to India for health programs in 2005 and 2006, angering the bank’s board of directors; the directors felt that he should have consulted them first. It also contributed to the board’s insistence that Mr. Wolfowitz, who resigned in May, develop consistent standards for handling corruption cases.
Many migrant workers are bringing AIDS to rural parts of Mexico, which are not prepared to handle the epidemic.

Radio Caracas Televisión, the network forced off the public airwaves in May by President Hugo Chávez’s government, restarted broadcasts on cable. The network, called RCTV, is expected to reach no more than a third of households, leaving only state-controlled and private broadcasters that are not explicitly critical of Mr. Chávez’s policies with national audiences. RCTV said it would continue a legal battle to return to the public airwaves, pressing ahead with claims that the nonrenewal of its license was an attempt to stifle dissent by the government.
Lawmakers have shelved Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge motorists in some parts of Manhattan.

In one measure of the progress that countries are making to combat domestic violence, the World Health Organization credited Malaysia with developing crisis centers for victims of child abuse and setting up services for survivors of domestic violence in all government hospitals. Mozambique has developed systems for recording the details of violent deaths and injuries. The W.H.O. report, “Third Milestones of a Global Campaign for Violence Prevention 2007,” also said Brazil, Mexico and the United Kingdom had published their first national reports on violence and health.

A roadside bomb planted in Lebanon’s coastal south exploded as a United Nations vehicle drove past, the second attack on the peacekeeping force in less than a month. No one was hurt. The bomb struck the United Nations jeep as it drove near Tyre, according to a statement from the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, known as Unifil. A car bombing in June killed six peacekeepers. No one has claimed responsibility for that attack, but in a videotape last week the deputy leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, blessed it. Lebanon has been fighting Islamists in the north of the country for weeks. The Unifil force has been greatly expanded since last year’s war between Lebanon’s Hezbollah militia and Israel.
President Evo Morales said his government would take control of the country’s railroads, a move that would upend American and Chilean investments.
Prosecutors asked for 60-year terms for three men found guilty of 11 of the 14 charges against them, which included murder, rape and enlisting child soldiers.
Health advocates predict that this may be the year tobacco regulation is made law, but many reject some of the bill’s provisions.
When the City of London Police raided the offices of three major British soccer teams on Monday morning, they took suspicion of corruption in the game to a new level.
Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said he would force lawmakers to go on record in votes around the clock.
As the W.W.E. trumpets its drug-testing plan as a credible deterrent to the abuse of banned drugs, questions persist about whether it is stringent enough after the Chris Benoit family tragedy.
Farfur, an anti-Israeli mouse on Hamas television, has been replaced with a bee named Nahoul, who says he is Farfur’s cousin.
With its decision to entertain bids for Volvo, Ford appears to be dismantling its collection of luxury auto companies.
A rented army of 130,000 civilians suffers and dies alongside 160,000 United States soldiers and marines.
Business 2.0, a seven-year-old Time Inc. publication that covers start-ups, technology trends and changes in the new economy, might publish its final issue in September.
The New Jersey Governor announced Monday that the state would provide $6.4 million towards a $100 million cancer center at Cooper University Hospital.
North Korea’s decision to shut down its plutonium-producing reactor and admit international inspectors was only the first of several steps it needs to take.
Forty-four former state attorneys general have asked Congress to investigate whether politics played a role in the case against former Gov. Don E. Siegelman of Alabama.
Hours before he was scheduled to die, the Georgia State Board of Pardons and Paroles granted a stay of execution to a man convicted of killing a police officer in 1989.
We carry with us footprints of vanished places.

The Austrian Ski Federation gave lifetime bans to Wolfgang Perner and Wolfgang Rottmann, both retired biathletes, and the former coaches Emil Hoch and Walter Mayer yesterday because of their involvement with blood doping at the 2006 Turin Olympics.

The N.F.L. announced yesterday that Kansas City defensive end Jared Allen had been suspended for the first two games of the 2007 season after two arrests for driving under the influence.The 25-year-old Allen entered a diversion program in connection with the first charge and pleaded no contest to the second.

Miami Dolphins receiver Chris Chambers, who was arrested early Saturday for driving while impaired, has had his case delayed until Aug. 15. Chambers did not attend a hearing yesterday in Mecklenburg County court in North Carolina. He was also cited for reckless driving and speeding.
The Islanders signed defenseman Chris Campoli to a three-year deal yesterday worth $1.9 million. Campoli, 23, has 10 goals and 38 assists in 131 career games.
The Jets have signed the free-agent wide receiver Juan Wong, who spent the past season with the Hamburg Sea Devils of N.F.L. Europa.

With a score of 16.175 on the balance beam, the highest mark of the day on any event, Shawn Johnson clinched the gold medal yesterday in the women’s gymnastics all-around at the Pan American Games in Rio de Janeiro. Johnson, 15, totaled 61.725 to lead a United States sweep, with Rebecca Bross winning silver (61.050) and Ivana Hong bronze (59.375).

Seve Ballesteros of Spain officially retired yesterday, after a record 50 victories on the European Tour, 5 major championships and a Ryder Cup career that helped Europe shed its underdog image.He has not been a factor the last decade because of back injuries and has rarely played during the last couple of years.Ballasteros, who made his professional debut at the 1974 Spanish Open, won the British Open three times and the Masters twice. He won 87 titles over all. He was the youngest Masters champion, at 23, until Tiger Woods came along. He returned to Augusta National this year, but finished last after rounds of 86-80. He tried one Champions Tour event after turning 50 in April, but again came in last.

BACK TO BACK Domestic airlines are expected to post an aggregate profit of about $4 billion this year, which would make 2006-7 the first back-to-back years of profitability since 1999-2000, the Air Transport Association said in a recent outlook for 2007. Debt levels remain high, however, “leaving the airlines vulnerable to fuel spikes, recession or exogenous shocks” like terrorist attacks and natural disasters, said John Heimlich, the trade group’s chief economist. True financial health for the industry, including the ability to add new-model aircraft to fleets, will require “many years of profitability,” Mr. Heimlich said.

(TCM) FLIGHT (1929) Turner Classic Movies devotes 24 hours to aeronautics, starting with Jack Holt, Lila Lee and Ralph Graves in this early Frank Capra film about marine aviators competing for the love of a nurse in Nicaragua. Highlights include Howard Hawks’s “Flight Commander” (1930), with Douglas Fairbanks Jr., at 8; Glenn Ford in “Flight Lieutenant” (1942), at noon; Katharine Hepburn, above left, as an adulterous aviator in “Christopher Strong” (1933), at 4:30 p.m.; “Too Hot to Handle” (1938), with Clark Gable as a newsreel photographer and Myrna Loy as a pilot, at 6; “Julie” (1956), starring Doris Day as an airline attendant trying to escape her obsessive husband (Louis Jourdan), at 8; the stewardess caper “Come Fly With Me” (1963) at 10; and “Three Guys Named Mike” (1951), whose guys are all in pursuit of one flight attendant (Jane Wyman), at midnight. The marathon comes in for a landing with “Murder in the Clouds” (1934), at 4:30 a.m.

An article on Saturday about a guilty plea by an employee of a Halliburton subsidiary who admitted receiving kickbacks in exchange for awarding contracts to supply equipment to the American military in Iraq and Kuwait misidentified that employee. It was Anthony J. Martin, 58, of Houston who pleaded quilty -- not Rodger A. Heaton, who as attorney general for the Central District of Illinois prosecuted the case.

FRANKIEL--Rita, aged 74, died peacefully in her sleep, a victim of cancer, on the morning of July 16. She is survived by her loving husband, Roy Schafer, her stepdaughters Laurie, Amy, and Sylvia and their families. Dr. Frankiel was a psychoanalyst and psychotherapist of children and adults. A graduate of Syracuse University, subsequently she earned an MA in child development from the University of Minnesota and a Ph.D in Psychology from Teachers College, Columbia University. She trained as an analyst at the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute, and she went on to become a senior faculty member of the New York Freudian Society and the NYU Postdoctoral Institute for Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy. Her publications on loss of loved ones and other topics are widely recognized. There will be no funeral; a memorial service will be organized in early autumn. Friends are invited to visit her husband at home in the evening, 6-9 pm, through Thursday. Family requests donations to the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, Weill Cornell Medical Center, NY in lieu of flowers.

Radio Caracas Televisión, the network forced off the public airwaves in May by President Hugo Chávez's government, restarted broadcasts on cable. The network, called RCTV, is expected to reach no more than a third of households, leaving only state-controlled and private broadcasters that are not explicitly critical of Mr. Chávez's policies with national audiences. RCTV said it would continue a legal battle to return to the public airwaves, pressing ahead with claims that the nonrenewal of its license was an attempt to stifle dissent by the government.

WALSH--John H., passed away suddenly in Los Angeles, CA on July 12th, 2007. Born in Syracuse, NY on November 7th, 1950, he dedicated his life to the healing arts and uplifting the lives of others. On a spiritual path since childhood, John was committed to raising the consciousness of the planet, one soul at a time. Indifferent to social positioning, John treated everyone with the same exquisite care, profound compassion and deep insight. His natural psychic and intuitive abilities were immense. His intensive healing sessions were always life-changing and often described as 'miraculous'. John's sweet joy, contagious laughter, vibrant zest for life, and unforgettable ability to caress the heart with the twinkle from his eye or the warmth of his hug, left an indelible mark on all whose lives he touched. John is survived by his brothers, David of Breckenridge, Colorado and Peter of Southeast Asia; his sister, Susan of Syracuse, NY, and numerous nieces and nephews; his healing partner Judith Johnson, former-wife Carol LeFlufy and hundreds of dear friends. There will be a celebration of John's life in August in LA, Boulder and NYC. Email: johntribute@eye-forward .com. Heart-felt donations may be forwarded to Carol LeFlufy, 6311 Romaine St., Los Angeles, CA 90038. Proceeds will be distributed to John's favorite charities.

With a soapy hand, I fumbled around for my cellphone in the dark, pushing a random key so the display screen would light the concrete walls of the tiny bathroom in Cherident, Haiti. It provided enough illumination to find the large plastic bucket that contained the cold water I needed to scoop over my head with a plastic cup. Since there was no mirror in my room at the Episcopal parish guesthouse anyway, I shaved in the dark, carefully feeling my face for whiskers and hoping that I didn't leave any noticeable patches.

An article on July 7 about Bridgeville, Calif., which is up for sale for the third time in five years, referred incorrectly to the role eBay played in the town's sale the first two times. The town was advertised on the Web site's real estate auction site; it was not auctioned off or otherwise sold through a typical eBay transaction between buyers and sellers, or ''through the impulsive rush of online bidding.'' The article also referred incorrectly to two aspects of the town's history. Although Bridgeville is in Northern California, where the Pony Express ended, the town was not a stop on the route. Also, the town was founded in the early 1870s, in the wake of the gold rush; it was not ''an important stop on the wagon trail connecting San Francisco to Eureka'' during the gold rush, which was over by the mid-1860s.

International Business Machines will purchase the DataMirror Corporation for 170 million Canadian dollars ($161 million) to gain programs that help businesses access data faster. I.B.M. bid 27 Canadian dollars a share for all the outstanding common stock of DataMirror, which is based in Markham, Ontario. The price represents a 20 percent premium to DataMirror's closing price on Friday, which was 22 Canadian dollars a share. I.B.M. will gain more than 2,200 customers with the purchase.

Contrary to interpretations of their private conversation last week -- caught on an open microphone for all the political world to hear -- neither former Senator John Edwards nor Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is secretly plotting to block lesser-known rivals from future Democratic presidential debates, the two candidates' advisers said yesterday. The issue came up after a forum of the eight Democratic candidates, when Mr. Edwards leaned in to Mrs. Clinton and said, ''We should try to have a more serious ... smaller group.'' Mrs. Clinton replied, ''We've got to cut the number,'' adding ''our guys should talk.''

A brief article on Thursday about the possibility of water on another planet referred imprecisely to the star that the planet orbits. The star is about three million miles away from the planet, known as HD 189733b -- not from Earth.

Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

The Empire Company, which owns the Sobeys supermarket chain in Canada, agreed to buy Thrifty Foods for 260 million Canadian dollars ($249 million) including debt. The acquisition, which will quadruple the number of grocery stores Empire has in British Columbia, includes 20 stores, a distribution center and a wholesale division. Thrifty Foods, with 3,700 employees, will become a unit of Sobeys.

The American public's trust in the federal government has dropped to its lowest level since before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Only 24 percent of those surveyed said the government in Washington could be trusted to do what is right just about always or most of the time; 75 percent said the government could be trusted only some of the time or never. The public's trust of the government has been eroding after rising to a record high of 55 percent in a Times/CBS News Poll in October 2001. Over the same period, Americans have become increasingly pessimistic about the direction of the country, and disapproval of both Congress and the president has also been at record lows.

KAPELL--Betty Richter, passed away peacefully on July 14 at the age of 101. She was the proud mother of William L. Richter, the loving grandmother of Ari and Molly Richter, and devoted greatgrandmother of Mia and Adam. She was predeceased by her husbands Joseph Richter, Milton Goldman, and Judge William Kapell. Graveside services will be held Wednesday July 18th, at 2pm at the King Solomon Cemetery, Dwas Line Rd and Allwood Rd, Clifton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to American Friends of Bar Ilan University 235 Park Avenue South, 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10003.

FRIEDMAN--Frances Karo, July 18, 1920 -June 24, 2005. We are at the grave sight in honor of a great lady we portrayed the qualities which make us proud. This is your birthday and we are here to pay tribute. Years past we would celebrate but now we can only recall such beautiful memories each and every day. We love you from awakening to retiring. You are always with us. Anita, Georgie, and Oscar

MULLIGAN--Roseanna Connelly, age 84, devoted wife of the late Hon. William H. Mulligan, former dean of Fordham Law School, member of U.S. Court of Appeals (2d Cir.) and partner of Skadden Arps. Loving mother of Anne O. Hartmere, William H. Mulligan, Jr. (Mary Liz) and Stephen E. Mulligan; adoring grandmother of Michael C. Hartmere (Virginia), Maura Logan (Kevin), Jenny, Billy, Kate and Rory Mulligan, great-grandmother of Jacob, Stephen and Abigail Hartmere; caring sister of Genie Flannery and Neil Connelly. Elegant, beautiful and dignified, she will be sorely missed by everyone who knew and loved her. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7-9 Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Thursday, July 19 at 10 am. Contributions may be made to Mulligan Scholarship c/o Fordham Law School or Catholic Charities.

An article in Sunday Styles this week about the popularity of the video game Guitar Hero among bar patrons misspelled the surname of an artist whose song appears in the game, and misstated the title of that song. He is Stevie Ray Vaughan, not Vaughn, and the song is ''Texas Flood,'' not ''Texas Blood.''

An obituary on Wednesday about the Hollywood character actor Charles Lane misspelled the surnames of two other character actors. They were Byron Foulger, not Folger, and Howland Chamberlain, not Chamberlin.

KALMANOFF--Martin, on July 14, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Kalmanoff. Devoted brother of Blanche Perlman. Cherished uncle of Jonathan, Wendy, Alan, Jeannette, Nancy, Clarence, Kathy and Jane. Funeral services Tuesday 12 Noon, at Frank E. Campbell F. H., 1076 Madison Ave., NY.
JOHNSON--Lady Bird. Where she walked, flowers and friendships bloomed. To continue her work, visit www.wildflower.org. With admiration and love, Marybeth Weston & family

President Evo Morales said his government would take control of the country's railroads, a move that would upend American and Chilean investments. Mr. Morales, speaking Sunday at the inauguration of a passenger rail route outside La Paz, criticized the results of a broad privatization program implemented in the 1990s that included the sale of railroads previously under control of the central government. The president's plans for the railroads would affect Genesee & Wyoming Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., and the Luksic Group of Chile, which operate railroads in Bolivia. Mr. Morales has also moved to assert greater state control of the energy, telecommunications and mining industries.
To the Editor: Re ''Poor Kids Living in a War Zone,'' by Bob Herbert (column, July 14):

In one measure of the progress that countries are making to combat domestic violence, the World Health Organization credited Malaysia with developing crisis centers for victims of child abuse and setting up services for survivors of domestic violence in all government hospitals. Mozambique has developed systems for recording the details of violent deaths and injuries. The W.H.O. report, ''Third Milestones of a Global Campaign for Violence Prevention 2007,'' also said Brazil, Mexico and the United Kingdom had published their first national reports on violence and health.
We were told we lied. We walked in darkness for many, many years. CARLOS PEREZ-CARILLO,
POSNIK--Flora Zwart. Beloved by all who knew her, passed away July 9, 2007. Private graveside services were held. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at a future date.

The World Bank has debarred two India-based pharmaceutical companies from consideration for bank contracts because a bank investigation found they had colluded to fix prices on a bank-financed maternal and child health project in India. Nestor Pharmaceuticals is ineligible for three years, Pure Pharma for one year. The case prompted Paul D. Wolfowitz, then the bank's president, to delay some $700 million in loans to India for health programs in 2005 and 2006, angering the bank's board of directors; the directors felt that he should have consulted them first. It also contributed to the board's insistence that Mr. Wolfowitz, who resigned in May, develop consistent standards for handling corruption cases.
To the Editor: I do not begrudge great wealth. But I do begrudge the tycoons featured in ''The Richest of the Rich, Proud of a New Gilded Age'' (front page, July 15).

A picture caption on Saturday about anxiety in the Muslim world over the radicalism among its doctors and engineers misidentified the religion of Dr. George Habash, founder of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a leftist group, whose photograph was shown with those of Muslim professionals identified as militants. He is Christian, not Muslim.

Mitt Romney has begun running a new television advertisement in the early presidential battleground states of Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina, stepping up an already aggressive advertising campaign despite a recent drop in his fund-raising. The 60-second spot features a child frolicking in the ocean as Mr. Romney speaks in the background about the ''cesspool of violence, and sex, and drugs, and indolence, and perversions'' that he believes surrounds America's children today.

To the Editor: Vern Clark and Thomas R. Pickering are correct that the United States should finally ratify the Law of the Sea Treaty (''A Treaty That Lifts All Boats,'' Op-Ed, July 14). In their discussion of why United States ratification makes good sense, they touch upon the treaty's provisions concerning marine environmental conservation. This point needs to be emphasized.

APPEL--Bluma. The Council for Canadian American Relations announces with deep sadness the passing of its founder, Bluma Appel. Her achievements and contributions generated wide respect and numerous honors in her beloved country of Canada. She was known in New York and Florida for her pride in, and support of, Canadian accomplishments. Bluma was a woman of great passion and impact affecting the many social causes she took up. She will be greatly missed. Board of Directors, Council for Canadian American Relations

Former Senator Fred D. Thompson, who has spent the last six weeks ''testing the waters'' before he decides whether to dive into the presidential race, has been raising money at high-price fund-raisers around the country and through his Web site. And because Mr. Thompson has not officially declared his candidacy, he has been able to bypass requirements to disclose his fund-raising and spending.

President Bush announced an initiative on Monday to shore up the Palestinian president and to begin building a Palestinian state, signaling that his administration will use its remaining months to make a major push for peace between Israelis and Palestinians. Mr. Bush called for a regional peace conference this fall to be led by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice that would include high-level Arab envoys and their counterparts from Israel and the Palestinian West Bank. He exhorted Israel's Arab neighbors to open talks with Israel and to show leadership by ''ending the fiction that Israel does not exist'' and ''stopping the incitement of hatred in their official media.''

To the Editor: Re ''U.S. Diplomat Hints at Delay for Kosovo Independence'' (news article, July 9): Delaying the resolution of Kosovo's final status until next year is not just a ''setback for Kosovo's ethnic Albanian leadership.'' The credibility of the United States is on the line.

Just when you thought it was safe to go back online, ''Obama Girl'' is back -- and this time, it's personal. Every summer blockbuster demands a sequel, and with more than 2.3 million hits on YouTube, the ''I've Got a Crush on Obama'' video is no different. So from the team that brought you that sensation, here comes ''Obama Girl vs. Giuliani Girl,'' which premiered yesterday and had already been watched more than 11,000 times by late afternoon.
To the Editor: I am afraid that Maureen Dowd's July 15 column, ''Who's Sorry Now?,'' is the closest the American people will come to hearing any type of apology from George W. Bush.

At 1 p.m. on a weekday, the emergency department at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Upper Manhattan is in full cry, with bays crowded, patients on stretchers lining the hallways, and paramedics bringing in more sick people. Time for the Rev. Margaret A. Muncie to work the floor. Not shy, this pastor with the clerical collar, the Ann Taylor blazer and the cheerful insistence of one whose own mother called her a steamroller. Among the first women ordained an Episcopal priest and a self-described ''Caucasian minority,'' she's an odd bird among the ethnically diverse staff and especially the patients, most of them black or Latino. But she keeps pecking her head behind curtains, parting gatherings of worried family members, impervious to startled looks of suspicion.

DIAMOND--Shirley, died July 16, 2007. Dearly beloved wife of Emanuil Gelfand; and cherished sister of George Diamond. She also leaves behind her sisters-in-law Mary Diamond and Anna Gelfand; a niece Penny, and a stepson Vladimir; as well as countless friends. Shirley was a graduate of McGill University in Canada and was for a long time corporate librarian for the law firm Dewey Ballantine. She was a special person and we will miss her. May her memory be ever lasting. The family requests that contributions be sent to The American Cancer Society. Services will be held grave side on Wednesday July 18th at 2pm at Bethel Cemetery, Forest Avenue, Westwood, NJ.

JONES--Elinor N., 77, playwright, died of complications after surgery on June 11 in Manhattan. ''Ellie'', a member of the Dramatists Guild and the League of Professional Theatre Women was best known for her play ''Colette'', starring Zoe Caldwell and Mildred Dunnock. Her other works include ''A Voice Of My Own'', ''Out Of Season'', as well as her oneact plays ''Box Office'', ''What Would Jean Moreau Do?'' and ''6:15 On The 104.'' She was beloved by a multitude of friends and is survived by her brother Norton Wright, her sister-in-law Susan Watson Wright, and her nephews Rob Wright and Doug Wright. A celebration of Ellie's life is scheduled for the York Theatre.

The Jets have signed the free-agent wide receiver Juan Wong, who spent the past season with the Hamburg Sea Devils of N.F.L. Europa. General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said that Wong, a native of Mexico, would receive an International N.F.L./E.L. exemption on the Jets' roster. The 5-foot-11, 179-pound Wong played two seasons in N.F.L. Europa. He finished the regular season with one reception for 11 yards. He also had one reception for 26 yards in the Sea Devils' 37-28 victory over the Frankfurt Galaxy in the World Bowl.

BRONSTEIN--Julia, age 79 of Bayside, New York on July 13 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Maurice Bronstein. Loving mother of Geraldine B. Ertel and Liane B. Rosenberg. Adored grandmother of Noah, David and Emily. Also survived by brother Dr. Henry Feingold and sons-in-lawDr. Alan Ertel and Jack Rosenberg. Gifts in memoriam can be given to The Myositis Association, 1233 20th St. NW, Washington, DC, 20036. We will miss your warmth, intellect and wit. You will be in our hearts forever.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the anonymous online postings of John Mackey, chief executive of Whole Foods Market, misstated the status of a Securities and Exchange Commission examination of the posts. It is an informal inquiry, not a formal one.

Hamas television, which was criticized for a Mickey Mouse-like character named Farfur who spouted anti-Israeli and anti-Jewish nostrums at children, has replaced the mouse with a bee named Nahoul, who says he is Farfur's cousin. Farfur was beaten to death by an Israeli who wanted his land on the previous episode of the children's show ''Tomorrow's Pioneers.''

METH--Johannes (John) M., M.D., loving father to two surviving sons Ernie and Marcel, grandfather to five wonderful grandchildren, Molly, Alex, Zack, Maddie and Miles and surrogate father to a wonderful, loving Ilse, died peacefully at home on June 30, 2007. He had survived his wife Sophie who he missed every day of his life and battled dementia for the last nine years since her death. Dr. Meth was a psychiatrist affiliated with the Karen Horney Clinic in New York City. Born on April 12, 1915, in Dresden Germany, he and his mother were holocaust survivors who had migrated to Ecuador and then the United States. His wit, insightfulness, playfulness and menschlichkite made this world a better place. We will all miss him.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about lobbying by hedge fund and private equity fund executives against a proposal that would increase their tax liability misspelled the surname of one executive, a co-founder of the Blackstone Group. He is Stephen A. Schwarzman, not Schwartzman.

Heath Bell lived a fairly anonymous lifestyle when he played for the Mets. The only time people recognized him, he often said, was at airports because he shuttled between the big leagues and Class AAA Norfolk so much.
Eyewitnesses talked about the fear and confusion caused by an apparent steam explosion near Grand Central Station.
Senator John McCain may be running out of money and out of campaign staff, but he seems to be holding on to one key group of supporters: fellow senators.
The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Live-In Maid," an Argentine film about the 30-year relationship between a woman and her maid.
As a result of a severe water shortage in Nevada, officials are promoting dry landscaping, or "xeriscaping," to residents.

Bruce Beck, a sportscaster for WNBC-TV in New York, finished a round of golf at Shady Canyon in Irvine, Calif. on Tuesday, strolled into the pro shop and spotted a hulking, somewhat mysterious figure, sitting in a large chair. Was it him?
