U.S. intelligence agencies describe "a persistent and evolving terrorist threat" from Al Qaeda and other Islamic extremist groups.

I just got my first AT&T bill for my iPhone. (Apple loaned me an iPhone to review, but I paid for the service myself so I could go through the setup process like the average Joe. The Times will reimburse me.)

Several readers have reviewed our roll-call vote from today's expected, but still much anticipated, showdown in the Senate over the Iraq war debate vote, and questioned why the Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, cast a vote with the largely Republican minority.
Melena Ryzik of The Times hoofs it to Newark for the premiere of "Hairspray" the movie.

Here's a topic sure to spark debate: A recent study by GE Money Home Lending found that the biggest turn off for British citizens contemplating buying in Spain is the number of Brits already enjoying their place in the sun.

Un-seasonal summer rains have finally vanished. That's just in time for the start of outdoor cinema in the city's Parc de la Villette, where the movie classics started flickering this week and will run until August 26th. The cinema and the glowing stars are free, but there's a price if you want to upgrade from picnic blanket to deck chair. (6.50 euros) This is an annual event with a huge screen erected overlooking the Prairie du Triangle with screenings of classic movies in their original language. This year's theme is "Première classe et strapontin" or "First class and folding chairs" with a schedule of 36 movies ranging from George Kukor's "The Philadelphia Story" to Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby."

The pushback against easy debt for buyouts isn't going unnoticed. James Dimon, the chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase, warned on a conference call Wednesday morning that banks like his may be left holding more loans than they would like.

This morning's story on an indictment that ties Michael Vick to a slew of ugly dogfighting charges left off with the question of "how the league, the Falcons and Vick would deal with his legal troubles in the weeks ahead."

How did Elizabeth Edwards become the most interesting spouse of the 2008 presidential campaign? As NBC News's First Read puts it, "We knew it was possible that a spouse might become the story in this presidential race. But [we] thought it would be Bill, not Elizabeth Edwards."
You've heard of drive-by shootings in the hip-hop world, but if you're a YouTube obsessive you also know about drive-through ordering:
No, it isn't "The Simpsons Movie." It's a live-action movie imitating the animation in the TV show's iconic opening:

The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Dow Jones board member David Li over an insider trading case linked to the News Corporation's bid for the Wall Street Journal publisher, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson has gone further than many of the other Democratic presidential candidates by supporting a "7 Point Plan for Iraq" that calls for withdrawing troops immediately and leaving no residual forces behind.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's July 18 column, "Help Wanted: Peacemaker".
We promised more from the second-quarter campaign filings, so more you shall have:
Melena Ryzik of The Times hoofs it to Newark for the premiere of  Hairspray the movie.

On May 28, Jane Perlez reported from London on a play called "Fallujah," which purported to tell the story of the November, 2004 assault by U.S. forces on the Iraqi city where four American contract workers had been killed the previous spring and hung from a bridge.
One of the most vexing challenges for humanitarians has been the lack of evidence that foreign aid is effective.
Sallie Mae, the nation's largest lender, has been campaigning against legislation that would overhaul the student loan system in recent weeks. Now it has found a Democratic ally in the House.
"Johnny says we can save as much as $30,000 if we get rid of the roof deck," my bride announced without preamble during dinner. "It's totally your call. What do you want to do?"

Back in the 80s, a Japanese company's ownership of 30 Rockefeller Center in New York was often cited as evidence that an Asian power was subsuming the United States economy. Since then, of course, the storied building has reverted back to American hands, and Japan's economy has gone through a years-long recession.
In her column today, Robin Toner writes that the "2008 presidential campaign is taking a decidedly populist turn, and the backlash and counterattacks have already begun:"
I've been remiss in failing to point out an interesting coda to the story I reported in this blog about Daniel Boulud's pique with the Queens chef-restaurateur Danny Brown.

Reflecting the stepped-up role of Elizabeth Edwards in the campaign of her husband, the Edwards campaign unveiled a 30-second television ad in which Mrs. Edwards endorses the hardworking and compassionate nature of her husband. The ad will be shown in New Hampshire, where Mr. Edwards has been slipping in the polls.
... except make thousands of julienne fries:
An encore presentation by David Pogue.

Does Sears Holdings want to put grocery chain Safeway in its shopping cart? Judging from the unusual trading activity in Safeway's stock and options, a few people think some kind of deal is in the offing.
After three days of deep-sea diving into the second-quarter spending reports filed by the presidential candidates, a few big thoughts and smattering of small revelations, in no particular order:

Complaints about "Tintin in the Congo," a comic book originally published in 1931, gathered momentum recently when David Enright, a lawyer in London, happened to pick up a copy as he strolled through a Borders store there.
Bear Stearns may have two sinking hedge funds on its hands, but little Lime Capital is sailing along quite nicely, thank you.

Tsagaan Battsetseg surged into the lead of the U.S. Women's Championship with two wins on day 2 of the tournament. She now has 3.5 out of 4 points. Anna Zatonskih, the defending champion, and Katerina Rohonyan are only a half point behind, each with 3 points. The championship is being held in Stillwater, Okla., from July 16 to 20. The games can be followed live or replayed here at Monroi.com. There is also an official Web site for the event.
The housing starts numbers out today show an industry in freefall. The number of single family home starts is running at its lowest level in a decade, and the permit picture is even bleaker.
Hundreds have been snatched by Pakistan’s military and intelligence services since 2001, rights activists say.

For a company that just had two big hedge funds evaporate, Bear Stearns seemed to be faring relatively well on Wednesday. Its shares were down 1.1 percent in late-morning trading Wednesday, far less than the after-hours decline of 3.6 percent they registered Tuesday night. That is when reports started emerging that two Bear Stearns-run hedge funds, worth an estimated $1.5 billion at the end of 2006, has lost nearly all their value because of mortgage-related bets gone bad.

One of the hottest (and most divisive) debates in the community of people who care about Darfur has to do with a No Fly Zone. As I noted in Monday's column, I'm in favor of a version of a NFZ. A lot of aid groups are opposed. Ken Bacon, the head of Refugees International, here charts a middle position. Ken argues that it's too soon to move toward a NFZ, until all diplomatic options are exhausted, but that it would be a bad idea to take a NFZ off the table.

For the last few days, presidential candidate John Edwards has been traveling around the country on a three-day tour meant to draw attention to one of the signature issues of his campaign - poverty. But these days, it seems that the person who poses the biggest threat to stealing the spotlight from him is not one of the other candidates, but rather, his wife, Elizabeth.

Shawn Higbee had a huge three-lap lead over the next closest rider in a three-hour motorcycle Grand Sport Touring race at the speedway in Newton, Iowa, last weekend, when he and a slower rider collided. Higbee's bike burst into flames after it hit the track's outside wall and broke apart. It was a total loss.

On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

Through a quirk of fate, my wife, Cree, grew up down the road from Hunter S. Thompson's place. He was a family friend. This was in Woody Creek, Co., in the late 1960s and early 70s, when Thompson was just finding his first fame.
For many observers, Tuesday's National Intelligence Estimate on terrorism offered few surprises in its 736 words.
Almost 200 people were feared dead after a plane skidded off a runway and crashed into an office building and a gas station across a highway.
Rudy Giuliani is "Nixon's political twin," writes former Bush speechwriter Michael Gerson in his latest Washington Post column. Gerson elaborates:

J.P. Morgan Chase said its second-quarter net income rose 20 percent from a year ago, lifted by record investment-banking fees and strong gains in its private equity portfolio. Its earnings came to $4.2 billion, up from $3.5 billion in the comparable period in 2006.
A steam pipe explosion beneath a street near Grand Central Terminal propelled a giant scalding jet of brownish steam toward the sky, sending commuters who had been heading home stampeding to safety.
Mail Fetcher offers you the chance to have outgoing messages stamped with your regular e-mail address.
Apollo Management, the giant buyout firm led by Leon Black, plans to join the private equity firms going public, but by going through a back door.

Sandler O'Neill & Partners, a boutique investment bank, said Tuesday that it had hired Raymond E. Chandonnet, the former head of bank strategy sales at J.P. Morgan Securities, as a managing director in fixed income sales. Mr. Chardonnet will serve as chief strategist in the balance sheet management group in Sandler O'Neill's New York office
It's now up to the Bancrofts.

The California State Teachers' Retirement System, which has invested more than $10 billion in private equity funds, is wary of private equity funds selling shares to the public. In an interview with The Financial Times, the group's chief investment officer argued that going public could distract from deal-making and create conflicts between the short-term demands of shareholders and long-term returns sought by pension funds.
Bear Stearns told clients in its two battered hedge funds late Tuesday that their investments, worth an estimated $1.5 billion at the end of 2006, are almost entirely gone.

Jupitermedia, an Internet research company that also sells photos and art, has agreed to pay as much as $23 million for Mediabistro.com, a Web site for job-seeking media and creative professionals. The deal includes a payment of $20 million in cash and an additional $3 million over two years.

United States Steel may be the latest suitor looking to buy or invest in Stelco, Reuters reported citing a Stelco union leader who said representatives of United States Steel visited Stelco last week.

The Toronto-Dominion Bank has agreed to provide 3.8 billion Canadian dollars ($3.64 billion) in financing for the proposed takeover of BCE for 34.3 billion Canadian dollars by the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners.

A Qatari investment fund, Delta Two, has approached J Sainsbury, the British supermarket group, with a takeover bid that values the company at 12 billion pounds ($24 billion), Reuters reported. Sainsbury and Delta Two confirmed the report about the bid but did not disclose the price being discussed.

Air One has pulled out of the bidding for Alitalia, throwing a wrench into Rome's plans to auction the carrier ahead of Monday's deadlines for final offers. Air One withdrew citing impossible conditions, said Reuters, and now leaves only MatlinPatterson of the United States and raises questions on whether a different procedure for the crucial sale is needed.

While it may not be a full re-boot, Dell,the computer maker has at least avoided being delisted from the Nasdaq stock exchange after the Nasdaq's board of directors allowed the computer maker to continue trading, despite Dell's failure to meet listing requirements.

Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts is examining a takeover of Macy's, Women's Wear Daily reported Wednesday. Citing private equity sources it did not identify, the paper said Kohlberg Kravis teamed up with Goldman Sachs on an offer for the $27 billion retailer valued at about $24 billion, which may or may not exclude Macy's debt.

A private equity consortium led by Brookfield Asset Management is readying a takeover bid for Canadian Pacific Railway. If successful, the deal would be the country's second-largest leveraged buyout in history.

Britain's Imperial Tobacco agreed to buy Franco-Spanish rival Altadis for 12.6 billion euros ($17.4 billion) on Wednesday in a deal that will see it jump to No 2 from 4 in Europe's cigarette industry.

Despite a Royal Bank of Scotland-led consortium's increased offer for ABN Amro, Barclays isn't backing down. Reuters reported that a senior Barlclays executive said the bank is confident it will win the battle for the Dutch giant.
LKQ, which recycles auto parts, plans to buy Keystone Automotive Industries for $48 a share, or about $811 million in cash.

India's Tata Motors is in the early stages of evaluating a bid to acquire Jaguar and Land Rover, which Ford Motor has earmarked for a sale, The Daily Telegraph reported. Such a deal, if completed, would rank among India's biggest overseas takeover deals.

The proposed acquisition of Taiwan's Fu Sheng by the California buyout fund Oaktree Capital Management appears to be back on track. That news would seem to quiet fears that private equity investors were being frozen out of Taiwan.

Sage Electrochromics, which makes energy-saving windows that can be tinted on command, has raised $16 million in a venture capital round led by Good Energies. Applied Ventures, the investing arm of Applied Materials, and Belgium's Bekaert also participated in the round.

Spark Capital, a Boston-based venture capital firm, has reported closing a $360 million fund, The Mass High Tech Business Journal said. The fund invests in the media, entertainment and technology industries. The new fund, Spark's second, increases its total capital under management to $622 million.

Arrowhead Energy Partners has spun off its energy-related investment banking and private equity division to create Arrowhead Financial Services. The new investment arm will be based in Houston and plans to add analysts and other staff with engineering, geology and lease-acquisition backgrounds over the next three quarters, The Houston Business Journal reported.
Linden said Tuesday it has committed $40 million to acquire a majority stake in a psychiatric hospital operator, Behavioral Centers of America, TheDeal.com reported.

PPR, the French luxury group, has secured a majority stake in the German sporting goods company Puma. PPR's bid of 330 euros a share, which valued Puma at 5.3 billion euros ($7.3 billion), landed it 62.1 percent of the sneaker maker.

Satiety has brought in $30 million in Series D funding to support the first United States clinical trials of a new medical device to control obesity. The six-year-old startup now has more than $50 million in investments.

In what would be the third-biggest initial public offering in Canada this year, Lockerbie & Hole plans to raise as much as 150 million Canadian dollars ($144 million) in an initial public offering set to be priced the week of July 30, Bloomberg News reported.

The Merlin Entertainments Group announced the disposal Tuesday of some of its most valuable British property assets, including Madame Tussauds London, in a 622 million pound ($1.27 billion) sale and leaseback deal.

WCE Holdings, the parent of the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, confirmed Tuesday it has received an unsolicited takeover bid of 50 million Canadian dollars from an unnamed party, Reuters said. The new offer trumps a June bid by Intercontinental Exchange.

Sir David Walker, a former Bank of England director and a former Morgan Stanley International chairman, presented his findings in a preliminary report on private equity on Tuesday. Among the more salient points to be made were that large buyout funds need not appoint independent, nonexecutive directors to their portfolio companies. Making such a shift would "go right across the grain" of the private equity industry, said Walker according to TheDeal.com.
The iPhone may not have a lot of built-in programs, but developers have made dozens of Web-based applications that run right in the phone’s mini-Safari browser.
Family Tree Maker’s Web site says it has abandoned efforts to create a Mac version of that genealogy software. What can Mac owners who want to computerize their genealogy do?
In corporate America, flouting the rules of the Financial Accounting Standards Board can lead to a tangle with the S.E.C. But that threat does not exist for governments and their related agencies.

The Warner Music Group has declined to bid against a British private investor for the EMI Group, a decision that would at least suspend further consolidation of the global music industry even as album sales plummet, The New York Times reported.

As VMware prepares for its initial public offering, software vendors are considering who gets to manage the infrastructure that supports virtualization technologies. An industry analyst firm, The 451 Group, takes a look at which companies play where in virtualization management, and who is likely to be shopping for them.
Tudou, sometimes called the "YouTube of China," has landed $19 million in venture financing from a group led by General Catalyst Partners of Cambridge, Mass.
Images from the newly renovated Liberty Science Center.
Gianni Versace’s shooting 10 years ago put fashion on the 11 o’clock news: a personal look back.
Endless summer, all on the wall and more.

It was 3:45 a.m. when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, walked through the doors of the cloakroom to take her seat in the back row of the Senate chamber. She was, at this hour, the only Democrat seated at a desk on the Senate floor.
Forgoing color does not have to limit decorating options.
Tim DeBoom, a two-time Ironman triathlon world champion, tests a new breed of laundry detergents that claim to eliminate sport stink.
More than 175 people are feared dead after a plane skidded off a runway and crashed into an office building and a gas station across a highway.

It was shortly before midnight when the senators arrived back on the floor of the Senate to cast their second vote of the marathon Iraq war debate. The Democrats circled Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, with a purposeful plea: Won't you please delay the next vote until a little closer to sunrise?
There are far more intoxicating reasons to visit Amsterdam these days than its infamous coffee shops or its red-light district.
For a little while at least, just after 10 p.m., the political theater finally found a willing audience.

It gets more and more obvious every day that the Yankees will not lose Alex Rodriguez unless he opts out of his contract and signals that he wants to leave town. They will find a way to sway him with an extension, because they cannot afford to lose him. He showed why -- again - with a dazzling all-around performance in Tuesday's 3-2 victory.
The Rangers traded center Matt Cullen to the Carolina Hurricanes for defenseman Andrew Hutchinson, forward Joe Barnes and a third-round pick in the 2008 draft.
In the writer and director Sang-il Lee’s “Scrap Heaven,” three strangers share a general dissatisfaction with life — and a fateful ride aboard a hijacked bus.
Nostalgic as only a project steered by two former campers can be, “Summercamp!” is a riot of talent shows and campfires, canoeing and holistic clowning.
Lambrusco, a fizzy, semisweet confection once associated with the wine-cooler craze of the 1970s, deserves a fresh new look.
The head of the Department of Veterans Affairs resigned after serving two and a half years marred by budget shortfalls and the theft of personal data.
A steam pipe exploded near Grand Central Terminal in Midtown Manhattan. More than 20 people were injured, two critically.
A review of the final installment of J.K. Rowling’s monumental, spell-binding epic, which was 10 years in the making.

Men convicted of downloading sexually explicit images of children generally receive lighter sentences than child molesters and they are on parole for shorter periods. But a new government study has found that a high percentage of convicted Internet offenders — more than 8 in 10 — have also committed acts of sexual abuse against minors.
Virginia is imposing fines as high as $2,500 for going 20 miles above the speed limit or other reckless driving.
Military officials provided a new explanation for why the leader of a notorious insurgent group has eluded capture: he never existed.
The online auctioneer’s quarterly earnings beat Wall Street estimates by 2 cents a share, as sales were up 30 percent from a year earlier.
The company’s performance shows that it is making progress in its shift toward selling higher-margin software.
Although the step coincides with concern about tainted imports from China, the White House insisted that the safety effort was not aimed at that country.
The British police arrested a man on suspicion of plotting to murder the Russian exile Boris A. Berezovsky.
Ben S. Bernanke said he expected “moderate” growth, but that problems in housing had tempered the forecast.
If approved, the deal would be the largest acquisition in the European tobacco industry.
The deal would be the biggest acquisition in the tobacco industry in Europe and end a  takeover battle with CVC Capital Partners, a private-equity firm.
The steep decline of the dollar against the euro has made eye-popping prices a lamentable part of the traveler’s tale.
A report by the National Petroleum Council, billed as a comprehensive analysis of the world’s energy challenge,  involved 350 participants and suggestions from over 1,000 people.
The 2008 presidential campaign is taking a decidedly populist turn, and the counterattacks have already begun.
United Nations officials today urged Israel to reopen the main commercial crossing to Gaza.
The American tenor was noted for his bright lyric voice, lively acting and adventurous choice of repertory.
A bill by a state senator in New York would make it illegal to send or read text messages while behind the wheel.
The generals who rule Myanmar today opened what they said would be the final session of a constitutional convention that critics say is itself undemocratic.
North Korea today offered to disable all its nuclear weapons programs in return for aid, an envoy said.
A military convoy was attacked this morning in the lawless tribal region on the border with Afghanistan.
The ambush on a dangerous section of the nation’s main highway was only one of several attacks on a violent day.
After a rare all-night session, Senate Democrats fell short in their attempt to force President Bush to begin withdrawing  troops.
A plane skidded off a runway in São Paulo, crashing into a building and a gas station and setting off a conflagration.
Starter Orlando Hernández limited the Padres to two hits in seven scoreless innings and the Mets’ offense rebounded from recent struggles to defeat the Padres on Tuesday night.
Robinson Canó lined a single in the bottom of the 10th inning, bringing Alex Rodriguez around from third with the winning run in a victory on Tuesday night.

A man, 27, was fatally shot in Brooklyn yesterday shortly before 9 p.m., the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, was shot multiple times in the torso in front of 187 Buffalo Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant and taken to Kings County Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. There have been no arrests.
Results of the runoff in a special election to fill the vacant seat in Georgia’s 10th Congressional District were too close to call late Tuesday night.
The decision will at least suspend further consolidation of the global music industry even as album sales plummet.

Johnson & Johnson posted a 9 percent increase in second-quarter profit yesterday, as the acquisition of Pfizer’s consumer health products line offset a continuing decline in sales of its stents and a top drug.
The producer price index declined by 0.2 percent last month after shooting up by 0.9 percent in May, the Labor Department said, citing cheaper energy.
The airline is offering the buyouts in an effort to cut costs as the discount carrier heads into a period of expected slower growth.
The Plains Exploration and Production Company said  it would nearly double its output by acquiring the Pogo Producing Company in a $3.6 billion stock-and-cash deal.
Higher customer fees offset rising loan losses and pressure from interest rates and mortgage lending.
Seeking to placate critics who want details of how the city’s schools will use state money, Chancellor Joel I. Klein released figures that showed a Queens district as the winner.
This week, the Democratic Party chairman in New Jersey gave the state’s political establishment a bit of a start with his comments on television.
Corrections

An article in Business Day on Monday about a decision by Courtroom Television Network to change its name to truTV referred imprecisely to the occupation of Steven Brill, the network’s founder. Although Mr. Brill, a journalist and entrepreneur, is a graduate of Yale Law School, he has never practiced law.

An article last Wednesday about the planned executions of 20 men in Iran for morality crimes incorrectly translated part of a statement by a judiciary spokesman about the kinds of offenses the men had been convicted of committing. The spokesman, Alireza Jamshidi, said they included “rape, insulting religious sanctities and laws, and sodomy” — not “and homosexuality.”.

A sports picture caption on Monday about the Mets’ victory over the Reds on Sunday omitted a credit in some copies. The photographs of Lastings Milledge hitting a double in the second inning and making a catch in the first were by Barton Silverman/The New York Times.

Because of an editing error, a headline yesterday with an obituary about the designer of Matchbox cars rendered his surname incorrectly in some copies. He is Jack Odell, not O’Dell. Also, the obituary misstated the name of the military unit in which Mr. Odell served during World War II. It is the Royal Army Service Corps (part of the British Army); there is no Royal Army.

An article in Business Day last Wednesday about China’s execution of a former food and drug regulator for taking bribes referred incorrectly to pet food that led to the deaths of cats and dogs in the United States. The ingredients came from China; the pet food itself was not “Chinese-made.” (It was produced in the United States.).

An article Monday about a record settlement to be paid by the Archdiocese of Los Angeles to victims of sexual abuse by clergy members referred incorrectly to the location of Our Mother of Good Counsel Church, some of whose parishioners were upset by the terms of the agreement. The church is in Los Feliz, a neighborhood of Los Angeles; Los Feliz is not a town in California.

A front-page article on Saturday about the conviction on fraud charges of Conrad M. Black, former chairman of the media company Hollinger International, misstated the location of a small newspaper covered by a noncompete agreement that was central to the fraud charges. It was in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., which is in Mono County. (There is no Mammoth County in California.).

A picture caption yesterday with an article about Senator Barack Obama’s campaign fund-raising network misstated the date of an event for Obama donors in Birmingham, Ala. It was on July 9, not on Monday.

A picture caption on Sunday with an article about the living conditions for Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, who is in prison near The Hague while being tried for war crimes, gave an incorrect date in some copies for the photograph, which showed him in court in Freetown, Sierra Leone. It was taken in April 2006, not this year.

The Saturday Profile article on July 7, about Avraham Rabby, an American diplomat based in Trinidad who lost his sight at the age of 8, referred incorrectly to a distinction. He is the State Department’s first diplomat who was blind at the time he was recruited; he is not the only blind diplomat the department has ever had.

Leo Nunez took a shutout into the fifth inning in his first career start, outpitching the 15-year veteran Tim Wakefield last night to help the visiting Kansas City Royals defeat the Boston Red Sox, 9-3.
football.

Kathleen Hersey won the 400-meter individual medley and Jessica Rodriguez took the 400 freestyle for the United States in the swimming competition at the Pan American Games yesterday in Rio de Janeiro.Shawn Johnson, the 15-year-old who won the women’s all-around gymnastics title Monday, won gold in the balance beam and uneven bars and a silver in the floor exercise. And Jason Turner won his second gold in shooting, winning the 10-meter air-pistol title.

Wide receiver Troy Brown signed with the New England Patriots for a 15th season yesterday, giving him a chance to increase his team record of 557 catches. Brown, 36, has spent his entire career with the Patriots since being drafted in the eighth round out of Marshall in 1993.

Lynn University’s 2005 Division II softball national championship will be vacated after the N.C.A.A. announced sanctions yesterday. The N.C.A.A. found that the former coach, Thomas Macera, made improper payments of $3,188.61 to pay for tuition and books for two players in 2005, the N.C.A.A. said. The N.C.A.A. did not refer to Macera by name, but said the former head coach committed the violations.

Andrew Svoboda, a 27-year-old professional playing out of Winged Foot, posted a three-under-par 68 to take the early lead at the 30th New York State Open at the Bethpage Black Course. Svoboda holds a one-shot lead over Chris Damiano of Westchester Hills Golf Club. They were the only players under par on the 7,241-yard course.
David Nalbandian, seeded fourth, lost to Igor Kunitsyn, 7-6 (5), 7-5, in the first round of the ATP Countrywide Classic yesterday in Los Angeles. Kunitsyn, 25, is ranked 99th.

Lindsay Davenport said yesterday that she was considering a return to the WTA Tour. Less than six weeks after giving birth to her son, Jagger, the 31-year-old Davenport was planning to play in a World Team Tennis match Saturday in Sacramento. A gold medalist at the 1996 Olympics, Davenport also said she would like to play in the 2008 Beijing Games.

The California Court of Appeal said yesterday that the San Francisco 49ers may continue to pat down fans before they enter Monster Park for the team’s home games. Two season-ticket holders sued the team for invasion of privacy in 2005, when the 49ers instituted the policy.

Daunte Culpepper, a former Pro Bowl quarterback, was released by Miami yesterday. The Dolphins tried unsuccessfully for weeks to trade Culpepper. The move came a day before a breach-of-contract grievance — filed by the N.F.L. Players Association on Culpepper’s behalf — was scheduled to be heard. Culpepper, 30, became expendable six weeks ago, when the Dolphins made a trade with Kansas City for Trent Green, who will be Miami’s starter entering this season.
A 500-pound man was pulled to safety from the St. Croix River by dozens of rescue workers who spent hours carrying him to a navigable part of the waterway.
Three people charged with enslaving members of a Chinese acrobatic troupe in Las Vegas have been released from jail while prosecutors continue investigating.

Enveloped in a corruption scandal, the minister of the economy, Felisa Miceli, left, resigned, after more than $60,000 was found in the bathroom of her office last month. Ms. Miceli denied any wrongdoing, saying the money was part of a real estate transaction she planned to make. But opposition leaders openly scoffed at her account, and government investigators were demanding to question her. The departure of Ms. Miceli, who has been replaced by Miguel Peirano, the secretary of industry, comes barely three months before the presidential elections.

Britain’s second largest supermarket chain, Asda, apologized for criticizing the publisher of the Harry Potter books, ending a dispute that had threatened to keep the latest volume off its shelves. Asda, which is owned by Wal-Mart, withdrew a statement accusing Bloomsbury PLC of “blatant profiteering” on its suggested retail price for “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.” Bloomsbury said earlier that it was canceling Asda’s order for 500,000 copies of the book, the seventh and final volume of the series, because Asda owed the publisher money. Asda later said it had sent money, but neither side would disclose the amount involved. Asda said the book would be in its stores by Saturday.

A man who took his 10-year-old son running with the bulls in Pamplona has lost his visitation rights. Spanish television captured images of the boy smiling as he ran ahead of a pack of charging bulls with his father. The images angered Pamplona city officials — and the man’s ex-wife. According to city regulations, runners in the festival must be 18 years old. On Monday, a judge in the town of Fuenlabrada, southwest of Madrid, revoked the father’s visitation rights. City officials in Pamplona also fined the father $200.

President João Bernardo Vieira announced the postponement of legislative elections in a bid to save costs. Instead of having the vote in March, Mr. Vieira said, the polls would be held alongside presidential elections in 2009. The head of the national electoral commission said that Guinea-Bissau, the world’s fifth poorest nation, was not in a financial position to organize parliamentary elections for March 2008; civil servants have not been paid in months.
Dow Chemical will remove 50,000 cubic yards of dioxin-contaminated sediment and earth from the riverbed and levees of the Tittabawassee River.
The Bush administration has asked for more time to respond to subpoenas related to the National Security Agency’s program of wiretapping without warrants, and the panel has agreed.

A 28-year-old man was sentenced to three and a half years in prison for possessing materials deemed likely to help plan or commit terrorism. The man, Yassin Nassari, was arrested last year at London Luton Airport when he returned from Amsterdam. When they raided his house, the authorities found that he had information to build a viable rocket and that he had videos of beheadings and documents with titles like “Preparing the Fighter Who is Going for Jihad.” Deputy Assistant Commissioner Peter Clarke of the Metropolitan Police said it was unclear what Mr. Nassari had planned, but that “his research could have ended up in the hands of individuals or groups willing to put it into practice.”.

A senior Chinese official rejected the findings of a recent World Bank study that said pollution caused 750,000 premature deaths in this country every year. “I think the World Bank report lacks a precise, scientific foundation, regardless of how many people it says die in China because of pollution.” said the official, Zhou Jian.
The discharge of chemicals into the Gulf of Mexico has increased so much that government scientists are predicting that this year’s area of oxygen depletion may cover the largest area ever.

China announced the first sentences for people implicated in a large-scale slave labor scandal involving brick kilns in Shanxi Province. Zhao Yanbing, a guard at one of the kilns who was convicted of beating a mentally handicapped worker to death with a shovel, was given the death penalty, while the plant’s foreman was given a life term for imprisoning 31 workers.
Coming off a dynamic 2006 in which he hit 41 homers and drove in 116 runs to compensate for his uninspiring debut season with the Mets, Carlos Beltrán has reverted back to his 2005 form.

The Department of Homeland Security is expected to announce that New York will receive $134 million this year to prevent terrorism attacks or respond to them, despite calls for more money from New York officials.
The authorities identified a man shot to death by a state trooper outside the governor’s Capitol office as a 32-year-old with an apparent mental problem.
Luis Vizcaíno has pitched well enough lately to make a case for Kyle Farnsworth’s eighth-inning role, but Manager Joe Torre has no plans to give it to him.

The head of the state Republican Party filed legal papers yesterday in an attempt to block the governor’s former companion from joining a lawsuit over whether e-mail messages between her and Gov. Jon S. Corzine should be made public. Tom Wilson, the Republican Party chairman, argued in legal papers that the former companion, Carla Katz, failed to demonstrate that her intervention in the lawsuit was warranted. Ms. Katz, whose relationship with Mr. Corzine ended before he took office, is president of the largest state workers union chapter, Communications Workers of America Local 1034. Mr. Wilson has said he is seeking the e-mail messages to determine whether the relationship tainted labor negotiations.

The New York State Education Department said yesterday that it would review the records of all people with Touro College degrees who received professional licenses or teaching certificates from the state in recent years to make sure their records were not falsified. Tom Dunn, a department spokesman, said the department was undertaking an investigation “to ensure the public is protected from unscrupulous, unqualified and unlicensed individuals.” The investigation follows the announcement on Monday by the Manhattan district attorney that Touro’s former admissions director and former computer center director had been indicted in a scheme to sell fake college transcripts to people who had never attended Touro and to change grades for actual students, and that they may have altered or created hundreds, if not thousands, of falsified transcripts. Ronald J. Aiello, the lawyer for Andrique Baron, Touro’s former admissions director, said yesterday that his client “received no money to change anybody’s grades,” but had tried to help authorities by “exposing a system that was susceptible to corruption.”.

Five people were arrested yesterday in connection with false records and certifications filed with the city Buildings Department, prosecutors said. The people, including two expeditors, two engineers and a contractor, were charged with a variety of offenses related to the fake records, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said city investigators found cases in which plans were certified as correct without inspections or review. In one case, he said, an addition to a house was discovered that could have collapsed on its occupants; in another, a gym had to be closed and vacated because of numerous violations and a fake certificate of occupancy.

A Brooklyn girl, 4, was treated yesterday at Maimonides Medical Center after being sexually assaulted on Monday in Borough Park, the police said. She was discovered by a neighborhood resident wandering alone in the street about 9 p.m. on Monday after a man picked her up in a black car on 52nd Street between 19th and 20th Avenues, drove her to an unknown location, exposed himself and forcibly touched her, investigators said. The police were seeking the assailant, who they said was wearing a black T-shirt. Assemblyman Dov Hikind, who represents Borough Park, urged parents to be vigilant. “There are sick predators out there who may be watching our children and waiting for the opportunity when they are unattended,” he said.

A former Philippine National Police officer was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to six years and four months in prison for his role in a plot in which he obtained secret United States documents in an attempt to undermine the Philippine government. The former officer, Michael Ray Aquino, 41, pleaded guilty in July 2006, admitting he possessed the secret documents. Also pleading guilty in the case was Leandro Aragoncillo, 48, a former marine who worked as a military aide to vice presidents Al Gore and Dick Cheney before becoming an F.B.I. intelligence analyst. Mr. Aragoncillo is scheduled to be sentenced tomorrow and faces 10 to 15 years in prison. He admitted to passing information to Mr. Aquino and opposition politicians in the Philippines.

Workers who say that toxic dust from the World Trade Center site has given them serious health problems filed a lawsuit yesterday against an insurance fund set up by Congress to insure the city and its contractors after the Sept 11 attack. The lawsuit, filed in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, is seeking compensation from the fund, WTC Captive Insurance Company, on behalf of thousands of workers who became ill after working to clean up the site. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the workers’ lawyers were incorrect about the purpose of the fund. The mayor said the insurance fund could pay only workers who win judgments against the city. “The truth of the matter is, Congress didn’t set up a victims’ compensation fund,” the mayor said.

The Oyster Creek nuclear power plant shut down yesterday morning after a pump failed, forcing the 636-megawatt reactor off line, plant officials said. One of three pumps that supply water to the nuclear reactor broke down, causing water levels to drop inside the reactor and triggering an automatic shutdown at 5:22 a.m., said Leslie Cifelli, a spokeswoman for the company that owns the plant, AmerGen Energy. Ms. Cifelli said the cause of the pump failure was under investigation yesterday, but preliminary indications were that an electrical problem caused the shutdown. She said she did not know when the plant would return to service.

Hospitals, schools and other nonprofit groups seeking tax-exempt financing through the state’s 115 industrial development agencies received a reprieve from the State Senate on Monday. The Senate approved a seven-month extension of the agencies’ power to sell bonds on behalf of nonprofit organizations, which had expired on June 30. However, one of the largest projects that had been expected to be financed through such a request, $190 million for the construction of three parking garages at the new Yankee Stadium, will not be among the projects considered at next week’s meeting of New York City’s industrial development agency, an agency spokesman said. The project could be discussed at a later meeting, agency officials said.

Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, left, announced plans yesterday to create a solar power development center on the site of the former I.B.M. complex in Kingston. Under the proposal, the site, now called Tech City, will be the host of a consortium of research and manufacturing groups that will develop solar power devices, the congressman said. The House was expected yesterday to approve $1.5 million to start the project, said Jeff Lieberson, a spokesman for Mr. Hinchey. The congressman said the consortium was expected to create 300 to 500 jobs.

A fraternal order of black firefighters filed court papers yesterday for its effort to join a lawsuit in which the federal Justice Department has accused the city of inadvertently discouraging blacks and Hispanics from joining the Fire Department. Lawyers for the organization, the Vulcan Society, filed papers in federal District Court in Brooklyn seeking to join the lawsuit, which argues that a written exam used by the city in 1999 and 2002 to screen new employees included questions that did not measure someone’s ability to fight fires. The city, while acknowledging that the department is primarily white, has said it has taken steps to encourage diversity.
Opponents of abstinence education cite a study that found no sign that it delayed a teenager’s sexual debut.
Libya changed the death sentences of six medical workers to life in prison after the families of the infected children each received $1 million.
Some Republicans who have gone public with their complaints about the war strategy also weighed in against the Democratic withdrawal plan as ill advised.
Candidates are already building up operations in states whose early primaries have forced a burst of spending.
Chris Demarest, the assistant head football coach at Rutgers, was arrested early Saturday and charged with assaulting a woman after an incident at a bar in Long Branch, N.J.
Assassinations and car bombs killed at least 39 people in Iraq on Tuesday and details emerged of a massacre of Shiite civilians in Diyala Province on Monday.
The Jupitermedia Corporation, an Internet research company that also sells photos and art, agreed to pay $23 million for Mediabistro.com.
Even by Albany standards, the battle for the State Senate has become unusually open and hostile.
A rare all-night Senate session unfolded earlier in the day with the traditional pageantry: the unveiling of nearly a dozen metal cots, in case senators wished to rest during debate.
A final decision will be made by the company’s controlling family, the Bancrofts, which could seek to scuttle the sale.
President Bush’s top counterterrorism advisers acknowledged that the strategy for fighting Osama bin Laden’s leadership of Al Qaeda in Pakistan had failed.
A court ruling that forces voters to register by party could return Mississippi to the days of racially polarized politics.
Yi Jianlian, the 7-foot power forward from China who was selected by the Milwaukee Buck in the N.B.A. draft, will “definitely not” join the Bucks, according to a report in Tuesday’s Beijing News.
A plane landing at an airport in São Paulo, Brazil, skidded off a runway and crashed into a gas station.
Most of the United States national team that may end up in South Africa for the 2010 World Cup will be a delicate mix of young and old, experience and exuberance.
The company told investors that two of its troubled hedge funds that bet heavily on risky subprime loans now have “very little value.”
State officials say that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used a doomed strategy to push for congestion pricing.
Apollo Management plans to sell shares of itself quickly while avoiding the disclosure involved in a public offering.
The company will significantly expand its Print Ads program, in which advertisers purchase ads in newspapers through the Web.
The Falcons’ Michael Vick has been indicted on charges that he sponsored and gambled on dogfighting and authorized acts of cruelty against animals on property that he owned.
The officer, Russel Timoshenko, 23, died five days after he was shot in the face by a man in a stolen car.
There’s a chance that a mid-21st-century Californian will look back in horror at the enormous consumption footprint of someone living in the state right now.
According to testimony Tuesday, exporters have been able to bring tainted products into the U.S. because the F.D.A. has neither enough resources nor inspectors to stop them.
With little fanfare, Taiwan companies are playing a big role not only in the production of Apple’s latest device but in a wide array of other communications equipment.
Christopher Cox will call for the passage of  several measures intended to bolster the powers of  the board that oversees financial disclosures by state and local governments.
Michael Reardon, an internationally renowned rock climber who climbed without a rope or safety equipment, is presumed dead after he was swept away by a wave Friday off the coast of Ireland.
Public health officials now recognize that condom-distribution programs are integral to any meaningful AIDS prevention program.
Eleven big food companies have agreed to stop advertising products that do not meet certain nutritional standards to children under 12.
Following are the “key judgments” released by the White House from a July 2007 National Intelligence Estimate on “The Terrorist Threat to the U.S. Homeland.”
Will the roof-dwellers, ballhawks and bleacher bums keep a historic home run ball hit by Barry Bonds, a disliked opposing player, or keep with Wrigley Field tradition and throw it back?
In Totowa, N.J., a retired police officer sprang into action when he heard gunshots outside his front door.
Habitat for Humanity International, a grass-roots movement, is fraying under new leadership that is trying to centralize it.
For next year’s final presidential debates, New Orleans should emerge hands down as the site for the debate that will be dedicated to the nation’s domestic problems.
The money needed to treat ailing ground zero workers could soar to $20 million a month by the end of this year, up from about $6 million a month now.
Federal officials said that the officer, Darren Moonan, had a secret life as a one-man security team for a gang of robbers.
Tokyo Electric Power, which operates the plant,  said it had found more than 50 problems caused by the earthquake on Monday.
What appear to be pages from the eagerly awaited final installment in the series have been circulating online.
The chip maker, a closely watched indicator of the overall health of the technology industry, reported net income of $1.3 billion, on revenue of $8.7 billion in the second quarter.
Candidates expressed commitment to reversing the Bush administration’s approach to abortion rights, judicial appointments, sex education and contraception.
By now, Congress surely can see through the president’s fear-mongering and show him the exit from Iraq that he refuses to find for himself.
In many respects, a new intelligence report suggests, the terrorist threat against the U.S. is growing worse.
Citizenship and Immigration Services reversed a government decision that prevented thousands of legal immigrants from obtaining work-based permanent visas.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,610 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
A proposal by a joint task force to block three unguarded streets straddling Canada and the United States has, if anything, united two cross-border towns.
In a turnaround as swift as it has been stunning, the Big East Conference has transformed from a college football punch line into a national power in the past two years.
More than 200,000 customers of the Internet company could lose telephone access and money paid in advance now that it has gone out of business.
A pilot program by the Federal Reserve and state banking  regulators will examine firms that account for the majority of subprime loans.
A report says the most common problems at the seven city-operated beaches are too much litter and too few lifeguards.
After overseeing the rising fortunes of the Xbox 360 game console, Peter Moore will run the sports division of the leading game publisher.
The nation’s largest retail brokerage said stronger investment banking results and fees from stock transactions helped boost profit to $2.07 billion.
The drought in majors for Europeans in golf stands in chiaroscuro contrast to the surplus of titles they have claimed collectively.
A professional rugby player played for more than three months without knowing that an opponent’s tooth was embedded in his head.
The World Trade Organization called on the United States and Europe to lower their farm barriers in return for greater export access to India, Brazil and other developing countries.
I.B.M. has been reorganized from a classic multinational company to a more seamless global enterprise.
To help protect its brand, the College Board is creating a list of classes that high schools are authorized to call AP and reviewing the syllabuses for classes.
Elizabeth Edwards is again making sharper comments on the presidential campaign trail than any of the actual candidates.
A House subcommittee will examine flaws in the federal procurement system that let contractors with poor performance records renew contracts.
The company said that Coca-Cola Zero soda and Dasani bottled water spurred the biggest sales increase in almost 13 years.
Chrysler is the first carmaker to announce a change in production plans related to efforts in Congress to require vehicles sold in the United States to consume less gasoline.
Investigators said that the professional wrestler Chris Benoit had extremely high levels of testosterone in his system when he killed his wife, his son and himself.
A suicide bomber detonated a powerful bomb 100 yards from where the country’s suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, was to speak at a rally.
The youngest and first black pilot to fly around the world in a single-engine plane celebrated his achievement with Sonny Grasso at Rao’s in East Harlem.
Played on windswept courses that are linked to the sea, the British Open is often an exercise in hitting low, running shots, while other PGA Tour events call for high shots that land softly.
Hopes that a diet low in fat and full of fruits and vegetables could prevent the return of breast cancer were dashed by a seven-year experiment.
Carleton Mitchell won the prestigious Newport Bermuda Race a record three consecutive times, and chronicled the joys and challenges of sailing in his books, magazine articles and photographs.
Dr. Ward helped devise the process by which winners of the MacArthur Foundation’s “genius awards” are selected each year without their even knowing they have been nominated.

10 P.M. (22, 26) DAVID HOCKNEY: THE COLORS OF MUSIC Mr. Hockney, left, an Englishman living in Los Angeles, has long been known for his color-splashed paintings and prints of California’s natural wonders, particularly its swimming pools. But across three decades he also designed sets and costumes for 11 opera productions — from Mozart’s “Magic Flute” to Stravinsky’s “Rake’s Progress” to Ravel’s “Enfant” — even as he went deaf. This 2005 documentary, in its television premiere, follows Mr. Hockney, a passionate music lover, as the connection between what he sees and what he hears fails him. “You lose the desire to hear,” Mr. Hockney says. “If you still had that, it would be painful.”.

To the Editor: Re ''Heroes and History'' (column, July 17):

The New York State Education Department said yesterday that it would review the records of all people with Touro College degrees who received professional licenses or teaching certificates from the state in recent years to make sure their records were not falsified. Tom Dunn, a department spokesman, said the department was undertaking an investigation ''to ensure the public is protected from unscrupulous, unqualified and unlicensed individuals.'' The investigation follows the announcement on Monday by the Manhattan district attorney that Touro's former admissions director and former computer center director had been indicted in a scheme to sell fake college transcripts to people who had never attended Touro and to change grades for actual students, and that they may have altered or created hundreds, if not thousands, of falsified transcripts. Ronald J. Aiello, the lawyer for Andrique Baron, Touro's former admissions director, said yesterday that his client ''received no money to change anybody's grades,'' but had tried to help authorities by ''exposing a system that was susceptible to corruption.''

MORRIS--Jewell. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Jewell Morris and extends sincere sympathy to her family and friends. Ira A. Eichner, President Arthur S. Loring, Secretary

An article in Business Day on Monday about a decision by Courtroom Television Network to change its name to truTV referred imprecisely to the occupation of Steven Brill, the network's founder. Although Mr. Brill, a journalist and entrepreneur, is a graduate of Yale Law School, he has never practiced law.

RIFKIN--Lawrence. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of Lawrence Rifkin. Son of our esteemed members, Barbara and Dr. Howard Rifkin and extends heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Andrew Warmflash, Rabbi Stanley Platek, Liz Kislik, President #

F. Champion Ward, a noted educator and former Ford Foundation executive who helped devise the process by which winners of the MacArthur Foundation's ''genius awards'' are selected each year without their even knowing they have been nominated, died July 2 at his home in North Branford, Conn. He was 96. The death was confirmed by his son Geoffrey C. Ward, the historian.

A handful of Republicans who have distanced themselves from President Bush on the war in Iraq refused Tuesday to back a plan to withdraw American troops from the conflict, leaving Senate Democrats short of the support needed to force a vote on their proposal. As the Senate headed into an all-night session complete with cots in Capitol meeting rooms and an antiwar vigil across the street, some Republicans who have gone public with their complaints about the war strategy also weighed in against the Democratic withdrawal plan as ill advised and driven mainly by partisan considerations.

Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about a controversy over an ad campaign by the condom maker Trojan, referred imprecisely to its ownership. Although the private equity firm Kelso & Company joined Church & Dwight in purchasing Trojan's parent company in 2001, the Trojan brand is now owned solely by Church & Dwight.

In a rousing indictment of the Bush administration and the Supreme Court it created, Senator Barack Obama told a Planned Parenthood convention here on Tuesday that the next election would decide a fundamental question: ''What kind of America will our daughters grow up in?'' The speech by Mr. Obama, of Illinois, came on a day when the leading candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination expressed their commitment to reversing the Bush administration's approach to abortion rights, judicial appointments, sex education and contraception.
GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly -dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love Fran

To the Editor: Security personnel should treat the children they are caring for with respect and fairness (editorial, July 16). But the hundreds of out-of-control students who curse, bully, never stay in their seats, throw objects, steal and never listen to instructions create a far greater problem for urban schools than awful security guards, who can be removed far more easily than uncontrollable students. Elliot Kotler

A Brooklyn girl, 4, was treated yesterday at Maimonides Medical Center after being sexually assaulted on Monday in Borough Park, the police said. She was discovered by a neighborhood resident wandering alone in the street about 9 p.m. on Monday after a man picked her up in a black car on 52nd Street between 19th and 20th Avenues, drove her to an unknown location, exposed himself and forcibly touched her, investigators said. The police were seeking the assailant, who they said was wearing a black T-shirt. Assemblyman Dov Hikind, who represents Borough Park, urged parents to be vigilant. ''There are sick predators out there who may be watching our children and waiting for the opportunity when they are unattended,'' he said.

An article last Wednesday about the planned executions of 20 men in Iran for morality crimes incorrectly translated part of a statement by a judiciary spokesman about the kinds of offenses the men had been convicted of committing. The spokesman, Alireza Jamshidi, said they included ''rape, insulting religious sanctities and laws, and sodomy'' -- not ''and homosexuality.''

Five people were arrested yesterday in connection with false records and certifications filed with the city Buildings Department, prosecutors said. The people, including two expeditors, two engineers and a contractor, were charged with a variety of offenses related to the fake records, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said city investigators found cases in which plans were certified as correct without inspections or review. In one case, he said, an addition to a house was discovered that could have collapsed on its occupants; in another, a gym had to be closed and vacated because of numerous violations and a fake certificate of occupancy.
Mom, Have Pity To the Editor:

PINOVER--Harriet, on July 17th, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Loving and devoted mother of Constance Seldin, Eugene and the late Richard. Caring and much loved grandmother of Julia, Benjamin and Hannah. Admired mother-in-law of Diana Elzey Pinover, Dr. Leslie Seldin and Betsy Pinover Schiff. Her strong will and determined way were an inspiration. She was a lady and knew how to conduct herself. She has a keen eye for art and impeccable taste. Foremost she was devoted to her family. She will be dearly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Alzheimer's Association. Funeral services Wednesday July 18th, 2007, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Private Interment.

ADAMS--Glenda. We are deeply saddened by the death of our friend, fellow writer, and former associate director on Wednesday, July 11, in Sydney, Australia. Glenda, 67, was the author of several novels and short story collections, including ''Dancing on Coral'', which won both the Miles Franklin Award and a New South Wales Literary Award in 1987. She taught writing at Columbia University and Sarah Lawrence College, as well as at several universities in her native Australia. She played an important role in the early days of our organization, and we will miss her good friendship and wise counsel. The writers, staff, and Board of Teachers & Writers Collaborative

Because of an editing error, a headline yesterday with an obituary about the designer of Matchbox cars rendered his surname incorrectly in some copies. He is Jack Odell, not O'Dell. Also, the obituary misstated the name of the military unit in which Mr. Odell served during World War II. It is the Royal Army Service Corps (part of the British Army); there is no Royal Army.

The Oyster Creek nuclear power plant shut down yesterday morning after a pump failed, forcing the 636-megawatt reactor off line, plant officials said. One of three pumps that supply water to the nuclear reactor broke down, causing water levels to drop inside the reactor and triggering an automatic shutdown at 5:22 a.m., said Leslie Cifelli, a spokeswoman for the company that owns the plant, AmerGen Energy. Ms. Cifelli said the cause of the pump failure was under investigation yesterday, but preliminary indications were that an electrical problem caused the shutdown. She said she did not know when the plant would return to service.

HINDES--Dr. Theodore, son of Fanny and Harry Hindes, died Monday July 16, 2007 in Lake Worth, FL at the age of 84. He is survived by his loving wife Gloria and his cherished son Dr. Richard Hindes. Teddy had two wonderful marriages. Teddy and Elaine. his late wife had two children, their beloved son Henry (Hank) and Richard. Teddy was also the loving stepfather of Lisa Gladstone, Sandi Nussbaum, Marla Wolfson and Pearl Lockwood and father-in-law to Roger, David, Lance, and Andy and his adored grandchildren Sarah, Meredith, Wesley, Cliff, Lloyd, Reuben, Zoe, Lee, Rachel, Lana, Brianna, Michael, Trevor, Kate, Jack, Harry, Lizzie and Samantha. The Funeral will take place at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, NY on Thursday July 19, 2007, at 10am. HINDES--Theodore. Our deepest sympathy goes out to Teddy's family. He was a devoted husband, loving father and adoring grandfather. He will be greatly missed. All our love, Jane, Stanley, Robyn and Margot Blum.

APPEL--Bluma. The Council for Canadian American Relations announces with deep sadness the passing of its founder, Bluma Appel. Her achievements and contributions generated wide respect and numerous honors in her beloved country of Canada. She was known in New York and Florida for her pride in, and support of, Canadian accomplishments. Bluma was a woman of great passion and impact affecting the many social causes she took up. She will be greatly missed. Board of Directors, Council for Canadian American Relations
POSNIK--Flora Zwart. Beloved by all who knew her, passed away July 9, 2007. Private graveside services were held. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at a future date.

China announced the first sentences for people implicated in a large-scale slave labor scandal involving brick kilns in Shanxi Province. Zhao Yanbing, a guard at one of the kilns who was convicted of beating a mentally handicapped worker to death with a shovel, was given the death penalty, while the plant's foreman was given a life term for imprisoning 31 workers.

The Department of Homeland Security is expected to announce Wednesday that New York will receive $134 million this year to prevent terrorism attacks or respond to them, despite calls for more money from New York officials. The grant is part of the department's Urban Areas Security Initiative, which will divide about $747 million among 45 urban areas.

BROTHERS--William, 86, passed away peacefully, July 11, 2007. Father of the late Bill, Jr. and Denise, grandfather of Lily and Ben. Formerly vice president of Revlon. An avid golfer. My grandfather was a source of inspiration, I shall miss his love and encouragement, they will stay with me always. Ben Brothers

COLBY GARRELTS never doubted that his hometown would appreciate his skill in the kitchen. He had climbed from busboy and steakhouse line cook to sous-chef at one of this city's most adventurous restaurants. Then he wandered the culinary horizon, but he always intended to return home.

A 28-year-old man was sentenced to three and a half years in prison for possessing materials deemed likely to help plan or commit terrorism. The man, Yassin Nassari, was arrested last year at London Luton Airport when he returned from Amsterdam. When they raided his house, the authorities found that he had information to build a viable rocket and that he had videos of beheadings and documents with titles like ''Preparing the Fighter Who is Going for Jihad.'' Deputy Assistant Commissioner Peter Clarke of the Metropolitan Police said it was unclear what Mr. Nassari had planned, but that ''his research could have ended up in the hands of individuals or groups willing to put it into practice.''

FRANKIEL--Rita. The New York Freudian Society mourns the loss of Rita Frankiel, respected teacher, writer, mentor and cherished friend. Her vitality, intelligence, courage, and capacity for deep understanding and love will be greatly missed.

FRIEDMAN--Frances Karo, July 18, 1920 -June 24, 2005. We are at the gravesite in honor of a great lady who portrayed the qualities which make us proud. This is your birthday and we are here to pay tribute. Years past we would celebrate but now we can only recall such beautiful memories each and every day. We love you from awakening to retiring. You are always with us. Anita, Georgie, and Oscar

PRIETO--Jose Raul. A Memorial Mass will be held at noon, July 19, 2007 at St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79th St.

A man, 27, was fatally shot in Brooklyn yesterday shortly before 9 p.m., the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, was shot multiple times in the torso in front of 187 Buffalo Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant and taken to Kings County Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. There have been no arrests.

MULLIGAN--Roseanna. Hartmere, William H. Mulligan, Jr., Class of 1974 and Stephen E. Mulligan, Class of 1977. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. GENSER--Ruth & Sid. Happy 59th Anniversary! What I would give for just one more day...Always remembered, missed & loved. -Barbara

Enveloped in a corruption scandal, the minister of the economy, Felisa Miceli, left, resigned, after more than $60,000 was found in the bathroom of her office last month. Ms. Miceli denied any wrongdoing, saying the money was part of a real estate transaction she planned to make. But opposition leaders openly scoffed at her account, and government investigators were demanding to question her. The departure of Ms. Miceli, who has been replaced by Miguel Peirano, the secretary of industry, comes barely three months before the presidential elections.

An article Monday about a record settlement to be paid by the Archdiocese of Los Angeles to victims of sexual abuse by clergy members referred incorrectly to the location of Our Mother of Good Counsel Church, some of whose parishioners were upset by the terms of the agreement. The church is in Los Feliz, a neighborhood of Los Angeles; Los Feliz is not a town in California.

Pacific Natural Foods, a company that makes organic products like soups, started producing ready-to-drink teas in shelf-stable boxes of a generous 2 liters (about 2 1/2 quarts) last year. These were sold mainly on the West Coast, but now they are available nationally, in Whole Foods supermarkets and natural food stores, for around $5 a box. The unsweetened green tea variety is a delicious, slightly herbaceous quencher to keep in the refrigerator, ready to pour. Other flavors are peach, lemon, raspberry and sweetened black tea.

President João Bernardo Vieira announced the postponement of legislative elections in a bid to save costs. Instead of having the vote in March, Mr. Vieira said, the polls would be held alongside presidential elections in 2009. The head of the national electoral commission said that Guinea-Bissau, the world's fifth poorest nation, was not in a financial position to organize parliamentary elections for March 2008; civil servants have not been paid in months.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Top White House AdvisersAdmit Failure in Pakistan President Bush's top counterterrorism advisers acknowledged that the strategy for fighting the leadership of Al Qaeda in Pakistan had failed, as the White House released an intelligence assessment that has forced the administration to consider more aggressive measures inside Pakistan. A1

URIARTE--Ignacio. Rest in peace dear friend and colleague. With love and sympathy to Susan, Ignacio Jr., Sebastian and Andres, as well as his entire family. Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, July 19 at 6:30pm, Botanical Gardens, ''Snuff Mill'', Bronx, NY. ICD Group International Inc and UMC

Russia says it will respond in a ''targeted'' manner to Britain's expulsion of four diplomats in a confrontation over the radiation poisoning of a former KGB officer in London, an official warned. The official, Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksandr V. Grushko, suggested that Russia might limit counterterrorism cooperation with the British government, threatening what had been a strength in their relationship, though he offered no specifics. Still, both Mr. Grushko and British diplomats tried to assuage concerns that the dispute would disrupt business between the countries, including a large BP investment in Russia.

The New York Philharmonic reached into its family tree and plucked Alan Gilbert, the 40-year-old son of two Philharmonic musicians, as its next music director, making him the first native New Yorker in the position and a rare American in the job. Philharmonic officials also said they would appoint an elder statesman, Riccardo Muti, 65, to serve in a supporting role equivalent to principal guest conductor.

What does it take to run a national presidential campaign more than half a year before the Iowa caucuses? New finance reports show that the candidates are already building up their operations in several states whose early primaries have forced a burst of spending that is severely taxing the campaigns. The candidates are opening offices in states like California, Florida, Michigan, Nevada and others that now expect to hold nominating contests by early February, according to the reports, which were filed last weekend. In past elections, candidates focused their early resources largely on Iowa and New Hampshire.

McKENNA--Ron. My dear, precious friend. Your death is not only a loss to The Pines, but a loss to humanity. Your sun-kissed smile and personal gifts of help and kindness have been so special to me and made being home in The Pines joyous.
