KRON--Leslie. Idealistic 16year-old, beloved daughter of Joan and Sam, and sister of Daniel. Died July 19, 1968, aboard the hospital ship, S.S. Hope, in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Never forgotten.

A month after being named chairman of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, John Tusa relinquished the post yesterday. He was to begin the job in November. Mr. Tusa explained that when he was appointed, he had already agreed to become the chairman of the University of the Arts London, and that neither organization saw a conflict of interest in occupying both positions. But afterward, he said, ''The possibility of confusion about where my loyalties lay risked damaging one or both institutions.'' He continued, ''After serious discussion and hard thought, I have reached the conclusion that such concerns are both realistic and reasonable.''

Services Thursday, July 19, 2007, 10:30 am at the ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

Researchers at Boston University said they had found a vast underground lake, roughly the size of Massachusetts or Lake Erie, in Darfur that could provide water to the parched region and help ease the conflict that has devastated the region for four years. A team of geologists from the university's Center for Remote Sensing has called for 1,000 wells to be dug in the region to provide water to farmers and herders, thereby decreasing competition over scarce resources. Scarcity of water and farmable land is believed to have helped spark the conflict that has killed at least 200,000 people and sent 2.5 million fleeing their homes.
WARD--F. Champion. Florentine Films is saddened by the loss of F. Champion Ward, and extends our sympathy to our dear friend, and colleague, Geoffrey C. Ward and his family.

The generals who rule Myanmar, still insisting they are on the march to democracy, opened what they said would be the final session of a constitutional convention that critics say is itself undemocratic. More than 1,000 government-approved delegates gathered near the commercial capital, Yangon, to approve guidelines for the long-delayed constitution. It is the first step in a seven-stage ''road map to democracy'' that is supposed to lead to new elections and what the junta calls a disciplined form of democratic rule. The draft that has been published assures that the military will remain in command through an allocation of parliamentary seats and control of the presidency and key government ministries.

Detroit Tigers outfielder Gary Sheffield was fined an undisclosed amount by Major League Baseball yesterday for remarks he made about umpires. Pat Courtney, a baseball spokesman, said the fine stemmed from comments Sheffield made June 28 in which he questioned the integrity of umpires.

Greenpeace said it was seeking hundreds of adult volunteers to pose in the nude on a Swiss glacier for publicity photos about global warming that will be shot by the American photographer Spencer Tunick, who is renowned for his photos of crowds of naked people. Greenpeace says the campaign is intended to draw attention to melting Alpine glaciers, which it says are a sign of man-made climate change.

The comedian Dave Chappelle was hospitalized for exhaustion over the weekend, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Chappelle, 33, checked into an emergency room on Saturday and was released a few hours later, Carla Sims, his press representative, said. ''It was exhaustion; he had been traveling,'' she said. ''He's fine.'' In May 2005 Mr. Chappelle was said to have walked away from an estimated $50 million deal to continue his Comedy Central Show. He has since returned to the stand-up circuit.

Dan Golden, a New York cartoonist, has had his work published in Opium Magazine and The San Francisco Metropolitan, a monthly arts newspaper, but he was seeking a wider audience. ''I wanted to get my work out there,'' Mr. Golden said, adding gumptiously, ''like Charles Schulz or Jonathan Adler.'' Deciding that ''it would be so audacious to put cartoons on rugs,'' he teamed up with Ford Lininger, an interior designer, to produce six hand-tufted designs in New Zealand wool, including ''So Long, Suckahs!'' far right, and ''Keep Dogs Off Grass.'' The rugs come in four sizes, from 4 by 6 feet to 9 by 12, and start at $3,000. Available from Qui, 601 West 26th Street, (800) 836-1798 or quiny.com, and dangolden.com. LIZ ARNOLD

To the Editor: ''On L.I., Forbidden Tours of a Lost City'' (news article, July 16) correctly notes there are numerous fences, boarded windows, locked doors and no trespassing signs at the former Kings Park Psychiatric Center. Despite all the warnings, barriers and newly announced additional police patrols, adventure seekers break the law and trespass to gain access to these faltering buildings.

After the government promised to satisfy some of its demands, the Greek Archaeological Guards Union said yesterday it had called off a strike that would have closed the gates to the Acropolis in Athens from Saturday through Tuesday, Reuters reported. Demanding better pay for night duty and for six-day weeks, the union closed the Acropolis, the most visited monument in Greece, last weekend, disappointing thousands of tourists who climb its steep marble steps to visit the Parthenon and other monuments on the hill. ''If the government does not keep its promises by the end of August, we will strike again,'' said Yannis Dimakakos, a union member.

Clayton Borough's former police chief and his wife were indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $150,000 from Mothers Against Drunk Driving, state prosecutors said. The former chief, Frank Winters, and his wife, Bernice, were charged with conspiracy and theft by deception, said the state attorney general, Anne Milgram. Ms. Milgram said the Winters were both former leaders of the New Jersey state chapter of the organization. She said they were charged with placing orders for promotional items of behalf of the organization with companies that they owned, and failing to deliver the items. Compiled by John Sullivan

That ''Hairspray'' is good-hearted is no surprise. Adam Shankman's film, lovingly adapted from the Broadway musical, preserves the inclusive, celebratory spirit of John Waters's 1988 movie, in which bigger-boned, darker-skinned and otherwise different folk take exuberant revenge on the bigots and the squares who conspire to keep them down. The surprise may be that this ''Hairspray,'' stuffed with shiny showstoppers, Kennedy-era Baltimore beehives and a heavily padded John Travolta in drag, is actually good. Appropriately enough for a movie with such a democratic sensibility, there is plenty of credit to go around. Mr. Shankman, drawing on long experience as a choreographer, avoids the kind of vulgar overstatement that so often turns the joy of live musical theater into torment at the multiplex. The songs, by Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman, are usually adequate, occasionally inspired and only rarely inane. And they are sung with impeccable diction and unimpeachable conviction by a lively young cast that includes Nikki Blonsky, Amanda Bynes, Zac Efron and the phenomenally talented Elijah Kelley.

A Russian government inventory has determined that more than 160,000 artifacts are missing from that nation's museums, Reuters reported. ''The main thing we have found is that over the past 80 years, 160,000 items have gone missing,'' First Deputy Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev said. ''The situation is very alarming. We have probed 500 museums with 20 million items. This is one-quarter of the country's total museum collection.'' The investigation began after nearly $5 million in thefts from the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg focused attention on the antiquated inventory and security systems of Russian cultural institutions.

Ilevel, an art consulting and installation service, offers an easy solution for those who return from vacation with lots of new photographs. For $240, it will send someone with a trained eye to advise how to create a wall of framed photographs that can expand with each successive vacation. If you like, the consultant will hang them, too. Most projects are done within four hours, said David Kassel, the owner. Each additional hour is $60. Ilevel works mainly in the New York area, but its consultants will travel for an additional fee; (212) 477-4319 or ilevel.biz. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

The Bush administration has named a veteran federal prosecutor from Tennessee as the acting deputy attorney general at the Justice Department, an agency still reeling from the uproar over last year's firings of United States attorneys. If he is nominated and confirmed, Craig S. Morford, the interim United States attorney in Nashville, would take over as the No. 2 official at a department that current and former officials have described as demoralized, with lawmakers in both parties calling on Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to resign.

Harry Potter's witching hour -- the release of the seventh and final volume of his adventures -- has incurred the wrath of the trade and industry minister of Israel, Eli Yishai, below, Reuters reported. ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' by J. K. Rowling, is scheduled to go on sale in Israel at 2 a.m. on Saturday, during the Jewish Sabbath, and Mr. Yishai, a member of the Orthodox party Shas, said: ''It is forbidden, according to Jewish values and Jewish culture, that a thing like this should take place at 2 a.m. Saturday. Let them do it on another day.'' But Israeli stores pledged to proceed. ''We will hold the launch as planned because we are contractually bound to do so,'' Alona Zamir, a spokeswoman for the Steimatzky book chain, said. ''The book will go on sale here at the same time as in other places around the world.'' Mr. Yishai said, ''We will certainly issues fines and prosecution orders, but I hope it won't come to that.''

''Optimism'' is the first line of furniture produced by Council, a collaborative venture modeled on European companies like Cappellini and Established & Sons that pool the talents of an international group of designers. ''I've been designing and making furniture since I was a kid,'' said Derek Chen, the founder of the company, which is in San Francisco and will manufacture and distribute the line in the United States. ''Along the way, I found out two things: I can't make all this by myself, and customers want some sort of diversity from a collection, not just one point of view. That's how Council began.'' Among the first pieces are the Peel ottoman and chaise (below and below left, starting at around $2,500), by Khodi Feiz, a designer living in the Netherlands. Other contributors to the collection include Arik Levy, Mike and Maaike, One & Company and Mr. Chen. Information: councildesign.com. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

The British Broadcasting Corporation suspended all phone-in competitions and contests on its radio and television shows after a series of incidents in which, it said, the shows' makers misled viewers and listeners by, among other things, announcing fake winners and pretending that members of the production team were winning callers. ''The behavior of a small number of production staff who have passed themselves off as viewers and listeners must stop,'' Mark Thompson, the BBC director general, said. He also said that 16,500 employees involved in show production would attend a new mandatory training program, Safeguarding Trust. The BBC was already embarrassed last week when it emerged that footage in a promotional clip for a forthcoming show had been chronologically manipulated to make it appear that Queen Elizabeth had huffily stormed out of a session with the Vanity Fair photographer Annie Leibovitz. In fact, the queen was not being particularly huffy and never stormed out of the session.

An article yesterday about proposed changes at Habitat for Humanity International that are meeting with opposition from the charity's affiliates referred incorrectly to the location of the homes built by the group, and to the founder of the first affiliate in 1976. The 226,000 homes built so far are worldwide -- not just in the United States, where more than 66,000 have been built. And Faith Lytle, who started the first affiliate, in San Antonio, is married to a retired Presbyterian minister, not to a Methodist minister. The article also misidentified the hometown of former President Jimmy Carter, a longtime volunteer with the charity. It is Plains, Ga., not Americus.

An article yesterday about a special election in Georgia to fill the Congressional seat of Charlie Norwood, who died in February, misstated the year Mr. Norwood, a Republican, began serving in the House. It was 1995 -- not 1994, which was the year he was elected. (An updated article on the close vote count is on Page A21 today.)

An article last Thursday about opposition by the nation's largest firefighters union to the presidential candidacy of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani referred incorrectly to Richard Shierer, a Giuliani supporter, who was commissioner of the city's Office of Emergency Management on 9/11. Mr. Shierer is a former fire dispatcher, not a former firefighter.

A 20-year-old woman was sexually assaulted early yesterday in the East Village, and the police were investigating whether the attacker was responsible for three similar assaults. The woman, who was not identified, was attacked by a man on East Ninth Street shortly before 2 a.m., the police said. The earlier attacks took place on June 12, July 7 and last Friday, all around 4 a.m., in the East Village and the Lower East Side, the police said. In each case, a man between 18 and 24 followed his victims into their apartment buildings and attacked them, the police said. In two of those cases, the women fought the attacker off; in the third, neighbors fought him off, the police said. No arrests have been made.

Flatbar, the latest furniture collection from William Emmerson, a British interior designer based in Los Angeles, includes a coffee table, a console, a side table and variously sized mirrors, all in glass, brass and steel. What Mr. Emmerson, right, calls the furniture's ''perpendicular properties'' -- most pieces are square or rectangular -- are a departure from the round organic shapes of his previous collection, Ab Ovo. But the minimal lines are the same, as is his inventive use of materials. Prices start at $2,600 for the 20-inch-tall End Table, above. The 31-inch-wide Square Mirror, left, on a leather strap, is $5,500. Emmerson Troop, 8111 Beverly Boulevard, Los Angeles, (323) 653-9763 or emmersontroop.com. LIZ ARNOLD
KESSELER--Howard J., M.D. July 19, 2006. You are missed & forever in our hearts & minds. -Your loving family

A report in The Caucus roundup on Tuesday, about the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll measuring Americans' trust in government, referred incorrectly to some results about President Bush and Congress. Disapproval of both has been at record highs, not record lows.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Barbara Amiel, the wife of Conrad M. Black, the former media executive recently convicted on fraud charges, misstated her age. She is 66, not 65.

A UNION MAINLY OF RETIREES The United Automobile Workers union is entering national contract talks with more retirees than active workers in its ranks. That shift has the greatest impact on medical costs, so that even as the struggling car companies try to shed workers, their health care bill continues to rise as those people age. The Delphi Corporation and its former parent, General Motors, will lose out on more than $1 billion under a revised financing plan intended to bring Delphi out of bankruptcy by year's end. [C3.]

The leading Democratic presidential candidates yesterday seized on a newly released intelligence report that found the United States was losing ground on several fronts in the fight against Al Qaeda, saying it bolstered their arguments that the war in Iraq had been a costly distraction from broader efforts to keep the nation safe. The leading Republican candidates for president offered far more muted responses when asked about the report.
To the Editor: Re ''Bush Advisers See a Failed Strategy Against Al Qaeda'' (front page, July 18):

SLEPIAN--Florence. A light has gone out on Earth and moved to the heavens. Florence Geller Slepian passed away peacefully on July 16th in the 95th year of a rewarding life. Loving wife of Dr. Solomon Slepian (predeceased), devoted mother of Dr. Marvin Slepian (wife Donna), loving grandmother of Sara Elizabeth and Rebecca Claire. Warm and loving sister of Helen and Ann (predeceased), caring great-aunt, aunt, cousin and friend. A graduate of NYU and Columbia, in her professional career she served as teacher, guidance counselor and Principal of Thomas Jefferson High School (Elizabeth, NJ). Beyond this, she was a life long teacher and mentor to many, standing for education, communication and vision. To all who knew her she always reflected warmth, friendship and grace. She will be dearly missed. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Tucson Hebrew Academy, 3888 East River Road., Tucson, AZ 85718. Service Thursday July 19th 12 noon Yablokoff Chapel, 1978 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

A front-page article last Thursday about high prices for parking spaces in Manhattan included incorrect information from the New York Department of City Planning about the areas of Manhattan where spaces in new buildings are limited to 20 percent of the number of apartments. The 20 percent limit applies to new buildings below 60th Street, not below 96th Street. (Between 60th Street and 96th Street on the East Side and between 60th Street and 110th Street on the West Side, the number of parking spaces cannot exceed 35 percent of the units. In some areas outside the core of Manhattan, developers may be required to provide parking spaces to accommodate higher levels of car ownership.)

Federal health officials will do more tests on people exposed to formaldehyde in trailers provided for Gulf Coast residents after Hurricane Katrina. The Federal Emergency Management Agency said air samples taken from unoccupied trailers had shown that ventilation effectively reduced the levels of formaldehyde, a carcinogen. But the agency said it had asked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to do more tests on trailer residents. The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform plans a hearing on the subject today.

WHERE has all the color gone? Unlike the show houses of recent years, this summer's Hampton Designer Showhouse is filled with rooms decorated in taupe, mauve, beige and more beige. Neutrals overshadowed brights in the new 7-bedroom, 9 1/2-bath shingled house in Bridgehampton, Long Island, which opens to the public on Sunday to benefit Southampton Hospital. ''I used a neutral palette because while I adore color, I like it soft and muted,'' said Mark Epstein, one of 17 interior designers who decorated rooms in the house. ''It's just easier to live with.

HADLEY--Jerry. New York City Opera deeply mourns the untimely death of Jerry Hadley, a lyric tenor of keen intelligence, suave Italianate voice, and all - American charm. Educated in his native Illinois, he began his career at Lake George Opera and was soon discovered by Beverly Sills, who engaged him for City Opera. His City Opera debut, as Arturo in Lucia di Lammermoor in 1979, has long been part of company lore, for the radiance of both his singing and his plumed hat, which grazed a candelabrum and caught fire. For the next decade, he graced our stage with memorable performances of leading tenor roles in works including Faust, Werther, Manon, The Rake's Progress, The Student Prince, La Boheme, Les Pecheurs de Perles, Rigoletto and Madama Butterfly, telecast on Live From Lincoln Center. Even when his career took him to such venues as La Scala, Covent Garden, Vienna State Opera, Deutsche Oper Berlin, Hamburg State Opera, Glyndebourne, Aix - en - Provence, Salzburg, the Metropolitan Opera, Lyric Opera of Chicago, and San Francisco Opera, Jerry remained a beloved member of City Opera's extended family. We grieve along with his family and his many friends. May he rest in richly deserved peace. Gerard Mortier, General Manager Designate Susan L. Baker, Chairman, Board of Directors HADLEY--Jerry. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our dear colleague, Jerry Hadley. He sang 12 major roles at the Met between 1987 and 2002, including the title role in the world premiere of John Harbison's ''The Great Gatsby'' in 1999, and leading parts in four other new production premieres. We will remember Jerry not only for his superb lyric tenor voice but also for his personal warmth, professionalism, and, especially, his infectious sense of humor. We offer our sincerest condolences to his family and all those who loved him. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Dir.

President Bush on Wednesday announced the creation of a panel of cabinet officials who will look for ways to minimize the dangers from food and other products shipped into the United States. Mr. Bush established the panel, to be known as the Interagency Working Group on Import Safety, by executive order. Although the step coincides with concern about tainted imports from China, the White House insisted that the safety effort was not aimed at that country.

HAWES--Richard Thomas, passed away on Tuesday, July 3, 2007 in New York City, New York. Born on November 6, 1963, in Greenville, Pennsylvania, Tom completed his undergraduate degree in Economics at Baylor University and received an MBA in Finance from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. Tom worked in the investment banking community and was employed by CIT Securities LLC. Tom had also worked for UBS Warburg LLC, Bear Stearns & Co., Inc., Nomura International PLC and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Tom is survived by his mother, Jean Hawes of New Bern, NC; brothers John Hawes and Chris Hawes both of Houston, TX; sisters, Ann Evans of Sharon, PA; Cate Geiwitz of Transfer, PA, and Peg Geary of Santa Rosa, CA. In addition, Tom is survived by seven nieces and nephews. Tom's father, John Charles Hawes of Greenville, PA., preceded him in death. Donations can be made, in Tom's name, to the American Heart Association or to your local public library.

A dark oil-on-canvas painting of a bearded man that was expected to sell for $600 to $1,000 fetched $420,000 as a suspected early work by the Renaissance master Titian in fierce bidding at an auction last week in Market Harborough in central England, Reuters reported. The painting, offered by an unsuspecting, unidentified local woman who purchased it in a house clearance sale in 1974 and had it hanging on her wall for 33 years, could be worth several million dollars. Mark Gilding, the auctioneer, said someone in the London art trade bought the painting. ... The French government has agreed to buy the 17th-century masterpiece ''The Flight Into Egypt,'' by the French painter Nicolas Poussin, The Associated Press reported. Initially attributed not to Poussin but to his workshop, the painting, depicting an angel guiding the Holy family, was sold by an unidentified private owner for an undisclosed sum. It will join the permanent collection of the Fine Arts Museum in Lyon after it is displayed at the Louvre in Paris.

Thailand's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate for the fifth consecutive time this year to spur an economy blighted by slumping consumer confidence after last year's coup. The Bank of Thailand reduced its one-day bond repurchase rate to 3.25 percent from 3.5 percent. Lower interest rates may help the baht retreat from a 10-year high against the dollar, making exporters more competitive. ''Consumption and investment remain weak,'' said Usara Wilaipich, an economist at Standard Chartered Bank in Bangkok. ''Inflation is not a concern now because a slump in spending has curbed price increases.''

North Korea offered to declare all its nuclear weapons programs and disable them by the end of the year in return for energy aid, the South Korean nuclear envoy said, raising hopes for quick progress in international efforts to eliminate the North's nuclear armament. The North Korean offer came only hours after the nuclear monitoring agency for the United Nations confirmed that the North had shut down all five of its declared nuclear facilities, as it had promised to do in a February agreement. That news gave an added push to a new round of six-nation talks with envoys from the United States, North and South Korea, China, Russia and Japan.

MEISLER--Pauline G., on July 17. Loving wife of the late Joseph Meisler. Adored mother, mother-in-law, and grandmother. Retired assistant financial director and comptroller of the American Museum of Natural History. Service at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY, July 20 11:00am. Donations to the American Parkinson Disease Association.

Leo Scarff, an Irish designer who specializes in atmospheric mood lighting, recently introduced a collection of four lamps at the NoHo showroom of Clodagh, the Manhattan interior designer. Lightweave ($1,550), left, a cylindrical maple-veneer floor lamp, casts a basket-weave of light and shadow on a wall. (Hanging versions are $1,200 and $1,925.) A wild tumble of a chandelier made from curly white polycarbonate ($2,700) looks like the dangling paper garlands children make to wind around a Christmas tree; a cylindrical lamp is made of slender strips of bamboo ($825); and a conical swath of parchment-colored polycarbonate, lighted from within, resembles a handkerchief ($900 and $1,125). Clodagh's showroom, which is open to the public, is at 670 Broadway (Bond Street); (212) 780-5300. ELAINE LOUIE

LEDERER--Dr. Herbert, formerly of Storrs, CT, died peacefully at the age of 86 on Wednesday, July 18, 2007. A scholar, educator and author for more than 40 years, Dr. Lederer served on the faculties of the University of Connecticut, Queens College (CUNY), Ohio University, Wabash College, and the summer language institute at Middlebury College. He was married for more than 50 years, until her death, to his beloved Eva Marie (nee Hohenberg). He is survived by two children, Barbara Lederer of Simsbury, CT, and George Lederer of Portland, OR; and three grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Friday, July 20, 2007 at 1:00pm at Temple Sinai, 41 West Hartford Road, Newington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Connecticut Foundation Herbert Lederer Fund, 2390 Alumni Dr., Unit 3206, Storrs, CT 06269. The family will be observing Shiva. Services: Weinstein Mortuary, Hartford, CT.

Four men were sentenced to prison for inciting murder and racial hatred last year during a raucous demonstration against the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. Marching among several hundred protesters in front of the Danish Embassy here, the men had called for the death of those responsible for publishing the cartoons, which were first published in a Danish newspaper in 2005. Three of the men -- Mizanur Rahman, 24, Umran Javed, 27, and Abdul Muhid 25 -- were sentenced to six years in prison; the fourth, Abdul Saleem, 32 was sentenced to four years.
SILBERFEIN--Richard. It's been eight long years. You are and always will be in our thoughts, hearts and prayers. Love, Your Family

An article on Sunday about the Army's decision to drop court-martial proceedings against Specialist Eugene Cherry, a former medic in Iraq who failed to return to his base at Fort Drum in upstate New York, referred incorrectly to the treatment provided by Hannah Frisch, a Chicago psychologist who diagnosed him with post-traumatic stress disorder. Dr. Frisch gave him counseling but did not prescribe antidepressants.

Roger Federer, the three-time defending champion, heads the men's field for the United States Open, which includes all players ranked in the top 100. The United States Tennis Association announced yesterday that the field would also include the former Open champions Lleyton Hewitt, Andy Roddick and Marat Safin. The Open will be played Aug. 27 to Sept. 9 at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens.

CYCLING jerseys, running shorts and sports bras made from synthetic fabrics are a godsend for wicking sweat -- but they are the devil to clean. Freshly washed synthetics smell innocuous but buried odor is reactivated as soon as sweat hits them again. A possible solution? A new breed of laundry detergents that claim to eliminate sport stink. Unlike traditional detergents, sport-specific ones aim to flush out the odor-causing oils and bacteria embedded in densely knit fabrics like polyester. Some also claim to help synthetic fabrics wick perspiration better.

''The Singing Bee,'' NBC's new karaoke-themed game show with former 'N Sync star Joey Fatone, below, as host, delivered another strong performance on Tuesday, helping the network clear a ratings victory for the night. Nielsen estimates that the half-hour competition drew the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 and 11 million total viewers at 9:30. NBC led the rest of the night as well, with ''America's Got Talent,'' from 8 to 9:30 (10.3 million), and a ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' repeat at 10 (9.5 million). ABC finished second over all, with one of its best nights of the summer. The premiere of ''Just for Laughs,'' ABC's new hidden-camera series, ranked No. 2 in its time period with episodes at 8 (8 million) and 8:30 (8.6 million). Meanwhile, ABC's ''Primetime: Family Secrets,'' about the actor Daniel Baldwin and his struggles with addiction, also earned second place at 10 (6.9 million), ahead of CBS's ''Pirate Master'' (4.4 million). CBS and Fox, whose ''On the Lot'' earned just 2.2 million viewers at 8, ended the night in third and fourth place, respectively.

LEVINE--Aaron on July 17, 2007, age 89. Beloved and devoted husband of Francine. Most caring father to Lewis and David. Dear father-in-law to Caryl and Susan. Loving Papa to Alexis, Danielle and Jonathan. Extraordinary son, brother, uncle, nephew and friend. The most good natured man. Services Thursday July 19 at 12 noon at the Star of David Chapel in West Babylon, NY. 631-454-9600

PYLE--Thomas O., of Boston on July 18th at 67 years of age, after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Cherished husband of Regina (nee Schlank), father of Scott Laughlin of Natick, MA and grandfather of Cameron and Katie, and uncle of Ann Banks of Fishers Island, NY. Memorial celebration of his life will be held in late September. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Tom's name to, ''Gastrointestinal Cancer Center'', 100 Charles River Plaza, Boston, MA 02114.

Sales of the new T. I. album ''T. I. vs. T. I. P.'' (Atlantic) dropped 63 percent in its second week out, but were still strong enough to hold the No. 1 spot on the Billboard chart, beating new releases from Smashing Pumpkins and Interpol. ''T. I. vs. T. I. P.'' sold 175,000 copes, according to Nielsen SoundScan, while Smashing Pumpkins' first record in seven years, ''Zeitgeist'' (Reprise), moved 145,000 to reach No. 2. Interpol's major-label debut, ''Our Love to Admire'' (Capitol), opened at No. 4 with 73,000, and last week's No. 2, Miley Cyrus's ''Hannah Montana 2: Meet Miley Cyrus'' (Disney),'' fell one spot. With strong reviews for its new album, ''Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga'' (Merge), the indie-rock band Spoon made its Top 10 debut, reaching No. 10 on 46,000 sales.

Six Afghan policemen were killed when their convoy was ambushed with machine-gun fire and rockets on a dangerous section of the nation's main highway from Kandahar to Kabul that is a frequent target of the Taliban, a police official said. Two suicide attackers outfitted in military uniforms killed three policemen and a civilian at the main police station in Khost, said that province's governor, Arsallah Jamal. Taliban insurgents also attacked a surveying team from a road construction company in southeastern Paktia Province, killing an Afghan and a man from the Philippines, according to police officials cited by Agence France-Presse.

SHAPIRO--Irene, 81, a survivor of the Holocaust. Member of the Resistance of Bialystok Ghetto and teacher at Bronx High School of Science. Survived by husband, Marvin, children Ellen (Arnie) Greenstein, Andy, Steve (Barbara) and Jan Sharpio, grandmother of Jeremy, Evan, Eli and Daniel. Funeral Service 11am, Friday, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, (exit 17 Saw Mill). Memorials to Simon Weisenthal Center, 9760 West Pico Blvd., LA, CA 90035

State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hoboken who is the Senate majority leader, was in intensive care at Jersey City Medical Center last night after suffering a broken leg, four fractures in his pelvis and a broken nose in an early-morning accident. There were conflicting reports yesterday as to what happened. At first, a law partner of Mr. Kenny's was quoted on the Jersey Journal Web site as saying that Mr. Kenny, 60, had been involved in a car accident. Later, The Associated Press reported, Hoboken's police chief said that Mr. Kenny had apparently fallen while jogging near his home. John McKeegan, a spokesman for the medical center, said last night that the senator had been given pain medication and was ''resting comfortably.'' Mr. Kenny has been a legislator since 1987.

SHAFFER--Robert N., 1912-2007. Established first leading glaucoma practice in the West; Co-founder of Glaucoma Research Foundation; San Francisco, CA. Robert N. Shaffer, M.D., one of the leading glaucoma specialists in the world, died on Friday, July 13, announced Glaucoma Research Foundation President and CEO Thomas M. Brunner today. Born January 18, 1912 in Meadville, Pennsylvania, Dr. Shaffer received his medical degree from Stanford University, and did his residency at Stanford Lane Hospital while the campus was still in San Francisco. Dr. Shaffer's first practice was in San Francisco where in 1949 he established what became the leading glaucoma practice west of the Mississippi. Dr. Shaffer's proudest accomplishment, in the view of both he and his wife, was the establishment of the annual Shaffer Fellowship whereby Dr. Shaffer and Virginia ''adopted'' promising young doctors for a year of personal training in the diagnosis and treatment of glaucoma. More than 40 Shaffer Fellows received this very personalized training. The couple ultimately retired to their home in Greenbrae in Marin County, California. With his two partners H. Dunbar Hoskins Jr., M.D., and John Hetherington M.D., Shaffer founded the Glaucoma Research Foundation in 1978 which continues his legacy of helping those with glaucoma through education and the funding of research to find better therapies and ultimately a cure for glaucoma. Dr. Shaffer is survived by his wife of 68 years, Virginia, and by two sons. John and his wife Susan live in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Stuart lives in San Diego, California. Daughter-in-law, Kim, resides in Grass Valley, California. Dr. Shaffer was proceeded in death by a son, William. He is also survived by three grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers or other remembrances, donations be made to the Glaucoma Research Foundation, 251 Post Street Suite 600, San Francisco, CA 94108 or through www.glaucoma.org.

The State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it would not start a new investigation of Consolidated Edison's response to power failures caused by windstorms last year in Westchester County. The decision allows Con Edison to pass along to customers the costs the utilities incurred as a result of the power failures. Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester assemblyman and one of several dozen elected officials who had sought the new investigation, known as a prudence proceeding, called the move ''inexplicable and wrong'' in light of the commission's earlier decision to allow such an inquiry into last year's blackouts in Queens.

RIFKIN--Lawrence, on July 16, 2007. Beloved husband of Stacy. Loving father of Ethan and Henry. Devoted son of Dr. Howard and Barbara Rifkin, cherished brother of Barrie Shackman. Services were held on July 18 in Hewlett, L.I. RIFKIN--Lawrence. To our dear friend Larry, we love you and will miss you very much, but we will never forget you. Amy & Andy Silberfein

McKENNA--Ron. Friend, you will be missed, your kindness, civility, loyalty, and your generous and giving nature will always be with us. You really taught us what friendship was all about. With all our love forever. William and Ron

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the growth of communications equipment manufacturing in Taiwan misidentified the controlling political party there. The Democratic Progressive Party captured the presidency in 2000 and was re-elected in 2004; Taiwan is no longer controlled by the Chinese Nationalist Party. (A coalition led by the Chinese Nationalist Party still has a majority in the Taiwanese legislature.) Also because of an editing error, the article misidentified Taiwan's geographical location. It is an island east of China, not south.

Irina Krush won her last round game today to take clear first at the U.S. Women's Championship in Stillwater, Okla. In an conference call this afternoon with reporters, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton harshly criticized the Pentagon, calling it "offensive and totally inappropriate" for a Defense official to suggest that information she requested about departmental plans for withdrawing troops in Iraq would fuel enemy propaganda.

Interesting that the Yankees' top two baseball operations officials, Brian Cashman and Mark Newman, are in New Britain, Conn., now watching a doubleheader for Class-AA Trenton. The starters are Joba Chamberlain and Alan Horne.

UPDATE (Monday, July 23, 3 p.m.): Mission controllers received telemetry from both rovers this morning that indicates the power situation has stabilized and that skies might be clearing a little. Opportunity is now getting about 210 watt-hours of energy a day from its solar panels - allowing it to recharge its batteries a little - while Spirit is at 350 watt-hours. That is still a large drop from the approximately 800 watt-hours of energy that each was getting before the dust storm began swirling in late June. Spirit has enough power to maintain normal communications with Earth. Opportunity, with less power, will remain quiet until Thursday. "Everything else is fine on the rovers," said John Callas, the project manager.

CNN and YouTube have just announced that St. Petersburg, Fla., will be the debate site for the Republican presidential candidates on Sept. 17. It follows this Monday's CNN/YouTube debate for the Democrats in Charleston, S.C.

When many people heard what caused the explosion that blew a hole in a Midtown Manhattan intersection on Wednesday, leaving one woman dead and more than 40 people injured, a common reaction (after relief that it wasn't terrorism and sympathy for the victims and their families) was something of a doubletake.

The World Chess Federation has announced that it will hold a public hearing on July 28 in Athens to determine whether Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, the former world champion, and Silvio Danailov, Topalov's manager, violated the federation's code of ethics during and after last year's world championship match betwen Topalov and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia.

The July 31 trade deadline is rapidly approaching, and soon - if we haven't already - we will be inundated with rumors, far-fetched possibilities, deals that could happen, deals that should happen and, just as likely, a whole lot of nothing. Omar Minaya said yesterday that he doesn't anticipate a whole lot of movement because there just aren't that many attractive pieces available.
Though Ann Romney darted around South Carolina this week, traveling to five towns in two days on her first major campaign swing without her husband, she wasn't complaining about the grueling pace.

Yet another debt deal has been delayed, thanks to worsening conditions in the loan and bond markets. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts' banks have extended a deadline for investors in 9 billion pounds ($18.5 billion) in loans for Alliance Boots, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing an unnamed banker. The buyout firm also plans to sweeten the terms of the deal, the banker said.

Google's latest quarterly earnings report -- though it showed a huge revenue surge and a 28 percent increase in profits -- still didn't measure up to Wall Street's lofty expectations, and the Web giant's stock tumbled more than 5 percent Friday.
The double will have to wait.
In his Web column today, Jeff Zeleny compares war sentiments among Republican senators and presidential candidates, and asks Senator Chuck Hagel if he sees an opening for an Iraq critic in the field:

As private equity chiefs go, David Rubenstein of Carlyle has been remarkably candid in recent months about his concerns for the private equity business. At a conference in Tokyo in May, he said, referring to the industry as a whole, "we need to prepare people for the reality that some deals will fail," adding that "greed has taken over."
Well, you knew Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wouldn't waste much time in this climate of unease and anger over the war in Iraq (amid a presidential campaign) to dash off a reply to the Pentagon.

Having seen a few cool concerts in recent weeks, I wanted to remind visitors to Rome about the wonderful outdoor concert series that takes place in July and early August, called Estate Romana. Every night there are half a dozen worthwhile musical events scattered around the city, in parks or on stages set up amidst Roman ruins. They officially start between 9 and 10 pm, as the sun is setting and the breeze picking up. Even without music this moment each night in Rome is glorious.

A devout disciple of Schopenhauer, Machado de Assis -- the founding father of Brazilian literature -- subtitled "The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas," his most famous work, "Epitaph of a Small Winner." De Assis's fictional alter-ego, cleaving to a pessimistic weltanschauung, argued that while existence is a zero-sum game, he had managed to get out ahead by not having children, and bestowing on them the same load of suffering.

As Wall Street feverishly takes the pulse of the buyout boom, Time magazine points out what it considers to be another possible trouble sign. Flush with cash and facing a narrowing a debt window, private equity firms are increasingly choosing to crash into each others' deals.

The New York Times is not a name you normally associate with open-source software. Perhaps it makes you think of checking in with our Web site during the workday or lazy Sunday mornings with the printed paper, but never code. Which is a pity, since there are plenty of ways in which code -- and increasingly, open-source code -- is critical at The Times. We're not just talking about the Web site (at least 10 million hits a day, incidentally), but also the archives (4 terabytes of images), and the gigabytes of databases on subjects like campaign finance. There's a lot of architecture working behind the scenes, and more and more of it is based on open-source software.
