RICHARD III In the midst of its seventh season, Nicu's Spoon is doing something a lot of other small companies might envy: opening a show in its own theater. Shortly after signing an eight-year lease in April, the company is offering Shakespeare's ''Richard III'' at the newly named Spoon Theater. ''Richard III,'' directed by Heidi Lauren Duke, is typical Nicu's Spoon fare, which means it is not at all typical. The company, run by its artistic director, Stephanie Barton-Farcas, attempts to challenge stereotypes by collaborating with artists from across the spectrum of ethnicities and abilities; a production of ''Buried Child'' last year featured a spoken performance by a deaf actor accustomed to performing in American Sign Language. In ''Richard III,'' Henry Holden, right, is Shakespeare's villainous king who was ''cheated of feature by dissembling nature'' and, partly out of bitterness at his physical deformity, resorts to evil. In the mouth of Mr. Holden, who contracted polio in 1952 at 4 and walks with crutches, Richard's words take on a more particular meaning, focusing the play directly and inescapably on the issue of disability. Nicu's Spoon has dedicated its entire current season to the theme of disability and will hold a panel discussion on July 31 called ''Beyond Handicaps and Handouts: The New Face of Disability in the Arts.'' Panelists will include, among others, Ms. Barton-Farcas, Mr. Holden and Ike Shambelan, the co-artistic director of Theater by the Blind. Nicu's Spoon is also offering a summer reading series. Scheduled for Monday is ''Identity,'' a semi-autobiographical piece by Nicholas Linnehan, a playwright with cerebral palsy. (Mr. Linnehan plays the lead role, too.) ''Forgiveness of the Saints,'' a black comedy by Christian Gaul, is on Tuesday. (''Richard III'' runs through July 29, Wednesday through Sunday at 8 p.m., Spoon Theater, 38 West 38th Street, fifth floor, Manhattan, 212-352-3101, theatermania.com; $18. Information on the panel discussion, readings and fall productions is at spoontheater.org.) STEVEN McELROY Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

''The Mistress and The Muse: The Films of Norman Mailer,'' a two-week series of screenings and discussions in Manhattan, will begin on Sunday at 4:30 p.m. at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, with a screening of ''Tough Guys Don't Dance'' (1987), followed by a conversation with Mr. Mailer and Kent Jones, associate director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, and a screening at 8 p.m. of ''Maidstone'' (1971). The series will continue through Aug. 5 with events also scheduled at the Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, and the Paley Center for Media, 25 West 52nd Street. Tickets to the opening at the Walter Reade Theater are $35 for both screenings and the conversation ($25 for Film Society and Anthology Film Archives members) or $11 ($7 for members) for the 8 p.m. screening only. The closing screening at the Walter Reade on Aug. 5 will feature ''The Executioner's Song'' (1982). Information: (212) 875-5600; filmlinc.com.

Jelena Prokopcuka of Latvia, who won the women's race at the New York City Marathon the past two years, and Marilson Gomes dos Santos of Brazil, the men's upset winner last year, will compete in this year's marathon, which is Nov. 4. Last year's wheelchair champions, Kurt Fearnley of Australia and Amanda McGrory of Champaign, Ill., will also return. The 30-year-old Prokopcuka could become the second woman to win the race three consecutive years. Grete Waitz of Norway won from 1978 to 1980 and 1982 to 1986. A victory would probably assure Prokopcuka, who was second in the Boston Marathon in April, of the $500,000 first prize in the World Marathon Majors' first two-year series.

SCHUSTER--Marian Mayerson, of Dayton, OH and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on July 19, 2007 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Benjamin Schuster, M.D. Devoted mother of Marla Nissan and Debra Tanger, both of New York City, and of Karen Brace, of Westwood, MA. Adoring grandmother of Benjamin and Gregory Nissan, Schuster and Andrew Tanger and Tyler and Alison Brace. Cherished sister of Manuel D. Mayerson and the late Evelyn Greff, both of Cincinnati, OH, and adored aunt to her nieces and nephews. An active member of numerous boards and civic organizations, she and her husband were major benefactors of the Benjamin and Marian Schuster Center for the Performing Arts and were recently honored by the naming of the planned Benjamin and Marian Schuster Heart Hospital at Kettering Medical Center in Dayton, OH. Her indomitable spirit, devotion to family and community, extraordinary wit, strength and grace inspired and touched all who knew her. Donations in her memory may be made to the Schuster Center for the Performing Arts (Arts Center Foundation) or the American Cancer Society.
KAHAN--Melvyn S. A year since his death his friends miss him daily. --One of them.

Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants took aim at a familiar target on Saturday. Not a pitcher, not Commissioner Bud Selig and not Hank Aaron. Bonds spent most of a 20-minute pregame session with reporters taking jabs at them. "I got to have my tape recorder because some of you are downright dirty," said Bonds, who tapes interview sessions and posts the audio on his Web site. "You all keep saying what you say and I'll keep recording it." Between Bonds's sometimes playful, sometimes serious shots at reporters inside the visiting clubhouse at Miller Park, he discussed a myriad of topics. Bonds, who is three homers from passing Aaron's career record of 755, said he was happy that Selig attended Friday's game. Selig was here Saturday, too. When Bonds was asked if he wanted to talk to Selig, he said, "About what? We haven't talked in a while. But I have respect for Bud. Like I said before, I don't care what you say or what you write. Bud has always been nice to me, always been nice to my father. I like Bud." Bonds reiterated that he respects Selig and would not lose respect for Selig if the commissioner does not shadow Bonds for his record-breaking game. Selig is expected to follow Bonds's hunt for 756. If Bonds breaks Aaron's record and Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees chases Bonds down, Bonds repeated that he would be in the front row to watch Rodriguez. "This is our fraternity," Bonds said. "If we don't stand for each other, who is going to stand behind us? I'll stand behind a fellow player, regardless." Using that logic, is Aaron refusing to stand behind Bonds by not going to Bonds's games? "I don't know," Bonds said. "The thing is, we respect Hank regardless. Like I've said before, it's not fair, in a sense, if you're asking somebody to take away whatever they have to do. You can't predict something like this." Bonds said he feels good when he is "by myself" and added that he feels best when he is "just like the other 24 people in here." Since Bonds has long had more privileges than any other Giant, it was a curious statement. Bonds has never wanted to be treated like every another player. Since Bonds is not scheduled to start on Sunday, his next appearance in left field will probably be on Monday. The Giants return to AT&T Park for seven games, a perfect time for Bonds to eclipse Aaron because he would be assured of being cheered. But Bonds was not predicting a timetable for the historic homer. "Everybody who goes through milestones, go back and look at it, it takes a while," Bonds said. When someone reminded Bonds that the national reporters who are covering him would disperse once he gets to 756, he invited them to leave now. "You all hate me anyway," Bonds said. "I don't know why you're here anyway. Most of you say whatever nasty things you say about me anyway. If you really, truly believe all the things you write, why are you talking to me anyway?"

Lewis Hamilton's McLaren Mercedes broke apart with five minutes left during the last qualifying session today, sending the championship leader flying off the track into a tire barrier. The impact was so heavy that the driver was clearly shocked, and was unable to stand up after the accident. He was taken to the medical center where track doctors declared he was unhurt, broke no bones, and would spend a couple of hours resting under observation, according to a McLaren team spokesman. There is as yet no word as to whether or not he will race tomorrow. I will update the news as it develops.

The first time I heard about this bizarre idea was at a dinner with the Auto Hebdo journalists in Bahrain. The new editor of one of my favorite motor racing magazines - I like to read Autosport, but I like to have a counterbalance too, and for that I turn to my weekly read of Auto Hebdo, the top selling French magazine - outlined his idea that night in Bahrain. Pascal Dro, the editor, said they planned to buy a Volkswagen van and travel Europe throughout the European leg of the F1 season, going from race to race as journalists did in the old days, camping out and taking in the real culture of the venues. None of this first class travel from airport to hotel and from hotel to circuit and back again. This would be the real hardy stuff of the old days. The purpose of the trip would also be to document the old days, digging up and visiting the old attractions of the venues, and countries hosting races and interviewing people who had something to do with the sport over its 57-year history.

Oakland safety Jarrod Cooper was suspended yesterday for the Raiders’ first four regular-season games for violating the N.F.L.’s policy on steroids.Cooper can participate in training camp and in preseason games. But he will not be able to join the team’s active roster until Oct. 1, the day after the team’s fourth game of the season, against Miami.Cooper is the second Raider to be suspended for violating the league’s substance-abuse policy. Running back Dominic Rhodes was also suspended for four games.

San Francisco’s Golden Gate Yacht Club sued the two-time America’s Cup champion Alinghi yesterday, seeking to replace the Spanish syndicate Desafio Español as the official challenger for the next regatta. Golden Gate asserted that Club Nautica Español de Vela was an “invalid challenger” because it never held a regatta as stipulated in the rules of the “deed of gift,” the regulations that govern the America’s Cup. The suit was filed in the State of New York’s Supreme Court, which has jurisdiction to settle all disputes in the competition.

An article in Science Times on July 10 about William A. Wulf, an engineer and entrepreneur of computer science, referred imprecisely to the duration of Dr. Wulf’s work with Tartan Laboratories. Dr. Wulf left Tartan in 1988, before the company was sold to Texas Instruments, not after. Also, the article misstated the year that Texas Instruments acquired Tartan. It was 1996, not 1995.

A front-page article on Sunday about a new era of wealthy and powerful men incorrectly described the management role of Robert C. Pozen at Fidelity Investments, and referred incorrectly to his pay. Mr. Pozen oversaw the entire investment department at Fidelity; he did not manage any funds, including one that made a profit of $1 billion one year. The manager of that fund, not Mr. Pozen, was paid $15 million. Also, the article misinterpreted comments by Mr. Pozen about managing a company. Mr. Pozen was referring to the manager of the portfolio that made $1 billion — not to himself — when he said, “In every organization there are a relatively small number of really critical people.”.

A picture caption yesterday with an article about hotel reservations for the 2008 Democratic National Convention misstated the affiliation of Tina Akintayo, who was shown checking the accommodations of a hotel in Denver. She is the housing director for the Democratic National Convention Committee, not a representative of Denver Marriott South.

An article yesterday about investigations into police misconduct in Chicago referred incompletely to a list obtained by The Times showing complaints against more than 600 officers. Although the list detailed the dates and the number of complaints, it did not include the names of the officers; those had been redacted.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) — Terry Francona, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, was ejected in the first inning Friday night after J. D. Drew’s drive just cleared the wall in left field but was not ruled a home run.

NASA’s Mars rover Opportunity, caught in a swirling dust storm, has been told to not even bother calling home until Monday in order to save energy, the agency said. It is the first time in the three-and-a-half-year mission that the rover, which runs on energy generated by its solar panels, has needed such drastic energy conservation measures. Dust is blocking 99 percent of the direct sunlight above Opportunity, and the storm is so large that it is also affecting Spirit, another rover on the other side of the planet. Opportunity was to have begun exploration of a half-mile crater this month, but that has been put off until the skies clear.

The owner of a nightclub that caught fire during a rock concert announced the creation of an education fund for more than 75 children who lost a parent in the blaze. The February 2003 fire in West Warwick, which began when pyrotechnics for the rock band Great White ignited flammable soundproofing foam, killed 100 people and injured more than twice that many. The owner, Jeffrey Derderian, above, said the Station Education Fund could cover expenses like tutoring, books, field trips and athletic equipment. Mr. Derderian is also encouraging colleges and universities to waive tuition for the children. After the fire, he was sentenced to probation and 500 hours of community service. His brother, Michael, is serving four years in prison, as is the former Great White tour manager, Daniel Biechele, who pleaded guilty last year to igniting the pyrotechnics without a permit.

Federal agents arrested 274 illegal immigrants over five days during raids in Dallas, Fort Worth and surrounding suburbs, federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement said. The authorities took into custody 233 men, 28 women and 13 children, said an agency spokesman, Carl Rusnok. The operation, which began Monday and ended yesterday, yielded illegal immigrants, people wanted by immigration authorities and immigrants with criminal records. Of those arrested, 99 had criminal convictions, the agency said. “These operations are a critical element in removing threats to public safety,” said Nuria T. Prendes, field office director for the agency’s Office of Detention and Removal Operations.

A light earthquake jolted the Bay Area, breaking glass and jarring nerves, although no injuries were reported. The 4.2-magnitude earthquake struck at about 4:40 a.m. about 2 miles east of Oakland, according to the federal Geological Survey. It was felt on both sides of the San Francisco Bay and lasted up to 10 seconds. Residents east of San Francisco were shaken awake as pictures slipped from walls and objects tumbled. Some businesses delayed opening because of broken windows, and Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported that some customers in Oakland briefly lost power. The earthquake was relatively minor, but it was widely felt because it was centered in a heavily populated area on the north segment of the Hayward fault.

A senior Spanish judge has ordered the police to confiscate copies of a satirical magazine containing a cartoon that depicts Crown Prince Felipe and his wife, Princess Letizia, in a graphic sexual pose. Judge Juan del Olmo wrote in a court order that the cartoon on the cover of the magazine, El Jueves, showed the royal couple in a “degrading” posture that may have broken laws protecting the royal family and the dignity of the crown. The laws carry a maximum penalty of two years. The Spanish public reveres its royal family, and publications generally steer clear of its private affairs.

The Kremlin has announced new rules for visiting Lenin’s tomb on Red Square, saying they were put into effect to reflect declining tourist interest in the site. The Federal Guards Service will no longer cordon off Red Square during the mausoleum’s visiting hours, as they have done since 1973 to accommodate what were once long lines. A spokeswoman said the practice was disrupting visits to the square itself, and the changes were made “for the comfort of tourists who want to stroll on the square.”.
Seeking to cool China’s rapid growth rate, the People’s Bank of China announced Friday that it will raise interest rates to 6.84 percent, the highest level in eight years.

Arms negotiators failed to set a deadline for North Korea to disable its nuclear facilities following the shutdown of its reactor at Yongbyon, but top envoys planned to meet again in early September. Wu Dawei, a Chinese envoy, said working groups would meet before that to discuss technical details for the North’s next steps: declaring and disabling its nuclear programs. The United States had hoped the three days of talks would end with a deadline for North Korea to take those actions.

A polemical proposal to transfer the seat of government to Sucre, a genteel city of whitewashed buildings in central Bolivia that lost that distinction in a brief civil war at the end of the 19th century, drew hundreds of thousands of demonstrators into the streets of high-altitude La Paz, where the president and legislature are based. Many supporters of President Evo Morales who are from the Western highlands oppose the idea, seeing it as an effort by relatively prosperous lowland states in the east to weaken the president’s authority. The proposal has been put forward by delegates working to rewrite the Constitution. Proponents of the change view moving the seat of government to Sucre, already home to the Supreme Court and considered the country’s judicial capital, as a way to draw government spending away from La Paz in the west into Bolivia’s central regions.

The Seattle SuperSonics acquired the veteran forward Kurt Thomas and the Phoenix Suns’ first-round draft choices in 2008 and 2010 yesterday in exchange for a conditional second-round draft choice.Thomas, who turns 35 in October, averaged a career-low 4.6 points in 67 games last season. He provides Seattle the veteran presence it was seeking to tutor Kevin Durant and Jeff Green, the second and fifth overall selections in last month’s draft.

Andrew Svoboda shot a 72 yesterday to win the North Fork Bank New York State Open yesterday at Bethpage State Park’s Black Course.Svoboda, a longtime Winged Foot member and a former St. John’s star, added the Open crown to the Met Amateur and Met Open titles he has won.

Derek Fisher completed his widely anticipated return to the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday by agreeing to a three-year contract reported to be worth $14 million.Fisher, a 32-year-old guard, asked to be released from his contract with the Utah Jazz just over two weeks ago so he could move to a city with more advanced medical care for his 1-year-old daughter, Tatum, who has a rare form of eye cancer. He played for the Lakers when they won N.B.A. championships in 2000, 2001 and 2002.

Alexei Yashin, the former Islanders captain, will play next season with Lokomotiv Yaroslavl of the Russian Super League after failing to get an N.H.L. contract offer to his liking.Yashin, a center who had the final four seasons of his 10-year contract bought out by the Islanders in June, agreed to terms yesterday on a one-year deal with the Russian team he played with during the 2004-5 N.H.L. lockout. Financial terms were not immediately available.Yashin, 33, had 18 goals and 32 assists in 58 games last season, his second as the Islanders’ captain.

8 P.M. (HBO) LITTLE MISS SUNSHINE (2006) Abigail Breslin, top, earned an Academy Award nomination for her portrayal of the unlikely pre-teen princess Olive Hoover in this comedy about a family of everyday misfits determined to get their 7-year-old daughter to a beauty pageant. Alan Arkin won for best supporting actor as the heroin-snorting grandfather who helps put Olive’s talent routine over the top; Greg Kinnear and Toni Collette play the parents driving the ravaged family and its equally dilapidated VW bus; Steve Carell is Frank, Olive’s suicidal gay uncle; and Paul Dano is Dwayne, the Hoovers’ teenage son, who has decided to keep his mouth shut about the situation. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film “a tale about genuine faith and manufactured glory that unwinds in the American Southwest, but more rightly takes place at the terminus of the American dream, where families are one bad break away from bankruptcy.”.

Boo Weekley had never traveled outside North America when he booked a two-week trip to Scotland to compete in the Scottish and British Opens. Since arriving, he has taken in a few of the local delicacies, including the flavorful Arbroath Smokies, a kind of barbecued fish. He has avoided driving because he cannot get used to the steering wheel on the right side of a car or the rules of the road. He said he believes he has family from somewhere in Britain, but he is not sure where.

FRANKIEL--Rita. I miss your warmth, insights, your joie de vivre. We were so lucky. Love, Joelle FRANKIEL--Rita, Ph.D. The White Institute community mourns the loss of Dr. Rita Frankiel, a former Associate Director of Continuing Education and a revered and beloved colleague who distinguished herself as teacher and supervisor. She will be missed by many. Joerg Bose, M.D., Director

A front-page article on Sunday about a new era of wealthy and powerful men incorrectly described the management role of Robert C. Pozen at Fidelity Investments, and referred incorrectly to his pay. Mr. Pozen oversaw the entire investment department at Fidelity; he did not manage any funds, including one that made a profit of $1 billion one year. The manager of that fund, not Mr. Pozen, was paid $15 million. Also, the article misinterpreted comments by Mr. Pozen about managing a company. Mr. Pozen was referring to the manager of the portfolio that made $1 billion -- not to himself -- when he said, ''In every organization there are a relatively small number of really critical people.''

ELSOHN--Margit Subak, 96, passed away July 18, 2007 in her home in New York City. Margit was educated at Charles University in Prague, and at King's College in London. She came to the United States on New Year's Eve of 1941 from her native Czechoslovakia. She enjoyed a remarkably long and storied life as a potter and beloved wife of the late Jule Michael Elsohn. She taught pottery at Greenwich House from 1965 to 1971 and at the Potter's Studio from 1969 to 1980. She exhibited extensively and her work is included in many private collections in the U.S. and abroad. Margit was predeceased by her sister Gerda and nephews John and Frank Subak and is survived by many devoted grand nieces and nephews. A funeral service will be held at 11:15 am on Sunday, July 22 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel on 180 West 76th Street. She will be lovingly remembered and dearly missed.

INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Musharraf Loses in Court,Casting Doubt on His Fate Pakistan's Supreme Court ruled that the suspension of the country's chief justice by President Pervez Musharraf was illegal, dealing the president a strong rebuke and raising new questions about his ability to continue ruling past this year. A1

A grandson of the German anti-Nazi hero played by Tom Cruise in a new film has been given a cameo role, Bloomberg News reported. In the movie, ''Valkyrie,'' Mr. Cruise, 45, plays Count Claus Schenk von Stauffenberg, a disillusioned officer who was executed in 1944 after a failed bid to kill Hitler. Philipp von Schulthess, 34, a son of Stauffenberg's youngest daughter, Konstanze, will play another military officer. The film, which began shooting this week, has caused controversy in Germany because of Mr. Cruise's adherence to Scientology, which the German government sees as a cult. And government officials also refused to allow the film to be shot at the memorial site where Count Stauffenberg was executed.

LASKER--Milton, 82, died in Burlington, VT, July 19, 2007. Born in the Bronx, NY, November 13, 1924, son of Joseph and Freida Lasker. Survived by his two children, Seth and Cynthia; his two grandchildren, Moriah and Alex, all of Burlington, VT; sister Sally Chaifetz of Floral Park, NY. Predeceased by his wife, Betty Ann and daughter, Abby Rachael. Services Monday in Vermont.

To the Editor: Our culture idealizes the ''rugged individual'' presumed to be independent of others. This causes many people to feel inadequate because they cannot live up to this ideal. However, as David Brooks notes (''A Partnership of Minds,'' column, July 20), there is no self without the other.

Leon Fleisher has canceled his appearance at Tanglewood tomorrow afternoon, citing tenosynovitis (an inflammation of the sheath around the tendon) in both hands. His replacement for Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Piano Concerto with the Boston Symphony Orchestra will be Marc-André Hamelin. Mr. Fleisher, who will turn 79 on Monday, lost use of his right hand more than 40 years ago because of a neurological disorder, but after therapy has returned in recent years to two-hand repertory. A spokeswoman for Mr. Fleisher said he is expected to play his next scheduled concerts, in Coral Gables, Fla., on Aug. 2, and at the Ravinia festival in Highland Park, Ill., on Aug. 9.

To the Editor: In ''A Battle Between the Bottle and the Faucet'' (Week in Review, July 15), you tapped into the growing skepticism over the bottled water industry. But while the article rightly addressed the environmental and consumer implications of Big Water, it did not ask: Should corporations be bottling and selling our drinking water in the first place?

MacDONALD--Yong Ash. She fought her illness with great strength and dignity. We have always admired her kindness, warmth, optimism and consideration for others. Our deepest condolences to her husband, Mayor Jack MacDonald, who treated her with great love and tenderness. We will miss her, and mourn her untimely passing. Barbara and Michael Ditzian Lorinda and Peter Ezersky Gloria and Philip Levin

After a seven-week run as the No. 1 song in the country, Rihanna's ''Umbrella'' has been bumped off the top of the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart. It will switch places with last week's No. 2, ''Hey There Delilah,'' an acoustic ballad by the Chicago band Plain White T's.

Andrew Svoboda shot a 72 yesterday to win the North Fork Bank New York State Open yesterday at Bethpage State Park's Black Course.Svoboda, a longtime Winged Foot member and a former St. John's star, added the Open crown to the Met Amateur and Met Open titles he has won.

An article yesterday about investigations into police misconduct in Chicago referred incompletely to a list obtained by The Times showing complaints against more than 600 officers. Although the list detailed the dates and the number of complaints, it did not include the names of the officers; those had been redacted.

A polemical proposal to transfer the seat of government to Sucre, a genteel city of whitewashed buildings in central Bolivia that lost that distinction in a brief civil war at the end of the 19th century, drew hundreds of thousands of demonstrators into the streets of high-altitude La Paz, where the president and legislature are based. Many supporters of President Evo Morales who are from the Western highlands oppose the idea, seeing it as an effort by relatively prosperous lowland states in the east to weaken the president's authority. The proposal has been put forward by delegates working to rewrite the Constitution. Proponents of the change view moving the seat of government to Sucre, already home to the Supreme Court and considered the country's judicial capital, as a way to draw government spending away from La Paz in the west into Bolivia's central regions.

Because of an editing error, an obituary last Saturday about the baseball umpire Shag Crawford misspelled the surname of a Baltimore Orioles pitcher who made a critical errant throw during the 1969 World Series. He was Pete Richert, not Richerts.

We extend our condolences to his many colleagues at the Hearst Corporation and Foundations. Martin C. Hausman, Chair Jerome Belson, President Edward R. Matthews, Executive Director Ronald J. H. Napal, Chief Development Officer United Cerebral Palsy of New York City

A picture caption yesterday with an article about hotel reservations for the 2008 Democratic National Convention misstated the affiliation of Tina Akintayo, who was shown checking the accommodations of a hotel inDenver. She is the housing director for the Democratic National Convention Committee, not a representative of Denver Marriott South.
July 20, 2007 Midday New York Numbers -- 250; Lucky Sum -- 7

A senior Spanish judge has ordered the police to confiscate copies of a satirical magazine containing a cartoon that depicts Crown Prince Felipe and his wife, Princess Letizia, in a graphic sexual pose. Judge Juan del Olmo wrote in a court order that the cartoon on the cover of the magazine, El Jueves, showed the royal couple in a ''degrading'' posture that may have broken laws protecting the royal family and the dignity of the crown. The laws carry a maximum penalty of two years. The Spanish public reveres its royal family, and publications generally steer clear of its private affairs.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the quarterly earnings at the McClatchy Company and Dow Jones & Company misstated the context for a statement about declining advertising revenues from L. Gordon Crovitz, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. The statement, ''Essentially the whole of the decrease came from three advertisers: Cisco, Apple and I.B.M.,'' refers only to the decline of online technology advertising at The Journal. It does not refer to advertising over all at the paper.

Indians and South Asians dominate the 23 writers on the ''longlist'' announced yesterday for the inaugural Man Asian Literary Prize, a $10,000 award for Asian fiction not written in English. Of the 243 submissions, about two-thirds were from South Asia. Among the writers recognized are, from India, Reeti Gadekar, Saikat Chakraborty, Nalini Rajan, Kankana Basu and Sanjay Bahadur; Ameena Hussein, from Sri Lanka; Shahbano Bilgrami, from Pakistan; and Xiaolu Guo, Jiang Rong and Mo Yan from China. The nominees will be winnowed further in October, and the winner will be announced on Nov. 10 at a ceremony in Hong Kong.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the widespread distribution of ''Atlas of Creation,'' a book with an Islamic creationist point of view, misstated the name of a company that shipped some of the books. It is SBS Worldwide Ltd., not SDS Worldwide.

BLIER--Madeline. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Assoc. Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus
To the Editor: ''Keeping Peace on Salty Planks and Shifting Sand'' (news article, July 14), about Officer John Nevandro and the Coney Island Boardwalk, was very nostalgic for me.

Vice President Dick Cheney will take over as president on Saturday -- but only temporarily, White House officials say -- while President Bush undergoes anesthesia during routine screening for colon cancer. The White House press secretary, Tony Snow, said Friday that Mr. Bush would invoke his authority under the 25th Amendment of the Constitution to transfer his presidential powers temporarily to Mr. Cheney during the colonoscopy.

Seth Rogen, below, the star of ''Knocked Up,'' may not have the kind of physique we expect of a costumed crime fighter. But soon he may be wearing the mask of the Green Hornet for a new movie adaptation. Variety and The Hollywood Reporter wrote yesterday that Mr. Rogen, 25, was in final negotiations with Columbia Pictures for a deal to be a writer on the film and possibly star in it. The Green Hornet character, introduced on the radio in 1936, is the vigilante alter ego of Britt Reid, a wealthy newspaper publisher, and on his crime-fighting rounds is accompanied by Kato, who in the 1960s television version was played by Bruce Lee. Mr. Rogen is to write the adaptation with Evan Goldberg, with whom he wrote ''Superbad,'' to open next month.
To the Editor: Re ''A Settlement in Los Angeles'' (editorial, July 17):
This is not any subversive thing like trying to legalize marijuana or whatever. This is just practical agriculture. We're desperate for something that can make us some money. DAVID C. MONSON,

The Kremlin has announced new rules for visiting Lenin's tomb on Red Square, saying they were put into effect to reflect declining tourist interest in the site. The Federal Guards Service will no longer cordon off Red Square during the mausoleum's visiting hours, as they have done since 1973 to accommodate what were once long lines. A spokeswoman said the practice was disrupting visits to the square itself, and the changes were made ''for the comfort of tourists who want to stroll on the square.''

Lindsay Lohan, below, turned herself in to the Beverly Hills police on Thursday afternoon to face drunk driving charges in the crash that sent her to rehab, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, 21, and two others were in her Mercedes convertible when she lost control, and struck a curb and shrubs on Sunset Boulevard on May 26; shortly thereafter she entered a rehabilitation clinic. She checked out of that clinic last week, and on Thursday went with her lawyer to surrender to the police. Her blood-alcohol level at the time of the accident was above California's 0.08 percent legal limit, Officer Brian Ballieweg said, though he would not disclose how high it was. She also faces a misdemeanor charge of hit and run. Ms. Lohan was released, and a court date was set for Aug. 24.

ACKERMAN--Sidney, 91, passed away on July 19, 2007. A caring, gentle man, who loved family. Cherished husband of Anita for 59 years, beloved father of Ken, Marjory and Andy, and father-in-law to Helen and Jeanne, adored ''Poppy'' and champion whipped cream maker to Gregg, Amanda, Jack and Allie. Private funeral. Donations can be made to the Alzheimer's charities.

Nancy Pelosi, speaker of the House of Representatives, will write a memoir to be published by Doubleday next summer. In the book, Ms. Pelosi, a California Democrat and the first woman to be speaker, will focus on her ''remarkable life both personally and professionally,'' the publisher announced. Ms. Pelosi's collaborator in writing the book has not been determined. House rules prohibit members from receiving advances, but they can collect royalties.

LOOK--Carol (Cummings), age 89, resident of Litchfield CT, previously of Forest Hills NY, passed away on July 19th. Mrs. Look leaves four children, Patricia Kunstenaar of Woodacre CA, Jared Look of Litchfield CT, Linda Look of NYC, and Richard Look of Novato CA; five grandchildren, Howard Look of Palo Alto CA, Erika Kathryn Look (deceased), Karen Davis of Woodacre CA, Zoe Kunstenaar of Aptos CA, Edwin L. Hofmann of NYC, and five great-grandchildren. Funeral services are at 1:00PM Sunday July 22 at Riverside Memorial Chapel in NYC.

An article in Science Times on July 10 about William A. Wulf, an engineer and entrepreneur of computer science, referred imprecisely to the duration of Dr. Wulf's work with Tartan Laboratories. Dr. Wulf left Tartan in 1988, before the company was sold to Texas Instruments, not after. Also, the article misstated the year that Texas Instruments acquired Tartan. It was 1996, not 1995.

In the latest attempt to keep the Barnes Foundation, a significant but financially troubled art collection, in the small town where it was founded outside Philadelphia, the town has passed a zoning ordinance that would more than double the visitors allowed each year, The Associated Press reported. The Barnes collection, whose founder, Albert C. Barnes, stipulated that no picture could be lent, sold or even moved in its galleries, has been in Lower Merion, Pa., since 1922. Three years ago the foundation won a long legal battle to move the collection to downtown Philadelphia to increase attendance and improve its finances. The Lower Merion Township Board of Commissioners passed the zoning change on Wednesday, but the Barnes's executive director, Derek Gillman, said that the new rules, while helpful, were not enough to keep the collection from moving. ''It will not come close to providing the additional revenue sources that are essential to the financial health of this and all not-for-profit educational institutions,'' Mr. Gillman said in a statement. Last month, Montgomery County proposed buying the foundation's buildings and land for $50 million or more, using money that would be raised through bonds, but the Barnes rejected the offer.

An obituary on Wednesday about F. Champion Ward, an educator who helped devise the process under which the MacArthur Foundation ''genius'' award winners are selected, misstated his position at the University of Chicago from 1947 to 1954. He was dean of its entire undergraduate program, not just its undergraduate humanities division.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about parishioners who have protested the closing of the Church of Our Lady Queen of Angels in East Harlem by continuing to hold their own services referred incorrectly to an ecclesiastical district in Rockville Centre, on Long Island, whose spokesman said the unofficial services were not sufficient and that Catholics had an obligation to attend Mass if they were able. It is a Roman Catholic diocese, not an archdiocese.
To the Editor: In response to Joe Nocera's column about postal rates (Talking Business column, July 14):

In a long-expected move, the Orchestre National de France has named the Italian conductor Daniele Gatti, below, its next music director, replacing Kurt Masur. His five-year term will begin Sept. 1, 2008, MusicalAmerica.com reported. Mr. Gatti, 45, has been music director of the Teatro Comunale in Bologna and the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London. Mr. Masur, 80, has led the Orchestre National de France since 2002 and will become its honorary music director; he also left his position as principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra at the end of the 2006-07 season.

WEINER--Edith, passed away on July 18th, mother of Estanne and Marty Fawer, Jeri and Michael Oestriecher, Maxeene and Moshe Weg. Beloved grandmother of Rebecca and Eli Gridish, Leah and Menachem Pinck, Tammy and Carey Wolchok, Simmy and Aryeh Ganz. Greatgrandmother of 27 and greatgreat-grandmother of two. Burial and Shiva will be in Israel. May her memory be for a blessing.

To the Editor: ''2 Lymphoma Drugs Go Unused, and Backers Cite Market Forces'' (front page, July 14) suggests that oncologists withhold radioactive pharmaceuticals because of decreased reimbursement. In fact, there are many reasons these drugs are not prescribed more frequently.

Brad Greenspan, founder of MySpace, revised his proposal to take a minority stake in Dow Jones & Company yesterday and said his plan could increase the shares of the company to $100. Mr. Greenspan's group calls for Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, to buy back 50 percent of its shares at $60 each, using debt. His group would lend $400 million to $600 million to the controlling Bancroft family to buy out members who wished to sell.
MASTERS--Esther Shady. Her friends and longtime neighbors at 895 Park Ave note with sadness the passing of Esther Shady Masters, a gracious lady who will be missed.

OLSHEVER--Irving A. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Debra (Mark Snyder), and Robert M. (Janice). Cherished grandfather of Samantha, Erin, Ryan and Elana. Dear brother of Muriel, Edith and Robert. ''Sinai Chapels'' (718)445-0300.

An article yesterday about a decision to allow passengers to carry cigarette lighters on board airplanes misspelled the surname of the man who tried to ignite a bomb in his shoe during a flight from Paris to Miami in 2001. He is Richard C. Reid, not Reed.
The significant moments in the career of Barry Bonds, the all-time leader in career home runs.

I've now learned two things about New York Times readers. They don't believe in God, but they do believe in, and in fact, worship, democracy. They also believe that democracy's imperatives - one man one vote, majority rule, freedom of speech, the right to petition, respect for individuals and their opinions - should apply always and everywhere. (The religious of course believe the same thing about God's imperatives.)

The Bush administration appears to have angered its Pakistani allies by insisting - as officials did again on the Sunday talk shows -- on holding open the option of military action inside Pakistan against a resurgent Al Qaeda.

My Monday column is about genetic tinkering, and my concern that the limits of the permissible are defined by businesses eager to develop new markets, rather than by any reflection on the consequences for our species. In the column, I raise several issues: Should we allow "womb-rental" across borders? Should we allow PGD to cull embryos linked to genetic risks for disease? To cull embryos based on sex? To cull embryos so as to "enhance" the capabilities of the chlid? I'd welcome your comments on where to draw the line, and if you have experiences with PGD or sex selection I'd love to hear them. Just hit the comment button.

Damion Easley's father, Raymond, passed away Saturday night in Riverside, Calif., after a lengthy illness. Easley has not been with the team since Monday and is not expected to rejoin the team in the next few days. Considering how long Easley will go without playing, it's probable that the Mets will ask him to play a few minor league games before he rejoins the team. Willie Randolph spoke to Easley and said he was holding up "surprisingly well."

Presidential candidate Mitt Romney told a group of Hispanic Republicans today that immigration is "at the very foundation of the whole concept of America," even as he tiptoed around what could be a sticking point in his effort to court Hispanic voters -- his opposition to the comprehensive immigration bill that failed in Congress last month.

James Blake struggled yesterday but advanced to the final of the ATP Countrywide Classic in Los Angeles, defeating Hyung-Taik Lee of South Korea, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. Blake will face Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic, who advanced when Nicolas Kiefer of Germany withdrew because of a sore knee.

Lawmakers acknowledged that there were still many differences on a proposed law to manage the country’s oil.
A book for use in Arab schools describes Israel’s war of independence as a “catastrophe” for the Arab population.
The final book in the series by J.K. Rowling sold a record 8.3 million copies in its first 24 hours on sale in the U.S.
Resolution and Friends Provident are in discussions to create a company with a market value of about $17 billion.
Pakistan’s foreign minister reacted angrily after a top U.S. counterterrorism official suggested that the U.S. would consider striking Al Qaeda targets inside Pakistan.
The prime minister’s party took nearly half of the total vote in national elections in what became a referendum on Turkish democracy.
The Taliban have threatened to kill 23 South Korean hostages unless 23 of their own fighters are released.
An 88-year-old Bronx woman died yesterday after a fire broke out at her home, the authorities said.
Storms dumped more than a foot of rain on parts of Texas, stranding more than 170 passengers on an Amtrak train.

Tim Herron birdied three of his last four holes to take a one-stroke lead over Tim Clark at the U.S. Bank Championship yesterday in Milwaukee. Herron shot a 65 and was at 12-under-par 198 for the tournament. Clark carded a 66 and was tied for second with Joe Ogilvie, the leader after the second round, who shot a 69. Kenny Perry (67) was at nine-under. Jeff Brehaut (65) and Charlie Wi (66) were four strokes behind.

ALBI, France, July 21 — Written off for dead less than a week ago after he faltered in the Alps, Alexander Vinokourov demolished the field on Saturday to win the first of two individual time trials and show that he retains an outside chance to triumph in the Tour de France.
In a tidy, upper-middle-class suburb about 40 miles west of Philadelphia, Tim Donaghy is either Dr. Jekyll or Mr. Hyde depending on which of his former neighbors you ask.
An analysis of recent N.B.A. games refereed by Tim Donaghy revealed little strong evidence of any wrongdoing, experts in sports betting said Saturday.

Maria Sharapova has been told that she will not be considered for the Russian Fed Cup team that will face Italy in the final in September. That decision, by the Russian Fed Cup captain Shamil Tarpishchev, could affect her chances of playing in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.A shoulder injury forced Sharapova to pull out of the semifinal last week against the United States, once again delaying her Fed Cup debut.“I feel it would be incorrect to invite Sharapova to play against Italy as we reached the final without her,” Tarpishchev said.According to the rules of the Russian federation, only those players who perform on the country’s teams in Davis Cup or Fed Cup can be considered for Olympic selection.

Rafael Nadal, the No. 1 seed, beat Feliciano López, 6-1, 7-5, in an all-Spanish semifinal to advance at the Mercedes Cup in Stuttgart, Germany.Nadal will face Stanislas Wawrinka, who upset the seventh-seeded Juan Ignacio Chela, 6-7 (2), 6-4, 6-1.López almost took the second set, but Nadal held on; he has not lost a set in this tournament. He has won 92 of his past 93 matches on clay.“To lose always hurts, but when you know you lost to the best player on clay and one of your closest friends, it is a little easier,” López said.

Lewis Hamilton, the Formula One championship leader, appeared to escape serious injury when he crashed into a wall during qualifying yesterday for the European Grand Prix in Nürburgring, Germany.Hamilton waved and flashed a thumbs-up sign from a stretcher before being taken by ambulance from the track. Officials said he was conscious and speaking on the way to the circuit’s medical center.McLaren officials said Hamilton, 22, would be kept in a hospital for observation for several hours. If he races, he will start from 10th on the grid.

Thiago Pereira of Brazil broke the 40-year-old record of Mark Spitz with six swimming gold medals in one Pan American Games.Pereira won the men’s 200-meter breaststroke yesterday to earn his sixth gold medal of these Games, being held in Rio de Janeiro. He finished in 2 minutes 13.51 seconds, beating teammate Henrique Barbosa (2:13.83) and Scott Spann (2.13.98) of the United States.Spitz won five gold medals at the 1967 Pan Am Games in Winnipeg, Manitoba.Pereira won gold in the 200 medley and the 400 freestyle relay Friday, after earlier victories in the 200 backstroke, the 400 individual medley and the 800 freestyle relay.Pereira has a chance to win two more medals.

Werner Eschauer of Austria and the qualifier Steve Darcis of Belgium advanced to the final of the Dutch Open yesterday in Amersfoort, Netherlands. Neither one has played for an ATP title before. Darcis, ranked 297th, upset the second-seeded Mikhail Youzhny, 4-6, 6-0, 7-5, and Eschauer defeated Robin Haase, 6-4, 6-4, in the semifinals.At the clay-court Palermo Open in Italy, the 18-year-old Agnes Szavay reached her first career final by beating Sara Errani, 7-6 (0), 6-1, in the semifinals. Szavay, seeded eighth, will face the second-seeded Martina Müller in the final today. Müller defeated Karin Knapp, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1.At the Western & Southern Financial Group Women’s Open in Mason, Ohio, Akiko Morigami earned her second berth in a final in three years by outlasting the qualifier Akgul Amanmuradova, 6-7 (8), 6-4, 6-3. She will play the top-seeded Anna Chakvetadze in the final today. Chakvetadze advanced with a 6-2, 5-7, 6-3 win over the third-seeded Sania Mirza.

Akiko Morigami outlasted the qualifier Akgul Amanmuradova from Uzbekistan yesterday to earn a 6-7 (8), 6-4, 6-3 win and her second finals berth in three years at the Western & Southern Financial Group Women’s Open in Mason Ohio.Morigami, the seventh seed from Japan, had 17 chances to break Amanmuradova’s serve and converted just four. The most crucial came in the sixth game of the third set, when Morigami returned a second serve deep to Amanmuradova’s backhand. Amanmuradova hit her return volley into the net.“It was a little bit tough,” Morigami said. ”I kept telling myself not to think about the breaks and just to focus on the next point.”She will face the winner of the semifinal match between top-seeded Anna Chakvetadze of Russia and third-seeded Sania Mirza of India.
Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants was dismissive Saturday when he was asked about a report that a federal grand jury investigating him had been extended by six months.
Alan Webb set the American record in the mile Saturday, running 3 minutes, 46.91 seconds at a sparsely attended meet.
Kason Gabbard allowed two hits in seven innings and Coco Crisp drove in five runs yesterday as the Boston Red Sox routed the visiting Chicago White Sox for the second straight day, 11-2.

Thiago Pereira of Brazil broke the 40-year-old record of the American star Mark Spitz with six swimming gold medals in one Pan American Games in Rio de Janeiro.Pareira won the men’s 200-meter breaststroke yesterday to earn his sixth gold medal. He finished the race in 2 minutes 13.51 seconds, beating his teammate Henrique Barbosa (2:13.83) and Scott Spann (2.13.98) of the United States.Spitz won five gold medals at the 1967 Pan Ams in Winnipeg, Manitoba. He was 17 at the time; Pereira is 21.Spitz holds the record of seven Olympic gold medals won at the 1972 Munich Games.On Friday, Pereira won the 200 medley and took the gold medal in the 400 freestyle relay even though he did not swim in the final. By swimming a leg in the qualifying race, he was entitled to a gold medal when the Brazilian team won the final.Earlier in the Pan Ams, he won the 200 backstroke, the 400 individual medley and the 800 freestyle relay. He has also set four Pan Am Games records.Pereira, ranked fourth in the world in the 200 medley, has a chance to win two more medals in Rio.In 1967, Spitz won the 100 and 200 butterfly and three relays: the 400 free, 400 medley and 800 free.

Lewis Hamilton, the Formula One championship leader, appeared to escape serious injury when he crashed into a wall during qualifying yesterday for the European Grand Prix in Nürburgring, Germany.Hamilton waved and flashed a thumbs-up sign from a stretcher before being taken by ambulance from the track. Officials said he was conscious and speaking on the way to the circuit’s medical center.Hamilton, an Englishman, hit the wall hard after the right-front wheel of his McLaren was damaged.“I’m absolutely fine and we will see later if I am able to race tomorrow,” Hamilton said in a statement released by McLaren. “Everybody has been looking after me really well. We know what caused the accident and I’m just pleased that everything is O.K., and I really hope I can race tomorrow.”McLaren officials said Hamilton had not broken any bones and would be kept under observation in a military hospital in nearby Koblenz for several hours. If Hamilton races, he would start from 10th on the grid.“It’s far too early to say, but at the moment he doesn’t appear to have pain anywhere, no broken bones,” the team leader Ron Dennis said. “We won’t be able to decide until after a few hours’ observation, but so far, so good.”Dennis said the crash was caused by the “failure of the right-hand wheel gun, so effectively the wheel wasn’t properly put on.”“At least we know we don’t have a problem with the car,” Dennis said.The qualifying session was stopped with 5 minutes 31 seconds remaining, and it took about 30 minutes for the session to resume.“Sometimes it’s difficult to wait, you have to be patient and do the best you can when you go out again,” said Kimi Raikkonen, who grabbed his second pole of the season and 13th of his career.Raikkonen, a driver for Ferrari who is coming off two consecutive wins, drove the fastest lap on the 3.2-mile

David Beckham was not expected to see much, if any, action, last night when the Los Angeles Galaxy played Chelsea in his first scheduled game with his new team.Beckham was treated for an injured left ankle behind closed doors Friday, while the rest of his teammates trained. He was not scheduled to start last night’s exhibition, and whether he played would be a last-minute decision, Galaxy Coach Frank Yallop said.“He desperately wants to play,” Yallop said. “It won’t be a big part in the game, we know that, because he hasn’t trained for a number of weeks, but we’re hoping he can get some time on the field.”But Yallop cautioned that Beckham’s health is the Galaxy’s top priority, ahead of pleasing sponsors and broadcasters.“What we won’t do is put him in harm’s way,” Yallop said. “If he’s not ready to go, we cannot do that. I’m hoping that everything will be O.K. to at least get him on the field.”That could mean that Beckham, a 32-year-old midfielder, plays only a few minutes in front of a sellout crowd of 27,000 and a live television audience.

IN the seven interminable years since their team last appeared in the World Series, Mets fans on the Upper East Side have grown warmly accustomed to the sight of a 1953 Ford Customline sedan scrawled with Mets autographs and crammed with Mets memorabilia. This blaze of blue and orange belongs to Metman, a masked super-fan whose alter ego, Eddie Sanchez, is a concierge in an apartment building on East 84th Street. A resident of the Poconos, on workdays he drives two hours to Queens in a Honda Odyssey and then switches to the lumbering Metmobile, which he keeps parked outside a funeral parlor in Astoria, in a spot reserved by a Mets-loving rabbi. After this year, Mr. Sanchez plans to retire so that he can attend more of his son’s Little League games. In the meantime, he hopes to have his “mobile museum” enshrined in glass outside the new Mets stadium. “The car isn’t for the Mets,” he said, “and it isn’t really mine. It’s for the fans.” SAKI KNAFO.

Before a Mets-Yankees game at Shea Stadium in May, ESPN’s cameras caught a moment that quickly became a YouTube classic. As a groundskeeper unrolled a tarp, a black kitten with white paws that had been hiding inside was flung into the air. Landing spread-eagled but on its feet, the cat froze for a moment, then bolted. Both cat and groundskeeper looked slightly freaked out.

THE management describes the atmosphere at Eli Cannon’s as “Irish-English-pub-American-trailer-park-fusion,” and that is only partly tongue in cheek. Eclectic also applies to a décor that combines round tables and booth seating with antique barber chairs and an old-style gas pump. TV screens, with the volume usually muted, are there, but you’re more likely to notice the out-of-use tap handles hanging like miniature totems from the brick walls, along with a festoon of banners and beer signs.
